description:
I had walked by a couple of times on my way to Triple Voodoo and had always wanted to try this place... and I finally did! On Halloween.

My date and I each had a cocktail - they don't have many instagrammable drinks, but they're tasty - which is probably most people's priority :) For entrees I had the shrimp and grits while my date had the pork chop. The shrimp was delicious. I ate the whole plate! Also for dessert I had a key lime thing. Ate that whole thing too. 

The place is pretty nice but it was kinda lame no one else eating was dressed up - although the servers were in costume.
author: Angela L.

description:
My friends came here for brunch and I ended up getting the chiqualles. We made reservations online through opentable but still ended up having to wait a bit before getting seated.

The food was okay, the chiqualles tasted like just a bunch of chips with some meat and hot sauce on top. Flavor wise it was kind of boring and one dimensional, nothing I would write home about.

Some of the other dishes my friends got looked a lot better though so maybe I just ordered the wrong thing.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Do you ever have a meal at brunch, and when you start out eating, you think you are enjoying it... but as you keep eating, you realize oh it's okay. I'm getting full and I don't love it as much as I thought I did. Then you leave the restaurant and you think, I guess it was an okay meal, but all I feel is full and that was kind of heavy. That's how I felt about Serpentine. 

To be fair, I don't think many places in SF are that great for brunch. Maybe I'll come back to Serpentine for dinner.
author: Sophia L.

description:
I like Serpentine! Good food, good drinks, good vibes. It gets pretty poppin so I recommend making a reservation. Otherwise you may have to hover around the first-come-first-served bar seating area.
The porkchop is pretty great, and I love love love love LOVE the house bread and honey butter. THAT HONEY BUTTER DOE. WORTH $6. I'm dreaming about it right now
author: Annie S.

description:
Solid food, excellent service, and a rotating menu based on freshness/season of ingredients. I haven't had trouble getting a table for lunchtime, but I would recommend getting one for dinner.

I've had their fried chicken and waffles, and, more recently, the shrimp & grits. Will definitely be back from time to time since this is close to the office!
author: Michael K.

description:
I've been coming here for years and was excited to introduce my fiancé to this restaurant. Big mistake. There's a server who wears skeleton earrings who maybe had a bad day, or maybe just dislikes her job...it's hard to tell. 

My fiancé ordered the burger and specifically asked twice for no pickles. He even repeated it before she left, and she nodded. Guess what? It came with an absurd mountain of FIFTEEN juicy pickles (15). When he flagged her down to show her, she sort of rolled her eyes, stared blankly, and asked, "Well, are you allergic?" 

WHY does he have to be allergic? He specifically asked for no pickles. It's not like he was asking for a soup to be remade without meat, or for fries to be fried in a specific oil, or anything like that. It was a simple request. The pickles were so juicy that they soaked through the bun and permeated the meat. She didn't write anything down, maybe that's the issue? She actively avoided our table after we brought it to her attention. Our next interaction was an hour later, getting our check. 

Aside from that, my catfish poboy was nothing spectacular. We didn't have knives to cut anything with, and we didn't have water on our table for over 20 minutes. To think of it, I had a 12:45pm reservation for Saturday lunch and we weren't seated until closer to 1pm (there were four tables open; the girl at the lobby was just on the phone while everyone crowded into the narrow awkward foyer). 

They tried to right it by bringing some hush puppies for dessert. But we didn't have plates or utensils, so we just sat there. A different server noticed we didn't have anything to eat them with, and eventually plates and forks appeared. It didn't make up for it, but it was a nice gesture. Our interaction just left a bad taste in our mouths aside from the lackluster food....coupled with how inefficient things seem to have gotten here. I won't be coming back.
author: May L.

description:
I remember coming to Serpentine years ago with some friends, but this was the first time that I came as a resident of the neighborhood. I am just 5 minutes away which is really convenient. Unfortunately, I didn't love food and think the food quality has really gone down since my last visit. 

We started off with the donuts and they were okay. The accompanying sauces were nice but the donuts were very dense. I ordered the short rib hash brown as my main and it was disappointing. The short rib meat was bland and needed more seasoning and the hash brown was this dense potato cake which was very soggy and tasteless. We ordered the french toast for the table to share and that was probably the best dish I tasted that day. 

Overall, I may come back to try out their dinner menu especially since they are on Opentable which is very convenient but for brunch, I will go to other more tasty options in the City.
author: Cicely T.

description:
Mash was heavy on the salt (like really heavy) but otherwise tasty. I appreciated the little bits of onion and carrots in it, I wish the salted ham had been worked into the mash somehow. The layer of chard was a good way to clear the palate. The soft-boiled eggs were perfect. It would've been a 4/5 for me had this not been so salty. 3.5/5

The breakfast sandwich was also very tasty, with the flavors all blending together very well. Definitely one of those dishes you could make at home, but one that just wouldn't be as good if done at home. I felt that it was a bit steep to add one piece of bacon for $5 though. The bread was perfectly crunchy and chewy. The potatoes were crispy and delicious, with the same sort of fried-ness as the fries at the Barrel Room. 3.75/5

Ambiance was very industrial, leading to a lot of echoing and conversation being a bit hard to have even though the space was not too packed. The service was a bit slow as we were seated in a corner and the waiter didn't come by very often. 2.5/5

Overall a 3.5/5 spot for me! Food was good, but overly salted.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Breakfast/Brunch has definitely stepped up and their cocktails are spot on

Overall Thoughts

A go-to spot for me if ever in a pinch and need a pace to go
author: Eddie W.

description:
We were looking for a place for dinner in the neighborhood and came upon Serpentine. Luckily there was no wait on a Friday at 6PM for a party for two.

We ordered two cocktails - Blood Brother ($13) and Mi Flora ($14). I preferred the Mi Flora - it was a lot lighter. 

We also ordered the Ham and Biscuits appetizer ($14) with buttermilk biscuit, country ham, pimento cheese, pickled jalapeno. It was very deconstructed and had four half-biscuits - pretty delicious but definitely not a Southern dish. 

For entrees, we ordered the Pork Chop ($28) with chorizo, marble potato, romanesco, pickled onion, brown sugar + sherry gastrique and the Scallops ($27) with asparagus, spring onion, green garlic, charred chile romesco, brown butter aioli, toasted almond oil. My friend really liked the scallops but has had more tender scallops. I really liked the pork chop dish - but my pork chop was pretty fatty; I personally prefer the fat more rendered.

Overall, decent food but very pricey. It's how pricey our bill ended up being that made me give this place a three-star for a-ok.
author: Judy S.

description:
We came here because we were looking for a place near the Midway because we were going to an art show there that evening.  Serpentine had 4 stars so we wanted to try it out.  We had an early reservation (5:45) and there were several open tables.  Most people were crowded around the bar so I am curious is they have a happy hour that is better than the dinner.

The menu is small and eclectic.  I was not too enthused at first because I did really see anything I was excited about. Most entrees had at least one thing in it that I dislike (mushrooms, mint).  When the waitress came I asked if they had any specials not on the menu and she said they had a ribeye so I opted for that.  I ordered it medium rare and it was cooked well I just wish it was a bit more tender.  

My wife had the scallops ($27) which were cooked well.  It is served with three large scallops and they were tender. The waitress warned that they were a little spicy if you are sensitive to heat, which my wife is, but she did not feel any heat. 

Overall it was a decent experience but nothing on the menu would make me need to come back to try it. I did look through the pictures on Yelp and saw that most were from brunch so maybe if I came back it would be to try that out.
author: Danielle B.

description: I had one of the best salads I have EVER had here. The chop salad was filled with huge slices of chicken and bacon, a boiled egg and lots of tomato slices and other veggies. I swapped the ranch dressing for their house balsamic dressing and it was perfect with the salad. They have a variety of different and cool drinks to choose from that are "Instagram worthy". Serpentine is clean inside and modern. Only negative thing I would have to say is there service was extremely slow. I went during my lunch break I was there for over two hours. Other than that, the staff was very friendly and their food was fantastic.
author: Brieanna S.

description:
Overall 4-star food quality & 4-star customer service.  Their burger and fries are excellent, but their Mac 'n cheese was very mediocre.  I'm not sure if they reheated the Mac 'n cheese, but the top layer of my Mac n cheese was rather dried, as though it were either overbaked, or reheated. 

I've returned several times to order their burger and fries for take-out :)
author: Colette C.

description:
I remember choosing Serpentine, because unlike other brunch institutions in San Francisco, they took reservations which saves a lot of hassle and dead time. It is located in the Dogpatch, which doesn't make it very conveniently located to anything, so eating here is a commitment.

My sister and I dined here a while ago, but I remember being remarkably impressed by both the space and the food. 

We shared half a dozen oysters and ordered the following two entrees:

-dungeness crab benedict ($17.50): two poached eggs, hollandaise sauce, spinach, a generous helping of dungeness crab heaped on two buttermilk biscuits + crispy potatoes. Renditions off the classic egg benedict are a dime a dozen, but the time and forethought placed into piecing together this dish made it incredibly good. I don't even like crab, but I thought this was superb.

My sister really enjoyed her polenta + eggs dish ($15). It's creamy polenta in braised tomatillo pork sauce topped with fried eggs and piquillo + poblano pepper salsa. The braised tomatillo pork sauce melded really well with the creamy polenta. The added kick from the salsa created an extra depth of flavor.

The space is bright and airy creating a nice ambiance. Brunch at Serpentine was a pleasant surprise - nice deviations from the usual brunch fare.
author: Trung N.

description: If you want delicious lunch or dinner, a tasty drink, and friendly service, look no further than Serpentine. With passionate, dedicated workers, it's hard not to love them.
author: Shira S.

description:
I went to Serpentine for dinner with a friend, he made reservations and they did seem a little busy for 6 pm. It is a really cute place, but the tables that are two tops are really close together and kind of hard to get in and out of during your dinner without moving the table around a little. The service was pretty good throughout dinner. 

We started out with cocktails, mine was an aperol, bourbon concoction that was quite tasty. My friend and I decided to each get out own appetizer but to split an entree and a side. I ordered the mussels and he ordered the mushroom soup, both were very big portions and tasty. The entree that we split was the sea bass and it came with chopped radish and parsnip with delightful kale. It was a really delicious dish. Then our side was the macaroni and cheese, it had some green chilis in it and had a beautiful crumble on top. The macaroni and cheese was bomb for sure, we both agreed it was probably our favorite part of the meal.

Overall, Serpentine was super yummy. I definitely want to hit it up for brunch one day because their brunch menu sounds amazing.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
While my cousin visit SF, we had a brunch at this place as heard great reviews of it.  Parking in the area can be tricky as this restaurant is surrounded by other businesses and warehouses so street parking is the way to go.  Be patient and you'll find one, I'll guarantee!  Came here for Sunday brunch; we made reservations for it but we were pretty early for the time we reserved for so then we would have to wait for a table to open up.  The bar area was open and free to sit so we decided to sit there rather than to wait another half hour to be seated when a table became available.  No problem there... the hostess was very flexible with us and so we decided to just sit at the bar area.  The bartender was friendly and attentive to our needs; the drinks were great and the food was also amazing.  The menu was of modern American food but playful.  Here's what we ordered:
1.  P B & J:  An interesting modern take on the classic PB&J but this had a confit pork belly, battered brioche (french toast), and jam.  The taste was of savory, sweet, and salty which was very yummy.
2.  Cornbread benedict:  Almost like a classic benedict but this included braised pork and a little heat from the chile.  It was good but not as memorable.
3.  Serpentine burger:  The burger was good; juicy and flavorful but tasted more of a regular burger you'd find anywhere.  I expected a little bit more from it.
Overall, it was a good experience.  Customer service was great and food was okay but we enjoyed the restaurant.  It was clean, comfy, and a lot of character.  We'll be back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Erna M.

description:
Short Story:  Great place for a fried chicken burger.  

Long Story:  I came here for a late brunch and the place was already packed!  I didn't have a reservation but was lucky enough to get a table without a wait!  We ordered the honey spiced fried chicken burger with fries, the soft scramble, and a homemade soda.  The service is pretty good and the decor was interesting.  They had high ceilings with chandeliers.

Verdict:  I'll come back the next time I'm in the area.
author: Michael W.

description:
Man, we really wanted to love this place. Unfortunately, it was a big let down. All 4 of us thought the food was very meh. The atmosphere, spirit, was so great. But we were all let down by the food.
I'd go back for the Bloody Mary, but that's all.
author: Kristin G.

description:
Wait - Reservation and 15 Minute Wait @ 13:15

Value - $15 / dish.

Dish Size: Medium

Spiced Honey Fried Chicken On a Biscuit - The honey fried chicken is reminiscent of Panda Express orange chicken. There's nothing wrong with Panda Express but the problem is charging $15 for one piece of chicken. The biscuit is not flakey or fluffy which left me guessing that it's not properly baked. Also, the fries are not crispy or seasoned well. Overall, the entire dish has a soggy/mushy texture which made it unappetizing. 


I fail to see the allure of Serpentine. My opinion maybe a bit biased as this place has been so hyped and recommend that I expected something more. The impression of Serpentine is a restaurant that thinks they are the sh*t and acts like they are the sh*t, but really, they are so far from being the sh*t. This is the worst type of restaurant because this illusion permeates all the way through to the service and the food. 

I'm usually pretty lenient on service, however what I can't tolerate is pretentiousness. There is an aloofness and ingenuity with staff which I find unprofessional. We arrived on time for our reservation and the hostess ensured that our table was being prepared. We thought it would be quite quick as it looked like it was a relatively slow day with open tables available. 10 minutes roll by and she comes back dismissively stating that our table is still being prepared. Another 5 minutes go by until she gesturally points her finger across the room to an open table. She has a smirk which we assumed meant, "I'm too lazy to walk over to sit you, so you can make your way over yourself." Overall, there is a lot to be desired with the service.

Much like the service, there is also a lot to be desired from the food. The overall quality of the food is subpar in relation to the premium price. If you're looking for brunch place around the Dogpatch neighborhood that serves a burger or fried chicken, I would recommend going to either Alta MSP or Marlowe. On a positive note, the one good thing about Serpentine is their Bloody Mary - it's light and refreshing with a subtle spicy kick. 

Overall, the brunch experience is unmemorable and unremarkable which is a great neutral baseline for other restaurants to be judged too. Serpentine needs a reality check as it doesn't even come close to the level other brunch establishments in the neighborhood.
author: Julian L.

description: A charming little brunch place tucked away in the Dogpatch, but aside from its surface level charm, it's just average and a little overrated in my opinion. The service was not great, it seemed like our waitress was still in training and was fumbling around quite a bit with our orders. When my order came, it was undercooked and underseasoned. Just overall very underwhelming. I really hoped the experience would be a bit better for a highly recommended SF brunch spot, but it was just disappointing.
author: Toshi P.

description:
Wow, just wow! My husband and I had dinner last night at Serpentine, and it was easily the best dinner we've had in San Francisco in the past year. This place has it all - cool location, modern ambiance, friendly service, and above all excellent food. We had a great time from start to finish.

We began by sharing the mussels as a starter and absolutely loved them. The broth was laden with ground chili, lime, and garlic that was a unique and delicious twist on a classic white wine and garlic preparation.  Beware that there's a good kick to it, but we thought the heat level was great and didn't detract from the flavor of the dish.

I had the scallops for dinner, and my husband had the halibut. Both were outstanding. I was particularly impressed by my scallop dish - again, a welcome departure from seared-scallops-and-puree. There were so many layers of flavor in the vibrant broth and the bed of rice laden with charred fresh corn and chanterelle mushrooms, and the scallops were just perfect. My husband loved his halibut as well, with its briny topping of capers and beautifully charred market vegetables.

We concluded our meal by each ordering the lime + graham cracker, an awesome variation on a key lime pie. It was creamy and refreshing, a great end to a great meal.

Suffice it to say, we left incredibly happy and can't wait to go back. Thanks, Serpentine!
author: Julie C.

description:
If it wasn't for the decor and the French toast, I'd give this place 1 star. 

Came here with a group of coworkers for lunch and had the worse experience. 

1) My coworker ordered a lemonade and waited 30 minutes before she had to remind the waitress to check on it 
2) I and a coworker shared the Catfish Po'boy only to have it served to us half cooked half RAW.
3) My other coworker ordered a burger without cheese and was served: a bunless burger with EXTRA cheese
3) Lastly, we waited over 1 hour for our food to be cooked when the restaurant was not busy. 

Not sure how a restaurant with 7 items on the menu can make such errors. 

Won't be back.
author: Sandra V.

description:
Food is delicious! Came for brunch, got the Bloody Mary (extra spicy) and steak and eggs. My friend got the quesadilla, both were extremely tasty! As well as the Bloody Mary was thick and a great morning cocktail. 

Only cons - steak and eggs were so good but portion was small, not enough to satisfy my hunger, and for 2 meals plus drinks, fairly expensive. Would definitely recommend to all!
author: Matthew O.

description:
I came to this place this past weekend with two of my girlfriends and we were excited because we heard good things about it. We came for brunch and I liked the atmosphere: high ceilings, a few big windows, so great amount of natural lighting and it wasn't a small space. Quite spacious for a SF restaurant, I think. 

We ordered the truffle fries, a salad, maple custard french toast and a short rib and hash brown dish. My friend said the salad was too dress so it tasted a bit on the saltier side, but perhaps this could be fixed with asking for the dressing on the side, so no biggie. The french toast was very egg-y, flat and not fluffy, and the fixings had mango and pineapple, so that was tasty, but the toast itself was underwhelming. The short rib and hash brown was kind of bland. The short rib meat came shredded on top of the hash brown and the hash brown came as a pile like mashed potatoes while the sides being a little brown but not at all crispy. It was topped with a sunny side up egg. I wasn't very impressed by this, BUT the great redeeming factor was the truffle fries! Omg I would come back for their truffle fries and maybe drinks. It was $10 for the fries, but it comes in a large plate and they're so tasty and so crispy! We all kept reaching for more fries cause it was that good! 

I would reconsider and give it a couple more visits because sometimes a restaurant just has bad days or maybe the dishes we ordered just didn't appeal to our tastes, but for now I think the place doesn't live up to the hype.
author: Christina C.

description:
I was looking for a brunch place in which I can make a reservation. I found this place and went there.
I called one day before I went and its all booked until 1pm! So definitely you should plan ahead.
I ordered egg Benedict not crab one. It's really simple and nothing special. I liked the atmosphere in this restaurant but my egg Benedict is just ok.
author: Saki ..

description: I would describe it as industrial chic. A cool hipster spot in the Dogpatch.  Clearly very popular, there was a line before 10. I got the red flannel hash and buckwheat pancakes which were great.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Delicious brunch with struggling service. 

Came for an 11am brunch with a group of 8 friends. Our reservation was for 11:15, but we weren't seated until 11:25 which wasn't a big deal- the real problem with the service began when no one would bring water or take our orders for coffee/drinks. 

After 15 minuets, someone finally took our drink orders and eventually came back to take food orders. The food arrived promptly, even before some of the drinks had been delivered. The food that came was great, but two of the items ordered never arrived and we had to re-order them. They ended up arriving after everything else was eaten. 

We had eggs Benedict, steak and eggs, French toast, and chopped salad. All dishes were fresh and delicious if not served a bit cold. The steak was one of the highlights. It was tender and flavorful and cooked perfectly, but many of the people at the table felt like the portion could have been more generous. 

We will likely go back with a smaller group and give this restaurant a second look.
author: Liz A.

description:
Went for dinner. Loved the service, appetizers, and sides! The main course was disappointing unfortunately. 

FOOD
Starters (1) House rolls - so good! Warm, sweet, and little salty on top. Wish the bread was complimentary but it was good nonetheless.
(2) Oysters - very fresh (raw). Grilled lemon was a nice touch.
(3) Truffled fries - Fries were cooked and seasoned well. I could really taste the truffle flavor so it wasn't worth the few extra bucks in my opinion. 
(4) Artichoke + Asparagus - Fred artichoke heart and leaves, grilled asparagus, and Meyer-lemon hollandaise. Extremely flavorful and tasty.

Main - Buttermilk Fried Chicken with wilted spinach, balsamic beets, vanilla-roasted strawberries, chipotle dust, and pate-biscuit. This dish was really underwhelming for me. The chicken breast was dry and in my opinion it was (overall) under-seasoned. The spinach and beets were nice. The biscuit was also dry and nothing very special. I much preferred the appetizer rolls. A very beautiful looking dish but not as good in taste unfortunately. 

Dessert - I was too full for a full dessert but asked if I could just have a scoop of ice cream which they accommodated. They get their ice cream from the place across the street (Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous) and it was DIVINE. Even for a plain vanilla cream flavor it was really clean and fresh. Great way to end the meal.

SERVICE - The waitress serving us was very friendly and accommodating. She answered all of our questions with a smile and made our experience very pleasant.
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Came here for brunch today with a group. We had a reservation for 10:30 when it opened so we were seated right away. The restaurant itself is gorgeous, very trendy with lots of natural lighting and wooden beams and high ceilings. Even the bathrooms were beautiful. All of us LOVED our meals - most of us either got the Cornbread Benedict or the Huevos Rancheros. Delicious. The sides of brussel sprouts were amazing as well. 

Only complaints were that it took quite long to get coffee, which we ordered immediately. We thought that our waiter forgot about it but then were told that it's still brewing. But be good to start brewing the coffee a bit earlier! Also, our waitress was lovely but she has way too many tables for one person. Felt awful as the restaurant was packed from the moment it opened.
author: Shoshana G.

description:
:/ I dunno, man....

My dumplings were deconstructed and my ceviche wasn't cut up so it didn't sit on my tortilla chips. 
I just feel like I have expectations- especially when it comes to traditional plates. And unless I am told that they are different ahead of time- I am pretty disappointed. 


But on the positive side when we got there- the table next to us had decided they were going to take up a lot of room and take over our side- and the hostess went over and told them politely to move. And then the waiter came over and offered them a bigger spot later. 

So great service- questionable food.
author: Julianna I.

description:
I have heard about this place for a while but have never had a chance to try it until yesterday. 

The Food: I like the length of the menu & the amount of options. Not too overwhelming. 

We decided to go to with Sea Bass & extra avocado ..  O M G - i cleaned the plate. 

It was so good yet very healthy since the base is quinoa & salsa. D e l i c i o u s !!  

The Service: erh.. I like the bartender & how attentive he was with us. 
A comment on the seat arrangement. 

1. I was sitting at the bar waiting for table to be open. I didnt mind at all. Then there's a table open up, I didnt want to move but he insisted that he had a party of 3 to use the space that I was at so I agreed to check out the table - but the table was tiny in the corner of the place & it's so inconvenient so I wanted to move back to the bar where I was. But as he said he has to fill it with 3 people, I ended up moving to the far end where the kitchen & the sink were. And what upset me was: MY SPOT WAS TAKEN BY 2 PEOPLE NOT 3 - You liar!!!! 

I ended up havjng a view of a pillar in front of my face, next to the kitchen where things are being prepped.. so here goes your 1 star to be 5.
author: Thao P.

description: Came to Serpentine for restaurant week, and I have mixed feelings. If you are simply looking for a wine and dessert bar, this is a great place to come. However, the courses we ordered at restaurant week were a bit underwhelming. The squash soup, fish, citrus salad, just didn't do it for me. The desserts were the best part of the meal I must say, and the wine was great too. Maybe the menu just wasn't what I expected. I would be willing to give Serpentine another shot.
author: Ross S.

description:
I absolutely loved my brunch experience at Serpentine. Even with a reservation my date and I had to wait about 10 minutes to be seated, but that's just testament to how good the food is and we grabbed some coffee at the bar and it wasn't an inconvenience at all. 

The Nashville hot fried chicken biscuit sandwich was massive and definitely a fork and knife dish than something you can actually pick up. The bisect is honey-sweet and the chicken is just slightly spicy so as to not be off-putting for a breakfast dish. The cornbread benedict was also great. The bread was sweet just how I like it, and tall/dense enough to stand up to the saucy goodness on top. On its own it was a tad dry but when I busted open that flawlessly poached yolk the bad boy was singin. I could have used another slice of bacon to get the ultimate balance, but I did not leave hungry so I'm not complaining.  

As great as the two entrees were, it all began possibly stronger...with the absolutely phenomenal buttermilk cinnamon sugar donuts. Crispy, dense, and slightly tangy, these are the donuts of my dreams. Served with two immaculate dipping sauces - salted caramel and vanilla icing - every bite was explosive, and the sauces were so good I kept them and dunked my perfectly crisped potatoes into the sweetness in between bites with ketchup and hot sauce.

If you're looking for a new spot to get some wonderfully creative yet super hearty breakfast I highly recommend checking them out.
author: Sean S.

description:
Didn't even know where Dogpatch is or was, despite living here all my life!  And finding Serpentine was fortuitous!

Still waiting for our reservations at aine! Stopped in for a real drink, Jameson, and a glass of bubbles for my bae. 

A bustling crowd in the early evening. No place at the bar and sneak-in was an hour wait. A gorgeous Robert Palmer look-a-like "Addicted to Love" server was gracious enough to perch us on a row of stools across from the bar. 

The cocktails were good and stiff. From looking at the fabulous entrees that passed is by, I was ready to put our name on the sneak-in list and enjoy the people watching crowd. Yes, John Kerry, the former Secretary of State was having a cold one!

Alas, we got pinged to go back to our original dinner plans. 

I will find Dogpatch again and return to Serpentine.
author: David N.

description:
What a find for brunch.
The place is young, hopping, and sexy. It's small, so there WILL be a wait. But, dude, it's worth it!  Cool interior, lot's of noise, lots of fun people. We were seated along the back wall, and had a great view of all the activities. The bar was packed, and the bartenders were working their magic. I started with a craft cocktail, (DOGPATCH PIMMS pimms no.1, hibiscus flower liqueur, lemon, ginger beer, cucumber)...very refreshing, as it was pretty warm out already.
Then we ordered the COCHINITA PIBIL - achiote-braised pork, over-easy egg, piquillo rice, roasted tomatillo salsa, cilantro, crispy flour tortilla... Looked awesome on the plate, and tasted even better!
Partner enjoyed the SHORT RIB + HASH BROWN - which was a sunny side egg, shaved radish, avocado-poblano-chevre, scallion. Again, excellent all the way around.
Service was great from our server, and the manager, who was constantly roaming and checking in with everyone. 
Definitely have Serpentine on our hit list and will come back again.
author: Greg S.

description:
EVENT: Confirmed dinner date with my loves! Haven't seen each other for MONTHZz! Busy! Busy! Busy! I walk by this place all of the time and finally... I get to try it!!! Woots!

SERVICE: very helpful server! She gave us some recommendations - and we took her advice! Must get... BRUSSEL SPROUTS!

FOOD:
(1) Pork - it kinda came out a little raw :(  but that's how it's normally made according to server girl. I love raw stuff... but...when it comes to any raw-ness in my pork... I alway send it back to the kitchen to make it well done (personal preference). They were happy to make my pork well done, which I really appreciate! 4 stars!

(2) Brussel Sprouts = OMG! 5 stars!! The best brussel sprouts ever had! Deep fried brussel sprouts (can't go wrong). Drench in some unknown sauce? Kinda taste like it's mayo, but it's NOT! It's aioli!!! Flavors melts in your mouth! EXCELLENT! **MUST GET** 

(3) Burger - delish burger! LOVE the fries... don't forget to sprinkle some salt on it! Excellent! Burger came out juicy! 4.5 stars!

**OVERALL: A must get is the brussel sprout! Excellent choice!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
This was in a cool location. We walked around looking for brunch, and not being from the area we relied on Yelp. Everything is true about this place. The food was unbelievable, the drink I ordered was so good and the service was excellent. 

I always have thing for rustic/industrial restaurants and this was one of those places. 

For the food, I got the cornbread benedict (HOLY BALLS it might be my top 5 bennys). We also had the buttermilk donut holes, which I recommend sharing. They were extremely good but I can't handle too much sweetness so my friends had the extras. The dipping sauces made it mouth-watering. My boyfriend had the crispy pork belly hash, unfortunately he wasn't impressed. It almost seemed more like a salad with chicharons. I had the Bloody Mary without the spicy vodka and it was still decently spicy. I sucked that thing down before my food even arrived. 

So overall everything was pretty great, maybe my boyfriend would try something different if we ever found our way back to San Fran, but if you're reading this it's a place that deserves to be checked out.
author: Nicole M.

description:
So, Serpentine has a new executive chef and owner, which explains the remodel.  I still have fond memories of Monice's Chinese Cafeteria which used to be in this space for many years.  It is always interesting to me how the spirit of a restaurant can help shape a neighborhood and be a beacon for locals to gather.  This is such a place.

i couldn't resist trying the truffled beets and burrata and split the pan seared scallops and dumplings with my friend.  The scallops were cooked to perfection and the dumplings were lovely.  The service was attentive but not intrusive, and prices are reasonable.

I must confess that I tried a City Sazerac as well.  Not my typical single malt, however I was intrigued by the combination of ingredients.  The Sazerac rye, star anise, and bitters made this an unusual drink for my palate, however it too was surprisingly good.  I'll return again soon.
author: Frank S.

description:
Had an open Friday and a few of us stopped by for lunch. Dog patch is really coming along these days with up and coming restaurants and cafes. With the warriors coming soon this place is going to blow up!

Pretty packed for a Friday but we had a ressie so no issue with seating. Service was a bit slow but understandable since it was busy. Decor is industrial but in an inviting way. 

I had the open face fried chicken sandwich and however they cook it, it was super tender! It came with some picketed and a slaw with a bit of kick to it. Top it off with a bit of honey and you have a mix of flavors going on. The sweet, salty and spicy all mashing together with various textures of the ingredients made this quite memorable for me. Had a great balance of flavors with none overpowering each other. 

Great place for brunch with some friends and there's mr. Miscellaneous across the street for some dessert!
author: Andrew S.

description: Came here for breakfast. Quite busy restaurant, but able to get a table on arrival without reservation, so probably not too hard to get a reservation on short notice if not during peak hours. Very well designed interiorly, has somewhat a lofty yet cozy feel to it. Loved their mimosas, was delicious. We had their fried chicken burger, which I highly recommend. Very well seasoned, very tender, right amount of grease to it. Cornbread Benedict was delicious also!  Everything just melts and the mixture of egg yolk and hollandaise and cornbread was quite heavenly. Overall, quite happy with our food, but was not exactly blown away. Service was awesome, although our server was clearly quite busy attending several tables, so we tried not to bother her too much. Will come back again for brunch. Hopefully no wait next time also!
author: Yingna L.

description: The food our group of four had here was really good. The place is pretty laid back and casual. We had reservations on a Friday at 5:30. The place wasn't crowded so we were seated right away. Our server was friendly and efficient.
author: Chris P.

description: Get the mussels!! A simple dish but the fermented chili paste and grilled pan au levain make it truly special. We went here for date night -- the food was delicious and the service was wonderful. Cocktails, digestifs, fancy desserts... this place is everything a night out should be and is not to be missed.
author: Elise S.

description: I walked into Serpentine on a Friday around noon. I had never been in before and was looking to kill some time and have a yummy cocktail. I was greeted right away with a friendly hello from the manager and bartender. I sat at the bar and asked the bartender to surprise me with a drink that was refreshing and herbaceous, but not too sweet. He nailed it. I can't remember what the drink was called but it had gin, lemon, and rosemary. After that he made me another drink, and it was also delicious! Overall, the atmosphere is great, the service top notch, and the staff super friendly! I will definitely be back to try the food!
author: Kelsey B.

description:
When I found out a friend was off on a Saturday (he normally works weekends), I decided to coordinate a brunch. After looking through OpenTable to see what reservations were avail, I decided on Serpentine. I made a reservation for three a couple days prior for Saturday, March 4th at 2pm.

*Fried Egg Biscuit Sandwich: fried egg, arugula, gruyere, dill aioli, crispy potatoes ($12)
*Cornbread Benedict: spicy maple bacon, poached eggs, hollandaise, crispy potatoes ($15)
*Prather Ranch Hamburger: pickled red onions, house made pickles, arugula, acme roll, french fries ($16), add Gruyere (+$2), Nueske's Bacon (+$3)
*Nueske's Bacon ($3)
*Bloody Mary: vodka, house bloody mix ($11)
*Senator: rye, lemon, maple, absinthe ($12)
*Avinyo Cava Reserva Brut Nature 2011: Catalonia, Spain ($12 glass)
*Organic & Fair Trade House Coffee ($3) ×3

I ended up getting the breakfast sandwich and a side of bacon. The breakfast sandwich was good. I love my oozy eggs and these were nice and over easy. I didn't really read the menu well though cuz I would have added sausage to my sandwich for the extra $4 if I did. I do love my meat after all. The side of bacon did fulfill my meat craving, but I wish the pieces were thicker and not as crispy. I like a little chew to my bacon. For drinks, I had a coffee and a glass of bubbly. After the night I had the day before, it was a good way to ease into the afternoon. My friends seemed to enjoy their meals and drinks.

Fun place for a simple low key brunch. I think we got one of the last reservations as Serpentine closes at 2:30pm. Or else, I think this place would have been bustling. I never get out to Dogpatch much, so I'm glad this restaurant popped up on my brunch search.
author: Elena N.

description: I absolutely love this place. The food is good and affordable. The service has always been great. I would go back.
author: Meeka W.

description: Been here 3 or 4 times over the years and it has never disappointed. Excellent cocktails, dishes, everything. Frequently changing menu but no matter what we tried, it was always a delight and a great effort from the chefs.
author: A K.

description:
We went here for a Saturday brunch and got lucky with no wait for two people. (The wait at Aina was too long!) The servers are friendly and informative about the menu.

We ordered the strawberry cobbler pancakes and the cornbread benedict. Also got a side of fruit (yay they gave blood oranges!). The pancakes were delicious! I ordered two pancakes for an extra charge and it was quite the helping (we had to togo it). Get the yuzu syrup too! The cornbread benedict was alright, the poached egg was a bit overcooked.

It seems their menu changes now and then so I'd definitely come back! Ambience is nice, decor is rustic/lighthouse vibes.
author: Michael T.

description:
So I've previously never heard of Serpentine and I ended up here after the wait for Aina on a Sunday morning was waaaaaaay toooooo long for even me. After walking a block over, we happened upon Serpentine. With no wait time and the menu posted outside to reel us in, we were sold. The inside is beautifully decorated and modern. There's nothing like a high ceiling to really give you that open, spacious feel!

Minus a star for the incredibly slow service despite how it wasn't very busy and another star for how awkwardly close tables are to each other... 

But onto the food!!! We ordered the salted caramel/vanilla donut holes, steak & eggs, benedict, and crispy pork belly hash. Those donut holes did not last long because we ate them so fast...Piping hot and the sauces were delicious! Benedict wasn't the most memorable, but the crispy pork belly hash was definitely a winner! The pork was so crispy and tender, a little on the greasy/oily side, but I didn't mind since the flavors were on point. 

I'll have to see what their lunch/dinner is like and hope for faster service.
author: Maleah M.

description: I'm sure a lot of their food is good, but if I'm craving a good burger and truffle fries Serpentine is where you'll find me. My favorite spot to sit is by the bar where I can see them work their magic with drinks.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This place has been on my list for years and I finally got the chance to pay a visit over the weekend for dinner, so admittedly I came in with super high expectations. Sadly, I left feeling underwhelmed despite the dining experience itself, from the welcoming hostess to getting amazing drinks at the bar, being fantastic. I can totally see this place being a great after work hot spot, and rightfully so. 

The food, on the other hand, didn't elicit any of the feelings I often look for with highly rated and raved about restaurants. You know, that feeling you get when you're having your favorite burger, ramen on a cold night, or chowing down on the best burritos in SF (El Farolito is the only true answer here). Each of these are memorable in some way and you think about them well after the meal. That's essentially what was missing for us. By no means were any of the dishes we had "bad." It's just that after we were done with our meal, there was nothing we had that we were particularly fond of nor would look forward to having again. 

For reference, we had their fried chicken, burger, and asparagus/artichoke starter.
author: Adrian D.

description: The people were very nice, but I was disappointed by the food. Maybe I ordered the wrong food by trying the dumplings especially since I dislike blue cheese. I guess I also had different expectations since they were more similar to potato dumplings.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Such an awesome place is Dogpatch! I never really explored Dogpatch until recently after I tried piccino. As an OpenTable fiend it was easy to make a reservation for this place weeks in advance to make sure we would avoid the wait. The place itself is sooo hipster it hurts. Perfectly located on a corner it's hard to miss with it's sign lining the wall. 

When you walk in you don't realize how small this place actually is. Not in the sense that it feels cramped but tables are limited so I was happy I made a reservation. From the moment we walked in we were seated right away and asked what we wanted to drink. The servers were super friendly and never rushed us to order. The menu is pretty small so it makes it easy to pick something. 

What we got: 

- Cornbread benedict: I was eager to try this since I'm a huge benedict fan. The cornbread they put it on was HUGE. I do feel that the cornbread was delicious but it was more on the dry side which made it hard to eat since it kept crumbling apart. The spicy bacon they add instead of ham was tasty as well. The poached eggs however were extremely overcooked - they were basically boiled eggs so I didn't get to enjoy the satisfying feeling of breaking the yolk. I felt so full after eating only half of my dish. 

- Eggs, potatoes, bacon, and bread: The portions for this dish was huge as well. They didn't skimp on any of the components and it was a very filling dish. The potatoes were perfectly crisped and salted as well.

- Pimms drink: My FAVE! I became obsessed with pimms after I studied abroad in London. It was such a refreshing drink and paired well with the gingerbeer and lime. 

- Brunch punch: Definitely on the stronger side of things but it was just as tasty and even had a sprig of rosemary in the drink. 

It wasn't too pricey for all we got which ended up  being around $60 with drinks. I really enjoyed this place and the service we got. I will definitely come back to try their buttermilk donuts! Yumm.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
Never disappointed with brunch here! Menu always slightly changes, staples are present with certain seasonal items, so I was disappointed to not have my savory bread pudding (yes it's been a few years), but happy to try other items.  There as an "apple pie pancake" (I can't remember the actual name) that was fan-f'ing-tastic. I am not even a big pancake person but that was probably the best pancake I have ever had.  

Oh yeah, we also ordered the grits with truffles and chanterelle (creamy, salty, good) and a cornbread Benedict which my friend said was only ok, although the crispy potatoes are like crack.

Best part is, no wait and free parking. Is there anything else you need to convince you to come?
author: Susan W.

description:
Serpentine takes reservations. You should make reservations otherwise the wait would be pretty long, especially on weekends. Also you'll be mad at yourself for the fact that you didn't have to wait if you had made a reservations. 

Their food is great (I love the red flannel hash and their buckwheat pancakes!) and a reasonable price for SF. The interior is super spacious with high ceilings and great lighting. There's plenty of parking in the area. THEY TAKE RESERVATIONS. It's pretty much all you can ask for from a brunch place in San Francisco. Love it!
author: Theresa L.

description:
We came here for a birthday brunch on a Saturday at 11:30am with a reservation. The place was already filled with people so make sure you make a reservation. Otherwise, you can sit at the bar, which was also full. We came about 10 minutes early and were seated at exactly 11:30am.

We had:
1) Avocado Chervre Toast ($14)
I was thinking of ordering this but the goat cheese stopped me. However, I did take a bite and it wasn't bad. Although I don't think I'd order it myself. For me, avocado by itself is already tasty enough that I don't think it needs all that jazz, meaning all the garnishes. 

2) Apple Cobbler Pancake (1 for $7/ 2 for $14)
This was delicious! That whipped cream...wow, love it! I usually stay away from flavored pancake, afraid it would be too sweet. However, this wasn't the case! The amount of sweetness was just right. 

So my eyes were bigger than my stomach and I ordered 2 pancakes! When my dish arrived, I was like OMG, so much food! One is already enough to share between 2 people, let along 2 pancakes! 

We also had coffee ($3). Everything was good and the service was friendly. I will have to come back and try other dishes but I'm giving this place a 5-Star for now!
author: Alice L.

description: This space is full of light and unique design details.  The food was excellent (Crab Benedict), and service at the bar was superb!!!
author: Alea M.

description:
We went here last night for a belated valentine's day dinner. We were seated immediately upon giving our reservation name which is always nice. The interior is super cute, rustic shabby chic.

They had so many delicious sounding appetizers, it was hard to choose. We landed on the hush puppies with local Dungeness crab. It was a good size appetizer so I'm glad my boyfriend convinced me we only need one app (I always want all the apps). The hushpuppies were FILLED with crab meat. They were so fluffy and delicious, would highly recommend.

For dinner I chose the adobo braised short ribs. I don't normally order red meat out because I prefer chicken and fish however, I also have some guilt for ALWAYS ordering the fried chicken. Next time, I'm coming for you, fried chicken! The short ribs did not disappoint. There were roasted parsnips and radishes with collard greens and green chiles all on top of grits. The portion was pretty large as well so I'll also be eating that for lunch today! We had to order the truffle fries [of course] because they were topped with real truffle shavings. Best truffled fries I've had in the city. 

We skipped dessert but the menu looked amazing. Would definitely come back for dinner and would love to try their brunch some time.
author: Katlyn H.

description:
My friends and I celebrated one of our birthdays at Serpentine. What better way to celebrate a birthday than brunch?!? We made reservations (YES, Serpentine takes rezzies so hop on that!) and we were set for a Saturday morning.

We all started off with the ruby mimosa which did not disappoint! The grapefruit flavor is rather faint, but I like my mimosas with 90% champagne anyways. ;) We did notice that our second round had a darker pink hue to it, and therefore tasted more grapefruit-y.

I ordered the crispy pork belly hash ($16). I was also looking at the chanterelles, truffles and corn entree and that sounded amazinggg... However I did want some meat that day because we had a full day of drinking ahead of us, so I ended up with the pork belly. I was super happy with my choice! The rich and fatty pork belly was crispy yet tender, and I loved the soft potatoes and crunchy turnips that balanced the dish out. I also wish I ate the levain toast, but I was too full by the end of my meal. 

It was a rather expensive brunch, but we did get two rounds of drinks and paid for the birthday girl as well... So I guess that is justified! If I ever come back, I would lovee to try the chantarelles, truffles and corn with grits and poached eggs. Someone ordered it next to us and I could SMELL the truffle. AHHHH!!
author: Tara A.

description:
Review #1405, what could I possibly add.
Brunch with out of town friends, Party of 4, 10ish.
- Not a fan of the hostess. Does she realize she's working in the Dogpatch and not high fashion?
-House Pimms, they should serve it by the pitcher, it was so tasty
- Truffle fries. On point. 
- House made donuts, are actually donut holes, huge in size, smoky cinnamon sugar and an orange marmalade that was not existent.
- 3 of us had the Breakfast sliders, aka the rock in my stomach for days.
- The biscuits were small, the egg was overcooked and the sausage was dense AF. I wanted the egg to run all over the sausage and biscuits. Nope.
-  The crispy potatoes weren't all that crispy, but good.
- If you need an upscale pregame Brunch spot or a good drink, its great.
- Saw the big plate o-meat fly by. Wish I ordered that.
- If its 50 and foggy outside and you can take a nap afterwards, its great. Very much a comfort food spot as advertised.
- Service was spotty at best. We were there 2 hours catching up and felt like we overstayed by 30 minutes. Staff wasn't happy.
- Another average restaurant that serves great cocktails.
Might be back.
author: Patrick Z.

description: The food was okay but buyer, beware! The descriptions were not accurate. I ordered the Live Lettuce salad with butternut squash and pear and blue cheese.  It arrived, was substantial, but where was the butternut squash? I couldn't find it, neither could my friends. I asked the waitress, she didn't see it. She went to check, came back, showed me it was smeared around the edge of the plate. In other words, it was a puree with probably a tablespoon spread around the plate under the salad. It wasn't the first lack of truth in advertising. One appetizer said  Pickled vegetables and listed the vegetables. The way it was worded made me ask: are all the veggies pickled? No, only the carrots and maybe the cauliflour. When it arrived, the okra was also pickled. They were fine but ask about everything you order. If it says caramel sauce, I would ask if it's a drizzle of caramel on the plate or actual caramel sauce. The hamburger was only so so and way too salty. Staff were completely unconcerned about what was included in the items and didn't know. Noisy. Too precious with the menu.
author: m j l.

description:
A really fun and local favorite.  The service staff is really friendly and it's a great date night spot or a place to take friends who are visiting.  The oysters were super fresh and the scallops were cooked just right and the sauce had just the right amount of heat.  

While I loved the place, the prawns were on the small side and fairly dry.
author: William F.

description:
It was fine.  In fact, it was pretty tasty.  The problem is that I'm not sure what distinguishes this place from the dozen or so other minimally-decorated, slightly-overpriced places that serve well-prepared high-end hipster fare.  

Even as I write this, I know it doesn't matter: I don't think restaurants like this were meant for me.  There is a certain cuff of the pant and coiff on the head that indicate you will be frequenting Serpentine and it's sister establishments throughout the city.  They should start checking for tattoos at the door: too few or too many will not be allowed.
author: Daniel K.

description: The menu for brunch is pretty limited. Our entire party ordered the same thing. This place does the Benedict a little different, instead of they typical english muffin this place sub it with corn bread. My entire party was running late and our reservation was near closing but the servers here allowed us to stay way past closing.
author: Annie Y.

description: I arrived early so ordered myself a drink, Fall Back. The birthday boy arrives with his wife and orders more drinks. The friend with a newborn is late because she's feeding her daughter. We decide to order a few starters, burrata with strawberries, Pork albondigas, and olives. The rest of our party arrives and we're chatting. The waiter was awesome! He knew exactly when to check on us and didn't rush us to order. He suggested we turn our menus over when ready and it worked. We ordered the halibut, skirt steak, fried chicken and pork chop. I had a piece of each entree and they were delicious. We ended the evening with a salted caramel dessert. I've been wanting to try serpentine and glad I finally did.
author: Minh H.

description:
Made a reservation for brunch the day of by calling in.

Too many dishes to choose from so I split the following items with my friend.

Buttermilk donuts - not fluffy at all. Quite dense and generously cited with sugar. Vanilla and salted caramel sauces as a filling in the donut would be much better and alleviate the dryness. 
Banana bread French toast - 3 sizeable pieces of banana bread that are lightly toasted smothered in whip cream. Banana flavor is quite strong yet not too sweet. There is some passion fruit sauce that adds a nice spin to the dish. 
Steak and eggs - steak is cooked medium rare and tender. There was a molasses butter that made the steak taste much sweeter. I preferred the steak sauce that was saltier. The potatoes are fried to perfection. 2 fried eggs with a runny yolk went well with the biscuit.

This brunch was extremely carby and made me quite full. My favorite dish was definitely the banana bread French toast. I loved the high ceilings and it was very easy to talk across the table.

One thing that was a huge disappointment was that they ran out of pork belly hash by 12:30 for brunch because both of us were looking forward to trying that dish.
author: Edward W.

description:
Came in yesterday morning for brunch. We had reservations which I would recommend because of the popularity of this restaurant. Everything from the hostess to our waitress to our food was a pleasant experience!

My friend and I both got the Benedict without ham. The veggies, poached eggs, and cornbread complimented each other perfectly! The space and decor was also beautiful. I would gladly return and recommend this spot for a great brunch.
author: Jasmina A.

description:
My friends and I made a brunch reservation for 4 on a Saturday and when we got there, we were seated right away! We were all so excited such a good lookin brunch place took rezzys & we didn't have to wait!! 

I ordered the Crispy Pork Hash which came with roasted potatoes, turnip, arugula, mustard creme fraiche, 2 poached eggs, and 2 slices of bread - and it was seriously so delicious. I took that first bite into the crispy pork and I swear my eyes lit up a little. I also ordered a ruby mimosa based off everyone's reviews & it was good, but not much grapefruit flavor.

I can't wait to come back & try the rest of their menu!
author: Carrie L.

description: Try the bread pudding!  Less a star as my steak was very slightly overcooked, but still exceptional!   Rendolent of the old Slow Club from days of yore, Serpentine feels like solid Dogpatch gourmet fare with lasting appeal.
author: Max K.

description:
Great food and environment. A solid choice for brunch, lunch or dinner.
Last time I went for dinner and I had amazing gnocchi.
It gets easily loud and crowded. Not much space to move inside
author: Fabio C.

description: Nice quiet place for business lunches. Had the Seared Ahi Tuna Salad - really tasty. Just found that $17 for a salad was a bit expensive knowing prices in the neighborhood. Friendly service.
author: Clémentine C.

description:
Restaurants like Serpentine is what amazes me about dining in San Francisco. Everything about this restaurant deserves 5 stars (and more). From the decor, to the food, to the friendly wait staff, everything was up to my standards! 

I dined here for lunch with my mom and can honestly say, we cannot wait to dine here for dinner sometime soon. I enjoyed a beautiful and healthy Mahi Mahi dish and my mom devoured her pork belly with brown rice dish. The presentation and the flavor of both dishes - wow! I never knew quinoa could taste (and look) that good! What I really enjoyed was knowing how healthy everything was. There was barely any oil used to cook my fish. 

Tip: Get their homemade lemonade. I went for the original, but the peach was also very good. 

The girls working at the restaurant were super friendly and attentive. The only drawback was the parking situation. It took us awhile to find a spot, but it was worth it. 

Can't wait to dine here soon! Thanks Serpentine for a delicious and memorable meal!
author: Anastasia N.

description:
The first time I came here for brunch, I was blown away. I ordered the breakfast sandwich and the apple compote pancake to share. The breakfast sandwich came with a delicious biscuit and spicy house made sausage and fried egg with some peppery arugula that did a good job of cutting through the heaviness and grease. I really like their crispy breakfast potatoes with rosemary. Their pancake was to die for, super rich but fluffy and light at the same time. And the apples were tart enough to complement the whipped cream and butter and crumble topping. 

The second time I came here for brunch, I ordered the basic breakfast which had all the same elements as my breakfast sandwich, minus the arugula. The eggs were obviously fried in butter, which I found to be too rich tasting. And the biscuit was dry and tasteless. The potatoes and sausage were still tasty, but who knew I would miss the arugula that much. Additionally, the pancake choice was strawberry rhubarb and they drenched the pancake in syrup to the point that it was practically inedible. It was way too sweet to eat; I was bummed. 

Their redeeming factor is that there is plenty of parking nearby and they take reservations. I'll probably be back if I'm on a tight schedule, but I'd prefer to go to Plow if I have the time to wait around for a table.
author: Leslie H.

description:
Don't come without reservations! I came on a Sunday with a friend and can imagine how horrible the wait would have been if we didn't have reservations. Also, parking is incredibly easy here so definitely a plus as well.

We ordered the red flannel hash and the buckwheat pancakes with berries. Thankfully my friend is down for family style so we were able to have both sweet and savory. The restaurant is really crowded and tables are set really close together, so if you're looking for an intimate setting this isn't your place.

Was incredibly stuffed after brunch and I think we even got the rest of our hash to go. Then like the fatasses we are we went to Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous after... and then made a pit stop at Neighbor Bakehouse even after that.
author: Megan K.

description:
After climbing nearby at Dogpatch Boulders, this was the perfect spot to visit. 

Started off with the breakfast slider. The homemade biscuits and sausage are amazing. 

The short ribs and hash browns go so well with the Aioli. 

Coming back for sure!
author: Louis V.

description:
Came here at 10:30am for brunch and the wait for a table was still 30-40 minutes. I couldn't wait any longer and just settled for a bar seating. I ordered the steak and eggs for $18 and it was INCREDIBLE. The size of the steak was amazing - it was juicy, medium rare. And seasoned to perfection. It came with 2 eggs on top of a deliciously baked biscuit. The potatoes were heavenly and the aragula added a nice touch to my meal. 

I would definitely come back again. The atmosphere, service, and food were all exceptional. You can't go wrong with a $18 steak and eggs meal. I'm usually used to $25-30 range for a similar entree so this was definitely a steal!
author: My N.

description:
Overall I really liked this place!

Snagged a brunch reso for a next day visit with 5 people so glad we didn't have to wait in any endless lines.

Place is very clean and hipster. 

Let's talk food: doughnuts, everything I wanted and more. Had good crisp then soft inside. Came with 5, so perfect for everyone to get one. Crab Benedict at $17.95 is steep. Wished we got more crab as ours had very little on it so in that sense I was disappointed but on the other hand it tasted great. 

I'll definitely come back but I'll prob try one of their other amazing looking dishes instead.
author: Mandi W.

description: Cute dinner/date spot with interesting dishes. Really interesting combinations of flavors in each dish. Avoid the table near the door - it gets extremely windy.
author: Steven W.

description:
Serpentine will always be dear to my heart. The first time I came here was over a year ago for my first interview in San Francisco. I ordered a stone fruit salad with steak and I was VERY pleased! You can tell a lot about a place based on the way they treat and present their salads, and I knew instantly that I liked Serpentine.

Fast forward a year, when I returned with high hopes. I came with my boyfriend, and whenever we go out to eat, we try not to order the same things so that we can try more things on the menu. That day, the Prather Ranch burger was calling out to both of us, and thank goodness we each had our own burger! I really enjoyed the pickled onions (and since my boyfriend doesn't like pickled things, I got double!) as well as the salad, which reduced the guilt of me eating a burger early in the day and so much so that I didn't feel bad stealing a few fries from my boyfriend. (But then again, that's what they're there for, right?)

All jokes aside, I'm looking forward to coming back!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Hipster vibes, awesome plates, beautifully executed cuisine!

Went for Sunday Brunch and knew that there would be a wait. We arrived around 11:00 and were seated by 11:30. Good service throughout the meal and often checked on by the server. 

I ordered the pork belly hash and it was heavy, but heavenly! Pork belly was fried to perfect--the meat very tender and the fat melting in your mouth. The potatoes were deep fried, turnips roasted, and the dish was topped with greens, a bit of mustard, and two lovely poached eggs. The flavors paired up beautifully getting that fatty crunchy with an earthy radish, silky egg yolk, and bitter green. Overall, a great dish but not for the faint of heart... A friend ordered the huevos rancheros and thoroughly enjoyed the lightness and vibrance of the dish--light tomato sauce, fried eggs, beans, and tortillas. Another friend had the eggs benedict over biscuits and enjoyed the dish. Next time, depending on my mood, I would likely go for something sweet or lighter like the huevos rancheros that do not have the deep fried potatoes as a side because they are heavy and filling. 

Looking forward to returning and trying more of the menu! Be prepared to wait on the weekend, but the food is worth it!
author: Emily P.

description:
Very good place.  Tried this place on a Wednesday night early in the evening so not crowded.  I assume it could be because the food was better prepared than most places.

Ordered the Prather burger.  Shared it, so got to try fried chicken too.  Both were great.  Very good dipping sauce for the chicken.  Have say, a bit pricey, that's why I knocked it down one star.  17 bucks for a burger is a bit high but everything is, in San Francisco.

Drinks looked fairly pricey based on the menu.

The waiter was personable and prompt.  

The atmosphere was industrial sheik I would say.  Wonder what the building history use to be?  

You could do lots worse, so give it a try.
author: Henry F.

description:
Please god, make Serpentine burgers amazing again.  

Context: I never write reviews, but feel so strongly about this topic, I cannot not write one.

Topic: The Serpentine Burger

What grinds my gears: what used to be one of the best burgers in the city is now a shadow of an ant on an elephant's dead carcass.

Reasons why:

1) The Bun: Between us, the bun is the glue.  It holds it together.  It covers you when you aren't ready for the show but you know you should have been prepared.  On a good night, it makes you Tom fucking Hanks winning the Oscar.  Unfortunately, this bun is now limp and lacks any sense of it self.  

2) No bacon, no cheese:  You no longer can choose what type of cheese you want on the burger or if you want to add bacon.  I mean, do you think you have 5 year olds ordering these burgers? 

3) No more truffle: there was an amazing time when you could add truffle to your Serpentine burger.  An amazing upsell worth paying for.  Whether its a high margin item off the menu or no is beside the point.  Short story, I am f'ing pissed I can't put truffle on my burger anymore.

4) Condiments: the mustard isn't ground anymore.  I expect more from you serpentine.  Plus, they took away the 3 condiment side that used to be standard (ketchup, aoili, ground mustard).  That standard made me feel special.  More importantly, it made me think you were a special establishment.  This is a small thing to some, but it shows me the attention to prep has lost its way...

5) The meat: when you ask for medium rare...jesus H, serve it medium rare.

If you have read this far, I am passionate about burgers.  But more importantly, I am passionate about Serpentine and what it has meant to me in my time in San Francisco.  It was the first restaurant I ate at when I first moved here.  I think its fair to say its special to many people.  It starts with the food before it starts with a remodeling.  You still have a chance Serpentine to bring that amazing factor back.  

All my love,

X
author: Xan S.

description:
Close to perfect. Made a reservation Sunday morning, only 2pm available w/1-seat remaining. We were seated in just a few minutes. 

Gorgeous modern interior, high cement ceilings with exposed beams, simple black lamps and a beautiful bar space. A diverse crowd, young and old, multi-racial, multi-style. This looks like the San Francisco that I used to know. 

Service was friendly, warm, and fast. The food was delicious. Alcohol free options, had a tasty lemonade with soda. To eat - Spring Toast, it was perfect = two fantastic slices of thick toast smothered with fava mash, herbed ricotta, roasted artichoke, fava leaves. Only ate one slice, since we also had the rice pudding. Don't overlook the pudding. Soft, sweet, and divine. A warm, comforting sweet treat.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Compared to my five star review, this time I was very disappointed.

Sunday brunch time opened at 10am and I made my reservation before. I arrived on time and I was assigned a table for 2. The waitress, she was not fast, and asked us what we would like to drink, I replied grapefruit juice, orange juice and a cup of cappucino. When I was waiting to be seated, I already saw the juice was ready and a jar of juice was sitting by the bar, so I assume it should be fast. NO, IT'S NOT!

A couple sat next to me 5 min later, waitress showed up and asked her what they wanted. The waitress did not come back with our juice and she took their order. Soon, other waitress came back and served the girl with the orange juice she requested. I was like what the hell, your sequence was wrong. Finally she came back around 10:22am, with our juices and coffee, explaining the coffee was little slow.

Immediately after that, in fact, entering from 10:00am, I have overly enough 22 minutes looking at the menu, I request to order, I order lobster and crab croquette, monkey bread, a side of toast, a side of biscuit and a side of fruit. And the table next to me placed their order as well.

I jokingly said if the next table would get their food earlier and it was just like what I said.  10:42am, next table got their two brunches served at the same time. I did not get anything. Few minutes later, we got our large fruit bowl. I think that is amused, that should be easiest side/fastest side they could serve but they did not serve it until 1047am, despite that I have been sitting there for 47 minutes!

Food was good, but I was so done. I don't have the mood to enjoy the food anymore. The crab and lobster croquette was very decent. The service is not tolerable. My last dish, monkey bread was not serve until almost 11am, but it was listed as the main dish of the brunch, not a side. What is the point of eating that if you serve the side dish first?

Here is the few things that I don't like about:

1. Serving sequence:If you have your juice ready, which I know you have a full jar already prepare, please serve it not until the cappuccino is ready. i am not sure what goes wrong but the serving time of your cappuccino is definitely below industry standard. Especially the next table ordered the same thing and she got it even faster than us. The serving of the drink delay the whole process of the order. If I knew  Serpentine served their drink so slow I would place my cappucino later when i ordered my entree. I approximately have 10 min delayed here.

2. Serving speed: Again, it is very slow and it is very easy to tell when the next table order everything later than you and got their food faster. If I knew your monkey bread could come that late, which was a order I placed at 10:22am but did not show up until almost 11am. Believe me, I can go to the Neighbor bakehouse, which is just less than a block away and buy a Ginger pull apart which is a similar pastry, wait in line and come back and still faster than the monkey bread. This was absurd!
author: Stephanie H.

description: Showed up with some friends for brunch this past Sunday at 10:30am. This place was recommended and supposedly didn't require a reservation. When we attempted to put our names on the wait list the host told us it would be a verrrrrrrrrry long wait. When we asked how long, he responded "I may be able to fit you in around 3pm". No other openings or tables for over 4 hours?? Needless to say, we were disappointed so we found another place just down the street.
author: Kenny T.

description:
I've always wanted to go to Serpentine! It's one of those places I've gone by many times but have never had an occasion to go. After a walking tour in a nearby neighborhood, my friend and I headed to the Dogpatch to find food and drink. Serpentine closes between lunch and dinner but we arrived just after 5 PM, when they re-open. There was a chair blocking the doorway so we had to ask if we could come in. The hostess was reluctant and didn't seem to know what was going on. There were still supplies and stuff up on the bar, so even when she finally let us sit there, it still didn't feel as if we were supposed to be there.

But that rocky first impression was quickly erased as we were greeted and served by a delightfully charming bartender. The hostess gave us a happy hour menu but said they weren't doing happy hour on the weekend, the bartender said it was fine so we're not sure what the rule actually is. In any event, it means some specialty cocktails are $5 (instead of $11/12) but the food is the same price as far as I can tell, it's just a limited selection.

We ordered delicious specialty cocktails; mine was some kind of vodka lemonade with a sprig of rosemary and it was delicious. My friend had a cool cucumber drink with black pepper from the happy hour menu. Super refreshing and yummy. After our first round, I ordered one of hers. We ordered a hamburger and a cheeseburger with salads and side of fries to share, per our bartender's suggestion. The fries are ridiculously good. Beware! The side salad with the burger is huge so we had plenty of greens with our decadent meal. The local grass-fed burgers were juicy and delicious, though at medium rare there was quite a bit that was rare. Medium might be a better temperature to order in future. Not sure I needed the gruyere for an extra $2.

You wouldn't know it from the outside, but Serpentine is bright and airy. The windows are not at ground level; there are sky high ceilings with huge windows high up that fill the place with light while giving it the feel of a secluded spot. It reminds me of Nopa on Divisadero but without the crazy crowd. It was filled with bar patrons by the time we left, and was starting to get busy for dinner as well. Not cheap but worth it and I'll definitely be back!
author: Angelique L.

description: Came here for dinner with a reservation for 4 with my high school friends. Arrived on time and got seated once the party was all here. They took our jackets to hang, which was nice. We took awhile to order since we were chatting due to the fact that we haven't seen each other in ten years, but the waiter was patient and kept checking in until we were ready. We started with mussels and truffles fries. The fries were a fairly large bowl which was filling for an appetizers, but it was deliciously seasoned and crispy thin. The mussels weren't really fresh, but the sauce was good and helped mask most of the oceany flavor from them. I had the main entree of the scallop and thought it was a perfect portion after the heavy appetizers. It was decent, but nothing exceptional. My friend's pork chop was too chewy for my tasting. Short ribs were flavorful and not bad, but again the dishes where were unique, but they were decent. We were too full for dessert so we wrapped it up early. It was a little less than $60 per person and they were kind enough to split the bill into 4 cards. Service was great though.
author: Amanda C.

description:
I came here for brunch and got the fried chicken sandwich. The breading of the chicken lacked seasoning. The chicken to breading ratio was much too high. 

My friend's hue is rancheros also lacked the flavor dimension.
author: S W.

description: Fabulous!! We went here for brunch last Sunday, it was terrific. Unique, tasty menu. Friendly, competent service. The donuts! The breakfast quesadilla! I wanted to order everything on the menu. What a beautiful atmosphere.
author: Mary D.

description:
So this review is long overdue in that I probably entered the door of this DogPatch staple. I enjoy Serpentine on any occasion but my favorite is clear. 

I like Serpentine on lazy weekday afternoons that are calling for a couple boozy whiskey cocktails and a walk along the water.  

In a great neighborhood (for a boozy walk along the water post lunch) spot, Serpentine is a place I get excited about going to when the idea arises.

I am stoked for my next meal there when they reopen on 9/12!  I might be sitting at the bar if you come thru.
author: Lee S.

description:
I always give extra star for any brunch place in sf that allows you to reserve online. 

-Location is great you get a ton of parking a block away. 
-wait was long once we sat down. And had to flag down someone to take our check as we waited and no one came by to check. 
-food was tasty. I love pork belly and savory dishes for brunch so downed that pork belly hash so fast. The fried potatoes were meh tho. Have had better at Plow.
author: Vy H.

description: We were initially suppose to go to a Lardo's popup for dinner, but they miscalculated their chefs and guest. So we came to Serpentine last minute since it was the closest restaurant that was walking distance. On top of that we were buzzed and had the drunchies lol! They accommodated us really fast, service was great, and service was fast. Also, the food was bomb!!! Highly recommend the mac and cheese, mushroom soup, fries, and other entrees. Their drinks are strong and delicious as well. I definitely want to come back here for a more intimate night like a date or birthday.
author: Foodie Sushi Q.

description: Been here 3 times now. Always been good. Great service. My only "negative" is I love to have a cappucino after a nice meal and they only served brewed coffee. Not a deal breaker but would be nice.  I love knowing about a place like this that is reliable. I know i'll have a good meal and good service.
author: Karen O.

description:
Came here for Lunch, got a reservation on a weekday, but didn't look like i needed it as the place was almost empty when i came in, but did get busy later.
I really enjoyed the food, i had a chicken parm and my wife had a tuna sandwich. The tuna sandwich was pretty awesome and i highly recommend it. The chicken parm was good perfectly  breaded and just the right amount of tomato sauce and cheese. lot of places make the mistake of loading it up a lot, but sometime less is more. 
got fries and salad as sides and the fries are really good, the salad I was just okay with but it was more because of my personal preferences, It had too much dressing for me and the other veggie than arugula, i think radish i just didn't care for.
