The service was good, the servers and hosts were all very nice and friendly, the waitress did have to check our order like twice because we did change it a bit. 

I definitely recommend this place and 30 buks for a really good quality lunch for two is not bad at all, esp in SF. 



FYI, parking is hard to find at lunch time on a weekday so beware.
author: Anuj C.

description:
Ssssssss.... When hearing about serpentine, I thought it would look like the chamber of secrets and be Harry Potter related and the bartenders would speak parseltongue to customers, but when I actually ate here, it was none of that and I still had an amazing experience!!! 

First things first, the ambiance and just overall architecture at Serpentine is divine! Yes I wish it was huger but the stone walls, modern paintings, natural lighting - just make it a perfect place to have a chill and relaxing weekend brunch! 

In terms of food and drinks, their bloody Mary's are not too spicy and pack a good punch, and their pimms cup and Monica's shrine were very light and complimentary to their somewhat heavy dishes!! For starters, the Brussels sprouts are seasoned perfectly and are a great side. 

For main dishes a friend and I split the red flannel hash and Maryland blue crab Benedict! If you don't like beets, you won't like the red flannel, and the crab Benedict is a little heavy on the bread, but both eggs in the dishes were done with perfection!!! I personally hope to try their burgers in the future, but this brunch went beyond my expectations and can't wait to come back again!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
I spent two nights in San Francisco in October and asked my friend Mike W. to suggest a good place for a group dinner. He's a 30-something who lives in the Mission, so he always comes up with something fun and worthy of a vacation meal, usually a recently opened hot spot. Hard to do, particularly for a large party, but this time, he got a table at Serpentine, for a party of eight, at 9PM on a Thursday.

We ended up being a party of nine, and when we walked in, it became clear that we were the only party even close to that size. They seemed a little stressed out about our extra person, but we squeezed comfortably into a group of clustered tables. The space was great--lively ambiance and trendy decor, faux semi-industrial with high ceilings. Service was solid. They took care of our unwieldy group quite well.

It's been a couple months and I was a couple drinks in when I got here, so to be perfectly honest, I don't remember the food and drink in tremendous detail. I think I had one cocktail, the Fall Back, made with mezcal, Ancho Reyes chili liqueur, Orchard Pear liqueur, and burnt orange, and I think I liked it.

The food was good. We all went in on some fried squash blossoms and bourbon glazed pork ribs, both lovely appetizers. The squash blossoms came with corn pudding and mojo verde, the ribs with pear and pickled pearl onion. The ribs were probably the best item of the night, tender and succulent with plenty of flavor. I had the fried Hoffman chicken for my dinner, served with cornmeal waffle, braised chard, parsnip, beet relish, and yuzu maple. This was a decent entree, if not the most viscerally satisfying fried chicken I've ever had.

I had a great time at Serpentine. I enjoyed the food and drink and the ambiance was right for a late dinner. It was a happening spot, but not so happening that we couldn't catch up at our leisure. I'd recommend this place for a night out in San Francisco.
author: Steph C.

description: Great Ambiance! Great service! but it supposed to be one of best brunch spots  in the city... and we ordered their specialty eggs Benedict and the egg yolks were completely baked not runny as it should be! Also their mini donuts looked super yummy but dough was quite dense and tasteless overall was ok!
author: amy h.

description:
Had a phenomenal experience here through Restaurant Week and will definitely be back!

First of all, the service here is excellent. I called to change my reservation time before visiting and they were super helpful in finding a time that would work for my increased party size on a busy Friday evening. Our wait staff were all attentive and helpful, and kept things moving along without rushing us. The restaurant itself is inviting and somehow manages to be cozy and modern/industrial (I think it's in a converted warehouse) at the same time. 

The food here was SO good -- possibly some of the best I've had in SF. We loved everything we had! The standout for me was the pork chop, which isn't on the Restaurant Week menu but is a sublime dish: the meat is flavorful and melts in your mouth and it comes served on top of amazing-tasting veggies and polenta. Seriously amazing. If you eat meat, I highly recommend this! The sourdough bread they serve is also noteworthily amazing (yes, even the bread is worth mentioning!). 

Re: the restaurant week menu, the Caesar salad and butternut squash soup appetizers were both delicious and creative takes on familiar dishes. The potato dumplings were comforting and delicious, and the seared ahi tuna was cooked perfectly and well seasoned. The salted caramel pot de creme was exceptional -- super flavorful and delicious -- and the apple crisp was a buttery and gluttonous indulgence that we enjoyed as well. 

Cocktails were good and there was a nice selection of beers and wines as well. I had the rosary, which was a vodka drink with herbal flavors, that was strong and went well with the food. We saw lots of dishes we'd go back for and plan to return in the future.
author: Christine G.

description:
Got brunch here with a few friends from out of town, I highly recommend serpentine if you are looking for brunch reservations on short notice. It's located in Dog patch just s short walk up the street from a cal train station, a muni stop is also not far away. 

The food was very good and pretty reasonable for what it is. The mimosas are also delicious it not bottomless, so get them if you prefer quality to quantity. I took off a star because our waitress was pretty hard to track down but that's only a problem if you are in a hurry.
author: Matthew W.

description: I had lunch here before a meeting and thought it was a great, lively and a good value. I had a healthier option with a mahi mahi which was very tasty and was presented nicely. My colleague had a fried chicken sandwich that looked awesome. It was packed for lunch, but that's usually a good sign, so I can't hold it against them.
author: V S.

description:
FOOD: Fan of their burger, high quality beef, can add bacon, arugula adds a nice bitterness, comes with fries. 
Fan of their pork chop entree reminds me of thanksgiving dinner very tasty and comforting. Fan of their cookie sandwich ice cream wow! Like an upscale way better pazookie from BJ 's restaurant. Love the caramel and even though it was salted it was a good balance. Ice cream is from next door so good to support local businesses. 

INSIDE: is a darker ambience. Kinda dive upscale modern industrial feel with a bar and seating area. Cute for a date or small group of friends. Bathroom was nice. 

RESERVE: reserve your table ahead of time! It's that kind of place. Server took a while to get to us at first but after that things seemed fine as far as service.
author: Michelle M.

description:
First Sunday brunch. Made a reservation and were seated promptly despite the crowd.  
Server was quick to take orders for drinks, being water and take food order. 
Food came out shockingly fast. I had the soft scramble and my dining partner has fried chicken sandwich
Soft scramble was a bit too "soft", verging on raw. I had to mix it up a bit to let the residual heat firm up the runny bits. All of that aside it was virtually tastelessness. No taste of the mushrooms, charred lemon or the manchego cheese. The frisée leaves had a nice, bright dressing that helped but I had to use more S&P than I remember doing in a very long time. The slice of slightly warm bread was delicious but would have been even better with a bit of butter (it was "dry")
I did not try it but my friend seemed to thoroughly enjoy the open-face fried chicken sandwich. He ate every bit with the exception of a few of the nice, crispy, SEASONED fries that I nabbed off his plate. 
Dogpatch Pimm's and then IPA were great. 
All said, for what we got in think $80+ is a bit steep, even for San Francisco.
author: Us And J.

description:
I went to Serpentine for dinner about a year ago and liked it.  So when the line at Plow was 1.5-2 hours long, brunch here sounded like a fine alternative.  We arrived, a party of four, around noon and were seated in a few minutes at a cute little half booth.  The menu looked incredible.  Everything was going well so far.  

But when the food came, it really didn't live up to what we (my boyfriend and I) were expecting.  We had agreed to go halfsies on our brunch, and I felt bad in doing so, because...

Maryland blue crab Benedict (two poached eggs - hollandaise sauce - spinach - fried lemon - fines herbes - buttermilk biscuit - crispy potatoes), my order, was dry and too fishy, the bread was oddly cake-like in texture, there was not much hollandaise, and despite the fried lemon on top being fried well, all the flavors together didn't make for a good dish. The potatoes on the side were over salted and not crispy enough, and the greens with fennel on the side were fine and surprisingly not overdressed.  I've had much better crab benedicts, and I didn't want to even finish mine.  Not making any assumptions - I noticed the woman next to us had ordered this same dish and barely touched hers.
  
Huevos rancheros )two eggs - spiced black beans - cilantro - avocado - hen of the woods mushrooms - sour cream - queso fresco - ranchero sauce - corn tortillas) were also not very flavorful or good. They were, however, better than the benedict, but only by a hair. The flavor was fresher and brighter somehow than the benedict. The tortillas were pleasantly crispy but sadly it was brought down by the bland sauce. 

The side of bacon we ordered was limp and not crispy.

The service was fine; it was just unfortunate that neither dish we ordered was delicious or satisfying. It just felt like a lump of unnecessary calories in my stomach, taking up room that could have been used by Mr. and Miscellaneous ice cream (located just across the street).
author: Christina G.

description: I met fellow yelper and friend Rosy H. here for brunch during my weekend in the city. We were the first ones in so service was quick and attentive. I ordered the huevos rancheros and we shared one of their apple pie pancakes. Both were good though I liked the pancake a bit more than my eggs. I wish there'd been more avocado and beans on the huevos rancheros as it was mostly egg and tostada. The pancake meanwhile was fluffy and not too sweet. Definitely a nice place to eat and catch up!
author: Alex Q.

description:
This is what all brunches should strive to be like. Serpentine, you got it right. And it's less than a 10 minute drive from my bf's place. I wish I had discovered you earlier. 

Buckwheat Pancakes: what?! I can have pancakes at brunch that aren't completely buttered and unhealthy-- yes, please!! These are topped with pomegranate, bananas, and apple slices as well as candied walnuts. They taste healthy, but I say that in the most delicious way possible. Not in a bland, overly oat-y way at all. I'll take an order of these.. every Sunday.. thanks.

Red Flannel Hash: big chunks of tender beef brisket with beets, potatoes, and arugula and topped with poached eggs. This was probably the most filling entree we ordered. That beef brisket, though, so good.

Dungeness Crab Benedict: The crab wasn't as prominent as I would've liked. This was my least favorite dish we had at brunch since I've had better benedicts. Thankfully, the pancakes and hash out shined the benedict. 

Why the one star deduction? Some might think this is petty, but other egg lovers will understand. The poached egg on the benedict and on the hash were not runny! Overcooked poached egg?! How am I supposed to snapchat #eggporn?! (kidding... kinda.. not really)

The space is modern and clean. Service is friendly and efficient. We came after the brunch rush around 12 pm and had a pretty short wait for a table. Again, you got it right, Serpentine. See you again soon.
author: Danielle G.

description:
Cute dogpatch brunch spot - pretty lowkey. Inside looks like an old warehouse, but they decorated it quite nicely. The name of the restaurant makes this place sound super gloomy, but it is actually quite bright and hipster inside. It is best to make reservations beforehand bc they can get pretty busy on the weekends. 

We ordered Winter greens and Maryland blue crab benedict. 5* for the presentation. The salad not only tasted refreshing but looked amazing. The radishes were beautiful and added a splash of color to the greens. It also complemented the benedict dish, as it was a little heavier and creamier. The side of greens was a great balance to the fried potatoes. Even after eating a full meal, I luckily had enough space for dessert at Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous. 

Also, the employees here were very pleasant and attentive. Would definitely come again. If you plan to drive to this area, there's always parking (unless there is an event at pier 70)!
author: Connie L.

description: Our group of 6 ate and drank a bit of everything. The burgers were super yummy. Mine was over cooked as the server didn't write our orders down... and he forgot our Mac and cheese. The pork chop flavorful with a nice smokiness too it. The oysters were clean and fresh. Nice pickled veggies and ham and biscuits for a starter. Oh, and the house bread tastes like Hawaiian bread. And I love Hawaiian bread. Halibut was perfectly cooked served over beans. The beans needed more spice so I'm told. Drinks.=yummy! Nice wine list. For dessert, we had rocky road ice cream with brownie, cream de pot and lime tart. Very good. The cream de pot was our favorite. All told, a good experience with a few minor bumps. $70 each person so not inexpensive but not outrageously priced either. Oh, and Mr. Server.... write down orders in the future and wear a nice shirt. Tee shirt was too informal.
author: Darrin D.

description:
Needed a place to eat coming a cross country flight from BOS without having to deal with the BS that is the SF dining scene. Serpentine was the perfect call. 
 - Heirloom & Burrata Salad - A
 - Oysters - solid
 - Wild Salmon - A-
author: Jeff F.

description:
This is definitely one of my go to restaurants in San Francisco. The burger is absolutely delicious as is pretty much everything on the menu. I went recently with two other people for brunch and we had the crabs Benedict and deconstructed enchilada both were amazing. The bloody Mary was also delicious!
Their service is also superior to a lot of places in SF. The wait staff is friendly and engaging and doesn't have any attitude like many other places in San Francisco. Definitely worth coming here!
author: Mona M.

description: It looks pretty. And that's about where the positives end. We came in for dinner on a Friday evening at 6 pm. We were seated in a corner table, removed from the main dining room, and it took a full 20 minutes for anyone to come greet us at the table (we asked the hostess if we could order after 15 and still waited another 5 minutes for service). We ordered everything in one go: chicken wings, brassicas, a burger, and two beers. Chicken wings were absolutely covered in a quarter inch of sauce, the brassicas were in a pool of oil, and the burger was meh.  Truly disappointing, and we certainly won't be returning.
author: Bailey D.

description:
Came here on a weeknight for dinner. Cost approx 60 per person for one entree, one appetizer, and shared dessert.  (Adds up quickly with the healthy sf fee).  
Food was fine. Heavy on the garlic. Truffle mushroom soup had no soup and mostly mushrooms. Scallops (only 3 in the entree) were a bit over cooked but the sauce was good.  
My friend was parked on 22nd outside and their car window was smashed in, laptop (hidden in trunk) was stolen during dinner. Maybe best not to drive here.
author: T Y.

description: I was really excited to try a new brunch spot, however, my boyfriend found wax paper in his meal and so did the table next to us who ordered the same meal.  The manager was gracious and immediately offered to replace the meal and comp it, but just thinking of the meal makes my stomach turn and unfortunately I cannot go back.  The wait staff was great, but a restaurant is about the food and this was not a great experience with the food.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Wayyyyyy overpriced for what it is. The albondigas (meatballs) were terrible. The burger was basically a big plate of from he freezer french fries.
Manhattan was weak and they only partially filled the glass it came it so it looked like someone took a big gulp before it got to me. 
This place is everything that's wrong with SF
author: James D.

description:
Took my boyfriend here for Sunday brunch on his birthday and had a great experience!

I HIGHLY recommend the Maryland Blue Crab Benedict ($17) and Red Flannel Hash ($16). The eggs in both dishes were perfectly poached, and the potatoes were perfectly crispy and seasoned. Portions were surprisingly generous, and they're both really flavorful, unique, and tasty dishes. Almost everyone sitting around us ordered these dishes too, and the popularity is well-deserved!

Side note: I'm not usually a huge fan of beets, but the roasted beets in the Red Flannel Hash were so well-cooked and paired perfectly with the brisket. Serpentine has made me a believer in beets!

My boyfriend and I also shared a buckwheat pancake on top of our two entrees (yeah...we eat a lot ^_^;;), which was also delicious. It was topped with apple, banana, pomegranate seeds, candied walnuts, and homemade whipped cream, and served with a side of maple syrup. All of the toppings came together in a tasty way and wasn't overwhelming.

Service was also great! The servers were attentive and very accommodating. They brought out the pancake with a candle lit for my boyfriend (I left a note that we were celebrating a birthday when I made the reservation through Open Table) and took a photo for us.

Overall, great service & amazing food!
author: Sara L.

description:
You've never had a good cocktail in your life, trust me, until you come to Serpentine. The best cocktails in San Francisco!

Friendly wait staff, delicious food, and amazing decor. People were lining up at the door to get in. I suggest trying the place soon because it's going to turn into one of those places where you'll be lucky if you can squeeze in a spot at the bar ;)
author: Devon G.

description: Great food.  Bartender was so amazing.  Great old fashion.   Had ribs and hashbrown.  Highly recommend.
author: Jessica K.

description: Yum! Loved the ambience and brunch. Menu allows for either a classic Benedict but with a cornbread twist or stacked enchiladas and more Mexican inspired dishes. The doughnuts were warm, fresh and covered with chocolate ganache with orange marmalade on the side. Would come back for more brunch or to try dinner.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Awesome. 
That is all that's needed. A bit of a shaky start getting a seat, but then we didn't book one for dinner. 

Dave sorted us out for drinks quick smart and the rest was plain sailing. 
We had the pickled veg, mushroom soup, wings and prawns for entree. All superb. 

Mains pork chop (one of the best I've had in a long time ).  Halibut was likewise very nice and the burger was rated by my colleague as one of the best he'd had in sfo. High praise from him. Trust me. 

Desert bread pudding. Wow
Rocky road. Not my thing but the others loved it. 

My fave bit, I left my phones and someone came after to give them back. Very much appreciated. 

Will be back that's for sure.
author: Mark H.

description: Been to brunch here about once a month for the last three months, because the dishes are consistently excellent and delicious.  Food is prepared with fresh and seasonal ingredients, presentation is beautiful, and service is top notch.  The hamburger is probably one of the best I have ever tasted.  I definitely plan to try dinner here soon.
author: Louise V.

description:
Stopped by on a Wed. early evening and was able to get a seat at the bar. The restaurant was fairly empty considering Opentable claimed there were only late reservations left. Tip-call the restaurant if OT shows no reservations.

Friendly bartender making craft cocktails served us wine :) The wines by the glass are resonable
priced, service was attentive. Split a burger and a salad. Both were very good, though the salad was a basic garden green, nothing special.

Good restaurant and will def. come back. They are closing for the next month for remodeling. Assume it will be even better afterwards. Hope this doesnt get too hipster and too crowded, nice to be able to just walk in.
author: Marie D.

description:
Serpentine is one of the rare SF places that simultaneously takes reservations and is delicious.

It's a cool, industrial space. I've had the butternut squash toast (burrata, balsamic vinegar, endive, sage, walnuts, brown sugar), crispy pork belly hash (pork belly, potatoes, turnip, beets, arugula, creme fraiche, poached eggs, grilled bread), and huevos rancheros (eggs, beans, cilantro, avocado, sour cream, salsa, queso fresco, tortillas), and everything has been absolutely delicious.
author: Christina S.

description:
Went there for brunch and was so disappointed!  I had been there for lunch twice before and loved it (have a very fond memory of an escarole and skirt steak salad that was to do die for) but I did not know that the ownership/kitchen changed in April of this year.  
My $16 hamburger was completely subpar with meat that tasted like a dirty grill.
I loved the "old" Serpentine and its predecessor the Slow Club was one of my favorites!
author: annyvonne l.

description: Probably my favorite restaurant I visited this year. Super friendly and attentive staff with a modern atmosphere. The parts were generous, I liked everything. We'll be back.
author: Addison G.

description:
The food was so good and that's what you want anytime you dine out! Yes, the ambiance can stand out but in the end, it's the food!

The hostess in the front wasn't very friendly or happy looking but the servers/bartenders were fun and very welcoming. The menu isn't huge, which helps you with picking and I can see why. Each dish is thought out and delicious. A few of my friends come here EVERY Sunday, that's how good it is. I know food is subjective, but this place is quite packed and that speaks volumes.

The huevos, the steak and eggs, the burger, the avocado toast. EVERYTHING was tasty and cooked well. Great seasoning, great flavors. 

Serpentine your way into this place because it was ssssssso good!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Yummy trumpet mushroom and kale soft eggs plus the best frisée I've ever tasted. Fresh simple ingredients win every time. Good fast service, polite and professional. We had just come from seeing art at The Minnesota Project. This is more of a hipster brunch place with predictable modern-rustic decor, but eggs never tasted so good and I can't wait to see how this place develops.
author: Anna E.

description:
DEFINITELY MAKE A RESERVATION

I cannot stress this enough! A lot of brunch places in SF don't take reservations, but I've noticed that a lot of brunch locations in DogPatch (Serpentine, aina, etc) do take reservations...so take full advantage of this!

We reserved ~1 weeks in advance. It's a staple place to take visitors for brunch. Great beef hash and super yummy country fried steak (heart attack on a plate). Bar seating is fun if you want to see the bartenders prepare fresh drinks (love that they use a lot of fresh fruits / garnishes and they prep in front of you) 

Also good for groups 4-8
author: Jennifer J.

description:
This is my first time in the Dogpatch and so far, so good!  Serpentine is a small restaurant with an industrial hipster vibe.  After ordering a glass of wine at the bar, we were promptly seated.  

We took advantage of restaurant week and had:

Amuse Bouche:  Hush puppy with dungeness crab

Starter:  Kale Caesar (with brussels sprout...and a meyer lemon undertone...yum!) and butternut squash soup (with curry and coconut milk)

Main:  Braised short ribs (with spicy pimento grits, collard greens, and roasted turnip) and seared yellow fin tuna (very nice sashimi grade tuna and seared perfectly, served with cauliflower, fingerling potatos, and pearl onions)

Dessert:  Warm apple crisp (very large portion!!!) a la mode...wonderful flavor with a cheddar streusel but a little on the sweet side

Overall, wonderful experience in a very cozy environment.
author: M L.

description:
Went straight to business for brunch with their delicious coffee cocktail "whiskey espress" 

A decent sized portion of huevos rancheros. Crunchy corn tortilla with your typical black beans, not so typical "hen of the woods mushroom" and a magnificently undercooked egg. Their red sauce is excellently well balanced. Their side sauce is the scene steeler if you can handle the heavy heat.

Side of sausage is bursting with flavor of herbs and spices with a little too much acidity(vinegar?) for my taste.

Great place, good service and definitely look forward to my next visit
author: Patrick M.

description: I had the Crab Benedict three weeks ago and still can't get over how incredible it was. Worth the wait.
author: Jacyn S.

description: I love the ambiance at Serpentine. I have been coming to this restaurant for years and each time I visit it lowers my expectations. The food has continuously dropped in tastiness and the service is lacking. I do however love the cocktails and the burger served on the dinner menu, but at this point that is all.
author: Hannah M.

description:
Cocktails were terrific, fries were also great but needed salt, which you have to request. Decent brussels sprouts. I ordered the burger medium as I always do, and when it came it was tough with tiny chunks of hard gristle in it. The pieces of gristle were too hard to chew through and I didn't want to spit them out at the table so I had to choke them down. I could only eat a few bites, and brought the burger home. Later that night I got hungry and tried again, but had the same experience and gave up. The bun was great, the way they prepped and combined the toppings was great, but the meat itself was unlike anything I have encountered in a burger. I'm hoping it was a fluke and will probably try again, ordering something else.

UDPATE: Came back here for brunch. Bloody Marys were great, but I wouldn't recommend getting it with the green chile vodka because it overpowers the other flavors. The crispy potatoes are as good as everyone says. Got the cornbread benedict with bacon and crab. You could barely taste the crab and it wasn't worth the additional $6. As other reviewers have pointed out, they purposely overcook the egg so there's no runny yolk to counteract the dryness of the bread. Thumbs down on the cornbread--it's slightly sweet and doesn't work with the savory of the rest. It would have been great with an English muffin and a runny yolk. This restaurant is confusing because it's almost great, but then some detail ruins the meal.
author: Young J.

description: Food was fine, a bit pricey but worth. This is the only place so far that had original belgian beer as "La Chouffe"! Make sure you try them!
author: Francis V.

description:
We had reservations at 10AM and were promptly seated to our table.

Location/Ambiance:  Easy to find parking on a Saturday morning. Small restaurant, with a very modern vibe. 

Food/Drinks:
- Orange Juice $4: Freshly squeezed juice in a large glass 
- Bread Pudding French Toast $13: Interesting. 2 slices of French toast topped with maple syrup, whip creme, & berries. Very thick/dense - defiantly reminded us more of bread pudding than French toast. 
- Salmon Benedict $18: well presented! The eggs Benedict was a typical poached egg, on top of pieces of salmon and a biscuit. The biscuit had a nice texture that's similar to cornbread. There was a good amount of hollandaise sauce, but this dish lacked some flavor..
- Country Fried Steak $16: The meat was battered & fried with a nice crunch (think of KFC) smothered in creamy sauce, topped with pieces of arugula. It came with a biscuit topped with sauce, eggs (requested for sunny side) & delicious potatoes. The best country fried steak I've ever had! Highly recommend. 

Service:
- Seemed like there was 1 waitress for the entire restaurant. She was pleasant and attentive. We also received our food in a timely manner.

Nice place for brunch, with entrees that are shareable friendly, with a unique menu.
author: Linda N.

description:
I knew we wouldn't have a lot of time to wait around for brunch before having to catch a flight back to LA, so I looked for a place with available reservations.  Serpentine popped up and seemed like a good option.  We brought our luggage with us and were seated where we could easily stash it all without getting in anyone's way.  The space filled pretty quickly shortly after opening...always a good sign.

However, my friend and I split the COUNTRY FRIED STEAK & EGGS and the POLENTA & EGGS and, overall, we found the food to be surprisingly bland.  We didn't eat very much and didn't take any with us.  How sad to leave SF on such a disappointing note!
author: Carol L.

description:
The space is beautiful and the service was excellent, but the dinner selections left something to be desired.

We had an early reservation, so we ended up eating at the bar instead of our table in order to feel a bit less weird about our early bird-style dinner...  The space is sort of industrial with a feminine edge, if that makes sense.  Importantly, they have tons of large windows, so it's very sunny and inviting.  I just felt happy being here.

The two guys working the bar were great - really friendly, conversational, made good suggestions, etc.  I had what I assume was a new cocktail because it's not on their online menu - they replaced the tequila with mezcal, which I thought was nice.

For appetizers, we had the Marinated Gaeta and Castelvetrano Olives and the Assortment of Pickled Vegetables.  I liked this both as starters - they were flavorful but still light and fresh.  They had some cool, funky veggies in the pickled vegetables dish, though the little pickled heirloom tomatoes were definitely my favorite.  We also had the Pan Seared Petaluma Chicken Livers which I was NOT into.  I think if you're going to serve whole livers they need to be a bit more deeply fried.  I also didn't really like the sauce - it had some good seasoning but it also tasted a little burnt.

For dinner, I tried BOTH the Potato Gnocchi with Eggplant Caponata and the Guajillo Pepper Farfalle with added shaved summer truffles.  I did not like the gnocchi at all - which made me very, very sad.  The gnocchi themselves were very mealy - either they were over-kneaded or overcooked - and the sauce had WAY too little seasoning.  I mean, it absolutely needed at least more salt.  I actually told them this (only because they asked me for my thoughts), and I thought it was kind of weird that they didn't take it off my bill (I didn't eat it, either).  

My boyfriend agreed on both counts.  He went with the burger (with added Gruyere cheese) and the Grilled Brentwood Corn for his dinner - he liked the burger and said the bun was on point (I thought it was cool that they added so many pickled vegetables to the burger, but that wasn't his jam...) and he seemed OK with the corn.

I think I would go back here and give them another shot because I enjoyed the experience and I liked the space, but I would probably try brunch next time...
author: Tay H.

description: I'm upgrading my review, as I honestly think the food has gotten better and better. The fried chicken is sublime. The salads are tangy, light and lovely. Terrific service and good cocktails round out a great experience.
author: Antonia T.

description: Had a rowdy group meal here - we do monthly dinners together. The chef's menu was ON POINT. We are excited to return. All choices the chef made were so delicious. Picky eaters were pleased as well. Price point was great - we have spent more and walked away with less. Is a noisy place but that helped our usually rambunctious group blend in.
author: Lindsay B.

description: A solid brunch spot. Never a bad wait. You can also make reservations as well. The food is okay. Nothing spectacular, nothing really stands out and maybe that is why the wait isn't long. I do like their **RED FLANNEL HASH, beef brisket, crispy potatoes, roasted beets, arugula horseradish créme fraiche, poached eggs with grilled levain. The beef brisket was very tender and soft. Good flavor. But everything else was just okay. Maybe if they have a special, something amazing, they will be a more popular brunch spot.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Popular brunch spot in dogpatch. Accepts reservations and although there was no line when we went there, it would probably be best to reserve ahead of time.

Red Flannel Hash - 3/5 - Had to try it because of the reviews and how good it looked, but the ratio of beets to everything else was just too high. Needs more meat and less beets for a good balance. 
Biscuits & Gravy - 3/5 - The gravy was very good but the biscuits had the consistency of cornbread. Decent, but there are much better biscuit options out there.
Buckwheat pancakes - 4/5 - Very good. Would order again.

Overall, Serpentine made for a decent brunch. I don't think I'd go out of my way to come for it again but I will likely be back to try their lunch/dinner options. Brunch was "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up. 

Came here for brunch on the weekend. This part of town, while sleepy looking, has a lot of good and popular restaurants. You think there is no one, but you'd be surprised the moment you step into a restaurant for a brunch - they are almost always filled with people. 

Serpentine is known for their cocktails. Naturally I got a Bloody Mary here to try. It was pretty good, savory, but with not enough of a kick. We got the chilaquiles and the breakfast with house made sausage patty. The sausage patty was well spiced, but it had that weird pork smell - like how most of the pork in this country smells if not properly slaughtered. The chilaquiles were good though.

I would definitely come back for dinner if not for more cocktails. The score is rounded up for the cocktails, but I think their food has potential. I suppose smelly pork is just a big pet peeve of mine having grown up with a mostly pork diet.
author: Alice C.

description:
+ THE FOOD
Came here for brunch and the food was pretty good. I had the eggs, meat, potatoes, and bread dish while my boyfriend had their truffle burger. The portion size of the dishes were pretty generous and I was pretty full before I even got close to finishing. I really enjoyed how the sausage patty wasn't too salty as it seemed more healthy. The potatoes were crispy and delicious, while the bread was crunchy and the jam was perfect. My boyfriend's truffle burger wasn't as truffle-y as he thought, but we both really enjoyed his fries. The prices here are a little steep but it's worth coming here once in a while for a nice brunch.
author: Cindy C.

description:
We went to serpentine on a Friday night. As with most places in San Francisco, I would definitely not show up here without a reservation. The restaurant was crowded, but with a pleasant ambiance.

We started with the Dungeness crab hush puppies which were excellent. I moved on to the seared Tuna which came with a beautiful assortment of cauliflowers. Good times were had.
author: John P.

description: We actually came here by chance. We wanted to try another brunch restaurant but the wait there was too long. We dropped by this place since it was near by, and was able to grab a couple of bar seats without a wait (they do take reservation for brunch). I got the eggs benedict, which has corn bread as the bread part! I'm not a huge fan of English muffin, so the bread part is usually my most disliked part of eggs benedict. But having corn bread instead of English muffin, in my opinion, was such an amazing substitution. The dish got great portion but not too overwhelming. Excellent poached eggs with great hollandaise. The bartender was also super friendly and suggested a couple of places we can visit nearby since it was a super nice day. Will definitely come back for their delicious brunch.
author: Sharon L.

description: We loved our brunch at Serpentine. The service was excellent, the food fantastic, and the staff were attentive and friendly. Would definitely recommend.
author: K P.

description:
Great service! Good comfort food

I came here with a group of 6. We were 30 minutes late to our reservation and still got seated immediately. I'm not sure if they're required to do this, but the waitresses served us food while singing along to the restaurant's music LOL

 The hot chicken sandwich was very rich in flavor and had a tinge of sweet sauce on the biscuits. The eggs on the sandwich were also very soft. The fries were perfectly crispy. My friends got the pork belly and it is more of a fried feel than the traditional braised texture. 

Their menu changes every now and then so these dishes might not be available later on. 

I give it a solid 5/7
author: Steven Z.

description:
It's a beautiful venue...sort of industrial chic. 
And I liked the waitstaff; they were very professional.

And I also liked my lunch ( burger/fries) and kid liked hers ( ceasar salad with steak.) 
But, I didn't love the food enough to compensate for the costly bill. Lunch was $50 for two with drinks (sodas.) For that kind of money, I want to be wowed.
author: El B.

description:
T . the bar seats with
O . out rsvp req to be
M . made at all

M . my brunch was
A . all good but the
R . ratchet sausage
V . veered into meh
O . only that was off
L . lizzled the mizzle
O . overall brah

R . realtalk son
I . i might return for
D . dat fried steak but
D . def biscs & gravy
L . liked that most of
E . everything i had
author: Dan B.

description:
Pretty good execution of most food with interesting twist to most dishes is Benedict with cornbread and bacon instead of English muffin and smoked salmon or banana bread French toast. The chefs executed well too ie poached eggs etc 
Service could be much better. At one point our server dropped food and splashed on my friend's jacket. She didn't say sorry or help to clean.
author: Lisa C.

description: If you can make a reservation in advance, I highly recommend heading to Serpentine. Everything that has bread in it is delicious. The biscuits, the pancakes, the chicken fried sandwiches... It's all amazing. And I appreciate that they do some fresh juices if you do not want to drink. This space is always lively and bright, the seating is a little cramped but still worth it!
author: Kaego R.

description: We were a group of 3 and were seated immediately even without a reservation for lunch. We ordered donuts to share which were really tasty and we each got the honey fried chicken since it sounded so great. Unfortunately my friend's fried chicken was raw. We let the server know about the raw chicken and they offered to bring another one or bring another menu option (they brought him a burger 20 minutes after, which they fully charged him). My chicken tasted "funny" but I thought it could be the honey flavor - I thought it was just a disappointing culinary experience. However, I should have read the signals better - the two of us that did get our fried chicken started feeling sick that night / the day after and got a mild case of food poisoning. Never coming back.
author: Federico G.

description:
I made a brunch reservation for last Sunday. I am so stoked on brunch reservations now - it's like I can't really imagine going back to the life where I wait two hours without a drink for eggs in the blazing sun. Of course I will have to at some point, and I shudder just thinking about it. 

We were promptly sat at a pretty sick table in the corner. We started with brunch cocktails, naturally. A Pimm's Cup for me, which was refreshing and delicious, and a tequila cocktail for him. I do not do Tequila cocktails at brunch, unless we are in an establishment that willingly selects Def Leppard for its musical stylings. 

I ordered the brunch burger, which is an odd choice for me. But we were running late for the reservation, and I was starving by the time we got there, and sometimes a burger just hits the spot. And did it ever. Serpentine's burger is a must-have. I ordered it with cheddar cheese (in retrospect, I should have had Gruyere and cheddar, but oh well), cooked medium, with fries (and not salad for god's sake. Why are you going to ruin a perfectly lovely burger with a side salad? If you're going to do a burger, do it right.)  My goodness, that burger was amazing - it was just cooked so beautifully - juicy, delicious, wonderful. The bun did not disappoint (9 times out of 10, when a burger sucks, it's because of the bun), and the fixings (I think, pickled veggies) worked perfectly. I want to do it again. And again. 

My boyfriend was less pleased with his dish, the biscuits, steak and gravy, but since this is my review and not his, five stars. Also, he ate half of my perfectly-cooked burger for his 157th career assist. 

To finish, I had a lavender cocktail with elder-whatever blah blah blah hipster cocktail. But it was great. I followed it with a double espresso. Then I took a long walk. 

Yep, you want to go to here.
author: Sunny S.

description:
First Date #4 of the weekend - 

We were trying to get into the new hotspot, Aina, but quickly learned that we were out of luck without a reservation. A quick Yelp search led us to Serpetine. It wouldn't have been my top choice but we were only a block away and decided to take a chance on it. We were seated after waiting only about 5 minutes. By then, I was practically ready to pass out from hunger. We strategized over the menu and agreed to share the Red Flannel Hash and Country Fried Steak & Eggs.

The food came out relatively quickly and I started with the Country Fried Steak while he started with the Red Flannel Hash. We had agreed to each eat half of the plate and then switch. I was enjoying the tender Country Fried Steak and the crispy potatoes that accompanied the dish were surprisingly flavorful.

When it was time to switch, I realized that he hadn't said much about the Red Flannel Hash. Then I took a bite and I realized that I had just traded away the better dish. If it wasn't a first date, I would've pulled the plate back and said "sorry!" Despite the hype around the Red Flannel Hash, it's just not very good. The beef brisket, which was arguably the most important component of the dish, was tough and bland. The beets did not go well with the meat.

Despite the slight disappointment with Red Flannel Hash, I was pleased with the experience. There are certainly hidden gems in the Dogpatch and I'm going to make a point to try to explore them more.
author: Yi Z.

description: My favorite brunch place. Love it. Cool ambiance and food is great. Service is also great. I've gone for dinner as well and it was great too. It gets pretty crowded on weekends for brunch, but you can make reservations.
author: Yoomi H.

description: One of my favorite spots in San Francisco! Best burger in the city! Amazing service as well. A friend and I were doing the Whole30 and wanted to go out for some catch-up​ time. We landed on Serpentine​ because of location. ​The kitchen was very accommodating​ and answered all of our questions! Highly recommend!
author: Danyelle C.

description:
Had a 2pm reservation here yesterday with a friend. Thought the space was super cool (big fan of high ceilings) and lots of light coming in.

I ordered the huevos rancheros since I was in the mood for eggs and something more savory. My friend ordered the pancakes and doughnuts. Biggest pancake I've ever seen. Thought my huevos rancheros were a solid (a little heavy on the sauce) choice.

I think I'd want to come back here to try some other things on the menu.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: I heard great things about this place and it did not disappoint. We came in about 45 minutes before our reservation and expected to have to grab a drink down the block while we waited, but they found a spot for us right away. The service was attentive, the food was excellent. My friend got the fried chicken and loved it. I got the scallops, which were cooked perfectly. Definitely will be coming back here.
author: Molly T.

description:
TL;DR: Decent brunch food, miserable service if you don't have a reservation

This is my second time at Serpentine, but my experience was so bad that I had to write a review. Called on the phone at 11AM on a Sunday morning, and they told us the wait would be ~30 mins if we walked in for a party of 3 (reservations are not allowed less than 2 hours prior) so we decided to go. They wouldn't put our name down on the waiting list, fine.

Get there at 11:45AM , and suddenly the wait jumps to 1 hour. Fine, slightly annoying, but we did get there 45 mins later, and there were 2 parties ahead of us in the line, plus they had their reservation system. We sat at the chairs in the entrance of the restaurant, waiting for a seat.

40 minutes or so pass by, and it looks like we're gonna be here for a while. They said some seats opened up at the bar, so we could take those if we wanted. We decided to do that because we wanted to eat (can't brunch ever be no-nonsense and simple?). Sat down, ordered our food, and we start to eat. By now it's passed the typical rush hour for Sunday brunch and the restaurant starts to die down.

There are a few tables that open up, so I asked the waiter if we could switch to a table instead of sitting at the bar. She informed me that "we usually do not do that" and that "they might have reservations, but they could check for me if they were free". It's almost 1:30PM, there are 2-3 tables that have been empty for some time now, why you gotta be like that? Are your tables really so precious? What do you mean you don't "do that?" Is my request really so ridiculous?

Anyways, after she talked to the hostess, we were informed that those tables were reserved and they couldn't do anything to accommodate us. Ok, honestly, if that's the case, fine. But what drives me crazy is that when we left around 2:30, those tables were still empty. There were multiple tables that were unused, and even though I asked politely to sit at a table, they don't "do that". I guess they don't "do" half-decent customer service. I feel like this was my biggest gripe - their table management and asinine reservation system. Suggestions: If you're gonna have a reservation system, let people reserve closer to the time, or just get rid of it completely for brunch. Leaving tables empty for the sake of accommodating people that don't make their reservations during one of the busiest time of the week makes little sense to me.

Food was alright. Customer service was off-putting. All service people look so goddamn unhappy, I think small mannerisms built up my frustration. This was just the biggest gripe I had.
author: Albert C.

description:
Was waiting for my mind to be blown...but it was merely a gust of satisfaction received from Serpentine.

I made reservations on a Saturday which was super simple to do over the phone (no hassle yay!). When my party arrived 10 mins before our time we had a short wait and we were graciously seated.

Service was pretty decent so I really can't complain.

 I was craving the Dungeness Crab Benedict and from the online pictures I was pretty hyped. It was served with some amazing breakfast potatoes and an odd tasting salad (waaaay too earthy for me). The crab portion was measly and the biscuit was super cold. The whole dish was cold besides the egg on top. Our waitress was nice enough to get me a fresh plate which was a better rendition of the meal.  I loved the lemon and hollandaise but everything else was just meh about the benedict. It was edible and believe me I ate it but wouldn't be my first choice if I decided to go back. 

They do have a pretty diverse menu so that's a plus...
author: Jenelle B.

description:
Popular brunch spot, but I came out here for dinner. A friend I wanted to meet up with came up for dinner in the City and wanted to meet somewhere along the caltrain line. 

I ordered the short ribs and lemonade (since I'm on a L-B-S reduction plan). The short ribs were amazingly tender and so delicious. It was slightly fatty though which made me kind of disappointed. 

Lemonade was average, but pretty good as well. Not sure if we got free refills or not, but hopefully they do that. 

We split the lemon cake and that was also pretty good. Nice fluffy and moist cake - definitely what I look for in a cake. 

Will have to try the brunch too! Not amazing, but not bad either. 

Protip: get the short ribs. SO GOOD.
author: Nina Y.

description: Wonderful brunch place in the Dogpatch. Great craft drinks and huge servings! I had the huevos rancheros and it was fresh! I did not like the red sauce so much though as it was curry/ Indian spice based not Mexican-based. Nice staff
author: Kitty D.

description: I visited this place on a weekday day night around 8:30pm. It was a good crowd and not too busy. My friend and I got seated promptly without a reservation, which was awesome! The service started off super slow, but got better. The food and drinks themselves were amazing! I ordered the burger and it was so juicy and the fries rocked my socks off! I will return soon!
author: Jeanette Jane G.

description: We have been here many times and usually enjoyed the experience. However today for the first time we came to serpentine with some friends and our 1 year old son, who was sleeping in his stroller. The server woman was rude, unaccommodating and inconsiderate. We were told that we could not eat with our son in the stroller and my husband and I essentially took turns eating with our friends while one of us has to be outside with our son. Several tables which were more suited to a stroller opened up but the server was completely unwilling to make it work for us. We have been to 100 different restaurants with our son and never been treated in such a poor manner. It's really sad when a restaurant cannot accommodate a baby. I think that's a reflection of the poor quality and lack of sophistication of a person and restaurant. A kind gesture towards a family with a child goes a long way which was completely lacking here. We are certainly not supporting this restaurant anymore, there are plenty of other places where the staff are kind and accommodating. Clearly this server shouldn't be in the service industry.
author: Meghna T.

description:
I came to Serpentine with a group of friends the day before my birthday. They graciously accepted a reservation for ten people, despite my call being pretty last minute - and I kept changing the number of people, even up to 1 hour beforehand (I'm sorry!). At first I was lost because I couldn't find it for the life of me, but it was right there on the corner, with "SERPENTINE" written on the outside. I would say a reservation was definitely required, because they were quite busy for Saturday brunch.

My friends ordered cocktails, all of which I sampled. They were all delicious and kicked off my birthday weekend right! I opted for the grapefruit juice, which was just as delicious. I ordered the Fried Egg Sandwich with fruit on the side instead of potatoes. I think the combination of dill aioli, gruyere, and a perfectly cooked runny egg made a simple dish more complex. I loved it! Because my friends and I believe that sharing is caring, of course I sampled their food as well. Of the food I tried, I would recommend the Huevos Rancheros or the Polenta and Eggs - the polenta was surprisingly good.

I have zero complaints about service. Service with a smile, through and through. Even as I changed the reservation so many times beforehand, they put up with me. The folks at Serpentine certainly made my birthday brunch awesome. Will definitely be back.
author: Eryn H.

description:
This place is awesome! Every time I've been in the service was great, the food was delicious, and the cocktails always hit the spot! 

Though the menu changes pretty often, I've never had a seasonal dish I didn't like. 

Do yourself a favor and check this spot out! Perfect for a quick bite or a date.
author: Hannah W.

description: Cool vibe & ambiance. Chicken was okay but the meatballs were super dry. Like dry enough that it's all I can think about while writing this review. The Mac n cheese was also fairly basic and disappointing. Some drinks were good others were bad. Can't recommend this place unless you're meeting a date for a drink and maybe a small appetizer given the ambiance.
author: Kartik S.

description:
I've heard a lot about Serpentine and have been meaning to go here for a while. My boyfriend's birthday seemed like a pretty good reason to try it out, so I set a reservation for 2 for brunch.

We were seated promptly and the waitress handed us menus (on cute little clipboards!) The menu is pretty standard: French toast, huevos rancheros, eggs, bacon, etc. My boyfriend ordered the fried egg sandwich and iced coffee, and I got the steak and eggs with a mimosa. The food came out quickly (less than 15 mins) and the portions were pretty substantial. The potatoes were perfectly crisp and not oily. The biscuit was sooo good and wasn't too flaky. The steak was perfect. My boyfriend also really enjoyed his fried egg sandwich. The mimosa was good. Another customer next to me had the grapefruit mimosa and I wish I tried that instead!

It did take a while for our check to come and also for it to be picked up for processing. BUT it was a busy Sunday morning and I understand that our waitress was overwhelmed with multiple tables. 

Overall, 4/5 stars. It's worth checking out if you're in the area.
author: Jeantelle L.

description:
Serpentine, you've been on my list for far too long, and I' glad we got to have brunch here the other weekend!

RESERVATIONS.
We made ours a week or two in advance, and I'd highly recommend them. They apparently only release 20% of their tables for brunch on OpenTable, so the bulk of the patrons are walk-ins, and it gets extremely busy. I suggest making reservations 2 weeks in advance if you want a real choice in your dining times.

COCKTAILS.
They made fantastic cocktails here, seriously. I had one with elderflower liquer, champagne, and orange peel, which was delightful, and the boy had one with coffee infused into it. You really can't go wrong with their options!

PRATHER RANCH HAMBURGER.
Praised as one of the best burgers in the city, and I can see why. It was perfectly seasoned, cooked to my specifications (although in retrospect I should've asked for medium-rare instead of rare), and came with a nice topping of pickled red onions and house-made pickles. The fries it came with were delicious, also!

RED FLANNEL HASH.
The boy's dish of choice, and also a real winner - two poached eggs, thick slices of bread, arugula, roasted potatoes, and large chunks of brisket. 


Overall, great meal, great location, and worth checking out!
author: Claire S.

description:
The burger. That's what drew me to Serpentine. One of my friends labeled Serpentine's burger as the best he's ever had.

Serpentine graciously takes reservations; we foolishly didn't have one. Fortunately, our post-noon brunch wait was only 15 minutes. The service here ain't sparkling--no, they won't let you split half fries-half salad; no, they won't cut your burger in half for you. Doesn't hurt to ask, kinda hurts to get rejected. That's life, no?

The boy got the $17.50 Dungeness crab Benedict: two poached eggs on buttermilk biscuits, topped with hollandaise sauce, spinach, fried capers & lemon, and herbs, served with a side of crispy potatoes (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/serpentine-san-francisco?select=4w3ceH2V1eJjNHpIJ5p6lA#4w3ceH2V1eJjNHpIJ5p6lA). Dude, this dish is DELISH. Instant kudos to the use of buttermilk biscuits over English muffins, and the somewhat petite portion of crab is ridiculously well-seasoned and works well with the smooth hollandaise. This is a solid dish.

All righty, judgment time. The $13.50 Prather Ranch hamburger was topped with arugula, pickled red onions, and housemade pickles, cushioned in an Acme roll and served with your choice of french fries or greens (but not both, evidently). Add $1.50 to upgrade to a cheeseburger, with a choice of gruyere, cheddar, or blue cheese. I requested medium-rare, which is what I got, yey (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/serpentine-san-francisco?select=4w3ceH2V1eJjNHpIJ5p6lA#nkJtHcNAtMT51Dr4tE1zKA)! The pitiful slice of cheese didn't do much to excite, but the thin Acme bun was a good choice, and the pickles and onions were faaaaaabulous. I'm not a fan of arugula, but the acidic bite from the pickles and onions helped mask the bitterness. Lastly, but nowhere leastly, the patty delivered a lightly salted, hearty meaty punch without too much juicy sloppiness.

My evaluation? Serpentine's burger is indubitably tasty, but on my list, it takes 5th. Bring on the next burger!
author: Adele F.

description:
Totally disappointing... their chef must have taken a hike and all his recipes!  

donuts were shaped like odd rocks instead of balls...  crispy potatoes were more salty than crispy, pancakes were soggy and IHOP could have done a better job, eggs were thrown together like a six year old with no supervision. 

I saw my neighbors food and theirs looked equally unappealing... 

Another couple left after minutes of not being attended to.  

The first clue should have been the non-existent line.  This place used to be amazing, but overpriced. Will not last very long if this keeps up...
author: Nick C.

description:
Having been to this restaurant both before and after the recent renovation, I can confirm that Serpentine has only gotten better in terms of both food/drink and ambiance! The things I loved about the restaurant before the renovation, like the industrial vibe complete with tons of light inside and the incredibly delicious menu, are definitely still there and have only been improved post-reno. There are some delicious new dishes and drinks to try, so get in here soon! 

A couple recommendations, the shandy is perfect on a warm day and the deviled egg salad is the best I have ever had!
author: nate r.

description:
Bored of the usual suspects. Needed a new hood to brunch at. Started the sentence with "back in the day" to describe Dogpatch is a sure sign of aging. These were once young girls who would not leave Cow Hollow or the Marina because there were no cabs available on Sunday mornings, it was way before Uber and Lyft showed up and way before people met online. These women met prospective dates through friends of friends, a big incestuous pool covering a few neighborhoods: Cow Hollow, Marina, Telegraph Hill, Russian Hill, Pac Heights and North Beach. It was quickly decided that good ones were swiftly taken and the bad ones forever got tossed back into the pool. 

Finally the struggle was complete and children after children later, they became ladies who lunch. They do FB but not Twitter nor Instagram; they talk about play dates and the difficulty of getting pregnant again in their 40s; and yes, they gossip about divorces and the "THAT" mother in their kids' elementary schools. You know, the one who's dialed in and get into everyone's business, but still so helpful in so many ways. City girls are now mothers with houses in the East Bay, Marin and Peninsula, notwithstanding the last one, who against all odds, stayed but moved to Inner Richmond, because Peabody is a better elementary school than that Catholic school in North Beach. 

Still, no matter how old these ladies get, they must find good places to brunch like the Sex and the City women did. They must because what else is left but that occasional escape from being a wife and mother? 

Incoming Serpentine who is rumored to offer great brunches in a neighborhood that has parking. You see, no matter how old you get, Marina and Russian Hill are still hard to find parking in.

Food. Yes food is good. Always go for what the waitstaff recommends. Pouched eggs with crab meat, very seasonal. Fried egg sandwich reminds one of something you had in Nopa, and the beef hash was filled with beets on the bottom and soft eggs on top. All delicious.

Industrial looking decor. A very young crowd. Not like the Outerlands, which is always filled with strollers, this is not for parents with little rug rats. Which in this case, is a plus. Service is very good. The coffee was filled frequently, and the water came with ice. Not to mention, they were superbly good at seating people right away - although, brunch reservation did have to be made over one month in advance.

For a successful brunch to end on a high note, one must examine the surroundings. Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous ice cream had sour mango, Spicer on Third had the perfect birthday present, and Magnolia Brewery was already open. The heart wandered to their pickles and smoked duck. Winemaker was where one did a team building event not too long ago. One girl said that Gilberth is a great little spot to dine in with an intimate setting, especially if one is looking for a secret spot to rendezvous with a new lover without having to worry about being spotted.

The ladies ate slowly and pulled out their iPhone 6s to select a weekend to do a girls weekend get away trip in San Diego. With all the holidays and obligations, it would appear May is perfect.

A relaxing place to dine, you did not feel rushed. You had a private booth to chat with your closest girlfriends, you make plans for the next brunch, and when you are done dining here, you book a table for two for Tuesday night next door at Gilberth's.  You are showing some love for this up and coming neighborhood, because Serpentine was a success.

And indeed, parking was superbly easy and free.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Walked in with my boyfriend on a Sunday and was immediately seated at an open table! This was a relief because similar brunch spots in the area had a 1-2 hour wait.

Portions were huge and the food did not disappoint! Would definitely recommend the egg sandwich and salmon benedict on a homemade biscuit
author: Emily Y.

description: We've walked by this place lots of times before, but the exterior isn't super welcoming, so we hadn't tried it until recently.  So glad that we finally came here for dinner.  The pork chop was absolutely incredible, rivaling the one at Nopa.  Perfectly seasoned and cooked, with deliciously crisp Brussels sprouts.  The ambiance is a little dark and dim, and I don't really remember the other food we got, but that pork chop is a must have!
author: Simon L.

description: The restaurant is really nice setting in dogpatch neighborhood. Drinks are very good. The menu selections are very nice, but very carbohydrates laden. Their buttermilk biscuits and beignets are awesome. I had the Pork belly hash which was okay.
author: Sridevi K.

description: I loved this place before the reno, but now I love it even more! The new inside is very similar to the old, but just a bit more elevated and cohesive and the new bar is really cool! Same delicious cocktails, same amazing burger with an added pimento cheese spread - YUM! My new favorite dishes is the deviled egg salad, the country ham hash and the honey fried chicken sandwich. Try them all, you will NOT be disappointed! So glad this place is back!
author: Chelsea P.

description: I stopped in to have a casual dinner at Serpentine with a friend on a sleepy Monday night, and can't say that anything I had there was overly remarkable but nothing I had was bad either.  My friend and I shared an order of the brussel sprouts, and I had the oven roasted chicken.  The sprouts were delicious, and definitely something I would get if I were to go back (especially since they seem to not always be on the menu).  The chicken was a generous portion and cooked well.  While I don't know if I'll be in a hurry to go back to Serpentine, it was certainly nice to have as an option in the Dogpatch!
author: Lisa I.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Sunday morning, without reservations, and were seated in 15 minutes. Impressed. 

The spicy Bloody Mary was flavorful and strong, the coffee was good. 

We got the biscuits and gravy, which is a side order of one large biscuit. It was so fluffy and the gravy was great- there was something unique about it, and I loved it. 

Also got the fried egg sandwich which was great, and one (huge) buckwheat pancake. All the food was fantastic and served to us hot, fresh, and quickly. Good value for the service and the quality of the food.
author: Jo K.

description:
I would review this place 3.5 stars. I came here for Sat brunch. I liked that I could make reservations and not have to worry about a looong wait time.  You MUST get the buckwheat panckages. OMG they are soooo good. Probably one of the best pancakes I've had in so long. 

I got the hash and it was alright. It came out in big chunks of meat and the potatoes are boiled in their gluten free fryer! But surprisingly they were quite good even though they did not look appetizing to me. Overall the brunch items seem OK, but the pancakes are the best!! Service was great too. I would come back just for the pancakes.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Have been here for both dinner and brunch. Dinner: Their homemade chips were just wonderful I could have eaten them all night! I have never enjoyed a kale salad more- their Caesar kale was so tasty I highly recommend it. The ambiance is great. It's a small space but they did an excellent job with the space. 

The brunch was good also, I had the burger and my friend had pork belly- both very heavy but tasty. We also ordered the donut holes. Big portions- way too much food for us we had to take it home. I ordered the Bloody Mary which I normally love everywhere but I would ask for it with less dijon (or hot mustard) next time as it was really spiced and I couldn't finish it, it had way too much kick for me. 

Will always come back here when I think of a nice date night!
author: Isabelle P.

description: Great food. Small and intimate atmosphere. They really do put a lot of energy to drinks which is great and definitely one of the best parts. Also great menu
author: Khurram M.

description: The space is awesome and brunch was outstanding. High quality food. A little pricey, but great service.
author: Sylvia S.

description:
They take reservations for SUNDAY BRUNCH!! That alone deserves 5 stars!! The staff was so friendly and accommodating, especially after we called to say we were running late. Nonetheless we walked in (15 min late) and easily got a table. 

I LOVE the open space of this restaurant. The industrial design and lighting make for great brunch atmosphere, which makes up for the food (ekk, burn i know). 

We ordered the buckwheat pancakes with fruit and whipped cream...tasty but nothing spectacular. Crab Benedict with capers on a biscuit...MEH. Country fried steak was more breadcrumbs than steak with a side of weak sauce (insert sad face).

Overall I would definitely come back but for the prices I'd probably brunch elsewhere. HOWEVER, for the mere fact they accept reservations this place is GOLDEN!
author: Caye Q.

description: Serpentine is a California icon.  The kitchen has a sixth sense when it comes to taste buds.  So does the bar.  The April 22 Sunday Supper is but one example of a tasting fantasmagoria.  The cornbread and deep fried catfish were to-die-for.  The mint julep was exceptional - this coming from someone who's not tasted bourbon in 30 years after a nasty experience with that particular spirit.  I could go on but... my significant other is thanking me again and again for bringing her to the Sunday Supper and, while she has exceptionally high standards, this is no mean feat having gained her approval too.  Great menu.  Great food, and service.  Great start to the evening.  Ted R.
author: Ted R.

description:
Solid brunch spot!

I was hoping to hit Brenda's but the line was crazel! So we stumbled upon Serpentine and was gladly seated quickly. 
Yay!!

Quaint but modern and chic. Great bar in the middle of the restaurant. Small booths and tables but the high ceilings make it feel much roomier. 

I had some of the country fried steak, it was lathered in creamy gravy and came with these great potatoes and fluffy biscuit. I also tried the red flannel hash and the brisket was tender and flavorful. I am a huge fan of roasted beets and it was so good. Portions are quite large but I couldn't stop eating!

I loved that they did both our order of eggs so perfectly. One poached and one sunny side up and the yolks were bright golden yellow delish! 

Surprisingly, I did not enjoy the pineapple and vanilla bean jam. It reminded me of Carmax lip balm.
author: Sonya T.

description:
As a native/long time SF resident I've been going to serpentine, like a lot of people, for years. I was really excited to hear about the remodel/revamp of one of my favorite spots so I went as soon as they reopened. Actually I've been a couple of time (which is why I've waited to write a review). IT IS AWESOME! The food is AMAZING (see descriptions bellow)! I love the new space - the light is amazing (esp. from the new windows). They've always had great drinks, but the new cocktail list is really worth exploring.I'm one of those people who eat with others primarily so I can try what everyone else is eating so I'm going to do a quick rundown of my favorites:

* THE BURGER, always considered one of the (if not the) best in SF is the same - they just added aioli, which if anything, enhances it's greatness!
* Bowls for lunch? Yes! I ordered the pork belly bowl last time for lunch and loved the the crispy egg fried garlic combo with just enough spice from the fermented chili vin. I also tried the both the salmon & veggie - all of which had really nice flavor profiles and combinations. 
* Deviled Egg Salad is also a hit! Two of my favorite flavors (deviled eggs & Caesar dressing) together is a combo that was happily discovered.
* Kampachi: I loved this! It's a fresh balance of flavors that was a welcomed on the warm evening that I had dinner. 
* I'm super particular about fried chicken and often skeptical about savory & sweet combos, but it was cooked perfectly and the spice really balanced out the sweetness of the honey. Plus, there's fried okra which can't be beat.
* And then there's the pork chop. What a chop! Cooked perfectly to medium and as thick as they get. I didn't get to each much of the Carolina Gold rice though b/c my dining companion got to it first (there's always next time...)

I can't wait to go back!
author: Daniel M.

description: Came in around 1pm on a Fri. Not too busy. Got the short rib & hash. The inside of the hash was a little bit too mushy for me. But I still enjoyed it. My friend got something with fries on the side and the fries were good. Feels a bit expensive for what you get, but that seems to be the norm for these more hipster restaurants. I'd consider coming back again if I'm in area and don't know what to eat.
author: J L.

description: Fries were good. Mc & cheese was good. The veggie bowl sucked. Egg Benedict was ok. Not worth the price. Only order the salmon or the chicken. Nothing else is worth your time or money.
author: Liberty B.

description: Serpentine has a great menu all day long, but I like to come for brunch. The cocktails are the stars here. It's in an interesting area, and I always find somewhere unique to visit in the neighborhood after enjoying a beverage or two (or three) here!
author: Jason J.

description:
Another hip little place in fierce competition with the SF brunch scene.

It has a neat ambiance, very industrial-themed with minimalist decor, accents of cement, and the telltale warehouse high ceiling.  They are also minimalist with the hipsterness--menus are on a cute clipboard but there are no mason jars.

The fact that Serpentine takes reservations is godsend, because the impossible Plow crowd plows up all my patience.  However, be sure to make the reservation at least a week ahead of time, because for some reason they only open up 20% of their tables for brunch reservations.  I was proud of myself for snagging a 1:30 timeslot and watching the OpenTable reservations quickly disappear, but then it felt silly to see several open tables when we arrived at the ungodly brunch-almost-turned-linner hour.

BAKED EGGS, $12.50 (two eggs, spiced garbanzo beans, spigarello, roasted summer squash, hen of the woods mushrooms, roasted cherry tomato salsa, rosemary salt, with toasted levain): Some previous reviews warned that that this was underwhelming, but it sounded unique enough that I decided to give it a try.  It was not mind-blowing, but I liked how it was lighter and vegetarian, compared to all the typical food coma-inducing bacony brunch fare.  I think they need to work on the composition though--there is nothing in the mix to soak up the glorious runny yolks, so it ends up being a greasy puddle.  (Perhaps brown rice would be good for this... mmm, breakfast bibimbap)  Also, the mushrooms were scant and there was an overload of garbonzo beans--tasty, but it got tiring to eat because the beans were so pungent and chewy.

RED FLANNEL HASH, $12.50 (beef brisket, crispy potatoes, roasted beets, arugula, horseradish créme fraiche, poached eggs, rosemary salt, grilled levain): A dish could not have a more hipster name than red flannel hash (FYI flannel is not a vegetable like I thought; it refers to the red potatoes in this dish.)  The beef brisket melts in your mouth!  The levain is a crunchy artisan bread which tastes delicious and looks good in pictures.  

Overall Serpentine has solid, creative brunch food (plus rumors of the burger run deep), but I think my main complaint was the service--the server was flippant, minimally interactive and minimally attentive.  She clearly smirked at us judgmentally  for taking pictures of our food -_-;;  Jeez, we are only showing our appreciation for the food and the ambiance, plus we're advertising for free!  Maybe she was trying too hard to be a hipster imitating Four Barrel's Instagram ban.
author: Edna C.

description:
Top 3 burger in the city. 

Great bartenders and lots of seats to belly up to the bar. 

Love this place.
author: D M Beezy e.

description: Excellent venue for creative apps, entrees, and most of all cocktails...suggest passing on the Mission, and make haste to Dogpatch, since at least you can park... burgers are as good as they can be in the city, and the grilled asparagus draped over an egg 'over easy' is not to be missed...cocktails, old school and new, are really outstanding...will be back without any reservation...
author: Joseph E.

description:
0 stars for service. The host sat us pretty quickly, but servers delivered food to our neighboring table, went back and forth for that table to get the chef's answer to their question (something about hot sauce). Then, the table right next to us was seated later but their order was taken first. It wasn't until we flagged down the waitresses did we even get a chance to order. And she seemed pissed to do it. We even scooted over because we were next to the corner table and the waitress told us she couldn't get to that table so she ordered us to move over. So we did; but no thank you, or sorry for the inconvenience, or anything, she just proceeded to take their order and then was about to disappear again before we stopped her. 

Really disappointing because we live in the neighborhood. We left pretty quickly, and let the hostess know we wouldn't be staying for brunch. No thank you.
author: Andy C.

description: I am pleased to have this spot in the neighborhood. I really like the space, the fact that we can walk there, and the quality of the food and drink. They are able to meet my vegan needs as well as satisfy my guy. He had the fried chicken last time and it looked great.
author: Sheila S.

description:
I visited Serpentine for the first time during SF Restaurant Week.

I ordered their Prather Ranch Hamburger with Gruyere cheese, while my two friends ordered the fixed menu. I do have to say thought that I was a bit disappointed with the burger, especially after our host and server hyped it up. There wasn't really anything special to it. After recently visiting Marlowe and getting the popular Marlowe Burger there, Serpentine's didn't quite do it for me. 

Luckily, my friends let me taste their dishes from the SF Restaurant Week menu. While I didn't get a chance to take a bite of their Dungenous Crab Hush Puppy, both said it was fantastic! The Kale Caesar Salad was delicious, somehow packed with more depth than your typical Caesar. For their main dish, they ordered the Chile-Modelo Braised Short Ribs, which I NEED to highlight since it was INCREDIBLE! Super tender, juicy, and just melted in my mouth! And finally for dessert, they ended their meal with the Warm Apple Crisp (which was a generous size) and Salted Caramel Pot de Creme. The Apple Crisp warmed my soul and went perfectly with the scoop of buttermilk ice cream that came on top (I'm drooling just thinking about it!). The Salted Caramel dessert was similar to a custard, which was also very tasty.

Good ambiance and service, overall pretty pleased.
author: Christine T.

description: I really enjoyed this place.  A colleague of mine, from San Francisco, introduced me to this little place and we had a great meal!  We started with the warm olives, which were excellent and we both had the burger with cheese and truffle fries.  Its a quaint place, nice service, excellent ambience and very good food.  They had the local Anchor steam bottles which we enjoyed with our meal as well.  Would definitely go back when I'm in San Francisco again!
author: MichaelAnthony C.

description:
Their brussels sprouts are to die for!!! I absolutely love brussels sprouts and these were cooked perfectly! They were crispy and buttery at the same time! I'm not sure how healthy they still were considering how much oil was probably used but they made the meal. The burger was quite good and the dijon mustard was tangy. Nothing to rave about, but it was good sized. My friend ordered the mushroom pasta which was also tasty and filling and a great option for vegetarians. It was nicely flavored and perfectly al dente. 

Lighting and ambiance was quite dim and romantic like most places in this area during the evening. Its one of the less crowded places to eat on a Saturday evening and there were quite a few empty tables around us. They also have a full bar with any cocktail you can imagine!
author: Lisa H.

description: Food was not as good as I expected. Scallop was pretty good, but the burger was kinda mediocre. Cocktails were terrific.
author: June C.

description:
