Sat at the bar last night and it was disappointing. The restaurant was 2/3 full with a large party and the bartender was busy making drinks for them. I'm pretty sure they were one bartender short, so we were fine with waiting. When we did get served he was still (understandably) stressed-out. I got a lesson on why my cocktail, which was light and delicious, would not be summer appropriate (but srsly, it would be with gin). 

We *really* wanted to order food and it took quite a while to even get a menu. And the food was not great. The citrus salad was full of very tough, bitter greens (dandelion, mustard) and large pieces of (pickled?) fennel, all of which were difficult to manoeuvre.  The warm olives are...a dish of olives.  Sure, fine. The mac and cheese was very soupy, with no crust, and overly-sharp cheese. Did not like at all. Loved the brussels sprouts--really crispy and flavorful.  Our bar-neighbor got bread; we had to ask for it.

We spent about $90 with tip for three $12 cocktails (all solid), two starters (including the aforementioned plate of olives) and two sides. No entrees. By San Francisco standards (ugh), it wasn't insanely pricey. But it really needed to be better.

If it were up to me (it seldom is), I'd eliminate the bar completely. It doesn't work well in the space. There are two pillars which make it feel very crowded even when all of the stools aren't full. Think of it like a stadium where half of the seats have an obstructed view. One end of the bar is right by the kitchen and there's no space for anyone to move freely or prep. There's a lot of rushing around. At one point someone was hastily folding napkins right next to me. It's just a really small space with poor layout, and I felt bad for the people trying to utilize it.

Tl; dr- If you're going to Serpentine don't sit at the bar and maybe avoid the small plates. Except the brussels sprouts. Get those.
author: Joe B.

description:
I just visited Serpentine last week with a couple of my girlfriends to check out what the newly remodeled space looked like...  The experience was stellar to say the least! 

I have always loved the industrial look of the restaurant and was so happy to see that the restaurant still has the same vibe and feel to it, just freshened up.  The updated service ware was beautiful and I loved the addition of the ficus which really brings a lot of life to the space!  As always, the staff was extremely friendly and helpful with recommendations.  

We wound up ordering the chipotle and chorizo mussels (which might be the best thing I've eaten in the last six months), the scallops with country ham, and the peppers as an appetizer .  All of the food was was perfectly seasoned and delicious...  Finished the meal with the Pot de Creme, which is a MUST if you visit.   To drink, I had "Erin's Drink" which was super inventive (like a margarita with a hint of cinnamon) and I loved it.  My girlfriend had the Genepy Spritz which was perfect for the hot weather. 

I'm so stoked this is across the street from my work... can't wait to go back for brunch!!
author: Brynn D.

description:
Tried this place for brunch today, serendipitously. Originally, my husband and our friends were thinking of going to Plow, but there was already a 2-hour wait for a table at Plow, even though we showed up at 9:30 in the morning on a rainy Sunday. Plow doesn't take reservations, so you really have to want to eat there to waste 2 hours of your life just waiting for your name to be called. Anyhow, thanks to Plow and their ridiculous wait time, we ran into this place and decided to try it. It was a score! I had the FRIED EGG BISCUIT SANDWICH
fried egg - arugula - heirloom tomato - gruyere - dill aioli - crispy potatoes + their house made sausage and also their APPLE COBBLER PANCAKES
apple compote - calvados gastrique - streusel - whipped cream. Both were exceptionally delicious. The biscuit they used for the Fried Egg Biscuit Sandwich was made in-house and fresh. It was sooo good. The sausage was also very, very tasty. There were several other things on the menu that also looks good, like their 
BUTTERMILK DONUTS
salted caramel - vanilla icing. There will definitely be another visit from me.
author: Rindah L.

description: Four of us came in for brunch today. We shared a truffle fry (a stand out), donut, and hushpuppy. We then ordered the honey fried chicken, the maple french toast, the short rib hash, and the stacked enchiladas. The fried chicken was off the bone, which I wasn't expecting, but it was great, would order again. The enchiladas needed some spice, but everything else was good. The donuts were nice and chewy, but I wouldn't necessarily order them again. I'd skip the hush puppy.
author: Jannah T.

description: Had an Amazing dinner I had the Ahi it was very good. The beet salad is truest life changing. It was busy when we went around 9p. The service was a little slow but the server and the host were super friendly. If you're in Dogpatch and want a great place to eat that has that city vibe go.
author: Chris A.

description:
Was excited to try this place cus it's been on my list for a while and everyone raves about the brunch here. I came with my friend on Friday morning, and we were presented with the lunch menu. Then we found out that they only served brunch on weekends. I didn't remember reading that on the reviews. Such a bummer cus we were really craving brunch :( 

The their lunch menu was quite limited, there really weren't much to choose from. We ordered the tuna salad, falafel burger and a side of fries. Everything was just decent, nothing special. The pickled cabbage on the burger was a little excessive in my opinion, I took it out of my burger. The fries came in a large portion. 

Although we didn't think our food was that great (maybe brunch would've been better), the service was great. Our server was very attentive, she constantly checked in with us and refilled our drinks. Probably wouldn't come back for lunch, but I would like to try their brunch next time.
author: Carmen G.

description:
Came by for brunch the other day with a reservation from a week prior via OpenTable. 

Service throughout the meal was prompt and courteous by the staff.

Started off with the Crab Egg Benedict which was mediocre. There was a small portion of real crab and the eggs were poached medium as requested. The potatoes were tasty, although slightly burnt and the salad was very good. Unfortunately, the buttermilk biscuit didn't quite look as such and wasn't very good...

Moved on to the Prather Ranch Burger that Yelpers were raving about and it was excellent. The patty was fresh and flavorful. The burger was cooked to medium as requested. Even the bun was fresh and fluffy along with being slightly toasted. The fries were perfectly fried...much better than the potatoes.

...the house pork sausage was a miss...definitely skip.

~$22 after tax and tip for brunch.

...the tables are pretty closely placed together...
author: Derek S.

description:
My group of friends doesn't hang in the Dogpatch too often, and it's a shame.

Serpentine is my ideal kind of brunch spot - great food and drinks (crab benedict and grapefruit mimosa!), easy street parking, takes reservations and is not so cramped that you can overhear conversations from neighboring tables. 

I came here and went to the Philz Coffee HQ around the corner to do some weekend work, but this would be a great brunch spot to hit up after rock climbing or boxing, which are only a few doors down from Serpentine. Solid spot!
author: Melissah L.

description:
Latisha made the night with her great service and recommendations . The food was amazing!!!!
The bartender was a bit aloof when we first arrived , but the service after more than made up for it. The flank steak. Get it !
author: Carol G.

description: I was impressed that serpentine delivered on not only tasty dishes, but also and notably, very large portion sizes. I would say that takes them from a standard, semi-exciting 4-star brunch to a 5 star due to value. They were also kindly accommodating of my pescatarian friend and offered crab for her Benedict to replace the pork, which honestly sounds even better to me
author: Neal B.

description: Eat brunch! Be happy! Menu changes sometimes is my only complaint because what I crave and come for might not be on the menu anymore but items are usually replaced with something better. I try to get over here once or twice a month from the mission. This city needs a better brunch game and Serpentine is definitely setting a good example.
author: Zac B.

description:
I finally got my buddy from out of town to come here with me, since all of my local friends had already been here, and didn't like it.

Came here for brunch on a Saturday and ordered a burger since the egg and bacon thing just wasn't speaking to me.

The burger itself was good, with it's medium rare center and the marinated onions.

The fries were lukewarm though, which dropped my experience down a star.

Also, the tables are super close to each other, which makes it seem like I was sitting next to the Sex in the City girls right next to us who were busy talking about getting their hair done while they drank mimosas for brunch.

I guess they don't need real food, only real alcohol.

So it was hard to hear my buddy over their loud laughter and gabbing about highlights and whatever hair tips they decided to share with each other.

We felt like we were in a salon.

The service was slow, and there was only one waitress for a large section....so it was hard to get anything. Water. Napkins. Bill. We were on our own.

So coldish fries...loud cackling table next to us...and lackluster service from our waitress= 3 stars.
author: Jack R.

description:
Hamburger was ok
Dumplings was very doughy. Ok overall 
Pork chop was good.
Steak was very good. The potato was excellent
Mac and cheese pretty good
author: Jones T.

description:
Came here for lunch on Sunday at noon.  Luckily there was no line when we got there, but I do think we took the last available table.  The restaurant had a very industrial and rustic vibe going on, but it let in a lot of sunlight!  

Pros:
- Large variety of drinks on the menu (both alcoholic and non-alcoholic)
- Twist on all your favorite breakfast foods (hash, fried egg sandwich, bread pudding)
- Good service

Cons:
- A bit pricey for a brunch/lunch

Definitely need to order:
- Red fennel hash (tender beef, crispy potatoes, poached egg, and beets)
author: Sophie L.

description: The food might be great but the noise level here is LOUD, not average as listed, due to the exposed industrial concrete and lack of acoustic tile. Consider another restaurant if you want a quiet dinner.
author: Joseph P.

description: Very nice trendy place in SF Dog Patch district.  We decided to go small plates round.  Ordered only oysters, fave beans, short ribs, and duck duck chicken plate.  Poured it over with very dirty-extra olives-Ketel One martini.  That was enough food for 2 of us.  Food was very fresh and tasted wonderful.  It is quiet loud in there, I guess the aquatics of the place.  Thing that I didn't like was waitress was coming over too many times, and was trying to take away plate even though we were still working on them.  Place is on tb red pricey side; for all of this text bill was around $110.
author: Maryanna K.

description:
Dinner @ Serpentine was good, but not as special or good as remembered or expected. Maybe the Serpentine strength is in breakfast / brunch. I wonder if Serpents are stronger in the morning. Server seemed a bit aloof, while pleasant and "on task" she acted like she had better things to do, she did accomplish the task at hand: to take our order and get it to the kitchen and get the food to the table. Surveying the tables, nary a millennial was munching, nuttin wrong w/ the middle aged+ Chardonnay sipping crowd, but the "who" in "who is dining at a joint" can be a temperature gauge of relevance. The bar is the center piece of the joint and with the many workers close by, I would guess that it is a popular watering joint; although directly across the street is the Dogpatch Saloon which dates back to 1912.

Had a few appetizers at the table (calamari / chicken livers / heirloom tomatoes), they were OK, nothing that stood out, the portions just seemed skimpy. 

Entrees:

Hanger Steak: ordered medium (because I wanted to share it with my honey since we both had a late lunch), came out RARE. Ms. Serpentine Server offered to return it to the kitchen for a few more minutes on the grill, I decided to take the steak home and just order another meal - the Duck on a rush. While pleased it landed on the table quickly, it was a disappointing dish. An OK taste but a bit too mushy (yes Martha, Ima aware of how the dish is prepared - braised), even if braised it should require chewing. 

Gnocchi - tablemate reported as OK, a consummate polite international student, so, not really sure it was enjoyed. Being young, not yet of drinking age and hungry does provide wiggle room for what is "good".

Ravioli - reported as underwhelming. 

Not sure what has happened to Serpentine, but RED FLANNEL HASH just ain't enough to impress diners on an ongoing basis. Seems like this joint needs a reboot. cltl-alt-delete. Refresh & UPDATE.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Was excited to eat here for the first time and won't be going back.  The service was REALLY bad.  Two waitresses were unfriendly, rude and rushed us through dinner the second we sat down, which I find surprising for a "high end" restaurant.

Also, I thought the food was just so-so and most had been pre made and was sitting in the kitchen.  For example, we ordered hush puppies and they were not warm nor crispy on the outside.

Very, very disappointed over all!
author: Alice L.

description:
Lovely place, grub and service in the heart of the Doggypatch :)
They've got a very organic menu with plenty of options for veggies, vegans and meat eaters. The day we went, they had a beet and watermelon gazpacho which was refreshing for a hot day.
They also had great sandwiches and lattes. I've heard that the brunch impresses too.
The place is right across the street from Mr and Mrs Miscellaneous ice cream (one of the best ice cream parlors in the bay)
so you can have a brunch and save some room for the creamy goodness too.
I would return!
author: Kinjal N.

description: I love this place. The staff are awesome. The food is awesome. The space is awesome. 5 stars. Go eat at this place. Get some drinks from the friendly bartenders. Get the burger. Get brunch. Do it and enjoy the entire experience. I love serpentine.
author: BRADY K.

description: I like this restaurant. It has a cozy atmosphere and home heat. I like the food and service has always been good for us.
author: Delilah G.

description:
First time dining at Serpentine for dinner (Monday night), and I had a very pleasant experience.

We ordered the salad wedge, burrata cheese, some burgers, the roasted chicken, and salmon, and all were delicious.

However, the thing that made me really enjoy Serpentine was the friendly service. The hostess, our waiter, and Patrick the bartender were all accommodating and friendly. Thanks, guys!
author: Alfonzo J.

description:
I came here for brunch with some coworkers. We all got the fried egg sandwhich which was excellent. Two of my coworkers are pregnant so they requested the egg over-hard and it was still delicious. Probably not the healthiest meal option, but I would recommend it along with their mimosa! I'd come back here for brunch again and try something else on the menu. 

You can make reservations for this place on opentable unlike most other brunch restaurants.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Dropped in for brunch on a Saturday morning a few minutes after they opened and the restaurant was quite filled up. 

Brunch means mimosas! I got the ruby mimosa and if I remember correctly, it was grapefruit flavor. This place had one of the best mimosas I've ever had. It was so yummy! I could've easily gulped down a few more glasses but I contained myself lol.

I got the fried egg sandwich and a side of their house pork sausage. My sandwich was good, but really, how can you mess up a fried egg sandwich? The dill aioli was a nice touch. The potatoes that came with my dish was perfectly crispy, I think I enjoyed them more than the sandwich itself but overall I would def order it again. I didn't really care for the sausage and I wouldn't order it again but my friend ordered a side of bacon and I really liked it. 

Service was quick and the servers were all friendly. I'll definitely be back if I'm in the area to try out the rest of the menu and for the yummy mimosas!
author: Joanne L.

description:
Experience:
I was working from home but really craving a burger, so I made an order for pick up. They said it'd be ready in 15m so I biked over in 10m (5m commute) and like clockwork, just as promised, it was ready to go. The guy who greeted me (tattooed guy behind the bar) was really nice and didn't hurry me since I was only doing pickup, he saw I was sweating from the bike ride and immediately offered me water and even refilled it as he was processing my payment. Most places try and get you in an out as fast as possible when making a to-go order and never ask if you need anything (besides utensils and what not).

The Goods:
Between the pickled onions, yellow tomato and crispy (but not overcooked or dry) bun, the crunch in this burger was perfect. The meat itself was cooked to perfection and definitely quality. The blue cheese was an added bit of flavor that the burger didn't even need (yet it was very much appreciated). Fries were thinly sliced and salted just right. Kind of like (dare I say it) a better version of McDonald's fries. The bun really stood out as well. It was really fresh and buttered nicely. I literally could have eaten the bread from the bun alone as an appetizer. All in all, each piece of this meal was good enough to stand out yet complimentary enough to all work together. 

Funny thing is, lunch/dinner isn't even what this place is known for (based on yelp), which only makes me want to come for their brunch and breakfast even more. Will definitely be back!

Cool staff, great food.
author: Gio L.

description: We ended up here by accident as another place had over a 2 hour wait time. We are so glad we discovered this place at it is not only a trendy brunch.. The food and service are awesome. We ordered smoked salmon Benedict which came with potatoes and some greens. It was so good I forgot to take a picture. The bread was different than we expected as it was more of a thick bread but still went well with the overall dish. Our Mimosas were about $10 a glass yet the bartender was very generous with his pour. Overall no wait time at the bar and the max wait time was 30 min for a table. We will return again!
author: Maria L.

description:
Made a last minute reservation on Opentable on the way home from After Dark at the Exploratorium last Thursday at 8:45.  It was packed so we had to wait a few extra minutes for a table.  I've heard about Serpentine's burger and told burger enthusiastic bf so we knew we had to get it. 

We both ordered the Serpentine burger and added bacon ($15 total), cooked medium w/no pickles.  I love how they use Acme bread for the bun, but the bun is bigger than the burger patty.  My burger was cooked a little more on the medium well to almost well done side however.  It was hot and juicy but started getting dry after eating half of it.  I enjoyed the pickled onions and arugula as well.  There was a little too much arugula though.  The fries served with the burger were perfectly crispy.  The bacon was so crispy and salty as well; they didn't skimp on it.  

Service was fine and straightforward.  I honestly expected Serpentine to be bigger, but it is a little on the small side.  I think if there was a little more meat to cover more of the bun and if the temperature of the beef was perfect, bf and I would both agree that they should be a getting a 4 for the burger.
author: Cat C.

description:
Today was my second time here for weekend brunch. I was happy to find out that they take reservations the day of. We had a group of 8 for noon.

The food took a bit to arrive but within reason as they were quite busy. I ordered the salmon benedict and subbed the crispy potatoes for French fries. More than half our group ordered the fried egg sandwich with avocado and bacon. They all enjoyed it. The portions here are quite large. Come hungry!

Great brunch location with friendly service. I wish they had more options on the menu.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I have been here twice. Both times I have not had to wait. I got the country fried steak the first time and huevos rancheros the second time. I thought both dishes was just ok. However, that's how I feel about a lot of brunch places in the Bay Area. We came here with a large group after trying to get a table at aina. Good service and ok food.
author: Shu T.

description:
I was finally able to try this place for Saturday brunch and I was not disappointed. Located in the dog patch it definitely had the hipster vibe. The inside of the restaurant looked liked a warehouse with nice lamps hanging from the ceiling - I personally appreciated it, I don't know about my friends.

I was able to try a little bit of everything. We ordered the pancakes, the burger, baked eggs and the egg sandwich. I liked everything except for the baked eggs..not really a big fan of whatever was in it. As for drinks we got mimosas and a Bloody Mary which were both on point.

I highly highly recommend the pancakes. One order was 5 dollars and it was enough to fill a small sized woman.

Would come back!
author: Andy H.

description: Went there unexpectedly Monday night around 7:30pm.  Got right in without a reservation but they had a pretty good crowd.  We had the Chicken & Short ribs with mac & cheese and brussel sprouts.  Everything was delicious and the service was very good.  Everything including 2 cocktails was $100 before tip.  Well worth it.
author: Chris F.

description: The waiter was really nice. It was a busy Friday night and it seems like he was the only waiter. Very efficient waiter! I suggest that you listen to him because he knows when you're ordering too much. Thankfully we listened to him! His service was 5 stars!
author: Susan H.

description: I used to love Serpentine, but after eating brunch there today I'll never return. Service was painfully slow even though the restaurant wasn't full. Food took forever to arrive. Water had junk floating in it and the glass had a lipstick stain. Food tastes good but my girlfriend threw up and I had very unpleasant bathroom experiences shortly after eating there. In sum, I am sad to say that Serpentine has lost its original attention to quality and detail.
author: Tom V.

description: Wonderful time and dinner.  The menu is small and everything we chose was amazing.  (Hence...the reason I prefer a small menu).  However, the downside to a small menu was I am not a red meat eater and only one fish and one chicken main entree. I didn't want chicken and scallops didn't jump out at me.  So, the two of us just opt'ed for a bunch of appetizers, soup, salad and of course martinis.  We even had a couple desserts. We shared everything.  The Brussels sprouts were one of the best I have had and yelp reviews steered me right with the hush puppies.  Soup was a meal in itself.  Salad was delicious, portions were generous and everything fresh.  Desserts were amazing...red velvet lava cake and our other was salted Carmel something.  I wanted to lick my plate.  (I recommend not passing on desserts).  I was glad we went the route of NOT ordering entrees bc we were able to try more things. One noticeable and annoying thing was I felt too rushed when asking questions about the menu and placing our order.  I never take long as I respect the server's time, so this should actually be a star deduction but I will let it go this time.  We were never rushed through our meal...it was only when the main server came by.  It is a trendy beautiful restaurant. Unfortunately, we sat pretty close to the front door and it tended to be very cold each time the doors opened and closed.  It was a cold night. I put my jacket on and off through dinner.  For this reason and...If given the choice I would have preferred a different section of the restaurant. It is a popular place therefore I also suggest making reservations.  Parking wasn't too difficult, we found a spot after driving around twice.  I look forward to a return visit next time in SF and I highly recommend.  I am sure most would enjoy this place.
author: Sherri S.

description:
Came here on a Sunday morning for brunch a few weeks ago before heading over to the Filmore Jazz Festival. Parking's usually not too bad in the area on a Sunday, there's lots of street parking nearby. 

They had plenty of empty tables but still had us wait to be seated. The food made up for it however - I got the Red Flannel Hash as suggested and a grapefruit mimosa - which they make with sparkling wine and it's SOO good. Also, surprising combination for the hash, but the beef brisket in the hash goes so well with the beets and poached egg. 

My friend got the Fried Egg Sandwich and loved it - however I feel like it was missing something and would go well with prosciutto or some other kind of cured meat. 

Overall it fits your typical hipster-y brunch place and you can always count on Dogpatch to deliver interesting new takes on old favorites
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Wow! Serpentine was an amazing find in the Dogpatch area. I first came across them after trying out Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous across the street, and decided to stop by for brunch the next time I was in the area. I was really happy I made a reservation, as the place was nicely packed soon after they opened. Portion sizes are quite hefty given a lot of the SF brunch spots I've dined at (although also reflected by the price). Well worth it, in my opinion!

I ordered the Red Flannel Hash, while my girlfriend got the buckwheat pancakes (x2, although she soon learned it was a lot). The beef brisket was really delicious, and amusingly dyed by the roasted beets. Lots of greens and potato, creating a very hearty dish for a jam packed day of exploring the city! The buckwheat pancakes were humongous, and having two was definitely enough for more than one person. Nice and fluffy and not too dense.

I'd love to come back for more!
author: Kevin J.

description:
Even though there are over 1000 reviews for Serpentine, I'm always surprised to find how many San Franciscan's haven't dined here yet. "It's just too far" or "I keep meaning to, just never make it that way." 

Well, let me tell you, the Dogpatch is getting better and better each day, so just make the time and mosey on down to 3rd Street. 

I've dined at Serpentine for lunch and dinner, both meals are exceptional. IMHO one of the most solid restaurants in the city. You can't go wrong with the food or the drinks... It the words of Goldilocks, "It's just right".

Of all the menu items I've tried over the years, the burger is tops. Yes, I went all the way to the Dogpatch to find a gourmet burger. Yes, there are a lot of really great burgers in the city. Yes, I realize this makes me sound very simple for choosing the burger. I don't care, it's good!

Pair that baby with a glass of red wine and you've got a happy camper on a cold, winter's eve. P.S., the wine list is also pretty damn great.

If you want to bump it up a notch, bring a date here, sit in a candlelit corner and order the full court press: cocktails, cheese plate, Brussels sprouts, roasted chicken, osso buco and get a full bottle of vino. Your +1 will be putty in your hands!

Or just do what I do and bring a gal pal, sit at the bar and order the burger with fries. Either way, it's gonna be a memorable meal.
author: Abby S.

description: We've been coming here for years. They recently remodeled and we love it!  The place retains the rustic charm, and the food rarely disappoints. Great vibe, great food, and great service.
author: David F.

description:
Everything on the brunch menu sounded really tasty so it was hard deciding what to order. We arrived here during peak brunch hour but managed to snag the last table before the rush came in. We sat at a booth tucked away in the corner of the restaurant next to the bar so it was more of a private space. It was nice not having to yell at each other across the table. The restaurant has a very modern feel to it and has a lot of natural lighting coming in, very ideal for brunch indoors!

I decided on the red flannel hash which was a good mix of beef brisket, roasted beets, and crispy potatoes. I usually steer away from beets but haven't really tried it enough times to really form a clear opinion on it so ordering this was kind of a gamble for me. I was pleasantly surprised by how tasty it was! The beets were perfectly roasted and tasted sweet and buttery. The potatoes were perfectly done, crispy on the outside but still soft on the inside. The brisket was also very tender and this was a great dish overall. A little overwhelming on the beets and I got too full to finish all of them. 

They also have an interesting list of cocktails and I saw a few that I wanted to try. I decided to pass on the cocktail to save room for dessert. Will definitely try one next time!
author: Maryann S.

description:
This place is small and in a little random location. The area is called dog patch and it's the crossroads of a bad neighborhood and the good neighborhood. 

I came here for brunch on a Sunday. The place is packed. Good thing we had reservations. I ordered the fried egg sandwich with a ruby mimosa. 
It was delicious. The side potatoes were crispy and the egg was perfectly fried. The ruby mimosa was refreshing and different from your regular OJ mimosa. 

I gave this place 4 stars because all in all the food and experience was bomb. The hostess needs to take more initiative, she was nowhere to be found for the first 5 minutes I was there.
author: Jenna T.

description:
My partner and I have been here twice and the food is exceptional. Every dish is well balanced and enjoyable to the last bite. Make sure to get the donuts which taste like a little piece of heaven. 

What impressed us even more than the food... if that's possible, is the level of service. Every one works as a team to ensure that no guest is left ill attended. Serena, one of the managers even came to our table with a treat when she recognized our food was taking too long. We did not mention this, she just knew.

I am certain we will be back time and time again.
author: Brian K.

description:
Serpentine made me realize how many awesome brunch places there are in the Dogpatch area... now I want to try them all! Like most brunch places on a Sunday morning, I would HIGHLY recommend that you make a reservation. Waiting could be around 30 minutes to 1 hour without one. Serpentine is a tiny and cozy brunch place with lots of cool items on their menu.

I started off with their Bloody Mary ($11) which tasted unlike any other Bloody Mary I've ever had. Their house mix is amazing! For my main dish, I followed Yelp recommendations and ordered their Red Flannel Hash ($14.50) with beef brisket, crispy potatoes, roasted beets, arugula, horseradish créme fraiche, poached eggs, rosemary salt, and grilled levain. The beef and potatoes were pretty good, but the dish got a little messy with the beet juices pooling at the bottom of my plate. Overall solid food and good service. The most memorable part was the Bloody Mary (not the food) but I would come back here again to bring a friend who wants to experience Serpentine.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I've always passed by this place on my way to mr and mrs, magnolia or third rail and assumed it was  just another basic-bitch-brunch-spot. 

Stopped by for dinner last night and discovered one of the best burgers I've had in SF so far! 

Get the burger medium rare and add some point reyes bleu. I didn't bother with the bacon and it was still phenomenal. The accompanying fries were similar to what you get at Chez, crisp and garnished with housemade aoli plus ketchup. I also ordered the duck duck chicken as a starter, which was a trio of liver mousse, foie pate with marmalade and salty duck prosciutto with a soft hazelnut-rye bread? (not sure yet it was to die for)  

Great fore date night and I 'd consider braving the sunday morning wait after this experience!
author: Katie O.

description:
Eh, I'm not impressed. My friend and I went for brunch and I definitely expected better in terms of food and service.

The hostess was pretty slow to seat people. There were plenty of open tables but she had to check like 3 times to seat each party. The space is pretty cramped. At one point, the table set for 4 next to us was seated for 5 people. That made the space really cramped for us and I didn't think it was very fair. Water filling wasn't very prompt. And no dessert for brunch, really? Disappointing.

In terms of food, I was excited about a bunch of items on the brunch menu. I got the country fried steak and my friend got the egg sandwich with sausage. Overall, I have to say the flavors were bland and everything was overly heavy. Basically I walked away from the meal feeling blah about the experience.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Came here for brunch with a party of 8. We made reservations so we had a table waiting.  6 out of 8 were there but they wouldn't seat us yet. So we stood around...saw a friend at the "bar" and slightly crowded around there....(I think we were in their way so they eventually just sat us). 

The waitress seemed very attentive...but more annoyed and in a rush...anyhoo

I had a moner's shrine drink....grapefruit juice...elderflower...gin...quite yummy.
I shared the eggs..pork sausage...potatoes and toast with a friend. average food.
tried a little of the pancake...yummy

overall it was okay, great spot to catch up with friends if you made a reservation. food wasn't too wow for me. parking wasn't too bad for friends and you can get ice cream afterwards across the street.
author: Christine M.

description: Great ambiance, a little loud, but the food and service are on point.   The beer selection is great with food that is cohesive.   We went for restaurant week but i went with the pork chop per our servers suggestion.   Not a bad choice!  Everything has kale and brussels in it.  If you like, great, if not -- don't get em!  My 1 suggestion would be a different choice of pasta for the mac and cheese.  Salad mac doesn't cut it.
author: Ray W.

description:
This reservation is for brunch, which was just ok.  The pros are: reservations are easy to get, open table!!  And it's in my neighboorhood.  The cons are: nothing spectacular and the extra sausage that I added to my egg sandwich was dry dry dry and $4 extra.

Overall the experience was ok, the ambiance was very cold and for a brunch crowd, it was very quiet.  Service was good and I've heard good things about the dinner, so I might have to come back and give that a try.
author: Janel C.

description:
Serpentine is great when you want Saturday morning without all the hype and fuss that usually accompanies brunch on a San Francisco weekend. My friends and I had a reservation for 11:30, which we were late for by about 10 minutes. Despite that, we were seated immediately.

The restaurant itself has a pretty chill atmosphere. It's relatively small, but doesn't feel cramped because of high ceilings and lots of natural light. There's also an extensive bar, if you guys want to get a little buzzed to start your day off right. Our server paid just the right amount of attention: she came by often enough to make sure the food was okay and that our waters were full, but didn't come by so often that she would interrupt conversation.

The food was pretty good; the part of my meal I enjoyed most was surprisingly the potatoes. Usually I'm kind of "meh" when it comes to potatoes, but these were delightfully crispy on the outside but soft potato-ey goodness inside. They were well seasoned as well. Portion sizes were fairly large, with no one in our party able to completely clean their plates. I got the crab cake benedict, which I did not really taste the crab cake for unfortunately.  However, I did enjoy the cornbread and the eggs were done perfectly.

Parking in this area is not too bad. If you go a block over from 3rd, you should find lots of (FREE) parking, quite the rarity in San Francisco these days. Another plus of Serpentine's location is it's proximity to Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous. Ice cream is another great way to start your weekend off right!
author: Denise C.

description:
If you're thinking about the Red Flannel Hash, pick something else!

My meal was unfortunately underwhelming. Did I not choose the right thing on the menu? The Red Flannel Hash sounded so divine, "beef brisket - crispy potatoes - roasted beets - arugula horseradish créme fraiche - poached eggs - grilled levain." Egg was poached swell, beef brisket was okayyyy because I got bored of the taste & texture after a few bites, arugula was a good touch with the creme fraiche, crispy potatoes were fine, beets tasted like it needed more ripening and grilled levain was nothing special. The meal was all together bland, I used the egg yolk and cholula to add more flavor to the dish. Got a bloody mary because why not, spicy with a good kick, flavor though seemed pickle juice based comparable to McClure's bloody mary mix which I ain't a fan of. Just another pricey breakfast establishment that I wouldn't care to try again. I understand the whole fresh farm to table concept, but I just expected a whole lot more.
author: Anna S.

description:
I've been meaning to write this review for about a year now, that's roughly the first time I went to Serpentine. 

If you're into that whole "SF amazing breakfast/brunch" - this is a great spot. 

Delicious food, went here several times and this place does not disappoint. Parking isn't too bad either. Lots of street parking.
author: Irina R.

description:
We had some delicious food at Serpentine before a show.  The vibe is super friendly and the decor is fun.
The calamari and chicken livers were outstanding! Then we had the chicken and a pasta with crab both of which were delicious.  Oh and the side of brussel sprouts was cooked perfectly.  Also check out the cocktail choices. The Manhattan and Monice's Shrine are tasty. I can't even express with words how yummy the dessert was...just think citrusy cake goodness. 
There are so many other things we need to try on this menu! If there was one complaint, it would be that the light over our table was out, so it was very dark which meant that we couldn't "eat with our eyes ".
author: Dawn R.

description:
Faced with an hour-plus wait at another local SF spot, we called over to Serpentine and found that they had not even opened yet! A short drive later, we managed to be 4th in line, guaranteeing us an opening table! On a Sunday morning in San Francisco, opening late is actually a plus. 

Once inside, we were greeted with a lovely ambiance followed quickly by solid bloody marys. The three of us split the polenta, the red flannel hash, and the buckwheat pancakes. All were excellent, although we got way too much food (maybe the short stack, next time?) and the red flannel hash was really the stand-out.
author: Ivana J.

description: Great place to eat breakfast food! If you come here on a Sunday, you might get lucky like I did and find free street parking right out front. I would suggest making a reservation if you want to eat here on the weekend. The line can be out the door first thing in the morning.
author: Katy C.

description:
Very nice place, good service, but a little bit disappointing..we share the huevos rancheros and the crab benedict for brunch, it was good but nothing to die for - and nothing that's worth waiting outside for a table! (a lot of people in the line, so definitely need to reserve, wich I'm happy I did) 
Coffee were a bit strong and big fresh orange juice delicious (4$)
author: Alice D.

description: Had reservations for 4 at 10, got seated shortly after. Waitress didn't come by for 15-20 minutes. Not a great start, didn't even get water or anything. Bf and I got the Apple strudel pancake, adovado toast, donuts (5). Donuts were good (4.5*)and worth going back for. Good sauces to pair with them, especially the Carmel. Avocado toast was fine (3*), good flavor and seasoning on the veggies. Crust on the bread to over toasted and too hard to eat. The pancake was terrible, tasted burnt and the crumble was so hard and crunchy. It was like biting rock candy. The Apple chunks were in the middle of the pancake and wasn't worth eating. Over food was spotty and service wasn't stellar. Latte was meh. Would only return for the donuts.
author: KoKo K.

description: Dungeness crab hush puppies, pan fried country livers with garlic chile sauce and pickled pearl onions - both delicious and unique preparations. Serpentine also makes a great burger. Love the local ingredients. Great wintertime spot that's both spacious in size yet cozy in atmosphere.
author: Sofia J.

description: Serpentine has a lot of great items on the menu, but I come for the burger, which is among the best in San Francisco.
author: Amir A.

description:
I've had brunch at Serpentine and was a big fan. I had the eggs benedict with crab and it was delicious. The crab was fresh.

I've done dinner here twice, first time I loved it, the second time was a let down. 

Both times I got a pasta dish. The first one had a nice light spot with crispy pancetta bits, and a poached egg. The second time I got mushroom raviolis and they just were not very good.

The burger is really tasty and the fries are great.

I've also had a steak dish before that was superb. Can't remember what the dish was exactly and the menu is constantly changing.
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
Ok. Serpentine was better the second time around. Brunch wasn't spectacular and actually forgettable. The menu was small and concentrated. But dinner!? 

Hats off to you Deepak Kaul! Dinner definitely showed your skill and range better than brunch. 

My group shared 2 starts and 2 entrees.

For starters:

pan seared Petaluma chicken livers - ooOoOo that fenugreek spice was delicious on chicken livers!!! not to mention the fact that the livers were cooked perfectly. great amount of moistness, not at all dry. 

Indian spiced pork ribs - these are small, especially for $11. our server told us they go by weight and an order usually comes with 3 or 4. we asked him to make sure it had 4 since there were 4 of us... Delicious sweet and savory ribs, the way they should be!

for our mains:

TAGLIATELLE WITH WILD MUSHROOMS
fava beans - bacon lardons - chili flakes - pecorino toscano - oregano - herbed breadcrumbs - soft poached    - I normally don't like lardons, but they were pretty good with the tagliatelle. We also added a poached egg. Pop that baby and let the sweet yolk run...

RAS EL HANOUT BRAISED PEKIN DUCK LEG
duck sausage - fresh corn polenta - carrots - turnips - cipollini onion - black mission figs - toasted almonds - micro licorice greens - good, but wasn't my favorite. although I have had terrible duck before...this was one of the better duck legs i've had. 

all in all, come for dinner and definitely have a reservation.
author: Susy C.

description:
Here's a tip: get a reservation. 1 hr waits to those that try to walk in. This is not the reason that the restaurant gets 4 instead of 5 stars, though. That was my bad for not being more prepared. 
My friends and I tried an assortment of items on their brunch menu to get an overall impression of the fare here. The pancakes were incredibly delicious with a host of complementary fruits on top and an airy texture. Next, the fried egg sandwich was crispy, hearty and cheesy yet bright. It was accompanied by some of the tastiest homestyle potatoes I've had the pleasure of eating (crispy and soft but not soggy?! madness). The benedict and the hash were both good dishes, with excellent technical execution. However, I found both dishes to be somewhat lacking in flavor. I just think the hype overcame the reality here.
author: Ruobin W.

description: The roasted pork loin sandwich is ridiculously good. Go here. Get it. Your mouth will thank you.
author: Megan B.

description:
Came for brunch on Valentine's Day after giving up on the wait at Just For You. Checked out the menu and it seemed like similar food/price point and we were seated in 5 min.

I had the eggs+potatoes+bread with sausage and my friend had the huervos rancheros. Love that they serve levain bread. Eggs were perfectly cooked and potatoes were crispy (they are fried cubed potatoes). We also had one of the buckwheat pancakes which was by far the best thing on the table--pineapple, pecans, pomegranate seeds, and fresh cream. So good! 

Service was kind and gracious. Space is very airy and industrial (similar aesthetic to most DogPatch restaurants). Definitely worth stopping by if in the neighborhood. Make sure to save room for ice cream at Mr and Mrs Miscellaneous across the street!
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Continuing my quest for the best burger in the city, came for lunch with my foodie in crime.

Cool open airy industrial design, relaxed, low key hipster-ish kinda vibe; definitely fitting for the 'Patch. I could imagine their bar during happy hour being popular.   (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=O7e5AF363kOhEZZbKLP92A#O7e5AF363kOhEZZbKLP92A)

*PRATHER RANCH HAMBURGER - $12.5
When the waiter delivered the burger he warned that it was a juice bomb. He was right, the thing exploded with meat juice once cut in half. Made me wish I didn't have to split it so my mouth could experience that glorious beef bomb.  

The airy and soft bun easily gave way to the almost aged/gamey flavor of the beef. Very good. The burger reminded me a lot of Slow Club's, later found it's the same owners.

The light and crisp fries dusted with herbs were good too. Not as good as Chez Maman's but similar.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=kCrYtNtrXpmYsBRwO1B5SA#kCrYtNtrXpmYsBRwO1B5SA)(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=I04_Cu-Ns6BGlhhFNuYRQQ#I04_Cu-Ns6BGlhhFNuYRQQ)


*BEER & TOMATILLO BRAISED PORK SHOULDER SANDWICH | $12.5
Taste and texture of the pork reminded me of insanely tender lengua meat, just melts. The toothsome deli roll was too crusty making the insides squirt out like toothpaste once bitten into. I think it'd be cool if they made sliders with softer Hawaiian or pan de sal bread instead. Til then, stick with the burger.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=V86QiiInqskn0elvwBth5Q#V86QiiInqskn0elvwBth5Q)


I hear this resto is popular for brunch. It ain't the biggest place and being allergic to crowds, I think I'll stick to the more low key lunch crowds. But yes, I'd come back for more of that beef bomb burger. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=1BnKu79r7R8I-w8LyKCj4Q#1BnKu79r7R8I-w8LyKCj4Q)

If you like this, you might also like Marlowe, Citizen's Band, Slow Club.
author: Earl G.

description:
Great little brunch spot. Super crowded, but worth the wait (about 40m on a Saturday morning). 

The food was all delicious from buckwheat pancakes, huevos rancheros to their beef & beet hash. 

Would go again.
author: Andy P.

description:
Though this hole-in-the-wall off 3rd Street was far from easy to get to, the trek through the city was well worth it for the atmosphere, the menu's offerings, and the service.

Having been my first time here (and, mind you, the kickoff to my winter break), I couldn't not start the meal --- and the morning --- with a cocktail.  I opted for a sparkly, refreshing mix, Monice's Shrine, which was the perfect fix for anyone gin-and-grapefruit-lovin'.  I had a sip of the Whiskey Smash, but drinking an entire glass of this might have been regrettable. Cocktails? Yes.

It's hard to tell if Serpentine is known exclusively for their brunch, but the menu was, without a doubt, lusher than many breakfast spots I'd been too recently.  Lucky for me, going out with a couple of food-loving roommates, I was able to get a taste of three different dishes, starting with my own: Frittata, Fried Egg Sandwich, and Red Flannel Hash.  

The Frittata was super clean, filled with friend turnips, carrots, and fontina cheese --- the flour-less dish would have been a great option for anyone Gluten-Free.  This in it of itself is also my one complaint; like, where is the crispy, doughy crust of the egg dish?! 

The Fried Egg Sandwich, which I only tried a bite of, is what one would expect from the classic breakfast sandwich, but it almost seemed overly bready, which, don't get me wrong, isn't always a bad thing.  

Thirdly, and absolutely the most unique dish on our table, was the Red Flannel Hash.  Made up of beef brisket, horseradish creme fraiche, poached eggs, and beets, the Hash was a colorful array of dynamic flavors, something I would recommend to the more daring diner.  Disclaimer: enjoying beets is a must for this one.  Dare I say there might have even been too many?

I needn't forget to mention the starter we enjoyed as we waited for the entrees: biscuits and gravy.  This was, hands down, the dish that made the meal.  While I'm a fan of the classic buttermilk biscuit and decadent gravy recipe, this twist of the classic had a crispy-on-the-outside-fluffy-on-the-inside corn bread, and a meaty gravy that tasted homemade.  It honestly could have been a little bigger, but keep in mind, this was split between 3 hungry people.

If you haven't yet made the trek to Dogpatch for Serpentine's brunch, there should be nothing stopping you.  It's worth the commute, and if you end up having to wait a few minutes (we didn't have to), don't fret, just hit up the bar and enjoy the big picture windows and cool crowd of late 20-somethings.
author: Rachel H.

description:
This is a brunch only review.

+Ambiance.  Industrial and modern with an open concept.  Lovely.
+Takes reservations.  Love when brunch places do that so you're not waiting forever!
+Good variety of food.  From polenta to your traditional breakfast, it has something for everyone.

-Food was just okay in my opinion.  Not bad but not anything special.
-Service is slow since it's busy.  I think there was a lot of people waiting outside also (make a reservation!)
-Be careful where you park here.  Since it's near an industrial looking area and "up and coming", cars are broken into quite often in broad daylight.  This happened to us!  You can see broken glass everywhere on the floor so take note.

Overall, this place is OK.
author: Mui K.

description: Amazing food and service! Can't wait to go back again!! Loved the Memphis Bell cocktail, and the scallops and dumplings were delicious! Get the pot de creme for dessert!  Seriously. Get it!
author: Kim H.

description:
Fantastic, vibrant and welcoming brunch spot. We were a party of 4 adults plus 2 children, they had no issues about sitting us on a nice table in front of the bar, I made a reservation on the phone 20 minutes before though.

The service is excellent and everyone seems to be committed to excellence in this place.

Food:

Definitely the fried egg sandwich with sausage is the highlight, along with the steak and eggs. They may sound boring or typical, but they definitely taste really good. The yoghurt with granola is nice as well as the pancakes. I would use a more elaborate vocabulary to describe all the items mentioned above but food is food and this place really nails it as a brunch option.

If you're in the mood for drinks: don't miss the espresso whisky - delicious and strong Af.

I will come back.
author: Javier F.

description: Really great spot for brunch! Highly recommend the pork belly hash and grits! Great ambiance, friendly staff and service (especially bartender Kelly)!
author: Ashley S.

description:
The food here is fantastic, and cocktails go for a decent $11 rate, so it's not exactly pricey, but portions for meals don't match the price. They don't skimp on alcohol here, so if you're having dinner at the bar, you're going to get a good drink and great quality food. Just be prepared to spend a bit (entrees range from ~$20 - $30, so if you're having some sides and a drink, it'll be at least $45/person before tax and tip).

Came here for dinner on a Saturday night, and the wait for a table for 6 was only about 45 minutes, which was fine, but I think it was shorter than usual because everyone was gone for Thanksgiving weekend. Service was prompt, and the fries (not twice-fried), brussel sprouts (very crispy), and cheese board was solid. The lamb cheek appetizer was particularly good. You don't get any of the gamey taste because of how well it's cooked, and it comes with a grain side (couscous?). Potato gnocchi entree was fantastic. The oxtail was simmered slow to the point where it was tender, and the gnocchi wasn't over or undercooked. The pork chop, though, was ridiculous. Excellent herb and peppercorn crust. Cooked so it's not even close to tough, but just right to the point where you can tell it just crossed from pink to white on the inside. Ambiance is low-key, but not so much that you couldn't dress up to get here. The only thing I wish would change would be a price change. I think the bartender had that in mind though, because the bartender took off a cocktail from my tab. Extra star for that.
author: Danny C.

description: I have been to this place several times in the past. After a 3 year hiatus, I decided to revisit last night and was disappointed.  The food was subpar and lacked taste.  The salmon was bland.  Overall, I was not happy with the experience and would not recommend anybody to others.
author: S J.

description: This place is great. My boyfriend and I sat at the bar without a reservation and ordered drinks then the potato dumplings (gnocchi) and chicken and waffles. There was a mix up with the chicken and we were brought the pork chop instead. We let them know that's not what we ordered and they were immediately apologetic and cleared up the confusion. The bartender, who had been so nice made us special drinks on the house and we also received the red velvet molten lava chocolate cake on the house! This was all a completely normal and understandable mistake but they went above and beyond to make sure we walked away happy with the service and food. Awesome place and awesome servers and bartender!
author: Lea H.

description:
Just visited serpentine after their remodel/reboot, and was super impressed. They left the spirit of the place intact, which I was relieved to see, but it feels a lot more crisp and modern -- more natural light, some really beautiful fixtures and details. The food was pretty outstanding. I've been going there for a long time, and while the menu doesn't feel like a radical departure, you can tell that there's just a lot of care being put into the food now.  It's like very comforting, easy-to-love food being done by folks who really understand fine dining and care about the ingredients -- refined without being fussy. Honestly it ranks with some of the best meals I've had in SF.
I also had a couple of really good cocktails -- i'm not always a cocktail person, but these were really thoughtful and interesting but super easy to drink.  Excited to see that the tradition of this dogpatch classic was honored with the renovation, but it simultaneously feels like a pretty exciting new addition to the city's food scene.
author: Matthew S.

description:
The service was slow. Really slow. They were nice and sat us before our full party was there (I had a reservation), even though there were others on the wait for brunch. But once we weren't ready the first time our server asked us about ordering, it was extremely hard to flag her or anyone down for anything. She always seemed really brusque and in a hurry - I always felt guilty for taking up her time somehow. Also we asked for bread at the beginning and it didn't come until way after our food did..

Speaking of the food, that was actually pretty good.

* Fried egg sandwich - 3.5 stars
pic: waiting on a friend!
(leadbetter's english muffin - fried egg - arugula - dill aioli - crispy potatoes. $10, add $3.50 for house pork sausage, add $1.50 for gruyere)
We really could not taste the dill aioli - even asked a server (after not being able to locate our own server for a long time) who insisted the aioli was in the sandwich - we actually took it apart and looked and could not find any. Maybe a small dab on top of the bottom bun. But not significant by any means. Not bad, not outstanding, a good sandwich though.

* Red flannel hash - 4.5 stars
pic: waiting on a friend!
(beef brisket - crispy potatoes - roasted beets - horseradish creme fraiche - poached eggs & grilled levain. $12)
Absolutely fantastic. The beef itself was incredibly soft, well flavored, and there was tons of it. Add runny egg yolk to anything and I'm happy beyond belief. The beets added a light sweetness, and the potatoes were good but could have used a thicker crisp.

* Baked eggs - 4 stars
pic: waiting on a friend!
(two eggs = spiced garbanzo beans - broccoli di rabe - hen of the woods mushrooms - tomatillo green salsa w/ toasted levain. $10.50)
Nice combo of flavors! Tried a bite of my friend's and enjoyed it.

Total bill was about $25 a person (one of us got a drink).

Next time, I'd like try the savory bread pudding.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
So happy I finally got to come here. I was so lucky to be able to have met my friends from LA here. Thank god I got there at 10am on a Sunday, because right after I was seated it got packed. 

I got the Wheat pancakes w/ fresh berries and whip and it was so freaking good I also ordered a side of eggs and it was made just right. I also had a cappuccino which was pretty decent. That's only because I am an caffeine addict and like them a specific way.  

The service was good for how busy it was. I would definitely want to come back and try all the amazing things on the menu.
author: Faith C.

description:
"Would you like to start off with an order of fries for the table?"

Wow - I haven't heard that one before at a restaurant. Normally, the server asks if you want water or an adult beverage. But I gotta admit, we were all impressed by the brazen inquiry. And naturally, our party of 5 said "Hell YEAH!"

Unfortunately, the crispy French Fries were the best part of my Serpentine experience.
Located in SF's Dog patch, this is definitely one of those off-the-beaten dining destinations. Though based on all the positive Yelp reviews, it was a trek worth taking.

However, after we received our order of fries for the table, things quickly dissolved. My co-workers and I were there for a lunch meeting. And the folks we were meeting with happened to be liquor reps (who work nearby AND have spirits on the cocktail menu). We all decided to throw caution to the wind (and embrace our "Mad Men" egos) and order a cocktail for lunch. This was all fine and dandy, except for the fact that it took over 20 minutes for our 5 beverages to arrive. And to be honest, these weren't complicated libations. In fact, none of the drinks we ordered had more than 3 ingredients. I kept looking around the half-empty restaurant and wondering what happened to our server and bartender. Were they on a cigarette break?

Finally, twenty minutes later, we received our beverages. I had ordered a Negroni, which is one of my favorites cocktails. This is a drink that is equal parts gin, campari, and sweet vermouth. You really need to measure your ingredients with this drink. And these guys clearly didn't. It was super bitter and almost undrinkable. And for $11, that's a pricey snafu.

For lunch, our table ordered the burger, a few salads with chicken and/or steak, the short rib hash with poached eggs, and I had the chicken tikka masala sandwich on focaccia bread. I think my cohorts all ordered better than me. They all seemed pleased (though no one was really gushing about anything in particular). The salads really looked quite tasty and filling (note to self: order that next time). My Indian-inspired sandwich (which sounded great on paper) was underwhelming to say the least. The thick chicken breast was a bit undercooked. It really had no spice or heat. The cabbage and cucumbers it came with really didn't add anything distinguishable to the mix. The side salad on the plate was completely under-dressed. If this was a run-of-the-mill neighborhood deli, I wouldn't have minded. But Serpentine is a casual-chic restaurant with over 4 stars on Yelp. 

At the end of the day, this place is fine. I'd be willing to give it another shot. But my biggest gripe was the service. There barely was any. It took us a long time to order our food and drinks. And then it took forever for the drinks/food to arrive. And even when it did, the server put the wrong drinks and the wrong dishes in front of the wrong people. Not once did the server come by during the meal to ask how we were doing or if we needed anything else - except to deliver the bill.

There was no love here today. What we had was was "hipster" food served by hipster people who clearly couldn't give a damn whether we were having a good experience or not. Given how off-the-beaten-path Serpentine is, I'm not exactly sure if I'll be making a trek back here soon.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Arrived at noon with 2 friends and was seated immediately! Ordered primps cup, which was sweet and not too strong. Friend ordered the whiskey coffee, which packed a powerful punch. We ordered the:

Polenta hash (check menu for name)- The polenta mash was very flavorful, creamy and I enjoyed this dish the best.
Huevos Rancheros- Eggs were cooked perfectly with delicious salsa.
Crab benedict- Had a bite but it was yummy. My friend said he got tired of this dish after a few bites.

Modern decor, clean and service was fast. The dinner items looked more appetizing than brunch. Would love to try the dinner items.
author: Rosanna T.

description:
I love this place, it's our go-to brunch/lunch spot even though we live on the Peninsula.  The service isn't always perfect (although usually good), but the food is consistently excellent, and it's reasonably priced.  The pancakes and huevos rancheros are both standouts - so good.  The only letdown here is the coffee - it's pretty bad, but Piccino is just around the corner and has excellent coffee, so we usually grab one there before or after.

I've heard the lines are bad, but we've never booked - we usually get there as close to 10am as possible and have never had to wait.
author: Miles C.

description:
Love this place. 

I've been here twice now for dinner, and each time has been awesome. I kind of classify Serpentine's cuisine/experience in the "new american/californian/sf" category, along with the likes of Bar Tartine, AQ, TBD, Outerlands, and NOPA. \

The space is in this cool warehouse-y/open plan building that looks magical at night. Location itself is in a cool part of SF if you know where to look afterwards. 

The ingredients and dishes are of course seasonal, but I recommend getting the pork ribs and calamari to start if they have it. I've had the rabbit when it was on the menu as a main, which was solid, and recently the vegetarian pasta dish: tagliatelle with mushrooms. The latter was a very generous portion. We also ordered the grilled corn as a side--a beautiful dish with the right amount of heat from the cayenne and brightness from the lime.

OH and my favorite part of the whole menu is their most amazing LEMON BUTTERMILK cake. one of my favorite deserts in SF!!!!

Have to try this place for brunch soon!
author: Sam R.

description:
The Dungeness Crab Benedict here and Homemade Granola were fantastic.  

I'm not normally a fan of brunch Benedicts on account of the bread portion being too hard to cut/chew through or the sauce hollandaise being too heavy.  But this Dungeness Crab Benedict was perfection.  It was savory with a hint of sweet from the delicious and fresh tasting Dungeness crab.  The buttermilk biscuit was light almost like a cake and was perfectly delicate to match the elegance of the crab. The dish was simply delicious and overall fairly light, amazing for a Benedict!

The Homemade Granola was a great addition as well. Not too sweet, not too crunchy--just right! Refreshing and light and delicious all on its own.
author: Victoria W.

description: What a wonderfully remodeled place.  This place use to be a factory and the owner did a great job making it welcoming with a lot of natural lighting.  Great place to go for a healthy light lunch or a relaxing dinner.  We went for lunch and loved how everything tasted clean and healthy.  No fancy or heavy sauces but you do leave full and satisfied.  We got to talk to the owner a bit and she's very friendly and nice.  The menu does rotate seasonally so you know everything is top quality!
author: Esther S.

description:
Meh. Its consistently uncomfortably hot in this place. Despite having huge windows up top that could ventilate, the heat collects and causes a sauna effect.

Anyway, I find the bartenders to be pretty moody and passive aggressive. Not just one. Does management treat them like crap? Understaffed? Who knows. One actually berated my girlfriend for touching a bar towel to HELP WIPE her spot at the bar. Wtf? Another gave a dirty look when we were trying to get a drink while seated at the bar. ?? Should this happen when we are paying over $100 for a damn lunch? 

Food is fine but too much salt. Stay away if you have sodium limitations. Menu never changes much and it gets boring. There's more to life than Prather, Neuske, and Mary's. Nobody cares. Switch it up.
author: Richard L.

description: Service is great, parking is easy but the food is just ok.  The scallops were ok.  The chickpea calamari was ok.  The burger was ok.  The pumpkin cheesecake is ok.
author: Chris L.

description: Best crispy pork belly, ever!! Terrific brunch and great service. Will be back to try other dishes including dinner.
author: Nancy R.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Saturday and the wait to be seated probably took 5 minutes. The tables are fairly close to each other and you can somewhat hear your neighbor's conversation. Music was playing, but can't really hear it since everyone was talking all at once, so yes, the place gets really loud. The ambiance is nice with high ceiling- kind of reminded me of a warehouse/loft. The menus are on a clipboard and they seem to be printed daily on what they are offering only for that time being. They have a full bar with minimal seats if you decide to eat there instead of the tables. 

I ordered the Prather Ranch Burger (medium well) and it came with crispy fries, however they seasoned it with too much salt. The burger was delicious. Everything on it was fresh- arugula, sliced tomatoes, pickles, and their own pickled red onions. My boyfriend ordered the Cured Salmon Benedict and he devoured it within minutes (I'm assuming it was that good).

The service is OK. Our waitress didn't check up on us at all and not once did she smile. The only time she interacted with us was when she took our order. She came by once to fill our cups with water, served our food, and came out with our check. *shrugs*
author: Katelyn F.

description:
TLDR:
- This 5-star review is only for brunch, which is better than the dinner (3 stars for measly uninspiring food).
- Recommend: red flannel hash. Highlights: large cubes of tender beef, excellently fried potato cubes, sweet beets, perfectly poached eggs.
- Big points for consistency and generous portions.
- Service improves as you get closer to the bar.
- Easy wait. Bar is first come first serve. If a wait, relax at Neighbor Bakehouse down the street.
- Easy parking.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Confession: I used to be afraid of chicories. Serpentine changed my mind. They are not bitter, they are actually bright and super palatable and make a great foundation for a salad! If you see them on the menu here, you should order them!

The same goes for the following:
Chickpea Battered Calamari
House Made Potato Gnocchi with Oxtail
Lemon Buttermilk Cake

Serpentine strikes me as a neighborhood favorite and though lots of people rave about the place for brunch, I can also add my vote for dinner.
author: Miriam W.

description:
This review is for the brunch only. I'll be returning to try out the dinner menu soon. 

I love the industrial and completely open loft vibe to the restaurant - totally matches the vibe of the developing Dogpatch neighborhood. I also love the friendly service and the classic menu. 

The highlights are the Country Fried Steak & Eggs, Fried Egg Sandwich with Pork Sausage and the Crispy Chicken Sandwich. When it comes to fried food, I like to think of myself as an expert and man oh man was I impressed with the consistency in quality across all three of these entrees. Crispy, juicy, tender and flavorful. Mmm. And the bloody mary and mimosas are very well made as well.  

The best part, however, is that you're allowed to make brunch resos on OpenTable beforehand! So you can easily avoid a disgusting wait time by making a reso a few days in advance! 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
As painful as long waits usually are, it's actually a piece of cake here when there's ice cream and alcohol literally within a 1 block radius.

As best as I can describe it, the interior of Serpentine is modern with restraint...minimalist yet still inviting.  The menu encompasses quite a range of dishes including huevos rancheros, smoked salmon eggs benedict and buckwheat pancakes.

Those aforementioned pancakes?  Get them.  Crazy delicious and topped with an awesome combination of cool whipped cream, pineapple and pomegranite whose temperature, juice and acid balance out the pancake's contrasting qualities exquisitely well.  Not far off in second place, the fried egg sandwich and its layer of gooey gruyere and dill aioli was piping hot and damn good...even sans pork sausage/bacon.  My friends' red flannel hash and house smoked salmon benedict were both great as well and quite fresh, just not nearly as standout in terms of flavors.

Regarding service, we were unanimously pleasantly surprised at how quickly all the dishes came out.  Made us wonder a bit how it took 1.5 hours to get seated...

Overall, a thoroughly tasty brunch spot in the city and worth coming back to for a repeat experience or to try their lunch and dinner.
author: Eric F.

description:
If I were a swordfish, I'd hope for a long and fruitful life, swishing my saber-like proboscis while swimming in whatever temperature waters swordfish swim in, ultimately, being snared by a sole angler from his family heirloom boat. He'll then bring me to a small market, where the chef of Serpentine procures my intact corpse, takes me home, cuddles with me a bit, and ends the night with a swift and skillful filet job. If I'm lucky, I'll be served on a Tuesday.

Because, I'd know, in my heart of fishy hearts, my fleshy parts would make you smile.

And while preferably not next, if I were to reincarnate with scales so shiny, I hope to see you some Tuesday.

Try the swordfish.
author: Damien S.

description:
Serpentine is emblematic of what I've come to expect from a good San Francisco restaurant.

The cocktails are first-rate.
The atmosphere is stylish yet warm and inviting.
The staff is friendly, considerate, and doesn't mind if you discuss poop.*
The menu is New American; short, well-executed and conscious of where they source ingredients.

I wouldn't refer to anything we ate as transcendant, but there were very few weak points across the board. I personally enjoyed my main of hanger steak, but the gnocchi, brussels sprouts, affogato, ice cream sandwich (house-cured) meat board, swordfish, chicken and more were all enthusiastically eaten around the table.

Head over, and have a good time.
_____________

*Perhaps this isn't as much of an SF-specific characteristic as the others, but the fact remains that the staff was fine with the fact that we discussed nothing but poop for at least 35% of the evening.
author: Peter D.

description:
Came here for restaurant week and did the pre-fixe menu that consisted of a a squash panna cotta, beet salad, mushroom gnocchi and banana pudding. Also did the wine pairing. Everything was delicious and the wine pairing was spot-on. 

Only complaints would be I wish the portions had been just a little bit larger. The price point was $40 and I felt they could have added a tad more to each course. Service was good overall but I received my wine pairings from different servers and not everyone said what the wine was.

Overall, happy with my visit and will be back.
author: Jay S.

description:
I came here for brunch on a Saturday morning. It wasn't too crowded, we originally had a table of 5 but later changed to 7, which caused our wait to extend from 30 mins to 1.5 hrs. We understood changing the amount of people would increase the wait time but who knew it would have tripled. Towards the end of our wait, parties that just arrived were seated immediately, which didn't make sense to me since we were still waiting for our table. I peeked in the window several times and saw about two opportunities where we could have been seated. 

Despite the unreasonable wait, we continued to wait for our table because this place was highly rated. I ordered the red flannel hash, which is the ONLY reason why this place gets a 3 otherwise it would be more of a 2. The brisket was real tender, soft, and teared apart like butter. The eggs were perfected poached. And I love beets which is why I got this dish. The only downside is that it came out room temperature, not even warm. It would definitely have tasted better if the brisket and eggs were hot. The salmon Benedict didn't have much flavor to it and it also came out room temperature. The presentation was real nice. Both the hash and eggs Benedict came with potatoes which were EXCELLENT. I loved their potatoes, that was the only thing that was warm on the plates. Nice and crispy exterior with soft fluffy potato goodness in the center. I tried a bite of their buckwheat pancakes which by itself I would pass on but their creme fresh was amazing. It was fluffy, light and not too sweet. It also definitely moistened the pancakes making them easier to take down. My friend liked her granola and my other friend said to pass on the country fried steak. His country fried steak wasn't warm either. Not sure if our food was sitting out for a while before it was served. 

Service was mediocre. Staff wasn't extremely happy but they weren't rude. It also took some time until a server came to help us. We chatted at our table for about 30 mins until we had our orders taken. At least waters came out quickly. It felt like the food took forever to come out. I didn't actually notice the time cause by then we were all starving and what seemed like forever might not have actually been that long. 

All in all, we waited 2 hours to get our food which tasted mediocre. Not hot or even warm. Room temperature to almost the point of cold. Will definitely NOT wait 2 hours for this place but I wouldn't mind coming back for those potatoes and red flannel hash.
author: Stephanie L.

description: This place always delivers. Whatever sounds good on the menu WILL be delicious. Cocktails are fantastic and food is excellent with solid portions.
author: Aaron A.

description: If you live in SF or are visiting and you are looking for amazing food, go check out Serpentine. The interior is cool and industrial, the staff was friendly and genuinely seemed like they wanted to talk to me, not just take my order and get on with their day. I ordered the polenta and eggs with pork and it was absolutely to die for. The portion was great, actually a little too much for me, and it was very decently priced ($13 I believe). My bloodymary was delicious as well- had the perfect kick to it; they offer endless bloody marys for the lush like me :) I will definitely being going back again.
author: Kim V.

description:
Had a great group meal here, the highlight being a few new nicknames for a few people in our group. Considering those names are Rosa Poops and Big Meat, you know we were throwing back some drinks. My poison of choice was the whiskey smash (eagle rare 10yr bourbon, muddled lemon, mint) which managed to have quite the kick, but also really great flavors from the lime and mint.  

We started with a few apps, which were delicious. I know they were delicious bc some of them never made their way to my end of the table. Anywho, the Serpentine meat board was excellent, my fave being the duck prosciutto and toscano, and the fried brussels sprouts were solid as well.  

For my main course I rocked the house made potato gnocchi with oxtail (broccoli di ciccio, grana padano, oregano, crème fraîche, breadcrumbs, shallots, braising jus) which was outstanding. Yes, I know oxtail is best eaten directly off the bone, but the meat managed to be flavorful and tender. I was supposed to 'share' some with the person next to me, but I allowed them to tell me a story while I ate the entire bowl. So, yea, it was good. 

Dessert menu looked cool, but by that time I was whiskey smashed up and needed to bounce. Next time (there will def be a next time) for sure!
author: Drew A.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE. The modern, casual, clean aesthetic makes the dining experience pleasant. The food was hearty but not heavy and the diverse menu left my mouth watering and made it very hard to chose. I ended up picking the steak and eggs which were delicious. Needless to say, at the end of the meal my plate was clean :). I would recommend this place for sure!
author: Emma J.

description:
Every weekend we wake up and say "Serpentine for buckwheat pancakes?"  Yeah we ate that last weekend but whatever, its the damn best pancake in SF. Or anywhere. Period. Hah. Its also the largest, one is enough for two people and two is enough for a small country.

The salads, benedicts, bacon, hash - all solid. Service is solid. The place is deceptively small, so get there before it opens for the first seating or you'll find yourself waiting and waiting. However if you are not lazy and have forsight, you can actually make advanced reservations for brunch. RESERVATIONS FOR BRUNCH! Revolutionary. *Mind blown*
author: Snuffles B.

description:
Located right next to Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous. (Okay maybe across the street) Came here a couple of Fridays ago to enjoy a dinner.

I got the chicken while babe got the fish. The interior is quite trendy and hipster like. I also ordered the monice's shrine drink. My chicken was pretty dry but babe's fish was not bad, tender and flaky. Monice's shrine had a very floral taste to it and was pretty refreshing, however it was a bit strong.

Our waitress was extremely friendly.

Probably won't come back for the food though.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
One of the few places that were open on the first Monday of the new year. Came by near 12pm for a table of 2.
