This place really wasn't what I was expecting, primarily because I was sort of expecting brunch options and not lunch options. So I'm thinking that maybe they only have a brunch menu on weekends? 

The first thing they asked us when we walked in was whether or not we had a reservation. So, I would highly advise that you guys make a reservation, they seemed like they had a lot of tables reserved and people who walked-in without reservations were seated at the bar. Not really an issue, but something to take into consideration. 

My friend ordered the dungeness crab penne and cheese and I got the chorizo spiced veggie burger. I tried some of the penne and cheese and it was delicious, a bit heavy for a meal by myself but that's probably why it's a smaller serving size. I enjoyed my veggie burger, the spices and the mushrooms worked well together. I got fries for my side and it was a little on the salty side. 

Overall it was a decent experience and the food was alright too. It's a little on the pricey side but I figured it would be after walking in. It looks like a place you would have a business lunch at.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
Pretty solid food! I made a reservation for my birthday dinner, as I typically force my friends to consume food with me. Its like a win-win for me. Celebrate and get to try the dishes on my friends plates! So for big groups (I had 8) they only seat at specific times...which is fine, but for 2 weeks advanced notice, I kinda wish I could have still had a 7PM sitting. *sigh.

Appetizers:
Scallops - Seared well, with a good sauce to it. YUM.
Meat platter - really good assortment of foods. I love pate, and they had such delicious pate. I just wish there were a few more pieces of toasted bread for us...
Fries - can't go wrong. Shoe string fries!

Mains - 
Steak - They asked if mid-rare was fine, which everyone said yes...but it kinda came out medium rather than mid-rare. =/
Swordfish - was really good and JUICY! Like seriously. Yum!
Chicken - If you go there HUNGRY, this is seriously what you should get. omg...it was half a darn bird!! Seriously. HALF. A BIRD. But it was pretty good. The skin was crispy, and meat quite flavorful. The breast meat was a LITTLE too cooked, but when you roast a bird like that, it's hard to get dark meat cooked AND breast moist. 

Our waiter was awesome, and started us out with drinks. He was super attentive all night, but wasn't annoying! He even asked if we wanted gratuity added to the bill - which I've never had asked to us before. I mean, restaurants either automatically add or let you choose...but not ask you of your choice. Wow. 

Overall, its a solid place to go for food.
author: Lily W.

description:
The polenta and eggs was CRAZY good. The polenta reminded me of grits a lot--same texture, saturated with cheese, the base of a small plateau of pulled pork, and three eggs over easy.

I would say that I couldn't get enough, but it honestly was so rich and so filling that I had a lot of trouble eating it all. Granted, I was also eating some of my friend's buckwheat pancake (never has a pancake felt so healthy yet delicious).
author: Rosy H.

description:
This review is for my 3rd (?) visit to Serpentine.

(Backstory: We originally were going to go to Plow. Showed up a little before 10, and there was a 2 hour wait. Holy cow! Forget that!

We then went to Just For You Café... Because beignets. There was a half hour wait. Okay, doable...)

But then I remembered that Serpentine was right across the way, and they opened at 10 -- so there'd be no wait! 

Awesome! I love when stuff like that works out!

We were one of the first tables to be seated. Ordered black coffees and bloodies. I think the Bloody Mary could have been a little spicier, and I typically like mine with lots of garnishes. There were two little olives and a cucumber slice. But it was decent.

Then all of us ordered the same dish - the hash - and it was awesome! Totally delicious and filling. Came out promptly, and warm.

Service was good. We lingered a bit at the table afterward because we were with someone visiting from DC, and one of the servers kicked us off for a reservation, but with 3/4 of us having worked in the service industry in the past we understood and didn't take it personally.

(Side note, the server had awesome animal tattoos! There was a duck? An octopus? Maybe a lion?)

Overall, solid, and of course, will come again!
author: Shawna A.

description:
ambiance//*****
chiq vibe with seating split between casual bar or formal eating
good for groups of 2-6

service//*****
excellent service~ my waitress was very kind and helpful whether it was to recommend a cocktail or a dessert

although there was a line out the door, i was never rushed to finish

food//*****
i enjoyed everything i tried, whether it was the gnocchi, coffee martini, or dessert
plus it always brings me joy when dishes are beautifully plated

oy! no dessert menu available online so i can't remember what i ate
just that it was delectable and perfectly paired with my cocktail
~*~
pleasant meal at an affordable price point

thx steph C. for the rec!^^
author: Donna S.

description:
Dinner here was OK but did not live up to expectations.  We were "greeted" at the door by an unsmiling woman who asked for our reservation name and then wandered off.  We were greeted a second time by a friendly young woman who seated us promptly.  After that, things looked up.  Appetizers were excellent (heirloom tomato and cuke salad, summer squash fritters with romesco).  

Pacing was a big problem, however.  We felt like we were having a race with the chef.  The moment one dish was removed, another appeared.  We sat down a little after 7:30 and by 8:05 had been served cocktails, two rounds of appetizers and two very large entrees.  Portions are large and the overly swift pace of service left me with no desire to face the large plate of chicken when it arrived just as our fritters were removed.  I ended up taking it all home.

The room is nice but a bit dark, which meant people at neighboring tables were using their cell phone flashlights to view their menus, which was extremely distracting.  A large, loud party across the room created waves of ear-splitting laughter that reverberated all over the space.

The unfriendly woman we saw at the door made several more appearances during the evening, bringing us food with a scowl on her face and not responding to our "thank-yous" or request for serving spoons.  Don't know who she is, but she apparently doesn't want us to come back....and so we won't.
author: Laura W.

description: We stopped in on a busy Saturday night before another party and found the mixed drinks to be quite good. I had a "whiskey smash" which was a concoction of whisky, lemon and mint that tasted quite good.  We also tried a few appetizers. I liked the squash blossom fritters -those were interesting.  On a side note, I would say that the service was decent too. The bartenders weren't super friendly but they did serve up some excellent drinks. I would return here.
author: David Z.

description:
I read about this place on a top 10 burger list in SF.  Finally had the chance to venture out here to try it.

HANDS DOWN BEST BURGER in SF.  

The bf ordered the Prather Branch Hamburger w/ cheese and bacon-  This photo ready burger tasted as good as it looked.  With each bite, blood drips like an animal still fighting for it's life as it slowly fades into darkness.  I'm sure it lived a good life cuz man, that was some good meat.

I ordered the Fried Egg and House Pork Sausage Sandwich-  I took a bite and died.   Great combination of ingredients.  

My boyfriend and I usually try each others dishes.  After swapping plates and taking one bite, I watched him take several more bites from MY sandwich.  He looks at me and says, "You can take another bite if you want"  Oh HECK no!  I hope he's not thinking about finishing it.  Eventually, we switched back and I was left with a decent amount.  Ladies remember, you control the meat.  If you want it, take it.  If you don't, leave it.

I can't disregard the fries!  The fries are amazeballs.  Thin, crispy, not too salty.  Love it.

Love the decor too.  Very industrial with a hint of modern.
author: Linda N.

description:
Pros:
- red flannel hash (juicy, tender beef, crispy potatoes, gooey eggs... yummm)
- quick and attentive service
- wide, open, well-lit space

Cons:
- seemed like they were trying to rush us out during crowded brunch hours
- the food was tasty, but now it seems forgettable

Bottom line: great dining experience; reminds me why I love San Francisco. I'm not dying to return, but the hash is worth trying.
author: Jiann M.

description:
Was expecting some amazing food from this place but I am afraid it wasn't there for me. The wait for a table can be expected in SF but once they seat you and take your order it shouldn't take about her half hour. Especially when people who sat after you are getting their meals. So the food came... I got the red flannel hash and biscuits and gravy. They seemed to forget the horse radish creme fresh as well as my gf's aioli... Had to request a side of those but it didn't really helpy pretty bland meal. Really just uninspired and probably the worst gravy ever. Nice fluffy biscuits and disgusting bland sauce with no meet in it.
On a lighter note my gf enjoyed her fried egg sandwich and Bloody Mary . The sausage on the sandwich was tasty but I can't find myself giving more then two stars for a tasty sausage. The rest was blah...
author: Derek C.

description: Went for brunch, food was delicious! The huevos rancheros had great texture with fried corn tortillas, and the mild heat in the sauce was well balanced by the avocado.
author: Andrew S.

description: Outstanding! very focused menu. Quality over quantity! Great coffee as well. Service was excellent.
author: Heather H.

description:
Wow, WOW!!! Serpentine has replaced Plow as my favorite brunch place in the city. We got here early, right around 10:15, so didn't have to wait. I got the crab eggs benedict and my boyfriend the buckwheat pancakes.

The eggs benedict was, by far, the best that I've ever had. I've been to Mama's in North Beach (it's know for their benedicts) and this place just blows it out of water. 

Here's the run down -- the sauce was rich and creamy, not too sour; the eggs were perfectly poached, with a super runny center; the sauteed spinach added depth to the dish (and a bit of veggie to make you feel better); the real crab is subtle but gives it an umami kick; and the kicker, the homemade flakey/buttery biscuit instead of English muffins. There's also a fried lemon slice and capers on top. The spinach/shaved fennel salad cuts the richness of the benedict and the fried potatoes is a great vessel of dipping into any left over hollandaise/egg yolk runoff. The dish is so perfect, it'll be tough to order anything else when I come here for brunch in the future.

I also tried my boyfriend's pancakes. Even though it's buckwheat, they were fluffy and the real syrup and whipped cream give it some extra moisture. I adore the earthy flavor of the buckwheat and the candied walnuts are the cherry atop the sundae. 

All in all, with the easy parking, Serpentine will become one of my go-to brunch spots. I also look forward to dinner here, as I've hear friends that swear by every entree.
author: Alice W.

description: My boyfriend and I had a very enjoyable brunch at Serpentine this past weekend. First time there after seeing the line snake around the building on several occasions. The crab Benedict was quite delicious and very nicely presented. I also must recommend the whiskey express cocktail. Bourbon and espresso make magic together. Prices were more or less reasonable for a place like this. I'm sure we will go back again at some point.
author: Patrick F.

description: We went for brunch based solely by Open Table reviews and were pleasantly surprised! Interesting food well prepared with great service! The Bloody Mary had just the right amount of spice! Lots of fun drinks for brunch. Grits with chanterelles, truffles, poached eggs and crispy kale was perfectly prepared. My husband had the pork hash and said it was the best hash he'd ever had! Up and coming Dogpatch neighborhood with an unassuming exterior. Cool industrial vibe inside.
author: M J.

description:
UPDATE:
Okay I wish I could give more than 5 stars. We got take out for my 
father-in-law's birthday because he doesn't get around great and honestly the service we received was nothing less than stellar. We worked closely with Serena (a literal gem of a human) and everything was ready & cooked to perfection, she asked if we had birthday candles (I didn't) so threw a whole box in and emailed me a few days after to make sure everything was perfect. Such a wonderful experience. 
 
Delicious! My fella and I came here for dinner with reservations. We got there a bit early and were directed to the bar to enjoy a cocktail until the kitchen opened. I had a Whiskey Smash and it was so delicious I got a 2nd! 

For dinner I had the Mary's Chicken - amazing! The au jus was so flavorful and was seasoned perfectly, the chicken was tender and roasted so well, and the bed of veggies were cooked to perfection. My fella got the hangar steak and it was delicious - the bordelaise sauce was good - tasted much like a standard au jus. 

The decor is urban/industrial, great atmosphere for a dinner party or date night. Overall really amazing - will absolutely return!
author: Sonia M.

description:
Yeah, yeah, they've got great cocktails (I got the Ransom Martinez: with gin, sweet vermouth, Luxardo, orange and angostura bitters--and it knocked me on my butt), beer from Kansas City (Boulevard!), and a burger that's as juicy as one can ever hope for (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/serpentine-san-francisco?select=kCrYtNtrXpmYsBRwO1B5SA#5G3NWtJb_XiHiLJwryZRPw).

But that lemon buttermilk "cake." Oh, that cake. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/serpentine-san-francisco?select=kCrYtNtrXpmYsBRwO1B5SA#8yamDYRuQSUpOd01-Zkn7w)

I use the term "cake" lightly as it was more of an airy pudding than a cake. But our server assured us they use flour. "What, like, angel flour?" I asked. OK, not my brightest moment, but honestly, my brain cells were on hold and trying to process the marvel of that "cake." It had a bit of whipped cream on top with a drizzle of huckleberry sauce around the plate. If you're a fan of lemon loaves, this is the desert for you. Our table INHALED that thing.

Christ, I'm still reeling.

The berry cobbler was great, too (no crumbly topping, though. More of a layer of crust, with berries and a scoop of BiRite vanilla ice cream), but it was no match for that "cake."

I had a bite of the hanger steak, which was great, as was the rabbit three ways (which we dubbed Bugs, Roger, and Thumper). Poor bunnies.

Oh, and the service was excellent; never a need for more water or scrambling to get the check. Very pleased, Serpentine.
author: Adena B.

description: We came here for valentines day brunch and the place did not have a line out the door as we suspected!  We started with drinks.  I had an arnold palmer.  We tried the red flannel hash and also the country fried steak and eggs.  I remember it being very heavy and not salty enough. Also we had to ask for butter three times before we got any.
author: claudia y.

description: Really great! We came here for lunch after climbing. We each got a salad--the Mixed Greens and the Apple with chicken. Both were delicious in different ways--the Apple was savory and filling, and the Mixed Greens was tangy and refreshing. The use of dill in the Mixed Greens worked really well. We'll have to come back sometime for dinner!
author: Alysha V.

description:
I came here on Saturday for brunch.

Neighborhood is sketchy but the inside of the restaurant proves otherwise.

Wait was long but there's no wait at the bar, so we sat the bar. 

Service can be lacking at times, but I was overly impressed with the red flannel hash. I think the combination of the flavors in the dish was perfect. I am not always the big fan of beets but I like the beets in this dish. It added a great flavor to the potatoes and eggs. I am a big fan of the potatoes, it was cooked to perfection. It was crispy and savory. Delicious. The arugula adds a hint of bitterness but it really adds to the dish.

I think next time I would want to try the cured salmon, yum! Come early to this place and enjoy yourself.
author: Margaret L.

description:
I came here for brunch a while ago and I still think about the burger sometimes. It's definitely deserving to be on the top burgers in SF list for sure.

I actually only took a bite of my bf's but IT WAS SO GOOD. I even forgot what I had ordered even after looking at the menu online. It paled in comparison to the burger by far. Juicy yummy savory goodness.

For some reason the savory bread pudding didn't appear to be on the menu when I went :/ but I def want to try that next time.
author: Emily C.

description:
I love the space and the menu! Ordered Red Flannel Hash: meat, beats, arugula, poached eggs, but the star on that plate was the potato!!

Coffee is good, but bright-tasting, if you like that kind. (I'm a Peet's kind of coffee lover)

Great service - they leave you alone! And free street parking.
Will be back for the polenta & eggs....
author: Teenie K.

description:
I've finally returned to Serpentine after a few years absence! My mother, sister and I came today (Sunday) at 11:15am and waited 30 minutes to be seated.

I had the Pimm's Cup cocktail ($9). It was fresh and tasted exactly how I hoped. 

The food came rather quickly! But...as my mother and sister were given their meals mine was MIA. Our server said it was accidentally placed at another table and they were making me a new plate. 

My fried egg sandwich was delicious but difficult to eat. If you don't want the yummy yolk all over your shirt I suggest using a knife and fork! I added the sausage for $3.50 and it was definitely worth it! 

The sandwich is served with their amazing home fries. They must be fried because their like pillows on the inside and perfectly crunchy on the outside. 

Hopefully it won't be four years until I return again!
author: Kate J.

description:
Outstanding frittata and buckwheat pancakes
Wait staff was slow, inattentive, and wrong in description of unworthy items

It's worth your time, if you call ahead but it's not special in any regard.
author: AxeMe A.

description: We had a fantastic brunch here today.  We both had the country-fried steak and eggs.  The steak was very good and covered in a nice crispy batter and the scrambled eggs were perfectly soft & fluffy.  The crispy potatoes were good, and I loved the heap of arugula on top because it made the meal feel a little less heavy.  The only thing I wasn't wild about was the biscuit, which was more like a bread, but it was by no means bad, just not amazing.  The service was great, the portion was big and all for a very reasonable price of $14.50.  I'll definitely be back for brunch and would love to try dinner too.  And I love that they take brunch reservations so we can actually eat here (I refuse to stand in line for 2 hours for brunch, which seems to be a requirement at most places in the city that don't take reservations).
author: A M.

description:
I didn't enjoy this place as much as I expected to, which was pretty disappointing. 

The interior of the restaurant looked sort of industrial, which I thought looked nice. The food, however, was unsatisfactory. I ordered the red flannel hash and was completely underwhelmed by the lack of flavor.  The beets just didn't taste good. My friend had the polenta, which I tried and thought was alright. 

It's a cute place, but not one I would come back to.
author: Sienna S.

description: I have heard really good things about this place. Unfortunately, I did not have a chance to try it. Came in for Sunday brunch. The host offered us two seats at the counter. I turned for a second to talk to my partner to see if he was okay sitting at the counter. In the meantime, two others walked in and the host immediately gave them the seats. Talk about poor service and way to make someone feel welcomed!
author: Joann T.

description:
We came in earlier,from out of town, to get some SF breakfast. It looked like a nice place for brunch. It took us 1 hr to get us seated even though there was only one couple in front of us on the chart. Granted we were with a 1year old child.
They finally sat us down at a table for two. Funny... while we were waiting, there were a couple 2 seat tables open. When they sat us down, they didn't have a high chair for our baby.
In the end we had to leave because we waited so long and our baby was starting to get restless. So We asked our server to box up our order.

Other than the personal inconvenience, the brunch was good! The restaurant is not the best place for babies or kids that require special seating.
author: Dr. Daniel K.

description:
Alas it was not to be. I had always hesitated on going to Serpentine because of mixed reviews, but after a friend suggested going there, I decided to give it a shot, mostly because of its close proximity to Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous hehe. 

I should definitely call attention to the friendly service - the waitress even voluntarily took $5 off our bill because our food was a little late in coming! Kudos to the team for noticing small details!

I had the red flannel hash that Yelpers raved about and my friend had the burger with gruyere cheese.

Unfortunately I found the hash to be really under-seasoned and lacking in texture. While it was an interesting combination of beets, brisket, potatoes and poached eggs, I didn't find anything to have much flavor, unfortunately. I added a pinch of salt which helped but definitely didn't love my dish.

My friend's burger was good, not great, but perfectly serviceable. I had heard great things about burgers but I think NOPA, 4505, Roam, and other gourmet places in the city make far better burgers.

It's a nice environment for brunch but I don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Kate M.

description:
Super busy place, I would recommend that you make an open table reservation before heading over. It will make your life 100% better, mostly on weekends for brunch. 

The things that were ordered:
The red flannel hash was amazing, the two poached eggs well placed on top of the delicious arugula and beets was almost just an amazing pairing. The eggs were poached to perfection with the yoke being runny, just the way I like it. I loved how the bread was toasted on the grill making the grill mark on the bread. The outside crunchy, with a chewy middle. To make it even more perfect, adding a runny poached egg on top. A match made in heaven. It seemed like a light brunch, but the crispy potatoes and the beef brisket made it a very filling meal. A def. must get at this restaurant. 

My friend got the sausage, scrambled eggs, and potatoes and he was very satisfied. He  loved the scrambled eggs, saying it was made with care and it reminded him of Gordon Ramsey and his video on how difficult it is to make a perfect scrambled egg is. He said they def. hit the bulls eye on this. He was very satisfied after this meal. So much so that we walked (or rolled) all the way back to SOMA. 

All in all, this place is an awesome brunch stop. The only con is that the service here needs work. We didn't get much attention at all by our waitress and I had to wave my arms really big in order to grab the waitress's attention, which is super annoying. Also, without a reservation the wait here can be ridiculous. However the price is good and the portions are very generous so I will be back for sure.
author: Catherina W.

description:
What a nightmare!  From the wine to the appetizers to the entrees... There were four of us, we ordered the salumi plate to share - there was 1 slice of each type of cured meat... ? I don't remember how much it cost but we specifically asked the server if that would be a good app to share.  The salad was fine. Unmemorable.  We ordered a bottle of wine, it was corked.  No big deal, but then a second bottle came corked!!  the server told us they store their wine in the sun so this happens a lot ?!? Not a great idea.  
The entrees were all less then mediocre - a chicken dish with grapes with seeds in them, chicken undercooked, flavor combo really not good.  Hamburger was ok. Nothing special.  Pasta dish was overcooked and just ok flavors.  Overall not good for the $300 we spent!!
author: john s.

description:
Ate brunch here on a Sunday morning. We had 4 and wanted to eat around 11am. They are typical of SF and are a smaller establishment. Due to this, and not having a reservation, we ended up waiting about 35 minutes. Nothing too bad. 

All four of us ordered different breakfast entree's and all of us loved them. Personally I had the baked eggs, but with egg whites instead of full eggs. It was a flavorful dish served in a hot pan with chickpeas, broccolini and mushrooms, topped with 2 eggs and green tomatillo salsa. All the flavors blended together quite well and as a lighter breakfast option, it didn't leave me feeling heavy for the rest of the day. 

We will definitely be going back!
author: Roz B.

description:
came here for brunch and it was awesome.. we never wake up in time for brunch and never go to the dogpatch unless for a show at pier 70

ordered (we shared family style between 3 of us):
-BUCKWHEAT PANCAKES: apple - banana - pomegranate - candied walnuts mead & mead's maple syrup - whipped cream.. 1 pancake was the size of the whole plate and was more than enough to split 3 ways.. my 2 other friends don't like pancakes but said this was the best pancake they've ever had.. 

-RED FLANNEL HASH:beef brisket - crispy potatoes - roasted beets - arugula horseradish créme fraiche - poached eggs - grilled levain.. good but not great.. i liked the potatoes, beets, and poached egg

-PRATHER RANCH HAMBURGER: arugula - pickled red onions - housemade pickles - acme roll - french fries.. good burger and even better skinny fries!

-COUNTRY FRIED STEAK & EGGS: flat iron steak - scrambled eggs - biscuit & gravy - crispy potatoes - arugula.. my friend's fav dish.. i was getting full by this point so i only had a couple bites before tapping out

what a great place.. the ambiance is pretty cool (really awesome playlist!) and love the big airy warehouse space 

be ready for big portions and food coma

i'd come back to try dinner
author: Raquel T.

description:
The cocktail menu has cool drinks I want to try with lively ingredients like smoked salt, elderflower, & fresh muddled mint to name a few...
It's a vibrant and fun ambiance inside and, perfect for a date (or a group of friends). 

Got the Snake River Farms Wagyu Steak:
The steak was moist and succulent. Cut into nice bite sizes pieces. 
The meat itself, had a lot of natural flavor and you could tell it was a cut from a local farm(Snake River Farms in Idaho is the sh**). 
The greens didn't do too much for me but, they did add a nice texture profile. At the end of the day, this is a steak I'd order time and time again and is not a dish you can just get anywhere else. 

The burger is also awesome..
I hear brunch is tasty and something that's on my bucket list. 
Hat goes off to Chef Deepak Kaul.

I'd recommend it and compare it to a place like NOPA where it's gourmet, new American fare, with the price tag and cool ambiance that goes along with it.
author: Naveed B.

description:
We've been coming to Serpentine for the last 7 years, we live around the corner, and it was always a solid option for a neighborhood meal. In the beginning we had great interactions with the staff, we even grew really friendly with a couple of the servers who would recognize us coming in.  It seems they've had a shakeup in staffing, or people just went their separate ways, but we've had a very different experience as of late.  A couple of recent examples:

We sat at the bar at kind an off time for a late lunch, and when the bartender asked us if we'd like anything, we asked if they were serving food at the bar right then, and he responded with a curt: "Well this is a restaurant.....", and he wasn't particularly friendly throughout the whole meal.

Today, I ordered a burger to go, and when I got home, realized the burger I ordered medium rare was very well done.  The bun was clean and dry, so it was pretty clearly overdone.  We called to tell them, and asked if I could bring it back to swap for a medium rare one.  I returned, and two people asked me in a snarky tone: "are you the burger guy?" when I walked in.  The guy that I spoke to basically blamed me for it being overcooked saying that when you get it to go, it continues to cook in the box, all without looking at the burger.  He then said they'd make another.  I waited for just over 25 minutes for a replacement, and there was no apology for me having to come back, or for how long it took to replace.  He wasn't very pleasant.  I actually had to ask, because it seemed like they forgot about me.

It makes me a bit sad, as we've been big fans of Serpentine, and brought many friends from out of the neighborhood here, but after the last few experiences we've had, I don't feel like I ever want to return.  They don't seems to understand what good service looks like anymore, and the quality of the food just doesn't make up for the way you're treated.
author: Cliff B.

description:
I've been in the city almost a year now and while I haven't made a ton of friends (y'all are cold as your weather), I have enjoyed exploring the city by myself. I recently decided I was gonna try some of San Francisco's best burgers. (based on various internet sources)

Serpentine's burger is amazeballs. The flavors of the meat, with the dressed arugala and super fresh tomatoes will make your day. Every flavor is literally spot on. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

It does get a little loud and crowded on a Sunday - like everything else in the city. It is in a converted warehouse and the design is industrial but warm and inviting.
author: Tara H.

description: Solid. Solid as a rock.  Good burger, good fries.  Nice pasta specials.  Good wine list.  HOT COOKIE WITH MILK (!!!) and a lemon cake that we ordered two off.  It's no Maverick, which has a similar menu but 1000x better, but since Maverick is closed for renovations after the fire, this will do as a good substitute.
author: Kamael S.

description:
I came here for brunch, anxious to try the famous savory bread pudding, but was sad to find out it wasn't on the menu anymore. I wanted this to be one of my staple brunch spots in SF, but unfortunately, the dishes I had weren't quite as great as I would have hoped for. 

About 20% of the tables are held for reservations, and the rest are walk-ins. I was surprised that at 1:30 pm on a Sunday, I had to wait for a table. The hostess wasn't particularly helpful - with empty tables around us, she told us there was no room and didn't offer the bar as a potential solution if we wanted to wait.

The food was pretty hearty (a bit on the heavy side) and the portions were large.

Fried Egg Sandwich ($10) + House Pork Sausage (+$3) - Usually, I don't complain when the portion size is large, but the phrase "less is more" should apply to this dish. There was just too much going on between the quantity of bread, the large fried egg and the sausage. It was almost too much to eat all together. I did like the touch of arugula, cheese, and fried green tomato. I did like the potatoes that came with the dish - they were crispy and had a good texture.

House Smoked Salmon Benedict ($15) - I had higher hopes for this, given that I love poached eggs and biscuits. This was supposed to be black cod instead of the smoked salmon, but they had run out. The hollandaise sauce was a little overpowering, or too much was put on, and the biscuit was the texture of cornbread instead of a real Southern, buttery, flaky biscuit.

I haven't completely written this place off, and may be back for dinner and drinks some time. I'lll be taking my brunching elsewhere.
author: Christina L.

description:
I can't believe it took me so long to try this place. 

I've heard so many good things about the place and was so glad  when one of my colleagues chose this place to have her going away lunch. 

It took us forever to find parking so make sure you give yourself plenty of time if you're driving around during the lunch hour.  We made reservations for a group of 9 and they seated us immediately.   Love the simple modern day deco in the restaurant. The service was amazing!  They were super friendly and kept our glasses filled with water and iced teas without us even asking. 

They had a simple menu and not many items to choose from so I chose the burger which was great!  My colleague was raving about the burger so I had to get it.  I also took a bite of my colleagues Hash and it was amazing!  Every.single.bite was so juicy - I immediately regretted that I didn't order the hash after trying hers. It's ok - next time I'll know to order the hash. 

Love this place and will definitely return with the family in tow next time.
author: Christine P.

description: My friends and I enjoyed our brunch here, although they messed up our reservation and we ended up having to wait for a table. The service was fast though and servers were friendly. I had the country fried steak and it was delicious! A little salty, but still good. The biscuit was super fluffy and light, but the salty gravy really weighed it down. I ended up scraping some of the gravy off, otherwise the biscuit just got soggy and mushy. The steak was really good too, but again a little less salt would have been better. I would go back if I were in the area to try their lunch or dinner menu.
author: Henna P.

description: I am rarely in the Dogpatch unless visiting La Fromagerie, or Poco Dolce.  However I recently discovered Serpentine, and had an A-OK lunch!  On this rather quick and efficient visit, I had a BLTA sandwich with smoked mozzarella, and enjoyed every bite.  Paired with some very average mixed greens, the meal was enjoyable, and I wouldn't hesitate to return if in the area.  That said, I wasn't blown away and I wouldn't drive across town to make this my destination for a meal.
author: Andy S.

description:
Perhaps, the best breakfast I've ever had. 

I'm a fan of beets and brisket so when I saw the red flannel hash, I had to get it.
The potatoes were delicious! I seriously am NOT a fan of bfast potatoes but these were like a mix of country potatoes and tater tots (I love tots).  The meat was so buttery and melt in your mouth, and the beets were (of course) delicious as can be. A little green arugula to make you not hate yourself was added up in the mix as well as 2 perfectly poached eggs and grilled levain bread. Best. Breakfast. EVER. 
My friend got the dungeness crab cake benedict and having a little taste of his- that was delicious as well. Still, dat red flannel hash doh... whenever I have friends coming into SF, I HAVE to take them there. 

Great coffee as well. The tiny pepper mill was also really FREAKING cute.  The salt dish is kind of gross though, unless they change the wood bowl AND the salt after every person. 

All in all, food is delish, the servers are just SOOOO nice, and the price was GOOD for how big the portions were. THIS is breakfast at it's best.
author: Meena N.

description:
We went here for dinner last night, no particular expectations, just looking for a place to go and where the wait wasn't too long. I guess we got in at the right moment because when we left there were people lining up out the door.

Everything was exceptionally delicious and really fresh tasting. It's not one of those places where they just deep-fry everything to get flavor. The chef really puts care into understanding the ingredients--all local and seasonal--and bringing out the best those flavors have in multiple ways.

The tomato and cucumber salad was one of the best I've ever had. Perfectly ripe heirlooms, just the right balance of tomato to cucumber so that it's not all acid or all bitter, a hint of shaved fennel and some herbs, and a vinaigrette that brought it all together.

The gnocchi were subtlety flavored and tender with a mix of roasted veggies and bacon cubes. There was a light caramelization on the veggies, like they had been briefly seared with a blow torch, and that gave the dish a hint of that marshmallows-in-a-campfire sweetness that was a pleasant surprise and somehow really complemented the flavor of the gnocchi.

We also had the hangar steak, which comes with a demi-glace reduction and chimichurri. Simply seasoned but perfectly seared medium rare, with a mix of veggies on the plate to complement the meat. Some pieces of steak would end up sitting in more of one sauce or the other, and going back and forth between them kept it from being too much the same.

Everything was really enjoyable. We will definitely be back.
author: Aaron G.

description:
There's a genuine surprise in Dogpatch, and it isn't on the bottom of my shoe. I know Serpentine has been around for three years, but because it's a converted warehouse with all its windows up high, I had no idea what it was about. There's also been at least one major turnover of chefs there, so that usually means a roll of the dice when you try a place, especially one that Michael Bauer dismissed as fussy in execution. I don't know what he had, but Jamie W. and I were pretty enthralled by the food we had there courtesy of chef Deepak Kaul. 

It's an understated, dimly lit place that's not too crowded nor too loud considering how high the ceiling is. We liked it because we were surrounding by couples who weren't in an amorous state but honestly getting into the food they ordered. While we enjoyed some fresh Acme wheat bread slathered in butter, we decided to share a $9.50 Chicories Salad, a really nice combination of crunch and sweet (see photo). It featured all sorts of chicory leaves with a nice nutty crunch dressed in a fresh citrus juice. Pistachios provided even more crunch, the cara cara and blood orange slices provided the sweet. Herbed goat cheese was crumbled throughout. Tasty freshness. 

Entrees were uniformly excellent. Mine was the $25.50 Grilled Storm Hill Ranch Hangar Steak, sliced and prepared succulently in a medium-rare state. I twas accompanied by a pile of goodies - roasted rainbow carrots, creamed nettles, sunchokes, crumbled feta cheese, and fried shallots - all in a shallow pool of sage jus (see photo). As great as that was, Jamie's order was the evening standout, the $19.50 plate of Housemade Potato Gnocchi. Gnocchi can be a hit-or-miss affair depending on where you order it. Here it was perfectly cooked to a pillow-like texture and accompanied by a variety of pungent but not overwhelming flavors. 

There were baby fava beans, hedgehog and black trumpet mushrooms, green garlic (my favorite), pecorino piccolo, oregano and bite-size shards of Nueske's applewood-smoked bacon - all of it topped with breadcrumbs put under a broiler (see photo). A really outstanding dish. We decided to share a dessert since we were impressed with everything so far. We went simple and ordered the $7.50 Dark Chocolate Bundt Cake, as old-fashioned as you would think but perfectly baked with a raspberry puree and sprinkled with chocolate malt crumbs. A big scoop of Bi-Rite Creamery's Chocolate Ice Cream was thrown on the side for good measure (see photo). 

Decadent but not overly sweet like the dense Pineapple Upside Cake at Wayfare Tavern. We were wondering why they didn't just get their ice cream across the street at the equally wonderful Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous ice cream parlor. Oh well, you can just get your ice cream yourself if your stomach allows. However, our experience at Serpentine was more than satisfying on its own. 

FOOD - 5 stars...an unexpected delight in Dogpatch 
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...suprisingly relaxing given that it is a cavernous space 
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...attentive, informed and very conscientious here 
TOTAL - 5 stars...as those great philosophers Earth, Wind & Fire said, "Gonna tell a story, morning glory, all about the Serpentine fire!"
author: Ed U.

description:
Brunch always tastes better when you don't have to wait in line for 1+ hours..

Walked in on a Saturday afternoon and it was surprisingly empty! Well maybe not that surprising, since it is located in Dogpatch, but still! It's so highly rated. The service was excellent, as was the food! My bf decided to do family style between us and ordered the little gem salad, red flannel hash, and buckwheat pancake. The little gem salad was really good, but I would ask for the dressing on the side next time because there was a little too much for us. The red flannel has was phenomenal; the poached egg was perfect and the beef was so tender! The bread, potatoes, and greens complimented it well. The buckwheat pancake was amazing too! Especially the cream; it was so light and delicious. That with fruit on top just made it one of the best pancakes I've ever tried. 

Also, Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous is right across the street for ice cream after! I will definitely be back here!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Atmosphere
The space, an old tin can factory's boiler room, is standard industrial-chic fare: a mishmash of wood and steel, bare bricks, concrete walls stripped of their paint, and metal bar stools designed with one purpose in mind: to remind you that factories were not comfortable places in which to sit.

Food
The lunch menu had a reasonable range of options: kale salad (arugula is soooo 2010), citrus salad (which citrus that is is anyone's guess as neither the menu nor the server had any idea), a burger, and a couple of other sandwiches.  The Huevos Rancheros and Eggs & Polenta - odd choices for lunch - must be popular hangovers from their brunch menu.  I considered, but bypassed the Bacon Melt (does one really need gruyere and fontina??) and opted for the Mojo Pork Sandwich whose menu description - or list of ingredients rather - is: "savoy cabbage slaw - calabrian chili - pickled red onion - mustard aioli - english muffin - greens/fries."  Let's start from the outside in, shall we? 

- The bun - errrr, I mean English muffin . . . I think: Two bottom halves of a brioche bun do not an English muffin make.  Nowhere to be found was the slightly sour taste or the deep nooks and crannies (yes we all remember the Thomas's commercials) that define the English muffin - whose American home at one point, ironically, was San Francisco.

- Mustard aioli: When the plate hit my industrial, brushed-metal table, I did a double-take and thought "I didn't think there was cheese on this sandwich." But then I quickly realized that this mass of oozing, yellowish, semi-liquid goo pouring out of my sandwich wasn't cheese but roughly a quart of the mustard aioli.  I'll be the first to admit: in certain circumstances - as a dipping sauce for fried potato-based fried products, for example - mo' aioli is mo' betta, but not so much as a blanket for every service of a sandwich. And certainly not when it's neither very mustard-y nor very aioli-y.  A piquant Dijon mustard would have complemented the pork just fine. 

- Savoy cabbage slaw - calabrian chili: In my experience, cabbage slaws contain at least two - and often many more - ingredients: 1) cabbage, 2) at least one other ingredient.  This was the first one-ingredient slaw I have ever had (i.e. just cabbage).  I didn't know what a calabrian chili was before I ate this sandwich and I still don't.

- Mojo pork: I am an unabashed lover of pork in all its forms from head to foot (literally . . . just the other day I had a lovely fried pig head and trotter sandwich at Belcampo in LA's Grand Central Market).   Additionally I am no stranger to the animal's adipose areas - pig fat can be transformed into magical stuff in the right hands.  I was looking forward to biting into slabs of mojo-marinated citrusy/garlicy pork shoulder.  Instead, hiding under the gushing "mustard aioli" was a glistening, quivering, translucent pile of unappetizing pig fat with scant pieces of actual shoulder muscle clinging on for dear life here and there.  At this point, after several unsuccessful attempts at peeling back layers of fat in search for some actual meat, I sent the sandwich back and asked the server to have the chef examine its contents for the purported ingredients.

Service
The bright spot to be sure. The sandwich's massive mound of goo must have made on impression on my attentive server as she graciously comped me the price of the sandwich.  Additionally, she customized one of the dessert items swapping out a chocolate chip cookie for one of their delicious pistachio biscotti.
author: Doug H.

description:
I loved the food here, but the service was so slow. My bf and I arrived at 8:45 for our 9:15 reservation, really early. We gave them the benefit of the doubt, just ordered cocktails to begin with. I ended up getting the Acadian, it had Absinthe in it, and I was interested. It was a pretty strong drink, I enjoyed it and felt a good buzz but my bf didn't like the taste. 

Anyway, 9:15 rolled around, no one seated us yet. 9:30 rolled around, and we noticed that everyone sitting down from when we arrived at 8:30 was still siting down!  It was puzzling that no one had left yet. My bf complained, and they gave us FREE champagne since the wait was ridiculous. They then seated us at the next leaving table.

We ended up ordering the Brussel Sprouts and Chicken Livers. Both were delicious - I'd definitely get the Brussel sprouts again. It had crispy shells but soft centers as well; the best of both worlds!  The Chicken liver was good but a little gamey. My boyfriend loved it.

For entree, we both got the burgers. We heard about the burgers before from a Zagat article (http://blog.zagat.com/2012/11/sf-burger-guide-best-patties-by.html) and were very eager to try it. The burger itself was delicious. It's an upscale burger with your choice in cheese (cheddar, gruyere or point reyes blue) for $13.50, and is also topped with Arugula (yum) and an Acme roll (super good quality, you can definitely tell).  Fries were good too...but what made them stand out was the Ketchup. I asked why it tasted so special, and they said it was Heinz - but ORGANIC!  Quite a wow. Whenever I buy ketchup, I will purchase the organic from now on!

But overall, service was still slow even when we sat down to get our food. We didn't get out until around 2 hours later! Even when we were eating so late at night. It was just stupid. I might come back....perhaps for lunch. Since it's right next to Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous, you might as well stop by at both places!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I wish I didn't have to give this place such a low rating because the food was actually quite good, but the service was too atrocious to be forgiven.

I'll start with the positive. 

Serpentine offers upscale-ish American brunch fare with sophisticated cocktails to round out the experience. My boyfriend got the eggs, toast and potatoes plate, while I got the country-fried steak and eggs. His dish was good but pretty standard--nothing that would distinguish it from the millions of carbon copies at other brunch places. My dish was more interesting and what I imagine a million wannabe-Southern restaurants wish they could create. The steak was battered perfectly (so crisp!) and smothered with the most amazing country gravy--thick, creamy and savory. The accompanying biscuit was HUGE and unbelievably moist and sweet, yet perfectly complemented by the same savory gravy in which it was smothered. The potatoes were seasoned, starchy perfection and the arugula was the perfect fresh "green" touch to balance out all the richness.

Now the bad--the service.

First, we were forced to wait almost 10 minutes for someone to seat us (despite having reservations) because there was no one at the host(ess)'s desk. Yet, there were plenty of staff members milling around with nothing to do but chit chat with each other. Whenever I tried to make eye contact with one of them long enough to gesture to them, they quickly looked away, as if afraid to do their job. WTF?

Second, when we were finally seated, we had the coldest, unfriendliest waitress. She seemed to hat everything about her job and never once checked in on us for the entirety of the meal.

Third, our food was brought out by someone who was not our server, yet was equally cold and rude. In fact, our server never actually did anything else for us after she took our order except hand us our bill.

Fourth, it's not fun having to try to flag down someone--preferably your waitress but at this point ANYONE will do--for close to 15 minutes just to get your bill, so you can pay and leave for pete's sake. We're busy people with a lot to do, and neither of us enjoy wasting our time because other people refuse to do their jobs.

The ONLY thing that made this experience remotely worthwhile was that Serpentine is across the street from Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous, which I finally got to introduce to my boyfriend who'd never been before. But that's really a positive reflection on Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous, not Serpentine.
author: Josephine L.

description:
The two $$ signs are definitely misleading if you're trying to come in for dinner. 

My cousins and I had just finished bouldering at Dogpatch Boulders and wanted a quick meal (which quickly turned into a longer dining experience). Following the reviews on yelp, we found Serpentine which was conveniently located down the same street. 

Dinner ranged from $21-31 that evening (their menu changes daily or so we were told). The chicken entree was cooked to perfection and the gnocchi was really soft and light on the tongue. Dessert was also heavenly. Nothing we ordered came out too heavy or overly sweet. Both servers were really patient with us. The ambience was definitely intimate which added to the character of the interior design. 

I am definitely looking forward to returning.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Went the first time on a date, service is top, so are drinks and food! I just love it but would avoid going with a group of friends
author: Serena P.

description:
I wish I could have written a review over here about their food but we never got any.  Instead we received the worst service ever.  

I wrote a long review here explaining the details but thought the best of it.  In short, we were there for an hour and half but:

- our drinks were horribly late although the bartender was right in front of us (we sat at the bar; also reminded him after 15 mins but still took another 15 mins to come through)
- four parties around us who came after us got served and left before us
- bartender forgot to put our food order in

After an hour and half without food and horrible service, we decided to just leave.  We asked the bartender to cancel the order and requested our cheque.  He pretty much didn't care but he did say sorry and that it was super busy.  But we couldn't buy that because EVERYONE else was served.  I don't know what his beef was but this was literally the worst experience I have ever had in any restaurant.  Super disappointed.
author: Jyotshna K.

description:
I came here for lunch. I really liked the lay out and space and the staff was attentive, but the menu was...a bit boring. My friend and I shared the burger and the fried chicken while another friend had the salad with grilled chicken. She really liked her salad, but the burger was a regular burger with skinny fries and the fried chicken was good, but not outstanding. It had a good crust and the meat was moist. The potato salad was better than the fries.
I don't know that I would go back even though I thought it was really clean and the staff was gracious. I wasn't excited about the lunch choices.
author: Susan B.

description: Good and friendly service. Kale salad was underwhelming. The dressing was bland and the chicken breast was dry. The teriyaki chicken sandwich was the table favorite, but even that was a bit bland. Would recommend the warm cookie for dessert. Paid with Cover and that made for a smooth, quick exit.
author: Caroline K.

description:
Really enjoyed my time here. I came here for brunch at 11 on a Saturday and immediately got two seats at the bar. The space is really cool- very industrial warehouse like, but has a lot of artistic and fun little touches. Definitely well designed. 

My food was great! I had the friend egg sandwich (arugula, gruyere egg, cheese, fried green tomato) and a grapefruit + gin cocktail (forget exactly the name.) The sandwich was incredibly oily but really really yummy and the cocktail was a little refreshing. Service was a little slow at the beginning- took more than five minutes of sitting to get water and menus, but after we got them, the bartender was incredibly nice and helpful. Will definitely come back!
author: Vinitha R.

description:
We went on a Saturday and expected a wait.  Was pleasantly surprised to show up a little after 11 to be seated at once!

The service was great.  And the food too.

I had the fried egg sandwich which came with home fries.  The sandwich itself was basically bread, egg and greens but you could add: house made sausage ($3.50), cheese or avocado for an upcharge.  I kind of wish more came standard on the dish.. but it was tasty none the less.

There were other tasty things on the menu I would definitely make the trip over there for.
author: Lily B.

description: Outstanding - food and service was just awesome. They accommodated our group of six (Emily, you were just wonderful to us) with ease. Great buildout, comfortable environment, easy to have a conversation, bright and airy. The group loved the Red Flannel Hash, Huevos Rancheros, Country Fried Steak and Eggs, and Fritatta. And if they have the Pineapple with Rosemary marmalade - take home a quart!
author: Robyn W.

description: Not bad! Great drinks and pretty yummy food. Went here for brunch last month on a Saturday and had a delicious espresso-like cocktail and a nice frittata.
author: D R.

description:
Meh!! I think this place is over hyped. The food was mediocre, and small portions. The service is horrible and the place is over price. 

I actually wanted to give this place a second chance to see if maybe they had an off day but no... I walked in on Sunday for brunch and waited to be seated. The host look right at me and ignore me while continuing doing nothing. After calling her over she was super rude and I decided to just walk out. Not coming back.
author: Chiara M.

description:
Came with a group for dinner to celebrate a friend's birthday. All 3 people who ordered the fish got major food poisoning. We didn't hang out before dinner or do anything after so I'm sure it was the fish.

On the upside, service was very friendly, atmosphere was nice, and the food was generally pretty good (but not amazing for the price). But nothing cancels out a whole day of puking my guts out.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I came to Serpentine for brunch with my sister and it was delightful. Service was friendly and quick. We were seated immediately for our 11:15 am reservation.

Since Serpentine's menu changes often these reviews might become outdated rather quickly, but the quality of their food was overall superb. The chicken in the garlic marinated chicken sandwich was juicy and plump and paired very well with the gruyere cheese. I think the chicken itself could have used more flavor but texture-wise the sandwich worked out well.

The baked eggs were good, but I wasn't in love. The dish was waterier than I would have liked - after I cleaned off my plate there was quite a bit of sauce and fat left over. I did enjoy the novel mixing of mini heirloom tomatoes, eggs, and oyster mushrooms. 

The crispy potatoes are like square versions of fries and fun to eat. 

Price-wise I think Serpentine is a good value. The portions are moderate and filling, and the prices aren't ridiculous ($10 to $15 price range for brunch).

All in all a fun and cute place to meet a friend or 2 for brunch but I would suggest making reservations, since San Franciscans love their brunch and it's no fun to walk in and have to wait.
author: Brandy A.

description: Serpintine service was very open to my request for tobasco. The  bottle was well kept with minimal crusting. While they only brought a small two-ounce (59 ml) bottle, my server was friendly and probably would have receptive if I requested more than the two ounce serving. But I didn't need that much tobacco.
author: Peter S.

description:
First off, Victor, has awesome customer service! He took time to share in detail how to make drinks and what was in them. Must go see him at the bar!

Great place to be to have a chill drink with some friends and has a great menu for food.
author: Corey F.

description:
Freakin delicious.

This place pops off, so me and my homegirl sat at the bar, which was an excellent choice. The bartender was friendly, cute, and attentive, made our Bloody's like right after we sat down, took our orders, and checked back with us a couple of times. Yes, this should be standard service anywhere you go, but let's be honest, it has become somewhat of a rarity.

Speaking of rare, my burger was off the charts great. Perfectly juicy and salty, I had cheddar on mine and I smothered it with their peppery mustard and some Tabasco sauce.  But no tomatoes? Hm... I got the fries and she got the salad for sides.

Ambiance was simple and rustic, exposed light bulbs, which are a personal favorite, and green and yellow orchids by the very large bunch.

Highly recommended to any lover of burgers and the Dogpatch.
author: Crystal C.

description: Great food ! Sat at the bar since the wait time was 30 mins for a table. Ordered fresh grapefruit juice, red flannel hash, buckwheat pancakes and crab Benedict. My favorite was red flannel hash. The meat melts in your mouth. Greatly paired with beets, egg and potatoes. Service was amazing
author: Shaz K.

description:
Reservations... for brunch... in SF? What?? Awesome! :) The restaurant isn't too big so be prepared to wait for a bit if you don't have a reservation. We had reservations at 11 on a Saturday and that was about when there started to be a wait time.

Their menu changes regularly but I tried the crab benedict, which came on a biscuit. The biscuit was a nice change from an english muffin, in my opinion. It was light and fluffy and fell apart in my mouth. The spinach in the benedict got a bit lost, but overall it was delicious!! We had a bit of fun trying to figure out what the fried thing on top of the benedict was (fried lemon! yum). The side of potatoes was also super crispy and delicious! I like when food doesn't make you feel gross and heavy, and the crab benedict was filling but still really light. 

If you get an egg sandwich, watch out for all the add ons! Be prepared for the price of your meal to go up quickly if you add anything extra that they suggest to you. Not everything is listed with a price on the menu but those add ons aren't free! Some of my friends were a bit surprised when our bill came and their sandwich was pricier than expected.
author: Sophie Y.

description: This is a great local place!  Food is good and service is great! Our second visit in two week and both visits were well worth it.  A happening place in Dogpatch
author: Richard B.

description:
Another brunch spot crossed off the list! Serpentine takes reservations, which is ALWAYS a plus when it comes to these crazy, popular brunch locales in SF. While street parking is fairly easy, the space is not super huge, so reservations are highly recommended. The bar area is also a nice alternative for walk-in dining.

I ordered the baked eggs, which was prepared with two eggs atop spiced garbanzo beans, broccoli di rabe, hen of the woods mushrooms, and topped with a tomatillo green salsa. Three small (and plentiful) pieces of toasted levain were presented alongside. 

Overall, the dish was healthy and light, and a great way to start your day. If you prefer a heavy breakfast, then I suggest choosing something else like the massive buckwheat pancakes, which I also tried. They were a bit drier that I would like, and didn't have a whole lot of flavor. I sampled the polenta and eggs in addition, which was an equally tasty egg dish! If you enjoy eggs, I definitely suggest either the baked eggs or the polenta & eggs.

P.S. Head across the street to Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous for some delish ice cream post-brunch!
author: Mansi A.

description:
Two stars for the nice service, the neighborhood, and the menu concepts

Minus three stars because several dishes were WAY too salty ...and the beer selection leaves much to be desired
author: Venice Beach Dad K.

description: I am a long-time Serpentine customer since I work in the area.  I have eaten at the revamped Serpentine twice and have left disappointed both times.  It may be a little unfair to compare it to the excellent restaurant that it used to be, but if you keep the name but entirely change the quality and approach to the food that is what is going to happen!  The burger and fries used to be amazing, and are just OK now.  The fries have the look and texture of frozen french fries.  On both occasions the iced tea has tasted off, almost coffee tasting.  I miss the ability to add protein to a variety of salads - now the menu is much more limited without the range of options it used to have.  The salmon was just mediocre and the food in general doesn't seem to be spiced in any particular way - bland and tentative comes to mind.  The servers seem very nice, and the space is still very lovely and I like the new windows brightening it up.  I'll probably give it another try in a few months to see if the kinks get worked out.  I hope the new restaurant ends up being a success but there are definitely improvements to be made.
author: Julie J.

description:
Came here for a late night dinner/snack and 2 of us ordered 2 starters and they are both excellent.
Grilled asparagus salad- soft boiled egg added creaminess to it, blended with fried pork belly just give this dish a sophisticated taste.
Chicken liver- i have never had chicken liver before and was surprised by the texture to be honest. You need to be adventurous to try it lol. The sauce is a bit spicy and the accompanying salad add lightness to this dish which is a nice touch.
Looking forward to coming back here for brunch and more!
author: Will C.

description:
Came in with some friends to have a nice hangover brunch. The hype and wait to get in shouldn't be so revered, but the food was good. I liked the cohesive looks of the lumberjack waiters and post-scene waitresses, but the EDM playlist sort of clashed and wasn't great for the environment. 

I'll be back.
author: Anders L.

description:
A place to go for lunch when I have craving for burger and fries.  I remembered my first time...the burger was perfect.  Middle rare and juicy.  I finished the burger, fries, & salad. I had to ask for extra napkins a few times.  I love the thin french fries. Dressing on the salad was perfect.  

 Came back a few more times and burgers have not been the same each time after that.   It was overcooked.  I didn't even finished my burger.  My coworker had a veggie burger and it was also overcook.  We asked if there is a new chef...ansqer was no.  they did offered to make us another one.  We had to go back to work so we said no.  They came back with the bill & didn't charge us for the burger.  That was nice when we didn't ask for it. 

Service was and is still great.  Just no consistency in the burger.
author: Savvy C.

description:
Super adorable restaurant in the Dogpatch neighborhood, definitely fits in perfectly to this up and coming area with its exposed brick and industrial type ceiling. Not a huge space but it makes for a more intimate setting.

We ordered:
*Pan seared scallops - perfect appetizer. All the fixings used to decorate the dish was yummy as well. 
*Hanger steak: was okay, kind of hard to mess up that kind of dish.
*My hot date ordered the cod and that was a great dish. I had a bite and was very impressed at the really good flavoring infused in it. I'd highly recommend this dish. 
*Dessert: I forgot the name of it but it was chocolate cake with ice cream on it - SO delicious. Mouth watering delicious. I could eat this over and over again. 


 They also have great cocktails!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
After attempting to go to plow at 10am, and realizing how horrible of a fail that was... we decided to stop by serpentine. 

I was surprised at how crowded they got in the morning - even at opening it would be smart to get a reservation. There was only 1 table left at 10 for 4 - we had to sit on a barstool table, not a regular table which might be a little uncomfy.  The place is a little tight, but has a cute earthy urban decor - very san francisco esque. 

I looked at the menu and nothing really struck me about it - the menu is pretty short and simple for brunch. You have a few staples to breakfast: pancakes, french toast, eggs, egg sandwich, hash, eggs benedict, nothing too extensive in terms of fancy omelets or anything extravagant. I do wish they would have had more selection. 

I ended up getting the hash on recommendation of the waitress and I was blown away at how much I loved it. I loved the pairings they they had. So it's basically chunks of very tenderly cooked pork, their house potatoes (crunchy), with beets topped with arugala, creme fraiche and then two poached eggs. Finally you get two pieces of toast. I would say this is very well paired and put together! Delicious!

I would definitely come back here to taste their other dishes. I'm intrigued by their pairings.
author: Christine B.

description:
This was my second time at Serpentine as I tried it for a small group get together and fell in love with the food the ambiance and space.
Nestled in the DogPatch district, I was immediately impressed by the easy access parking and intimate set up inside and hip music.  A bustling bar with creative cocktails such as "The Stalker" I sipped on additional cocktails  from my boyfriend who raved about his. 
No long wait and super chill, easy going fun servers.  I ordered the cheese plate which was a great way to wet my palette before my main course, "The Burger".  Off the hook juicy, enormous and well worth my full tummy.  I savored bites of my groups meals knowing that I would definitely be back to get my eat on with the rest of the menu.
author: Veronica C.

description:
Serpentine is a brunch gem in the up-and-coming Dogpatch. It features natural lighting paired with exposed brick and industrial details. It's also across from Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous, which serves up some of the best artisan ice-cream in San Francisco. I came with a friend for brunch on a beautiful Saturday on an OpenTable reservation. You can probably come without a reservation - there were a number of empty tables when we were there at 1:30PM.

- Red Flannel Hash ($12.50): Juicy beef chunks tossed with beets, topped with creme fraiche, potatoes, arugula, toasted bread, and two poached eggs - are you overwhelmed yet? Each bite was a balance of sweet-and-savory and refreshing-and-flavorful. It's more of a meaty salad than a hash. I really really enjoyed this, and for the first time in a while, I didn't regret resisting the eggs benedict.

They also have fresh squeezed orange and grapefruit juice for $2.50 (small)/$3.50 (large). Service was friendly - there was a misunderstanding with my friend's juice flavor, and they switched it out immediately with no fuss.

Serpentine is a solid brunch choice with creative menu options (not items you look at and realize you should have just made it at home). The prices were also quite reasonable for traditionally overpriced brunch and the amount of food you get. Yes, it is worth the trip to Dogpatch!
author: Jessica F.

description:
The last few times I've been here were last minute dinner reservations.  I'm happy they were able to accommodate us, or else I would never have...
-pigged out on their fried Brussels sprouts with roasted chestnuts
-inhaled their juicy burger with arugula, gruyere and bacon
-devoured their french fries
-and enjoyed their tasty Meat Board with duck proscciutto, piccante salami, and duck liver mousse.  

In washing all that down, their drink department did not disappoint....with their perfect rye Manhattan and the Firestone Velvet Merlin oatmeal stout.  

Unforgettable dinners, an inviting atmosphere, and friendly staff....I'll be returning for sure.  Brunch is calling out to me!
author: Bobby L.

description:
Went during restaurant week. My husband got the tasting menu, and I ordered a la carte. 

It was two months ago and that's all I remember about the meal. That and I did not like the desserts.
author: Dimple B.

description:
This was one of the weirder dining experiences I've had in a while.

The space is cool, and the neighborhood itself adds to that with the excitement of so much that is new and interesting popping up all over the place. The decor is unique and really made me appreciate how these old buildings are being transformed without losing their character.

The food is average. It's tasty enough, but not unlike anything I've had before. What really made things a little blah, though, was the service. Our waiter seemed to be in such a hurry. Everything he said came out of his mouth like he was in some sort of fast-talking contest, and his answers to everything were so curt - not rude - just kind of (sorry to say) hipster-disinterested. Halfway through our meal, we saw him eating in a booth with other staffers...and it's not like it was closing time. Was he that hungry?!

Dinner came to the table in, oh, maybe 5 minutes? The portions weren't very large, so we were done in another 10. And that was about that.

So...I guess it's good to know you can dine in a real restaurant in well under an hour? That's gotta be useful for someone, I'm sure.
author: Kiesha R.

description:
While I'm fortunate enough to live nearby, Serpentine is worth the 'trek' out to Dogpatch. Do so, and Serpentine will certainly slither it's way into your list of fave SF brunch spots!

Clean, quaint, and modern decor embellishes the interior of this urban brunch paradise. Quick service, hooks under the table for your coats and purses, and beautiful lighting prime you for an excellent dining experience!

Any item on the brunch menu is terrific so far. The country fried steak was tender, and the potatoes are fried to a crisp perfection. Also shared a buckwheat pancake--texturally it was a bit grainier than a 'traditional' pancake, but I thoroughly enjoyed it. Fresh cream and fruits adorn the pancake, along with a thick, rich, and delicious syrup!

The highlight for me has to be the Bloody Mary. Their mix is PERFECT and absolutely DELICIOUS, a must if you visit Serpentine (which you should!)
author: Emmeline A.

description:
Super tasty food!! Had the kale salad and added flank steak which was tasty and cooked to perfection. I suppose
My only complaint is a smaller menu but delicious food and would totally come
Back!!

Looks like a great place for happy hour and would DEF give that a try..
author: Brittany E.

description: Don't miss the weekend brunch. Sure, there can be a wait, but HOUSE SMOKED SALMON BENEDICT is all I have to say. And they take reservations. The "ho-so-good hollandaise sauce is not to be missed. The bartenders make a strong cocktail too. Can't wait to visit there again!
author: Gil M.

description:
Walking up to Serpentine, visions of a password through a peephole necessary to enter swirled about when inching closer to the entrance.  With an exterior resembling an actual warehouse in another life, one could easily mistake it for an underground club.  

They must save a lot on electricity with the dimly lit arrangement inside.  Most of the light comes from candles situated all over the place from table tops to wall crevices.  A relaxing vibe reverberates from each end of the restaurant.  With one side a bar full of chatty folk and the seating area on the other, space is economically used to the tee.    

OUR ORDER:  
*Asparagus & watercress soup - Coming down to this or the meat plate, we chose to share this.  The thought of the meat plate just seemed too overwhelming for the two of us.  The soup was very smooth and not watery.  The dimly diluted cream on top was very necessary and the almonds were definitely a nice touch.  The bowl seemed warmer than the soup if that means anything.  All in all, it was a good and light starter.  

*House made potato gnocchi - A very cute plate with a pinch of pizzazz describes this dish to a point.  Bun picked this right away; I guess you really are what you eat.  Before she could demolish the plate, I sampled the a couple pieces and dabbed the dressing that it came with.  Execution wasn't pristine and I would have elected for the extra bacon for an extra kick which she did not.  Looking at the homemade gnocchi's consistency alone, they were excellent.
   
*Prather ranch hamburger - I bypassed all the really delicious sounding choices from the dinner set for the burger.  This burger went down every pipe from my mouth so cleanly you can feel the natural freshness of the ingredients.  The dark setting totally underscores the quality of the juicy burger.  I added blue cheese which was a little heavy handed and also the bacon.  I highly recommend adding the bacon for substance.  Bun sampled the portion I cut for her and she also thought the burger was delicious.  This is someone with a dairy allergy chomping on a blue cheese filled burger.  All the adjectives of a superior quality burger one can think of should be stamped on this.  One question I still have, why it cost a buck more for dinner compared to lunch is beyond me.       

Best part of Serpentine is their attractive mood setting tone.  A collective of familiar and intimate at the same time describes its personality.  Food from dinner garnered as a whole was more than an arm's length higher than above average.  When ordering their much praised Prather ranch hamburger you'll get an ultra premium grade burger with a very compatible blend of fixings.  From our patron neighbors picks I was a little envious, but still glad I got the burger.  Next time, my next prerogative is to make an attempt at their brunch or breakfast which I also heard is very appetizing.
author: Arnold T.

description:
This Juicy burger belongs on a list somewhere, it's excellent. 

Service was great and our little table in the corner was wonderful. The restaurant overall was really lively but our little spot was very pleasant and not so loud, especially for a Friday night at 8PM.

I had the Burger with Blue Cheese and it was perfect. This is definitely a Top 10 San Francisco burger. I love it!
author: Justin S.

description:
Greeting- No
Vibe- no vibe
Parking- street
Service- hit or miss
Bathrooms- Fail
Wine List - not good
Prices- avaerage
Food
 Calamari was very good $8.50
Lamb meatballs were good $9
Gnocchi were perfect $18
Lemon custard cake $7.50 was not good

WIGB? Yes
author: Hungry K.

description:
Wonderful neighborhood bar and restaurant.  We had a nice wine, a round of burgers and a chickpea calamari. 

The atmosphere of this restaurant was superb and it's one of the best "mingle at the bar" scenes I've come across.
author: Anand A.

description:
Really disappointing. The reason for this 1 star review is pretty simple. I went there for brunch last weekend. My guest is a vegetarian, they had a meat burger on the brunch menu & a veggie burger on the lunch menu.

They refused to make a veggie burger for a vegetarian.  ** veggie burger is on our lunch menu** it was around 12:30pm. We ended up leaving & finding elsewhere to eat.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Had a great time. We now have a 6 month old daughter so have switched from having dinners out to breakfast/brunch/lunch. Priorities have changed in that we need a place where kids our welcome too and I have to say they were very very accommodating of a 6 month old with all the noise she makes.

Good with Kids - Excellent
Food Quality - Excellent
Food Taste - Excellent
Food Originality - Excellent
Price - Excellent
Customer Service - Excellent
Ambiance - Excellent
author: Vibhor C.

description: Had dinner here on Friday night, April 29.  It was uncomfortably loud.  The asparagus was good, chicken was OK, service was fine.  The dessert menu was uninspired.  Overwhelming all of this was the noise level.  I just wanted to get out of there.
author: Bay G.

description: Beautiful setting, great service, and good food.  Stopped by for brunch and sampled the wilted chicory salad with Chicken, pancakes with a side of bacon, and their biscuit.  All was quite good, with the salad being excellent.
author: Patrick S.

description: A really tasty breakfast option, with really good food.  Not sure why they open so late for a breakfast spot, but it worked out with our timing on the day that we went.  Friendly employees, and plenty of easy parking close by.
author: Steve L.

description:
Ate dinner here the other night and had a great experience. Very hip decor and wonderful ambiance. Sophisticated cocktails and well groomed entrees made for a very delicious evening.

Some folks were dessed well and others wore just tees so there was a variety of style, but over all a wonderful place for a two or three course meal.
author: Tucker M.

description:
This little gem is just blocks away from my work, definitely will be noting this spot for escape drinks. I loved their cocktail menu, and the cocktail I had. Yumm, my friend also had a cocktail off the menu, which they altered, instead of gin made with vodka, soooo good.

What we ate:

garbanzo beans crusted calamari, with garbanzo beans. I'm so getting this again
My friend had the scallops dinner portion, they were cooked perfectly. I had the pasta with the mushrooms and pancetta, with an egg, incredible.

The service was perfect, we sat for another hour after paying our bill and nobody rushed us out of there, even though they were packed. 

Next time I'm getting the burger, it looked phenomenal.
author: yana Z.

description:
A nice find while trying to take a leisurely stroll to the ballgame.  We came here for brunch and couldn't have been happier to find this place!

Most of the other places around had a wait and we were able to walk right in (we may have snagged the last table before a wait started...).  No wait usually turns me off when the other restaurants around have a wait, but we weren't too hungry and decided to give this place a whirl anyway.  

Fresh fruit cup/small portion: honestly, the best bang for your buck and utterly beautiful and fresh fruit.  Figs and persimmons were in my bowl!

This place knows how to do crispy potato.  Every little square was crispy and delicious.

This place is easy to miss, so keep your eyes peeled and get there early for an enjoyable brunch.
author: Lauren R.

description:
We went for Sunday brunch last week.  I had a delicious crab benedict, the potatoes were awesome as was the Hollaindaise. 

My wife had a tasty baked eggs and asparagus dish that weirdly had garbanzo beans. Not sure why they were there but they  detracted somewhat from the overall dish. 

Still a tasty brunch and pleasant service, would go again.
author: Alan S.
