description: Great food and quality service. The menu is constantly changing and new food is being added. The menu is also not what you'll typically find at "New American" restaurants boasting wonderful soup and main dish concoctions. I leave satisfied every time I eat here!
author: Angela B.

description:
I hate that I came here when I wasn't that hungry as half my meal went to waste. It was sooooo good! We came here on a rainy mid-week afternoon to enjoy a lunch in a little nook behind the bar.

Here's what I had...a cappuccino. Thanks, yum.

And a hash that was a beet and potato base with a poached egg (I AM OBSESSED WITH EGGS) that had some greens on top. This was the best balance for a lunch. I loved it. 

Service was great and so was the Acme bread they served while we waited.
author: Amy O.

description: Wow! We came in expecting a cafe experience, not only did Serpentine deliver it rose above! The menu is cohesive, and the food is fresh and delicious. The atmosphere is friendly and you can easily hold a conversation, the decor gives of an industrial and modern vibe. This cafes charm is alone a reason to visit, and the food makes this a stop not to miss.
author: Olivia T.

description: Came here for dinner w gf - great cocktails and good farm to table food
author: Marie r.

description:
Great appetizers, ok entree.

Poor service - waitress forgot win, kitchen forgot the main order.

Price for two: $115.
author: Lucas G.

description:
Dinner review: Underwhelming. I felt like this place was trying so hard to be trendy that I couldn't even fit in. I wanted to... but everything about the ambiance was just SO trendy... the mixologists whipping up drinks, the extra high tables sort of squished into the bar area section. The low lighting. I at once liked the atmosphere and wanted to be a part of it, but also felt like I didn't because it was just too trendy for me. I can't explain it lol 

The drinks mixed up for me was fine. I enjoyed the performance of it all, but not really the actual drink so much. I wanted the brussels sprouts to be fabulous, but they were a little sour. My girlfriends got burgers, and though we didn't discuss the quality of the meal, neither one finished. 

I am interested in the brunch experience, but I probably won't be back for dinner when there are so many other options now in this area to try out.
author: Ashley J.

description:
Great brunch spot.

Their bar area is first-come first-serve, which was great when my boyfriend and I just dropped in for brunch one day. We got lucky and were able to snag two seats within a couple minutes. 

The Dungeness Crab Benedict is a good choice for you seafood lovers. Delicious lump crab topped with perfectly poached egg,hollandaise sauce and capers. My boyfriend was happily satisfied.

The Country Fried Steak and Eggs is just divine! I loved the batter that Serpentine used on the steak - which was fried just right. Perfectly crispy potatoes with soft centers. Gravy on point with a yummy biscuit. I chose scrambled eggs, which they made great. In sum, a must try dish! 

The bartenders were friendly and funny. Though we didn't order any drinks, it was fun to watch them make cocktails and I could tell they enjoyed their job.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Ahhhh I really enjoyed my dinner here.

Came back for brunch this time on a Saturday morning after volunteering at Food Bank with a group of 10 girls.

Parking was super easy around the corner on a Saturday morning

Everything looked yummy - I had to pick from a short list of 3 which was tough...(this is especially difficult if you are starving - I wanted to order like two dishes).

6 or 7 out of 10 girls ordered Red Flannel Hash.  Yes it just sounded amazing (and I ordered it too).  It sure did not dissapoint. It wasn't too salty (corned beef can sometimes be a little too salty - but not at Serpentine!).  Other girls had the simple Eggs.Meat.Potatoes.Bread & Country Fried Steak & Eggs.  

Apparently biscuit that came with the steak was on the dry side but everything else tasted really good. 

Tasty without being too heavy, too salty or too anything.

This will be my go to restaurant (*provided I can get a reservation) in SF.
author: Sujan H.

description:
Fantastic space. Amazing food 
We were lucky enough to score a table on Sunday for brunch just as they opened. 

Food was creative and very tasty 
Space was warm, inviting and had a great vibe. 
Will definitely be back
author: Foodie C.

description:
Duck hash, eggs benedict, bacon cooked in brown sugar, french toast. If any of these sound tiring, perhaps you've been going to the usual San Francisco brunch spots too long. For as much of an individual touch each SF establishment likes to put on their dishes, brunch hasn't followed suit. Rather the status quo has been to stand in line for 3 hours for yet another eggs benedict made from somewhat happier chickens raised in a slighly larger yard giving eggs with infinitesimally more warm fuzzies.

Well, no more.  Serpentine turns all that on its head.  You will find your eggs benedict, but with a unique shrimpy twist.  You will find hash, but done as their "Red Flannel" hash with sinfully tender beef brisket and just the right amount of beets.  And you will find the polenta, pork and eggs, with polenta as good as any Italian restaurant.  There are several other menu options I look forward to trying also.

What brunch is complete without delightful BEvERages? Serpentine's bar is seemingly endless, I had an Espresso Whiskey cocktail which was great - two of my favorite things in one. The Pimm's Cup was also great.

Perhaps the most important thing is that there was *no wait* since Serpentine takes reservations. I know, a San Francisco brunch spot where you don't have to wait in line for hours. Next thing you know the city is going to build more houses and a small studio will cost less than $3k a month. Will wonders never cease.
author: Rishi G.

description:
I'm so diggin' the fact that Serpentine is located in the Dogpatch. I love seeing the assimilation of such awesome restaurants into an area that can certainly be somewhat shady.

Serpentine, hm. I've driven down 3rd Street a thousand times and I've never given it a second glance. My friend suggested we come here for lunch and I'm glad we did! It's a hip little spot, well-lit during the daytime, and staffed with really friendly and non-pretentious people. I think we came on a Monday afternoon and it was pretty packed; it would be wise to make reservations! As for the food, well, it was delicious [see photos]! Came out quickly & the perfect serving size. I will definitely be back!
author: I. L.

description:
**3.5**

+'s:
- No wait even on a Sunday around 12pm
- Easy street parking
- High ceilings, lots of natural light filtering in
- Lots of attractive SF hipsters

Ordered baked eggs, the hash, and a side of fries with my friend... overall, food and coffee were pretty good, but not mind-blowing enough to come back... way too many other options in SF to check out!
author: Diana K.

description:
The first thing I MUST mention is the space where Sepentine resides--an airy loft with high ceilings, windows for days & an intimate eating area...when all those design shows claim a place has got 'character,' *this* is what they mean. I'm entranced by the atmosphere this spot creates. 

BFF & I visited for brunch just as they were opening at 10am. We planned and plotted to share buckwheat pancakes, which by the looks of our neighbor's dish, had a tropical twist (mounds of pineapple, bananas & whipped cream--my head spun  like the exorist to get a load of that baby.) But after his chicken fried steak & eggs ($13.50) and my baked eggs, neither of us had room in our bellies. Next time we'll START with the sweets! 

My baked eggs ($10.50) were divine. Underneath two poached eggs (covered in a yummy tomatillo sauce) was a forest of veggies: hen of the woods mushrooms & a leafy green similar to spinach or kale. Beans gave it some protein & oomph and a side of corn bread made sure the dish was not too health-conscious. Really amazing, fresh flavors. An unexpected winner with friendly hipster staff, low-low prices & a playlist that kept my head swaying (and sometimes bobbin'.)
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Draaaaaaaaanks. Go for the drinks, stay for the food, leave in a very merry mood. That's what I did. 

We were a group of eight or so, and even after arriving late due to unforeseen delays (that may have had something to do with myself) the staff was super accommodating and sweet. They showed us right to the table and the fun fest began shortly thereafter. 

I'll just say this: Serpentine serves a barrel-aged Negroni that rivals my darling husbands, and even though you've never had his version, I'll tell you it's a big deal. They also have a fabulous Bourbon Smash on the menu that slips down quite easily and I may have had a few. These two were the stars among a strong drinks menu featuring any spirit you like -- I just happen to like Negroni and bourbon. 

Now onto the food: oxtail gnocchi, roasted chicken, spiced lamb shank, grilled swordfish -- any of these dishes will do ya well, and we sampled all that we could. The stand-outs were the gnocchi and the hangar steak, cooked beautifully and seasoned to perfection. The chicken was a tad on the under-seasoned side, but with the addition of beautifully fried and dressed Brussels sprouts and asparagus to go around the table, I was happy as could be. Happy happy.
author: Hilary H.

description:
Rude host. I've definitely experienced better. And frankly the restaurant deserves better. 

We were a family of four (2 adults, 2 preteen boys). We had waited 30 minutes outside for the restaurant to open on a Saturday morning. When the gate lifted and the waiting masses flushed inside the walkway, I was second in line and there were maybe 5-6 parties waiting behind us. 

The host seated the first party, then approached me to ask how many. I told him we were four but I was standing alone because my husband and kids were just outside. He then said he couldn't seat us until everyone was here and motioned the party behind me to step in front. 

I then spotted one of my sons in the back of the walkway and called for him to come up and called out for my husband and other son. My husband came up. I then said to the host, "OK we are here" but then noticed one of our sons was still not standing with us. My husband said, "We are all here but I have just asked my one son to stand outside for a minute because he is being punished." Ignoring my husband's explanation, the host then said, "OK, so when you are all here, I will seat you," then went around us to usher in the people standing behind us. 

I immediately called our other son to walk up, which he did right away, and at that point a different host, who had been standing just 3 feet away the whole time, asked us robotically, "How many in your party?" and "Are you all here?"

I understand that this is a popular restaurant and there is a seating protocol aimed at managing the efficient flow of customers without bottlenecks in service. But that particular host (dark hair, man bun) is executing on the protocol so rigidly, it's obnoxious. The bottleneck that he sought to prevent was literally one minute. One minute that was meant to teach our preteen son a lesson about proper public behavior. Instead of welcoming us in to be seated, to peruse the menu or order a drink for that one minute, the host preferred to lay down the law, send message of rigidity, and refuse service. 

The only reason we didn't walk out was because we were there to celebrate Father's Day and did not want to ruin our morning. The meal was good. The waiter was lovely. But in a city full of amazing restaurants, amazing famiily-friendly restaurants to boot, we see no need to spend money at Serpentine again. And we will warn all our friends that this restaurant is NOT family-friendly.
author: TK B.

description:
I almost don't want to give this restaurant five stars because I don't want others to find out about this great "neighborhood gem" of a spot. Serpentine has become a go-to dinner spot for my wife and I. We absolutely love it, from their appetizers (especially the brussels sprouts) to their main courses. I hear they've got a great brunch, too!

This is a fantastic restaurant; if it had opened up on Valencia Street, it would be packed to the gills every night of the week. Fortunately for us, it's in the Dogpatch, and that seems to make for a quieter atmosphere.
author: Andrew V.

description:
My friend and I dined at Serpentine last Sunday.  It's been on places to try and was a bonus that I was able to make a reservation on opentable.com.

I had 1pm reservations, but we arrived at 12:30pm.  I checked in with hostess #1 who said we were early and there wasn't any seating available.  She continued to say she would let us know if we could be seated earlier but most likely it wouldn't be until 1pm.  

Ten minutes later, I notice there's an empty table for two.  I thought maybe the people were a bit late.  My friend went to the bathroom and when she came back, she mentioned there two other empty tables towards the back, but we still waited patiently.  I noticed hostess #2 talking to hostess #1.  She was speaking with hostess #1 with and I'm assuming she was asking who was part of which party.  I did hear the hostess #1 state and pointed to us and another Asian party and said we were all together.  Hostess #2 looked at me for a minute and asked if I was part of that party.  I said no, but we had reservations. She asked me for my name and said she would seat us.  Hostess #1 looked at me and said I never checked in with her.  I told her that I did, I had a 1pm reservation, and that there was nothing available but she told us she would let us know when we could be seated.  Instead of apologizing, she looked away and said "oh yeah, that's right...".  She definitely should not be the first person customers interact with...JUST PLAIN RUDE!

I decided to order the Dungeness Crab Benedict ($15.50) which was quite a letdown. While the crab was sweet and the hollandaise sauce was rich and creamy, the problem was with the egg.  As I cut into the poached egg, my yolk was overcooked.  How could you have a benedict with a non-oozing yolk?!   The benedict was accompanied by an arugula salad and fried potatoes. 

Don't expect much service here.  After flagging our waitress down, she took our order and checked on us once.  

Parking should be relatively easy to find.  We parked about a block away.

Nothing here is worth coming back for...
author: Nicole S.

description: I took my bf and my sisters here for Sunday brunch courtesy of my "waitress friend - Leticia". She served me and my bf at Delfina on our 1st date and on the 3rd time we dined there, she suggested that we come here and give their brunch a try. So good thing that they take reservations because I cannot stand waiting in line for hours just to get seated. (There are tons of places to eat everywhere!) We arrived 5 minutes late to our reservation so we had to wait a while. (About 15 minutes. It was ok) We got seated on a decent table for 5 so my little sisters were happy. When we got there, it was a different lady who started serving us. I said hello to Leticia and after 10 minutes, she became our waitress! She was excited to see my bf and I. She gave us a complimentary buckwheat pancakes (pomegranate - bananas - pineapple - candied walnuts - mead & mead's maple syrup - whipped cream) to start with. How sweet and nice was that?! It was really good and filling. We all had a small bite as we wanted to enjoy our dishes too. (I will give that a 5) The boyfriends both had the Country Fried Steak & Eggs (flat iron steak - scrambled eggs - biscuit & gravy - crispy potatoes - arugula). I had a bite and the chicken was nice and tender. The gravy had just enough salt. The potatoes were roasted and crispy. (I will give that a 4) The sisters had the Huevos Rancheros (two eggs - spiced black beans - cilantro - hen of the woods mushrooms - avocado - sour cream - queso fresco - ranchero sauce - corn tortillas) and the Dungeness Crab Benedict (two poached eggs - hollandaise sauce - spinach - fried capers & lemon - fines herbs - buttermilk biscuit - crispy potatoes). Both were amazingly delicious and well-done. Kids were happy. (I will give them a 4) I had the  Flannel Hash (beef brisket - crispy potatoes - roasted beets - arugula - horseradish créme fraiche - poached eggs - rosemary salt - grilled levain). The beef brisket was tender and not too salty. It was very yummy. The beets and craime fresh made the dish quite delicious as it wasn't served too dry. (This is a 5) Over-all, the dish sizes were portioned very nicely; not too small nor too big for 1 person. Their lattes and cappuccino were also very good! The boys had some beer ciders that they also enjoyed. Over-all, it was a nice brunch especially with Leticia serving us. She took care of my table just the way I like it. :) It is quite pricey but I'll have to say, everything was worth it. I paid $130 for 5 people. It might be a bit expensive but I will definitely come back again! Thanks Leticia! You're awesome.
author: Anna Y.

description:
Cute little spot that hopefully stays a (semi) hidden gem! Had a friend visiting from LA who wanted brunch and ended up here because everywhere else was already reserved and too busy. 

I loved the decor of the inside - it was super hip and clean. The food was delicious (got the dungeness crabs benedict and the chicken fried steak) and came out pretty fast. I hear the burger and sandwiches are to die for, so those are next up on my list of must try's!

Would come here again to avoid ridiculous brunch lines and get quality food.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Our anniversary was approaching and I was unsure of what'd we do for our celebration or where we'd go. Bunny said he'd make reservations. He listed a few restaurants and said I could pick. I forgot what the other names were but all I could remember was choosing Serpentine because it had a catchy name.

Prior to our outing, I had browsed over the menu online. Since I had such a love for potatoes, the House Made Potato Gnocchi sounded perfect! Bunny had read good things regarding the burger and had his mind set up to order The Prather Ranch Hambuger.

It was a Friday night and I headed to the city straight after work. I was wearing my casual Friday Uggs and jeans. Not sure if there was enough time to change or being a bit lazy to bring other clothes, I thought I'd be fine with my attire. Boy was I wrong! The outside of the restaurant looked old and was in an area that was nearby the docks. However, the interior was a whole other story.

With dim light and a romantic setting with candles, I felt a slight embarrassed. After being seated, I felt better knowing that no one could really see since the lights were so low. We decided on the same entrees and decided on adding a soup. We picked the Aspargus and Watercress Soup. Remember an experience with ordering a heavy meat sampler as an appetizer and being too full to finish our dinner, we both felt a soup would be just right. That was a good start to our evening. It was green colored and had cream on top. We shared it and liked our choice.

The gnocchi was great with all of the potates. The texture was chewy and there was a side of dressing which added flavor to the dish. I enjoyed my dinner. Bunny's burger was so huge that it had to be cut up. Adding blue cheese and bacon added a special touch to the burger. The meat was fresh and it was a nice burger. It wouldn't have been my first choice because I usually have sandwiches and burgers for lunch, but I didn't mind trying some.

The presentation and dining had a nice feel to it. I wouldn't coming back here again to try some of the other dishes. All in all, it was a fun evening and great way to celebrate our 5th anniversary!
author: Doris W.

description:
Their burger is amazing! A must try if you love burgers.  The meat is so juicy and cooked perfectly. The bun is nice and soft. The greens were fresh, and the cheese was tasty. The fries were crisp. The only thing I regret is not getting the bacon... Next time. 

Tip: make reservations. This place gets packed. If you're dropping in get here early. They have a small amount of open seating. 

A must try if you're in the area. Get the burger!
author: David B.

description: My 3rd home for, I believe, 4 years now.  I have only been here for brunch on Sundays and Mondays.  They are consistently delicious, especially their seasonal salads.  Their Whiskey Smash is bomb.  Price isn't so bad compared to other places that charge more for mediocre food.  Service isn't always great, especially the host/esses, but it's ok.  They have already captured my heart and would be hard to get rid of me.
author: Savinie L.

description: This place has a wonderful ambiance, I admit. Although the amount of food you get for the prices you are charged just do not match up. I found that Serpentine was very overpriced. Upon my last visit, I had the California black cod, which cost $30. It was a small serving and I finished the meal still feeling very hungry at the end.
author: Terilyn A.

description:
3 1/2 stars.  Our meal here was not bad, but not overwhelmingly special.

We started with some sort of cold bean appetizer.  It was far too salty, and our party left it untouched after we each took a few nibbles.  I liked what I believe was the smoked herring appetizer, and the pickled vegetables were fine.

I had a ravioli dish.  It was fairly flavorful, but the raviolis were not very plump.  I also sampled the gnocchi with Dungennes crab - the gnocchi was fine, but the sauce was so buttery (and a little too salty) such that it masked the crab flavor.

Ambience was nice, and they had a nice cocktail list.  The service was friendly.
author: Connie T.

description:
I love brunch places that accept reservation!  Came here for my sister's bday brunch.  One of my sisters was running late, but they didn't rush us at all.  This place is small so big groups can be limited.  I love the industrial feel and high celing.  

Food:
I ordered red hash... i'm not a beet lover but i still got this because it looked good.  beet = taste like dirt to me.  The dish was good but I had to push the beets aside.  
hubby got the crab benedict and it was okay.  
I got pancakes too... big and yum... always great when it comes with maple syrup.  
My brother in law raved about the bread pudding and when I tasted it, yup it was good.  Too bad I'm cutting on carbs.  

Will have to come back to try it again.  Parking isn't a problem here IMO.
author: Claire J.

description:
Seriously? 4 stars based on 1000 reviews? Have the other reviewers actually eaten at any respectable dining establishment in the world? Is this the gateway to the restaurant world after a lifetime of In and Out? I came here with a friend and we had the polenta/pork and eggs, steak and eggs, and a side of bacon. The bacon amounted to 3 borderline anemic slices that were thin, chewy, and flavorless. The steak last for 4 bites although I will give them credit for actually cooking it to medium. The pork that came with the polenta  was stringy and unexciting. Everything else on the plate tasted dull and had a texture reminiscent of microwaved food. The only way to make the polenta  or the eggs palatable was to carpet bomb the entire region with ground pepper and hot sauce. I would be highly skeptical of the palette and credibility of anyone who recommends this place. 

I'd give it one star if not for the decent service, ambience, and drinks here.
author: Cory N.

description:
In an effort to better familiarize myself with Dogpatch, I made dinner plans with Alice L here two weeks ago. Between the two of us, we ended up sharing the Blossom Bluff peach and apricot salad [ http://flic.kr/p/cfz9UE ], gnocchi with braised oxtail, almond torte, and their version of a New Fashioned (involving rum, cherry, bitters, and a few other things).

While the gnocchi was a bit disappointing, because the pasta was a bit too mushy, with flavors that were a little too bland, the rest of the meal was quite enjoyable. The mint in the salad was a little unusual, but overall, the flavors worked together well to create a tasty salad. The torte, definitely the highlight of the night, was not too sweet, with flavors that melded together just right, to create an amazing dessert. The New Fashioned was a great drink as well, though perhaps a bit more a matter of preference, as it has a fairly medicinal kick to it.

The space has an industrial warehouse feel to it, which is neat. Service was quick and friendly, and prices were as expected, coming out to ~$38 a person after tax and tip (I believe I've omitted one dish from the aforementioned). While I'm not sure I'd come back for their mains, I can certainly see myself coming back for their dessert and cocktail menu!
author: Johnny W.

description:
Took the BF akaJaySmash here for his Bday Dinner. Made reservations for 8pm. We didn't get seated until almost 9pm. :/ 

BUT, they did comp us our first round of drinks at the bar and our dessert for the inconvenience! That was unexpected and made our experience much more enjoyable. They were out of the ceviche, which was the second disappointment of the night. We were really looking forward to it! 
Oysters were good, nothing to write home about- reallllly teeny tiny oysters...  I'd skip these next time.

Scallops were delicious! 
Mushroom Gnocchi delicious!
Salmon delicious! 

 the chocolate spiced cake. YUM!

Will definitely come back!
author: Gloria y.

description: Beautiful food, angry service. Come here for the flavor, withstand the server that wants you to die.
author: Jay B.

description: For dinner we had fried chicken, which was tasteless, and Tuna, which was also without flavor. Fried chicken is supposed to be a tasty treat, but I guess they don't prepare it the right way. Bland meals.  And fairly expensive. The citrus salad was good. The brussel sprouts were OK, not great. Not likely to return. Unimpressed.
author: Bill S.

description:
I SO wish i could give this place a 3.5, but since i can't, I'll bump it up to a four.

We had dinner here with an out of town friend, and another friend who lives in SF and had enjoyed Serpentine on a previous visit.

Parking was a breeze, and free. 
I had made a reservation , and we were seated right away.
Our drink orders were taken quickly, but it took our server awhile to get back to us.

We shared some oysters, and calamari. I'm not usually a big fan of calamari, but theirs had really great flavor. Maybe it was the chick pea flour? Although, we all would have preferred if it hadn't been sitting in any kind of liquid, since that killed the crispiness.

My friend and i both ordered the grilled yellowtail. It was paired with: himalayan red rice ,dungeness crab, petite asian greens, &  coconut & green mango curry. 
It was a very light and delicate dish. I didn't see or taste the crab,and my friend sent hers back because her fish skin was soggy. She ended up with the gnocchi, which she said were AMAZING.She also had the brussel sprouts which she raved about.
I liked the fish dish, and appreciated it's lightness, but wasn't overly impressed with it.
My guy had the steak, and his dish was the clear winner at our table . We all tasted it, and it was fabulous. All the components of the dish were delicious.(roasted kohlrabi, parsley root,mustard greens ,aged cheddar potato puree & sauce bordelaise.)

Our other friend had the fried chicken, it was good, but i 'm not really into fried chicken.

The four us shared the ice cream sandwich.Each of just wanted a few sweet bites to finish the meal, and this did it. While we all liked it, but no one was blown away.

Their cocktails were creative and well made, and we all liked our drinks.

I've eaten at their sister restaurant, Slow Club, and I prefer it to Serpentine.
author: Amanda G.

description: ate at the bar and the bartenders made the meal. my first chicken & waffle experience. ask about gin shots! dont miss dessert.
author: Jon W.

description:
12.26.13

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/serpentine-san-francisco?select=ssagxWRSe8KA2a7IsGrWpw#ssagxWRSe8KA2a7IsGrWpw

Nice, quiet, neighborhood gem, that you can easily miss if you're not looking carefully.  Thankfully, we did, parked across the street, and strolled in early for our 6:45 reservation.

The wait staff was friendly and patient while we mulled over our wine decision.  They let us have a taste before taking the plunge - and the bottle was ever better than the tasting!

We shared the chicken livers - I don't know what you have in that "Thai bird chili", but layer it on!  I had the tagliatelle (I'm a sucker for fresh pasta) and it was decadent.  I mean, cooked with black truffle butter?  Yes, please!

The fried brussels sprouts were great, and made an awesome sidekick to our mains.

Total damage for two: $130
author: Jenny L.

description:
This is the best food I have had in California.

Our table started with Calarmari (7 out of 10). OK.

The BBQ pork ribs were great (9 out of 10) and the pickled corn relish it came with was incredible.

Then they brought out a summer fruit salad. This is literally the best salad I have ever had in my life. Incredible. Chock full of flavors and *fresh*. I could taste how fresh it was.

Was going to do the steak for dinner but did what I have never done before - ordered another fruit salad. BOOM!

Stole some sea scallops off my wife's plate (9 out of 10) and tried some of their french fries. They were OK - too overcooked though.

Anyway, let's go back to the salad. That was delicious. I left asking myself, why in the world is it so hard to get a GREAT salad in the world. For me, I have found it is harder to find than a good main entree.j

I WILL BE BACK!
author: Jason M.

description:
To celebrate the holiday season, seven supremely lovely ladies gathered together for brunch at Serpentine one Saturday morning.  Although the wait was just a teeny bit too long to get seated with a ressie* that morning, the staff overall was friendly and accommodating.  Oh, and the food?  What to have?  

For sweet, let me suggest the buckwheat pancakes topped with fresh fruit (ours was persimmon!), candied nuts, and whipped cream (indeed, it is dessert for breakfast).  4 out of 7 of the supremely lovely ladies ordered this dish.  One had the audacity to order two stacks. (A word to the wise:  one stack will suffice as the portions are quite large and pancakes tend to expand in your stomach.)  

For savory, go with the dungeness crab benedict with a side of greens, potatoes, and surprisingly fried tart lemon wedges.  3 out of 7 of the supremely lovely ladies ordered this dish.  Three other ladies conspired to order an extra dish of this to share just because.  

Exclamations of "yum!" "this is delicious,"  and "I would give away my firstborn child in exchange for this meal" were heard emanating from the table.  

A divine time by 7 out of 7 tastebuds was had by all.





*they don't take ressies or have space avail for 9 or more (although you may be able to squeeze one in if you are not holiday chubby).
author: Peg S.

description:
This is purely reviewing Serpentine's service. I understand that this place gets their vegetables from organic sources. But does that mean that customers should then happily expect bugs in their dishes? My friend got a small bug in her dish and she called our waitress over to let her know about it. She was courteous and matter of fact, and all we sensed from the waitress was that she wanted to make it look like it wasn't a bug or that she was trying to get out of the situation by making something up. But she was wise enough to halt mid sentence and then took the dish back to the kitchen. Then came out the manager or whoever and he wasn't helpful or nice about the entire situation at all. It really could've have been solved easily and pleasantly for both parties. But he was pushy and impatient. He first didn't even apologize for the fact that the washing wasn't done thoroughly and straight up blamed on the organic sources thing. Then he just said "So do you want something else or are you full?" when it could be seen easily that my friend only took a few bites of her dish. Don't assume that you can just half-heartedly ask that question and then be done with it. When my friend asked for the same dish again, but perhaps switch out the arugula on which the bug was found, the guy literally didn't even wait until my friend was fully finished before he just asserted that nothing could be done about that and asked to put the arugula on the side - it was definitely more of a command than a question. 

I don't care how good your food is, if you treat your customers like this then please don't expect, at least my friend and I, to go again.
author: Nancy Pian-Pian L.

description:
Went back for dinner and it was just as good as lunch here. I ended up getting the gnocci and my friend ordered the burger. I should've made a reservation via open table because we got seated at the bar again. I want to try the actual experience here but it's nice to see a place like this that's a bit tucked away busy all the time. I ended up getting the Ginger Root to drink and it was very refreshing. I will definitely have to see what other cocktails they have to offer. My friend got the Dogpatch Dispatch which was just ok.

Prices for entrees are about $16 and up.
author: Amy J.

description:
Portions were small but good size for lunch. Celery root soup was well done but the spices were not to my liking. Crisp apple garnish on top was good though. Seared rock cod was very good as was the penne w/broccoli rabe. Empanadas were wonderful.

Place is small and hip. Get there early or reserve.
author: Mark M.

description:
Oh yes! Some of the tastiest, most delicious breakfast food I've had in a long time. I went here with a time limit, hoping to grab some brunch real quick. It was just myself, so I easily snagged a bar seat. I was in and out of there in less than an hour! Talk about service!

On a Sunday, late morning, this place is packed. It's not very big to begin with, though there were crowded tables everywhere. There were quite a few bar seats open, and it gave me the chance to make some new friends! Plus, in talking with the bartender, I was perplexed by their sage based liquor there were carrying. Without asking or with hesitation, he gave me some to try so I could get an opinion of my own. I loved it! I thought that was a great move on his part.

I had the fried egg sandwich. It sounds greasy and basic, but it was everything but. It was a large sandwich served with some of the best fried potatoes I've ever had. They were crunchy and golden brown, with just a dash of salt. The menu selection wasn't huge, but it had a little something of everything and some really unique choices.

I absolutely loved my breakfast. I can't wait to go back for more!
author: Tara H.

description:
Please put the Veggie Burger on the dinner menu! I absolutely love that chorizo spiced, chickpea deliciousness but never get to taste the vegetarian glory because you eliminate the opportunity. 

Dogpatch vegetarian options are quite bereft. Can't you be a trend setter oh sweet Serpentine? Can't you help me? Won't you fill my belly? The moment I see that sandwich available at dinner this three turns to a five because you deserve it otherwise.
author: Grant L.

description:
Great dishes, great ambience, and good is delicious. Waitress and waiter worked together and were very attentive. Loved every minute of my friends birthday celebration! Thank you for the wonderful experience. 

The price was also fairly reasonable.
author: April W.

description:
We came here for afternoon brunch (is that a thing) on Easter Sunday.  We easily found parking- such a nice change, walked into Serpentine, and were seated within about ten minutes of arriving.

We ordered the Red Flannel Hash and the Dungeness Crab Benedict to split.
The food was yummy, and interesting take on some classics.  I loved the brisket and the roasted beets.  There's something fun, and surprisingly yummy, about eating bright pink breakfast!  The Benedict was good, not the best that I've had in my life, but certainly not the worst.  I'll echo others' sentiments in saying there really isn't that much crab meat.

The service was nice, the wait staff wasn't overbearing, but made sure we were comfortable and had full drinks.  

I would go again if I'm in that area of town again, but probably forgo the Benedict.
author: Cass H.

description:
The space may be small but it was comfortable.  The hostess and the waiter were friendly and pleasant.  Definitely good comfort food. 

I enjoyed every course of my meal.  Started with the curried coconut soup (with pomegranate seeds - cilantro & pepita salsa secca), which looked and tasted like butternut squash bisque.  Despite it being vegan, the soup was smooth and creamy.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=TTh38lLBgGswZfBNzJskjQ)

Followed that with Serpentine meat board (pancetta, speck, duck prosciutto, piccante salami, duck liver mousse, pickled peppers & green tomatoes, whole grain mustard, grilled levain toasts).  It's hard to describe how great it was.  There was a lot going on and I can only say that everything on the board was gone.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=bLGgmxBnCHFfm1ZTU2ODag) 

The entree, pan seared cod with braised fennel, caramelized daikon, apples, jalapeno in spiced cider broth.  The fillet was well seasoned and seared perfectly.  The spiced cider broth was tangy and subtle.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=7XA1RG8gNfh3BnsMo4i_Sw)

I didn't think I could love fried brussels sprouts anymore but this was served with roasted chestnuts and topped with fresh grated cheese. Delish!!!   http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=VXJi8ym28ERb9cbvTVwClQ

The dessert was probably the least of my favorites.  I've had better Affogato - vanilla ice cream with a shot of espresso.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=fix4uqoTA5zd1QfM1L8fBQ)

I washed all this down with Bundaberg ginger beer.  Definitely a great meal I've had in a awhile.   

The plus to great food...no worries in finding a parking spot in this neighborhood.
author: Hannah C.

description: I've only been here for dinner and highly recommend it! The burger is simply amazing. They have a great selection of wines and beers to choose from, and the service is impeccable. Definitely one of my favourites!
author: Katarina D.

description:
I came here with a large-ish group of 7, and enjoyed my meal, my wine, my cocktail, my dessert, and our waitress. The only bummer was the ambient noise--very difficult hearing people who weren't right next to me! I didn't expect to be able to converse from one end of the table to the other, but maybe one or two folks away would have been nice... 

Still, the food, drinks, and service were great. I sampled: oysters, scallops, a salad, cheeses, olives, calamari, flank steak, agnolotti, and brush sprouts. Desserts were: lemon cake, a decaf affogato, and a fruit crisp. 

All the food was great. If I had to choose stand outs, I would pick the Chickpea-crusted Calamari, and the Seared Scallops. Both kinds of seafood are notoriously difficult to cook well, and they were both original and refreshing tasting. 

Favorite dessert had to be the lemon cake--it was so bright tasting, without tipping over into face-puckering. The espresso in the affogato was well pulled too.

Will definitely be back.
author: Allison S.

description:
Dinner here is great, but brunch is amazing!  My last visit I ordered a buckwheat pancake that came out the size of my plate!  That alone should have been enough, (and with all the awesome toppings that came on it, it was enough).  However- I also had the Country Fried Steak & Eggs and could barely walk out after I finished.  

Serpentine serves the kind of meals you want to continue to stick your fork in, even after you're already full and know its time to throw in the towel!
author: DJ P.

description: Came here for my birthday dinner because it was close to the bar for my party. Place does get crowded, so try to make reservations. To drink ,I had the Smokey Bandit, which I liked a lot. The food was just ok, I had the Oven Roasted Mary's Chicken. Service was decent.  If I could, I would give this place a 3 for food and 4 for drinks. Would come back here again for drinks only and maybe try brunch.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Unbelievably good! While I can't say that I can afford this for a regular lunch break from work, it is one of the best places to eat in the Dogpatch!

Creative menu and craft cocktail selection, modern and inviting atmosphere with solid service. Highly recommended.
author: Ethan B.

description:
I'm glad I finally tried Serpentine, thanks to a Yelp Deal for an oil change at nearby Tech One automotive. It was the most pleasant wait for auto services ~ I also couldn't resist stopping in for a scoop of ice cream at neighbor, Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous on my way back...pardon my digression.

Coming back to Serpentine, luck was on my side and I was quickly seated at the bar. The ambiance is part industrial, modern, natural finishes and light, high ceiling. Roomy, it put me at ease.

I had the most delicious buckwheat pancake with fresh blackberries, strawberries, whipped cream, candied walnuts, and maple syrup. The side sausage was on the dry side for me. Good coffee.

Service was pleasant and helpful. I look forward to returning ~
author: Cathy K.

description:
Time for brunch. 

* Buckwheat Pancakes $9 (4 of 5) strawberries & bananas - candied walnuts - maple syrup - whipped cream. Very fluffy wheat pancakes and very tasty. If you want to try wheat pancakes, I would recommend this place.

* Red Flannel Hash $12 (2.5 of 5) beef brisket - roasted beets - crispy potatoes - horseradish créme fraiche, poached eggs & grilled levain.  The beef brisket was a little dry and the meat was a little grainy. I don't recommend this dish. 

* Wild California Salmon Benedict $15.50 (3 of 5) two poached eggs - bearnaise sauce - sauteed spinach - shaved fennel salad - fried capers & lemon - fines herbs - buttermilk biscuit - crispy potatoes. A little salty for the whole dish. The fried lemon was a little bitter because of the skin. This wasn't a really well executed Salmon Benedict dish.

* Savory Bread Pudding $11.50 (4 of 5) house cured ham - gruyere - caramelized onions - asparagus - poblano peppers - carrot - rapini - served with green salad. Tasty and great crunchy texture on the top of the bread pudding. This is probably my second favorite dish here.
author: Janice T.

description:
Very cool spot. Back in its prime it used to be a boiler room for a candy factory. 
Went to serpentine for the first time during SF restaurant week. The Roasted chicken was flavorful, nice and tender and fell off the bone. 
Great Manhattan cocktail as well. Staff seems to be very friendly
author: Trev V.

description: Drinks are artistic and excellent. Food is fast and delicious. Service, handsome and attentive. Crowd, friendly and upbeat. And SO much more. Went before a concert and they were accommodating to our timeframe. It can get very crowded. Highly recommend.
author: Denise R.

description:
I called to place an order for takeout. Lady answers and says sure but asks if I can hold on. I say sure. She puts me on hold for nearly ten minutes so I figure she forgot about me and I call back. 

A guy answers the phone. I ask to place an order for takeout he says they're really "slammed" right now and that they "have to take care of the people who are actually here" and to try calling back in ten minutes. I explain what happened about me being on hold and he interrupts me and goes, "what do you want?" as rudely as you can imagine. I go "umm" trying to catch my bearings by someone being so rude and he goes "what do you want?!" I decided not to order after that. 

I'm pretty sure this is the rudest service I've ever had. I'm a polite, respectful person and I expect as much from anyone else.
author: Y C.

description:
Hidden gem in Potrero Hill, with dim lights and intimate setting!

Appetizers
1. Meat Board: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=t2P3iUeL_2ixymKLBBMwig
+ Various types of meat and sauce (like duck, salami, duck liver)
+ Bread to eat with the meat!

2. Winter Vegetable Salad: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=LYTRtPlbXOfHRRIrA7UHpA
+ Refreshing -- I loved the combo of vinaigrette, watermelon, and pomegranate! 

3. French fries with aioli: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=pXhg_iUKPqMccCITgR0yFA
+ Lots of fries!
- Nothing special -- a bit too salty too, can't eat too much.
- Sauce was just okay; ketchup was better than the aioli!

Entrees
4. Spicy Braised Pork Osso Bucco & Manilla Clams: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=3cjU3K8lDP6bmsgdkuKY4Q
+ Pork was EXTREMELY tender...and the spiciness definitely kicked in at the end of each taste!
- Clams were just so so
- Too much sauce at the bottom, IMO

5. Hangar Steak: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=ZLa1Nw6AguQfRSxRDNrzww
+ Tender as well
+ Mashed potatoes with gravy complemented steak very well
+ LOVEDDDD the onions. Soft, and full of flavor from the gravy!
- More rare than expected (Medium rare was actually rare)

Dessert
- None because they didn't sound too good. As a dessert lover, this was a major disappointment for me ):

Service:
+ Very attentive -- water was always filled (;
+ He explained every dish when it was delivered!

Loved loved the place! Heard great things about the brunch here, so can't wait till I come back and try more!
author: Evelyn S.

description:
Found this place off of yelp and I'm glad I did! 

I was looking for a place to have brunch with a few friends on my last visit and everywhere I wanted to go was fully booked, but like I said, yelp eventually brought me here! 

The food was fantastic! I highly recommend the dungeness crab benedict! It was super fresh and delicious!! My friend and I also split the braised pork and polenta which was sort of disappointing, but that might have been because we ate it after the benedict, so it was a bit cold. My other friends also got the chicken friend steak, which they liked a lot! One of my friends went to school in the south and said it was just like the chicken fried steak they make in the south, so that's probably a good thing! 

Overall, great place for brunch away from the crowds, and it's super hip! Definitely a good place to try!
author: Amy S.

description:
Honestly id put 3.5. The place was decent, i checked out the menu, ordered the fried chicken and waffles with the buckwheat pancakes. It wasnt anything special, my fried chicken was underseasoned(the batter), but my pancakes were decent. 

Service was pretty good, luckily i was seated at the bar, if not they told me to wait for an hour, at least. I dont think its worth the wait so i made a pretty good choice. Id go here again if i was in the area but i wouldnt travel all the way here. But hey, mr and mrs miscellanious is right next door so get yourself an scoop of ice cream after eating here!
author: Cavin T.

description: Went here on Saturday with a small group. Bartender was a smartass and the food was OK. Not good and not bad, just not memorable. Won't be going soon.
author: Dawn M.

description:
Brunch review: 
Food: Dungeness Crab Eggs Benedict was delicious. Generously sized fluffy biscuit with a fair amount of crab. Great texture with the home fries style potatoes, crunchy outside and soft inside. I really enjoyed this meal.
Cocktails: Bloody Mary was good. Pimm's cup was refreshing and my favorite, but not a good choice if you don't like ginger.
Ambiance: It was a Sunday brunch, crowded and loud, somewhat difficult to have a conversation. We had a reservation, so I'm not sure what the wait would be.
Verdict: Great brunch food and cocktails, but a bit loud. I would return.
author: Estrelania W.

description:
Their large soup is tiny (just six ounces)! Also the "warm" salad was room temperature, not warm. 

A little pricey for what I got (I spent $18 on lunch and left hungry). 

The only positive was their seasonal ingredients.
author: Jade P.

description:
haven't been to a serpentine in a while...man, have i missed it.
the quinoa salad is amazing, definitely check it out.
i was so glad to see that the veggie burger is still on the menu.
this is by far THE BEST homemade veggie burger i've ever had.
usually they crumble and fall apart, not this one.  coupled with
the best fries in the city, oh and a lovely glass of pinot gris make it divine.
i will definitely be coming back sooner than later.

and the wait staff...super nice and accommodating.

big thumbs up for what's going on over at serpentine.
there's a reason they made this list:
http://www.thrillist.com/eat/san-francisco/most-underrated-restaurants-in-sf
author: J. Katy V.

description:
I found this place on Yelp & it exceeded my expectations. 

Serpentine is another amazing find in SF artistic Dogpatch district - it's beautiful rustic with modern industrial decor and fresh honest (like the menu says) food to match. 

For lunch, I had a Pimms cup cocktail with a beet salad with some sort of beef or pork hash which was all phenomenal. 

My boyfriend had the rock cod, which was cooked perfectly. The outside was crispy and inside melted in your mouth. LOVE. LOVE. LOVE.

A++
author: Jazmine G.

description:
Had Sunday brunch here and it was fabulous. Originally called in to get a reservation for my friend and I for 11am but ended up showing up right as they opened at 10am. Just the fact they take reservations for brunch (which rarely exists in SF) deserves 5 stars! Found street parking very easily which isn't unusual in that area. A few other groups of people were there too but it wasn't super crowded even as we were leaving later around Noon. 

As for the food: My friend and I both got the single pancake with a side of potatoes (huge bowl!), coffee, and bacon for me. Everything was delicious!! The bacon was a little oiler than usual but still nice and crunchy while the pancakes were sweet but not too sweet and really moist. The pomegranate seeds were an interesting touch too sprinkled on top of the whipped cream. Added a bit of tartness to balance out the sweetness of the rest of the dish. I was so full by the time I left with a small take out box for my leftover potatoes (which was amazing!). The ambiance there is super relaxed and great service/ attitude from everyone who works there. I'd definitely come here again for brunch. Their bar is fully open for brunch as well and I saw lots of people at other tables getting the grapefruit mimosa so i'll have to try that next time. 

Price: Worth it. Total including tip for the two of us was $40 but that's on par with pricing as other brunch places in the City these days. $2.50 for coffee, $7 for one large pancake, $3.50 for side potatoes and $4 for side of bacon (3 strips).
author: Deb Y.

description:
Went here with a couple friends and the experience was good. Ordered the crab cake benedict since it's crab season and it was good, but I was a little disappointed with how much actual crab meat you get-- it's not a whole lot. But let me tell you, the potatoes were so freakin' good. I had to order another side of them because my bf kept eating mine! The bf got the baked eggs which were delicious, but I would say a small portion if you're a guy's guy and have a pretty healthy appetite.

I'd definitely go back, but this time try the egg sandwich or the egg, meat, potatoes, bread.
author: Kimberly F.

description: Located a bit off the beaten path won't deter me from coming back. The food was fantastic as was the service. If I didn't have a gift card I would have never found this gem. I'm glad I did.
author: Jillian C.

description:
Nothing in the world causes my head to spin like the pulse-pounding dilemma of figuring out what to order. Decision quicksand! I settled on red flannel hash and a cup of coffee.

I picked the entree because my friend kept raving about it, even though I had reservations about eating a big slab of beef for brunch when I knew I had other meals lined up for the day. And, let's not lie, I wanted to order about three other entrees as well. Happy to report that the beef brisket was out-of-this-world delicious. I get stars in my eyes just thinking about it.
author: Sharon L.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend on a Saturday afternoon. The decor has a nice, airy,  cool tone feeling to it with distressed gray wooden walls and dark curtains hanging in front of their restrooms. My boyfriend and I ordered the Prather Ranch Burger with cheddar cheese while he opted for the gruyere cheese and pickles.

Prather Ranch Burger with cheddar cheese: Let me just say that my favorite burger is from Roam Artisan's, but the Prather Ranch Burger from Serpentine is a close second! They use Acme buns which is one of the reasons this burger is so good. Besides the bun, the ingredients were fresh! The tomatoes were yelp red, the pickles and mustard are made in house, and they had the leafy crunchy lettuce. Absolutely delicious! It's a bit pricy at $12.50 minus the cheese, but you should definitely indulge at least once. :)

The service was phenomenal and they kept on refilling our waters which is definitely a plus! Our waitress was knowledgeable about their products which is something that I appreciate. I'll be back!
author: Joyce E.

description: Came here for brunch on a Sunday morning at prime brunch time (11:30am) and snagged a free table without reservations! They do take reservations so I would recommend that if you are a larger group. I ordered the polenta & eggs and my husband had the red beef hash. The beef hash is definitely on the heavier side but the polenta and eggs were cooked perfectly. We want to come back to try their crab benedict and burger next time! Service was perfunctory at best, our waiter never came back to check on us, not even once. Figured that with the $1/per person SF healthy charge, that should be a minimum requirement. 3.5 stars for the total dining experience.
author: Betty C.

description:
Brunch is pretty much my favorite meal. Not only was this meal created just so you can sleep in on the weekends but it's never complete without a healthy portion of starchy potatoes or a bread/pastry of some sort. Not to mention somehow the combining of the two meals makes consuming a cocktail before noon acceptable without appearing to be a huge lush. I noticed Serpentine when making one of my trips to Mr & Mrs Misc for ice cream. So I yelped it, read all of the splendid reviews and decided to finally make it out this way just this past weekend. 

I loved the former warehouse industrial look of the restaurant with high, paint scraped ceilings but yet bright and airy below. The restaurant was pretty efficient in having the table set aside for reservations as we were seated immediately upon checking in. 

I ordered the buckwheat pancakes (1 ct) and the gem salad. The buckwheat pancake was wonderful and was larger than I'd anticipated. And usually I'm not a huge whipped cream fan but along with the berries, syrup and the walnuts, I enjoyed every single sweet, nutty bite. The little gem salad was pretty simple but the full-of-spice vinaigrette dressing made it what it was with Armenian cucumbers, cherry tomatoes and slices of peach. C had the savory bread pudding which came with a side salad. I took a few gruyere flavored bites to sample his dish and it was delicious. They offer a pretty decent list of cocktails and juices to go along with your food. 

I'm sure I'll be back in the near future to try dinner. With a satisfying brunch that was just had I'm sure they do just as wonderfully for dinner.
author: Esther A.

description:
I heard the food here is amazing, but sadly I will never experience it due to the abysmal treatment we got from the hostess today.  In fact we ended up eating at Chocolate Lab http://www.yelp.com/biz/chocolate-lab-san-francisco,  which was great. 

My friend was raving about this place so we decided to brunch there. When we got in we were told it was a 40 minute wait - completely reasonable as this is SF on a Sunday. The hostess then told us we could wait at the bar until our table is ready. We grab some seats, sit down and order drinks. 5 minutes later, the hostess informs us that we can't actually sit at the bar, as there is a waiting list and a couple wants our seats. Um, ok. So we tell her were still waiting on our drinks and we'll move after we pay. 

Shortly thereafter, the hostess comes back and says she can seat us at a table, but we can only sit there for 40 minutes. WTF? No thanks, we say, we'll wait. At this point, I really don't want to eat here anymore, but my friends want to stay. 

The people seated next to us at the bar are leaving, so the bartender says we can just scoot down to take their seats. Just as we are moving, the hostess comes back again and says, no, we can't sit there either, but we can stand at the end of the bar. I'm really pissed off at this point, and I tell my friend we can stay, but I'm not eating. Why should I support a business that would treat me like this? This is when the hostess comes back up to us and tells us that we can sit in the seats at the bar - the same seats she had just told us not to sit in, and she had the nerve to act as if she was doing us a favor. I am not eating here, I inform my friends for the umpteenth time. They finally get the point, and with that, we left. 

If you are going to eat here, make sure the short chubby chick with blondish/brownish hair (and pocked skin, according to my friend) is not the hostess. She is terrible. The bartenders, however, are great. Kudos to them for trying to smooth out the situation.

EDIT: Apparently I am not the only one who had a bad experience with the front of the house. Whoever owns Serpentine needs to get that together ASAP.

http://www.yelp.com/biz/serpentine-san-francisco#hrid:u-fzDPUbrvpu-Ovaucxwag

http://www.yelp.com/biz/serpentine-san-francisco#hrid:Rt0AbMV0O3A1wJ0VGfyErA
author: Miss S.

description:
When I'm craving good ole wholesome Californian food with high quality, sustainable ingredients, I come here. I can taste the love in the food. I am gluten, dairy, and egg intolerant. I've been a fan of Serpentine for awhile, even in my gluten/dairy/egg eating days. Love the industrial decor, atmosphere, and space.

They make killer calamari, burgers, and frites which are hard to find, and non-existent in the South Bay. Drinks are great. Brunch is amazing! FINALLY THERE IS A RESTAURANT WHO KNOWS HOW TO MAKE A PROPER FRUIT BOWL. They use seasonal fruits, cut them fresh, and don't use melons. One of my pet peeves is getting a fruit bowl of melons, pineapples, and grapes that have been macerating in their own juices for days. 

The service here is super friendly, and they are also extremely tolerant of the gluten, dairy, egg intolerant, which makes me happy. You won't feel like a glutard here. :)

So far, they have been great on not cross-contaminating my food. YES!
author: Jöne P.

description:
I've been coming here with my girlfriend for years. Serpentine is impeccable. On the weekends, make a reservation ahead of time because it fills up fast.  The dishes are all classics, and their staff are friendly and unpretentious.  The restaurant itself is very visually appealing, with a classic San Francisco hipster feel.  I highly recommend the calamari, the meat board, and the chicken.  Their burger is also unstoppable.

Good cocktail menu and a diverse set of wine options.  It can be a fun date night to visit one of the neighboring wine bars before/after dinner.

I've never had a bad experience, and Serpentine will remain on the restaurant rotation as long as I remain in SF!
author: Andrew C.

description: Very cool and hipster. But I feel like just because things are hipster these days doesn't necessarily mean it's good. Looks good, yes, but the food was just boring. Especially with the 45min wait that hyped it up. I didn't get to try their cocktails but I'm glad that I didn't because it cost as much as my meal.
author: kim w.

description:
Parking was easy, which is always nice.  

The hostess could have communicated a little more; you can tell that she was avoiding eye contact so that she wouldn't have to engage in conversation.  I didn't want to shoot the shit, just wanted to know when we would have our table.  Since I got these signals from her, I didn't bother her.  She was not scrambling around busy.  Not a big deal, but room for improvement.  Maybe it was an off day.

My benedict was good.  I can't remember if it was salmon.  I think it was. It's similar to Chouquet's benedict (on a similar biscuit) but they do it better. The crispy potatoes were really good, as was the aioli I dipped them in.  My friend got the burger and I got to try it.  It was good, and what I know Serpentine for, but not among the better of SF burgers.  Definitely can skip.

I liked this place and the food, but I probably wouldn't come back because it feels like there's no air circulation here.  I wish I had some room left for Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous!
author: Erika C.

description: Everyone loves a good brunch spot. While you may consider this place as a "brunch spot" it is beyond that definition. The food is impeccably refreshing and not the boring pancakes and burger from all other places. Truly amazing. My words a will never do this place justice.
author: Jane E.

description:
I love Serpentine's laid back style, friendly service, and great quality food.

Nice cocktail options too.

I've been here for brunch a couple of times and for dinner about three times.  Their menu changes, but not often to the point where you don't lose some of your favorites (chicken dish for me). 

Generally a casual place to get reliable service and food.
author: Adrian N.

description:
My group's experience at Serpentine was good! We made a reservation for noon, but the hostess accidentally scheduled it for 12:30 -- no problem, we grabbed a quick coffee at Piccino Coffee Bar while we waited.

We ordered a wide variety of plates -- the smoked salmon benedict, the hash, the steak and eggs, etc. All were delicious. I ordered the smoked salmon benedict, and enjoyed the dish. It was a bit salty for my taste, but the eggs were poached nicely with runny yolks and the hollandaise was tasty and well-prepared. I had a bite of the steak and eggs, and absolutely loved the fried steak -- so delicious.

For drinks, I ordered a bellini that I really enjoyed and tasted my friend's bloody mary, which was delicious. I'd definitely try the bloody marys here.

Overall, the service was prompt and professional, the food was delicious with a great ambiance for brunch -- I'd definitely return here.
author: Tanya P.

description:
Serpentine surpassed expectations.  Was late to meet a friend for dinner, and they had my Hendrick's and grapefruit at the ready when I arrived. 

The food was excellent!  I had the hangar steak, piled with delicious veggies and potatoes.  She had the duck liver - something I would never eat, but it really looked delicious too!  We shared the cauliflower app, and they supplied ample bread and great service during the whole stay.  

I drove through the neighborhood this weekend and announced to my friends how I can't wait to go back. Really an incredible and pleasant meal at Serpentine. Not to be missed.

UPDATE - Feb. 2018: Had dinner after over a year away. This used to be my favorite restaurant. They did some nice remodeling, but did they get a new chef? 

The food is not nearly as impressive as it used to be, and the menu no longer has a cheese plate or a steak. The flavors are not as magical as I remember, in general. Even the dessert was not impressive. 

They charge for bread now (what tastes/looks like Hawaiian sweet rolls). They used to have more unique breads, and they were complimentary, with butter that had large grains of delicious salt on it. Seems like small complaints, but when you love something and it does a 180...I can't say I'll make a point to go here again. They're nice enough, of course. I still like the place, but disappointed in the food, which is really the point, after all.
author: Adrienne K.

description:
Wow. So many amazing things to this place:

(1) Service:
We get to the restaurant without a reservation and they manage to squeeze us in. As we're waiting for our table, one of the waitresses comes over and starts chatting with us (just being friendly :)

(2) Food
Delicious - get the scallops and the hangar steak!!

(3) Cocktails
If you're we whiskey fan (like me) start with the Acadia and then move to the Manhattan (one of the best manhattans I've had since moving from NYC)

(4) The Space
High ceilings, beautiful light coming in from sunset -- a perfect, intimate spot for a Friday night date :)
author: Arjun S.

description:
Came here a little ways back for a hot date with the Woman.

Just down the street from our current place, so +1 for location (Dogpatch FTW).

Easy parking (Dogpatch FTW x2).

Good, solid food (with a semi-fancy price value).

I do plan on coming back here eventually... just not sure when.
author: Victor C.

description:
Tucked away in the dog patch, I would've never discovered this place without the help of my friends on yelp. Awesome brunch spot that still accepts reservations with a short wait if you arrive early (before 10am) or if you don't mind bar seatings, those have a shorter wait. I came with a party of 5 on a Sunday morning ~10am and waited only 20 minutes. 

Food: delicious!!!! Way more unique than your average brunch spot and each dish is beautifully plated to make you feel extra fancy. What we ordered:
- Red Flennel Hash- tender beef briskets + roasted beets + poached egg + more delicious ingredients I cannot recall. Definitely one of my favorite breakfast items. ever.  SO good. 
- Buckwheat pancakes w fruits + whipped cream- since I would love to eat pancakes daily but probably shouldn't, this is the perfect "lighter" option if you love those fluffy flatcakes like me. Even the pancakes here are fancy.
- Dungeness crab bennie- hm the hollandaise sauce wasn't my favorite and like all crab bennies, wish there was more crab!

Decor: High ceilings with clean white walls- modern and fresh feel that's inviting.

Service: Good but I could tell they were busy and hoping we would eat faster to seat the next party. 

Parking: CONVENIENT. major bonus for any destination in the city.
author: Patricia K.

description: This place is soooo overrated! It's just down the road from me so I couldn't wait to go. We brought some out of town guests for brunch and it was not a good experience! The food was OK, biscuits sucked. The service was some of the worst I have ever experienced. It was awful. Not sure if they were just understaffed or what but because the service was so bad I do not plan on returning...
author: Mallory R.

description: Fantastic food and cocktails. I could probably eat their ribs appetizer everyday for the rest of my life and be the happiest woman in the world.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Lived up to the hype to say the least. 

Food:

Red Flannel Hash: not a big fan of beets but damn the brisket is good. even better? their crispy potatoes! eggs were poached to perfection and arugula complimented the entire dish. love love love! the levain bread is light and not too dense. 

Ruby Mimosa: downed it

Service: Pretty standard. A little bummed that the hostess told us to come back at 12:50pm, and upon arrival I saw that she seated four parties of two who signed in after us. Bad guesstimate, but it was busy and thankfully the warehouse sale was that day so we occupied our time. We were seated at a pretty awkward corner table and the seats were facing the entire dining room. Kind of uncomfortable.

Ambience: effortless and simple design, great lighting, very open. bar is crowded.

The only thing keeping me from giving this place 5 stars is the crowded waiting area and the slight snobbery -- which is unavoidable these days. I'll be back for more crispy potatoes.
author: Kristy H.

description:
Serpentine is extremely minialistic in decor (more on the industrial side), with a white-cement color-blocked interior. There was one wall of exposed brick in the "dining area". This place has no more than 10 tables that seat about 4 [at each table], and a long dining bar. Reservations are recommended (it was busy on a Tuesday night!). Everything on the menu looked pretty fabulous, but there was only so much we could order. 

The reviews - 

Marianted gaeta and castelvetrano olives: A mix of large green and small [light] aubergine olives that were perfectly salted. The green ones were a little sweet and balanced out the savory nicely. 

Shaved summer vegetable salad: This salad consisted of arugula, summer squash, radishes, fennel, torpedo onions, ricotta salata breadcrumbs and a green peppercorn vinaigrette. The salad was light and didn't look like it had any of the dressing on it... but wow! What a salad! Sweet, savory, sour, and with a little texture. The hints of breadcrumbs were pretty much awesomeness in my mouth; they were the size of rock salt granules. Perfect.

House-made potato gnocchi with wild mushrooms: When I see a menu with gnocchi or papperdelle, it's a must order for me. I haven't found the best gnocchi yet, but am en route to doing so! I have to say though, the gnocchi was pretty good. Smooth enough to want more, however not as smooth as I imagine the best gnocchi would feel. The creamy sauce wasn't too weighty as most cream sauces are. There was more of that awesome rock-salt-sized bread crumbs, lots of wild mushrooms, and some broccoli di ciccio (side note: "broccoli di ciccio is an heirloom, old-fashioned kind of broccoli. It's sweet like 'regular' broccoli, it's what they developed the giant broccoli heads from. All stems and leaves and everything can and should be eaten. Chop the whole lot and cook as you would a bag of 'convenient broccoli florets' reference") 

Would I go again? A definite yes yes yes! And next time I'll take pictures!
author: Rachel B.

description:
Came here after the Yelp Holiday Hangover 2.0 on Wednesday night.  The place was packed full on a weeknight!  Well now, that does tell me that a table here during the prime time hours are hard to get.  Luckily, we got here after 8pm so we had roughly a short wait before being seated.

The dining room and bar itself is on the small side...I counted maybe 35-40 seats and another 10 at the bar.  The place has warehouse like tall ceilings with ceiling fans for circulation so I didn't feel even remotely claustrophobic.

As for the food, we tried their pumpkin curry coconut soup, the cheese pureed potatoes, the burger, and the gnocchi.  The soup was decent although with the taste of curry in there, it was difficult to taste the pumpkin although the soup was pumpkin colored.  The pureed potatoes were a nice soft consistency...not too rich in butter to make it heavy.  The gnocchi was served very rustic style with a lot of veggies and different flavors mixed in with the pasta.  The pasta itself was soft and tasted very fresh.  I'm not sure if gnocchi is usually served in this fashion elsewhere but I have to say that I'm a fan of this dish.

I asked our server about the bread pudding and she told us that it actually was a savory dish, not a dessert.  Bummer!  A savory bread pudding wasn't what I wanted to hear but I wouldn't mind coming back at brunch here to find out!  

Lastly, I have to say that the front of house staff busted their asses working this night.  Being seated near the kitchen, I noticed that they didn't have any bussers to assist them so I saw a lot of back and forth jaunts from kitchen to dining room.  The ladies who I saw waiting tables deserved every cent earned.  

I may likely come back to try brunch as my dinner experience was great.
author: Ben H L.

description:
I have to say, brunch was much better than dinner!  I think the semi industrial yet hip setting is much better during the day, especially with the high windows and skylights.  Plus, the wait wasn't too horrible on a Saturday morning.

For breakfast, they have some more unique cocktails like the espresso/whiskey one, which my friend loved.  I loved Monice's shrine last time, and I had to get more of this during brunch.  Coffee has unlimited refills, which is nice.

Brunch items:
1. Crab egg benedict: served on a biscuit, good hollandaise, perfectly poached sphered eggs, and lots of crab meat that's well seasoned
2. Egg sandwich: get it with pork sausage, make sure it's runny.  Not amazing, but not bad.
3. Polenta and eggs: lots of soft polenta, fried egg, and pork
4. Savory bread pudding: unique, lots of vegetables, served warm in a ramekin with a side of greens. The ramekin isn't huge, but it's quite the filling dish
5. Burger: they wouldn't add the egg at dinner, but I got my sunny side up egg with brunch!  I also added gruyere, and it's topped with lots of pickles and pickled onions.  Definitely get fries instead of a salad.. they're thin, seasoned well, crispy

I've always been a big fan of brunch, and Serpentine did not disappoint.  I like the variety on the brunch menu, and they have lots of creative options.  Bonus: the dogpatch is always easy to park in!
author: Marilyn H.

description:
Occasion: Brunch with Linda 

What I had: Salmon eggs benedict 

Food: The salmon eggs benedict included: two poached eggs, hollandaise sauce, arugula, fried capers & lemon, and fines herbs, all on buttermilk biscuits. Loved the fried capers as a garnish, and the hollandaise sauce wasn't too heavy! The crispy potatoes on the side were also amazing. Probably the best breakfast potatoes I've had in the Bay. 

Service: Nothing in particular about the service. Our server was friendly, and our food came out promptly. 

Venue: Free parking on the street and right behind the restaurant is a HUGE plus. The restaurant itself is clean (lots of white wood, a bar, and metal chairs) and has high ceilings and plenty of light. 

Overall Impression: BRUNCH. RESERVATIONS. I'll say it again: BRUNCH. RESERVATIONS. You can expect a 20 minute minimum wait at any of your standard brunch places in SF, but at Serpentine? Plan ahead and you'll be rewarded with zero parking time and zero wait time. Fantastic food and no hassle make this brunch place a 5-star in my book.
author: Rachael K.

description:
Brunch by far has to be my favorie dining occasion.  It always signifies that you are in your weekend mode and its proof that you have an active social life (brunch should not be done alone). It can also set the tone for the rest of the day.

Last Saturday we were able to hit up Serpentine.  The building was great, and fit in with the rest of the dogpatch, a bit industial with a touch of  modern chic.  From the outside there didn't seem to be that many windows, but inside it was well lit with natural lighting.  The windows must have been higher up on the walls.  

The vibe was definitely electric with the place being busy in stark contrast the quiteness of third street.  It was almost liked I walked into a secret place.  Everything on the menu seemed delicious, but we went with the Baked Eggs, Buckwheat Pancakes, The Red Flannel Hash, and a side of bacon for me of course (Neither Steph nor Jenn touched it...hopefully not out fear that I would slap their hands...haha).  

All the food was prepared well with delicate flavors.  Each element of each dish stood out on its own.  A dash of salt made it perfect.  The Baked eggs were okay, not the greatest dish ever.  The Red Flannael Hash with the corn beef and potatoes swimming in a crimson tide of beet juice was on point.  The highlight for me (other than the bacon, which is always a highlight anywhere) were the Buckwheat Pancakes...light and fluffy and covered with Candied Walnuts and Strawberries with some Creme Fraiche!  Amazying!  

This was a great place for brunch...I need to hang out in the Dogpatch more!
author: Veasna H.

description:
4 other girl friend's and I came here for a birthday dinner on a Monday evening. As we entered, there was no one to great us at the host stand so we stood awaiting further instructions. The host came over after a few minutes and found our res and took us to our table which a booth at the far end of the restaurant. There was a crowded bar and not too many tables. I liked our table in that it was pretty secluded with walls on all 3 sides. 

The server was nice but I wasn't sure if she was a tad passive aggressive. I'll assume it was just me because the service was great overall. 

My friend ordered oysters and out came 2 of the smallest oysters we have ever seen. Then came our Meat Board appetizer. The "board" was smaller than my kindle. However, when our entrees arrived we were pleased to find that they were normal sized entrees and not minis like our appetizers. 

Many people on yelp raved about the burger so I got that with fries. The burger was cooked medium and it tasted superb! My other friend ordered the gnocchi which I tried and thought was ok. I thought it tasted a bit bland. 

We had told the server that it was our friend's birthday, and she brought out a small birthday dessert for her with a candle but she charged us for it. It would have been a nice gesture if she didn't..! 

Overall the ambiance was pretty casual with dimmed lights. The bill for 5 came up to $160. This included a salad, meat board, oysters, 5 entrees, and 2 desserts. Not too bad but not sure if I'd come back.
author: Runa T.

description:
When I jumped on this zero/reduced beef kick, one of the first things I started to crave for was a burger.  Now, I'm not talking about just any burger you can get at a fast food joint.  No, I'm talking about a real, legit burger that's been all gussied up and done right.  The type that just oozes quality when you bite into it, and filled with fresh condiments.  The kind of burger where you know the cow from whence the meat came died for all the right reasons, with cheese that doesn't feel like its been made into a sheet and squared.  No, I'm talking about a real burger....am I making you hungry yet?

Ended up coming out to Serpentine with a few of my buddies so that we could specifically try their offering of said burger.  After one of them found it listed on the 7x7 list of best burgers in the city, we obviously had to put them to the test.  And although briefly perusing the menu revealed a few other dishes that seemed rather appealing, we were all pretty set on what we were going to get. - four Prather Ranch burgers, beers, and their meat board starter.

The meat board appetizer included five varieties of charcuterie (duck prosciutto, duck liver mousse, speck, piccante salami, and spicy coppa) with some pickled green beans, mustard, and grilled levain toast.  Overall, it was pretty decent and tasted about how you would expect...hard to mess it up though.  However, I liked that the duck prosciutto was on there for something a little different.
