Oddly enough, my favorite part of the order was actually their grilled levain toast...some of the best bread I've had!

As for the burger, I don't know how it compares overall to the other entries on the 7x7 list (Spruce and Marlowe come to mind), but I liked what I had.  Served on an ACME roll with arugula, pickled onions, homemade bread 'n' butter pickles, a slice of gruyere I added and fries, it was definitely a hefty plate of food.  The patty was pretty thick and juicy, and I was impressed it was cooked just as I ordered.  Though it was seasoned well, it was actually the gruyere and pickled onions that brought the best out of the burger for me.  The gruyere is a nice change from the usual cheeses you get, and that twang from the onions was a perfect complement.  A little messy from the juice/oil, but it was delicious.  

As for Serpentine itself, it was pretty hard to find something to complain about.  Our waitress was awesome, really friendly, and made some great beer suggestions when it came time to order. The restaurant itself has a unique personality top - a nicer, casual sort of feel (if that makes sense to you like how it does to me, then you get a gold star), but in a warehouse sort of environment (high ceilings, wide open, commercial type of space).  Definitely plus points for both.

I knew that at some point during this pledge, I was likely to breakdown and have myself some beef.  While I've been disciplined for the most part, one can only stave off those cravings for so long.  I'm just glad that Serpentine was about to help me cave the right way.  After all, if you're going to get caught stealing a car, you don't want to get caught breaking into some janky ride, do you?  Four stars for now until I have something comparable to compare it to, but I definitely want to come back to give brunch a shot!
author: Mike L.

description: Went for dinner. MUST HAVE RESERVATION! Cramped seating. Slow service. Good food. Small portions. Might check out brunch, will not return for dinner.
author: Amanda M.

description:
I really like this place. Celebrating my honey's birthday, we started off with cocktails at the bar as we waited for our table.  The Smokey Bandit cocktail was the perfect way to start the evening.  The drink was a little sweet with a bit of smoke.   

Crowning my honey with a red sequin Santa hat (I couldn't find a king's crown), we all wore similar Santa hat in different colors (silver, gold, and green). The wait staff loved us and said we were the most festive bunch that evening. On to the meal. 

We shared the meat plate, cheese plate and the sweetbread dish. The meat plate consisted of 4 different cured meats and liver pate. The liver pate was just divine.  The sweetbreads were fried to a nice crisp. My honey said it tasted like KFC, which is a good complement.   The cheese plate consisted of a  substitute cheese of goat and  cows milk, as they ran out of the original one. It still was a slight pungent and salty, which I liked.  

We all ordered the steak dish for our entree. Mines rare (of course) was deeeeeeeeeeeeelicious!   I finished that meat as if there was no tomorrow.   Seared on the outside, raw in the middle....as the French would say, "Bleu".   

Dessert, we shared the ginger cookie sandwich, chocolate cake and bread pudding. All the desserts were delicious, but it was the ice cream that accompanied the desserts that won me over. Mr. and Mrs Miscellaneous, you've won another person.

The staff was very friendly and accommodating for the birthday evening. High 5's to them all as they made the night Special and Great.  You Rock!
author: Marck N.

description:
4.5 stars, actually. 
I ordered a ginger beer coctail and the bartendress had said that they ran out of ginger so the drink had only about 1/2 its usualy potency so it was on the house. OK, I'll take that. The drink was still good i thought.

Appetizers were tasty. My fave was the sweet breads. They actually deep fried it in a spiced batter, so it was like a flavorful fried chicken outer coating and soft warm goodness on the inside. 

For the entree I had the hangar steak done medium rare.  It was so delicious. 

Service was very friendly .
author: Kenson K.

description: Great brunch place. The restaurant itself is quite unassuming from the outside, but the interior is really nice. We sat at the bar because most tables were reserved, but had a great experience. The buckwheat pancakes are excellent as is the beet/poached egg/hash combo. I also have to say that the bartender gave us amazing service - can't wait to go back!
author: Taz M.

description: Came in for the very first time during lunch--made a handy reservation on yelp. Really liked the interior and overall atmosphere. Ordered the garlic marinated chicken sandwich, which comes with the choice of fries or greens. Waitress immediately recommended the fries as we were deciding and she was right when she said they were good. The sandwich itself was filling and full of flavor. Friendly service, definitely contributed to the good experience. Would absolutely go again, but next time for breakfast!
author: Julian G.

description:
Definitely a great brunch spot.  The wait wasn't too long, about 15 minutes.  Service is mediocre, depending on how busy it is.

I generally rate breakfast spots on their eggs, bacon and pancakes.  I always say, if you're not good at cooking eggs and bacon, then you have no business in this business.  Needless to say, they do a divine job with those two ingredients.  Now pancakes are another story.  I'm serious about my pancakes.  There is no middle of the road for me, it's either delicious or not.  Their buckwheat pancakes are yummy!  mmmm

Now that we got through the basics, I would definitely come again to try the other scrumptious sounding menu items.
author: Delilah B.

description:
Finally made the trek to Dog Patch for this place.  It's definitely retaining the decor of the area, industrial, unfinished but yet warm with a touch of trendy.  

The service was great even though our friends were late and we had to give up our table and wait for another one. The hostess was very nice about it.  The bar kept us entertained and so did the great drinks.

The food was great, the lamb cheeks were delicious and the sauce was something I wanted to lick off the plate, OK and with the help of the bread I did.  

The olives were salty and I hate pitted olives, please replace them with better ones.

The entrees we had the steak and gnocchi.  The steak was good, well flavored, nice sides, but a bit chewy for my taste.  The gnocchi were amazing, the kind of amazing I would want to come back for.  They were light, tender, everything in that dish was scrumptious, too bad I was sharing because I wanted to eat them all.

The least favorite part was desserts, nothing even looked good to order so we skipped and went somewhere else.  

Not sure if this is the norm, but we didn't have to pay a corkage fee!  So not only was our dinner, great it was cheap.
author: Inga W.

description:
Helen T (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=elS2lEZV63V7uypJ7Z5cOg) and i were craving something MEATY! so i was looking at the 7x7 article on the best burgers in SF and serpentine was featured in it so we decided to come here. along with some other friends we ordered the calamari with chick pea appetizer, meat platter, and we all got an order of the prather ranch burger with fries.

the calamari with chick pea was a little different since i never had it with chick pea before but it was nothing special.

the meat platter was a lot smaller than i expected but i liked almost everything, except the pickled beans and something that looked like olives but was not good to me at all. the meat platter came with duck prosciutto, duck liver mousse, speck, piccante salami, and spicy coppa and small grilled toast. to a couple of my other friends the meats were too salty but i love salty cured meats. my favorite would be the duck proscuitto and duck liver mousse over the grilled toast.

i got my burger without cheese because last time i ordered one of these gourmet burgers with cheese, the cheese completely masked the taste however this time i wish i had gotten cheese. the burger was very juicy (my other friends said it was too greasy but even though i had a lot of juice come out of my burger when i cut it in half, it didnt feel oily or anything) its a fairly big patty and came with only a small amount of arugula and pickled onions. 

the fries here were delicious! i don't really know how to describe just how delicious they were but probably one of the best fries ive ever hard. it was so light and crunchy and we had different dipping sauces (organic ketchup, garlic aioli -my favorite- and mustard)

overall it was a nice dining experience. it was a very relaxed atmosphere and our server was really friendly and nothing was too overly priced.
author: Katherine C.

description: Both the weekday lunch and weekend brunch were awesome. The menu features delicious items without being too extensive. It has a simplistic and trendy atmosphere with good lighting during the day. The burger was ridiculously juicy and cooked perfectly. Red Flannel Hash had components that went well together. And the complimentary bread is fluffy with a great crust.
author: Tim G.

description:
Well, considering it's clear on the other side of town for me, this place might as well be out of state.  However, I was very motivated to meet my girlfriends here for brunch, so, I made the hour-long bus ride trek.  It was my first time here and I have to say, the menu was inspiring.  I always like a menu where I have to narrow it down to decide my order.  

My friend who had been there before said that all her friends had raved about the bread pudding, so, I went for that.  Glad I did.  When I hear "bread pudding" I usually think of something sweet and dessert like, but this was more on the savory side.  It has onions and peppers in it, but it's not spicy.  I was also surprised by how reasonably priced everything was.  Isn't that refreshing?!  We all enjoyed our dishes as evidenced by our clean plates.
author: Chloe M.

description:
Hi yelpers,
I used to come to Serpentine for lunch a lot with my coworkers, but have never been for dinner. And finally, we came here with another couple. 
We ordered meat platter, which I personally didn't like; but at least they give hot bread with this dish. Hot bread makes the whole fish delicious. 
Also we ordered pickled vegetables as an appetizer. I personally think they should bring that dish at the same time with other appetizers, because eating pickled vegetables alone might make your stomach hurt (vinegar is acidic). But I absolutely loved their pickled vegetables. 
We also ordered nectarine and prosciutto salad that doesn't look like salad at all. I really enjoyed that salad. They also include sliced mushrooms that give an amazing touch to it. I highly recommend. 
And for our main we all got hanger steak. The steak was delicious. Although I only eat medium rare steak, I ordered medium well, and absolutely loved it. 
I do recommend to go there, it may become one of your favorite spots in the city.
author: Jenna F.

description:
What a cute spot!  This restaurant really adds to the neighborhood.  The outside is modern, the inside is warm and inviting, the food is TERRIFIC!  I came here with my cousins and was pleasantly surprised.

I ordered the fried egg sandwich and it was delicious!  Runny egg on a english muffin with arugula, green tomatoes and added bacon.  The combination of tastes were very refreshing and all of the ingredients were well prepared.  It comes with a side of potatoes that look like fried potatoes but taste as great as tater tots...YUM. 

They have a full page menu for brunch and is made for the meat lover.  And if you choose something as I did that did not have meat, they allow you to add on sides with all the bacon, sausage, steak fixings that you wish.  I left very happily full. 

What I appreciate about this spot is that brunch places usually don't allow reservations, but they allow Open Table reservations all day long and seat you right away.  There was a line outside and they still allow reservations!  No fuss and the staff is very hospitable.

Next time I want to try their buckwheat pancakes.  They look great!
author: Sandy L.

description:
Nice fashionable space, but the food didn't live up to my (admittedly very high) expectations. The waitress was really nice and accommodating, which I appreciated. I ordered the savory bread pudding, as I rarely resist bread pudding, and this sounded like a combination of all my favorite things - tomatoes, gruyere, peppers, bread pudding itself... I was so entranced I didn't stop to think about what they'd be like all together. 

The cherry tomatoes were amazing - incredibly sweet and some of the best I've ever had. But they were actually TOO sweet for this dish - I would have preferred other, less sweet tomatoes. This was a problem, as the bread pudding overall was not nearly savory enough for me - I would have liked a sharper, more pronounced cheese. And it seemed pretty eggy to me, which I wasn't expecting (although that's an inherent dividing issue with bread pudding). I wouldn't get it again. I did like the lightly dressed side salad though - that was nicely done, and I'd think about getting a salad in the future. I would definitely go back to try something else, like the burger or pork sandwich, and would try the cocktails.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Great brunch spot for when you don't feel like waiting for hours. They take reservations but don't fret if you don't have one. We walked in today and were seated immediately. 

The buckwheat pancakes were yummy! Strange combination of fruit (banana, pineapple, pomegranate, persimmon) but it worked!  The spicy potatoes were great as well. 

-1 for the 'fresh' orange juice. I saw the bartender pouring it out of a plastic gallon container. The waiter claimed it was fresh squeezed but just done beforehand. Regardless, it just didn't taste great (I'm spoiled, I know)

Anyway, the service was warm and friendly and the food was good. I'd definitely go back.
author: Gowri R.

description:
Perfect hipster place to enjoy brunch on a rainy/cloudy day, esp. when you know you're going to enjoy Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous after a hearty meal.

On that note: I was here with friends on a Sunday after church service; we wanted brunch and ice cream (on a chilly day during the break of the rain) so Yelp suggested we come to Serpentine.  Perfect casual place for yummy, hearty food!  I had the "Eggs-meat-potatoes-bread" with 2 slices of crispy neuske's bacon.  Simply named item that had a generous portion of nicely seasoned, crispy, cubed potatoes, 2 slices of grilled levain (a traditional French bread) that comes with homemade jam, and 1 sunny side-up egg.  Too bad I didn't order seconds because the potatoes were THAT GOOD!  I wanted more!  Dipping the potatoes in ketchup makes it even better!  The bacon came out well also; not too oily nor overcooked at all; both bacon strips were seasoned well and had a crispy finish, just like it's supposed to be!  The eggs were typical, nothing too special about sunny side-up.  

My little quibble here is that the bread, I felt, may have been overly grilled.  Perhaps that's how it's supposed to be, but I had a hard time biting on my bread; I prefer my bread toasted or either plain (not toasted).  I find that much easier to enjoy, having less chances of wasting delicious food.  The jam, while I applaud & appreciate their efforts for it being homemade, and at least I tried it, I prefer a fruit jam over a floral-flavored jam.  There's something about floral jam that seems a bit strong for my taste; perhaps it was also my first time trying an unfamiliar jam flavor (I guess that's not a quibble, more a personal opinion).  

The amount of food hit the spot; enough room to enjoy ice cream (then again, there's always room for dessert) and keep us energized for our short hike up Corona Heights.  I hear the burger is popular...will definitely try on my return trip!
author: Jessica S.

description: Excellent Service - International Staff - Awesome Chef. OMStars.... Fusion Food - really do it......The City is alive with GEMS.
author: Shawne F.

description:
Always delicious.

I go here for brunch and for dinner after Tuesday night trivia at Yield Wine Bar across the street. It's delicous, service is great, and the quality to price thing here is pretty solid.

They have a great menu of cocktails, and their food has always been stellar. I love this place.
author: Jeff M.

description: We have been there many times and it was always good: the food and wine etc.. The service is excellent, people are super nice. It is definitely one of the best places in the city. The only flaw I noticed that some of their dishes are too salty.
author: Sophie N.

description:
. 
                    Sleek Industrial Space
               AND 
          Best 
     Peach 
 Bellini 
     Ever 
          Imbibed
                  AND
                       Savory  
                             Breakfast  
                                 Bread  
                                     Pudding  
                                          With Ham  
                                               Cheese 
                 Spinach and Tomatoes
                AND
        Perfectly 
     Cooked 
 Crispy 
  Potatoes
       AND
              Unbelievable
                    Warm Peach
                        Upside Down 
                               Cake with 
                                       Vanilla  
   My New                           Ice Cream 
           Favorite                      AKA
                         Brunch Spot
author: Amy C.

description: Great atmosphere, very good service and food. One if the best restaurants in dogpatch
author: Cricri B.

description: What do people like about this place? The food tastes bad. The hosts are rude... Orange juice tastes like it came from a machine...
author: Chris N.

description:
Although it's not centrally located, it is on the metro T 3rd line, and there is plenty of parking in the small, but growing Dogpatch neighborhood. The food was delicious and they have alternative versions of some yummy brunch standards. The Red Fennel Hash is as good as it sounds: beef brisket  - crispy potatoes - roasted beets - arugula horseradish créme fraiche - poached eggs - rosemary salt -
grilled levain, a value at $12. The country fried steak, and polenta eggs were also tasty and good values. The restaurant is airy, well lit and roomy, with exposed brick and high ceilings. I have been here three times, and have yet to wait for a table for two.
author: Juan F.

description:
I've only been here for brunch on a Sunday afternoon. The wait wasn't too bad. Give or take 30 minutes, but your best bet is to make a reservation. Why wait?

Anyways, I had the poached egg w/ crab! So goooood! It was loaded with a lot of crab meat and well worth it!  Add a bottle of ginger beer to the meal and I was well satisfied! YUM!
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
Brunch.  The food is five stars, for sure.  The baked eggs dish (which I've had twice) could not be more delicious.  Yummy benedict.  Perfect potatoes.  The atmosphere?  Lovely.  The service?  Well, at first she was friendly when we sat down, even when we didn't know right away what we wanted.  My friend and I were catching up after not seeing each other for a while, so we were chatting.  However, the mood turned chilly when we were mostly done but not letting her clear our plates right away because we were still nibbling.  Finally she said, "Look.  The host wanted me to give you until 11 and now it's 11:30, so we really need your table.  People are waiting."

I understand that we took a little longer than perhaps you were predicting.   Maybe our table was one you had reserved for the people who made reservations.  I think waiting for brunch at a great restaurant in SF is not that unusual.  But even if you blame it on the host, it feels bad to be asked to leave, so you could be a bit more diplomatic about it.  Tell me about how cold it is outside, how many people are waiting, how badly you feel about telling us to leave, but don't tell me that you've been generous with our time allowance and your patience is up.

When we walked out, we saw 2 bigger groups and only 1 couple.  That twosome must have been destined for our table, since it was a tiny corner table for 2.  I hope they had a reservation, because otherwise I can't imagine why we were ushered out.  The food is great, but I wouldn't come back unless I knew for sure we'd eat fast.  And that's not why I go out for brunch.
author: Samantha G.

description:
Excellent place for brunch. We also had dinner here and were happy with it. The service from the bartenders is great and their cocktails are on point. 

For me it misses a star due to a couple reasons. 1. The acoustics of the place. It's a bit noisy when it gets crowded. Too many hard surfaces. 2. I wished the portions of the dinner items were a bit larger for the price, or included sides to help fill the belly. I left a bit hungry.

Another BIG plus, they take reservations for brunch.
author: Brian C.

description:
Came here with a friend around 1 on a nice Saturday.  NO WAIT!  Woohoo.  Took a couple of minutes before someone approached us, but when someone did, they were friendly.  

Both of us ordered the crab benedict with a nice drink.  The benedict was AWESOME and the potatoes it came with were the best side potatoes I've had.  They were crispy and perfectly seasoned and the drinks were refreshing.  I got a mimosa and friend got a blood orange something..  We both left content and I wasn't hungry til around 8.

I've been having dreams of this crab benedict ever since....
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
New American is quickly becoming my new favorite food genre. It's fine, fresh, creative, more edgy than the norm,  well-made and gourmet.  Serpentine does all of this well.

We tried and recommend: fresh made gnocci, fava beans, pea and garlic soup, a cheese plate, and paired it all with Campari and orange.
author: Amber K.

description:
Serpentine is one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  Their meat board, anchovy flies (seasonal), blue cheese burger are juicy and awesome.  The burger used to come with heirloom tomatoes which were one of the highlight of the burger, but anymore ):  Their cocktails are good, too!

If you are ok with sitting at the bar and waiting for 15 min.,  you don't need to make a reservation.
author: Suki K.

description:
I went with a group of six and it took them about 25 minutes past our reservation time to seat us, other than that, this place was nice for a group. I'd say it's not special enough for an impressive date night.

For me the food stayed in the "good" range with nothing that wowed or tanked. I love burgers and Brussels sprouts like most people, but do we really need another passable version of them (but I'm a Nueske's loyalist so it's always nice to see some WI bacon on the menu)? Serpentine is a restaurant that seems to have a consistent output with a small menu and reasonable prices, perfect for a Thursday night.

I would come back, however, for the bar. It's off to the side of the main dining area and the cocktails were great.
author: Brandon K.

description:
Came here for brunch on a recommendation and I think I'm hooked. We shared the Buckwheat Pancakes and I had the Red Flannel Hash. 

I really enjoyed the pancakes; don't let the healthy name fool you as they hold their own to their more famous buttermilk siblings. One pancake is enough to fill you up. It comes with fresh fruit, not too sweet syrup, and candied walnuts.

The hash was delicious and I pretty much cleaned my entire plate. The brisket was flavorful, the eggs were runny, and the potatoes were crisped up. A great combination for a nice brunch.

Overall thoughts: Will return and recommend. It gets busy so I will need to plan ahead. It also doesn't hurt that Mr & Mrs Miscellaneous is across the street. ;)
author: Stephanie K.

description: We ate there on 8/20 for my birthday.  The staff was friendly and attentive.  We had the shaved veggie salad, which was awesome, 5 stars.  We had the chicken livers, which were the best I've ever had.  I didn't care so much for the salad that accompanied the livers.  The calamari was good, not great.  We followed that with the duck which was outstanding.  We then ordered the lemon cake (only because my companion insisted that we get something with a candle on it) and it was to die for.  I was a bit dissatisfied that Serpentine didn't comp the dessert, which is the norm in most restaurants when it's a birthday. And I loved the fact that they had a separate bathroom for women.
author: Jan F.

description:
this place was an absoulte HOME RUN - Henry and his team knocked this meal out of the park; from the food to the vibe to the service to the smiles - this place has it ALL; wow - I wish I could give 6 stars: 

FOOD: 

general comment - everything here has some swag; a new twist on even the most simple dishes - like the olive oil that is served w/ their bread - its made in house from olives they soak in house marinade; to die for - this was something small, but all the small things add up

apps tried - oysters; briny, large & delish... shaved veggie salad - so fresh, so clean, large portion... brussel sprouts - so overplayed, so offered everywhere, so different and awesome here - served in a cast iron skillet, partially deconstructed, amazing charred flavor but not burnt at all

mains tried - rabbit 3 ways - bomb.com, and Im not even a huge rabbit fan, generous portion of braised/roasted/confit'd meat, perfectly cooked veggies, sauce to die for... scallops were amazing, eaten in 2 seconds (small portion) by my aunt, who then helped with the giant portion of.... chicken ordered by wifey - so moist, so tender, perfectly crisped skin; wing was heavenly crunchy, breast was juicy, veggies and sauce were uniquely delish.... chicken liver salad - so flavorful and fun for friggin livers - if you can make livers taste like that, you're playing  ball... steak - my uncle likes his way more well done than me, but he smashed on that meat like ive never seen him eat before; you could tell he was stoked

deserts tried - strawberry tartlet type thing; I couldnt eat it (lactose intolls), but the table loved it; OG mom is a french desert maker herself, and she was floored by the creativity and flavor of this (large) treat; they deconstructed the ice cream sandwich for us (read: service) - so I got the vegan macaroon cookies and the table got the ice cream w/ homemade caramel; ice cream got rave reviews, cookies were so uniquely made - fluffy crunchiness - hard to explain how bomb

SERVICE: 

we changed our reservation time - moved it back 30 minutes; Henry called to confirm; then we showed up 20 minutes early to a packed house, but were seated immediately; uncle was late so we sat for 20 minutes - they were cool w/ it - no pressure to order - just brought bread and water (we werent drinking); wife still wasnt there so we ordered (including for her); gave them an update re her arrival - apps came while she was away - 25 minutes later food is served, she walks in 1 minute later - they had it dialed in; no pressure for deserts/coffee/to pay/leave - just amazing service w/ a smile - great teamwork and understanding of needs

VIBE: 

dates, families, celebrations, groups at the bar - everyone was having fun; large space where you'd think you couldnt hear yourself think, let alone hear across the table, yet it was remarkably easy to talk and take in the scene

BOOM - and bill was only, w/ tax & +20% tip, 48 person - WOW

HIT THIS PLACE UP YALL
author: Mark B.

description: By far the best salmon eggs benedict I've had so far eating brunches. It was complex and light. There were baked capers, lemon tempura, tomatoes, peppers, ...
author: Thomas C.

description:
I was really excited to try this place after reading the reviews. Though this restaurant is super chic, sadly the food didn't blow me away. We ordered two vegetarian dishes - the shaved vegetable salad and the gnocchi entree.

Pros:
* Great ambiance
* Friendly servers
* Unique dishes - seemed to have a lot of interesting non vegetarian options (which we didn't try)

Cons:
* Vegetable salad was a little too heavy on the citrus for my taste. Though the toasted hazelnuts were a great addition, the strong lemon flavor combined with the bitterness of the arugula was not to my liking.
*The gnocchi was very light which was refreshing and I liked that it was coated with breadcrumbs. Unfortunately, yet again, the citrus flavor of the sauce overpowered the dish. (We also substituted greens for the mushrooms which may have contributed to the problem). The sauce was lacking in flavor and was not as full-bodied as I would've liked to accompany the relatively bland gnocchi.

Though I was not impressed with dinner (mainly due to the lack of vegetarian options), I would come back to Serpentine for brunch which is what most of the reviews talked about.
author: Vaibhavi U.

description:
Was here last night... Food was very good, drinks were great. David at the bar treated us well. 

Our server was very helpful, if ever in doubt as to what to get ask your server.

I'll definitely be back.

I usually don't bookmark places on yelp, but this one is a must
author: Samuel M.

description: Always so tasty. I live and work nearby, and I can go there for dinner and lunch and dinner again. The menu is different every day, but they have some great staple salads (stone fruit is one of my favorite), burger is super good. In the evenings once I had their five spices ribs and omg it was incredible. The high ceiling also makes the environment feel good. Book ahead for weekend lunch.
author: Ting C.

description:
They are right at the corner of 3rd Street near my work place.  I passed by so many times, and I finally have an excuse to check them out for my friend's birthday lunch.
Food is great and service is fantastic.  Servers are attentive and friendly.  Price is reasonable and the dining area is clean and seat comfortably.
Their menu will routinely change, so you will never stuck at the same old menu.
author: Steve L.

description:
I'm a fan for sure!!!
Where do I start, great staff, great bartenders, great food and drink! 
Consistent every time, always warm, and, welcoming. 
Chef Deepak Kaul and his crew do a great job with the menu. I have not had a bad meal here since he (Deepak) took over awhile ago. 
Keep up the good work!!
author: WildBill C.

description:
Damn you lo-carb diets!

On Sunday, 10/10, my friend and I came to Serpentine for a late brunch at 1 PM. We walked in without reservations and were able to snag the last open table. Serpentine is a tiny restaurant (table seating for 25 or so, communal table for 8 and bar seating) and I can imagine it getting busy during peak and dinner time, so it would probably be wise to make reservations. 

FOOD:
I have to note that Serpentine's brunch menu is NOT diet-friendly; well if you're on a lo-carb diet that is. I spent nearly 10 minutes trying to figure out what I can get and what I can substitute out to make it somewhat healthy. Although the savory bread pudding with ham, gruyere and caramelized onions sounded divine, I didn't want to regret it later so opted for the Baked Eggs.

Baked Eggs - Black beans, White corn, Squash, and Guacamole ($11.50): I opted out of the corn bread and added a side of house made sausage ($3.50). YUMMY! The veggie mixture was topped w/ two baked eggs and a tablespoon of guac. The veggies were tender, yet had a bite to it. The white corn was sweet and crisp and the guac was savory and buttery (I wish there was more though). However, the eggs were overcooked as the yolks almost solidified. 

It's a good thing I ordered a side of sausage, otherwise I would have still been hungry. The sausage was very flavorful, it was salty and smokey w/ a slight sweetness. You can taste the fennel seeds, which gave it a mild liquorice flavor.

Although my food came out fine despite the overcooked eggs, I have to note that my friend's order had an EYELASH on the poached egg! We didn't send the order back and instead the affected portion was just cut away. Talk about unappetizing... 

SERVICE:
Although our waitress was friendly, she was aloof. After taking our order and bringing our food, she never checked in with us. She also messed up the order after repeating it to her several times. My friend specifically told her no biscuit and no potatoes on the Crab Benedict. Our waitress tried to convey that it comes with a biscuit and my friend had to repeat again, no biscuit and no potatoes. Yet, the Crab Benedict came with the starches. Not a big deal I know, but there's nothing worse than wasted food. *sigh*

I had requested no corn bread and a side order of the house made sausage. 5 minutes later, our waitress said she can only substitute the corn bread for sausage for a fee. Ummm...I ordered a side of the sausage full knowingly that I will be charged and never asked for an equal substitution.

AMBIANCE/DÉCOR:
Serpentine looks a lot bigger from the outside than it really is (45-50 or so capacity). I love the simplistic industrial design; rustic hardwood floors, ivory walls and ceilings, mirrors throughout and vases of ivory calla lilies. 

PARKING:
Very easy street parking which was the main reason why we went here.

Serpentine's food is 4-Star worthy, however because of the eyelash incident and the mediocre service I have to drop it down to 3-Stars. However, I would definitely return for that Savory Bread Pudding one of the days...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Serpentine... 

I was excited for this place after having multiple people mention it.  So when it was dinner time and my boyfriend suggested Serpentine, I was down! 

Needless to say it was just an okay experience when factoring service, quality of food and pricing.  Serpentine is comparable to Marlowe in price and type of food, except I'd hands down choose Marlowe.  

The service at Serpentine was slow, like really slow.  We walked in and got seated at the bar.  After some time we ordered out drinks, which were great cocktails, nice & strong!  Then we had some cold bread that was alright -- nothing special.  

For the food we ordered scallops as appetizer, hanger steak and of course the burger (I believe this is one of the entrees they were really known for). 

Scallops were okay.  Appetizer sizing comes with three pieces. The sauce that it came with could have been better. 

Hanger steak @ medium rare again was just okay. Nothing special and not anything that I wowed about.  The flavoring on the steak wasn't great and I guess I didn't realyl taste much to it except for the steak itself. It came with some peas and vegtables that were decent, but I would have preferred fries or mash potatoes to go alongside it. 

The burger my boyfriend liked, but in my honest opinion, I just wouldn't pay that much for a burger. The fries were good though. 

Overall, the service was just lacking. I know they are busy, but it's not like this is a fast food joint.  I've sat at bar for Marlowe as well as being seated at a table and the service has both times been impeccable and personal.  Our bill was about $90 with tip, which is close to the same as Marlowe, so I'd say go there if you can instead of Serpentine. 

Maybe next time I just need to come for brunch as it seems there are a lot of reviews for this as well.
author: Suzie B.

description:
There is a great buzz in Serpentine for dinner on a weekend evening. The decor is urban and modern and gives a good ambiance.

As far as the appetizers go, the meat board was very good. The duck prosciutto was an unusual twist. The calamari, however, were overly oily and a bit soggy. For entrees the roasted chicken was well cooked and and went well with the mushrooms. The gnocchi with mushrooms was a little disappointing. The mushrooms in it were tasty but there was far too much herbage in the dish. Also the gnocchi themselves were not great.

All in all, not bad but nothing really stood out.
author: Michael S.

description:
I'm not much of a "New" American food kind of person.  I'm definitely more biased towards ethnic foods like Indian, Mexican and Asian, so when American food can impress me, it's gotta be good.  Serpentine did just that for me for brunch this past Sunday.

Fried Egg Sandwich (Leadbetter's english muffin, fried egg, arugula, dill aioli, crispy potatoes) - The texture whore in me was jumping for joy!  My anticipation was climbing as I assembled the beautiful layers.  The english muffin was toasty and crusty.  The fried egg was fried just enough so that the yolk was still a bit yolky without the risk of exploding everywhere upon the bite.  The arugula was fresh and crunchy.  The dill aioli was singing my name.  One Bite....... HEAVEN.  Also, they were not kidding when they said CRISPY potatoes.  These golden nuggets were crispy and crunchy.  

Country Fried Steak & Eggs (flat iron steak, scrambled eggs, biscuit & gravy, crispy potatoes, arugula) - The preparation for this country fried steak was unique.  It had a tempura-like batter making the fried steak almost "light" and airy.  It was delightfully (yes, I said delightful!) tasty - perfectly seasoned and crunchy.

The biscuit - I have to talk about the biscuit by itself.  Something in my gut told me to order a biscuit on the side and that something was sooooooo right!  This biscuit was fluffy and dense at the same time?  How is that even possible?!  The grill marks on the outside left a nice chewy texture and the fluffy and dense inside was mouthfuls of carb heaven.  Could it get any better?  Yes, I added on a pat... okay not a pat... I slathered on some butter.  It was perfect.

Conclusion:  Brunch was fantastic!  Can I have some more?
author: Michelle W.

description:
Good but not great. I wanted to like Serpentine more than I did. 

Nice space. Industrial-esque with high ceilings, exposed brick - the usual.  Terrific chandeliers. Nondescript bar that screams for touches that would make it visually appealing. 

Nice banquettes paired with not-so-nice chairs.  Horrible barstools.  The place reads - and feels like - " trendy" ,  but not in a well thought out way.  Bad "art" badly hung.  Nice floors, ugly blonde wood here and there that does not work in the space. 

Unfortunately this transfers to the cocktail menu. First impression: drinks that were formulated because their ingredients look cool on paper.  Impression on the cocktails (two different) I had: lacking skill on their formulation. (I had Modern Bond and Stalker.)  Okay - but not thought out well, lacking, not well balanced. 

Excellent beer list. 

Excellent service at the bar and, from what I observed, on the floor as well. 

Pedestrian bread served with decent enough butter. The squash soup I had was wonderfully textured, good flavor (that would have benefitted from a pinch more salt), but marred by large nuts that didn't work. (A fine dusting of finely minced toasted nuts would have.)

Delicious burger on a very good roll, arugula (which I love - but it wilts in the heat of the burger and loses crunch, not such a good thing). Excellent fries. Ketchup, good mustard and a superb aioli served on the side. 

I will likely go back and try the food again. But I don't feel any rush to do so. Unfortunately.
author: Kevin K.

description:
This review is for brunch ONLY. 

I have been to Serpentine in the past many times for dinner and it has been fantastic. Creative, delicious dishes in a great atmosphere and fair prices. Plus, this is where I popped my Speakeasy Big Daddy IPA cherry and I will forever remember the moment! 

Anyways, I hadn't been to Serpentine in a long while. I live a 10 minute walk away and had never had their brunch, so bf and I decided to make reservations on a Sunday morning. We got there and we ordered blood orange lemonade to start. He got the red flannel hash and I got the baked egg dish. We split a large fruit plate as well. 

Lemonade was awesome. Fruit plate was meh. It was mostly pineapple and bananas, with bits of orange and strawberry. I happen to dislike pineapple and bananas so boyfriend got to eat most of it. My baked egg was really disappointing. I think I had expected a drier dish with tomato salsa on top of it per other reviews, but instead it was more like a watery soup/stew, topped with an egg. There were chickpeas, swiss chard, hen of the woods and *canned* tomatoes, which resulted in a watery and extremely sour/acidic dish. All I could taste was the canned tomatoes, nothing else. I didn't finish it :( Boyfriend said that the separate ingredients in his hash were great, but the dish was lost on him when he put them together. He didn't finish his either :\ 

All in all, pretty disappointed. I probably would've given a 2 star rating, but I know that dinner here is so good. I hope it was just a hiccup and that dinner will *still* be good- now I'm worried that perhaps the quality of the whole restaurant has gone down, since I haven't been over for dinner in awhile. I will probably never be back for brunch, sad to say. It sucks when the best part of the meal is the drink.
author: Emily H.

description:
I could start and end with the burger and it would justify the 5 stars.  I have been on a quest for a good burger here in SF and time and time again been let down by the hyped up places.  I dont think it is too much to ask that a place know how to cook a burger a proper medium rare, but most places screw it up.

At long last!!!! a place in SF that corrects a burger medium rare and juicy.  You dont have to put mushrooms or bacon or any of the other crap that the fancy burger place tries to sell you.  This place just serves a perfectly cooked patty with a little pickled vegis on top.  it was was seasoned, well cooked and was just what i have been looking for.  simple, but hard to find.

On top of the burger, the ribs, salads, calamari all were perfectly seasoned, texturally interesting and came out to a proper temperature.  

Service was friendly.  not as attentive as some places, but I never found myself needing something during the evening, so I guess it was the right level of attention for my needs.  

I would totally go back for the burger alone, but the other dishes looked and were tasty.
author: Scott C.

description:
The food here was very good, but service was horrendous. We came here for dinner and made a last minute reservation for 9:15. We arrived at 8:45 hoping we could get seated early. They were pretty busy, so we definitely didn't get seated till at least 9:40.  My g/f and I also noticed that many of the patrons we first saw when we entered were still sitting at the tables when we got seated. Not sure if that's the fault of the patrons or the restaurant. 

At this point I was a little annoyed and very hungry. We immediately ordered what we came here for. Service was also very slow and a bit inattentive. We had to constantly flag down our waiter to place our order, to clean our table, and to ask for the check. Nonetheless, we got the burgers, which I do admit were very, very good. I would consider coming back here for them, but at least not for awhile. Otherwise, I would upgrade this to another star had service been much better
author: Justin L.

description:
Came here for brunch this past Sunday with a GF for brunch. This is probably the second time I've been here and I am definitely a fan. I ordered the crabs egg Benedict and my friend ordered the red flannel hash and they were both on point and delicious. We finished every little single thing on our plate and felt like little fatties after but it hit the spot. 

The only complaint that I had was that they were out of some things from the menu and when I ordered a mimosa, they didn't have chilled champagne so I had to wait a bit for that and when my friend ordered a cocktail the server came back to our table after about 15-20 mins of ordering the drink and said they were out of some kind of liquor so they couldn't make her drink but overall we had a great time and loved our food. I will definitely be back!
author: Daisy W.

description:
I came here for weekend brunch on a Saturday, arriving around 1pm. Even though I didn't have a reservation, the wait was minimal (maybe 5 minutes tops?). Staff were friendly and the interior is comfortable and interesting. 

I tried the Fried Egg Sandwich, having read elsewhere that it's one of their hit menu item. I also ordered the Buttermilk Biscuit which came with homemade jam. I'm a huge fan of homemade jam from Venus (in Berkeley), so I really wanted to find something at that level. Oh and a Ruby Mimosa to go with it, as I had recently fallen in love with mimosas.

The Fried Egg Sandwich was good, but a little too greasy for me. The bread was a little thick (I'm trying to cut low on carbs!), considering the other ingredients. Overall, I got the feeling that each ingredient was good, but the combination didn't really amuse me. The Ruby Mimosa was good but quite plain (it made me wonder why the Mimosa at La Note in Berkeley tasted so good). Maybe try again next time? 

I got the impression that Serpentine and Slow Club are operated by same management, or at least have a friendly partnership (since Serpentine had Slow Club business cards in their front desk and had a similar drink menu). Between these two, I think I like Slow Club a little bit better. However, if you don't want to wait to get a decent brunch, Serpentine may be your place.
author: Soo Jung R.

description:
Don't let the menu on this site fool you, the actually offerings change with the seasons so it is always better just to go in and ask what is good! 

Same goes for the cocktails, not that liquor only grows in certain climates, but a little conversation with your server or bartender goes a long way.

I won't go into details except to say, make a reservation well in advance, and I love the architecture of the building. you won't be disappointed.
author: John C.

description: Love this place for brunch, they serve amazing bloody marys, and great hash so I am won over already! Last time I was here I got the hash with beets, steak, and poached eggs, was wonderfully done! Price is kinda on the high end but you get what you pay for! If yelp would allow me to.. I would actually give this place a 4.5 as the wait for brunch can be horrendous if you dont have a reservation!
author: Eleana H.

description: Came for Sunday brunch. Had the huevos rancheros and flannel hash. It was good, not exceptional though :( . Very loud restaurant. Would not go back.
author: Margaux M.

description:
We really enjoyed our evening here! We sat at the bar and ordered a cocktail and some appetizers. The shaved arugula salad with beets was delicious and the fries were good too :) I'm not a big fan of arugula but that salad was pretty special! Their dessert menu was pretty awesome too but we didn't have any because we really wanted to try Chocolate Lab too that same evening.

We will definitely be back to try other dishes on their menu!
author: Vickie Z.

description:
I had the best Crab Benedict you could ask for. The poached eggs were perfect. The capers on top of the eggs were such a nice touch. 

When we called prior to arriving they said we might have to wait a couple of hours for a table. When we arrived, the host squeezed us in, and we ate in no time. The wait staff was always ready to help at the drop of a whim. This is a great spot for Brunch with friends. I can't wait for my next visit!
author: James A.

description: Lovely setting; menu looks appealing and interesting but doesn't deliver. Had veg burger and fries. Fries were like standard fast food 'cut' - fine but not very good -guessing maybe they aren't house made from potatoes; burger had no flavor and was very dry.
author: Cathy C.

description: I think this place is a sleeper hit.  I had an impromptu meal here and it was perfect.  We each had a negroni and side salad to start.  Hangar steak as an entree.  Ice cream sandwich for dessert.  High fives all around.  We walked right in and sat at the bar and were served promptly.  Ample parking, great food, killer bar...why is this place not slammed?!
author: Darin E.

description: Their burgers are to die for. Best burger I've at the $15+ mark w/ cheese; usually I'm disappointed if I'm thinking of the price compared to the quality of food, but in this case the price point and food quality match up. Solid fries as well. Also, they have this mayonnaise with a garlic flavor = A-mayo-zing! Pun intended.
author: Matthew F.

description: continuing with dogpatch dining...whiskey smash to start...good cocktail enjoying at the bar and table...$eight.fifty drink...placing order for heirloom tomato salad and stone fruit salad...decent $ten.fifty bite, but not impressed...chicken $twenty-three and decent...lot of dry white, but seasoned well...handsome burgers and fries probably the better choice...a lush and roughly $sixty-five per person....
author: Hen A.

description:
We went to Serpentine this weekend for brunch and had an enjoyable meal. The decor inside is pretty bare but in a good modern way. The brunch menu was a little different with some different ingredients but the basics we there as well. 

My dad and I started with bloody marys which were nice and spicy. For the main meal I had the chicken fried steak and eggs. Both were very good and the was a lot of food on the plate but it was definitely eatable in one sitting. 

This was our first meal he so I'd be curious how their lunch and dinners are but we had a good experience for brunch.
author: Blake B.

description:
We made a brunch reservation for six people a month or so in advance. We picked Serpentine because of the multiple vegetarian options on the menu, the 10:00am opening time (flights needed to be caught right after), and the ample parking nearby. We'd vaguely heard good things, but no raves, and were hopeful the food would be good-- and we were not disappointed. 

We ordered the huevos rancheros, the frittata, the polenta & eggs, and the buckwheat pancakes, and also a side of crispy potatoes. Coffee was a dark roast but the attentive refills were appreciated. One of our party ordered the senator and was a fan. We loved the huevos rancheros -- two poached eggs with spiced black beans, hen of the woods mushrooms, and corn tortillas with a few avocado slices. The crunchy tortillas were a nice twist to what is usually a (wonderfully) mushy mess of dish and we also loved the flavorful salsa (some heat but not too much) that came on the side. 
The polenta and eggs was also solid-- roasted vegetables - braised spigarello (which according to wiki is a leafy green that tastes like broccoli), fried eggs with runny centers, and piquillo & poblano pepper salsa. 
The buckwheat pancakes were good-- not too sweet as some brunch pancake dishes can be, but nothing too special. 
The frittata was probably our favorite-- it was rich, but perfectly done, and we loved the tomatillo salsa on top. It might be hard for one person to eat alone but as a shared dish it was fantastic. 
And the side of crispy potatoes was totally worth it-- creamy on the inside crispy on the outside and served hot hot hot. If you consider the potatoes at Plow to be #1, these are definitely contenders for second place. 

Given the positives this place has going for it, we will be back-- definitely for the frittata and the potatoes, and perhaps to try the fried egg sandwich. Ideally we'd time it such that we could go to mr. and mrs. miscellaneous across the street to finish the meal on a sweet note.
author: T K.

description:
This is a 3.5 star review.

After going to Slow Club for brunch Sunday I wanted to give it a try for dinner.  When reading the dinner menus for both Serpentine and Slow Club, we were torn.  Liked the entrees and appetizers from Serpentine and the desserts at Slow Club.  Decided on Serpentine after tossing a coin.  

Really loved the interiors.  An open industrial space with washed ceilings, old wood floors and wooden accents highlighted with beautiful light fixtures.  We were seated in the bar area.  Our server attentive and enthusiastic, in the right kind of way.  

We started with cocktails.  My friend ordered the Acadian: bulleit rye, sloe gin, honey, lemon, rosemary, absinthe.  This concoction was delicious, not too sweet and perfectly balanced with just a hint of rosemary.  I had the the 3rd from the bottom.  A blend of batiste rhum, grapefruit, maple, lemon, cayenne.  The server warned this was a spicy drink, I appreciated the hint of heat on the back.  Our evening off to a good start.

We ordered the Spiced Brentwood Yellow Corn soup with lime creme fraiche, spiced croutons, and summer vegetables.  This soup was the highlight of my meal.  Perfectly creamy.  The flavors bright, you got a different flavor and texture in every bite.  The perfect way to highlight the farmers market ingredients currently available.  

Entrees:  Pan Seared California Halibut topped with oil cured olive tapenade and served with fresh cranberry beans, summer beans (both green and yellow), cherry tomatoes, and sauced with a delicious herb puree.  This dish was visually stunning and quite tasty.  I ordered the Grilled Wild Alaskan Sockeye Salmon topped with slivered almonds and served on a bed of quinoa, watercress, in a delicious romesco sauce.  Also on the plate were three mussels.  When the server brought the plate there was an overwheming "fishy" smell.  The fish ordered medium was overcooked and dry, maybe too long under the heat lamps?  I really enjoyed the quinoa and romesco sauce.  Perhaps this just wasn't the dish for me.

I'll give Serpentine another try.  The atmosphere and service make it worth another trip to Dogpatch.
author: Kim A.

description:
Located in a former warehouse space with 20 foot ceilings, poured in place concrete stanchions, and exposed brick walls, Serpentine a dishes up solid, sustainably farmed new American fare.

The menu focuses on sustainably fished seafood as well as meat and produce from farms and ranches that practice ecologically correct agriculture. Spiced lentil soup with pomegranate seeds and creme fraiche was not the best combination.  While a little small for the price, the Serpentine "meat board," a collection of salumi with grilled levain toasts, is a great starter.  Served on an Acme roll, the Prather Ranch burger with arugula, pickled onions, and house-made bread and butter pickles is not one you want to smother with condiments: ketchup, mustard, or mayo would only adulterate the pure beef goodness. Light and crispy, the French fries were crispy and perfectly cooked.

If you order a G&T, you will not be turned away, but the bar emphasizes hand-crafted cocktails featuring super-premium, low volume spirits.  While bottled craft brews abound, there are no beers on tap and only an "adequate" wine list.

Service at the bar was glacial: flatware was not delivered at the beginning of the meal, water glasses were left unfilled, and used plates were not promptly removed. One can only hope the table servers are more prompt.

All in all, Serpentine delivers good, new American fare, but falls,short on execution.
author: CJ G.

description:
A very cool looking place for brunch.  I love the light fixtures (how many reviews have I written that included a note on light fixtures?? Too many!) Thank goodness we didn't have to wait long for a table. Sunday brunch gets pretty agressive in terms of crowds in San Francisco. We got seated right away, but then about 15 minutes later, the front of the restaurant got packed! Whew, made it just in time.

The food here consists of hearty and fulfilling staples. The country fried steak and eggs was hefty, ample, and fulfilling. My son enjoyed his burger (made of Prather Ranch beef - yay!). And after eating a ton of sausage products in the last few days, I opted for the household granola with yogurt and fresh fruit. Simply refreshing and delightful! The food is good, the place is cool, the prices are reasonable. Solid for sure.
author: Angela T.

description:
Hitting up Serpentine's for weekend brunch is a sure bet.  Plan accordingly - as they pack out.  The food is fresh, high quality and tasty.  Service can be hurried & the bar backs up - dude pick your battles.  Having dined at tables and the bar on several occasions, these are some of my favorites:

- You like your pre-noon cocktails as much as I do: Monice's Shrine.
- Country Fried Steak & Eggs.  Holy Goodness.
- Crab Benedict
- the Bacon.
- Flannel Hash
  
I'm a sucker for interiors.  It's a great warehouse conversion with industrial elements and lots of light.
author: FancyPant S.

description: Came here for dinner and loved it. Ambiance, food, their fried brussels sprouts! I will definitely return next time I'm in the city!
author: S C.

description: Had reservations at 1:30 pm, seated pretty quickly. Ordered the Red Flannel Hash since they were out of the Dungeness Crab Benedict. I was disappointed, but the dish I ordered was decent. My favorite part of my visit here was the music. I love that the restaurant is conveniently located next to Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous. Save your tummy for dessert!
author: Sandy W.

description:
Went here with my boyfriend on a Saturday without a reservation.  Parking was super easy, and the wait was about 30 minutes so we were able to walk around Dogpatch a little bit which was nice (there is a small coffee shop next to Piccino's, so we stopped there to get a little caffeine while we waited.)

The place itself is very cool looking, it is a converted warehouse and it looks great.  It is a little loud (high ceilings) but we were able to hear each other and gossip about people around us without being overheard. We also had enough room to read the paper for a little while before the breakfast was brought over. 

The food came out really fast! I ordered the local dungeness crab benedict, it was one of the best benedict's I have ever had.  It is not a crab cake, but actually just delicious crab underneath an egg sitting on a buttermilk biscuit.  The potatoes were also very good, very cripsy and none were burned!

My boyfriend ordered the polenta and eggs, which was also very good. 

Next time I want to try the fried egg sandwhich!
author: S E.

description:
LUNCH REVIEW on Korean Braised Beef Sandwich ONLY:

Oh boy, the Korean Braised Beef Sandwich is absolutely amazing.  I wasn't impressed by the savory bread pudding, but the beef sambo seriously put a smile on my face for the rest of the day.

LOVE that it's in "the hood" for us.  Cute little place, not a ton of seating but so far we haven't had to wait very long.  For me, the beef sambo is the only thing that really interests me.. but for that alone, 5 stars! Can't wait to go back again.. reasonably priced as well.  I feel like most places would hike up the price easily to $15 for lunch.
author: Melody T.

description:
A solid place for brunch in the Dogpatch with a very similar menu to Slow Club.

Red flannel hash - I thought this was pretty good, but it's definitely very beety. The turkey sausage hash at Slow Club is much better.

Crab benedict - This was a nice dish. The buttermilk biscuit was better than I thought and definitely not dry or too doughy. The crispy potatoes were nicely seasoned and perfected fried.

The space itself it quite small, but they make efficient use of it. Make a reservation as there were lots of people waiting when I arrived. Service was prompt and attentive. I hardly noticed that she had come by and refilled my coffee. Street parking is easy on 3rd St.
author: Kenny J.

description:
dinner at serpentine included:
* meat board - most were made in house and all packed a punch of flavor, taking me to yum town
* house made potato gnocchi with dungeness crab - generous amount of crab
* storm hill ranch hanger steak - perfectly cooked to a medium rare, you could taste the grill char (in a yummy way and not in the yucky burn way) - preferred this over the gnocchi
* french fries with aioli
crispy brussels sprouts - very good, preferred over the french fries
didn't make it to dessert

brunch included:
* crab benedict - good, but i would've preferred a little more salt or flavor on them.  also, i would've wanted an english muffin.  the biscuit was a bit doughy for me.  my husband loved it, but he loves doughy stuff.  the biscuit itself was good, just not my thing for a benedit
* bloody mary - pretty good
* pimm's cup - very good
* country fried steak + eggs - pref this over the benedict.  gravy was yummilicious
* side of bacon - yummy

* prices were reasonable
* staff was friendly
* decor cute
* close to me!
author: Tina F.

description: Decided to try this place for brunch. The huevos rancheros were delicious. However, the "poached" eggs in the brisket hash were far from poached - they seemed hard boiled. Three stars due to the overcooked eggs.
author: Carlos J.

description:
Excellent! 

Service was great. Ambiance is amazing. Food was delicious and best of all, on a Saturday morning at 11, there wasn't a line!

How often does that happen in SF for brunch?
author: Abhi M.

description: biscuits and gravy were bomb. bloody mary was nothing special. potatoes (home fries??) tasted dusty, i thiiiiiink it might've been from the salt on the table in the open salt cellar. i might be crazy but every time i crunched through a potato nugget after sprinkling a pinch of salt on, all i tasted was dust.... dusty.... ick.  pancake was good, especially with the homemade whip cream. oj looked delicious but i didn't try any. service was good and quick, if somewhat brusque.
author: Jan Y.

description:
Warm and cozy dining in a vast industrial space. I wish I could move in. 

The wait staff and mixologists are knowledgable and fun. Great cocktails. Delicious food.
author: Mrs. E.

description: I used to love this place and tell people that it's one of the best burger spots in the area.  However, service went downhill and they charged me for dessert on my birthday! If you are going to put a candle on top of a dessert for someone's birthday, don't charge us.  That's just rude.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
Thanks for making my morning warm and comfortable! NOT

Right from the get go: what is it with these restaurants with stupid policies that make there staff become ignorant, nasty and quite simply oblivious to creating a good vibe! 

We had a reservation for 11:30am, I was on time, my friends were 15 mins late! It was cold outside and the painful door person stated she would not seat me until everyone arrived even though I stated I was cold, getting over being sick, and told her the other 2 had just text and were on route to be there! Still she made me wait where I would stay cold! Of course there were 3 tables sitting open!!!! Smart! Yeah, really clever of you!

Beyond that; the waitress was pleasant, but we waited quite some time for our food, and when it came, seriously, how is this place getting so many reviews of amazing food?  I had polenta and eggs. It was bland, I added salt, pepper and hot sauce to get some flavor and  I was still very hungry after I finished! So for $12 I'll go else where thank you!
author: daniel l.

description:
After eating brunch here recently, I was reminded what a PERFECT last-minute destination this place is. On nights I couldn't get reservations at "hot" places, this has always been a great backup for bar seating or a relatively short wait for a table. I've been eating here for maybe 10 years? At least 6? At any rate, always somewhere between adequate and delicious. When chefs have changed the quality has not suffered. 

When I've traveled to other cities, and been a tourist, I've wanted exactly this kind of place with a bar to saunter up to while I choose between a meal of two appetizers or a reasonably priced entree, over a well-made cocktail. 

This, people, is a great example of my home base of exactly that. In recent memory some standout lunch favorites have been little gem salad and savory bread pudding; recent dinner favorites have been gnocchi and fried calamari with Indian spices; and I FINALLY tried brunch, which was great too. Brunch cocktails better than dinner cocktails. And YUM that egg sandwich and interesting way presenting crispy potatoes.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Hipster brunch? Yes it is.

Savory bread pudding
Biscuits and gravy
author: James G.

description:
Great place for brunch.

Located in the Dogpatch. Space is industrial and minimal, with high loft ceilings, exposed brick and cement beams. Open and airy with lots of natural light during the day. Serpentine is incredibly hip, while still maintaining a down to earth vibe. Service is friendly and attentive. Came for lunch on a Sunday and sat at the bar which was lovely.

Creative menu with ingredients that are fresh and locally sourced. I recommend the (Prather Ranch Burger) med-rare, with cheddar. So juicy and flavorful. Topped with arugula and house pickles on a light brioche bun. Fries are crispy and well seasoned.

Also across the street from Mr. & Mrs. Misc. Definitely a plus.
author: Ashley K.

description:
**Serpentine is SOOOOOO Ang Style***
The PERFECT place to spend my birthday :)
 
Understated sophistication sums it up.  

I'll start by saying that even on my big day, I'm still a service snob.  Serpentine managed to make me very happy in the service department.  My girlfriend made the reservation for 6, but unbeknownst to both of us, a party of 10 surfaced!  Impressively, the staff managed to accommodate us in a matter of 30 minutes.

**Amazing food around that table** Not too many veggie options on the menu, but it was totally ok because what remained was pure perfection.  Their salads are divine.  So are the fries, and so is dessert!  It was chocolate cake with coconut ice cream and moscato d'asti for all.  I had the único b.day vanilla bean ice cream that was so memorable, my mouth is watering right now.   

Friends, food, fun.  I couldn't think of a better way to turn the big "I'm-not-saying".   Serpentine, you're going straight to the top of my SF faves!

Last little tip for ya:  parking on 3rd was a bit tough.  Go one street parallel, toward the water.  A plethora of spots.
author: Angella S.

description: Had to wait for a while past our reservation for Brunch due to a group that wouldn't leave, but, food was great, healthy servings. As usual, a small space in SF; given the beautiful sunshine and loft interior with lots of windows, it also got pretty steamy so I recognize they arrange for better ventilation or A/C. A little bit pricey. Friendly service, and directly opposite awesome ice cream at Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous! Menu changes as they go, which I think is neat. Had crab benedict, pretty yum, with buckwheat pancakes. Pancakes not particularly fluffy or flavorful, but nice enough. Crispy potatoes good. Brunch popular, so definitely make a reservation versus walkin.
author: Miriam W.

description: One of my new favorite brunch spots in the city. Making a reservation is great -- and my friend and I came here on a Saturday morning, and it wasn't totally slammed like the other parts of town (wondering how this place is on a Sunday, though). Otherwise, had a great time, and love the coffee there, too.
author: Mel G.

description: Love this place. I had the crab benedict once and the salmon benedict another time. Both were on top of a biscuit with a side of arugula and crispy HEAVEN potatoes. That's right. GET THE POTATOES! It's crispy to the right texture! The portion size is a good amount, not too little, not too much. Bestie had the hash once and then the country fried steak with biscuit, crispy potatoes and arugula. That hash was pretty good. Not sure about the steak, meh. I've had better. Overall, this place rocks. To make it all even better? My favorite ice cream place is right next door!
author: Laura T.

description: Really nice place and the chorizo burger is delicious! Staff is very friendly too, and they have a nice net selection.
author: Rafael O.

description:
Burgers is something that has a lot of competitiion to get right.. this place gets it right!  

I had a bacon, gruyere burger.  The mixt green salad had waaaay too much dressing on it but the burger was good.  The bottom bun soaked up all the juices so it was soggy but the flavor is very good.
author: Toby I.

description:
Good solid food.  I had some darned tasty swordfish for dinner and my other dining companions all enjoyed their food.  Grilled sardines and fresh oysters for appetizers, then on to hangar steak, swordfish, gnocchi and rabbit.  Good wine and dessert to round out the meal.

I've been a regular at Slow Club however I find Serpentine a more dining-centric option to Slow Club's bistro/bar vibe.

I'm a fan!
author: Rick G.

description:
I've been here twice for weekend brunch and had great experiences both times.  I think the reason I always forget about this place and don't go more often is because it's out of my way, but I just remembered it this past weekend when I was starving after a morning of volunteering at the food bank.

Parking was easy in this neighborhood and I was able to be seated immediately at noon.  The space has an industrial feel to it, but still manages to feel comfortable.  (That might be due to the close proximity of the tables.)  They also have a long bar (full bar - BTW) where you can eat.

I honestly can't remember what I had during my first visit, but I remembered that my Mom ordered the Savory Bread Pudding.  When I went this weekend I ordered that and was glad it was just as good as I remembered it.  It was made with their own cured ham, carrots, and onion.  It kind of reminded me of the dressing that my Mom makes at Thanksgiving (which is a *great* thing).  The simply dressed salad on the side was perfect to cut the richness of the pudding.  I would definitely order this dish again.  I was getting ready to go to the gym to run and couldn't order a Mimosa, but I can vouch for the coffee, which was strong and refilled several times.

If you're in the neighborhood, I would recommend trying this place for brunch.  I was looking around at other items that people ordered and it looks like they also have a mean egg sandwich and hamburger!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
Serpentine appears far roomier on the inside than the outside. Considering the quality of food served here and friendly attitudes of all employees I've encountered, its popularity isn't surprising. 

Head out to the Dogpatch and pick whatever looks best. You'll enjoy it. For my lunch, I ordered a bacon cheeseburger with fries, and a pork shoulder sandwich with garden greens. Fortunately for me, both sandwiches were so good that I had trouble eating only half of each, and taking them home for another meal. 

This was a heckuva burger. Serpentine uses Prather Ranch meat for its patties, which are quite flavorful. I did miss tomato(es) on the burger though. The fries tasted really good also, thanks in part to the salt and herbs that are served up on them. 

As good as the burger was, so was the pork shoulder sandwich. The pork, roll, and greens combined well together. Yes, I suspect that the aioli and avocado in the sandwich were fairly influential too! Whatever the reason though, don't pass it up if you enjoy anything like this.

Oh, and there's the unique pinot noir grape juice. Yes, it's fairly sweet, but non-alcoholic, grape juice. It's a local product (comes from Navarro) and surprisingly tasty, even when compared to the fresh orange juice, which I'd ordered for brunch previously.

Pro Move: If you order bacon for just a burger, you'll get enough for both that burger and another sandwich, as I found out.
author: Mike H.

description: Went here for dinner with friends. They have pretty good food here. I ordered lamb, My friend ordered the burger. Yummy! The place is small so it does seem like you'll need to get reservations if you want to not wait for hours to get seated. They also have a good selection of alcoholic beverages.
author: Pam Y.

description: Brunch is always solid here.  (Menu rotates frequently, so my suggestions may not exist).  I've tried the tri tip hash and the dungeness crab benedict.  Both were delicious, fresh and generously sized.  Their biscuits are delicious!
author: Timan G.

description: I've heard so much about the Serpentine burger and finally had the chance to try it recently.  It was very good but didn't blow me away.  Of course, this was in part due to the fact that I ordered my patty medium well (I had a bad experience with rare hamburger meat once and have been traumatized) so it wasn't as juicy as it would otherwise be.  The bun was nicely toasted and the pickled onions made the flavors in each bite much more interesting.  But what makes this burger 4 stars in my eyes are the fries.  The fries are perfection.  Sometimes it's hard to get skinny fries right, but Serpentine's were uniformly crisp while still being moist on the inside.  They were served fresh out of the fryer, the portion size with hefty, and I finished almost every single fry.  Of course I was stuffed silly afterwards but it was well worth it.  I also tried the ginger squash and coconut soup with chives, cashew, and chili oil and it was excellent.  Each and every ingredient was discernible and united in perfect harmony and I was so inspired I came home and made my own simpler take on this soup.  So Ironically, while it was the burger that initially drew me in, I was much more impressed with the fries and the soup!
author: Beatrice W.

description:
My wife and I thought this was a good place to celebrate valentine's day.

We recommend the meat board (get extra bread), petrale sole, and lamb shank.

We'll definitely be coming back perhaps to try the brunch & lunch menu.
author: Francis M.

description:
This place is straight out of Brooklyn, so hipsters and creative foodies one and all - rejoice!

I came in for brunch and (along with OJ and a cappuccino) had the Brisket Hash with Roasted Beets, Crispy Potatoes, Arugula, Poached Eggs & Toasted Levain. First of all, it's A LOT of food. Second of all, it's a lot of DELICIOUS food. The brisket was so juicy and tender and practically melted in my mouth. The potatoes were crispy as advertised and the eggs were delightfully runny. It was also a happy surprise to discover horseradish cream at the bottom of the plate! Gave a great little extra bump of flavor and heat to the dish.

Serpentine has a great brunch menu with the exception of no sweet offerings (for the love of pancakes, why?!). A good selection of cocktails and drinks too. 

As for service? Eh. Serpentine is the perfect example of service that suffices but is in no way remarkable. Food was timely and our order was taken quickly, but we weren't checked on throughout the course of the meal and our waiter wasn't openly friendly. Still, it was nothing worthy of a complaint. 

Brunch was good, and I would definitely come back to Serpentine to try out their dinner or sample their cocktails.
author: Sarah S.

description:
By far one of the best brunch places to go in the city. My roommate and I came here one saturday afternoon around 1pm. Was told to be about 30 minutes wait but since the bar opened up, we were able to get seated in 15 minutes or so.

I myself got the country fried steak and eggs. My roommate got the eggs benedict. The steak and eggs was REALLY GOOD. The steak was moist and the breading was flavorful as well. It was a tad bit under seasoned but I wasn't complaining. The eggs were made the way it was supposed to be made. You can tell it was done on low heat and cooked slowly. The eggs were soft, moist and well seasoned. The dish also came with their homemade biscuit and gravy, and a small arugula salad. The salad and eggs paired together amazingly well. The biscuit was also really tasty. When you first see it, you wonder if it is actually a biscuit. Honestly, it looks like some kind of cake or corn bread but it was so delicious. Crispy exterior with moist center and tastes exactly like a biscuit. I ate everything off the plate because it was so delicious. The service was also absolutely fantastic.

I would definitely recommend coming here. I will be back here again.
author: edward k.

description:
I had been meaning to give this place a try for a while now and recently went for brunch.  The place has a nice ambiance and the food was pretty good.  I had the brisket hash with beets.  Thought it was an unusual combination but it worked for me.  I would state that they probably needed to season the food a little better but overall the quality and taste was good.

The server was nice but overall service was a little mixed.  The initial person who greeted us told us she had to ask someone about seating 2 then went of to do something else.  Luckily another came around and promptly seated us.  We had our pleasant meal and sat for a short while chatting after we paid the check.  The server came around stating that they will need the seats for another group.  She was pleasant enough and we were just about to leave anyway but I thought that perhaps it was a little much to essentially ask us to leave.

I would go again but plan to not spend a too leisurely brunch there.
author: Figaro D.

description: We came for dinner, they were able to accommodate a large group, reservations available via open table, and the ambiance is cute.  Interesting cocktails and adequate wine list.  The food was good, but a little too rich that ended up giving me a tummy ache after, but all things considered it was good, but not entirely 'great'; but decent date night location. Would consider trying it again for brunch.
author: Ella B.

description:
Love the ambiance; it feels verye intimate with the high, dark wood booths and low lighting. 

We thought it was expensive until we started eating.  The swordfish & gnocchi were delicious.  The cocktails were top-notch as well (can't remember what we had).

Bonus: Because it's somewhat off the beaten path, parking was really easy to find.
author: Dagmar H.

description:
The best thing is that they take reservation. 

Get the bloody marry and you won't be regret! The pancake is huge so order one only if you have a small appetite like me
author: Ting R.

description:
Solid restaurant tucked away in Dogpatch.  Came after a bouldering session at Dogpatch Boulders (nearly at 10pm and they still accomodated us) and the food was quite satisfying.  We ordered the roast chicken and burger, both were solid, the fries were to die for.

Would definitely go again if I'm in the area.
author: Jessie K.

description: A friend and I had dinner here last night and I thought the food was very good, however, there were a few things that could have turned this into a 5 star experience.  It was a very busy night and as we were waiting to order drinks, a man interrupted the bartender while he was making drinks and asked for 4 manhattans.  He wanted them a particular way, so the bartender said "please....."  and then the guy asked again, and the bartender said "please" - wanting the customer to say please.  Then, there was an older lady next to me using a light from her phone to see the menu because it was dark and the same bartender asked her to shut it off.
