I mean, not a great experience for my first time at this place. The waiter was very friendly and sat next to us to take our order. He was a doll.  The food was great, but the mushrooms dish and calamari was room temperature.  We asked if we can have the mushroom dish hotter and he obliged.  All in all, I will go back but I will steer clear from this bartender who seemed pretty stressed out. He shouldn't be in the hospitality business if everyone annoys him.
author: Pina C.

description: Food is great, but this place is so loud that I can't handle eating their. It's cool looking concrete box but it reflects sound worse than any restaurant I've ever seen. Table conversation is challenging because of it.
author: Richard P.

description:
i'm gonna put this down as one of my new favorite top brunch spots. i've always been intrigued by Serpentine but i could never tell whether it was open or not at first glance. now that i'm aware it's a lunch/brunch spot, i'll be frequenting it a little more often.

amongst two, we shared...

country fried steak and biscuits with gravy. i typically don't ever order country fried steak but for some reason i felt this calling my name and i'm glad i ordered it. the gravy was really good and the biscuit was moist, crisp and buttery. the dressed arugula helped to cut through the richness quite nicely.

buckwheat pancake with fruit and candied walnuts. holy yum! i'm pretty particular about my pancakes. i typically think they're dense discs (disks?...just wiki'd it and it seems there's no differentiation) of pointlessness but this one was super light and the buckwheat added a nice texture. the fresh whipped cream and seasonal fruit was nice, as was the not-too-sweet-syrup that accompanied it. 

wild smoked salmon benedict. served with fried capers and fried lemon slices. i liked this dish, though i could have done without the sauteed spinach. this was served atop one of their biscuits. the dish was a bit salty but i don't really mind salty. 

sorta can't wait to come back!
author: Regina C.

description:
Serpentine never fails to deliver with amazing food at a reasonable price.  This was my third visit (well, more like 6th, but this is the third I'm writing about) was for brunch with my cousin.  We had tentatively planned the wonderful nearby Just For You (which is a great spot) but that was really crowded, so we headed over to Serpentine around 11:15a on a Saturday.  No reservations? No problem, said the hostess as she showed us to the one remaining four-top available.  I don't know what it is, but this place always seems to have one -and only one- table available.

I had the dungeness crab Benedict with crispy potatoes and about died with how  good it was.  The table also had the baked eggs, the country steak breakfast, and one buckwheat waffle for dessert.  Add in a Pimm's cup and Bellini and the rainy day went to blue skies.  Literally.  we can debate about whether it was the food or this crazy Spring weather in San Francisco, but it was rainy when we came in, and blue peeking from behind clouds when we left.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Serpentine's brunch is really good, down to earth, yet still a little hip to the tongue.  

I had the red flannel hash after reading Jen L's yelp review.  The dish was deceivingly light at first, the meatier elements of this dish hiding underneath the arugula.  Two poached eggs lay on top of the forest of green. 

As I pushed into the depths of the dish with my fork, roasted beets and hearty cubes of brisket I found.  Super buttery, crisp, perfect potatoes steaming hot and just like Jen promised.

Lovely place.  Worth a visit. :)
author: Tracy L.

description:
Kudos to me.  This was the second place I visited this week that has been lingering on my bookmark list since last year.  Weird, but it's such a satisfying feeling to delete things off that list...like I accomplished something.  Haha.  Anyways...

At coworker Dave N's suggestion, we hit up Serpentine for lunch today.  Unless you know that it's right on the corner, you can easily pass it up.  I've driven by here hundreds of times and never noticed it until I put it on my list.  Inside is pleasantly bright.  The seating is kinda tight, but the amount of space overall does not feel claustrophobic.  After hearing about how good their burger was, that's exactly what I ordered, medium rare with cheddar.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/68-n3xi30GwhEvkElVNgiw?select=1OteAW4s7Z7MZTNzzi8HmQ)  Right away, you notice that the exterior of the bun is stiff.  Is it toasted?  I can't tell.  But that's what it felt like. The entire burger as a whole is pretty thick.  And speaking of...the patty itself is pretty thick .  Wait, I take that back.  It's not thick, it's THACK!  Seriously, that's one big ass patty.  (My apologies if anyone out there is named Patty.)  The flavoring of the burger was okay.  It wasn't bland, but it wasn't eye-popping either.  My love for the Marlowe burger has been well-documented.  So unless I find something completely mind-blowing, I'm pretty much ruined for other burgers.  Oh, it gets oily too.  Fries were good tho!

Our waitress was meh.  She wasn't rude, just not in the happiest mood it seemed.  I scored a parking spot a block away on the other side of 3rd.  I'd say Serpentine at most rates 3.5 stars for me, but I'm rounding up cuz Mr and Mrs Miscellaneous is right across the street.  Hell yeah we went there afters!  Love that place!!
author: Joe M.

description: With their ever changing menu, I never exactly know what I am going to eat when I step in.  The one sure thing I know in the 4 times I've given Serpentine a try is that this place never seems to disappoint!!!  This time I got down with the Rock Cod... yummmm!
author: Selene C.

description: Great place. Service is good. Great food. We had the chicken, burgers, salad, scallops & affagato.. All were really good! I would eat here again.
author: C A.

description:
Food was good, and server was ok.  My only issue was that we called early Saturday morning for a Saturday brunch reservation.  They said on the phone that they can't take reservations, but just come in and there will be no more than a 15 minute wait.

We did just that, showed up and spoke to the hostess.  She said there was a 45 minute wait.  I explained that we had tried to avoid this by making a reservation, and were told that we couldn't.  She said that was because all the reservation slots had been taken for the day already, a day ahead of time.  

We looked around the restaurant, and there were a few empty tables, but we gave benefit of the doubt, and took a walk around historic Dogpatch.

We came back 40 minutes later, and checked with the hostess.  The same two people who were waiting when we showed up the first time - were still there.  The hostess told us "don't go too far"...and that we'll soon have a place to sit at the bar, since the tables were always for people who had reserved.  There were no less than eight empty tables in the place at the time she said that.  I just waited to see what she chose to do.  She came back five minutes later and told us "I can seat you over here at one of these tables, actually."  

Fine, but it just seems like we could've been seated earlier than 45 minutes, and not told we would have to sit at the bar, when it's obvious there were empty tables.  Just seemed kind of dumb.  The food was good though, and came out quickly, since we were starving at that point!
author: Scott L.

description: We are staying nearby having just moved from Brooklyn and have eaten brunch at this place three times already. Everything we have tried has been delicious from the green salad to the crabby Benedict. The service is always great but the ambiance of the place is better. High ceilings and tons of light with good music.
author: Sheryl W.

description:
Came here for brunch. A bit on the slow side for food to come out, but their food is solid. My favorites: savory bread pudding and the salmon benedict on a buttermilk biscuit with the bernaise sauce. They're both two things that you definitely can't get just anywhere.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
The staff here were extremely attentive and nice...the food was okay..not great. Perhaps we ordered the wrong dishes...because as I finished up my Cod with fennel and fava beans..I found myself salivating at the burgers and fries at the adjacent table.
I like the vibe of the place..will likely give it another try.
author: Mimi T.

description: I liked the atmosphere, service was good. I ordered the crab benedict, it was very tasty but my complaint, there was barely any crab, bummer. Nothing much to brag about, everything was fresh tasting and good but I don't know if I would go out of my way to come here again. I would be back if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Karen T.

description: Serpentine is definitely a new favorite of mine! Came here on a Sunday and was impressed by the decor and atmosphere. We were sat within thirty minutes and the service was great. I had the country fried steak and eggs... WOW, so good! The only gripe I have is that parking was a bit difficult. Nonetheless, I will be frequenting Serpentine brunch for sure.
author: Nicole V.

description:
Getting "all the way over" to Dogpatch is always a bit of a chore, but I am happy that I did yesterday morning for "Brunch" here.

I had the "baked eggs (two eggs - spiced garbanzo beans - roasted root vegetables - broccolini - hen of the woods mushrooms - tomatillo salsa - with toasted levain)". I really liked all of the vegetable ingredients in the hash-like dish (served in a personal-size cast iron skillet). The tomatillo salsa was very tasty also.

One very important thing that I noticed while sitting at the bar/counter: they do not offer any crap Beers at all! I saw that they do have a few excellent Beers: Unibroue La Fin du Monde (which is one of my current favourites ~ even if it is from Canadialand) and Almanac Beer Co. Farm to Barrel Series, as well as a few other very good Beers.
author: Brian M.

description:
Strolled in here around 2 pm on Sunday...so glad they are open later for brunch for us lazy people.

I had the jalapeno avocado chicken sandwich. It was filling and spicy! 
Manfriend had steak & eggs with a biscuit. I thought he was going to lick the plate. 

Easy parking. 
No wait. 


Mr and Mrs Miscellaneous across the street if you feel like having dessert after brunch :)
author: Sara P.

description:
Simply a delicious brunch that highly satisfied a hungry group of New Yorkers that are used to brunch as a weekly institution.   The food quality and price was excellent, the presentation was beautiful and cocktails were well-crafted.   An added bonus for accepting brunch reservations, which seems to be a bit of a rarity in San Francisco these days.

Our group sampled a lot of stuff:

- Homemade granola with fresh fruit and yogurt - sounds simple, but probably the best combination I've had anywhere
- Brisket hash with roasted beets and eggs was fantastic
- The burger lived up to everyone's expectations.  Best in San Francisco?  Not sure, but it was definitely good.
- Chicken-friend, flat iron steak was superb

The service isn't perfect - our server was a bit forgetful when it came to drink requests, but she realized one of her mistakes and comp'd us the cocktail she'd forgotten.   It's also in a cool little neighborhood that deserves a walk around afterward. 

We'll be back...
author: Chris U.

description:
solid brunch place! great ingredients (source chosen with care for eggs, vegetable, etc) and the prices are super reasonable ($11-13)

Given that it's possible to book for brunch online without a 3-week advance in SF, it's high on my list even though the location is a bit out of the way (parking was easy!)

bread pudding -- innovative, on the rich side, best to share with someone, crunchiness on the top (reminding me a bit of the guyere in the french onion soup). great side salad with a bit of fennel.

baked eggs -- the mexican sauce on the baked eggs put a great finishing touch on the dish. great balance without the heaviness of huevos rancheros

My friend and I finished every bit of the dishes!
author: Rebecca C.

description: Banging! Well the drinks are that is. I cant wait to return and try some of the food. We had 5 cocktails off the list. Fuego, Arcadian, Smokey, Monice's and the Shrub Runner. All were equally perfected and totally different ranging from refreshing (Monice and Arcadian) to bold (Smokey and Shrub Runner). Great drinks, friendly service and a great atmosphere.
author: Michael B.

description:
Great burger, wonderful cocktails.  Menu is limited/ moderately priced, but the everything is delicious.

Service has always been pleasant and the atmosphere is intimate, yet open.  Interesting design and love the fresh, large bouquets by the entrance.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Definitely make a reservation at Serpentine otherwise you could get stuck waiting awhile.

Came here for dinner - its an incredibly comfortable restaurant. The temperature isn't too cold (and not too hot) its not too noisy. The wait staff is very patient.

We started with the Chicories Salad which has cara cara & blood oranges, herbed goat cheese and spiced pistachios topped with a citrus vinaigrette. Something about the spiced pistachios paired perfectly with the goat cheese. The salad was complimented with Chickpea Battered Calamari with warm spagna bean salad, tomato and mint. The calamari was by far my favorite part of dinner and I will definitely be back for the calamari.

For dinner, my friend and I split the Oven Roasted Mary's Chicken with bacon roasted brussels sprouts, baby beets, farro verde, black cumin seed, sage and sherry jus. They do a great job with their chicken, but what mainly impressed me was the brussel sprouts. I usually despise brussel sprouts, but like I firmly believe, bacon makes everything better. So I supposed I could either give credit to the bacon or the chef. (Really the chef gets credit for being smart enough to roast the brussel sprouts with bacon).

If you're looking for a nice night out in the city without having to worry about parking - go to Serpentine. I'm definitely going back and am going to try the gnocchi and grab another order of their delicious calamari.
author: Analisa S.

description:
Beautiful rustic decor with nice service and great American breakfast.

I stumbled on this place and it was  a great discovery.

I will definatly come back again.
author: Ling W.

description:
Beautiful dark decor (reminds me of NYC). 

Excellent service. 

The lamb shank I ordered fell right off the bone. Mint and coriander chutney was interesting on top. But overall rather bland food.
author: Varun V.

description: Despite my New York culinary chauvinism, this placed rocked. Food was delicious, friendly and attentive servers, and the physical layout of the restaurant was open and inviting. A gem!
author: Neil Z.

description:
The other half treated me to brunch for my birthday here. We made reservations just in case, and then thought we were crazy for doing so especially right when the doors open (who makes reservations at opening time?), but 20 minutes after being seated, the restaurant was actually full. It actually got loud to a point where I felt like we had to raise our voices high enough so that the table next to us can hear our conversation.

I had the crab benedict and a mimosa, he had the country fried steak and eggs, and we shared the buckwheat pancakes. The crab benedict was served over a biscuit instead of the traditional english muffin, so that was a little different. However, everything was really good and flavorful, and we both enjoyed our meals. The portion was big enough to hit the spot without making us feel fat and bloated. Service was attentive, and our coffee and water were always full.

Would definitely come back again to try out other items on the menu.
author: Zell C.

description:
Been here a couple of times for lunch in the last month, and the food is decent...scratch that the burgers are good and the fries are GRRRRREAT! Had real moo and their garden burger, perfectly cooked on a perfect sized toasted artisan bun. The star of the show is the fries, to be accurate they are more like frites, crisp on the outside and moist on the inside, very similar to those at Buchon in Yountville, with their house made ketchup I could live on those alone.

So here are the clouds from the rainbow above...the high ceilings in the converted warehouse make a decent conversation almost impossible especially when the place is half full, can I get ear plugs with an extra side of ketchup? Minus one more star for the astronomical prices for beer and wine, how is am I supposed to get my buzz on or at the very least wash down my chow without taking out a second on the house, really?
author: vic f.

description: Great atmosphere and service, good food, expensive.  The breaking point came for me when I paid $18 at lunch for a faux egg-Mcmuffin.
author: Chuck M.

description:
4 stars for this spot during lunch on weekdays. hipster central haha

I was able to sample 2 of their sandwiches the beer & tomatillo braised pork shoulder sandwich and the Prather Ranch Hamburger.

the pork sandwich was delicious, the pork was tender, the toppings were interesting green tomato good, sauteed peppers & onions was ok the cilantro was not overpower more like feint the lime creme I don't think I tasted it all on a deli sweet roll. For this sandwich delifinitely a must try solid 4 on taste, presentation 5, thrill factor again 4 a must try if you love pork haha

the Prather Ranch Hamburger, we were forwarned by our server it would exploded with juiciness, HE DID NOT LIE!!! cut this bad boy in half you can see the juice drip out on a medium rare cooked patty screaming bite me. the roll was ok I think if they used the sweet deli roll from the pork sandwich it would of contained the beast of juiciness from escaping. the pickled red onions I did not care for, the butter pickles were delicious, we did not get the added toppings of bacon or alternate cheese, simply because we wanted the full flavor of meat hitting our palettes. The meat again hands down one of the better burgers made in the city not the best but better then most.

two sides we sampled were their fries and the salad, the fries were delicious almost like they cooked it in foie gra, crisp thin, delicious, the salad was standard with a light vinegarette nothing special just ehh

one of the sauces they also offered was very good it was orange in color if i remember correctly it was tangy with a mayo consistency, might have been mayo with thousand island mix dunno but it was delicious!!!

food **** must try if in the area, the pork sandwich is a definite go, and prather ranch burger also must try, if you are on the budget just get their fries...
price $$
service ***** very helpful staff with very fast service
ambiance **** out of the box design, definitely does not the match the surroundings of outside, when you walk in kinda feel like you could be in the marina area haha
author: Clarence A.

description: Thanks for telling us that there was a table waiting for us then 2 min later tell us you had to give it away because there was a rush. We called to make sure there wasn't a long wait and this is the kind of service and respect we get. Not happy. Need to train your hostesses a bit better.  It's 7.27.14 at 11.30am.
author: a g.

description: Maybe it's because I'm from the east coast, maybe I'm an unsophisticated asshole though for my $100 it's gotta be better than this.
author: Chris A.

description: The chicken was undercooked and way too expensive for a plate with only chicken. The bread is dry. Not a place that I would ever go back to. The gnocchi portion is tiny and expensive.
author: Betty L.

description:
A simple review for a simply clean and simply tasteful spot.  Recommended.

-Nom Nom
author: Edward M.

description:
Blog Post - http://dabblewith.com/2013/05/25/serpentine/

Erin Rooney started her restaurant businesses with Slow Club in 1991 in Potrero Hill. In December of 2007 Rooney added Serpentine to her collection. With the recession setting in soon after Serpentine opened Rooney decided upon keeping everything concise, so the staff is few extensively trained people and the menu is limited but packed with exceptional dishes (20 dishes max both small and large). Eric Held help Serpentine maintains its original space which was a boiler room for a 100-year-old can factory with an industrial interior design. Eric Held did so with exposed brick walls, a stained and mottled concrete ceiling 20 feet high, and large warehouse-style paned windows, painted black. Rooney chose the name Serpentine because it is the California State Rock and it was a jagged specimen of which she found under the floorboards during construction.

Serpentine is known as one of Dogpatch's must try stops, they serve new American Cuisine for weekend brunch, weekday lunch, dinner (everyday) as well as extensive cocktail menu. However, there menu has changed because last year Serpentine underwent a huge tragedy when their lead chef Caesar Chuc was 628x471killed in a 20 person street brawl in the Mission District. Deepak Kaul is the new chef and his menu is slightly more expensive but definitely worth the wait. Kaul actually has a pretty unique path having left Boston University Medical School to follow his true passion cooking. Starting off staging dishes at Union Pacific Restaurant, led him down a path of working in the kitchens of Jardinière, Rendezvous Central Square, and Nettie's Crab Shack, and now at Serpentine. I would highly recommend checking out Serpentine because Kaul has mastered the use of San Francisco's fresh and local ingredients and gives each dish a unique flavor with his extensive use of spices. The menu of 20 dishes often changes with the season but they do repeat popular dishes. Below are the dishes I would recommend:
Brunch:
* Prather Ranch Hamburger: arugula, pickled red onions, house made pickles, acme roll, french fries
* Buckwheat Pancakes: pineapple, bananas, strawberries, candied walnuts, maple syrup, whipped cream
Lunch:
* Coconut Carrot Soup
* Fried Green Tomato Sandwich: Nueske's bacon, arugula, aioli, torpedo roll, greens / fries
* Pan Seared Local Rock Cod: hen of the woods mushrooms,sautéed ramps & fava leaves, roasted asparagus, carrot puree, black olive tapenade
Dinner:
* House Made Potato Gnocchi with Wild Mushrooms: leeks, baby spigarello, grana padano, oregano, creme fraiche, bread crumbs, mushroom stock
* Grilled California Salmon: fingerling potatoes, cauliflower, fava leaves, olive tapenade, sorrel nage
Cocktails
* Ancient Lemon: hangar one vodka, aqua di cedro, lemon
* Ransom Martinez: ransom gin, sweet vermouth, luxardo, orange & angostura bitters
* Desert Sage: siete leguas reposado tequila, sage, lemon, honey, lemon thyme
author: Cameron M.

description:
Serpentine is a decent neighborhood joint for brunch -- high, open ceilings, with minimalist decor and lots of natural sunlight (granted that it's a nice day, of course).

Savory Bread Pudding = Filled with nicely-rich flavors that give it the perfect amount of saltiness. The texture was a bit too much like a quiche, though -- I would've liked the general center to be a bit fluffier, and not as soggy. I added a side of scrambled eggs to eat along with the bread pudding, which definitely helped balance out the sogginess at the bottom. 

Country Fried Steak = A thin cut of beef, breaded thickly and drenched with gravy. The flavor of the gravy is there, but there just wasn't enough substance. The steak was much too thin, so it tasted essentially like fried breading and gravy. The biscuit that came with it was horrible -- flat, tough, and bland.

The brunch food here is average, and not really memorable. It's definitely not good enough for me to come back just for it, but I would revisit only if I didn't want to wait in line for brunch elsewhere.
author: Roy C.

description:
One of my favorite place for Brunch, Lunch, AND Dinner in Dogpatch.

Let's start with the drinks:
-Excellent Bloody Mary for brunch, with lots of ingredients.
-A very mean, refreshing "Whiskey Smash," not many bars know how to make this drink!

Bruch food is, as I always think, overrated, but they make them just as you expect from a fine Dogpatch restaurant. Lunch is mediocre, but dinner dishes are quite well crafted. Best part? Menu changes everyday, so you can try something new with every visit! Very fresh, indeed.

But the best part? It's right next to Mr/Mrs. Misc. for dessers ;)
author: Rui R.

description:
Really yummy place to go to for brunch! The brunch menu is relatively small (5 or 6 items), but what they do have, they do well. 

Their Egg Sandwich with fried potatoes was really tasty. It comes with their homemade biscuit (which i subbed for their sourdough bread - just to cut calories/fat), dill aioli, arugula and a deliciously runny sunny side up egg.

All of their food is either organic and/or from local farms, another major plus! Service was friendly and hospitable. Ambiance was modern, but warm and welcoming. I can't wait to head down there for happy hour as they have all four flavors of Hanger One Vodka - yum!
author: Rana A.

description:
Yummy, solid, New American restaurant! Came here with some friends for a burger since it's on the 7x7 top 20 burgers in the city list. 

Between the 3 of us, we split the Prather Ranch burger with American cheese, another burger with Blue cheese and the fresh egg pappardelle pasta, which was actually my favorite.  The pasta came with dungeness crab, a creme fraiche sauce, cara cara oranges, and some herbs.  So tasty, but there could have been a bit more crab.  The pasta was also a bit on the bland side, but that was an easy fix with both salt and pepper.  My favorite part about the burger was the braed since it came on an acme roll.  The burger was cooked a perfect medium rare and good, but nothing to write home about I thought.  It may have been better with the blue cheese instead of the half I had, which was topped with American cheese.  

Service was great, waitress even made some recommendations.  I was so torn between choosing the crab pasta or the white bean cassoulet, with duck confit.  I will definitely be getting that next time, especially on a cold day.
author: Jenny W.

description:
So happy I finally tried this place! 
 
Pros: ambiance, service, food (pretty much everything)
Cons: waiting in the cold for the place to open (ok I know its not a legit con but I couldnt think of another con lol)
author: Natasha I.

description:
Food - gets an A++
Every time I come here, I have a fabulous meal. It's a bit of a trek to Dog Patch but so worth it. I went to Serpentine for brunch - I really wanted to try everything but I went with the red flannel hash - their version of corned beef hash. It was a hearty meal but there was the perfect amount of beef, hash along with roasted beets and arugula. I got the best of both worlds - meat/potatoes and veggies. The beef brisket was so tender. I don't want to forget my perfectly cooked poached eggs and this delicious levin bread. How can you mess up eggs - people do and my poached eggs were perfect. I'll have to make it a point to head out to Serpentine again very soon. The dinner menu is just as good too. 

Service - gets an A
Ambiance - gets an A

P.S. Easy parking
author: Jen R.

description:
I have eaten here twice. Once for dinner and the other time for brunch.

I wouldn't come back from dinner but I would def come back for brunch.
I just feel like the dinner choices were not that appealing.  On the other hand brunch was amazing.

Dinner: Salmon was just ok
Brunch: Chicken fried steak was amazeballs!
author: Anne-Mary P.

description:
One of the best dinners I've had in SF, ever.

Oysters, Calamari, Gnocchi(next time getting chicken), Scallops, Duck Liver Mousse, Cobbler and Ice Cream Sandwich, in addition to the quality service were all together far more superior than most dining experiences I've had here in the last 5 years.

I shall return.
author: Kevin O.

description:
We love Serpentine! Been here 3 times for dinner, and it's noisy, busy, hip. Because it's a super popular spot, be advised that you should make reservations at least a few days in advance.  I always book via OpenTable.com. The food and the service is excellent. In particular, Tommy, was our server all 3 times--he just rocks. Our water, bread, wine & drinks came within minutes. My wife and I also share dishes, so we generally always order a salad, then an appetizer or two and then split an entree. We've eaten the Shaved Salad, Little Gems Salad, Scallops, Prather Ranch Burger, Hanger Steak, Mary's chicken. Be forewarned though, if there is a big party of 6 or more, you may have to wait even if you had a reservation. This a small sized restaurant. 

We also love that you can find free parking within 2 blocks from the restaurant. We're going here for brunch next.
author: Al G.

description: Super-friendly maitre'd, attentive wait staffer, great cocktails. The braised Ox Tail with Gnocchi was truly genre defining: top of the braising game. Braise-tastic.
author: Mark S. I.

description: This is one of the best brunch places and the best thing of all is that there's always ample parking!  Haven't had anything on the menu that I didn't like.  It does get busy on the weekends for brunch, but definitely well worth the wait!
author: Lisa L.

description:
Everything on the menu is delicious but I'm in love with one dish and I get it every time I go to lunch here.. the Red Flannel hash is sooooo good. Juicy pieces of beef, greens, beets, some roasted potatoes sprinkled it and 2 eggs leave me satisfied and ready to take on the rest of my workday without a post lunch coma.  I can't get enough!

Serpentine can get busy at lunch but they take reservations if you have a large lunch outing.
author: Chrissy L.

description:
I decided to go to Serpentine for Mother's Day Brunch. I took my 1 1/2 year old son, my wife, my mother and mother-in-law. First they didnt have a booster seat for my son and I had to have him on my lap for 30 minutes before they could get the only one they have from another party. 

Secondly, the brunch was below average. Food was slightly cold and the benedict that I ordered had mediocre ham. 

I would go to PLOW any day over this place. Just 5 blocks away. The only stickler is that there are long lines to get a seat at PLOW.
author: Daniel M.

description: Don't really come out to Dogpatch neighborhood much, but after visiting Serpentine I think this area is definitely going to get more lovin. Really nice brunch spot and easy to find parking. Got the egg sandwich which was delicious, all the other dishes my friends ordered seemed pretty solid as well. Will definitely be coming back again!
author: C W.

description:
Multiple visits, most recent 9/12 dinner

Serpentine is sister restaurant of Slow Club. It's more spacious, with higher ceiling, but not as noisy. Menus are daily renewed and presented on little clip boards. 

On a previous visit during lunch, I had the arugula salad with grilled herb chicken breast. The blossom bluff stone fruit gave a nice citrusy kick to the salad.It also came with toasted hazelnuts, ricotta salata in a white peach and ginger vinaigrette. The only sauvignon blanc by the glass was a Bedrock Sonoma County. That was tasty but I'll prefer to have a French one by the glass.

For dinner I decided to try something different other than the oven roasted Mary's chicken---which was a very generous portion of half roasted chicken, crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. I had the house-made potato gnocchi with braised oxtail. Never been a fan or either so that was an outrageous diversion from my comfort zone. The braising  jus was very rich but tasty. 

My friend's hanger steak was very raw, almost bloody raw, not medium rare as he had requested. It was nonetheless good.

We skipped dessert because they served bi-rite ice cream. My friend had Mitchell's in mind so we went over there to get our treats instead.

Service could be a tad more attentive. The party of three next to us that arrived later had their appetizers and main courses before we did. We only caught up with them because we decided not to have desserts.

Dinner for two with wine $77
author: Matt Y.

description:
Nice place for lunch. Great atmosphere and great food. 
I went there several times and really enjoyed their salmon salad, cheeseburger and sandwiches.

Definitely a place I will come back!
author: caroline s.

description:
My brunch at Serpentine was...good, maybe just okay. I've heard a lot of good things about this venue and I think unfortunately that caused some hype to cloud my culinary expectations. My brunch was filled with ups and downs and that really gets to conclude that Serpentine was simply...(by SF standards)....average. Let me explain...

Food - 

The good: I ordered a great item on the menu: fried egg sandwich (buttermilk biscuit, fried egg, arugula, tomato). The pork sausage that I added for an  extra cost was very tasty and well-seasoned. The egg was cooked to my liking (overmedium) and the arugula really worked with all the other components of the dish. 

The bad: my pork sausage was undercooked. I cut open the medium-sized patty and the inside was undeniably pink. Now, i may not know a lot about cooking (as opposed to eating), but I am uncomfortable with pink centered pork. In addition to the undercooked sausage, I didn't like how they cut the tomatoes. They looked SO fresh, so tasty, and I really wanted to eat with the rest of my sandwich, but what was the problem? - they were not cut into thin slices like most tomatoes are for sandwiches. They were cut into thick wedges similarly to how they are presented in a salad. How am i suppose eat the tomato with the sandwich if the tomato cannot even be fit  between the two slabs of biscuit? :::confused:::: Cute, but not practical. 

Service - 

Average, maybe slightly disappointed. I had to almost ask twice for them to replace my undercooked pork. I referred my waitress to it and it was like she had to take a second glance to make sure I wasn't making something up. If a customer is providing a legitimate complaint, you need to honor that complaint without question. 

Overall, I'm glad I tried it b/c there was so much excitement about this venue's brunch. Now i'll be glad to bring my business elsewhere.
author: Nathan T.

description: First explored Serpentine for Easter brunch and it was a success! We began our meal with a freshly squeezed OJ and cappuccino which did not disappoint. The crab benedict was a delicious alternative to the traditional options. The pancakes were a sweet treat and a nice way to end the meal for the diner who ordered savory. If we could modify one thing it would be the biscuit, not a fan. Otherwise it's a great place!
author: Ula K.

description:
Never written a review? hmm. 

With Ancient Lemon Drop (real delicious fresh lemons used here) and a hamburger for lunch or dinner, or even breakfast (at 4 in the AM, post-anything-romping)...this place makes me so happy. Ahh, throw in calamari, and that should max out my happiness level for at least another 24 hours. Guaranteed
author: Carla Y.

description: Excellent brunch menu and service. Coffee was very fresh and the refills were hot.  The bacon is some of the best we have had in the city.  The interior is very nice and it has a great neighborhood feel.  We will definitely be back.  Seating is tight, but it is nice to chat with the other patrons.  The din is a little loud, but the music mix buffers it and makes for an all around energetic feel.
author: April M.

description:
Had a brunch date here several Sundays ago and while the venue is lovely, high exposed beam ceilings, iron cast stools,  and dark wood flooring, the service was just so so.

They weren't crazy busy with about 4 tables populated and yet it took us 20 minutes to be seated, as I saw some of the staff slicing bread in the back, laughing and chatting with coworkers, then coming back to us to tell us it'd just be a minute more.

But um... more than half the tables are empty in here? I'm not sure I understand...

Once we were finally seated, along with a group that came well after us, the other table received menus and water. While we just waited around, waiting...

Slightly annoyed and definitely famished we flagged the hostess down and made our order and asked for water. Drinks definitely needed to be part of brunch after the patience we've had to maintain. I had a bloody merry and followed up with a mimosa. Both drinks were worth their value, I assure you. 

Being already somewhat tipsy and my normal gluten self, I ordered the country fried steak and eggs. It was fairly tasty, but nothing that completely stands out and warrants another visit. 

The experience aside from all the wait time was not bad, and the prices affordable.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I been here a few months ago for brunch.  very good, typical brunch stuff.

but 5 stars when i came here last week and got that burger.  med rare perfection, juicy like crazy and no need to really chew and just swallow.  man so delicious...but what made it super crazy over the top was when we had the chicken livers, OMG that shit was amazing.  it had a hint of black bean chinese style flavor and damn it was crazy.  it was so good, we decided to cancel the roast chicken entree and just add another chicken liver.  and check this out, everyone should try this; i put a piece of chicken liver inside a bit of burger, OH SHIT chicken liver pranther ranch burger!!!  best meal i've had this year!!!  6 stars for my burger creation.  i told the chef!
author: Kevin L.

description: I've been wanting to check out brunch at Serpentine, but I ended up coming here for lunch. I ordered the ginger, lemongrass sandwich and the savory bread pudding, sadly it was just alright for me, I wasn't too impress with their lunch menu. I'm hoping brunch will be tastier.
author: Ennie L.

description:
We went here for dinner on Friday night and had a reservation bit still had to wait 20 minutes for a table. They had overbooked their tables. :( the manager felt bad and have us free drinks only because I'm 9+ months pregnant, and my husband complained that there was no place for me to sit. As for the food,
I enjoyed the roasted chicken out of all the dishes we had ordered. My burger was okay and could have passed on the pickled onions that came with it (I love Umami and Marlowe for burgers). This burger wasn't even close. The chocolate ganache we shared was also tasty. I liked how they added a chocolate toffee crunch to it. I've heard better things about brunch so I guess I'll give it another chance.
author: Elaine L.

description: Delicious pulled pork & polenta but the lamb sandwich had tasteless lamb and the "muffins" were a poorly executed hamburger bun. Orange juice isn't homemade either. Staff was OK,  a bit cold & hipstery.
author: Fabien-Pierre N.

description:
Is there anything bad about a leisurely weekday lunch of a burger and a beer?  Nope.

Food = 4.5  - Serpentine = Super tasty! I had the burger (with bacon and gruyere) and fries.  I washed my lunch down with a pint.  Then, I rounded out my lunch with one of their ginormous chocolate chip cookies.  My only complaint about my food is that I wish I ordered two of everything!

Service = 4.0 - Nice staff and timely service, even though all of the servers were hipsters.  

Atmosphere  = 4.0 - Light, airy and open floor plan.  Me likey!
author: Eddie L.

description:
Disclosure: I'm vegetarian (ok actually pescetarian)

Appetizer:
Goat milk's cheese plate. 3 stars. I've had way better.

Main:
House Made Potato Gnocchi with Dungeness Crab. 2 stars. Mainly tasted like butter.

+ Thumbs up for the very friendly bartender (bf and I sat at the bar)

Really happy they use produce and meat from "ecologically sound agriculture, whenever possible". 3.5 stars round down to 3. Boyfriend did like his Kashmiri Spiced Braised Lamb Shank and would probably rate Serpentine a solid 4.
author: Rebecca L.

description: What I like most about Serpentine are its industrial decor and chill vibe.  Of course, the food here is quite delicious as well.  For brunch, we ordered the Red Flannel Hash (beef brisket, roasted beets, potatoes, horseradish créme fraiche, poached eggs, and grilled levain) and Savory Bread Pudding (ham, gruyere, caramelized onions, asparagus, poblano peppers, carrot, nettles, and greens); both were amazing.  The portion sizes are perfect; I did not leave feeling over-stuffed or under-fed.  Even though our entrees used a lot of cheeses, creams, and eggs, they did not taste heavy at all, but actually quite healthy!  With easy street parking in Potrero Hill, I will definitely be back again and again...maybe even to just get the I-actually-found-parking-in-S.F. high once in awhile.
author: Ally W.

description:
The brunch here is phenomenal!

Here's the skinny:

Dungeness crab benedict: using the freshest ingredients, this dish is exceptional.  Its served on levatin, layered with sauteed spinach, perfectly poached eggs, and topped with the right amount of Hollandaise, fried capers and a lightly breaded and fried piece of shaved fennel. Its accompanied with a shaved fennel salad.  Who knew fried capers and breaded fennel would be so good?

Prather Ranch hamburger: This burger ranks up there with the best.  A definite competitor with my tried and true Father's Office burger.   No cheese was needed in this juicy treat.  Topped with arugula, house-made pickles, and pickled onions on buttered brioche, this burger hit the spot.   I now believe pickled onions are the perfect accoutrement to any burger.  I move to make this the standard. 

Coupled with some delicious house cocktails, this made La journée parfaite!
author: Francine S.

description:
Parking is a bitch. Can I say "bitch"? Took us half an hour to find a spot. AKA Half the time it took us to eat.

I entered the restaurant grouchy and thinking, "This place had better be worth it." For the most part, it was. The trendy interior reminded me of the restaurants in Portland that were similarly renovated from old warehouses. The atmosphere was laid-back, and, oh my goodness, how much did I love listening to '90s pop and R&B! The music seemed a little out of place, but I haven't heard 112 for the longest time, so whatever.

I don't know about dinner, but lunch prices are very reasonable. My oxtail pappardelle was delicious, and the sandwiches were hearty. I especially liked the (very meaty) pork shoulder sandwich.

If I'm feeling up to brave the parking challenge again, I'd love to try dinner here. I could imagine the place looks so romantic at night.
author: Kym M.

description: Ok, I've been here twice and I'm feeling like I'm missing something. Our friends love love love this place for brunch. They rave about everything, especially the red flannel hash and the smoked salmon Benedict. I've tasted both and felt that they were ok, but nothing too special...I tried the steak and eggs this time and it was meh. The breading from the steak fell off the steak and looked liked someone picked through it before coming to me. Also had the buckwheat pancakes and that was good, but not memorable. Given that the wait here is long, I wouldn't rush to return for just mediocre food.
author: Ava C.

description:
This place never fails to disappoint. 

But then again, my poor student wallet limits me to ordering the $12 Prather Ranch Burger every time I am there before walking out the door several dollars lighter before entry.

Highlights:
- Intimate ambience
- Excellent service
- Fresh, local ingredients used in the meals 

Do:
- bring a date, or go solo (which I have done in the past)
- make a reservation ahead if you plan to bring a party
- show up for the brunch and order the red flannel hash
author: Camie K.

description:
Neat little place in the Dog Patch.

Went on a Sunday afternoon with friends and got seated in about 30 min (not too shabby). The venue itself is pretty snazzy with lots of light, and that lofy, warehouse-y with some rustic/home-country flair.

1. LOVE their coffee. meant to ask who they use but forgot :\ 
2. fresh grapefruit juice was delicious (ruby reddd)
3. Baked Eggs: so so, i was not a big fan of the cornbread that accompanied. The baked eggs itself was a bit underwhelming and not flavorful enough.

With that said, Serpentine didn't blow me out of the water with their brunch, however I think I'd be down to return just to check out some of their drinks. We sat at the bar in front of the bartender, and kept seeing all these delicious intricate drinks being sent out.

Bottom line: Neat place, great service, "ok" brunch, delicious-looking bevvies.
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description: This review is for brunch only. I came here with two friends on Saturday and got seated within 15-20 mins. I got the smoked salmon benedict or something like that and it was okay.. I felt that the smoked salmon was already quite salty so why the hell would there be hella capers added?! I think the capers were too much and just made me really thirsty. Do not think I will be back for brunch but i do wanna try dinner!
author: Jessica C.

description:
I took my girlfriend here for her birthday (was recommended by a friend) and we loved it. We showed up a touch later than our reservation, but still managed to get a nice cozy corner table for us to sit at. The food was amazing, our server was a doll!

I would highly recommend Serpentine to anyone wanting a casual yet fancy evening of delicious foods.
author: C M.

description: Great lunch spot. I had their lunch special with grilled cod and cherry tomatoes and it was super delicious.
author: Nadia A.

description: Been back twice. Very good, highly recommended however do go early to avoid the long wait times in the weekends.
author: Brian T.

description:
Excellent. Excellent. Excellent.  Came with my husband and sister-in-law for a birthday dinner.  The menu is full of seasonal ingredients, so everything had great flavor and was very fresh. We ordered:

Spring Carrot Salad - it was quite acidic, but I love vinegar and acidic flavors, so I didn't mind. 

Crispy Brussels Sprouts - PERFECT

Cured meat platter - my husband was a little disappointed with the size, but I was happy with it, because come on - its a platter of saturated fat!  So it was an appropriately moderate size. Comes with toasted bread rubbed with garlic. The chicken liver mousse was to DIE for and it was my favorite part of the platter. But it is small, so if you have more than 3 people in your party, it's not perfect for sharing. 

Lamb shank - very tender, not super gamey, flavorful sauce. It came with quinoa, which was a surprise. Normally braised meat dishes come with mashed potatoes, which is always delicious, but it can be quite heavy. So the quinoa kept the dish light and, of course, more nutritious. 

Petrale Sole - needed more acid, so I could have asked for a slice of lemon but I just decided to enjoy it as is. It got cold pretty quickly, so I don't think it was piping hot when it came out. But the fish was perfectly cooked and the sauce was a beautiful bright green and very tasty. 

Gnocchi with Crab - this was my least favorite dish. The gnocchi was light and airy, but the sauce had this strange flavor I just did not enjoy. Grapefruit and fennel?  With crab?  It tasted... Weird. That's all I can say. 

For dessert:

Lemon Buttermilk Cake with Huckleberry Sauce - OH. MYYYYYYY.  GOSH. Incredible dessert. The texture of the cake was ridiculous. So airy and light. Did they steam it? I am still amazed how they did that. The lemon curd on top was a little eggy. And I wish there was more huckleberry sauce.  But that's ok, it was still a delicious dessert.

Strawberry Mascarpone Tart - compared to the lemon cake, this was not as sweet, and that was actually brilliant because it was nice to go back and forth between the two.

But if I had to pick just one dessert to order again, it would DEFINITELY be the lemon buttermilk cake. 

The service was very good. The place was jam packed, even at our 8:00 reservation, but we never felt neglected. If you don't like noisy or dim restaurants, then don't come here. But I enjoyed the ambiance, it's very intimate, the music was good. I would definitely recommend this place for a third date, when you don't need to talk as much and you feel more relaxed with each other. 

Definitely coming back here!  There were so many things I didn't get to try so I'm excited to return and sample more things.
author: Maya A.

description:
The boyfriend and I came here after dropping off food we collected at our holiday party at the SF Food Bank.  I LOVE LOVE LOVE the space . I love the exposed brick walls, the high exposed beams, it was such a warm and inviting feeling.  They nailed it on atmosphere, in my opinion.  It was a perfect brunch feeling.

I ordered the fried egg sandwich and the pomegranate lemonade.  Delicious!  I do kind of wish the egg was a little more runny, but I guess that would have also made it ridiculously messy.   The lemonade was phenomenal.  I was a little obsessed with watching the bartender mix drinks and squeeze lemons and do everything he was doing.  I was very impressed at his meticulousness.

The boyfriend ordered the baked eggs, and it wasn't what he was expecting when he brought out the dish, but he proclaimed that it was incredibly delicious and fulfilling.

We're not really brunch people.  We don't often go out for brunch, but if there were more places like this for brunch, we'd definitely make it a weekly habit.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
The bloody mary is delicious!  They have a great  liquor selection at the bar.  For food, I ordered the "baked eggs" it was so good!  

I recommend you make a reservation if you can. We didn't and the wait time was 45 minutes. We walked over to Piccino Coffee Bar and the hotstess was nice enough to give us a call when our seats opened. We were already walking back when our seats were ready.  Most definitely recommend.
author: Norma A.

description:
One of my favorite places to eat in SF. Why? 
1. Chris the bartender rocks out amazing cocktails.
2. You can always get the freshest California cuisine.
3. Their burger rocks.
4. Really good prices.
5. What else do you need.
author: Gabriela H.

description: Here is the deal...best buckwheat pancakes ( but request for fruit to be cooked inside the pancakes for better melding of flavors) in the city bar none and best quality maple syrup and bacon.   However, I have yet to come across a more inattentive, inexperienced and unprofessional rude waitstaff in all of my many years of dining out and having worked in the industry for many years.  This restaurant has incredible potential but they would need an entirely new wait staff to be hired to make them worthy of repeat visits.
author: Mary W.

description: I went here with a girlfriend and it was perfect. The bartender suggested a delicious bottle of wine for us. My burger was amazing!!! It was crowded when we went and the tables are close together but it didn't feel loud or hectic, just popular because it's so good.
author: Rachel M.

description:
NYE Dinner 2012.
I would give this place 5 stars if it had seemed a bit more organized time wise.
My recommendation is come in at the time of your reservation or 5 minutes after. If you are early (even a few minutes) you will wait at the bar to get a drink and settle your bill therefore getting you to your table 20 minutes later than your reservation pushing their schedule back a bit. We were told when we got to our table that they had a reservation for that spot at 7:30 (it is now 6:20) so we felt a bit rushed. When 7:00 rolled around and we had just gotten our entrees we mentioned to our server that we were feeling this way and asked if perhaps he could move us to another place.  He didn't know that we were told our table had a so called expiration time. He made us feel comfortable by telling us we have time and ended up telling us we had until 8:00 PM. Funny thing was, we left the place at 7:45, if we had been seated right at 6 and ordered our drinks at the table, this wouldn't have happened. 

The food was AMAZING. I would come here again knowing the key to getting to your table on time and not feeling rushed. Amateur mistake from the child of a Marine who has to always be on time or early or her stomach hurts. Our server was out of this world, very efficient, light conversation and super cute.  The drinks are classic cocktails with a modern spin and are made by bartenders that know how to make drinks.

Meal highlights:
::  Rome Beauty Apple Salad - sharp cheddar, spiced pecans and perfectly dressed
::  Swordfish - so light and tender, not heavy and steaky like some swordfish, clams on the side were perfect.
::  Lemon Buttermilk Cake - need I say more? If there is a lemon dessert on the menu, that is what I am getting and this made me feel like I was floating on a lemon island.
::  Bourbon dessert drink with coffee beans on top made the ride home a lot more fun!

Recommended for a date night for sure!
author: Katie S.

description: Red flannel hash was mouth watering. Bicyclette refreshing. Would have been 5 stars but the service was luke warm and slow. Nevertheless, I will have to go back for the hash, my God, that hash! Maybe our server was having a bad day
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Dinner here was pretty good.

Not recommended for brunch. We ordered the salmon (too salty and fishy) and the country fried steak. Too much butter or milk made it rich and hard to eat. Potatoes were good.
author: E T.

description:
Super cute place!  I came here with a friend to grab a quick bite at the bar.  We ended up sharing the burger, and both of us were impressed with the quality.  The patty was thick and juicy.  Yum!!  The seasoning wasn't too overwhelming and complemented the meat well.   The fries that came with it were also perfectly salted and crunchy.  

I wasn't a huge fan of the blossom bluff salad.  The toasted hazelnuts were great in the salad, but the champagne vinaigrette was too overwhelming.  Get it on the side.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Fourth visit, 1st time for brunch. wonderful as always. Had the red flannel hash. num!
(this really happened back in May, discovered it was not published)
author: Cat R.

description: Brunch was okay--wasn't very memorable. For all the brunch places you can try in SF, I'd probably skip this one. Let me be clear--it wasn't bad at all, but to me, it was just okay. I'd prob rather try other places before I come back (or suggest this). I do love the setting of this place though.
author: Diana Y.

description:
i was hoping for amazing things here given all of the reviews. maybe its because we went for dinner instead of brunch but the food was underwhelming, the lighting was way too bright for dinner (making the vibe less than ideal) and prices were too high for what we were getting. 

will try again for brunch one day but definitely don't recommend for dinner.
author: Nadine H.

description:
Another solid brunch place, love that they have brunch on Saturdays. A group of us were going to the Crushpad event and Serpentine was conveniently located down the street.

We ordered:

Strawberry Buckwheat Pancakes - toasted walnuts, whipped cream and maple syrup. Oh my. I didn't know what to expect from the buckwheat pancakes but these were fluffy and damn good. The real whipped cream was heavenly.  

Alaskan Sockeye Salmon Benedict - poached eggs, avocado, bernaise, fennel salad , corn bread and crispy potatoes.  I had a bite of this and it was quite good - poached eggs were just right, corn bread just a little bit crispy on top and the crispy potatoes - PERFECTION. I haven't had potatoes like that in a while - perfectly fried and NOT OILY. That's a big deal for me.

Baked Eggs  - grilled squash, cerry tomatoes, spinach, rosemary, lemon ricotta and corn bread.  I loved my baked eggs, this came in a round baking dish.  Eggs were sunny side up with a medley of veggies underneath. The rosemary was used sparingly which was great.

Everything was delicious, service was friendly and accommodating.  This was my first time in the Dogpatch neighborhood and now there are two reasons for me to be back - Serpentine and Crushpad!
author: Nette T.

description:
Went here with a pretty large group about 2 weeks ago and were able to land a seat on a Sunday at 12 in 15 minutes. Score.

We ordered a majority of the menu amongst the 8 of us since they do have a smaller menu. Everyone seemed really happy with their dishes overall and I did thoroughly enjoy the buckwheat pancakes + a standard scamble with toast. The granola was also a stand-out in my book.

Also, their decor was just wonderful. Very modern with soft lighting, brick walls, and metallic contrasts. Absolutely loved it.
author: Raina B.

description: Came here for brunch on a Saturday. Very quick service and amazing atmosphere. The polenta and eggs is delish and the sayulita sunset is to die for. Will be coming back soon!
author: Ana J.

description:
Serpentine has a scrumptious and creative brunch menu offering unique dishes. However this place might get crowded, and with such a limited seating, I recommend you better make a reservation. I tried their crab benedict and it was quite yummy with a generous amount of crab meat. I can tell that the crab is fresh because it's moist and not too flaky. And not to forget the oozing poached eggyolks. YUM!

My friend had the red flannel hash and the other had the savory bread pudding. The savory bread pudding is something to be craving for a few days after that brunch morning. Other than the popular duo of Mimosa and Bellini, Serpentine has more morning boozes to offer you. Check out their brunch menu and you'll see what I mean. Service is efficient, and coffee refills kept coming.
author: Rika P.

description:
I'm so digging this neighborhood, just hope it stays that way. Love the street parking. Love that the saloon and wine bar are just across the street. Love the rustic warehouse ambiance. It's very open with high ceilings (maybe they'll expand with a loft, lots of dead space) so it's a bit loud when busy but the staff is super friendly and approachable. 
Chickpea battered calamari was delicious. Lupini beans had a good flavor but is an acquired texture (crispy.) Ancient Lemon, Hibiscus Fizz and the Fall Back were all great drinks. The latter being a bit spiced with cinnamon but not overwhelming, made for a very unique drink. Do not forgo dessert. As simple as an ice cream sandwich sounds, it's heavenly. Freshly baked cookies with a subtle banana ice cream, topped with caramel sprinkled in toffee pieces. Even if you are not hungry, you'll devour this in no time flat.
author: Naomi K.

description:
Lunch Review.

+++ Red Flannel Hash - brisket, beets, greens, poached egg - 5 stars

+++ Tuna sandwich - Gruyere cheese, pickled jalapenos - 5 stars

+++Prather Ranch Hamburger -acme roll - arugula - pickled red onions - bread & butter pickles - french fries - 4 stars

I have only had lunch here(take out & eat in).
The service is ok, but the food is always good.
Flannel Hash is amazing.
author: Alyjaa S.

description:
I saw that this place was nominated for one of the 10 best burger places in the 7x7 magazine so we stopped by, but they seem to be more known for their breakfast/brunch that we quickly noticed that we were the only ones ordering a burger.  The server was very friendly and attentive in refilling our drinks.  The food took awhile, but it was definitely worth the wait!!!  

The burger came with pickled red onions, pickles, and greens.  I added swiss cheese to it, which was an additional charge.  As soon as it arrived, my mouth just watered!  The burger came with a mound full of fries, which was really addicting too.  It had to have been a 1/2 lb. burger as it was definitely bigger than what I would normally eat at the Counter.  I still can't believe I finished the whole burger!  Definitely have to go back for it!
author: Erica S.

description:
It was a Saturday morning and we were somewhat hungover ... after debating whether to get burgers or the oxtail plate from across the street, we went with Serpentine. I did get the burger and my friend got the braised rabbit over polenta. I've been hearing about the burger alot, so I was dying to try it. Now .... 
1. The meat was super juicy/watery, which made it soft and tender
2. Unfortunately it caused the bread to be all wet and soggy, which made the whole thing fall apart. I like my bread a little crunchy.
3. Pickled vegetables and the pickle was ok. Not a huge fan of it, just had a weird taste to it

Overall .... Umm... it was ok. The fries were pretty good at least.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to explore the Dogpatch for a perfect romantic anniversary date, idea courtesy of the folks at 7x7 (http://www.7x7.com/love-sex/8-solid-first-date-ideas). When he called to make a reservation the day of, he was told that it was all booked up, BUT the nice guy on the phone said that he could reserve a table usually saved for walk-ins in the front. Dinner was set for 8:30. 

We get there at 8:25, table wasn't ready yet. No problem, since the vibe of the place was perfect: we're both New Yorkers, and this place definitely had that kind of thing going for it. The hostess was extremely apologetic for the delay, but since the people at our table weren't moving, there was nothing she could do.

After about 45 minutes, we get shown to a table, and it's a real table, not the ones in the front of the place that are reserved for walk-ins -- sweet! And to top it off, the waitress sent over two glasses of champagne and a free appetizer of calamari. I don't even like calamari, but I couldn't get enough of these. Seriously, order the calamari. 

I really don't remember what else we ordered (because this night is already a few months ago), but I remember that it was great, including dessert. The whole experience was so incredible that I will definitely venture to the Dogpatch more willingly in the future.
author: Cynthia S.

description:
Dogpatch has come a long way from the days of dogs (which also Yelp in a sense) sniffing out discarded slaughterhouse waste as the only good eat in the hood!  By the same folks that brought us Slow Club comes Serpentine.  Palate pleasing dining, fancy cocktails and a gentrifying crowd make it worth the stop in if you ever do make it out to Dogpatch!

Gascon Style Duck Sausage: The combo of white beans and sausage was hearty, like an ad hoc cassoulet.  I was expecting more a complex confit-like flavor, but it just turned out to be more sausage-tasting than duck-tasting.  Still satisfying.

House Made Potato Gnocchi: Also hearty and so homemade tasting.  A very light sauce of garlic, cheese, mushroom and nettles.  Hit the spot for comfort food with some personality.  

French Fries: Good, but then again, it's not that hard of a side since you just need to make them crispy.

Salted Caramel Pot De Crème: Everyone is getting on the salted caramel bandwagon!  They took the approach of mixing it all together in one uniform crème.  I would have preferred the salt granules to have been separate so to be more expected and pronounced.
author: Adam B.

description: Had a fabulous meal. We enjoyed the duck and a flat iron steak. Service was excellent. They also make a great Manhattan. The space is a bit noisy, but we were still able to have a conversation.
author: David P.

description:
I went here the first time after I moved nearby and I was blown away.  The food was amazing, the drinks were amazing, and the service stellar.  It was so good I was dreaming of the chicken dish I had days after I left.  I went back a week later with some friends who typically never set foot in the Dogpatch/Potrero area, but did this time because I had been raving like a lunatic about how good this place was.   Well, Serpentine didn't disappoint because my friends really enjoyed it.  

One thing I noticed on the second visit was just how expensive this place is.  I understand its San Francisco, but the place has a warehouse feel and is located in the less expensive (rent wise) area of the Dogpatch among industrial buildings.  I don't expect them to lower their prices because judging by the amount of people in their restaurant each night they have no reason to.  I think the cheapest way to enjoy Serpentine is to go in for their delicious burger along with a beer.  You can do that for under $20.  

Also, if you are not worried about the extra fat that builds around your mid section, you will definitely want to try their desserts.  They have dessert which I am in love with.  Its got two cookies on the outside and ice cream in the middle (forgot what they called it).  Its amazing.  I'm afraid of eating though because if I do I will want it everyday.  For now I stay away for my own good.
author: Ash S.

description:
This is a place I have wanted to try for awhile.  It is one of those neighborhood restaurants in SF that doesn't really stand out on paper.  There seem to be 100 Serpentine like restaurants in SF.  It is so hard to work my way through the list.  I am glad I finally checked out Serpentine.

The decor has a great industrial vibe, but it still comes off as very SF in style.  Pretty cool.

This place reminds me a lot of Nopa.

This place has the best burger in all of SF so far.

My previous favorites were Nopa, Mission Beach, and 4505 meats.  This burger beats them all in my opinion.

It comes with house made pickles and house pickled onions.  The meat was prather ranch, which is an all grass feed beef.  For some reason, the beef had a nice fatty richness to it that I am accustomed to with grain fed beef.  It was seasoned perfectly.  I find most burgers to be under seasoned for my taste, but this was right on.  
I ordered my burger medium rare, and for the first time in SF, it came out medium rare.  Most times I order medium rare and it comes out Medium.  Medium is a great way to enjoy a burger, but sometimes I prefer medium rare, and no place at SF has managed to deliver except this place.

I typically add mustard to my burger, but because the burger had pickled onions, I decided against it.  There was enough "acid" on the burger without the mustard.   

I opted for blue cheese instead of cheddar.  The blue cheese was from cowgirl creamery and it was heavenly.  I havne't had a burger with this quality of blue cheese in a long time.  Despite having a lot of blue cheese on the burger, I was suprised that I couldn't really taste it on some bites.  When I did taste it,.....WOW! 

I had a nice, big,  (perhaps jammy) Zin to go with my perfect burger.  
It was a winning combination. 

Aside from possibly dry aging the beef to get a more intense flavor and perhaps adding a bit more blue cheese, I would say this is the perfect burger (for my tastes). The addition of bacon would have detracted from the other flavors IMHO.

We had some calamari as well.  Calamari is a common dish that is not that exciting anymore, but Serpentine found a way to make it interesting again.  They breaded it with chickpeas to give it a unique texture, and they also made it with a broth that had a fair bit of acid in it (lemon juice maybe?).  It was a great dish and I really enjoyed it.

We also had sweetbreads.  It is rare that a place like this would even offer sweetbreads as an appetizer. The sweetbreads were very good.  

Overall, this place was great and I would come back again. 

I wouldn't say it is better than Nopa, but if you live around dogpatch, it offers a solid alternative.
author: Jeremy R.

description: Great place for brunch but service is a bit slow and luke warm (they are not rude but hardly a smile). You will still have to wait a little bit even with a reservation but I do like their food selection, ambiance and local ingredients.
author: Maggie C.

description:
I love a fuss-free brunch in the city. Easy parking, no wait, great space, wholesome food. Have yet to try their lunch/dinner menus. 

Their fried egg sandwich is always a favorite with a good balance of protein (runny yolk!) and greens. The crispy potatoes on the sides are indeed crispy on the outside, fluffy inside. Yum. Another egg dish winner is their dungeness crab benedict. Definitely generous with the crab. The shaved fennel on the side is also a nice accompaniment. 

Even their salads are substantial. Last time I got the red leaf lettuce with watermelon radish, avocado, and tomatoes. Get the levain bread on the side (from acme!). Comes with some wonderful strawberry jam and butter. 

Don't let the savory bread pudding go cold! Last time when I was here with a group, we ordered one to share and no one touched it till we were done with our own food and by that time it lacked a little luster.
author: Annie W.

description:
Serpentine....a super cool, uber industrial, concrete box of a place with an airy quality of...yadayada whatever!  I'll spare you the affectations and such of my usual writing style and get to the point:

Deepak Kaul is the best chef in the City and here's why:

He seasons his food with something OTHER than salt and pepper.   Herbs, alliums, exotic spices, you name it, he uses it liberally and well. Everything that guy touches is flavorful, from the marinated olives to the buckwheat pancakes at brunch. Everything is well thought out, balanced and delicious!  This is what happens when you get a man of color running the kitchen!

Plus he's gorgeous, which has nothing to do with the food, of course.

Service overall is great, and love the bartenders, especially Chris, Andrew and that cutie Fred! 

I'm done....
author: Candace W.

description:
"Sorry, the kitchen is closed"

?!?  Must. Have. Dessert. 

*slides into a bar stool*

"We just want some dessert" 

*bats eyelashes*

Minutes later, sinking teeth into oatmeal-gingersnap ice cream sandwich, sipping a cappuccino, *sigh*. That's more like it.

Serpentine is a sure thing and a neighborhood stand-by.

It'll be there for you the next morning to cure your ache and pains with fresh breakfast cocktails and dare I say artisan, corn beef hash. Big chucks of tender beef, heavenly fried chunks of potato and an occasional vegetable.
On less indulgent mornings, opt for the baked eggs.
Nearing noon when you're hankering for something hefty, steak 'n eggs.

The service (nor the concrete and cold steel space) doesn't show too much of a soft side but they get it done.
author: Alissa A.

description: Yummy everything from the bartender Paul to the Arcadian cocktail to the country dried steak and eggs , rabbit, red hash, pancakes.  Everything was top notch. Come for the food. Stay for the bartender and cocktails
author: Jerry W.

description:
Definitely a great spot and great experience!

AMBIANCE 
- Great atmosphere. Interior is more industrial, but they manage to pull off a warm, friendly, and inviting environment. Noise levels let you know you're not alone, but somehow there's still an intimate feel to your table.

SERVICE 
- excellent service. attentive and knowledgeable about the drinks and food.

FOOD 
- this was my 2nd time here, and while the food was good, it wasn't great this time around. 

TIPS 
- fries are a must!
- try as many drinks as possible.
- gnocchi was soft.
- sea bass had unmet potential
- roasted chk was unmemorable.
- get the burger!

i would repeat visit for the overall experience of great drinks, environment, and decent food.
author: Good U.

description:
It took me 3 visits to write my review, but I think I'm finally ready! Serpentine has very recently become our neighborhood go-to restaurant. We are in Mission Bay to their Dogpatch,but it's a walkable distance and helps us burn off some of those indulgent calories.

Though it's not really a burger joint, Serpentine has to have the best burger in town, and I don't say that lightly. In fact I would put them ahead of Father's Office (LA) and Umami Burger (LA). If you've been to either of those you'll know what I'm talking about! The patty is lightly seasoned and perfectly cooked to your chosen temperature. Topped with thinly sliced bread and butter pickles, pickled onions, arugula, tomatoes and your choice of cheese- blue is fantastic. The bun is soft and very lightly toasted, not heavy, or too crusty. This burger needs no condiments. It's really that good.

Also noteworthy:
Lamb belly 
Calamari
Gnocchi 

I'll have to politely disagree with the naysayers, the staff are very friendly, attentive, organized, and accommodating. Both the servers and bartender answer questions about the food accurately and intelligently, and make appropriate wine pairing recommendations. Fantastic beer selection.

They do take reservations, and I would recommend them if you plan on dining later and prefer a table. We arrived at 9pm last night (Tues) to a packed house, and waited about 15 minutes for a seat at the bar. Not a problem for us, and we had great service.

Last night's bill: Calamari, 2 burgers, 1 wine, 1 beer came to just under $60.
author: Carnley P.

description: I expected more from Serpentine, my friends had raved about it, but they'd only ever been here for breakfast. Last night we double dated for dinner. Even though we had a nice time and the food was good, I wasn't impressed with the restaurant. It's terribly overpriced for what you get. I won't likely return, at least not for dinner, perhaps just for cocktails. Speaking of, I ordered the Vista, and mmm mmm, it was worth the $11. I can't say the same for the small plates we ordered. The cheeseboard appetizer was tasty, but sharing the miniature-sized portions between 4 people was a joke. We liked the seared padron peppers side dish, but they tasted the same as what I make at home for a lot less than $8. Two of us received generous platings of our mains: oven roasted chicken, and the hamburger w/blue cheese and bacon. I had the burger, so I can attest that is was very good. $20 good?? I suppose, I wasn't unhappy with my choice. However, our two vegetarians each ordered the ravioli, and their sad little servings really shocked us. Also, the ravioli wasn't that great (reminding us of that classic Annie Hall joke "the food is terrible...and such small portions!") Well, the ravioli wasn't terrible, it just wasn't anything to rave about, and for $18, it should have been. Finally we ordered desserts, and the chocolate cake with ice cream definitely did not disappoint. Delicious. I wish they'd remembered to bring me the decaf coffee I'd ordered along with it. But that's the only ding on what was otherwise super-attentive and friendly service. The last thing I want to mention is that the noise level in this restaurant is ri di cu lous. I was hoarse after two hours of trying to converse with my friends, the din is nightclub level. Don't come here if you want to have a relaxing chat over dinner, Serpentine is not the environment for that.
author: Christine C.

description:
I was really excited to come here for brunch, but was sadly, very very disappointed.

Came on a Saturday around noon, and was told there would be a 45-60 minute wait for two people. They ask for your phone number to call when your table is ready, but I decided to stand right outside on the ramp. Luckily we didn't have to wait that long, and she came out and called me by another name. When I told her that wasn't me (I didn't want to take someone else's table), she asked for my name, and told me she just called me. It was weird to me that they don't call out the name to the crowd outside before calling the number. My phone was tucked away and I didn't hear it. Anyways, no big deal, then we were seated at a cute little booth.

I got the Baked Eggs (two eggs, spiced garbanzo beans, rapine, mushrooms, and green salsa) and a Buckwheat Pancake. The baked eggs came with a few thick slices of bread with butter. The bread was SO HARD. I seriously had to gnaw at it so hard, my friend started laughing at me because I looked RIDICULOUS. She even asked why I was still trying to eat it. The baked eggs weren't good, either. It just tasted weird.. Sour, almost. When I drenched the food in hot sauce and egg yolk, it was bearable. Safe to say, I didn't finish it. I don't like my brunch sour tasting. The buckwheat pancakes came topped with whipped cream, a couple pieces of pineapple, strawberry, bananas, and walnuts. Whipped cream on pancakes? Isn't it usually butter? Unless it was a sweet pancake, I'd expect butter on it. And buckwheat...... I guess I've never had buckwheat because it was disgusting! I ate all the fruit and took a tiny piece of the pancake dunked in syrup, and it was DISGUSTING. I can't even describe the taste, but I took a bite of my sour baked eggs to get rid of the taste in my mouth.

Not only was my meal disappointing, the service was seriously lacking. After we were served, the waitress did not come back in the hour and a half we were there. Not once. Everyone that came in after us were already gone. There were moments of eye contact when I was about to ask for a box (for my sad pancake I thought my dad might like) and the check, but they just turned around and walked away before I could say anything. Another 10 minutes went by, still nothing. Finally got the attention of one of the girls, but she decided to begin taking the order of the table of 12 next to us. Waved down another one of the waitresses and asked for a box and the check. She boxed the food, came back. No check ... Waited another 10 minutes and they FINALLY, very nonchalantly, brought the check. No eye contact. No thank you. Good thing we didn't park in metered parking.

Disappointed. I won't be coming back.
Luckily, Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous is right across the street!
author: Jaime H.

description:
Cocktail menu was quite interesting. I had the scallops and my friend had the duck... both executed very well.

My only complaint is how loud this place is. The high concrete ceilings create an echo chamber. Some sound dampening elements could really help.
author: Ty V.

description:
Oh bomb diggity, hello there Serpentine.

Went here for brunch with my lovely friend and we had a fantastic time.  Yes, we had to make a reservation, yes we were squeezed into a corner table where I was basically sitting on a baby's lap... but it was fun nonetheless.

The drinks were pretty strong I might say... or we could just be two lightweight Asian girls on a Sunday morning.  The mimosa and bellini were perfecto.

Bread Pudding: AMAZE.  I don't even know what bread pudding really is, but it was darn good.  I definitely got a winner for this one.  The melted, crusty cheese on top was just beyond.

Baked Eggs:  My friend got that one, she liked it.  I didn't even have time to look up from my alcohol or my bread pudding to try any.  

Overall:  I loved it, but a $70 brunch, I can only do once every 3 months.
author: Isabella O.

description:
Sepentine was amazing! Everything from the easy to find parking, modern decor and of course the food! My boyfriend and I got the biscuits and gravy, Dungeness Crab Benedict and Braised Rabbit & Polenta. Wow, the crab was like fresh from the sea and the tempura fried lemon on top was a nice surprise. I've never had polenta so easy and soft before and even the biscuits and gravy were done in a way I've never tasted before.
