There is something definitely special about this place since I couldn't keep my eyes off of what everyone else around me was having. Definitely coming back here for more brunches!

Thanks to SF Weekly for their great recommendation and OpenTable for making easy reservations!
author: Caren K.

description: Great food and fun dog patch!  Woof Woof
author: Michael A.

description: Oxtail was very well cooked.  I like the atmosphere and setting; old warehouse.
author: Frank G.

description:
Finally came back to get the Red Flannel Hash. DELICIOUS! YUMMY! 
I am not sure which I like more - the hash, bread pudding, or burger - I love you all. Only lackluster item was the cornbread side order - kinda bland and dry. But that's okay, everything else is more than heavenly. Serpentine, you are still one of my absolute favorite brunch spots. I love you.
author: Veronica H.

description:
I heard a lot of good reviews from people about this place in the Dogpatch. The place was very crowded when I walked by earlier at 7pm on the way to a meeting nearby. My group was starving after our meeting ended at 9:45pm. Thankfully the staff here was nice enough to take us in and entertain us before closing. 

I opted for a scrimshaw pilsner for drink, but they had an interesting list of cocktails that I'll have to come back to try. We shared the meat board of mixed charcuterie, coppa, salami, proscuitto, and olives.  I had the steak for my entree and and shared some sides (I forget). Everything was delicious, even though we were the last ticket in the restaurant.

During dinner the space is really dark; our table was lit by only a couple of tea lights. They were playing instrumental R&B and hip-hop beats in the background. It's a warm and cozy ambiance, but our party was actually trying to get some work done after our meeting earlier. Despite our attempt at productivity, we were thoroughly appreciative of Serpentine's service and atmosphere. I'd definitely come back for a proper and casual dinner.
author: Jermaine R.

description:
Brunch is my favorite meal because somehow it magically becomes acceptable to drink at 10 in the morning. And when what you're drinking is gin + elderflower + grapefruit + sparkling wine, well, that's a pretty great morning. 

What makes that morning even better? When you can pair that drink with a lovely little smoked salmon benedict that uses biscuits instead of English muffins and tops the stack of salmon/spinach/perfectly poached egg/Hollandaise with a crispy fried Meyer lemon. The potatoes and simple shaved fennel and greens salad that came alongside were also delicious, but seriously, that lemon. I had no idea lemons could be fried, let alone be fried to the absolute pinnacle of tastiness. I want to eat fried lemons all day e'ery day. AND YOU CAN'T STOP ME.
author: Corinna K.

description:
The food here was awesome.. Have been wanting to try this place fro sometime.. The burger looks great.. Figured I would go back and try it sometime. 

I had the lamb winch was a big cut of meat. Enough to share. The chicken liver was spicy and great flavor. 

Desserts look good but by that time we were already stuffed!! A definite try..
author: Mike S.

description: We were a large group with a baby and they were extremely accommodating! They even brought us some free pancakes because of a small wait! The food was amazing, not just mine but everyone else's that I snuck a bit of. The ambience is great and the prices is amazing to match too! I highly recommend this spot.
author: Kaitlin T.

description:
I thought the reviews about this place sounded great so I gave it a shot.  Needless to say, It was a bit of a turbulent experience.

First off, our server seemed a bit impatient.  He was helpful but he managed to pick up our tray of oysters before we were finished and picked up my girlfriends glass of wine when she clearly was not done as well.

Second, portions were lack luster and masked by the same sides on multiple dishes.  I ordered the salmon and they convinced me to order it "their" way.  Which I did.  It was cooked on the outside properly, but RAW in the middle.  I like my salmon tacky unless i'm getting sushi.  The gnocchi was good, but there was only  6 pieces on the plate and it was masked by the side of broccolini.  The same side I had on my plate as I mentioned earlier.  Some variety between sides would have been nice so that you don't feel like you're eating in a cafeteria.

Dessert was good.  Went with the ice cream sandwich and i loved it.

Overall, I may try this place out again.  I would have given 3 stars if I didn't feel like we were being rushed out of there  by our server and they would have been a little more descriptive on how they cook their salmon.  And selfishly, I like different side dishes cause I usually pick up the leftovers off my ladies dish and don't want to eat the same thing I already had.
author: Matthew B.

description:
Another SF gem in the dogpatch.

The food is always inventive and tasty and the cocktails are well made. I would rate this place along with Universal cafe as the two best places in SF to experience California cuisine.
author: Vijay S.

description: Had our monthly dinner club here a couple weeks ago and it was yum! I had the spring squash salad and the hanger steak! awwwwwwwwwwesome. We also got the calamari as an app and that was amazing! Would def go back! Good little hot spot for friends or date night!
author: Ricquel N.

description:
this review is about DINNER. 

HOLY MOTHAF-ING GNOCCHI. Pillowy, soft, melty, delicate gnocchi. These gnocchi had such a mystifying texture that pulled me in and I couldn't stop. The medley of flavors in the dish was divine - the mushrooms, grana padano, leeks all added to the heavenly flavor of the dish. I would eat this as my last meal. 

LEMON BUTTERMILK CAKE OF THE GODS. Literally sent down from heaven. Serpentine is the king of texture. I don't know what gave this cake its smooth and melty consistency, all I know is that as soon as this cake hits your tongue, you are transported to another planet. Throw your dessert inhibitions to the wind. This is the time to splurge. 


Other items on the menu were VERY good but it was the prior two that took this place to the top. Other wonderful items: 

BRAISED PORK OSSO BUCCO: Nice and hearty with a delicious lavender broth that caused everyone at the table to keep stealing bites off my plate! Keep yo hands to yoself!

CHICKPEA BATTERED CALAMARI: not totally awesome but a nice idea. 

PICKLED VEGETABLES: I REALLY enjoyed this dish. If you love all things pickled (as I do!), this is a great plate to get. 

SALMON: pretty boring. 

Can't wait to go back for round two. Sunday brunch, I'm a'comin.
author: Sylvie C.

description: Lunch today was amazing.  I had the Red Flannel Hash which includes  beef brisket - roasted beets - arugula - crispy potatoes - horseradish creme fraiche -  poached eggs & grilled levain.  I am not sure what that levain is but everything else was super tasty!  (maybe that was the bread thing?)  Well the beef was crumbling as I spiked my fork into it and the eggs were poached perfectly.  Then as we were wrapping up the stars of Mythbusters showed up...
author: Gene X.

description:
If I could only eat one brunch dish for the rest of my life, the red flannel hash at Serpentine would be it. Veggies at brunch (or in general, for that matter) typically don't enthuse me, but the roasted beets and fresh arugula in this dish are so flavorful, I could eat them by the bucketload and not once think about my usual bacon-and-eggs-dripping-with-grease brunch. Those yummy beets and arugula can hold their own, but combine them with crispy potatoes, beef brisket, two poached eggs, and toast triangles, and you've got the kind of dish that I'll scarf down Cookie Monster-style. The potatoes shatter on contact, the beef melts in your mouth, and the eggs burst into puddles of warm yolk, begging to be mopped up by the crunchy toast. Morsels of heaven!

Other favorites:

- Chicories salad with chicken: Fresh, leafy greens with a variety of oranges, garlic croutons, and maple vinaigrette. I'm not a fan of most croutons, but these were delightfully crisp and packed a garlicky punch. The chicken was surprisingly moist, tender, and well-seasoned - I'm not sure I can go back to eating the dry chicken breast in packaged Trader Joe's salads anymore.

- Buckwheat pancakes: Fluffy pancake with bananas, freshly whipped cream, and candied walnuts...what's not to love?

I've also heard rave reviews of their burgers. Must try next time!

Love the vibe of this place: industrial, modern, and laid-back. The bartenders and servers are jovial and chic, but they don't seem to mind when my inner Cookie Monster comes out. Great atmosphere, and phenomenal food.
author: Jen L.

description: Service sucks, food is mediocre. Sat down for 10 mins without anyone greeting us. ON a NON busy day. I can get better food and service eating at Denny's. The salt is out in the open uncovered which may lead to unsanitary health hazards if everyone touches it. If you asked me if I would eat here again, no I would not. Not in a million years. Save your money and time and go elsewhere.
author: Alan C.

description: Tried it based on Yelp - but definitely not four stars. Greasy fried egg sandwich and charge extra for bacon on it. With so many other options around, just not worth it.
author: Mark P.

description: Pretty AWESOME! We got three plates for the two of us and everything was amazing. A bit stuffy, but the food is amazing.
author: Y L.

description: Don't come here unless you have time to kill. Every thing takes FOREVERRRRRR, even the check. Waitress brought back our check and announced that my card had been declined, insisted that she run it again and wouldn't you know it, it went through. Awful, slow, service and good food. The wait could have been justified if the food was ah-mah-zing.
author: Craig P.

description:
The service was very good.  Attentive, but not overbearing.  Though, the lighting was too dark.  I think the food was nicely presented but it was so dark, we couldn't  really see very well.  We got more candles for the table, which helped a little, but the tables are small it was a bit precarious to have so many.

The black cod dish was tasty, though the fish seemed simply prepared, the sauce had a lot of flavor.  

Overall, it was a bit pricey for what you get, but I would go back again.
author: Janey A.

description: Great service. Sit at the bar and ask bartender to make you his latest creation.  I read in other reviews this place was loud but the night I went it was pretty quite.  I will be back for sure! I haven't tried the food as of yet.
author: Dani A.

description:
Talk about the quintessential San Francisco premium dinning experience.  The atmosphere is casual, from the long bar to the sun bleached wood flooring, but the menu is amazing. 

Starter:
I ordered the Pan Seared Petaluma Chicken Livers with fenugreek spice, thai bird chili, cilantro, and hearts of palm salad. The chicken livers were beyond the best I have ever had. They were so tender and fatty that I, for a moment, thought they had given me fois gras. The sauce was tangy and spicy, which went well with the green salad. Melt in your mouth delicious.

Drink:
Now, I'v had quite a few Manhattans in my years in SF. I'v been served the entire spectrum, from a sub par well drink served on the rocks, to the rare bourbon mixed by a pro bartender served up in a martini. Serpentine serves theirs up and serves it right. Easily one of the best tasting and smoothest manhattans I've ever had.

Entree:
The Masami Ranch Pork Loin End Chop came out glistening in a reddish hued cherry-mustard jus. Presentation was perfect. The chop itself could have been a little more tender, but the flavor spectrum in this dish was amazing. A side of mushroom flan? You may be skeptical, as I was, until you realize this savory, fatty dish is meant to be eaten with the chop, bite by bite, and it does not disappoint. Truly an amazing dish.
author: Ryan K.

description:
Came here before we headed out to Il Pirata.  This is a really outstanding date spot.  Much better choice than Bacco.  First the atmosphere here is just a lot more sophisticated and classy and thankfully younger.  Where Bacco just felt like it was about to go to sleep at 7 pm, this place felt like it was just getting up and ready for spending the night out. 

I had the gnocchi. Which was delicious. Just the right amount of oregano.  I could taste it but it didn't overwhelm the other flavors.
He had the Prather Burger.  

The service was great. From reading the reviews, I had expected it to be much worse, but our server was totally on top of things, bringing us refills and the desert menu just as we were about to call for it.  

Totally in tune with us and able to keep up.

We opted not to have desert because we were going dancing, but I would totally love to come here again, next time I get the chance.
author: Nikki K.

description: This is a awesome place to grab brunch with friends and then cap it off with ice cream at mr. and mrs. miscellaneous across the street after!  Bloody Mary was awesome!
author: Lisa Z.

description:
Came here last minute on Saturday right at 12:30 pm when primetime is and were stoked to easily get a table for 3 right away! We had heard amazing things about brunch at Serpentine so yay for us!

Firstly, LOVE the decor. It looks wherehouse-y in the inside but is brightly/well-lit and feels very cozy. There are both high-tables with stools to sit on or regular tables and even booths. Luckily, we were able to get a cozy booth. (Love the color/furniture in here - very rustic yet modern with brick walls!)

We all ordered the ruby mimosa, super tasty, and we also started off with the biscuits and gravy. The buscuits are soft and chewy and sooo yummy, and the gravy that it comes with is good, but it's very meaty so it's not veggie friendly. Luckily, we got it on the side because we had one veggie person. The gravy is definitely tasty and comes with chunky pieces of pork.

For the main dish, we ordered the salad, the fried chicken sandwich, and the baked eggs. Salad in my opinion was good, but not outstanding. Everything in it was very fresh and was delicious, but it wasn't anything special. If you're used to fresh salads in SF, this will be another one. The fried chicken sandwich was YUMMY and very filling. The fried egg in it is crunchy and tasty, and the potatoes that come on the side are great too. My personal favorite was the baked eggs - what a unique dish. It comes in a skillet with a bunch of veggies (garbanzo beans, squash, tomatoes, etc.) and it's topped with the egg. I don't know what it is about it, but it tastes very very Indian almost! The flavoring tastes a little masala-esque or something. All of us absolutely LOVED this - it is by far one of the most unique tasting brunch menu items I've had. I highly recommend it because it's fresh and not too heavy and so yummy!

I'll definitely be coming back to Serpentine again to try more items on the menu. Staff is very nice and will help you pick our items.
author: Priya G.

description:
Quick Serpentine update....even though we told them straight up that we were using them for their booze while waiting for our table at Piccino, the staff at Serpentine treated us as though we were VIP's. From the hostess to the bartender to our awesome waitress, smiles all around. 

When my friend showed hesitation over ordering a drink with Mezcal in it, our waitress told her that if she didn't like it, she'd swap it out, no problem. And not only did she say this, she followed through, checking in on us at least four-five times to make sure everything was ok.

The customer service we received at Serpentine made us instant fans and a few of the newer hipster hot spots could learn a thing or two from them (I'm looking at you, Flour + Water) Thanks to our great cocktail experience we are definitely coming back soon for dinner.
author: phil h.

description:
Went on a Wednesday, so not too crowded. Food excellent, service attentive, nice space.  Worth going back.

Got the ice cream sandwich for dessert, but not a big fan (it turns out) of an ice cream sandwich that is meant to be eaten with fork and knife, as on the first application of fork to cookie the whole thing falls apart.
author: Joel S.

description: They have been getting better and better with handling the volume  of customers.  Drinks are on time, food is on time... The staff are so kind.  So all of the other things I already said about how great the place is... plus this new update.
author: Aria Anaïs Electra S.

description: Their Red Flannel Hash is a must try! And for $12-13, they definitely don't cheap out on quantity. I've already been here twice for the hash. The second time around wasn't as great as the first, but it was still a good meal. The brisket is super tender and the beets, potatoes, and poached eggs all complimented each other so well. I can't wait to try their brunch on the weekends!
author: Kristina T.

description:
Pretty typical progressive American. Went here for dinner.

Appetizers:

Meat board: Nothing too exceptional as far as the meats, but the chicken liver mousse that came with it was delightful: very light, creamy, and tangy. Likewise, the bread the was deliciously garlicky. It's refreshing to see a chef not afraid to use garlic. 

Duck livers: Probably the highlight of the night, the spice lifted the livers into something completely extraordinary. The sweetness, with the natural after taste of the liver created something truly gripping  Would recommend. 

Pan Seared Scallops: Pretty boring, some of the scallops were underseared  which was visually offputing. Nothing to disparage, but nothing to gawk at either.

Saffron pappardelle: Very satisfying pasta dish, not too heavy.

Overall, good not great.
author: Soyan M.

description:
Took my honey here for his belated birthday dinner and had a great meal. The food was excellent:  he had the burger, which is probably one of the best I've tasted in the city (Mission Beach Cafe is still the one to beat), and I had the hangar steak, which was so very tasty. Our only complaint was that the food was heavy on the salt. 

For drinks, I started off with their perfect rye Manhattan, which I highly recommend to Manhattan lovers. It was very well balanced and was one of the best Manhattans I've ever had. With dinner, we had the "Surround" cab Sauvignon blend from Sonoma, which went very well with both of our entrees.  It was a 2007, but needed a little more time in the bottle, IMO. 

Our server, Tommy, was great. He was very friendly but also super knowledgeable of the menu and the wine pairings. It's amazing how much difference a server makes for a meal. Thanks, Tommy, we'll certainly be back.
author: Scott L.

description: Serpentine is a popular hotspot in the Dogpatch neighborhood. The place was packed, as it is on most nights, and everybody was having a good time. In one word, I think it's overrated. The food is alright, but way overpriced and the portions are small. We paid $25 for what had to be $5 worth of salmon, and there wasn't much else on the plate. They have a wide selection of specialty cocktails and fancy beers so I would be inclined to classify Serpentine as an upscale bar rather than a nice restaurant. It's a very social place and a good choice for small groups looking to hang out and buy several rounds of drinks, that is, if you manage to get seated. Then again, if that's the case, you're probably better off going to the Dogpatch Saloon across the street because it's actually a bar rather than a restaurant with a bar in it.
author: Laurent L.

description: Great place to dine before Cirque du Soleil!
author: Peter O.

description:
This is my last SF review before I move onto a slew of Disney World restaurants and then some inevitable Orange County ones (back to explore the gastronomical world that is the land of snooty people, nice cars and even nicer beaches).

L and I set up a brunch date to gossip about everything.  We decided that gossip was best done over biscuits and gravy, baked eggs, and red potato hash.  So, that's exactly what we got.

Yum biscuits and gravy.  Best gravy ever.  Not your average biscuit .. it's something way better that words cannot even describe.
Yum potato hash (think of a corned beef hash.. but red and with potatoes).
Meh baked eggs.  The eggs were a little too tough for me, and the beans and salsa and carrots on the bottom kind of made it too spicy and soggy at the same time.

Service was pretty sparse - my glass sat empty for a long time until they finally came and refilled it.  I would definitely make reservations for this place, as it's pretty small and fills up very quickly.

I loved the sound of the other food stuff there (um hello, Crab Benedict??) so I would definitely go back and get pretty much everything else on the menu.  With a heaping side portion of gossip, of course.
author: Tori S.

description:
Good coffee, great time with friends catching up over holiday brunch, and they had Nueske's bacon (I must do the North Central WI shout-out - we know beer, we wrote the book on cheese, and apparently we do bacon well too). I intended to share with my lovely brunch mates, but got put on Santa's naughty list for eating it alllllll myself. Totally worth it. Luckily, they were all enjoying and photographing their own meals, so none were the wiser.

The dungeness crab benedict was good, but doesn't make my top 5 bennies list - the accompanying greens and the fried lemon wedges were terrific though. I was intrigued by the baked eggs and savory bread pudding, which means at least one more brunch visit with my hubby in tow (one of the best parts of being married is getting to split two dishes by "going halfsies").
author: Keri B.

description:
1) if you're visiting for lunch make a reservation
2) if you're visiting for lunch give your self plenty of time for parking (check Illinois)
3) if you like meat- order the burger.
author: Valerie A.

description:
I've been hearing about Serpentine from friends and finally went over for myself. I was blown away.  It was too early for dinner so we had drinks and appetizers at the bar.  If you haven't tried their unique calamari dish you MUST try it.  Fabulous.  We also enjoyed the meat plate and the chicken livers which before you say 'ugh' this dish was so popular that of the six groups at the bar, five of them had ordered it.    

The bartender was helpful, resourceful and kept his eye on our plates and drinks.  

This is a great place to meet a friend or relax after a hard day at the office. Hope to see you there!
author: Carol S.

description:
been here for both a company dinner and brunch. both pretty good. more recently the brunch so ill comment on that:

country fried steak -- 4/5
dungeness crab -- 4/5

overall, a great experience. will most likely be back!
author: Janet Y.

description:
Ribs!  Get the pork ribs!  Three large ribs with small salad on the side.  Perfect as a hearty app for one, or you can share.  Fall off the bone tender, seasoned to perfection.

Entrees - hubby had the gnocchi with mushrooms and bacon.  Doesn't look like a whole lot, but it's very rich, and oh so yummy.  I went simple with the burger with cheddar cheese and fries.  Sometimes simple is best  - and my belly was very happy with this meal.

No room for dessert, but this place is definitely is worth a return visit.  Simple yet delicious food.  The place isn't too big, so make reservations.  At least it didn't seem too big, because there was a party of 20 that took up most of the main dining room.
author: Denise M.

description: came here for dinner. the burgers, cocktails and soup were excellent! the customer service was great and the ingredients were top notch. highly recommend.
author: Greg T.

description:
One of the better brunches I've had in a long time. The Baked Eggs is perfect if you don't want a heavy brunch that sits in your tummy until 5pm. 

It wasn't too noisy and the place was nice and bright with natural lighting. I don't really like going to a loud and dark restaurant for brunch...I need some zen time to wake up to the day.
author: Susan P.

description:
I think bitter is the new salty. It seemed just a short while ago that everyone was going bacon crazy, and foods with a salty component were the craze. Now I'm finding bitter elements in everything. I suppose it's just the current food revolution. Either way, I'm super sensitive to that flavor, and it's a little annoying to find it's now a key component in today's food culture. I guess you can say I'm bitter about bitterness.

I am so totally off topic. Serpentine. Met up with my date there for an impromptu late dinner and deemed it tasty, if overpriced. He had the burger and cleaned his plate. I did as well with my oxtail gnocchi but that was partly because I felt that the portion size was about 2/3 the size it should have been for the price tag of $20. Oxtail is a cheap cut of meat, and gnocchi is made with potatoes. Talk about a huge food cost markup. 

Though I find the menu items to be inventive and of good quality, due to the portion sizes I would have said I might not return. But it looks like I may be moving to that side of town, so maybe I'll give them another shot and go for brunch sometime.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Excellent food for lunch or dinner. Haven't eaten there for breakfast yet.

Drinks are tasty and the bartenders are cool.

Nice granite counter top.


Don't leave without the chocolate chip cookie. Crisp on the outside, soft and chewy in the middle.
author: Evan W.

description:
Anything coming from the folks at Slow Club, one of my all time favorite spots for both brunch and dinner - has to have something going for it. And luckily, their sister spot Serpentine makes good on the reputation. 

Sadly, right now they don't serve brunch on weekends but they do lunch Mon-Fri and then dinner Tue-Sat. I hope that changes one of these days, as well as perhaps an addition of Sunday dinner.

Anyhow, I've now been for dinner, which is excellent. Think variations on American classics: burger, short ribs, pork chops (from Anderson and Prather Ranch no less). 

But if you have the chance, try going for lunch, when it's less busy and you can really spend a relaxing hour or two. Here you can still get their hamburger, but there's also some fantastic sandwich options that change often (my roast beef was as good as meat gets). 

Serpentine isn't showy; like Slow Club, there's a real sense of localness to the place. Don't worry though - what they lack in pretense, they do manage to make up for in taste and style.
author: Nish N.

description:
I came here with my dad and my husband last night.

It was a little noisy inside, but not too much, and the atmosphere was lovely. Our waitress was very personable, friendly, and outgoing. My dad has pretty sophisticated tastes in alcohol, and he seemed pleased with their selection. I was also very pleased with my cocktail, "The Hard Fall," although it turned out to be too sweet for dinner, so I mostly saved it for dessert. We also ordered a bottle of wine, and the waitress was thoughtful enough to leave it to breathe while we waited for our food.

They served some delicious bread, but I thought it could have been more well-sliced. It was just four big pieces. As it turned out, though, we didn't have much chance to eat it anyway, as dinner arrived VERY quickly. I have never before complained that my dinner came too fast, but on this occasion, I could've used a bit longer to converse and savor my cocktail. No big deal, though.

When our food arrived, another waitress came to pour the wine, and seemed a little confused. She interrupted us to ask if we wanted our wine with dinner. Um...it's not a dessert wine and someone clearly told you to bring glasses? I think she was unsure because we all also had other drinks, but that was still weird.

My gnocchi with bacon was quite good, but I ended up wishing I'd ordered my dad's lamb shank, which looked amazing. (I actually have his leftovers in my fridge, so I guess I'll find out!) I kind of felt like my portion was disproportionately small compared to theirs, and it wasn't as beautifully presented, either. I felt like the gnocchi should have had some kind of a side vegetable or something, in retrospect. My husband had the burger with Gruyere, which he seemed to enjoy quite a lot. I munched his fries and they were possibly the best french fries I've ever had, with several dipping sauces for them, too. Our wine was by Storybook Vineyards, and it was perfect with my food.

I was still kinda hungry after my entree, and my tablemates saved room for dessert, so we had the salted caramel pot de creme (two of them, actually), apple rhubarb cobbler, and affogato. All of them were amazing, but I loved the cobbler especially. I wished the pot de creme had a biiiiiit more salt, but then I am kind of a salted dessert fiend.

We stayed and drank for quite a while after dinner was done, and didn't feel rushed at all. All in all it was a wonderful dinner and I hope to return soon!
author: Lynae Z.

description:
Loved this place for brunch on the weekend, decided to try them out for dinner.

Was very disappointed. Steak though ordered medium came medium well, if not well done. It was horrible completely ruined the flavor and texture - it felt more like brisket than a steak. It was a shame because other than that the dish looked promising.

Same thing happened with the Salmon. Waiter informed us it comes medium-rare. Medium on the outside, rare in the inside - and asked if it is fine with us. We said yes. The fished was completely overcooked not even a little pink on the inside - again the rest of the dish was promising - but the salmon - the heart of the dish was just so dry.

We didn't have success with deserts either. We had the chocolate cake with the ice cream. The ice cream was nice, it was from Bi-Rite, the cake was the most simple chocolate cake ever. Not to insult anyone there in the kitchen, but it kind of tasted like something you can buy in safeway bakery - or even a shelved cake. Really nothing special. The combination of the chocolate cake with ice cream is always a success - but it was so mediocre in its quality, not a restaurant dish. 

So why 3 starts and not just 1?

Service was OK (though he forgot to bring our padron peppers), I love their brunches, cocktails are very good.

Stay away during nights, get here for brunch.
author: Too M.

description: Good food and great ambiance with super easy parking
author: Jocy V.

description: Nice little place in Dogpatch!  The food selection was good, ambience good for meal with friends (not too loud or quiet), and service was friendly.  I had their scallop dish, which was delicious - scallops cooked well and the sauce was a great blend of flavors.  We did have a little bit of an issue with the staff and our service dog, but it was all in the best interest of safety.  The other people we were with are regulars and had the burger - they said it was excellent as usual.
author: Lightphoot _.

description: Amazing brunch experience! The fried egg sandwich was spectacular - great flavor combination with perfectly cooked eggs. I subbed shoestring fries for the breakfast potatoes. They were delicious, although the potatoes also looked good. I will definitely be returning.
author: erin l.

description:
Yummies!

Lunch time!! Definitely make reservations.  It  does get pretty crowed.  I think this is by far my favorite place for burgers.
author: Jessica P.

description:
My party of four opened brunch splitting a single buckwheat pancake four ways. Dessert before brunch! And the space soars. 

Yum + Space = Winning!
author: Mandy H.

description:
We came for brunch around 10:30am and had no problems getting a table.  I had the tuna melt and the spicy bloody mary.  I guess it was kind of early for a tuna sandwich, but it was delicious!  It went perfectly with the mary, which was excellent.

I also tried the egg sandwich and the pancakes.  Like at Plow, the egg yolk exploded all over me but it was worth it.  The fried potatoes it came with were nice.  The pancakes were good, pretty dense.

I'll definitely return.  Since Dr. P is always in this area, it'll probably be soon.
author: Seong P.

description: We arrived for dinner without a reservation at around 6:45 on a Thursday. We didn't have to wait long for a seat at the bar as the nice host was able to move some folks around to get us 2 seats that we only slightly behind a pillar that obstructed one of us from the bartenders. The drinks looked interested but we opted for a beer (the don't have any on draft) and food. I had a mushroom gnocchi that was good and a little different since they seared the gnocchi rather than boiling it. My boyfriend had a burger that he said was good- it's pretty hard to mess up a burger. The dessert was the highlight- a yummy chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream and toffee on top. Overall it was decent, I'd maybe go again if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Brooke G.

description: Loud and somewhat anonymous, but really solid food and cocktails. Their veggie burger is great, since they understand that "vegetarian" and "healthy" are not synonymous.
author: Ben G.

description:
My friends and I came here for a birthday dinner. There were 13 of us total. The restaurant is dim and small, so we were placed in the corner, splitted into two tables. Despite our large party, our waiter was very nice and attentive. He refilled my glass of water, brought us new wine glasses and came to check on us very often. It was a pretty packed night too. 

Onto the food. We ordered the clams and mussels and the Serpentine meat board as starters. The clams and mussels were pretty flavorful. The meat board was just okay except for the duck liver mousse. It was amazing! I spreaded some of it onto the bread they gave us, and it was delicious! That thing is 100x better than butter (not factoring in cost that is)!

I ordered the Pan Seared California Halibut as an entree, and I also had a taste of their Grilled Storm Hill Hanger Steak. My fish was super salty and dry. The radish rabe beneath it was super salty as well. However, the potato was delcious! One of my friends ordered halibut also, but hers was bland. Maybe they double-seasoned mine. The hanger steak was delicious! If I ever go back, I would order the hanger steak. It was perfectly seasoned and super tender.

The waiter brought out a sliced of chocolate bundt cake for the birthday boy. OMG, that cake was so rich and moist but not overly sweet. It was delicious!!! If I didn't feel stuffed, I would have eat the whole thing!
author: Mandy C.

description:
My awesome sister-in-law who loves good food as well suggested this place and I really enjoyed my meal.  Yes, I'm a suburbanite who drools at the sight of a menu that isn't laminated, but this place offers a stellar brunch.  

I opted for the Red Flannel Hash (think gourmet corned beef hash with beets and perfectly poached eggs), my 2 girls (ages 2 and 5) shared an order of 2 buckwheat pancakes with whipped cream (best buckwheat pancakes EVER--they actually were light and fluffy like buttermilk ones!), my brother got the fried egg sandwich (which looked amazing!), and my sister-in-law got the baked eggs with beans.   Everyone was happy with their food and we had no complaints about any of it.  I would definitely go back to eat there again the next time I'm in the city.

With OJ, milk, and tea, the total bill was about $60 and I left a $12 tip as I always feel bad about the disarray left behind because of my kids.  They are really good compared to most kids, but I am hyper sensitive about their behavior.  I expect quiet indoor voices, no playing with the silverware, and no eating with their hands.  Nonetheless, I often have to wipe up messy tables and sticky seats with whatever leftover napkins I have, so I always leave a nice tip.  This isn't really a kid-friendly place, but they gave us a huge booth in the back and my 2 year old had a grand time sprawled out on the bench seat.

So the tip was more about my guilt over bringing my kids here.  Service was ok.  It's on par with the service I get at ethnic restaurants or the diner down the street from my house in the suburbs and those places are far cheaper--they came by to refill water once, they cleared the completely empty plates (I did say it was good food!) about 5 minutes after we finished eating (which is still prompt enough but at these prices I expect more precise and attentive service), and they offered straws for my kids' drinks.  They didn't bring me extra napkins, which is standard at most restaurants when I bring my kids.  So I couldn't  clean up after them today but luckily I didn't let them have syrup on their pancakes so it wasn't bad at all.  It really was only worth a perfunctory tip if I hadn't felt guilty.

Still, easy parking, good food, and spacious seating means I definitely would return!
author: Anna W.

description:
I have nothing good to say about this restaurant.  I'll mention that my friend and I are both bartenders at very busy restaurants in San Francisco. Both of us will not be back.

I just left Sunday brunch service. The restaurant was half empty, including multiple open bar stools. We informed the host we wanted to sit at the bar - he asked us to wait, walked over to the bar and bussed two dirty glasses. He came back, said nothing to us, and greeted 3 parties behind us. After seating them in the dining room and ignoring me for another few minutes, I walked over to the bar, moved some dirty plates away, and sat down. There were 6 vacant stools all together. I chalked it up to confusing, awkward hosting.

We were not greeted by the Bartender, whose name was Paul (a fact I learned only by reading his name on our bill.) In fact, he didn't utter one single word to us. Not to ask us what we wanted, if the food was OK, if we needed anything. He pulled out a piece of paper, looked at us, and waited for us to place our orders, which he scribbled down and turned away. He could have been a mute. I will never know. Not tip worthy service by any means. 

While waiting for our food, I became hypnotized by watching a certain food runner/server carrying plates from the kitchen to various tables in the dining room. She had long blond hair, falling over her shoulders to about mid back. Each and every plate she carried had her hair dunked gracefully in the food. I watched her run a sandwich to a table by the window, with her hair covering the plate she held closest to her body on her forearm. Her hair actually clumped up in the aoli and over the fries, and as she dropped the plate, the aoli globbed up in her hair and on her shirt. I was absolutely disgusted. I prepared myself for the awkward "please take this plate back as your hair is all up in it" conversation. However, a nice brunette dropped our food, with her hair tucked up in an elastic. I was relieved.

I ate 1/3 of of my food, drank half of my bloody mary, and bounced. We were there for exactly 28 minutes, at which point I was so turned off that I didn't even want to stay. 

Its against my beliefs to leave 0% gratuity, because a percentage of my tip outs are left for bussers and dishwashers and other back of house employees. I hope the tip we left Paul goes directly to them, because he earned absolutely none of it. 

Go to Plow in Potrero instead. This place was foul.
author: Mariposa D.

description:
Consistently consistent. Solid menu. Solid bar. Solid staff.

My only complaint is when they're too packed to accommodate me and my friends.

Please don't come here. I hate to wait.
author: T Shane G.

description:
I wish I could say I was a team player.

Our football team once got destroyed by a rival.

Was I upset about the loss?

Not really.

I had an interception, two sacks (hehe, sacks), and 14 tackles.

Screw the team, I dominated.  

So on a recent visit to Serpentine, I ordered the burger while everyone else got random items like Gnocchi, Salads, etc.

If I was a true team player I would give this place a 3 and I would bitch and moan about the gnocchi and the overdressed salad.

Given I had quite possibly the best burger ever, I had to jump it up to 4 stars.  

Seriously delicious burger.

While my "team" left a little disappointed, I was well liquored up and dreaming about my next excuse to run down to Serpentine to grab a burger.

Apparently the brunch is good too.  Need to check that out.

Solo.
author: Archie R.

description:
Another excellent Fall restaurant debut. I must say I don't spend too much time in this neighborhood and I'd been meaning to give Hard Knox a try forever now but Serpentine has beaten the Knox to it. Let me say that I love the fact that a lot of the building's original elements like the exposed brick, hardwood floor, high ceilings and textile factory style windows were kept. Add to that new wood, metal accents, and double draped restroom pods in the middle of the room facing the sizeable bar, you get a dichotomy of classic industrial and modern sleek.

The place isn't very large although the high ceilings give it a more open feel than it actually is. I'd say my one gripe about the place is that it's a bit cramped. We were both bumped from behind multiple times from both patrons and staff trying to get around our area and we were against the wall! However the delicious semi upscale comfort food and drinks made up for it.

We started with the savory bread pudding which had butternut squash and topped with a buttermilk bleu cheese dressing. Not only heavenly but super filling. We got the appetizer portion and it came out as a huge mound and if we didn't stop ourselves and get it boxed we would have been full on that alone. Great deal especially if you have 3-4 people. I also got the lamb riblets, braised in what was a savory/semi sweet sauce with some greens. This was tasty but it didn't wow like te bread pudding. For the entrees we got the buffalo short ribs with what seemed like drits and grilled persimmon. Delish in the braise and fall off the bone with a meatier bite texture than your standard beef ones. The entree was the roasted rabbit loin accompanied by a wilted spinach mash and buttery crisped spaetzle. This might be the best rabbit dish I've ever had since it was moist and the skin was  cripsed (like the spaetzle) perfectly. I thought the seasonings were flavorful throughout all of our dishes. 

The ambiance gets pretty noisy as the night carried on. We got their early in order to make a show and shortly after we got our drinks the place filled up to capacity. The service was a little uneven at first because of the rush but smoothed out as they got in their flow. As I mentioned earlier the only issues I had were with the space because it is quite packed in. Definitely returning to give the other items a try and if they stick with their sustainable virtue, the menu will change as time goes on. 4.5 stars.
author: Kim N.

description:
I was here for brunch and had a pleasant experience.  The food was good and the service was great.  The food is a little bland, but then at least you have the option to add more salt and pepper yourself.  Portions tend to be smaller than typical brunch places.  

If I rated solely on food and service, it would get 3 stars.  What bumps it up from 3 to 4 stars is that they take reservations for brunch.  It's unfortunate that so many places in the city have huge lines for brunch, and then the food isn't worth the wait.  I wouldn't wait in line for Serpentine but would gladly come back as long as I can get a reservation.
author: Karen T.

description: Cypress! Bellini! Mimosa! Oh and the burger was pretty fine too. Jesse the bartender was the best part though.....owner seems to have an attitude problem however.
author: Emily C.

description:
Friends and I were in the Dogpatch/Potrero Hill area and decided to have dinner at Serpentine.  We didn't have a reservation but got a nice table for 3 in the bar area.  

My food was delicious.  Oysters to start, roasted chicken for my entree, and a pear & raisin crumble to share with my friends for dessert.  The meal came out to $32/person, very reasonable.  Service was top notch and the ambiance is nice (modern/industrial).

I'd be a regular if I lived in SF!
author: Jen C.

description:
'industrial chic' means cavernous, hard walls and ceilings resulting in an insufferably noisy box.

Food was OK yet unremarkable.   Nothing stood out.  No accolades.  
Lunch menu is very limited with some of the more exciting items mentioned on the web absent.

Burger and bun were ordinary.
Veggie burger wasn't even as good as CostCo's frozen food offering of a veggie burger.
Warm chicory salad contained fresh and nicely warmed/wilted greens, yet the ricotta was undetectable. 

Parking was difficult to find.
author: Anne J.

description: I really like this place.  Been back 4-5 times.  Tried the scallops, flank steak, pasta with truffle sauce, fried calamari, salads - all good.  Only one complaint and it's not the food.  It's so dark you can't read the menu or see what's on your plate.  I am not the only one with this issue as evidenced by the multiple patrons reading the menu by the light of their smart phones.  So Serpentine please turn up the lighting a little - at least enough so patrons can see the great presentations that are being created by your chef.
author: Ron T.

description: We wanted to end our holiday in cool style and Serpentine seemed to fit the bill. Unfortunately we didn't decide until that afternoon, and the earliest table was 9.15. By the way they use Toptable so don't bother phoning, just use the app. However, once we were seated all was good. The menu contained conventional dishes but each had an interesting twist, we started with deep fried crispy calamari which arrived on a cumin flavoured bed of chick pea, tomato and spinach. We then had the steak or burgers, the burgers were good but fairly standard, the steak was excellent. Go here for good food and cool, but you need good eyesight and an ability to lip read because it is dark and very noisy when busy!
author: Neville M.

description:
Came here to try out the Prather Ranch hamburger. Totally delicious for a $14 burger (cheese is $1.50 extra). The acme roll is just thick enough to absorb the burger juices but it's not feel overbearingly "bready." I also loved the bitter/sour combo of the arugula and pickled onions. 

We had the Serpentine Meat Board (duck prosciutto, speck and spicy coppa - my favorites!) before the burgers. It was decent but the servings were a little small. They also pickle their own green beans, which were yummy. 

I hear the brunch is fantastic, so I'll put Serpentine on the list to try out.
author: Karen L.

description:
You know that short list of go-to restaurants that is reliably great, service is consistently very good, and is not a total hassle to get into?  Serpentine is exactly that for me.  Brunch, lunch or dinner, it is undoubtedly a neighborhood favorite that has never let me down.

Brunch Favorites:  Fried egg sandwich; Red Flannel hash; Salmon benedict; Bread pudding.

The dinner menu changes, but the burger is always on the menu and is pretty awesome.

And don't forget the cocktail menu.  It's as interesting and delicious as the savory dishes.

The space is modest, industrial but still welcoming and intimate.  Service is always excellent, super knowledgeable about the menu and spot on with the cocktail recommendations.
author: Jen Y.

description: Pretty good but a bit expensive for what you get.  Also no beer on tap.  That was not so good.  Service was good and the food was good.  I thought the portions could have been bigger.
author: Bucky W.

description:
I was there this morning, and I thought the food was great, fresh and tasty (it CAN be compare to mama's @ north beach) I would have giving a FIVE stars if it wasn't the bad service. 

I was there for Brunch. I arrived at 1:30ish, no wait pretty easy parking. 

Great place for Sat/Sun Brunch.
author: Zee Z.

description:
Slowly but surely, the restaurant scene in the Dog Patch is blossoming.  You may recall (I am sure you do) that a couple of months back, d took us to Yield, a wine bar on 3rd Street which we all really enjoyed.  Well, wouldn't you know it, right across the street was Serpentine, a newish New American restaurant that is a sister restaurant to Slow Club.  The vibe is both cozy and stylish with leather booths (I love booths) offset by tall ceilings in this modern extension of a red brick warehouse space.

Featuring a limited but solid menu, Serpentine's offerings surpassed my expectations.  We started with a house favorite: the savory bread pudding with fennel, baby spinach, roasted garlic, and swiss cheese.  It was mouth-wateringly good.  We also had the little gems lettuce with hazelnuts and shaved red onions but let's get real, it was the zoe's bacon and blue cheese dressing which made this a little stand-out.  For my entree, I had their Prather Ranch hamburger with greens, pickled onions, and blue cheese on an acme roll.  For $13, it was a solid burger, one I can't wait to try again.  Dessert was so-so (I can't remember what we had) but overall, a really enjoyable meal.

Service was friendly and more than compotent, on par with Slow Club.  Check this place out, it doesn't hurt that you have to spend zero time finding parking in the Dog Patch.  For now, anyway.
author: Saminda W.

description:
NOM NOM NOM! Those were my second thoughts when I walked into Serpentine.  I love the original architecture of the restaurant; the high ceilings, abundance of light, and the clean lines made for an inviting atmosphere.  The partner and I grabbed a seat in the corner of the restaurant, and the bread and water came out promptly.  Get the Pranqster, it's to die for.  

I got the penne while my partner got the pork sandwich.  He killed that sandwich like no other.  I inhaled my my penne, since it had good stuff like blanc fromage, greens, and chili flakes.  Both dishes were superb, and most def we'll be back to Serpentine in one our most favorite neighborhoods: the Dogpatch.
author: Linh D.

description: Very small space with no place to wait as your tables are being prepared so you are in the way of the servers no matter where you stand. We had the burger which was excellent- cooked to perfection and very tasty. The soup (only one avail) was also quite good and could be vegan if you order without the cream garnish. The ambience is nice and servers are great. I would return.
author: Jennifer T.

description: I rarely give 5 stars but this is not just for the good wine menu and yummy burger. It's for the stellar service and the fact that our waitress noticed we hadn't touched our gnocchi...asked about it, and then quietly took it off the bill without us even asking for it. It's so rare that I've had such an experience - only noticed today when I was throwing out the accumulated bills in my wallet. Kudos to the establishment and their excellent staff. We will be back!
author: Koshika S.

description: I loved everything about my first experience at Serpentine. We were promptly seated on a Saturday night for a 7pm reservation. All of the staff couldn't have been nicer. Serpentine strikes a nice balance of hipness without irony and with delicious food. We had a bottle of a lovely California Rose then a couple of glasses of Pinot to go with our mushroom pastas. The burger and fries were just as good as promised. We ended our meal with some great desserts and were introduced to a new after dinner drink, "Nocino" a spiced walnut liqueur which was amazing! Will definitely go back.
author: Tom E.

description:
You can find dirt cheap food in SF in a shitty atmosphere or you can find supremely expensive food in a nice atmosphere. There's not much in between, and that's where Serpentine comes in.

I came here with my boy for brunch. I love the space though during brunch the light from the windows bounces off all that stainless steel and can be a bit blinding. 
 
He got the Country Fried Steak & Eggs (flat iron steak - scrambled eggs - biscuit & gravy - crispy potatoes - arugula). I got the Baked Eggs (two eggs - cranberry beans - summer squash - sweet corn - epazote - red spring onion - green garlic salsa) with corn bread. The food was delicious and most significantly, everything was executed perfectly. The country fried steak was just perfectly fried, didn't taste of old oil and was very tender.  The portions were fairly generous for the price.

We also drank a blood orange bellini and a grapefruit mimosa, or perhaps it was the other way around. In any case, our drinks had a great balance of juice to booze. 

Cocktails were less than $10 (8 I think). No entree was above $20. It's easy here to have good food and good drink without emptying your wallet. 

I love how close Serpentine is to Mr. & Mrs. Misc. too. This is a really great, reasonably priced restaurant.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Came here with a group of friends while visiting San Francisco. I was a little put off by the fact that they are only open until 10PM, even on weekends.

After waiting a bit for our table we all ordered a round of drinks. I went with a glass of wine that was really delicious.

I got the short ribs for my meal and was extremely happy with that selection. Falling off the bone meat was tender and extremely flavorful. Hubby's hamburger was one of the juiciest burgers I've ever had. 

Everyone else seems to enjoy their meals as well. I definitely see myself coming back here upon a return visit to San Francisco!
author: Amanda L.

description: Good brunch option in Dogpatch. Went here to celebrate Mother's Day the Saturday before and they have great service, letting us sit down before the whole party had arrived which was nice. The frittata w asparagus was delicious!
author: E C.

description:
Stumbled on Serpentine when in the Dogpatch for my first time ever for an ice cream tour (high marks to Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous!  And going on ice cream tours!)  

First things off, I love this space, very cool.  And the handcrafted cocktails were delicious.  The chickpea calamari is original.  And I'd highly recommend both of our entrees--gnocchi and the steak.  Only thing I wouldn't go for again is the cheese plate, which was pretty standard.  Can't wait to go back for my third ever trip to the Dogpatch!
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Very good food. Very poor service. Decent drinks. Loud atmosphere. 

The reason this place had four stars is that it's in the Dogpatch, where there is less competition and where locals are clearly happy to have a new arrival.

The chef does a great job, but the service is so poor as to be distracting. Meaning: waiting twenty minutes to be seated for your reservation, drinks not arriving till midway through the meal, credit cards charged the wrong amount, etc.  

A good spot if you live nearby; otherwise, not worth a trip.
author: Whitefaced M.

description:
I first fell in love with Serpentine over a year ago, actually in 2010 (based on the date of the review I'm updating).  That review was written after a second visit.  Since then, I've lost count of my return LUNCH visits.  We seem to show up at least bi-weekly.

Why? My palate and I have certainly enjoyed dining at certain restaurants. Yet, there are probably 3 (or less) restaurants where I'm a weekly+ visitor (and the grocery store doesn't count).  My top three reasons for returning to Serpentine: 1) service, 2) the fries! and 3) changing menu.  My favorite this month is the achiote pork sandwich.  I ask for it bun-less with greens and a delicious, flavorful salad arrives. Then I secretly hope that someone else at the table has ordered the fries as a side.  If they won't share , I steal some anyways.
author: M G.

description: I know this place gets a lot of great reviews and is a Dogpatch favorite... However, I really feel like this restaurant has some serious fundamental problems with service. Upon arriving, the greeter was pleasant, but the restaurant was completely booked in reservations. We opted to sit at the bar, which only had three other guests. Upon sitting down, the bartender was cleaning glasses and looked to be organizing a bit, but took over 5 minutes to greet us or even look at us. When he finally got us menus, he didn't smile or say anything like "good morning" or "how are you"... We ordered a mimosa and Bloody Mary, which he made quickly, but again, no smiles or small talk. When we asked for suggestions on house favorites, and in particular, the corn beef hash, his answer was curt and unwelcoming "I personally don't like it... It's ok." We ended up ordering the polenta and pork and the fried chicken, both which were kind of bland. Nothing to write home about. And the very end of the experience, he got our check, didn't ask us how our food was, and never said thank you or have a good day.... Not exactly the most pleasant dining experience...
author: Jennifer L.

description:
For brunch review only...

The biscuit and gravy wasn't your typical "biscuit and gravy". The gravy had a tomato base which made it taste like a tomato cream soup. The baked eggs with black beans, squash, and corn muffin was bland, under cooked, and dry. The crab eggs benedict could have just been poached eggs and bread because the crab was non existent. The Cubano was dry, bland, and tasteless. A side of bacon was $4 for two strips and a side of sausage (1 small patty) was $3.5. The only highlight was the bloody mary. Now that was good!

Four people and including drinks was about $120.
author: Anna S.

description: Delicious.  Ate the gnocchi & the duck.  Both dishes were lovely.  I really enjoyed the atmosphere of this restaurant.  It is small so I would recommend a reservation.
author: Christy L.

description:
Serpentine is a gem located (luckily) right down the street from my house. This restaurant effortlessly blends casual and upscale, and was the ideal venue for our recent Saturday night party of 10. Food, cocktails, wine & beer, and ambiance all exceeded expectations, and street parking was easy for friends who don't live in the neighborhood. Everything we tried was delicious - oysters, ribs, lamb, burgers, desserts - and I enjoyed the slightly creative twist on New American fare. 

Serpentine's service was fantastic as well. The restaurant generously accommodated our large party at a great table, and our server gracefully handled our table and made great menu and wine/cocktail pairing recommendations. In a city brimming with amazing restaurants, it's great service like Serpentine's that wins my loyalty. I can't wait to go back!
author: P K.

description:
Great service, friendly waitstaff; only complaint on that would be that they were a bit pushy on drinks- we ordered a bottle of wine, that should be enough for an early dinner. The wine, Horse and Plow, was decent, not amazing, at $36/bottle. They were fairly attentive about refilling water glasses, although providing more bread without being asked to would have been nice (very good bread with a nice crust and crumb; would have preferred nice olive oil over the butter provided though).

Food- very good, although I heard quite a few mutterings of "bland" and reaching for the salt- I understand it is easier to under-salt and let guests apply their own amount of salt and pepper, but it was very noticeable. For both the rabbit and gnocchi. The dishes were presented very nicely; the gnocchi were nicely textured- not too soft but well made, with beautiful mushrooms and a nicely spiced creme fraiche. The TCHO chocolate souffle with vanilla ice cream was wonderful, piping hot "souffle" underneath the ice cream, with caramelized cocoa nibs on top (not a fan of these, too much)- a small dessert but just enough for one person. The coffee was very good, but not amazing. 

Overall, worth checking out, unless you are really hungry, because you won't get filled up here. Before 7pm, it was quiet and easy to talk; after 7pm however, on a Thursday night, it got pretty loud and packed out quickly, even at the bar.
author: Amanda S.

description:
So freaking cute! Came here with friends for an early brunch one Sunday and oh my goodness. SO many delicious options on the menu! I went with the Red Flannel Hash (a whole lot of tender brisket with greens, potatoes, beets and poached eggs), which was really freaking good and filling. Friends both got the Fried Egg Sandwich and I totally lusted after it. Homemade sausage patty?? Hello! 

The savory bread pudding was second on my list and I'm definitely checking it out next time. Only downside was my bloody mary was kinda spendy and not that great. In hindsight, I probably should have gone with the pomegranate mimosa...
author: Karena Q.

description:
Solid food and most dishes were good but nothing was a Wow except for the bread pudding and the Earl Grey pot de creme.  We had the pate, mushroom toast, bone marrow, pasta with duck? meat, flat iron steak and bread pudding.  That was more than enough food for 3 people.  Oh, and the earl grey pot de creme.  

Would not recommend mushroom toast as it tasted more like a spinach toast.  Service was alright but the busboy kept rolling his eyes and rushed us out.  Hence the 3 instead of 4 stars.  Not good for groups as just for the 3 of us, we had to keep screaming at each other to get heard.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
WOW I was able to park right in front of the restaurant. 5 stars. Walked in and we got a table 5 stars. Happy prompt knowledgeable staff. 5 stars. Fiddlehead. 5 stars
Our experience here was wonderful the Rock Cod, half chicken and crispy oysters were fantastic... 
A great place for a bite with friends or family.
Highly recommend.
author: Lawrence T.

description:
Hipster decor, high ceilings and leather seating, with a simple menu that uses fresh ingredients.  Came here for lunch, although its not in the best of neighborhoods, I really enjoyed the feel of the restaurant and the food was pretty good for lunch.

I ordered the pork hash, which they mixed with poached eggs and a red beet salad and scalloped potatoes.  Paired with an arnold palmer, it was a great lunch. The hash itself was fresh, but thought the red beets overpowered the dish and made it too sweet. The poached eggs were cooked perfectly and the potatoes were delicious.

The only thing that annoyed me were the old business men who wouldn't move to let me leave the table. I was really surprised by the clientele that day especially considering we were in the dogpatch and it was difficult to find parking.  

4 stars for decor/ ambience, 3.5 stars for food, 3 stars for service.
author: SF Diner A.

description: This is the third time I've been to serpentine, and the last.  On all occasions the reception is between rude to non existent.  I was just there as a single person, told I could only sit at bar even thought there were ELEVEN empty tables.  Waited for five minutes for menu, the bar tender never came back to take order in the next ten minutes.  A second person was seated, and a new bartender went to her and took her order immediately.  If you want to be treated rudely, ignored, or have your very personhood denied, this is the place.  I don't know who is worthy of the attention, you may be lucky.  who knows.  I never will.  oh, about the food.  who cares when you are so badly accomdated.
author: robert h.

description: Hip location and ambiance. The food is incredible - I had the swordfish and my husband had the burger (and started with calamari). Definitely will come here again and bring guests.
author: Audrey G.

description: Great neighborhood place for brunch, lunch or dinner. Fun vibe, friendly service and fab bartenders. Order dessert, too!
author: Vicki L.

description:
SUNDAY BRUNCH!

Pros:
Free and easy parking
Located across from Mr & Mrs Misc
Hostess got us seated in 10 minutes despite the hour long wait and line to the sidewalk  because it was just 2 of us and our baby the rest were bigger parties
Cool warehouse look to the building because it is a warehouse
Felt warm and inviting, despite high ceiling and open arrangement
Fresh and delish food: Thank you yelp! Ordered the savory bread pudding and red flannel hash due to the reviews, both were everything I hoped for.
Food came out hot and fresh within 15 minutes
The hostess was sweet and other staff dressed in cool hipster styles hello-ed our baby. 
Reasonable prices for good food and good portions, our bill was about $35
Love the clipboard menus
Oh and they have a bar

Cons:
Long line and long wait for bigger groups than two, especially during peak hours
A bit of a tight squeeze, all the more if it's busy
My husband asked if I wore lipstick, when I said no, he pointed at my water glass, which had a bright red lipstick stain, Eww! Easy fix though, didn't drink from it, good thing he told me before I did. Still really gross though. Luckily, I always bring my own water bottle.
Had the $9 mimosa which was good but, next time I'll just skip the drink or get something else, like the Bellini because honestly, I can make it at home myself. Or better yet get dessert instead.


Definitely going back:-)
author: Mavi T.

description:
Manages to be cozy while in an industrial setting with high ceilings.  We had the stone fruit salad, which was delicious.  I know it's just a salad, but it hit all the right notes - not to heavy on dressing, extremely fresh little gem lettuce, tasty peaches and hazelnuts.  

The wine (Meyer Family syrah and Poco a Poca Zin) were served too warm, which is a pet peeve of mine - especially in SF, where we should know better.

Then, after reading all of the rave reviews for the burger, I had that, and my husband had the salmon.  The burger was the better choice.  While i don't think it's the best burger I've ever had, it was pretty darn good.  The pickles and pickled onions add a nice tang.

We had the ice cream sandwich for dessert.  The ice cream (coffee, BiRite) and toffee were wonderful, but the cookies were a bit hard and not as tasty as they could have been.
author: B. Y.

description:
This is one of our regular brunch/lunch spots in our neighborhood and we're never disappointed!  Awesome drinks! Just had their Blood orange bellini last weekend and I could have slurped down 10 of those.

Their bread pudding, hamburger, and buckwheat pancakes are hands down delicious and are great choices.  I had the crab benedict last weekend and it was one of the best I've had in a long while.  Creamy, flavorful and light.

Great place for sure.  I love the dogpatch!
author: Sharon T.

description:
Occasion:  Gal pal's birthday
Ordered:  Masami Ranch Pork Loin End Chop

We arrived a few minutes before our reservation time and found that our table was already for us.  The space had high ceilings and a very warm comfortable vibe.  The wait staff was very friendly and informative.  I had the pork loin chop and found it to be extremely tender and delicious.   My dining companies enjoyed their entrees as well.  One of the gals had a pork chop that was more on the medium rare side.  The waitress immediately took it to the kitchen and had it brought up to medium.  She returned with a fresh plate and a smile on her face.  The meal cost ~$30 a person.

Overall:  The food was delicious and the service deserves a A+!  Definitely a great first date location.
author: E C.

description:
Went for Sunday brunch last weekend - today is Thursday and The Hubs is still talking about his fabulous breakfast. We made a late day reservation, (1:30 pm) so we could watch the niners win and then relax at brunch. We got a great corner table with more than enough room. The minimalist decor inside was nice, but can imagine more nice for dinner. Something about the place doesn't scream cozy brunch spot, but it was definitely attractive. Hubs ordered chicken fried steak and eggs. Both were delicious. The scrambled eggs were the best eggs I've ever eaten at a restaurant, and they were the most beautiful looking as well. I ordered the savory bread pudding and side salad. Very filling and delicious. I went with something other than my usual creature of habit brunch ordering, and I'm happy I did. The vegetables and pork really lended to a yummy, hearty flavor.

Our waitress was very friendly and nice, although only served us one mimosa/bloody mary, and then never came back to ask if we'd want more. We couldn't find her to ask, so when someone came to bus our plates, we asked the buser for two more drinks. As exchange was occuring, our waitress popped up and put the bill on our table. It was a little awkward - because we basically drank our 2nd drink with no food and felt a little rushed. In hingsight, the food came out so quickly after ordering, that we didn't really have the leisurely brunch experience. She was a wonderful waitress, I just got the feeling they'd been slammed all morning and she needed to either - take a little breather (completely understandable, just random to not check in and then assume we're ready to leave/bring check).

We'll definitely be back, but next time I think we'll order drinks, then wait for a while to order our food... All in all, it was really great! Try the espresso whiskey concoction drink, too -- it was very good and quite potent.
author: Megan D.

description: Great atmosphere, good food, great drinks. Perfect for brunch or dinner. Their 1 indian dish should be taken off the dinner menu.
author: Tasha A.

description:
This Review is for Brunch.

Brunch is a tough situation in SF, especially in some neighborhoods. For that, Serpentine is a great find. It's run by the same folks at slow club, so the food should be good, and circling the block with parking (if you drive), and waiting in a big line freezing can be both avoided.

TIPS:

Make reservations. (why wait in line?) Or come before the 11 o'clock rush.

PROS:

Easy Parking. Easy access to public transit. 

Elegant and simple industrial decor. 

Full bar. There's mimosas, belinis, though, sadly not bottomless. Bloody Mary is delicious too, though no celery. I'm partial to having a celery stalk in my BMs.

Coffee - excellent.

Ordered in the group were, Burger, Baked Eggs, Crab Benedict. 

Burger got a firm thumbs up. 

Baked Eggs as well (though comment was the veggies were on the bland side). 

Benedict is tasty, though I found it a bit on the tart side, and if you order it I'd suggest getting a side of bacon or sausage. Benedict came with a pleasant arugula/fennel salad, and home fries were nice and crispy.

Pancake! If the server asks if you'd like to order one pancake to share, say: YES. (assuming no one is ordering pancake) We had a delightful banana pancake with whipped cream and candied walnuts. 

CONS:

Not much. A few times, had to ask for refills on coffee. But otherwise, service was decent.

Bottom Line:

Another good brunch place to keep in mind. Should try out dinner sometime.
author: Boris C.

description:
Serpentine I love you. I moved to Potrero Hill last year and just discovered Serpentine in February. I've now been five times and plan to return this weekend. It's not cheap but it's not crazy either. The wine list has some great reasonable options. The meat plate is always good and interesting, though once they'd "drizzled" a little too much olive oil on it. The crudo (a special I think) was delicious as is the gnocchi - add the bacon, it's worth it. However, my absolute favorite thing on the menu is the brussel sprouts. I know, I know, that's weird. But the red peeper and peccarino on the crispy roasted sprouts creates something truly magical. I crave them and have managed to make an acceptable version at home. But it's not quite the same. 

I love the atmosphere. Super high ceiling in an industrial setting. Get there before sun down for some great lighting from the high windows. The bar area (corner seat) is probably my favorite as you can get a great view of the space while you eat. It almost always has a good crowd and feels lively. It's really a 4.5.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great atmosphere, amazing cuisine.  From starters to dessert the food is top tier.
author: Kim F.

description: Went for a late lunch on a Sunday afternoon and place was packed when we walked in. First thing I noticed was this place amplifies all the conversations that's going on inside. It's like a competition to see who can speak the loudest. So as you can imagine, it was annoying as hell trying to hear the person you are with. Service was skimpy and they seem understaffed. My expectation was a little high given all the rave reviews but imo, it was just ok. I've had way, way better brunch. Saving grace....price was reasonable. Would I go again, yes but only if I'm in the neighborhood and I can avoid the crowd.
author: B C.

description: lunch here was a pleasant surprise. cool warehouse interior, good service, and it was nice to have fresh, healthy food instead of being drowned in grease.
author: Sherman L.

description: I am planning a dinner for 50 people in six months, and have called and emailed Serpentine numerous times since June 24, but as of today, no response.  Seriously, not even an acknowledgement like, "I received your message and will get back to you."  I actually was able to speak with three employees over the phone, but they just gave me the run-around.  I'm inclined to think that Serpentine does not want my business.  If this is the kind of service they give to inquiries, what kind of service will I get on the day of my event?
author: Julie O.

description: Delightfully innovative, Serpentine has a somewhat French style with an American backbone of dedication to their craft. The bar and the kitchen work closely to create a  perfectly balanced flavorful meal. Serpentine seems to push their dishes to their full potential, using fresh, in-season ingredients. I went here for lunch on a trip to San Francisco and was very pleased with the knowledgeable, friendly staff. The atmosphere is very modern, yet cozy and inviting. I wish I could visit this place more often to see what they come up with next! This is an excellent place to take friends.
author: Paul C.

description:
Phenomenal experience. One of the better meals I've had in the SF area, and certainly the best at the price point. The Osso Buco is exceptional. My wife had a gnocchi dish, which was also quite good. Chef pays attention to creating an interesting textural experience in addition to novel, yet familiar, flavor profiles.

We also enjoyed the interesting cocktail menu. Highly recommend the Whiskey Smash (muddled mint, lemon and Bulleit Bourbon).

Waitstaff was perfectly acceptable. Unremarkable, but unobtrusive. Host (Michael) was welcoming and courteous.
author: David G.

description:
We were excited to try this place after Jon Kaufmann's recent review heralding Serpentine as the best burger in SF. 

We had a bunch of the menu to start, calamari, chicken liver, asparagus salad, hamachi, pork belly, meat plate. Standouts were the shaved asparagus salad, and the chicken liver! The sauce on the chicken liver reminded us of black bean sauce, but it worked so well in the dish. So well we ordered another one.

The Prather Ranch burger came properly medium rare, nice and juicy. Toasted Acme bun, pickled onions, arugula...Everything came together, nothing overpowering, and perfectly beefy. With another half of the burger left, we cut up the leftover chicken liver and put it all together! LOL it was awesome. But seriously, the thing I like best is the acid on the burger, which was missing from Marlowe's (Michael Bauer's fave).

Service was great, and cocktails were nice as well. We'll be back.
author: Derrick V.

description: Happened upon this place a week or so back. The ambiance is super chill and kinda dark-lit so I imagine it would be great for a date-night spot. The drinks were awesome! Definitely try one from the specialty menu. On hit. We had the Calamari, Arugula salad and the Burger- split between 3 of us which was plenty of food. The Calamari had a chickpea batter. I was a little aprehensive of this but it turned out to be bomb! Like more of a savory dish. The burger was perfectly cooked and delicious as well. If Im in the neighborhood I will be back.
author: Tara M.

description:
It's hard for me to get excited about Serpentine.  Everything was fine, more-or-less.  I just found it expensive for what it was.  As I warned my girlfriend before she made her plea to try something different, I was concerned that this would be "insubstantial."  It was.  For $81, we got essentially a few small plates and a drink each (she got wine, I got a lemon vodka martini).  Portions were tapas-style.  The one outstanding side was the fries -- wonderful -- and uniquely plentiful. 

The number of vegetarian dishes is modest, and I think we may have ordered every one (I suspect they would modify some recipes on the menu should someone want to take out a non-veg ingredient, such as the pancetta in the other salad).  We had the mushroom gnocchi, a salad, fries, snap peas, and the soup of the day.  The gnocci was okay, but a tiny portion for the price.  The salad was okay.  The soup (scallion) wasn't good.  The snap peas were great, as were the fries.

It wasn't really a meal.  Neither of us was satisfied.  And it was over $80.  Is this what life in the City is like?  It doesn't have to be.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description:
after driving by plow and seeing the ginormous wait outside, we came here for brunch.  we were told there was a 15-20 min wait, but they took down our number, and we were able to walk around.  

i ended up getting the egg sandwich and mimosa w/ grapefruit juice.  i loved the english muffin that came w/ the sandwich.  egg was perfectly runny as well.  only snafu was that our food came before our drinks even did, but i was so hungry anyway that i didn't care.
author: Helen T.

description:
The food was so good. I love menus that don't have your "typical" selections.  The brunch menu is unique and oh so delicious!

Book in advance to avoid an hour wait. The restaurant was nice and cozy. It took a while for our waiter to come around but he was really nice. Great service and great ambience.  We will be coming back !
author: Luzette P.

description: Nice whiskey/bourbon selection, approved.
author: Lori J.

description:
My rating is 3.5 stars for this place.
I had Chickpea Battered Calamari and Roasted Mary's Chicken. Calamari was very tasty but it was pretty small portion to share. Chicken was crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. I like the sauce that came with it, along with artichoke and spinach. It was delicious but wasn't worth the price for me -$22. 

Pros:
*Overall great food
*Good atmosphere - you can sit at a bar while waiting for seats
*Friendly service
*Parking is available unlike other hot spots in the city. 

Cons:
*Not a lot of options on the menu
*Slow serice
*Overall a little pricy for what it is
author: Cartman P.

description: Nice cool atmosphere. Great brunch with a little twist. Cocktails were great and the savory bread pudding and pancakes were delicious. One of my favorite brunch places in sf! I don't want too many people to know about this dog patch neighborhood gem because there might be too long of a wait.  Plus how can you beat ice cream at mr. And mrs. Miscellaneous across the street.
author: Anthony N.

description:
