Serpentine is quite a find...I definitely had a pleasant experience all around, thanks to many things!

First off, you can't get any better service than this...I think I've found my favorite waitress by far.  She obviously loves what she does, has the biggest, most honest smile and is one the friendliest people you will ever come across.  It felt as if I was at a friend's house and she was cooking dinner for us...quite comfortable, amiable and absolutely personable.  I didn't get your name, but thank you!  You are awesome!

The drink menu is pretty extensive!  Cocktails of all kinds, an impressive wine list and a unique array of beer to choose from...you can't go wrong that!  Serpentine definitely strives to appease all libation palates.  Winner!  I opted for the Hibiscus Fizz--Be Careful!  You may want to down it like juice.  Nuff said.

So, onto the food..The menu focuses on fresh, local ingredients.  You can definitely sense this when going through the list of dishes.  We both wanted to order the Yellowtail but when I saw that the Alaskan Cod had BACON in it, I immediately changed my mind and didn't even look back!  

One thing that I noticed about my dish was the fact that each bite was wonderfully different.  One bite had a tinge of bacon with crispy skin (YUM) and the next was a mouthful of cod and veggies.  I don't think I've ever called a fish dish amazing...so there it is.  AMAZING.  My favorite part?  The artichoke chips sprinkled over the dish.  Definitely a lovely surprise!  I cleaned up my plate.  I was a bit embarrassed, being on a "first date"...but whatevs.  It's the real me, right?  :)

A definite must is dessert.  They turned an old childhood favorite into an unforgettable masterpiece!  The ice cream sandwich with Bi-Rite's Roasted Banana ice cream, ginger cookies, rich caramel and toffee bits.  Goodness Gracious!  An absolute winner!!!!  

Me Loves Serpentine...
author: Jennifer L.

description:
My friends had raved about Serpentine, but I had never had a chance to get over there.  Finally, my hubby and I went there and had an incredible meal a few nights ago.  We will definitely return. 

The space is ambient & the location is hot (with easy parking too!). The wine recommendations were DELISH; the service was great & the food was out of this world.  

The bread & butter to start was yummy; then we had squash w/arugula salad; cheese with mission fig jam & almonds; the sole; and calamari.  We were too full for dessert, but the people next to us had a few that looked unbelievable.
author: Sara W.

description:
What a fabulous place in an upcoming neighborhood.  I honestly never explored the dogpatch and really look forward to coming back. Plus for those who must drive, there's plenty parking.

We enjoyed dinner for 4 in a eclectically rustic but charming old building. Since it was so hot, 94* in SF, we didn't have much of an appetite so you can imagine our pleasure when the first item on the menu was a chilled tomato-watermelon soup followed by a-ok summer squash salad.  My issue w the salad was it was doused in dressing, making it hard to really enjoy the complexity of the arugula, squash and other yummy veggies.

Others also enjoyed salads and some side corn, which was a super nice touch. For dessert, we shared the fabulous fruit cobbler.
author: Tamz O.

description: Came here after a night at the Dogpatch bouldering gym down the street.   Comfy place with great food and a good selection of beers.  Will be back!
author: Bianca P.

description: Food was a bit overly complicated. And there were some odd tastes. But service was good and the wines were reasonably priced. The temperature in the room was uncomfortably warm though.
author: David B.

description:
Burgers on the Fly in Portrero!
I love to not only dine in, but found that this is my new fav neighborhood drive by when I want a good quality burger to go among other things! Fries were nice and crispy and withstood the quick drive home...in tact!
author: Lee M.

description: I was in last week for lunch, and I can't stop thinking about my meal! The stone fruit salad was one of the most delicious things I have eaten! The sesame addition was not only creative, but now a requirement in my at home rendition of this salad. Now, for that fried chicken. Crispy, moist, perfectly brined and seasoned, this chicken couldn't have been any more delicious! Served with this incredible potato salad. I am not kidding, my mouth is watering while typing this. Hats off to the chef and his staff! I can't wait to go back.
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
Really good food in a trendy hipster package. The only thing that really disappointed me about this place is that I hadn't gone before.

Some how I forget how close Dogpatch is from my home just like I forget how much it has changed in the last ten years and especially in the last couple years. One of the biggest changes has been the hipster restaurants that have opened in the area. Serentine with it's high windows blocking any view of 3rd street  and prices in the 20's for entrees is part of the 3rd street rail gentrification.  

All the food though was lacking in pretentiousness and deliver in quality, creativity and value. With most of the dishes under 20 dollars and many under 10, it's a good value for the quality and portion sizes.

The meat board is a great selection of cured meats with selections you wouldn't even find at the Boccalone meat counter. Highlights were the beef heart pastrami and the spiced coppa. The only average portion was the country pate which was really a terrine and a fairly average one at that.

The chickpea batter calamari is a great deal at 8:50. It is an entree sized dish with a huge heap of calamari on a bed of lupini beans. The beans were a nice compliment to the tender and crisp calamari.

Although I was advised by the waiter that the Harissa Rubbed Sonoma Goat Leg Roulade was an appetizer, I found it to more than adequate as an entree. The severing of Roulade was around 3 ounces and was wonderfully cooked. There was still the richness and tanginess of the goat that perfectly matched with the harissa. 

The vegetarian dish we had was just as good as all the meat dishes.   The house made potato gnocchi was light and fluffy and the sauce as well at the vegetables were delicious.

The only miss of the whole meal was the dessert. We had a chocolate cake with coconut ice cream and cherry sauce. The cake itself was dry and bland. The coconut ice cream was good but it is from Bi-Rite creamery and not made in house. The cherry sauce wasn't good enough to improve the texture or flavour of the cake.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
Summary based on 1 lunch:
--ok food.  I got the char siu pork sandwich, which was ok, but nothing special.  Fries were ok.
--ok prices for an upscale place
--ok service
--parking possible on street, but blocks away

When you walk into an aspirational hip place you get higher hopes for the food, though you know they're liked to come to nothing as you get indifferent service and a big bill.  Not really the case here, where the food matched the decor and the service wasn't bad, though one more staff person on the floor probably would have made sense.  

Instead of getting the default hamburger, which I generally find disappointing when compared with generic In-N-Out or Oscar's in Berkeley, I got the char siu pork sandwich, which had some greens on decent bread along with the somewhat limp fries.  Both were ok and appropriate in quality and cost to the place.  Not everyone like crispy fries, I guess.

I may have tried to sniff wifi, since I was dining solo, but didn't get any as I recall.  Too bad.  This is becoming a necessary amenity.  Several non-disgusting, though perhaps overloud, biz conversations nearby.  No mute button handy.

Parking is the usual horror for this area, but I had already parked blocks away for a work site meeting, so maybe I've solved that particiular issue for this area.

keywords: hip, innovative
author: Rich H.

description: I found the Bloody Mary's lacking in taste, texture, & garnishes....very disappointed!=(  The food wasn't all that great either.
author: T H.

description: Came here with the family for brunch on a Saturday with no reservations. The wait was about 30 minutes, but it was so worth it. I had the country fried steak which was simply delicious. The biscuit was not overly dry and the scrambled eggs were fluffy and light, just how I like them. Will definitely return.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
We came back for brunch and were as happy as ever. 
We got the 
-Red Flannel Hash: beef brisket  - roasted beets - crispy potatoes - horseradish créme fraiche - poached eggs & grilled levain (Sooo Good)
-Fried Egg Sandy: eadbetter's english mufffin - fried egg - arugula - dill aioli - crispy potatoes..with sausage of course (Good)
-Buckwheat Pancakes: bananas - candied walnuts - maple syrup - whipped cream (Delicious)

It was a wonderful place for brunch, I'm really glad we went.
author: ariana t.

description: Still a five! Treated dad to brunch and "toured" two tables before i accepted a booth, which we wanted. Hostess was cool in the face of my insistence, kudos to her! Crab benedict replaced with salmon, still very good. Out of town guest loved her hash and eggs and, as always, we all loved the spicy bloody marys. Serpentine is fine for the elderly, the very young and everyone inbetween. Very well trained staff and the food stands up to every high standard, Consistently. My go to, and could be yours too.
author: Kelly K.

description: Nice neighborhood spot. Consistent creative meals, great service. Brunch is sooo good, that red flannel short rib hash is the stuff of breakfast dreams.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Serpentine was ok. Went with a group of six, and had an argument about who got to eat what because I wanted an appetizer as my main dish and they all wanted that appetizer to share and I was just not willing to cave into peer pressure. I called it first! 

Seriously though, I was somewhat disappointed in the sense that the food was ok but not amazing considering how expensive this place is. Slow Club is a better deal for what they charge. Several of the dishes were tasty but greasier than I would have liked, and there's not much point in me saying which ones because their menu changes enough that it will probably be different next time I go back. They have almost no vegetarian or fish options (maybe only 1 of each on the menu). 

One of the better options in Dogpatch, but somewhat pricey for what it is.
author: Sam Z.

description:
This place has nice decor & ambiance.  Although at night it is a little too dark - it's hard to even read the menus. 

Best burger & fries!  They use Prather Ranch beef & their burger is *much* better than Nopa.  The burger is really juicy & delicious.  The fries are amazing.  

I love the crispy brussel sprouts.  

The chickpea battered calamari is great - especially for those that cannot eat wheat. 

The cheese & meat board was good - my friend really liked the duck liver mousse.  (I don't like liver or duck so I cannot comment as I didn't try it) 

My friend had the gnocchi with crab - disappointingly small portion (more of an appetizer portion) and good, but he would go for another dish next time.  

The one thing I would say is that the bread seems like great quality, but if it were warmed up it would be delicious.  Perhaps they would warm it on request ;-)
author: N A.

description: For all the style and pomp, this place is still a let down. The food was good...but it wasn't anything I couldn't make at home.
author: Lisa P.

description: Decent lunch menu: American cuisine. However blown away by their brunch. Love to find reasons to have brunch here.
author: Francesca H.

description: It may be in the Dog-patch, but it's so nice to get a brunch you don't need to wait in line for. We arrived at about 11 on a Saturday and they seated us right away! Everything was just superb. There were a few (2-3) vegetarian options, but they all looked superb.
author: Katie L.

description:
Fantastic evening at Serpentine! The bread pudding was incredible. The baked pasta was delicious and extremely unique; I've never had anything like it before. Great selection of dinner salads, their buttermilk dressing was fantastic. Lemon tart and apple streudel desserts were perfection. I had no issues with anything food related so cheers to the kitchen. 5 stars. Service, also 5 stars. Our server was excellent; he was super helpful with everything on the menu and very friendly.

Minus one star... and a big star at that: we were a table of 8, nice bill (food, desserts, wine, wine, wine)... we asked a staff member (hostess?) to kindly please call us a cab. She came back about 1 minute later and said "You should start calling, I called twice and can't get through." 

Um. Yikes. Not the kind of service you'd expect from a hopping new joint way out in the boondocks when you know a majority of your patrons are NOT from the area. Plus, on a Saturday night, you know that it usually takes a couple times to ring through. From there, we had to do our own work and it took about 40 minutes.

I will come back, absolutely, but will hope for a more friendly ending to the evening if I need some assistance.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Our friend observed that the "new Southern" is the new "new American" and after dining at Serpentine, we'd have to agree.  We started with the fried green tomatoes, sliced thing, along with cardoons (the stems of artichokes) -- crispy and delicious dipped into the alioli.  Entrees included the chicken (huge portion), the pork chop with peach chutney and black eyed peas cooked with bacon. I had the savory tomato bread pudding with squash and mixed greens -- a bargain entree at $11.50.  The space is industrial...all metal furniture and concrete walls. Sit in the booth in the back if you want to talk without shouting.

Dogpatch gentrification continues...
author: Vanessa H.

description: Came with a friend Sunday afternoon and made reservations ahead of time.  I had the Red Flannel Hash which was pretty much everything I love mixed into one dish with the potatoes perfectly crispy.  I also had a mocha which I think was the best mocha I've ever had!
author: Lindsey Y.

description:
Yummy for brunch- had a bite of the savory bread pudding :) and i had the country fried steak on biscuit- and the steak wasn't anything special by itself, but with the biscuit- it was quite remarkable.  
nice atmosphere, cool space.
author: Sydel S.

description: Amazing food, awesome ambiance but service could have been better. Several times it felt like the waiter forgot about us. But all in all not a reason not to visit this awesome Dogpatch spot!
author: Lizzie S.

description: Wonderful amazing service beautiful bar and restaurant, food was phenomenal! Victor is an amazing bartender
author: Angel K.

description: Part of the "great burger search" enaged with a friend, this was on the list.  A worthy contender.  A part of the city I never go to and was amazed to see what's changed in this area.  Nice parking.  Great warehouse feel.  Had the burger with chedder, medium rare.  Great seasoning, excellent bun, toasted and with some sort of light butter garlic spread that worked well.  Fries were plentiful and done well.  Nice beer selection.  I would return for sure as the non-burger selections looked very nice.
author: Marc S.

description:
Hmmm...  High expectations that were not met.  We popped in for brunch and I opted for the savory bread pudding and salad which was actually quite tasty.  On that alone I might give them four stars.  The rest...  The other egg dish was rather lack luster but the real kicker was that we were half way through lunch before our drinks were served.  Fortunately we weren't in to much of a hurry so we could linker over the bloodies which were nice and spicy, but it was so unprofessional?  There wasn't even an apology.  Additionally, although I'm a fan of industrial decor, this one was rather unimaginative.
I see the other reviews are generally quite good so I hope the waitstaff was just having an off day.
author: Kara H.

description:
Came here with a bunch of friends on a Thursday night. It was packed, but thankfully we had reservations. The service was very cordial, with the waitress actually making conversation with us. 
The cocktails were really good, strong and smooth, which led us to keep them coming. 
The portions were huge, but after a long day at work, I managed to wolf down my roast chicken. This was probably the best roast chicken I have ever had. It was marinated perfectly, and cooked just right, keeping all the juices in, and ever bite had that incredible flavor!
 I will go again to try the other options.
author: Gurpreet S.

description:
Crispy confit duck gizzards, 3 stars
Grilled swordfish, 2 stars
My husband had grilled sardines, he said they were just ok, so 2 stars 
Wine list, 3 stars
Service, 3 stars
Soy latte, 4 stars
author: Ali A.

description: Really bad hostess that ruins your experience. Doesn't know how to seat people. She pointed us to the table instead of seating us after a 1 hour wait. Eve is her name. She should mop the floors instead of seating people her attitude would better match that job.
author: Honor G.

description:
It was so good I almost didn't want to ask.

"It" being the house veggie burger that stopped me in my tracks as I was headed home from a peninsula evening with the grandparents. Two people whom I love dearly, but likely would not have shared my enthusiasm as they continue to be somewhat amused/appalled their grandson has evolved from eating ribs/beef to veggie/chicken.

I had planned on grabbing a sandwich elsewhere, but after seeing this chickpea patty, caramelized onions, butter lettuce and special sauce (as well as sauteed mushrooms and cheese for those of you inclined) concoction on the menu, I grabbed a seat inside.

The burger was splendidly delicious. In fact so good I was worried the crusted exterior meant the patty was fried. I didn't want to ask and ruin it but my curiosity got the best of me. My waitress replied with a no, it's just pan seared. Awesome.

I greatly appreciated how it was made as requested (everything I didn't want I didn't get, and sauce on the side was just enough to sample) and served up with a smile. The only reason why I'm not giving the full five stars is the price. I thought $10.50, even with salad or fries on the side, was a bit steep.

Delicious, veggie, house made, not fried, dogpatch. Just another excellent San Francisco moment.
author: Jason B.

description:
Not bad not bad.... I ordered the gnocchi with bacon. It was very tastey and creamy. However the portion was small, I was still hungry afterwards and I had eaten appetizers and bread. Also, it was more like I ordered bacon with a side of gnocchi. They really overdid it with the bacon...but who doesn't ike bacon. $16.50 for gnocchi and $3 for bacon is a bit expensive. I think it should be more like $13 for gnocchi and $2 for bacon, especially considering the size of the meal.

I probably won't come back. The place was not bad. It just didn't blow my mind and leave a lasting impression except in my waistline from the 10 pieces of bacon that were probably in my meal.
author: Mei C.

description:
Food was good but the wait time was horrible.  We were told it would be around a 20 minute wait for a table.  1 hour and 2 drinks later we asked how much longer it would be. Host said about 15 more minutes "you're the first on the list" same thing he said when we first got in.  Finally after 1 1/2 hours after arriving we got a table.  It would have been fine if we had been quoted an 1 1/2 hour wait time at the start or if the host had apologized and comped a drink while we were waiting but to state a 20 minute wait time when it's really an hour and a half is misleading.  To not acknowledge how long it took to get a table is kiiind of rude imo. 

Once we were seated the dinner was delicious and the service was fine, but not worth the wait.
author: melissa w.

description: I would have loved to have commented on the food but didn't get a chance to eat at Serpentine despite having a reservation for lunch today. Upon opening the door, I found the entryway to be completely packed as a mass of people, also with reservations, was waiting for a host. After 15 minutes, no host was to be found. Not even an acknowledgment of, "I'll be with you shortly." Rumor among the waiting crowd was that the host was pulling double duty as a server, which I am sympathetic to as having previously been a host myself, but it was unclear as all of the servers were studiously avoiding eye contact with the anxious and hungry hordes. Perhaps one of us should have aggressively grabbed someone but I don't think diners should be put in the position of begging for our existence to be recognized. Again, I can't comment on the quality of their lunch food, but I can with absolute certainty say that they have some serious problems with their customer service/front of house operations. Such a shame...
author: Tony P.

description:
I love that this joint takes rezzies for brunch. Brunch, as everyone well knows, is a crazy line enduring experience at the majority of brunch places in the city. It was a rainy saturday and we happily breezed by the crowd waiting and stomped by in our galoshes to our waiting table. I was really happy with my burger (of course) which was deiciously juicy and beefy. I added a fried egg to make it brunchy :) Others at the table had a crab benedict and the simple egg, meat and potato breakfast. They even concocted a fruit salad on the spot (even though it's not on the menu) which had a yummy variety of persimmons, pears and other yummy seasonal fruit. Thumbs up!

BTW - parking is a breeze!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
And so we come to #7 on 7x7's Best Burger list.  I was excited to try our Serpentine in general because I had heard such great things about it but had never been.

Quick notes of things I liked outside of the burger review:

1)Cozy atmosphere.  This is a warehouse turned restaurant but they manage to make it comfortable and warm.  You'd never know from the inside except when you look up at the vaulted ceiling which is unfinished.

2)Good cocktail menu.  I've shied away from cocktails lately but I managed to taste both Andrei's and Gene's and they were both tasty.

3)Great calamari.  Often people just default to batter, fry, serve w/cocktail sauce & tartar sauce.  This actually was much lighter and delicious.

Now for the burger...

Mind you, this is the 4th burger we've had and outside of Zuni, they were all pretty unique and tasty.  That being said, I wasn't disappointed in Serpentine's burger, there was just nothing to make it memorable.  The outside was pretty charred while the inside was very medium rare (I asked for medium) which is fine, but it seems like maybe the way they cook it is not making it even throughout the burger.  The meat was juicy and delicious tho, so a plus for that.  I asked for blue cheese which may have been a mistake because the taste is so strong but I enjoyed it nonetheless.  Other than that, there were pickled onions and pickles on a plain bun.  All were good but nothing that says 'this definitely should be on the top 10 burger list'.  

So with all that said, it was good - but when I go back to Serpentine (which I will!) I wont be jumping to get the burger.  I'm rating this #3 (or 4) of all the burgers we've had so far.  Stay tuned for the next burger review!
author: Melanie N.

description: We had a great dinner at Serpentine.  We shared an apple salad with spiced pecans, cheddar cheese, fennel, and an apple cider vinaigrette -- it was plenty for two to share.  I had the Indian-spiced braised lamb shank and my wife had the wild mushroom/chestnut ravioli.  The lamb was a huge portion - I took half of it home.  (No ravioli survived.)  For drinks I had the Broc Cellars Valdiguie -- an unfamiliar varietal.  It was nice but a bit light for my taste.  I loved the Travers Cote du Rhone, though.  My wife had a delicious aged Manhattan and a glass of Happy Canyon Merlot.  The desserts sounded great but we were too full.  Maybe next time.  The service was a bit slow -- it was a Friday night and the place was packed and the servers were working hard.  But otherwise everything was just great.
author: Robert W.

description:
I went here for brunch with family when they opted out of the wait at Just For You Cafe a block away.  It ended up being a satisying experience and I will definitely be back.

From the exterior, this place looks mysterious and one could easily pass by it without a glance.  We were seated immediately. I ordered a fried egg sandwich and it was divine. The bread...what was that stuff? I don't know, but I'm drooling thinking about it.  The bread they used for the sandwich was really unique and yummy.  The texture was crumby, but the moistness held it together very well.  All I know is it melted in my mouth.  

This place is clean and their bar seemed quite enticing. I will certainly be back for the food and to check out their bar.
author: Jaime L.

description:
My go-to place for lunch or dinner.  Their burgers are good and always cooked to order:  they truly understand "rare" which I prefer, and have hit the mark with all my friends regardless of burger preference.  I just had their pork tacos which were super yummy.  The service is always prompt, friendly and professional.  The decor is exactly what you would expect in Dogpatch.  I love this place!

UPDATE:  the above is my previous review.  Went to dinner there last night 9/7/17 for the first time since the remodel.  What's up???  New management and new chef too???  Not sure but it sure felt like it.  Super disappointed.  Ordered the pork chop - all bone a grizzle.  Not fit for human consumption.  And the ceiling fans - did the construction guys who did the remodel forget to leave the controls?  They are set on high and feel like a category 4 hurricane!   When the fan continues to blow out your table candles you ought to know there's an issue.  Service was good and thankfully they comp'ed the horrible pork chop.  Serpentine, you get one more chance before I become a 100% Piccino only person.
author: bill l.

description: Great food, great service, great people, great decor.  Randomly stopped for breakfast and was on a first name basis with the bartender by the time we left.  Everything was tasty, but the house-made strawberry jam was my favorite.  The sausage wasn't super memorable, but all the other flavors were strong and blended together perfectly.  If you're in the area, this place is the best.
author: Jorf D.

description: feels sexy inside. dark. Hipster-y. It's one of the few really great places in the immediate vicinity, but it's def worth a try for a nice dinner w/ friends. Great coktails. Good, interesting plates. Our table had a mix of fish, meat and poultry dishes. The fish was alright a bit overcooked, the meat dishes seemed to be the best.
author: Shanee B.

description:
With the holidays rolling in, I catch up with my friends I don't see that often.  With one friend in particular, we have an unspoken agreement that we try a place neither of us have been to in town.  We chose Serpentine because the menu sounded both interesting and comforting.  What I mean by that is it is American with a twist.  

What we shared:

Fresh oysters on the halfshell:  two different varieties, came out with grated fresh horseradish and prosecco mignonette, and lemon slices.  

Maple roasted pumpkin salad:  large slices of sweet pumpkin with dense texture (could have been kabocha), with arugula salad and citrus vinaigrette.  

Braised pork spareribs: they were really more like baked babyback ribs, with quince and cranberry mostarda

Chickpea battered calamari: with salad of italian butter beans and tomato

One ancient lemon martini: their version of lemon drop martini


The best part:  our server.  She was prompt, efficient and friendly.

Second best part:  fresh oysters.  But they did not require cooking.

For the most part:  This is one of those cases where everything falls a little short of expectation.  Roasted pumpkin was dry and the chunks were too large.  The ribs lacked the "braised" juicy texture, and they were dry.  The quince and cranberry mostarda was also just tart and dense. Calamari were not crispy even though they were battered and deep fried, they were rather swimming in oil.  

Our biggest gripe really was how cold it was in the restaurant.  The place looking like a converted warehouse, we kept looking around for portable outdoor heaters but found none.  Instead we ate with our coats on and still shivered.

Maybe I will try their burger next time if I happen to be in the neighborhood during summer time.
author: Alice A.

description:
Prior to working in the Dogpatch, I had no idea that there were so many cute little shops and restaurants that line 3rd Street. Now that I spend about 70% of my time working in area, I'm proud to say I know about all these great places and I'm happy to patronize them and recommend them to all. 

Before my shift, I like to take a seat at the bar for Serpentine's yummy brunch. Despite the noted wait times in previous reviews (as well as for any other brunch joint in SF on a Sunday), I've never waited for a bar seat and the service has always been quick and friendly. So far I've tried the Beef Brisket Hash and the Chicken Fried Steak. The hash was truly memorable as it was colored beautifully by the accompanying beets. The steak was the perfect little portion and boasted an amazing beefiness that only well sourced, good quality beef can possess. Both dishes came with home fries that were fried just like my grandma used to make em, with a light, crisp, golden brown exterior with a creamy interior. 

Even though I sit at the bar, I haven't had a drink yet, but the alcohol selection seems extensive with some organic pours on hand. I will have to stop in for just a drink sometime, post work. 

Go Serpentine for presenting a great brunch without the hassle of waiting. You are my go-to for a pre work Sunday brunch.
author: Christina N.

description: A solid local restaurant that rarely disappoints but rarely surprises me. As others have said the burger is excellent, and the brunch menu is more interesting than the standard SF mimosas and eggs. A good place for a lunch or a light dinner before going out, although the rather stark, minimalist feel to the place makes it difficult to feel like a venue for a 'special' dinner. Service is always friendly, although spotty in it's efficiency.
author: Sam E.

description:
After reading a newspaper article about the best restaurants to visit for burgers in the city, my mother, sister and I decided to give it a try.

We all had the ranch burgers, with salad and fries, which was very tasty, and true to the article's word, it was one of the nicest burgers I've had in the city. It was also cooked to perfection.

The staff were amicable and helpful, and the atmosphere of the interior space was relaxed yet still efficient. Would visit again and would recommend to friends.
author: Sophie R.

description: Love Love Love Love this place - Amazing Brunch and kick ass atmosphere.  I loved my server Victor, he really knew his menu and wines.  I highly recommend this spot!
author: megan K.

description:
Came here at a recommendation of some random person on Facebook.  Looked it up on Yelp, and our Saturday has been made!!

Loved this place!!

We (my gf and I) came around 11:30am, and were afraid that we'd get the usual S.F brunch line, but we didn't!  We were seated right away (even though the place was fairly full), maybe we got lucky judging from the other reviews!

It's intimate but gives you room to breath.  The service was so friendly and always there, without hovering.  The coffee was awesome (they serve Mr. Espresso from Oakland).

Of course The Food is the star here!  I had the baked eggs with spicy garbanzo, and my partner had the Red Flannel Hash, and we split a pancake (which came with strawberries, bananas, pineapple and walnuts!)

Everything was just so scrumptious and fresh, I can't wait to come back and try the other items on the menu!!!

One of my fav places to brunch!
author: Rollio R.

description:
I'm very happy with my first meal here - it's New American, the city's current rage.  The roast chicken, often a dangerous choice, was as juicy, crispy, and flavorful as any in town, and the bed of pureed squash and chicken juice was bread-sopping delicious.  Salad was strong.  Service was friendly but slightly unfocused - we said we were sharing but they didn't offer share plates or cutlery for two.  On the other hand the waiter made a spot-on wine recommendation.  The dessert list is slightly disappointing.  Each of the five or so choices was something you could easily do at home and involved a variant of Bi-Rite ice cream, so they were tasty but not at the creativity / effort level of the rest of the food and $7 seemed a little much for that.

I love the interior, and that's part of the charm.  It's a dramatic high-ceiling brick warehouse that they've left in rugged form, then added a warm modern appointments down below at diner level.  It reminds me of some of the best designs from the 1990s when SOMA first became the place to be.  Here in the emerging Dogpatch neighborhood, it can be very cold, windy, and eerily lonely on the broad long streets outside... but inside it's warm and there's a crowd even on a quiet night.

Even though it's not quite perfect the chicken was so good, and the vibe comfortable and endearing, so I would definitely put this on my short list where I'd like to come back because it all kind of hits the spot.
author: Gil S.

description:
In one of my many quests to find a nice restaurant for lunch within a 10 mile radius of Daly City, I came across Serpentine via Yelp and what a pleasant surprise!

The interior is lovely -- industrial chic with high ceilings and exposed red brick. We were a large party and were seated immediately at a nice roomy table. The lunch menus were attached to mini clipboards - very clever and suited the theme.

The menu itself contained 5 or 6 entrees (keeps it easy and simple) and there was something for just about everyone (pulled pork sandwich, burger, pastas, salads). The entrees were made with highest quality ingredients (i.e. sustainable, organic, etc.). 

I took the least healthy route and ordered the burger and WOW, was it savory and delicious!  My burger came with melted blue cheese, perfectly cooked medium. The soft bun and pickled onions took it to a whole other level.

All in all, my dining experience at Serpentine's was truly memorable.
author: Briar F.

description:
Came here for the first time for an Easter brunch with some old friends. I absolutely LOVE brunch and breakfast, and came with high expectations. I had also made the restaurant suggestion, so I was really hoping it wouldn't disappoint. Thankfully, Serpentine lived up to its 4-star rating.

First off, we had a big group and couldn't get a last-minute reservation so we were concerned about a wait. We made sure to get there right as they opened, and they were great about getting us squeezed in right away. Absolutely exceeded my expectations, especially for a packed holiday weekend! The service was great all throughout the meal, too. Attentive but not too pushy; speedy but friendly. 

The food was excellent. Our table sampled a lot of the dishes, and everyone seemed to quite like their food. I had a buckwheat pancake and split some steel-cut oats with a friend. The pancake was delicious, but the oats were slightly lackluster--too soupy for my tastes and just a few banana slices plopped on top. Meh. The coffee was nice and hot, and they kept it coming. By the end, I was stuffed, as was my wallet. Hooray!
author: Amy O.

description: Took my friend here for a birthday lunch. Their BURGERS ROCK!
author: Sue L.

description:
My absolute favourite burger in the city.
I really like their breakfast as well. Although, I wish that they had Eggs Benedict.
author: Conor L.

description:
I cannot say much about this dinner...

Well maybe I can. 

I still had trouble gauging from the alcohol consumed on this night. And not to mention the crazy cab ride over. The space is nice, this was my first introduction to the Dogpatch. Who knew SF has a Meatpacking District.

I always thought that was the Castro. Cheap shot, but hello - to my people.

But the lush warehouse interior was empty, industrial, and slightly vacant... but the service and smiles more than made up for it. We sat at the bar, because our crowd of three (a new mother, a crazy hairdresser and me) decided that's how we roll.

I don't remember our bartender's name, but he was from the East Coast--the hairdresser, Daniel knew him and he was cute. We called him Justin Timberlake. He was bringing sexy back in those delicious sidecars he made. He also looked so capable that I told him to surprise me, as I saw him pulling rosemary from a stem for another drink.

Bartenders that pull rosemary = they aren't fucking around.

We had a smorgasbord of appetizers. I don't remember the names, but I can list (some of) them off. I blame the third sidecar at this point.

Duck gesiers = never tried innards of a duck, but they were good...polenta, classy touch!
Calamari = really flavorful, accented well with some beans that I was chewing.
Meat board = I wanted more meat... paté was off the chain, I am a sucker for paté.

At this point, we were drunk and after getting a stink eye worse than Anna Wintour at Lindsay Lohan's debut at Ungaro from a few other patrons... we had to go. I guess it's not appropriate to talk about the penises, sexual practices, and things of the such over dinner.

I'd love to explore this neighborhood again and would perhaps go back here on a date. The cold interior makes for some perfect cupcaking atmosphere. Just be mindful that the chef and staff told us that we should shut up (nicely of course), they would tell you too.
author: Kim D.

description:
Had dinner here and the food was amazing. Between my partner and I, we ordered to share the Oso Buca..the pork with garbanzo beans and vegetables. It was so delicious how the pork pulled off the bone so easily. This dish had a lot of flavor.  I am a fan of brussel sprouts and loved the way Serpentine prepared it. It was deep fried and had a crisp grilled taste to it with some zest. We also had the lamp cheeks..so tender with a rich sauce. I had the rum punch and it was strong and tasty. Not bad to be know as a restaurant bar that has stiff drinks. They do not have beers on tap only bottled but they serve them in a glass and it's not a big deal.

The decor is minimal, modern, urban and nice: vaulted concrete ceilings, wood trim windows and mirrors. The only thing I didn't really enjoy and it's minor but would be a good thing for the hostess to know: we were seated at a two person table before the dinner rush. There were several tables to our side and when the next couple came in, they were seated right next to us instead of spacing them out at least one other table away since there were about 5 tables next to us. It felt awkward because all the other tables were empty and because we were so close there was no buffer zone for a private or intimate conversation at our table while there were several empty tables. I couldn't hear my partner. I had to keep leaning in to her him and he was talking loud and the couple next to us had to talk loud to hear each other as well.

I know it's a restaurant so I don't expect it to be private and of course I expect people to be seated next to me at the next table but if i were the hostess and I've have been one, I would not have placed two parties that elbow close in that situation of not having nearby tables occupied.

Overall, the food, drinks and service were great.
Glad that I was able to be have been there.
author: Racheljoy R.

description: JN told me this was her fave place in SF and I can see why. First off, the place is flat-out cool. It's beautiful, albeit a bit dark. Every item we had was delicious - the charcuterie had inventive and tasty selections, the chicken livers everyone else ate were said to be incredible, and my shortrib and wine glazed gnocchi was perfect. We gorged, and sadly we had no room for dessert.
author: David S.

description: Great drinks and food. Service was quick. I live off mission blvd and do not have a car so getting here is weird. Its further than I usually go but its totally worth the trek. Great date spot for dinner.
author: Courtney H.

description:
Came here a week after having a great lunch at Slow Club, their sister restaurant near Potrero with my boss - who's been eating there for about the past 12 years.

My wife and I both work in the city, and had driven in that day. Being Friday, and with a Giants game starting - we weren't looking forward to the commute home. With our daughter out-of-town, time for a well-deserved evening out. We lucked out and got in without a reservation, and settled into a nice corner table.

We each had a mixed drink - they've got a great selection of Bourbon, and Wife really enjoyed hers - I think it was a brandy-apple-pear something... A well-varied and tasty drink menu.

As usual, we split a salad, and two entrees. The food was excellent, with the highest-quality local ingredients and wonderful sauces. The hanger steak was perfectly done, and the sea bass on dungeness crab was insanely good. The crispy brussels sprouts were the best I've ever had brussels sprouts.
author: Kevin P.

description:
Brunch was quite awesome possum. I had perfectly scrambled eggs, and potatoes that I am sure had crack in them. Pork sausage was tasty...and I don't eat pork! 

You have to be comfy with the painful to be hip crowd...tight jeans abound!...but I'm being a meanie. Hipster boys I just want to wash and then I'll kick it with them.

Service was a bit spotty...coffee, Bellini, and a latte promised and then we needed to remind the server a few times...but because we sat next to the bar, we could see there was a bit of a breakdown in the service there. It seemed to get a bit heated, but honestly we shouldn't have had to wait as long as we did for drinks. That was the annoying part, but the food was so good, it was hard to ding them one star for that. Our waiter was trying hard to make the effort, and he was really nice about it.

But on the flip side, they were really nice to my daughter, each staff member stopping by to say hi as they passed. I can't hate on them for that.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Very cool spot, industrial with high exposed ceilings.  Wandered in here for lunch today with a friend and was immediately greeted by a very inviting and intoxicating aroma of cooked food.  I ordered the exceptionally delicious savory bread budding and drank a local IPA.  Friend had the cod and some fries.  Seeing as his plate was cleared in a matter of minutes I can only guess his was just as tasty as mine.  This food is serious.  Seeing other reviews, I'd love to try the burger but I was blown away with the bread pudding so no regrets!

Definitely would dine here again and again if I lived nearby.
author: Shaun T.

description: Was here with a girlfriend for Sunday brunch- delicious and not ridiculously pricey.  Highly recommend the Dungeness Crab Benedict or Buckwheat Pancakes. Make sure to make reservations tho- this place is popular!  And look for the hot waiter with scruff and a ponytail... ;)
author: Michael R.

description: My wife really wanted to get dancing lessons for our wedding dance so I found myself in the dogpatch area five Tuesdays in early 2013.  We ate here every night and it was delicious.  Wide open space and very trendy.  Try the hamburger and definitely get the salad with apples.
author: Jeff P.

description:
As a resident of Potrero Hill, I love staying in the neighborhood and sampling the various restaus in the area. 

I've been to Serpentine a few times now, sampling things from the Brunch and Dinner menus. The ambiance is great; I absolutely love the space, despite having no windows, the dining area seems larger than it is. Most recently I've had the burger which I think is one of the best in the city. Today, I had a bloody mary and the baked eggs. The bloody mary was great; the pickled accoutrement is excellent! The baked eggs were okay, I say this hesitantly as I think it would have and could have been a great dish had they not over cooked the eggs and more importantly, had I not found egg shells in them. C'est la vie. 

Despite the technical errors, service is prompt and attentive. A great place for simple food done well.
author: Douglas L.

description:
Great introduction to this restaurant in my new neighborhood.  Short menu with a great selection to satisfy most tastes.  Their idea is to use local, fresh ingredients.  Good cocktail list too.  This would definitely be on the regular list.

The chef's name was printed at the bottom of the menu card -- Deepak Kaul.  I was curious and so looked him up.  Turns out he is a med student who discovered a passion for cooking.
author: M. B.

description:
Dropped in to Serpentine at the weekend with a friend to check it out. Really liked the ambience from the moment I walked in, bustling and chatting but you can still find a corner to talk in. 

Had spiced lentil soup with creme fraiche and pomegranate seeds, was delicious. Oysters were great and then followed up with a plate of the house gnocchi, which was definitely something I'd get again. 

We had cocktails and the bill was about 40-45 per person. 

Great place and I'd go back soon.
author: Paul G.

description: Always delicious. I love their savory bread pudding...so yum & different every time we go. Make reservations for weekend brunch though, its crowded.
author: Ashly M.

description: Being the company man that I am, when obliged to go consorting I do just that. So I found myself among coworkers and vice presidents alike.  Sitting at a table across from my manager, all I wanted to do was get to the punch line of my joke. Maybe the set up was too long or maybe the days' tedious events were much to alluring to ignore, but either way I wasn't finishing my joke.  The starters were ordered along with plenty of red wine.  Mr. Villa and I are well known to partake in libations fermented with a grape base so we had the reins in term of choosing wine for the table.  A few olives and a couple of glasses later the table was ready to make its selections for dinner. I had the gnocchi with mushrooms while my coworker, seeking a way to stick it to the company, arbitrarily ordered the most expensive dish on the menu. This dish just so happened to be a large sloppy piece of bone-in lamb shank. My buddy was embarrassed at its sheer size. While everyone else opted for something more manageable, my buddy really went for it. My gnocchi was underwhelming in taste, but had a wonderfully complex presentation and an even better smell. If I only ate with my eyes I would have been full.  The dish needed more depth, or maybe just salt. I understand the idea of preserving a delicately flavored dish, and this dish was indeed that, but more was needed. My friend's dish on the other hand was flavor incarnate. He was up to his elbows in lamb before he started offering some to the rest of the table. I took a sliver and found it very rich without much balance. I could go on, but this review is becoming aimless and verbose. All in all the food was not bad the service followed suit, and a good time was had by all. Would I go back with the wife? Probably just for drinks...
author: George S.

description:
So I am a huge weekend brunch fan.  Unfortunately, there are many other SFers that like to laze over blueberry waffles or huevos rancheros with perhaps an early start to the nightlife via mimosas and bloody mary's.  Which translates to a lot of competition trying to grab brunch at the best places over the wknd.

Occasionally my go-to place, which is Mission Beach Cafe, has lines that are out of control so I was forced to find another place in my hood (soma/mission/potrero).  My friend recommended Serpentine to me for dinner, so on a whim, another friend and I decided to try it out for brunch.  We called for a "reservation" 30 min before we went into the restaurant, and was pleasantly surprised that we were seated immediately.

And the food was quite yummy.  They also use fresh, seasonal ingredients for standard brunch fare and also have a small but high quality selection of lunch food as well.  I liked the industrial-chic inside of the space with lots of light coming through the windows, so a check plus for ambience.  I quite liked my fried egg sandwich -- simple but made with high quality ingredients and flavorful.

I am torn on whether I should be writing this review since that means more people will discover this weekend brunch gem, but I couldn't resist.  Do try it if you are in the hood and you want a nice brunch at affordable prices without a long wait!
author: Ellen C.

description:
Fried Brussels Sprouts:  Yum!  No breading, just crispy and salty.  I'm still thinking about them!
Oysters:  Yum
Wine:  Yum.
Chickpea Battered Calamari:  Yum.
Roasted Mary's Half Chicken:  Super, freaking yum.
Cheese Plate:  Eh.  Basically, $6.50 for 2 oz. of gouda.  

I'll be back for the burger soon!  Loved the atmosphere, too!
author: Valerie D.

description:
::brunch review::

more like 3.5 stars actually, but i gave em 4 because they kept giving us free food! 

the girls and i came here for brunch one day. who woulda thought there'd be such a cute little spot in this area..haha. 

the food here is pretty average. typical brunch food with no twists..decent grapefruit mimosas (that are like $11 each...). the service was par, nothing extraordinary. the setting/decor was really cute, though. the place was a bit small, so the wait can be pretty long..

my girl and i shared the crab benedict (duh, if u know me by now) and the country fried steak. if youre debating between the two, go benedict. for sure. 

i'm not opposed to coming back here for brunch, however, i'd probably explore other options first. for what we paid here, we could have had bottomless mimosas with our brunch elsewhere! nothing spectacular about this place, but its a place i'd still recommend u make a stop at once in your life. haha.
author: Linh P.

description: I made reservations here for my boyfriend's birthday brunch for the two of us- first of all, let me say that again- I made RESERVATIONS, for BRUNCH, on a SATURDAY, in SAN FRANCISCO. They could have fed me anything and I've had been happy, but what they did feed me was amazing. My boyfriend had chicken with biscuits and gravy. he is pretty much a culinary expert and couldn't stop raving about the biscuit. I had "Eggs Meat and Potatoes" pretty straightforward and very good! Crispy potatoes cooked perfectly, and the bread was hearty. Service was a tiny bit lacking; I had to ask once for a coffee refill after a bit, but they were pretty busy. High ceilings, minimal decor, and bright lighting make this an excellent destination for a brunch.
author: Sidnie D.

description: great spot, though my only thing is more comfy chairs at the high table...brunch was awesome and they did their best to accommodate us!
author: Anna S.

description:
Two items you need to get:  country fried steak and the bread pudding.  

Country Friend Steak (yes, friend!):  The accompanying potatoes were perfectly fried in their diced manor.  Very fresh, very crunchy not burnt.  Perfect.  The scrambled eggs were slightly slimy and gooey.  Just the way I like it.  The steak sits on top of buttered toast/muffins?  I couldn't even tell..I just knew it was the shiznit the moment my tongue told my brain it was.  Yes, that wonderful.

Bread Pudding:  Personality - awesome.  Strengths:  Taste good.  Why - because it's official like a referee whistle.  Seriously, don't ask too many questions.  Just order and shove it in your mouth.  You deserve it.

The decor here was very modern, very hipster servers.  The guy had some chest hair sticking out of his low-cut vneck (you can't help but notice) in which somehow enhanced my meal.  I don't know why..but I guess it made the place very cool and I felt very comfortable as if a friend had cooked it for me?  I'm not sure..no, I was not attracted to this guy.

The sunlight just beams into the restaurant not so much in the form of windows you can stare out, but more from the ceiling!  I would have given this place 5-stars, but it lacked a patio to sit outside.
author: Yup S.

description: Uninspired industrial warehouse decor and curtain-closed bathrooms awkwardly plopped in the restaurant's middle aside, Serpentine was a delicious experience for us. Everything we ordered for our early dinner was portioned generously and prepared with a sharp focus on flavor: pickled vegetables, the famed burger, and lamb shank. Best of all, the cocktails available were thoughtfully composed and well balanced. Though the service was a little slow, and the volume of music unfortunately forceful, the meal was worth it. Bonus points for sensible pricing and ease of parking, qualities not to be overlooked in San Francisco.
author: Zach W.

description:
2 of us walked in at 9:15 on Friday late and was quickly seated.  We ordered a few small plates to share and they were good: fries (thin crispy fries served with ketchup and aioli), and peach & nectarine salad (very refreshing, frisee and butter lettuce were very fresh, amount of dressing was perfect); calamari with beans and tomato sauce on the bottom (tender calamari, beans were probably a tad undercooked).  

The more disappointing dish was the ice cream sandwich.  It was Bi-Rite roasted banana ice cream served on between 2 snickerdoodle cookies.  I expected to be able to pick it up and eat it like a sandwich, but it was basically a cookie placed on the plate with soft/melted ice cream plated on it with the cookie placed on the top, which slid off when we got our place.   The coffee was good.

It's a bit loud in there, but like the industrial/warehouse feel and tall ceiling.  I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but we were at the wine bar across the street and wanted to grab a bite afterwards so this was convenient place.
author: Irene C.

description: When I wake up the next morning still thinking about the food I had last night I know it is a special restaurant. Super tasty wine, great atmosphere, great wine list, decent prices. Loved eating at the bar with my honey... very romantic date!
author: Lisa J.

description:
First off, I have to say that the team at Serpentine is the best. My friends and I were stuck in cross town city Friday rush hour traffic and basically running extremely late for our 6pm reservation. 15 minutes before our reservation, we call in to give them a heads up and they say no problem they can hold our reservation for up to 20 minutes. Well those 20 minutes evaporate as we're still sitting in traffic and I call back again to see if they will still hold our table. They tell us sure, no problem. Mind you, I'm totally worried as past experiences with restaurants consisted of dealing with an irate host/hostess who looks at me with disdain at not arriving on time (it's not like I'm late on purpose, I know what a reservation is) or losing the table b/c the allotted 15 minute buffer time has elapsed.

Once we finally get to the restaurant, we were greeted with a warm smile and confirmation that they still had our table ready for us. Whew! That alone made our evening. The hostess even commiserated with us and recommended for us to relax with a nice drink from the cocktail menu. That's pretty much 3 stars in my book.

Dinner was great, I ordered the duck leg, and my friends ordered the Prather Ranch burger (with guyere) and the Roasted Mary's Chicken. I may have overstuffed myself eating the leg. The polenta and persimmons served as a nice balance to the duck and basically contributed to me hoovering down the entire dish. I should have paced myself as I couldn't even enjoy dessert which was a chocolate bundt cake with chocolate Bi Rite ice cream with raspberry sauce. The cake wasn't overly sweet and the ice cream was amazing. I could only manage a few bites, but those bites left me wishing I could have more. :( 

Guess I'll have to add another place to the list of must visit again.
author: vivian h.

description:
Good drinks! The chickpea calamari was mindblowingly good and so so so tender!  I wasn't even that excited about the calamari since I'm not a huge fan of deep fried food but this was delicious!  We also shared a meat plate - all duck parts I don't remember but I do remember that everything was super tasty.  They toasted our bread for us to go with the meat plate too :)

Shared the Moroccan lamb shank but it wasn't as flavorful as we had hoped.  Very tender but I've had better.  Should have just gone to a Moroccan restaurant instead...  Next time I'll come back and get the burger.

I wish this wasn't so far out in the dogpatch, I'd definitely be here more often, especially for the cocktails.
author: Joanne L.

description: Went for lunch and wasn't blown away by the food, especially given the price. It was simply OK. Maybe dinner is better?
author: Evan T.

description: Crab Benedict was good, not amazing.  Same with the hash. Good service. Nice atmosphere.
author: Amjad S.

description: Yum yum yum.  I love their salads.  I've found it's a good spot to have a business lunch/dinner meeting in Dogpatch as well.
author: Laci G.

description:
Went to Serpentine last night and was pleasantly surprised on a few fronts. 

1) it was very busy for a monday (albeit holiday) night at ~9pm. Always a sign they are doing good thing. 

2) The cocktails were awesome and not killer expensive [they also have Old Potrero Whiskey at the bar, which is not easy to come by].

3)  We split two entrees and a side. All were epic:

- Bussels sprouts side: I love cooking these at home and these really stood out. First they were super crispy on the outside leafs, but the inside was still soft and tender. They also had hot pepper and grated cheese for an awesome mix of salty and spicy.

- House made gnocchi and dungeness crab: Lots of crab involved here. The gnocchi were cooked perfectly. Pretty darn creamy but there were soem crunchy breadcrumbs on top to balance it out a bit. 

- Entree size of the diver scallops: These were seared perfectly on the outside, but not overcooked. Sunchoke chips on top added some awesome crunch. 

Cheers!
author: Louis A.

description: Serpentine has an amazing burger. I got mine with gruyere cheese and a fried egg...mmmmm. The meat was well seasoned and cooked to perfection, the bun was great, the atmosphere was trendy and fun. Think, a high-end place with a mission feel. A very stylish place with fantastic food and a better than average beer selection.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Great food, atmosphere and service. Wine list isn't bad either - many good choices by the glass. We had a great server too - she knew the wines and made some great recommendations.

We were there on a Tuesday night and while it wasn't busy when we got there, it was packed when we left around 8:30pm, a great sign!

I had been here for brunch a while back and had their savory bread pudding which was to die for so was dying to try it for dinner.

The three of us shared two starters - the peach and nectarine salad which came with pancetta (which instead of it being "raw" should have been cooked until crispy) and the calamari. Whatever they coat the calamari with is awesome - it was some of the best I had ever had. It came with butter beans and a tomato compote, unique for a calamari dish, but excellent!

Two of us shared the the goat appetizer and the roasted chicken. The goat, I know, may sound strange for some, but it was excellent. Very tender and if you like lamb, you'll love this. The chicken was good too; crispy on the outside with a rosemary infusion. Good, but nothing too out of the ordinary. Our other friend had the salmon which looked good.
author: Miki C.

description:
Quality Food.  Went to this place after a co-worker recommendation and recently visiting the Dog Patch area of SF.  We came before a Giants game and loved our experience.

Server was pleasant and efficient
Quick service, but not too quick
No feeling of being rushed
All organic - farm-to-table ingredients
Original wholesome menu options

We had the Buckwheat Pancakes topped with Strawberries, Walnuts, Maple Syrup and Whipped Cream - perfection...enough sweet and felt healthy.

Fried Egg Sandwich - Buttermilk biscuits, fried egg, arugula, dill aioli with crispy potatoes. Perfect amount of food.  The biscuits with the combo of egg, arugula and dill was a perfect combo. 

YUMMMMMMMM!
author: three's company M.

description:
It really is the best burger in SF.
I didn't really care much for the appetizers but the burger really lived up to the expectation.

I'd go back for the burger again.
author: A S.

description:
Overcrowded, noisy and full of hot and sweaty masses.
Usually, I go to Beauty Bar to get my fill of the above.  However, I've recently discovered that you can have all that while dining too!  (Replacing the gyrating hipsters with white collar networkers, of course.)

I don't know.  On the two occasions that I've dined here, I've found this place to be a bit overrated and overpriced.   Aside from the cocktails, which are fantastic, I found everything I had to be just ok.  No wow factor to warrant the rave reviews and exorbitant prices.  Even the salmon was blah.  Service can be hit or miss, ranging from being attended to right away, to being ignored for a good 15 minutes while seated at a reserved table.  

The space is nice to look at, sort of upscale industrial, with high ceilings and light-colored wood work.  But because there are hard surfaces everywhere, and it gets so bleeping crowded (especially during happy hour times), it is truly an insurmountable cacophony in there.  

There are better places for the money.  But if you're set on trying this spot, do be sure to make reservations, as it appears that people wait quite a long time for tables here.  Come to think of it, it does appear to be a giant collection of *those* people who stand around in the middle of dance floors, yelling "conversations," and dripping with sweat, sloshing drinks all over each other.  If that is true, that Serpentine is a magnet for those anti-dancers, then I may up my star-rating, because they are keeping these people out of the clubs!
author: Ravena F.

description: I was looking for a good dinner spot for a triple date that I was having with some old friends.  Since I like their sister company, Slow Club, I decided to give this place a try.  It was not as good as my experiences at Slow Club.  The food was just average and nothing special about it...and this is based on tasting a couple of dishes that my friends and I all ordered and had a small piece of.  Maybe I should come and try out their brunch instead since everyone seems to love their brunch menu.
author: Dimps I.

description: Great for brunch! All egg options are good, especially the polenta and eggs. The pancakes look amazing too.
author: Annie V.

description: When we arrived there was no one here but us. It was a couple minutes after they had opened. We ordered the Pork Loin Sandwich, the Red Flannel Hash, the Ranch Burger and a Macchiato. At first our server was surprised that we were ordering so much food. Overall the good was ok, nothing exceptional. After a while I when we were done we were ready for our check but our waitress was no where to be found. When she did pop up around 3-4 times she completely did not acknowledge us. I don't think we will be coming back here again.
author: cherry w.

description:
I think Serpentine has the best burger in SF! Really!
For a long time it was "Roam" that held the #1 spot in my eyes, but now Serpentine has de-throned them. (they still are a close 2nd though).
The shaved vegetable salad is amazing as are many of the items on their menu. And brunch is great too....
The staff is very friendly yet professional. Only slight negative, it tends to get noisy very quickly.
author: Anita B.

description:
Serpentine is in a great part of town and its super easy to park.  It may be the only nice restaurant I can think of where parking is just there waiting for you.  The food is fun, delicious and inventive.  Be careful about fats and oils if you need to though - everything is pretty decadent that way.  For the budget-conscious they have the best burger in town (promise) but I recommend at least trying a few of the starters with it so you can explore the really amazing range of flavors and ingredients.  
The space is cool but it is loud.  I don't have the foggiest notion why restauranteurs insist on creating loud, hard concrete spaces over and again.  I think the noise must add an exciting 'busy' element that gets people out earlier so you can estimate seatings.  Whatever, the noise level is high and the design pretty much creates that but its the only sucky thing about Serpentine.
author: Margaret G.

description:
Had dinner last Thursday with two friends.  Had made a reservation for 7 PM earlier in the week (the restaurant had called to confirm that day.)  I arrived 5 minutes early and chose to be seated instead of having a drink at the bar.  My friends got stuck in traffic and arrived 15 min late but no worries.  I enjoyed a cocktail while waiting.  It was a simple martini straight up with olives and was fine but was not in your normal cocktail glass - maybe they had run out of the normal kind as I could see them on other tables?

The ambiance of the place was chic / cool but quite loud.  The restaurant was nearly full and everyone was talking loud to be heard which just made it louder.

The dinner menu has quite a variety of starters but we decided to just order our dinners.  The dinner menu was limited to eight items but they all sounded interesting.  I and another both ordered the hanger steak while the other friend ordered the House Made Potato Gnocchi with Wild Mushrooms.  We all loved our entrees.  The steaks were marinated and perfectly done as requested and excellent.  The portions are pre-carved and served on the plate and could have been slightly more generous but they tasted great.  The gnocchi was really delicious and I would be tempted to try that next time.  The wine menu was reasonably priced for an SF restaurant but not real extensive.

The service was good.  Things came out a little slow but we were enjoying our cocktails and conversation so it was nice to not feel rushed.  Our server was friendly and helpful the whole evening.

My friends had been to Serpentine twice before and had recommended we dine there so I know they were happy to come back.  I recommend it and will be back again some time as well.
author: SF K.

description:
Stopped in a few weeks ago for a quick lunch with my partner and a friend visiting from out of town. Didn't realize we needed a lunch reservation but they managed to get us the last table for three in the place. We had a lovely experience. 

Misremembering all the food details but the fries were awesome. Salads were super fresh. I ate fish and glass of prosecco. Everything was great. The service was sprightly but not clingy; just right. Our waiter looked a bit stretched; it was a full house but he took good care of us. We will definitely go back.
author: Randall J.

description:
I drove by this place a million times, and I had no idea it was a restaurant.  Serpentine is located right in the heart of the Dogpatch district, a stone's throw away from Kitchenette (http://www.yelp.com/biz/kitchenette-san-francisco#hrid:nUOY87bnI1ZJDU47n86nFQ), Hard Knox Cafe (http://www.yelp.com/biz/hard-knox-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:l8pUraATN2sWCLf2Bn4MEg) and Just For You (http://www.yelp.com/biz/just-for-you-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:zrleE76ANbS5q8oEhCjHfA).  Serpentine manages to maintain a true Dogpatch feel, all the while remaining a more refined dining option than the three places I mentioned above.

When I showed up for breakfast at 10:05, my friends had already been waiting for me.  They were sitting in a booth that reminded me of a muscle car.  Could it have been the brushed stainless steel tabletop, the charcoal leather seats, or, perhaps the combination thereof?  Whatever it was, it looked cool.  It also seemed as though our car had a sunroof, because the whole place was lit up with tons of natural sunlight.  The decor had a distinct industrial look to it, without being fake or pretentious.  Very well done.

The restaurant was pretty empty for a Saturday morning brunch, which allowed the waitress to focus on us.  She seemed a bit out of it, but she was there when we needed her.  She also refilled my coffee once, although I did have to wait a few minutes.

We ordered the buckwheat pancakes, served with blueberries and homemade whipped cream.  Despite being made out of heavier buckwheat flour, the pancakes were as fluffy and light as ever.  The homemade whipped cream was also a big hit.  I would strongly recommend getting at least one pancake to complement your meal (1 for $5.50, 2 for $8.50).  

I also went with a basic scrambled eggs/bacon/potatoes/toast combo ($9.50).  The bacon was delicious: meaty, not fatty and cooked to perfection.  I was not a big fan of their "crispy" potatoes.  Whatever seasoning they use to make them golden brown didn't quite work for me.  It was OK, but I would have preferred simple, plain potatoes.  I really liked their levain toast which tasted like baguette bread, but a tad more sour.  It went very well with butter and raspberry jam.

No lines, easy street parking, pleasant atmosphere, decent sized portions and reasonable prices . . . you bet I'll be back SOON.  

More like 4.5 stars, but sometimes it's fun to round up.
author: Yan G.

description:
Meh indeed.  My fiancee and I had Serpentine on our list for months to check out and finally had a chance.  We made Reservations and we're rewarded by being seated literally in a corner surrounded by walls.  As I sat facing the corner, I basically felt like I was in either Time Out or a janitor's closet.  Not the best for ambiance.  I can barely even remember what the place looks like for that reason.

Otherwise, the Service was very friendly and prompt, which is why I'm giving it 2 stars, but the food was really just blah and overpriced.  I got the Cod, which was hilariously small and uninteresting.  I can barely recall any flavor at all.  It sounded great on the menu but I had no idea how small a portion it was without any real substantive sides.  It was easily the smallest portion I have gotten in years.  It looked like airline food.  I was hungry when we left.  My fiancee got the hanger steak, which was more in the right direction but still ultimately nothing to write home about compared to other hanger steak I've had at French or Italian resaurants.  Overall pretty blah flavors on a pretty plate, and not enough of them.  

I'm not a picky eater and am happy to pay for good food, but this was pretty underwhelming.  I was a little turned off from the start due to the seating, but the food didn't make up for it.  Oh, and we got a couple of 9 dollar cocktails that I forgot about 5 minutes after having them.  

I wanted to love this place, as it is close to home and has all the ingredients for a cool restaurant, but it just didn't happen.  Could of been an off night, but I don't think I'll go again to find out.  There's too much great food in this city at other places.
author: Sean H.

description:
I would highly recommend Serpentine. The food here is always amazing--with fresh, local ingredients to fit the season, their menu is always changing and interesting. Last night I took my boyfriend to dinner to celebrate his birthday. I called ahead of time and told the hostess about my plans for his birthday and they really went out of their way to make the experience special. They gave us the best seat in the house, had champagne chilled and ready to pour, and quickly brought the appetizer I had pre-ordered. At the end of the meal, they creatively served a cake I had baked and brought by earlier for the occasion. It was an all around fantastic experience. Thank you to staff at the Serpentine for making it so special! 
Also, the calamari, cod, and scallops were delicious!
author: Caity B.

description:
Ridiculously good. Kudos to the chef, Deepak Kaul. Good prices - fun ambiance - great food.

Crispy Brussels Sprouts - Phenomenal. I am not a huge sprouts person, but they were really good. ($6.00)

Grilled Asparagus - Again, not something that I always order, but I do from time to time. Yum! ($6.00)

Three Cheese Starter - Fine, not my favorite. ($15.00)

Gnocchi with Wild Mushrooms - to die for. I obsess over Gnocchi. I have taken the classes at Sur La Table, I have bought the requisite ricers and have tried the butternut squash kind, the ricotta kind, the sweet potato kind - but I really love the regular homemade potato kind. Until now, a quick go-to has been at Jackson Fillmore. This place - although entirely different (less of a creamy, cheesy, tomato (y) ) - and much more vegetable (mainly mushroom) focused was melt in your mouth delicious. ($19.00)

With a $50.00 bottle, you could do dinner for two for $100.00 - and leave happy. I would definitely come back.
author: Tripti P.

description: BEST brunch.  BEST Eggs Benedict and great Bloody Mary.  I love the attention of detail in the dishes.
author: Eliette K.

description:
Great brunch spot in this unassuming part of the city.

Enjoyed a lovely brunch with the ladies yesterday. Everyone enjoyed their food - the menu is twist on simple, fresh breakfast staples. There were too many good things I wanted to try... but I ended up ordering the Fried Egg Sandwich. Loved the homemade buttermilk biscuits they used. Two of my friends had the Red Flannel Hash - which was unique and tasty served with roasted beets. My other friend had the Savory Bread Pudding which was also very good. Hands down, we all enjoyed the shoestring fries!

I'll definately come again to enjoy the grub and nice selection of unique cocktails.
author: Mai N.

description:
I've always loved slow club (though they need to.tighten up the service lately) and also love serpentine. 

Great drinks, food, and now a veggie burger. Yum. 

Good for Brunch, Lunch or Dinner. It's a small space so can get crowded.
author: Danielle L.

description: Wouldn't go out of my way to come back here,  but cool spot if you're in Dogpatch. Very cool space and decor. Kale salad was solid,  as was the crab penne and cheese. Get the whiskey smash as a drink.
author: Sandra S.

description: everything was tasty but sadly I made a bad choice. Salmon tasted great but portion was tiny. Word of warning, don't arrive here super hungry. Don't get me wrong, I'm all about quality over portion size but this was an appetizer sized meal. left hungry & disappointed.
author: Nick l.

description:
I discovered Serpentine about a month ago, and have eaten here three times since. I literally LOVE this place. It is a great date place, a great place to take your out of town guests, or really, any reason you can think of!

The brunch? awesome!  
The dinner? try the gnocci or the steak! (I have heard they have a great burger too) 
Their wine list is perfect and traversable, and they really do make the perfect rye manhattan. All three times we had better than acceptable customer service and left fat n happy!  I would advise making a reservation for brunch or dinner if you dont want to wait 30 minutes.
author: Didi R.

description: I love the industrial look of the place. The bartender is friendly, and the food is yummy. Great place to feel relaxed, and converse as opposed to many other places at the heart of the city.
author: Balajee V.

description: Yogurt chicken sandwich had yucky chicken parts, the elderflower champagne drink was warm and had way too much elderflower, service sucked and our table wasn't ready even though we had reservations. I would not recommend.
author: Eno N.

description:
I came here a few weeks ago to catch up with a friend and let me just say - I still think about that meal to this day.  I ordered what is likely the freshest gnocchi I've had so far.  Like my last dish here - it was simple, not too heavy on the ingredients, but it was pretty darn delectable.  

It was packed on a Saturday night at 8 and they had no tables available - so probably best to make reservations if you're a party of more than 2.  Luckily - the bar wasn't packed yet so we just ate there.
author: Jean A.

description: My favorite burger in the city along with great ribs in Indian spices (are they biryani spices?), and a yummy corn on the cob with lime and cocoa nibs. Desserts could use a little more flair.
author: Marina N.

description: Loved it! Cool spot & great food!
author: Ziva H.

description:
Best.Fries.Ever.

No, seriously perfect fries.  I chose Serpentine for a midweek lunch simply because it was convenient in terms of bus lines.  But it was oh so tasty.  

First off, I loved the space.  I expected this Dogpatch joint to be empty on a Wednesday at noon.  Not so.  Plenty of bustle.  I also loved the fact that three things jumped out at me on the menu.  I decided to go with the chick pea veggie burger -- any establishment that can master the veggie burger can probably master anything.  And this was quite the veggie burger.  My dining companion was not as enamored as I was -- she felt her dish was a bit salty.

But I would definitely go back.
author: Shilpa P.

description:
Holy snakes batman
Even though Indiana Jones doesn't like snakes he would like this place.

Industrial feel with lots of wood that warms even Trent Reznor's heart.  Very friendly staff that will help you slither you way to your seat and constrict your choices from the menu.

Baby Spinach & Apple Salad mizuna, frisee, goat cheese, balsamic vinaigrette was delicious.

Grilled Meyer Ranch Flat Iron Steak lime pickled swiss chard, roasted yukon gold potatoes, fried shallots, sauce bordelaise was cooked medium rare to perfection.

House Made Potato Gnocchi wild mushrooms, collard greens, grana padano, bread crumbs was OK.

Sweet potato fries, Mmmmm.

Lamb or was it goat cheek? Either way it was flavorful and tender without major gaminess flavor.

Marscapone cheese cake, a good pick to finish off the night.
author: Po L.

description:
Brunch is my favorite of all meals and I think I may have discovered my new favorite brunch entree - the red fennel hash at Serpentine (with braised Prather Ranch beef brisket - red beets - yellow potatoes - horseradish creme fraiche -poached eggs & grilled levain) is absolutely to die for. The brisket is perfectly seasoned and melt in your mouth goodness, the potatoes cooked to perfection and the grilled bread is a great way to soak up the poached eggy goodness.


 I was torn between the hash and the fried egg sandwich since it was served on a homemade biscuit - we solved that problem by ordering a side of biscuits. Jo loved her fried egg sandwich - I may have to try that next time if I can tear myself away from the hash.
