The only item that we had that I wouldn't recommend is the pancakes - serving size is gigantic but flavor wise they were a bit bland and on the dry side.


 Our meal ended on a comical notea pigeon walked in the open front door and was cruising around on foot for a minute before deciding to check out the view of Serpentine from a pipe located directly over our table. Once he started grooming himself right above us we decided to move to the bar to have dessert/coffee. The staff couldn't have been friendlier and comp'd us dessert and gave us a discount on our meal for the trouble. A very nice touch, the type of gesture that will keep me coming back to Serpentine. Well that and the fantastic brunch items.
author: tvham

description:
Pros: Friendly staff, great atmosphere, superb cocktails

Cons: Limited and uninspired menu, oily preparation of foods, bland appetizers
author: Jacob M.

description:
Went to Serpentine for the first time last weekend on a visit to San Francisco... liked dinner so much we went back for brunch on Sunday! Great lamb, incredible french fries... the calamari are so tender :o)
Brunch was very good, but we were disappointed with the 'fresh' orange juice.  It's not fresh (which to me means it has been squeezed right before serving).  It's bottled.  Not from concentrate, but definitely not freshly squeezed. Otherwise the eggs benedict rock, and the biscuits and gravy really good!
author: Shannon L.

description:
Need a great place to take your mom for brunch, or your friends with the small child, but don't want crappy eggs and bacon plates and a line out the door? Serpentine is a fantastic, chill, and delicious brunch and dinner option for people who want consistently delicious meals without the scene-y trappings that so many decent brunch or dinner options in SF seem to come with.

The service is always flawless, the presentation and ingredients are classy and fresh, and they switch up the menu just enough to always be a good place to revisit.
author: Jess F.

description:
Thank you Elli, Yes that's 2 LLs haha for a wonderful evening. Your service was greatly appreciated! Your suggestion for Chickpea Battered Calamari was very delicious! It went well with my dinner the Roasted Mary's Half Chicken with grilled king trumpet mushrooms, sauteed bacon roasted brussel sprouts (I had to ask the Chief how he had cooked these) with the chestnut spaetzle! For it being a very small but comfortable restaurant the grand ceiling made it much more bigger if not open.
Thank you Serpentine for the enjoyable pre-birthday weekend experience!
author: Marco R.

description: Living in Bayview/HP only give you so many options to eat out. Dogpatch is one neighborhood over, and that is where this amazing place is. My GF and I eat here all the time. They always remember us, and the food is always so bomb. The cocktails are the bee's knees, too. Fresh, local, yummy and straight delicious. Brunch is great, as well. Whatever you eat here, you will not be disappointed. DO IT!
author: F.f. Durst D.

description:
Came for lunch and dinner - and they were both GREAT! For lunch, the egg-based entree was tasty, and for dinner, the gnocchi was FANTASTIC. The food is imaginative and tasty, and the general attitude very nice. 

One downside is that the place is rather loud - concrete walls and wall. But, the quality of the food makes up for that.
author: MandS R.

description:
We had brunch there recently, and I have to say that this place is good.  I had the wild salmon eggs benedict, and it was very good.  The salmon flavor was very present without being overpowering in the way that salmon can be sometimes.  This place is a bit pricey, but you can argue that you get what you pay for.

I'd definitely go back to this place and maybe try it for dinner sometime.  However, for what is essentially comfort food, this place is not for anyone on a budget.  I'd give this place 3 stars for value, but the food is definitely a 4.
author: Dave N.

description:
DINNER REVIEW.

HBTLM! 

AMBIANCE: Dimly lit and super cozy feeling. I liked it. Despite the limited restaurant space, margins between tables were generous, and the high ceilings added to the feeling of spaciousness. I thought it was great for groups, as long as you make a reservation ahead of time.

SERVICE: Stellar. Tim was our server-- he was super nice, funny, and responded well to friendly banter. It seemed like he was a bit harried towards the end of our meal (more tables to take care of?) but he always had a smile on his face.

FOOD: Good.
- Serpentine meat platter ($12): Tasty duck liver mousse. I didn't get a chance to try the other assortment of meats, but judging from the speed at which everything disappeared, I'd say it was pretty good.
- Chickpea battered calamari ($8.50): Unique batter. Beans that came in the dish were a little underdone for my tastes.
- Housemade potato gnocchi ($17): Delightfully soft, fluffy, perfectly seared little pillows. Based on the uber savory aroma emanating from this dish, I thought it would be too cheesy/heavy... but I was wrong! It was delicious and actually pretty light for gnocchi. 
- Pan seared local opah ($24.50): The fish was perfectly cooked: nice and flaky, medium, with a great pan seared crust. Too bad the fish alone was fishy tasting :( But when paired with the divine sauce, all was forgiven. It wasn't my favorite dish, but very well executed (save the poor base ingredient). 
- Ice cream sandwich ($7.50): OMG. YUM. Soft, cakey pumpkin cookies paired with Bi-Rite vanilla ice cream, SALTED CARAMEL sauce and nutty brittle? nomnomnom. This disappeared the instant it was set down. So good in fact, that there were requests I replicate this dessert for our puma potluck. :]

OVERALL: Great neighborhood eatery. I'd come by more often if I lived in the area. Since I do not, I'll settle for visits every once in a while. Definitely planning to return for BRUNCH.
author: Susanna W.

description:
This is a solid place. The restaurant is in the Dogpatch area of the Potrero Hill neighborhood and resonates a warehouse, industrial feel that only San Francisco can make sexy and one-of-a-kind. 

It has tall ceilings, exposed brick and cement walls and your signature SF hipster waiter with goatee and artsy glasses. When you walk in, you can't help but feel cool for living in SF.

I admire their menu - its surprisingly unique with dishes such as the Red Flannel Hash (and no, I'm not bias because I always wanted to fall in love and marry a rugged lumberjack in - yes, RED FLANNEL),  which features ingredients such as beef brisket, roasted beets and creamy, yolky, poached eggs that spills over into a hash that is made up of crispy, golden-cubed potatoes.

I also had the country fried steak on biscuits (modern SF style, you can tell they made from scratch).

This breakfast though does leave you sleepy, yearning for a nap and heavy, but if you're in the mood, its worth it.

Also, brunch they are usually available and great for big parties. I RSVPd for 8 people and they accommodated us wonderfully on a Sat morning - which is near impossible in SF as we are a city of obsessed urban brunchers.
author: Tian L.

description:
Wow. Serpentine would be my go to place if friends were in town and wanted to go to a place in SF they could have imaginative delicious cocktails, food that was cooked well and service that was extremely friendly. 

Food that is a must: Chickpea batter calamari, Seafood of Chef Dupak's choice and the ice cream cookie sandwich (flavors differ nightly). Love this place.
author: Michael C.

description: Great spot for brunch. Cool, modern space and well-prepared food. Good and friendly staff, too! Highly recommended.
author: James B.

description:
Ok 5 star rating is just for the BURGER and FRIES!!! 

I love their burger.. delish, savory, oozing goodness from the cheese and the juices from the burger just glistening all over... .. and the bun is great, greased and I think buttered and toasted to perfection.. oOoo and the fries.. perfectly crispy.. good meal. That was satisfying..
author: Kristina L.

description:
Forgive me but I judge places based on their fries. Serpentine's were delish. Finished a side of them. They were from my friend's burger. I am sorry. Kinda.
The Bourbon Smash cocktail was great, and when my difficult friend (and I) inquired about the sweetness level, our attnentive waitress was informative and had our drinks prepared sans shugga (still very good, don't f*ck with my bourbon). 
I had the gnocchi with roasted cherry tomatoes, fava beans, and other beans. Great texture and the ingredients came together in harmony. Want to come back to try the other dishes.
author: Kelly N.

description:
This was my second visit. To my delight I really enjoyed my lunch. I had the most Delicious Nicoise salad ever complete with:blue lake & yellow wax beans - baby yukon potatoes - spinach -hard boiled egg - toy box tomatoes - nicoise olives - sherry vinaigrette - tuna confit aioli. The tuna portion was very fresh and generously proportioned. 
My BF ordered Pressed Cuban Sandwich zoe's ham - braised pork - Gruyere cheese - cornichon - chipotle aioli - whole grain mustard - toasted torpedo roll - fries. the sandwich was A-mazing. 
This place was great, the service was good, and the food delivered.
author: Michele K.

description:
I've been there twice for brunch now, and both times I've ordered the same thing because they have the best breakfast sandwich I've ever had... and I've had a lot of breakfast sandwiches. 

The first time I went there, it was with 5 others and we didn't have reservations. It was busy and we were told the wait was about an hour. We happily sat at the bar, drank mimosas, and ended up waiting only about 45 minutes. Our server was fast and the food came faster. Everyone was satisfied and at the end of the meal, when the check was split, the brunch was only about $20/person- pretty cheap for such excellent food and drinks.

The second time I went there, it was Saturday afternoon and we got a table for two and ordered right away. Our attractive and attentive server brought out our fried egg sandwiches with sausage 10 minutes after we ordered and refilled my delicious iced tea (which is served with a bottle of sugar water! genius!) at the end of the meal. We were in and out in 40 minutes, which was ideal because we would've been late for our appointments otherwise.

Quick Tip: Go there if you're looking for an unbelievably tasty breakfast sandwich on a Saturday afternoon. Order it with the sausage! They close at 2:30pm so get there by 1:30.
author: Jan W.

description:
My friends and I visit this hidden little gem in the Dogpatch District quite frequently. This is the joint we go to to remedy our hunger pains. 

The food is excellent, the service is great, and the prices are reasonable. I've eaten here for brunch and dinner and man, you cannot go wrong. 

Best part of all, Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous Ice Cream Shop is right across the street! HOLY HELL! Whaddya know?! It's the best ice cream shop in San Francisco!!! How convenient!!! Do I hear date night at the Dogpatch District?
author: Mary Anne R.

description:
Service was great! Food was great!
I liked that it was elusive on the outside and the ambiance is perfect! 
Good place to bring a date and have a nice conversation.
author: Joan Z.

description:
4.5 Stars!

Walked in on Monday around 7:30PM without a reservation and was able to snag a bar table for 3 with minimal wait time of 5 minutes.  Waitress recommended a great beer to start and we ordered some apps:  pan-seared petaluma chicken livers and white corn soup.  both were delicious.  fun & raunchy conversation ensued.  *high five*  

next came the entrees:  prather ranch hamburger, roasted mary's chicken, and grilled california sea bass.  can't say much about the chicken or the sea bass as I only had a nibble of each dish, but i've gotta say that this was probably one of THE BEST HAMBURGERS i have ever had.  cooked to medium-rare perfection, this thing was so juicy and well seasoned that I couldn't put it down.  so simple, yet so delicious.

price was a bit on the higher side for entrees, but i would definitely go back over and over again for the burger.
author: Susan L.

description:
Good foods, nice place for friends and family. 
We reserved a table for Sat brunch, but no line outside the door when we got there. We  ordered a country fried steak and red flannel hash. The beef brisket in red flannel hash is tender even I who usually have hard time to chew down red meat can enjoy the meals. The fried steak with mushroom sauce totally earns a point from my hobby and daughter.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I've been here a couple of times for dinner and it is one of my favorite places.  It's got an industrial decor, which isn't appropriate for every meal but is good for when you want that vibe.  The food is very good and I haven't even tried the famed burger yet.  There's also a fairly extensive drink menu.  I have always found the service to be attentive and friendly.  And parking is a breeze.

On the downside, it's a small space and the tables are pretty close together, so it's noisy and hard to have a private conversation.  (In fact, on my last visit, someone sitting next to us interrupted, saying, "I couldn't help but overhear you say....")   The first time I went, it was also a bit warm inside, but I didn't notice that the last time.
author: Neill T.

description: This place really is A-OK. Nothing super interesting, wine pairing okay but not fantastic. My money would have probably been better spent at Tartine or St. Vincent.
author: X O.

description:
In my (seemingly never-ending) search for the best burger in SF, I may have found a viable entry in Serpentine's Prather Ranch Hamburger... MAN THAT THING WAS AWESOME!  The meat was perfectly cooked (medium rare) and something about the consistency of the burger was unusually good: soft and very fresh-tasting.  To really top it off, the picked onions were a great touch and the house-made skinny fries were excellent.

The other entrees, Osso Bucco and Gnocci were also excellent, each with their own unique flair, but it was really the burger that did it for me.

We also had a constant string of appetizers: Olives, Lupini Beans, Grilled Calcot Onions, Serpentine Meat Board , Little Gems Lettuce Salad, Shaved Asparagus Salad, and Chickpea Battered Calamari... ALL OF WHICH were AWESOME.  The standout appetizer was most definitely the MEAT BOARD though... their pate is especially memorable and unlike other pates I've tasted.

Overall the taste was very consistently homey and savory and fire-driven, but definitely with unique touches that push Serpentine beyond the garden-variety trendy SF restaurant category.  Chef Deepak Kaul (an amazingly friendly and cool guy) has a great thing going here and I really hope he and his crew can keep doing their thang!
author: Peter L.

description: Went for brunch with some friends,  I have but one word and that is "YUMMY":)..... Great location easy street parking, friendly staff must luv hipster tho this place is crawling with beautifull hipsters.  Cant wait for my next visit!
author: Jj M.

description:
Came here to celebrate a friend's bday. We started with cocktails in the bar area, then moved to a dining table. Originally we had reservations for 6, but the party grew to 9. The host, bar and wait staff were helpful, and accommodated us by changing tables. They knew we were celebrating a special occasion, stress-free, and made us feel at home. Very cool bunch:) 

For some reason, when I see uncommon menu ingredients, I'm curious to try them. This restaurant is definitely good for sharing plates, esp. btwn two people. Everything we ate was memorable and delicious. Will definitely be back again. Plus there is ample parking, even on a Giants game night. 

Shaved Asparagus Salad - arugula - fennel - easter egg radish - spring onion - ricotta salata - sorrel - hazelnuts - green peppercorn vinaigrette $ 9.50 

Pan Seared Sonoma Duck Livers - fenugreek spice - thai chili - hearts of palm & potato salad $8.00 

Braised Berkshire Pork Belly - lovage puree - rhubarb - candied young ginger - pork jus $10.50 

Serpentine Meat Board - coppa - chicken liver mousse - country pork pate - duck prosciutto - lonza - pickled green beans - apricot mostarda - grilled levain toasts $12.00
author: HY L.

description:
Serpentine for lunch.  In kinda the outer mission.  Kinda industrially designed.  You know, high ceilings, exposed brick, concrete floor.  

But good food at a good price.  And that's what counts.  For example, a salad of nectarine, arugula, hazelnuts, baby spinach and just a bit of bacon was great. Not overdressed.  Just perfect.

The Serpentine hamburger was a bit dry.  It came medium, as ordered and that may have been a mistake.  They use good beef, without too much fat.  Better to have gotten it medium rare.  The fries that came with the burger were wonderful.

Great place for a quick lunch.
author: David D.

description:
Solid 4 stars, 4.5 even. I just reserve the last half for "Slow Club", the other restaurant of the same owner. The food here is amazing and the prices are very reasonable for the quality you get. That's similar to Slow Club. What are the differences, then?

- Slow Club is slightly more "fashionable"
- Serpentine is more "intimate" (come with a date).
- At Slow Club you can see the chef cooking (great!)
- At Serpentine the industrial atmosphere is very nice.
- Slow Club has some more variety in the wines.
- Serpentine has slightly better service because they are less busy.
author: Javi V.

description:
great place!

last night, three of us essentially shared a bunch of appetizers.  everything was very good.

cocktails - i had a gin, elderflower liqueur and kumquat cocktail which was expensive but delightful.  they took a very long time to arrive which was kind of miss.

fried brussel sprouts - these were pretty tasty.  i kind of wish they were a little crispier on the outside.

sunchokes - they were in sage brown butter sauce.  very nice and sweet.  great texture

calamari - awesome!  it had a chickpea crust and was mixed with some veggies.  fresh tasting and not fishy.  well cooked -- no rubberiness.

nettle and sorrel soup - this was nice.  had never eaten sorrel before, so i didnt know what to expect.  tasted very green, i guess.  was good with the creme fraiche mixed into the soup thoroughly.

duck sausage - fabulous.  the white beans and that sauce were to die for.  it was a mustardy, lemony type of brothy, sauce that i couldnt seem to get enough of.  good for sopping up with sourdough.

gnocchi - homemade gnocchi was perfect.  cooked with several types of mushrooms and nettle i think.  really tasty.

this place had a nice vibe.  i would come back for sure.  curious what their brunches are like now.  i would also like to order an entree next time.  the flat iron steak and chicken sounded good.
author: Christian C.

description: the hamburger with fries was the entree of choice for our group of 5 dinner and it looked darn good. i opted for a healthier item and ordered the halibut which didn't disappoint. overall great food! and who doesn't like a place that offers bi-rite creamery ice cream for dessert!
author: Helen Y.

description: Just had our brunch here. We loved the food, grapefruit juice and fresh coffee. The bread pudding and red flannel hash was delicious, never had anything like that before. The fried potatoes was worth getting on the side. Fast service but wasn't rushed. Even on a busy Sunday morning we were able to have a relaxed Sunday brunch here.
author: V. And C. C.

description: We had our post-Valentine's Day dinner here and were thoroughly impressed with the food. Flavors were bold throughout and favorites included the chickpea battered calamari and the spicy osso bucco with piri piri. The spice was actually just right for me, not too overpowering but yet still present to make it different. We totally underestimated the portion sizes though (ordering three appetizers and two entrees) and left without trying any desserts... next time perhaps!
author: Andrey C.

description:
this place has a cool vibe.  people keep on talking about the brunch here, but i haven't tried that yet.  dinner here was really good though....we started off with the cheese platter (2 cheeses)....buttery, creamy goodness....and the cheese was good too.  that was a totally lame joke...like there's a component missing from it.  help?  anyway, that was good....it came with some marcona almonds and this rhubard compote that i would have gladly spread over ANYTHING.  i only spread it on the crostini here though, as that seemed like the most appropriate thing to do.  some dribbled down my chin as i was trying to take the first bite.  i'm smooth....really, really smooth.

we had this really great salad with, like, lettuce and stuff.  just kidding, it had some endives, blood orange, pistachios, and this goat cheese.  so freaking good.

i had the lamb tenderloin and belly.  i got the lamb medium, which was perfect for me (they normally cook it medium-rare)....so ridiculously good.  was served over a bed of veggies, including asparagus.  i totally forgot there was asparagus on the dish until i peed.

french fries.....mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.  that means i liked it.

the service was really nice and cool.....even when they tried to delicately tell us that there was some people waiting for that table.  we were there way too long (i had a lot of good stories to tell, whaddya want???), and they were very gracious and apologetic about asking us to move it to the bar, which we were happy to do....
author: Miss P.

description: decent place but honestly was a bit disappointed.  The menu looked great but the execution was a bit .. meh.  For a brunch place, the servings were a bit stingy (in particular the chicken fried steak which had the smallest chicken fried steak I've ever seen)  The bread pudding was just ok.  The coffee on the other hand was nice and strong.. just like i like it.
author: Susan L.

description:
I went here for dinner last night. The service was incredible, the food was delightful, and it was busy!
 Despite the busy Thursday night my party of 3 got seated right away by a friendly server. The waitress was very helpful when ordering our drinks (I got the lemon drop) and brought them soon after we ordered. We ordered the Chick Pea encrusted Calamari as a starter, it was very different and good. Our main dishes came out in a timely manor, and I got the hanger steak. It was cooked perfectly MR and the whole plate was nice looking. Our waters and drinks were always full. The hostess and another server also attended to us clearing plates and offering dessert. We had the carmel pot de cream, oh so good! They brought us the check and we had a wonderful night. 

Our waitress was so nice and checked with us after every corse to make sure everything was okay, without being in our hair. Thank you for making my late work night a little more fun and enjoyable. :)
author: Alisha W.

description:
As other Yelpers have mentioned, you definitely get that warehouse feeling once you are inside Serpentine. Although the gray, concrete walls inside the restaurant give it a cold feeling, the high ceilings, natural lighting, and modern menu makes you forget that you are in the Dogpatch District.

I went here for lunch with a group of co-workers, one who has been here before and loves their signature savory bread pudding. I didn't think I could have handled a rich dish for lunch, and then try to go back to work and be productive. So I opted for the smoked chicken sandwich with a side salad. 

I knew the sandwich came with a mushroom gravy, but I didn't think it was going to be the main flavor of the dish. I barely tasted the smoked flavor of the chicken, and the cheddar cheese might as well not have been there. Although it wasn't what I expected, I still enjoyed the dish. A few of my coworkers went with my second choice, the Croque Monsieur, and it was exactly what they expected - ham and swiss cheese with a bechamel (a white sauce) and dijon mustard on a toasted buttery bread. Darn it! I knew I should have went with that one.

It was a good lunch, and the service was quick and friendly. It seems like brunch may be a better option, so I'll come back for that.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
Serpentine's got all the potential for a five-star experience: A unique, creative menu... friendly, good-looking staff... tasty and interesting cocktails... and a hip, contemporary warehouse-style restaurant with a cozy locals-only vibe tucked away in the Dogpatch district. Really, the aesthetics and menu design are spot-on. Yet, all I can recall about the evening is: TOO SALTY!

Too salty as in way way way too too salty. I was left with cotton mouth and sodium bloat and had to recline on the couch and chug water for a couple hours to recover. Attractive, I know.

Delish: Savory Bread Pudding, Fried Oysters, Arugula Salad, Dessert, Lattes
Skip: Swordfish, Scallops

I love Slow Club and I want to love Serpentine, so I will definitely give it another shot. And I don't mean for this to be a slam on the place, I... liked it just fine. But as the old adage goes, "There is no greater sin than over-salting."
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Forget about everything else on their brunch menu - just try their breakfast bread pudding!!!! 
It's soft, fluffy, with bits of salty ham, cheese, corn and squash. My husband's been begging me to try to recreate it at home - since I generally dabble in everything bread pudding.

Their Kentucky buck cocktail is also pretty up there. A bit of strawberry, mixed with mint and lime. Mmmm.....

Wouldn't recommend the beef hash. The meat comes in big hard chunks. Not a fan of overdone meat.

Love their decor too. Very industrial. 
One star short of 5 for overdone meat, and for having only 1 sweet brunch option on their menu. Come early or get a reservation cause the restaurant is not too big.
author: P S.

description:
What a gem. A humble little exterior leads one into a small, yet light and airy interior filled with the familiar sounds of a busy dining room; intimately compatible with the unassuming, yet elegantly modern decor. The menu is small, but not limited by any means. I was lucky enough to enjoy my first meal here during one of their lively Saturday brunches, and the service was spot on.
 I am daydreaming about the baked eggs as I write this; a perfectly portioned little concoction of slightly al dente vegetables snuggled under 2 perfectly cooked eggs and crowned with a green garlic salsa that refused to be squandered, despite becoming uncomfortably full. 
The Prather Ranch hamburger my boyfriend had is known as one of the best in the city, and there are no arguments coming from this patron. Serpentine can consider itself on the list of reasons I need to live in San Francisco; truly a remarkable little spot.
author: Chel C.
Kimberly Q.

description:
Started with a fabulous drink from their drink menu.  Like a lemon drop.
Had the blue cheese bacon salad which wasn't quite as flavorful as one would expect. Had the chicken liver ad a main dish. Good but not phenomenal. Everyone in my party enjoyed their meal. Waiter was super friendly and attentive and answered well my numerous indecisive questions.
author: E C.

description: The food is fantastic. Try the burger. The wait staff are sexy and look great in the light that pours in through the windows at sunset. Jesse Allan's drinks are as amazing as his chest hair and smile.
author: Jeremiah L.

description: I have gone here quite a few times, although admittedly none of them were for dinner. Having said that, everything I have ever ordered, drinks or food, has been FANTASTIC. Don't miss the burger, and they have great bloodies/brunch.
author: Kaitlyn L.

description: I enjoyed the food greatly at Serpentine. The check was stamped on back "Slow Club" so I think it may be the same owner as that other good restaurant.  Both restaurants share some of the same characteristics. Food is quite good and well prepared. Both have a more industrial decor, with hard surfaces, so that both are also quite noisy when crowded. Service was somewhat better at Serpentine, but not without a few hitches (We were served another table's food. We said we were sharing and they did nothing to aid in that process and I had to ask for a serving fork/spoon to help split the dishes - my new pet peeve!)  Drink menu is interesting. Did not try dessert at Serpentine but the dishes we had were excellent. Hip spot, but noisy for talking.
author: Jake J.

description: This is our neighborhood go to restaurant. It is CONSISTENTLY good and the cocktails are amazing.
author: Palmer T.

description: Went for brunch and it was great. Had the hash with the brisket. Don't remember the exact name. THe meat was tender and not dry at all and the flavors worked well together. Would go back to try other menu items.
author: Mz S.

description:
We went for brunch and were very underwhelmed. 

Service was slow and evasive. We had to ask three times before being allowed to order. 

Food emerged from the kitchen haphazardly, one dish at a time, not all together as you'd expect. 

Crispy fried potatoes were almost perfect, highly salted, but not to excess, perfectly crisp on the outside and creamy inside. It was all downhill from there. 

The potatoes arrived a good 10 minutes before anything else, so they at least served as an appetizer while we were waiting for our main courses. But they had been ordered as a side dish for me. 

Second to arrive was my dining partner's Oyster Benedict. The oysters were almost inedibly old and stinky. I suggested that they be sent back, but she just pushed them listlessly around on her plate. 

More than 5 minutes later, my Nicoise salad finally was delivered. 

It looked as if someone had dumped a bunch of random items on a plate and sent it out without looking at it. Some of the sliced eggs were broken into bits and strewn across one side of the dish, The tuna was oddly served seared-side down, and was somewhat dried out from having sat around for a long time. And the boiled new potatoes were undercooked and inedible. 

When it was time for an iced tea refil, the waiter again developed a hearing disability and ran by repeatedly before grudgingly agreeing. He took my glass away and kept it for another 10 minutes before bringing it back with more tea in it. 

High prices, lousy service, and a kitchen which clearly does not care: this is truly a dining experience to be missed.
author: Jacob L.

description:
I ended up at Serpentine because the wait at 'Just For You' across the street was ridiculous. I never would have known it was there if a friend hadn't pointed it out. Its the sister restaurant of Slow Club in Potrero Hill, with a similar style and menu, slow food of course. The staff at Serpentine is more laid back, bordering on dippy, but the service is quite good.

The space Serpentine occupies is a classic San Francisco post-modern industrial brick affair with obligatory exposed pipes and white washed walls. We had plenty of time to take it all in as the wait without a reservation probably would have seen us seated and served back at 'Just For You', but hey, that's life.

With a round of musical plates I got to try the Brisket Hash and the Country Fried Steak. Neither really blew me away, although the poached eggs that came with the hash were pristine. The County Fried Steak seemed a little tough and the batter basically fell off at the approach of a utensil. The Hash was better, but very non-traditional with the addition of some sweet golden beets. The brisket was a little dry having been refried with the hash. The coffee was excellent.


I'd go back with a reservation. I think I am less picky when I'm not grumpy.
author: Zac H.

description:
I shall return...MOST definitely! 

I met a good friend for brunch at Serpentine. I'm so glad I did! It's in a particular part of San Francisco that has yet to be pummelled by all the hipster folks. The Dogpatch definitely gets love by folks who don't mind venturing to that part of town and it is getting some love, for sure with a place like Serpentine and Hard Knox across the road. 

In any case, I should tell you about what I had, really. I devoured the Savory Bread Pudding with ham, Swiss, rosemary, and a bed of fresh greens with piping hot earl grey...YUM...heaven! I'm accustomed to having sweet bread puddings so I had to give the savory a try and glad I did. The menu is not overwhelming but it's not skimpy either. The fare will definitely have you filled up and please don't forget a piping hot cup of tea or coffee with your meal. 

The ambiance is great because although a very open space with extremely high ceiling and a somewhat industrial feel with red brick walls and hard edges, the food is total comfort! The tattoo laden staff is friendly, sweet and easy on the eyes! So, your experience should definitely be a good one. 

Again, I shall return for dinner because it's just one of those places that will become a Dorothy S. favorite, no doubt!
author: Dorothy S.

description:
Great Food
I had the asparagus salad for lunch.  There weren't any vegetarian sandwich options so I had to stick to a salad.  It was very tasty and filling.  Flavors of the almonds, manchego and arugula go perfect together.

Great Service
The host gave us a free cookie!  It was a giant cookie equivalent to about 3 regular size cookies.  I loved it.  The edge was crispy and the center chewy.  It was the best cookie I've had in a long time and they are made fresh there every day.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I came here for brunch a few months back and was definitely underwhelmed. It's a bummer too because I don't often get over to the Dogpatch/Portrero Hill area and I wasted a rare visit on a blah restaurant.

The decor attempts to be edgy and minimal and instead comes off as cold and boring, especially for brunch. The menu wasn't all that exciting and whatever I ended up getting was totally average, especially for the price.
author: Lindsey S.

description: This place seems to get tons of reviews for brunch, but we had a really good dinner here.  All I remember standing out were the gnocchi and pickled vegetables, but that probably had something to do with the outstanding cocktails.  Very hip waitress completely sans attitude which was nice.  three couples rolling in from the marina, two pregnant chics in tow probably would make for some easy snobbery, but she was super nice and helpful.
author: Michael N.

description:
Came here on one of my many brunch excursions (I think I have a problem...I'm a brunch-whore).  Another great spot with actually very good food, when you chose right.  Can I just say one thing:  San Francisco restaurants have no clue how to cook southern food (and dont even say...go to Brendas...boring).  Country Fried Steak has no place to be served in this health- conscious city.  DO NOT attempt country gravy unless it is made properly...with pure sausage fat, cream, and flour.  Gross sounding, I know, but oh so good when its real.  

Anyway, good thing it was my boyfriend who ordered the CFS and not me (I gave up on that a few years ago after trying to get a taste of my southern upbringing in SF, but failing miserably).  I had the crab benedict, which was excellent!  It was served on a delicious biscuit-type bread which I will admit was South-worthy.  Great coffee too with ok prices and very good service.

All-in-all, I wasnt amazed by the experience but Ill go back again some time.
author: Mike H.

description: Ive eaten here twice in the past 9 months both brunch and dinner.nice good food, fun modern atmosphere, good crowd... Well prepaired grilled and stewed meats... For brunch.. Highly recommend the hash... Its deeeelicious.book on opentable!.
author: Ali A.

description: More pseudo-hipness with a trendy menu that doesn't measure up to the prices. Had the 'hash" today at lunch. Chewy chunks of fatty beef with red beets and horseradish creme fraiche and salad greens and potatoes. Hmmm. Last time I checked "hash" was not a salad with a bunch of chunks of food in it. What about: a hash that melded the flavors together with the creme fraiche on top instead of all gooey and gross on the bottom? With the salad on the side?
author: Marilyn P.

description:
Came here with a friend of mine on a Tuesday night after my friend recommended this place. We were greeted immediately by our hostess and had our choice of seating since it was relatively empty on a Tuesday night. My friend ordered the burger and I ordered the gnocchi with braised ox tail.

My friend's burger came with fries that I managed to pick off since he was on a low carb diet and it was really good, probably some of the best fries I've had. The gnocchi I had was very rich; the ox tail (it doesn't have bone for those who are wondering) was very tender. My friend also ordered some wine that our waiter suggested and he liked it, unfortunately, I don't drink so I can speak from personal experience. Lastly, our hostess and waiter was very friendly.

Overall, I found my experience here very enjoyable and could definitely see myself coming back. In terms of my rating, I tend not to give out a 5 star rating unless there was something that made it so that I couldn't wait to come back which this place did not do but is not any fault of theirs.
author: Richard C.

description:
Delicious, super fresh food, ample wine by the glass selection & a great cocktail list.

Recently moved into the area and discovered this gem. Their brunch menu is my favorite and is definitely popular among the locals. Advice; Get there early or make a reservation cause it gets packed. Try theLocal Dungeness Crab Benedict it's to die!!!
author: Gia L.

description:
A group of six came here on a Friday night and got a great table in a secluded part of the restaurant in an alcove.  Nice because it wasn't noisy.  We had a terrific server.  We ordered many dishes and tried not to duplicate.  We had roasted green chilies,  the daily cheese, the chickpea battered calamari, the Gravenstein apple salad.   The chilies were adored by all but not to my personal taste (just too plain and chili-ish).  The calamari were wonderful.  The daily cheese was  blue....I heard no complaints but did not try it.

Then we ordered the seared cod, the duck leg, the gnocchi, and the flat iron steak.  I actually ordered the gnocchi and received the cod by mistake; then the server insisted on buying us the gnocchi as well to share.  I am so glad I got the fish because this was one of the best fish dishes I have ever had.  It was so delicate and served with a crunchy slightly Asian-flavored (to me) vegetable accompaniment.  It was heavenly.  The gnocchi were perfect...not greasy at all...light, and with the peas, tomatoes, cheese...the best.  I tasted the duck and it was excellent...tender and flavorful.  My husband pronounced the steak a 91/2 out of 10.  Amazing.  

Dessert included two flavors of bi-rite ice cream (mint and banana) and the wonderful corn meal based upside down cake.  There was something else equally delicious but I forgot it in my blissful state.

The only criticism is that some of the apples in the apple salad were mushy.  This seemed to be a strange occurrence in such a great place so maybe it was on purpose.  But definitely not to my taste.  So, gee 4 3/4 stars.... ROUNDING UP!  You betcha!

We are coming back here as quickly as we can.
author: Thelma Lee G.

description:
Client, MUA, stylist, model, etc.. 11 females and one me. And I survived it all today. Well I actually liked it. Just as much as the food we ordered to go after the fun photo shoot.

I got the turkey, cranberry sandwich and it came with a perfectly light and season dressing on the marvelous salad.

I certainly would come back here for dinner.
author: Brandon M.

description:
Short Ribs = supple and flavorful, but the chipolte brq sauce was UNremarkable. 

Pumpkin Salad = delightful, unique and something to order again

Halibut= overrated and over recommended

Squash Soup= super boring. Too much olive oil maybe??? Something just didn't match here.

Would go again and order based on my own tastes rather than the tables.
author: SF U.

description: Oh man.  Three words.  Savory.  Bread.  Pudding.  Sounds strange but is oh so delicious.  Honestly when it came out...I caught myself thinking "I hope this is enough food for me."  But the dish was rich and very filling.  This was nicely balanced by a side salad that comes along with the bread pudding, which cut through the richness very well.  My wife had the fried egg sandwich with potatoes and sausage - I took a bite and that was really good too.  There were a few other things on the menu that looked good - now I'll have to see if I can tear myself away from the bread pudding the next time I'm here!  It's that good.  Hm gotta figure out when we can get back here!
author: Francis S.

description: Been here a few times now for dinner and it never disappoints!  Friendly staff, quick service and delicious food.  Could do with a few more vegetarian options, but they were happy to adjust the delicious pasta to make it veg, so can't complain. 5 stars!
author: Megan G.

description: The service and food were quite good.  I had the gnocchi but the menu changes daily.  Brussel sprouts are in season - delicious and definitely recommend.  parking in the area does seem a tad sketchy but the food is worth it.   took off a star because we had to wait 15min after our reservation time to be seated because the previous table wasn't done.  from looking at their reservation system (because we were waiting there for so long!), it doesn't look like there is enough time between seatings.
author: Win L.

description:
I love Serpentine. It's just around the corner from me and I've eaten there twice and have loved it both times. I'm also a fan of the Slow Club (same owners) and love the new twists on the classics. Last night I had gnocchie and mushrooms in a Sage sauce. My friend had the sole which wasn't quite as good, but still very tasty.

I love that the place is bright and airy - it's great for a drink at the bar or a full meal. The meals are a little on the small side, which just means there's room for dessert!
author: Kathleen P.

description:
I had friends coming into town and wanted to find something walking distance since we had too many people for a cab. After searching, I really didn't see anything that looked good, so extended and decided to give Serpentine a try. 

First of all, I had to change the numbers several times, and they were so nice every time. In fact, when one couple backed out several hours before and I called to let them know, they were so excited that I had called and said they could give me a better table. We had a great set up that sat 7, with 3 on the booth type bench, 2 on the ends (also in the booth area) and then 2 in chairs on the other side. It was perfect.

The table wasn't ready right at our reservation time, but we were a little late so it ended up being perfect. The tables are dimly lit, sort of hard to read the menu, but the space is great.

We ordered the meat and cheese plate, plus the lamb belly (delish) and someone got a salad which was huge and also good. Most got the pork chop, which they raved about, I had the salmon (tempted by the curry broth) and it was very good, but I wouldn't necessarily go back and get it. Someone else had the chicken, which was huge but also looked awesome.

They have fun drinks and good wine. I would definitely come back to this place and highly recommend it for the good service. I also now want to try their other restaurant, Slow Club.

The big downside to this place is that it's inconvenient to get to. Public transport takes forever to get there (even though it's just off the stop) and comes very infrequently late at night. there are no cabs.
author: Lauren M.

description:
I came here for my company holiday dinner not too long ago. The space is very similar to their sister restaurant, Slow Club. It's very industrial, but it had a cozy feel to it since it's on the smaller side. The place was pretty empty at 630p, but it was filled up by 8p. The service was a little slow for our drinks, but the appetizers were timely. Our waitress was very friendly and attentive to our needs. 

I really liked their pork ribs and duck appetizer. The pork was really tender and came with a very yummy sauce. It wasn't your typical BBQ sauce. The duck was also paired nicely with a creamy polenta. The garlic bread was so-so and the calamari was decent. The appetizers portions are pretty small if  you have a large party. It probably serves 4 and we had a table of 10. The waitress should've told us that 1 order wouldn't be enough, but we figured it out when the plates came.  

I ordered the flat iron steak for my entree and the meat was chewy! The flavoring wasn't spectacular either, but the texture was what bugged me the most. My colleague next to me didn't finish his flat iron steak either. No surprise there. Very disappointing. My other colleague loved her gnochhi, which I was just about to get. I figured it was a free dinner so I should really do it up. Dammit, backfired.

Good place for appetizers and martinis (they were yum!).
author: Freckles H.

description: Place is small so the tables are really close together. There is more outdoor seating than indoor seating do its great on a nice day.
author: Dee G.

description: This has quickly become one of my favorite places to get brunch in the city.  The food is great, there's always something interesting on the menu I want to try, parking is plentiful and the wait is usually not bad compared to a lot of other brunch places.
author: Alex H.

description: I love this place. The only reason for the 4 instead of 5 stars is.... I brought a group of friends there for dinner tonight. Three of us ordered the burger which is always delicious!!! The other two ordered the gnocchi and salmon, both said were just eh and they wish they had ordered a burger. Everything else was fabulous! The cocktails and spirits selection is great, the olives and grilled Brussels sprouts were incredibly tasty, and all the deserts were yummy. The atmosphere is great and the staff was friendly.
author: Jodi N.

description:
Had dinner here last night with girlfriends and I really enjoyed it. Industrial, clean look to the place but the people are warm & extremely friendly. Wine selection & service was good. 

For starters, we ordered the fries & an order of calamari. There is definitely better calamari in the city, but the fries were delicious & came with both ketchup & mayo! :) For dinner, we had the gnocchi & chicken. Both of my friends raved about the chicken & I will definitely be back for the gnocchi of the best I've tasted in the city. For dessert we had the ice cream sandwich, which was two chocolate cookies with mint chip ice cream from Swenson's...can you say heaven?
author: Kim D.

description:
A rare five stars. Reservations required.

My wife and I have been to Serpentine several times for brunch or dinner, and on occasion taken my boss, co-workers and friends there too.

They have a small, focused, fresh, French-inspired menu that changes reasonably frequently. They make great cocktails too.

I have never had a bad experience, drink or meal and people I've brought there have always said it was a good choice. That is a rare find in any city.

I disagree with some reviewers that it's too expensive - for SF their prices are pretty reasonable.

Regular items on the menu include the meat board (fine selection of charcuterie), a great burger, pan-fried homemade gnocchi (excellent), tuna with soba noodles (slight spicy kick which is awesome). The cheese plate usually has good cheeses but my only complaint is that it's too small.

Try it for yourself - it's even better than their Mission restaurant, Slow Club!
author: Pete F.

description:
Despite yesterdays sunny warmth, last night was bloody cold! 

With that said, I met a friend for dinner at Piccino... darling place, nice wine selection, yummy-looking flat bread pizza things, but freezing! And loud. Since all the warm tables near the oven were taken, we decided to walk over to Serpentine. (sorry, Piccino!! next time, I swear!!)

Once inside Serpentine, we were hit by loud layers of conversation. Quiet it wasn't. But it was warm and cozy, and there were 2 seats at the bar inviting us in for dinner. So we stayed.

So many things tempted me on their menu. There was roasted buffalo bone marrow, duck rillettes and savory bread pudding for starters, and stuffed quail, beef cheeks, and a burger for main courses.

Since I'd cooked quail the night before, am laying off beef for a few days, and felt like comforty food, I decided on the roasted chicken. My friend got the quail. For starters, we opted for the arugula salad with avocado, bacon, frommage blanc & a red wine vinaigrette. 

The salad was perfect. Light & peppery greens mixed with creamy cheese and avocado, tossed with salty, smoky bacon!

The chicken was lovely. A 1/2 chicken perfectly roasted and served on a bed of sauteed crispy french fingerling potatoes, spinach, frisee, fennel, and castroville artichokes, finished with a roasted shallot vinaigrette. I must admit, though, that the potatoes, while tasty, were not crispy. But I cleaned my plate.

The star of the meal was the quail. Cornbread Stuffed Wolfe Ranch quail on a creamy puree of butternut squash, grilled broccoli di cicco, and black trumpet mushrooms. It was the perfect combination of flavors and textures, and while I really enjoyed my dish, I admit I had a touch of food envy.

We opted to finish the meal with the apple thingy that was topped with airy lightly sweetened whipped cream.

In addition to the fine meal, I'll add that the service was great. The bartender described menu items in a lively and informed fashion. Courses were not rushed and our water glasses were never empty.

Another point is the wine list. Lots of old and new world varietals represented... I had the Rhone they offered by the glass, and it was perfect with my meal. (my friend had a 1/2 a glass with her entree... nice that they let her)

I will deduct a star for the noise levels... not really their fault, just from where we were sitting, sort of obtrusive and hard to talk over.

From this one visit I'll agree with Serpentine's tag line: Honest Food, Classic Cocktails. At least the food part. I'll have to go back and test out their side car. (and that quail!!)
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
Very good, but not blown away.

Unfortunately for SF restaurants, they have the Universal Cafe bar to meet for brunch. Nowhere has come near as of yet.

Serpentine suffers a bit of the same characteristic as Pomelo; every brunch item on the menu has about 3 ingredients too many.  Service was good, it is actually a good place if you don't want to get rushed out of brunch, they are attentive but not speedy.

I'll be back, but not rushing.
author: laura g.

description:
GREAT!!! That's all I need is another friggin' thing to keep me up at night. I was hoping after dining here I could figure out why it's called Seprentine. There wasn't a snake picture on the wall. No snakes served in the menu. Not even eggs cooked in snake oil! The spot doesn't haven't a snaking layout... nothing! Could it be a shedding of the old skin and like a phoenix reborn from the ashes a new restaurant is born in the Dogpatch?? I DON"T KNOW!!! What I do know is that this block is blowin' up! Within feet of each other you have Yield Wine Bar, Hard Knox Cafe, Just For You, & Serpentine (and hopefully my future film school)!!

I would love to tell you to hit up Yield before dinner for a drink but Serpentine may just make my current favorite cocktail in the city. The Whiskey Smash. And it is made with Pappy Van Winkles whiskey which is my Death Row whiskey. I would stop in and probably will just to sit at the bar and knock of few these badboys back.  

We had called on a Saturday to make some last minute reservations and the only opening was 9:15. We take the slot and head over an hour early knowing that they keep the occasional table open for walk-ins and worse comes to worse we drink at Yield. After being lulled into to bliss by the Whiskey Smash we are chatting with the awesome bartenders and someone taps me on the shoulder. The hostess had a table for us! I was actually a little disappointed with the expediency. I wanted a good reason to keep drinking and it had just been taken away from me!!!

My unhappiness disappeared quickly when our food arrived. First up, crispy fried oysters and hush puppies served with a dipping sauce. Spiced perfectly, the oysters were phenomenal and I'm not a big fan raw or otherwise. My main was hand cut egg noodles served with crispy pork belly. Clean, simple, and delicious. I've checked out the changing menu a few times since we've dined here and I was disappointed to see that this wasn't a staple on the menu as I envisioned myself becoming a regular at the bar and drinking Whiskey Smashes with crispy pork belly egg noodles. 

The non-Serpentine (damn you!!) building was beautifully restored with an untouched exposed ceiling. It's a very open and welcoming spot. Which is only accentuated by the incredibly cool staff. We just had a damn good experience here and I hope to eat many meals here in the future.
author: Bucky K.

description:
Had a delightful brunch at Serpentine yesterday with my family (who are mostly from out of town). When making the reservation for 11 people, we were told that our party would have to be split up; but when we arrived at the restaurant, we were pleasantly surprised to find that the staff had arranged a few of the tables-for-two so we could all sit together.

Of all the dishes ordered, the best ones were the savory bread pudding, the buckwheat pancakes, and the red flannel hash. The bread in the bread pudding was warm and delicate, and though I'm not usually fond of ham, it was just right in the bread pudding. The hash was excellent-- I was surprised to find out that the meat in the hash was actually brisket because it was so tender. Went amazing with the perfectly poached eggs. But what absolutely killed me were the buckwheat pancakes. The combination of the buckwheat, walnuts, and apple compote-- though I feel like compote is too squishy a word to describe something that was just the opposite of soggy and disgusting-- was just perfect together. It would be criminal for you to go to Serpentine and leave without trying them-- one huge pancake can be shared between two or three people who just want to taste.
author: Le V.

description:
Fantastico!!! We got three egg dishes for the table, and although the fried egg sandwich was pretty darn good, my baked eggs were outstanding. I have never had someone combine eggs with roasted brussel sprouts or celery root before, and after tasting this, I wonder why. The flavor combination sings! The cream in there thickened up when mixed with the egg yolks, and the whole thing was even better when sopped up with some of the accompanying cornbread. 
To seal the deal, these guys do dessert at brunch, and it rocks. We practically inhaled the pear upside down cake.
author: Purnima M.

description:
Serpentine has everything I look for in a restaurant.  Delicious, conscientiously sourced food that's house-crafted, creative without pretension, and satisfying to the senses and soul (intellect and other mind-body parts happy to be along for the ride, but optional).  A hip atmosphere without withering hipster stares.  Attentive service by people who meet all the foregoing criteria.  Lovely cocktail and wine list.  Prices that don't raise your blood pressure.  I'm giving 5 stars not because there was a dish that I'll remember on my deathbed, but because it was a night that I would like to.

Enough of the technicalities -- they did an awesome job with my 12-person birthday party last night.  Thank you, Serpentine!  FInding a restaurant of this caliber in SF that will not only cheerfully but skillfully host a party of 12, keeping your glasses full, the food coming, and the party flowing as you gab your way through the night like a family at Thanksgiving, is quite a feat.  Fait accompli at Serpentine.

Props to the Acadian cocktail (because no birthday party is complete without absinthe), the Spiced Brentwood Yellow Corn Soup -- bowlful of summer! -- and the Housemade Potato Gnocchi with Braised Oxtail.  On the last one, I had to know what fava leaves tasted like.  Answer:  a kind of green beany parsley, which with the rest of the dish added up to delicious. 

There's a bit of a story to how we ended up here for my birthday.  I tried to book a similar sized group here for my birthday 2 years ago, and they said sorry, they couldn't handle the large party, but referred us to their sister restaurant Slow Club.  We went to Slow Club and had a ridiculous good time.  So when this year's festivities rolled around, we asked Slow Club if we could stage a comeback, and they said sorry, they couldn't handle the large party, but referred us to their sister restaurant Serpentine.  What goes around comes around!
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
4.5 Stars

When we left the restaurant, the staff were eating dinner.  We were among the last diners left - we didn't want to leave.  it was THAT good.

First of all, the restaurant was buzzing like crazy on an otherwise quiet Tuesday night, so if you are going to go, I highly suggest that you make reservations.  (You are going to go).  Call or email the restaurant.  They are closed on Mondays.

It's a medium-sized industrial-style restaurant with high, high ceilings - almost like you are standing in a rectangle turned on its side.  Think lots of exposed brick and cement beams, but warm and inviting.  I love this type of restaurant - it plays up the structure of the space rather than trying to manipulate it too much.  The bar is long full of people, but they keep it well under control.  I had heard that it used to be cold inside, but they have fixed that problem and the temperature is warm and comfortable.  The overall feeling to me was slightly more dressed-up than Slow Club, which I liked.  It's also not nearly as loud.

Drinks are not listed on the website, but if you are inclined, the Whiskey Smash is an outstanding cocktail.  Minty, sweet, and just damned tasty - my friend ordered it, and I had such drink envy!  Also, the wine list is totally reasonable - many bottles in the $30 range.  We had a very nice Pinot from Sonoma with our meal, which they let us taste before they brought it.  Reasonable, affordable wines make me very happy.

And the food...wow.  The first thing that came out was the Crispy Hama Hama Oysters.  Divine!  Perfectly cooked, perfectly breaded morsels of juicy oysters served with tiny hush puppies and a delicious pimenton sauce for dipping.  MUST HAVE dish.

Heirloom Chicory Salad - it's nice to have a creamy dressing for a change after so many vinaigrettes.  Toasted almonds and citrus make for a great flavor combo.

Savory Bread Pudding - unique,excellent, another MUST HAVE dish. It has nettles in it, which makes the color of the pudding an interesting green with crispy brown edges.  The portion size is huge, plenty for 3-4 people to share.

Warm White Shrimp and Potato Salad - this dish was different than what we expected - think potatas bravas with some shrimp thrown in.  Not my favorite, but mostly because everything else was so outstanding.

Roasted Mary's Half Chicken - who is Mary and why is she roasted?  This is not a typo, this is how this dish is listed on the menu.  A simple, well-cooked half chicken - juicy and tender.  Mmmm.

Earl Grey Pot de Creme - wonderful!  so creamy (but somehow not too rich), balance of sweet and tea flavors, with shaved ice on top for a delightful little shock of cold and texture.  MUST HAVE.

Our server, Demitrius, took great care of us - he made great recommendations and the flow of our meal was orchestrated perfectly. We all laughed a lot, like old friends.  They were slammed with more business than usual (in light of the review that came out over the weekend), yet they kept their cool and we were very well attended to by all of the staff.  It was amazing to think that they have only been open for 3 months - they operate like they have been doing this forever.

The Ciffs Notes recap is:
- make a reservation
- drink the Whiskey Smash
- MUST HAVE the Oysters, Bread Pudding, and Earl Grey Pot de Creme

I will be back -the sooner the better.
author: Liz S.

description: Went with some friends the other night to check the place out. We decided to try a little of everything. I will have to say that everything was awesome. Started with some calimari and the nectarine salad. We also split an order of the pork spare ribs. There was no item we didn't like. We then finfished of with the burger. Wow this place is awesome, try it out. The dessert is great and plus they have one of my favorite ports ( Meyer Family Cellars). Go and check it out, I promise you will like it. I know I will be back!
author: Victor W.

description:
I was glad to see Serpentine open in the Dogpatch, as I work in the neighborhood and there just aren't many places you can go for quality food and a cocktail nearby.  I really like most of the food...the savory bread pudding is one of my favorites and the arugula salad is spicy and tasty and has edible flowers in it.  The short ribs are a bit too fatty but the fried Hama oysters are delicious.  I started eating here at least once a week, and whether I sat at the bar or a table, the service was cool and quick. 

I really like the staff here...the bartenders are great, the servers are intelligent and friendly and my food always comes how I ordered it.  Unfortunately, this restaurant is so badly managed that things keep going wrong every time I eat here.  And that's why one of my favorite restaurants gets a one-star review and why I will never eat there again. 

Why should anyone have to wait an hour for a table when they show up on time for their reservation?  Yet this has happened to me not once but TWICE and I have seen many folks having trouble with the same issue while I was dining. 

Once, my girlfriend arrived five minutes before me, knew I was on my way, and was told by the hostess that she could not be seated without me, even though we had a reservation.  My girlfriend offered to sit at the bar, and the hostess told her they needed the space for dinner customers.  Now that is just plain insulting. 

The day hostess in particular is snotty and unapproachable. She acts like it is a tedious chore to help anyone in any way, and seems to be much more interested in herself than any of the people that walk in the door.  I have seen her roll her eyes at honest questions from customers more times than I can count.  I finally stopped coming to Serpentine for lunch because every time I interacted with her it pretty much ruined my mood.

In fact, the whole host staff acts like it is beneath them to accommodate anything a customer asks. I just read the reviews here on Yelp and there are so many stories of hostesses making people wait needlessly, refusing to call cabs, ignoring customers, being unaccommodating, seeming annoyed, and so on.  You may ask...why would the management keep these people on??  

Ah, but I know why!! A few weeks ago, I spoke to one of my favorite servers about it, and the server told me that the hostesses are the managers.  Ah...now it makes sense.  

And it means I won't be going back to Serpentine. 

You know, you can tell a lot about a restaurant by watching their staff interact.  If it is a cool place to work, people are happy and brisk and chatty.  Most of the staff really seem to enjoy themselves and their jobs; they seem to be great people.  But the hostess/managers almost never interact with any of their staff and when they do, you can tell from body language that these folks don't like their employees too much. And the feeling seems to be mutual.   

The final straw was when I saw an off-duty hostess walk in and sit down with her friends about a half hour after my group was seated. We could not believe it when we waited 40 minutes for our entrees while watching their table fill up with some of the same dishes we had ordered.  

It's too bad that the catalyst for my entry into Yelp is negatively motivated; I've been reading reviews on here for months and have followed many recommendations that have proved fruitful.  I have been meaning to get on here and post some great things about some of my favorite restaurants and bars in the City...unfortunately, this just pissed me off so much that it became my reason to dive in. 

To recap: if you like great food and a quick, friendly, cool staff but don't mind being treated like an annoyance when you walk in the door, then Serpentine is the restaurant for you.
author: Good Food Lover V.

description: Wow. So I always see a line for Serpentine from the other line I am in at Just for You, a half block done. One day there was no line for Serpentine, and one for JFY, so we decided to try it out. The SERVICE was awful, as were the TASTELESS potatoes.  You would assume anything fried would taste good-NOT. Also, I asked for Kale (because I saw it on the menu) instead of bacon or sausage since I don't eat pork, and the server responded "Kale? That specific?  I can give you mixed greens". Really? So much attitude-not to mention: Scrambled eggs with mixed greens? Gross on both counts. Snooty Service. While I understand the customer is not always right in requesting substitutions, you don't need to be rude about it. Never again.
author: Margot G.

description:
How have I lived four blocks away from here for several years and never found this place? It opened 18 months ago, and I just happened to stumble upon it while, ironically, looking online for the menu for Slow Club, on the other side of the Hill (apparently, they are in fact sister restaurants).

Awesome space, killer brunch, fantastic bloody mary - what more do you want on a Saturday morning? It wasn't the most lively place, but this was moments after they opened at 10 AM. 

Can't wait to come back -- sometimes, more sophisticated cuisine beats greasy comfort food,  and for that, I'll definitely be back.
author: Joe K.

description:
Quite possibly one of the more difficult places to park during the day ...but worth it once you get a spot.

I enjoyed lunch and catch-up with a dear friend there today and was really impressed with the interior finish.  It's almost shabby...but then it isn't.  The ceiling is interesting, with lots of light streaming in from above.

She had a fish dish that looked divine and possibly pesto-ey.  I had an eggplant sandwich that was perfect, and on yummy bread.  Our server was sweet, not pushy, and never made us feel like we had to hurry up, which was good because we had a lot of gossiping to do!

I love that lunch gets dessert menus here, because once you have gotten to this unusual nook of the city, you'll want to stay a bit and make it worth the trip.  We both had a chocolate chip cookie,,,which was to date, the best cookie I've had.  Crisp on the edges and chewy in the middle...mmmm.

Sniffing out the Dogpatch...
author: Lea N.

description:
I don't really go to the "Dogpatch" area of San Francisco.
The only time I went, to my recollection, is when I went to Hard Knox Cafe.  Review here: http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=_pIG1_s6Bzymn1zeyLjBHQ&q=hard+knox
 
On Thursday night of last week - my friend and I decided to check out "Serpentine".  Now, I have never been to "Slow Club", which is on my list of PLACES TO TRY- but since Serpentine is owned by the same people of the allegedly fabulous SC - I was excited to try it out.
 
Well - WOW.
I'm impressed.
On a tall. white building, which appeared newly renovated, you see S-E-R-P-E-N-T-I-N-E spelled downwards on a building.  Compared to my lunch hour visit to Hard Knox when parking was impossible, dinner-time parking was simple.  Walking in - it's a hip location, very crowded with people eating, but also standing around just mingling at the bar area.  Many of the people hanging out at the bar were probably local to this area, and I had to agree that this was a good "after work" hangout.  The hostess was friendly and pleasant - and we were seated immediately in a corner table for two.
 
Our server was also quite pleasant, and while she was busy and not exactly attentive - - she did come around often enough to keep us content.  The food, however, took longer than I would have liked.  
 
The wine list is nice - - with wines from all regions and many different varietals, most available by  the glass.  
The menu is exactly how I like it.  When I read a menu, I want to see the offerings and descriptions, and WANT to try that dish.  I want to end up having a hard choice because I am not sure which, of the many, I'd like to have, since I have to narrow it down to a few.  Serpentine's menu reads delicious.
 
Alas, since it was only two girls eating dinner, and because I simply wasn't that hungry (unheard of, I know, but it happens once in a blue moon), we shared on appetizer and each ordered an entree.  The appetizer of the evening was:  BEEF MARROW BONES.  Served with toasted bread and coarse salt, you peer down a big ol' bone, dig your knife in and scoop out the goodies inside, spread it on your bread with salt, and wolf down.  It's a very heavy dish both in texture AND taste, but the kumquat salad that they served with it was a PERFECT blend with the kumquats sweet rind, sour middle and rather bitter flavor.  The citrus juices just really brightened up the taste of the marrow, and actually enhanced the dish.
 
For our entrees, my friend had the half-chicken - and the taste I had of it was tender and juicy.   It wasn't deep-fried, and very fresh.  It was good, but nothing about it stole the show, so to speak.  I, strangely enough, ordered the Hamburger, and added the option of Gruyere cheese, cooked medium rare - and it was very, very good.  It wasn't quite "medium-rare" but still, it was great meat frrom Prather Ranch, and the condiments just worked.  Extra points, too, for bringing out my ketchup, mustard and mayonnaise - ON THE SIDE.  The only one I use is mayo - so this was cool, or else I'd have to spend 2 minutes scraping off ketchup.  Blech!#@!@
 
For dessert, we shared a warm Apple Crisp with a vanilla cream type of sauce atop it.  It was pretty much a mashed up Apple Pie a la mode - - and who can go wrong with that?  I couldn't stop picking at it.
 
Now, more than ever, I am excited to check out SLOW CLUB.  If Yelpers still believe SC to be better than Serpentine, then it must be quite memorable.
 
For Serpentine, I'd go again to try their different dishes.  It was a good dinner with outstanding company, great wine, and even finished with a bang with that dessert.  It broke down to $45 per person or so including tip, which was alright, given that we only had two glasses of wine, one appetizer, 2 entrees, one of which was a mere hamburger, and a dessert, but it was tasty enough to not make me feel like it was money wasted.
 
Serpentine - GOOD FOOD!
author: Grace K.

description: This is my all-time favorite restaurant in S.F.  The staff, the food, the drinks.... all are amazing.  But, please, don't come here.  I'd hate for it to get too busy!!! :P
author: Kjerstin G.

description:
First, the food:  generally it was excellent.   Among us we had the beet salad, the spinach salad, lamb riblets, rabbit, the burger, and the flat iron steak.  While it was a very autumnal menu, well, it's cold outside, and it tasted exactly right.  The wines we had also were good.

Second, the ambiance:  whew.  Well, the bones are good, but the space is carved up a bit awkwardly (by the placement of the bathrooms amidship), and it's very loud.  I would have kept the integrity of the open space (by putting the bathrooms in back), and though it's heresy, I'd  possibly paint the exposed brick white to make it uniform in color and to provide a blank palette in order to hang warming art.  I'd break up the space not with the big wall of the bathroom, but instead with some library tables, or something antique.  (A similar cavernous space that's terribly warm is the delightful Boat Street Cafe in Seattle, which marries warehouse aesthetics with a pared-down Provence vibe to great effect.)

They should lower the din too, perhaps with some velvet curtains.   It would be worth the money to really consider how to bring the sound down some.  Way too loud last night until around 9:30.

But it's Slow Club in its food, and I liked it.  Serpentine's a welcome addition to the neighborhood.
author: Laurel B.

description:
Their slogan is "honest food" -- and a hamburger is $11.50. (Cheese extra.)

There are a lot of words I can think of to describe a place like this -- pretentious, obscene, insulting, yuppie, unnecessary -- but "honest" is certainly not one of them.

If you want a $12 burger, go to John's Grill downtown. At least that place has historical character and isn't just another addition to the blight of trendy restaurants swarming across the city like flies on a carcass.
author: John G.

description:
Would you like some dinner with your salt?  I was really excited by the fried green tomatoes.  Usually, they have a sweet tart taste and a crisp cornmeal shell.  All I could taste was salt.  I ordered the pork chops with green beans and cornbread.  The pork was too salty to taste if it was any good.  The cornbread was super salty too.  The green beans were limp and stewed in salty barbeque sauce.  It was about 90 degrees in the city today so preceding this meal with slight dehydration wasn't a good move.  My lips hurt.  crackle

The reason for the three stars?  Their pastry chef rocks.  Wow.  I have never had such a disparity in quality between desserts and the main food at a restaurant.  I had a wonderful nectarine praline tart with lemon verbena ice cream.  The ice cream was a bit too sweet (bi-rite ice cream tends to be like this and that's where they got it) but the praline crust was perfect.  I think the nectarines were a little past perfection because it's September, but the overall presentation, flavor combos, and texture profile was divine.  My friend had the upside down cake and it was also awesome.  Just naturally beautiful.

Come here for dessert and a glass of wine.
author: Elena S.

description: Had the coconut squash soup and the local cod: both cooked to perfection, the cod with the crispy skin on it, ohhhh. My friends had the ginger ice cream with pumpkin cookies and some sort of coffee float, they couldn't stop talking about it, I tried it and it was 5 seconds of heaven in my mouth. Definitely coming back here.
author: Carlos L.

description:
When the restaurant Serpentine comes to mind, my eyes close and lips purse while I hum sweet, "mmmmmm's," to anyone who will listen.

While this restaurant was inconvenient to get to (I live in the Marina), it was well worth the trip. The bread pudding was to die for -  a bready, cheesy, herby, square of absolute lip smacking goodness. The spinach bacon salad was fabulous as well. I got the pork shoulder as my main course - the meat was so tender it fell from the bone with even the tiniest poke. 

Throughout the meal, service was great - our server was very pleasant.  However, I had a major problem with the way they handled our departure. Like I mentioned earlier, my friends and I came from the Marina. We had arrived via cab. As our meal came to a close, I asked a server if somebody wouldn't mind calling us a cab. She came back 1 minute later to tell us that she tried but couldn't get through - so we'd better start calling ourselves. Okaaaaayyy.....my friends and I got through to a couple of places but after we'd been waiting around for a good 30 minutes with no cab in sight, we went back in to ask for help again. 

By this time we were the last customers hanging around the restaurant. I asked yet again that they help us get a cab where they proceeded to tell us that the cab company that they call had turned off their phones already. When we asked them if they had a phone book, they responded with a, "probably not," and walked away.

We finally flagged one down ourselves by sheer luck and made it home but I couldn't help but feel slightly miffed at the way the restaurant handled our situation. If you're going to have a restaurant in a location like the Dog Patch, you're more than likely going to have many patrons coming from neighborhoods that aren't near by and who will be requesting cabs. It would have been really helpful and less stressful for us had somebody been more hospitable in this area.
author: Julia N.

description: great restuarant. I got their fancy burger and the gnochhi. both were great. great ambience especially with the exposed industrial look.
author: Carl N.

description: We had an amazing experience!  It was our second time at Serpentine and everything was amazing.  My boyfriend had the burger which was cooked just as he ordered, and I had the steak with polenta and asparagus.  It was one of the best meals I have ever had.  The only downside to this place is the price, which means we can only go occasionally.  The atmosphere, service, and drinks were spot on.  Lower the price and I would be there every day!
author: Kristin F.

description: Nomz. All I have to say is that the burger was delicious, the decor was amazing and the price was reasonable. I love the ambiance of this place so chic. Highly recommended.
author: simon c.

description:
With 174 reviews Im not sure my two cents matter but . . . this is riveting information people. I have long been a very loyal, dedicated devotee to the Slow Club. In fact if you read my profile you will see that my last meal on earth is the sweet potato hash or their burger. I make regular trips back to SF just to fulfill my cravings for these savory delights. But, something profound happened during my last trip up north. My dear friend Michelle brought me to Serpentine. You see I have a French fetish. Im crazy about all things french. Especially young waiters with thick accents. Opps, I digress. We tried Cafe Claude earlier in the week. The food was so so. The drinks were fantastic and waiters w/ French accents lulled my irritation over some really shitty Rillettes so it was not a complete loss. This dear friend knew how crazy I am about the Rillette. You see, in addition to the French, I am also crazy about the Pig. Pig any way you cook it brings a smile to my face. So, off we go! We enter Serpentine and I immediately like the atmosphere. This is the kind of restaurant that doese not exist in LA. A neighborhood jem with good honest food - with no jacked up Hollywood $35 for an entree bullshit just because one of the desperate housewives wrote a check to the investors. I take one look at the menu and SQUEAL with joy. Marin Sun Farms Pork Rillettes 
whole grain mustard - cornichon - pickled shallots - toasted levain ?? Are you fucking kidding me? They blew me away. And then there's this Savory Bread Pudding 
I love bread pudding. And I love savory things. But this is OUT OF THIS WORLD. swiss - sungold tomatoes - garlic - rosemary, artichoke hearts and brioche.
