I'd swear off french lovers for the rest of my life if I could eat this every day (and in fact they would most likely swear me off too b/c this is no lo-cal treat)! A mear $8.50 for one of the biggest most delightful things I have ever eaten! 

F. Gary Danko or Micheal Minna!Who needs that pomp and circumstance when you can get food like this. With that said, I will edit my last meal on earth. . . 

Serpentine, I love you. I only wish you had open when I still lived on Potero.
author: Deidre H.

description: Perfectly cooked hamburger worthy of applause. Full of flavor and juicy.  Served in a setting bursting with energy.  Waitstaff pleasant and attentive.  A+ on the cocktails.  Highly recommend. Did I mention the excellent service?
author: Marc H.

description:
Brunch!  As good as it gets... YES!
OK, this is going to be a favorite brunch place.  Will be interested to try other times/menus.
We had the crab benedict and the red flannel hash.  Both were PERFECT. eggs were PERFECTLY poached.  Seasoning was PERFECT.  The hash had huge tender juicy chunks of brisket with a great balance of beets, potatoes and other garden goodness.  The crab benedict came with crispy homefry potatoes - dang, those are addictive.  I'll have a hard time not ordering an extra side of those next time.  We started with a Pimm's cup and S' version of Irish coffee - both PERFECT.
and we finished with an off-the-menu piece of (perfect) chocolate cake in a (perfect) raspberry coulis accented with Bi-Rite chocolate ice cream.  Now that's a brunch I'm going to remember for a long time... and the memory is going to be nagging me to go back.  Service was friendly and super-attentive without hovering (perfect).  The ambiance was industrial but still fun and even though they had a decent music track at good volume, the super high ceiling absorbs all the normal restaurant harsh sounds - very easy to have a quiet conversation.   So, if you want the perfect brunch experience, head over to Serpentine.  You will not be disappointed!
author: Bob K.

description:
Things I would definitely recommend: pickled vegetables, meat board (there was some kind of peachy syrupy sauce underneath one of the meats which was delicious), nectarine salad, and definitely get the PORK BELLY! favorite dish of the night! It was cooked perfectly, great texture, and it was well complimented by the other elements on the plate. 

Best left on the menu: oysters (probably my fault for ordering them in July but they were TINY, they were $2.75 each which is extremely overpriced, and my boyfriend had a bad one) and don't order the chicken livers, they were TERRIBLE (I usually am a pretty adventurous eater but these had an awful texture that made me want to gag, I won't go into detail but it was bad)

Besides these two mishaps it was a great experience. I especially liked our waitress who was very sweet and personable. I've also heard that they are not shy about their pours with their wines although I didn't have any this time around.
author: Nadia M.

description:
I had lunch there today. 

#1 Parking was horrible
#2 The place was freezing
#3 They mixed up our order
#4 The chicken pot pie was not a pie it was a soup, with a leg of chicken sticking out of it with a biscuit on top

They've only been open for 4 days so they're bound to improve but for now I think I will stick with Slow Club which is still awesome.
author: Nathaniel R.

description:
If only John G. knew how ironic his review is...

The owner and creator of Serpentine is the most UN-pretencious, UN-yuppie person in San Francisco.
 
And if your definition of 'honest', John G., is 'cheap' - well then - yes, maybe Serpentine is not the place for you. 

However, if you consider 'honest food' to be REAL food that comes from farmers and ranchers that the Serpentine crew has taken great care in choosing - or better yet - have chosen THEM (take for example your burger, which came from Prather Ranch, who approached The Slow Club/Serpentine to be the only restaurants in the city to carry this 'honest' beef!), then maybe you'll see the purpose of this new neighborhood restaurant - a place for people to gather and enjoy REAL food.

Lastly, when it comes to 'insulting', maybe you should take a look in the mirror.
author: molly t.

description: I've been trying biscuits and gravy at other SF brunch spots recently. Serpetine still wins out for the BEST biscuits and gravy, just FYI.
author: Leilani H.

description:
Ordered for pick up and the spot looked quite nice inside. Clean, crisp and industrial. And they have a full bar! If I'm ever in the area again, I'll try to stop by.

Truffled beef brisket sandwich: Beef was tender and sweet with lots of natural juices that soaked into the bread. OHMIGAWD. White cheddar brought a nice sharpness to the sweet beef and the grilled red onions and arugula added some veggies without taking away from the main attraction, the tender, delicious ass beef! The torpedo roll was surprisingly realllly soft but didn't turn to mush with all the juices from the meat. LOVED THIS.

Co-worker said the burger was realllly good especially with the blue cheese. I think blue cheese tastes like what it is, MOLD, so I didn't try any. I'll take her word for it. 

Sidenote: Fries tasted just ok and weren't even close to being spectacular like the sandwich.
author: Beverly T.

description:
I had dinner at Serpentine with two friends on Saturday night. We got a table right away at 6:30pm. I had arrived a little early and had a great margarita at the bar with El Tesoro tequila, not a brand your average bar carries. The bartender was nice but a little too introverted for my taste, I like mine chatty and fun. 

The food was well prepared, yummy and a pretty good bang for the buck.  I look forward to eating at Serpentine again and trying other selections from the menu. That being said, for "simple food", I'd rather eat at 1550 Hyde Street and Wine Bar, which I would go to more often if it was closer to my house and had easier parking.

One big plus Serpentine gets is for the convenient location, the parking in the evenings in Dog Patch is very easy and it's close to Bernal Heights (where I live). This is a big plus, sometimes convenience wins the day. I like to dine early, so the combination of parking and getting seated could sway me to eat here much more often. The price wasn't outrageous either, it was reasonable for the quality.

The food:

To start, we shared the Savory Bread Pudding (nettles - roasted red onions - swiss add mixed greens $11.50). That dish is FANTASTIC. It's like the best stuffing you've ever had and tastes of artichokes and butter. 

I had the Escarole Salad (shaved sunchokes - sieved egg - bacon lardons - tarragon garlic cream $8.50) which was very good and tangy although the shaved sunchokes added no special flavor to the dish, it was really more like a garnish.

For entrees...
I had the White Shrimp & Anson Mills Grits (sauteed onions - poblano peppers $10.50) which was very good and comforting, but should have been spicy, since it had poblano chilis in it, but wasn't.

One friend had the Roasted Half Chicken (roasted ruby crescent potatoes - baby fennel - nicoise olives - catstroville artichokes - savoy spinach $18.50) which was very delicious.

My other friend had the Marin Sun Farms Flat Iron Steak (parsley root puree - roasted shallots - baby carrots - broccoli rabe - anchoiade $24.50), which was good, but not my favorite.

For dessert, we shared a banana ice cream thing, which was unremarkable. Their dessert menu is nothing special and seems more like an afterthought. I have a feeling they do not have a pastry chef at Serpentine. Hopefully they will add a better selection of desserts in the future; thus, the one star deduction for this review.

With 2 glasses of wine and a large bottle of sparkling mineral water, the bill including tip was $45.00 each. Not bad.

Afterwards we walked down to the ReTox Lounge on 20th Street for a drink. I love the Dog Patch district and now there's another great place to eat there other than the Hard Knox Cafe.
author: Yvette K.

description:
I first tried this spot last year when a vendor took our sales staff out to dinner.  We were wowed by the cocktail menu as well as the look of this place.  Since we all work in the Interior Design industry we are total snobs when it comes to decor.  This place was dead on.  A great industrial feel, cold cement and filament light bulbs.  Horrah.

The cocktail menu is definitely worth the trip to the dog patch on its own.  The food was as expected for the decor and price range.  

I had a second visit with a group of friends in from New York.  I had mentioned that I've been before to my friend who organized the dinner so she made a rez and we checked it out again.  The cocktails, again, are still awesome.  The food was pretty delicious.  The service had a few mishaps (my drink was mixed up with someone else and they forgot one of our entrees), but the Owner (maybe manager) was really attentive to our group and made corrections quickly.  

Overall, probably the best place in the dog patch.  Somewhere to keep in mind when out in no mans land.
author: Mister G.

description:
We were charmed by this great restaurant nestled out in the dogpatch. Where can you show up at 7:45 pm on a Thursday and find parking it the City? That alone garners four stars. 

We were promptly seated in a back booth with great views of this industrial space.  This is the kind of space that appeals to me, not too much decoration to cover up the natural aesthetic of the building.  

They have a very reasonably priced wine list, not over the top in terms of selection but our $40 bottle of pinot was quite good.  We began with two salads, one with mustard greens and the other with beet greens, both were excellent.  I was really thrilled by the freshness of both, they were clearly right outta the ground and used seasonally fresh ingredients.  We also split the lamb riblets on the advice of our waiter.  TASTY!  Seriously sooo good.  

We then moved on to pork chops and sea bass.  Even though there were four of us we still did that dorky couple business where each couple orders the exact same thing, so much for variety.  I thought the chops were tasty, but not to the level of Nopa, my date had the same opinion.  For me the chop was a little too, um, savory?  The sea bass looked good, with both parties cleaning their plates so I think that's a safe bet. 

We finished the meal with the goat cheese dessert with strawberries, fresh cream and cracked pepper.  WOW.  It was seriously amazing.  The hit of the meal outside of the lamb riblets! 

I didn't notice any problems with the service, although I will say that it took quite a while for our entrees to come after the appetizers were served.  Not a problem for our group as we were chatting, but could be a problem if you were on a tight time schedule. 

All in all a great meal, I'm trying Slow Club next...but this place is great alternative, especially if you want to park, eat and ride.  Reasonably priced as well.
author: Claire C.

description:
I was seriously impressed with Serpentine. I absolutely loved the savory bread pudding, and could imagine ordering it every night for takeout to bring home and bliss out on its comfort-food perfection. Except I would probably gain 10 pounds in a week because that stuff was rich. The other stuff we ate was also fantastic, but it's obscured by the memory of that savory bread pudding...mmmm....

Cool semi-industrial decor. Adorable waitress. No wait to be seated on a Wednesday night around 7:30. Go now!
author: Melinda K.

description:
I was really excited to venture to Serpentine - I've heard so much about the place! Unfortunately, my taste buds weren't stimulated   

The service was fantastic..the atmosphere is friendly, but the food and beverages were a miss. I guess with all the hoopla and the $$$   for the area - my expectations were high.

My  martini was on the luke warm side, bummer!

We ordered the savory bread pudding - and for an extra 5 bucks they threw on a few greens and a small strand of carrots ..we actually laughed at the portion of carrots - musta been some greedy rabbits in the kitchen???

For the main we had the roasted chicken..it was a good roasted chicken -  but no wow factor. It was suppose to be served with spinach, fennel, and artichokes...there werea couple of little potatoes and the shallot vinaigrette...but the other vegetables must have been hanging back with the carrots??

..then we dared for dessert. Banana Creme Pie...well there was banana, there was a big puddle of cream (more like soup), and there was a soggy crust. We tasted it and left it to finish dying on the plate. Poor Poor Banana!

Well, I will try them out again cause I had fun with my date and the staff was really friendly - wish me luck!




We
author: Ron W.

description:
We ordered 5 dishes to share between 3 of us. All were really good, and 3 were totally exceptional. I find this very unusual. Normally, I hope to have one dish really impress me at a fancy place, but 3 of 5 was really impressive!
The homemade duck sausage with homemade mustard was to die for.  And I was incredibly smitten by the fried calamari dipped in a spicy garbanzo bean batter and refreshing dipping sauce/aioli. I don't usually order or enjoy fried calamari because it's greasy and boring, but this made me fall in love with the fritters all over again! The last dish that really stood out was the rack of lamb--soooo tender and juicy, with well balanced flavors in a Moroccan style sauce.
They also had great cocktails!
author: KarenYaella F.

description:
Never yelped before but thought i would start immediately when i was reading the Serpentine review before me  which appeared to be written by someone desperately bored and inexperienced.

For crying out loud who has that much free time to yelp a restaurant that hasn't even been open a week? I wish I could Yelp that Yelper.

Getting to the point, and setting the record straight. I went to Serpentine the first week it opened. It is just what that up and coming area needs! 
The staff was lovely and very attentive which was amazing for how slammed they were.  I am not one for experimental adult beverages and gave it a shot anyway, I am now obsessed with some grapefruit drink they invented.

I tried quite a few different things on the menu to get an overall feel for the place and was very impressed. Favorites being the savory bread pudding with greens, beet salad and the warm shrimp potato salad. The riblets were also excellent although I only got to have 1 bite of my friend's dish.

The ambiance was beautiful, industrial with some soft edges thrown in. Really tall ceilings and great attention to detail. I was told they are still putting in the finishing touches which I can't wait to see. 

I will be going back for sure and will give them a few weeks before I do so they can work out the opening kinks. It will most likely me my new staple.
author: ha s.

description: Came here for brunch on the recommendation of a friend and fell in love.  You would have no idea from the outside that this great restaurant lies within.  Beautiful light and casual decor, friendly service, and most importantly delicious and fresh food!  And the prices are criminal compared to what I would pay in Minneapolis ~ I miss that about SF; amazingly good food at affordable prices.  I had the Baked Eggs because it was unique with a local flair, and it was perfectly prepared, as was my coffee.  I would definitely return.  This is a place San Franciscan's go, you should too whether or not you are lucky enough to live here.  Yum.
author: D B.

description: Decent brunch place.  The crab benedict is pretty good, and so is the baked eggs.  There's also a "pear" jam that came with the eggs meat potatoes bread course that doesn't taste like pear, but has a very unique blend of flavors that I enjoyed.
author: Josh Q.

description: Delicious!  Flavorful and cooked to perfection!  Only down side was they were running late on the reservations and the restaurant was packed so still had to wait, but it was well worth it and the staff was very friendly!!
author: Danielle A.

description:
5 star potential but currently 3.5 star food. However 5+ star cocktails- always helps make up for any deficiencies.

I want to love this place, and I so love the interior, the feel, vibe, lighting, cocktails and bartenders. However we were underwhelmed by the food. The appetizer/small plates were much tastier than the entrees so I may go with several of those instead of an entree next time. 

I had the duck and my husband had the burger (which was very rare although he asked for medium). The duck was fairly fatty and lacked any discernable flavor. 

I did have a wonderful time and will be going back as it is blocks from my abode. Solid four and half stars. (I so want to give 5 but I just can't... *sigh*)
author: Adrienne P.

description:
YES WE CAN! 
YES WE CAN!
YES WE CAN!

oh yes we can eat a savory bread pudding and we should do it more often... that was d e l i c i o u s!!!!

oh yes we can eat a Hamburger on a bread roll rather than a typical hamburger bun..... that was t a h a h a s s s t y y !!!

oh yes we can drive all the way to dogpatch for a nice dinner some time... that was a g r e a t  idea!!!
author: Doro P.

description:
Not sure if my friend Ed U. Was secretly wearing ear plugs and communicating by sign language, but we could barely hear each other near the end of our meal, which was a little after 8. The location is listed as 3rd Street between 20th & 22nd, but it is actually on the corner of 3rd & 22nd, and easy to miss.
We shared the veal sweetbread w/artichokes and calamari for starters.  The sweetbread had a nice complex flavor that went well with the crunchy baby chokes.  Calamari was a little soggy, but was saved by the butterbeans.  I had a pomegranate lemonade that was the perfect mix of tart to sweet.  The duck leg with polenta had great flavor, but was way too salty and the polenta's texture disintegrated and was lost in the juices, but the soft boiled egg was a perfect addition. I loved the turnips and thought there should have been more.  Roasted sunchokes made a nice side, and were the perfect texture. 
Our server was everything you want in a server; there when you needed her, not when you don't. 
Oh, and the most important, dessert!  We shared a poached pear cranberry crumble w/ginger ice cream. The ginger ice cream is from Bi-Rite and has a nice bite...simply amazing!
author: Arlene C.

description: At first I thought this place was only open for brunch, but apparently it's even more popular as a dinner place.  It's in the Dogpatch so kinda out of the way if you live downtown, but worth the trip.  Interior has a warehouse/industrial feel, the tables are covered with sheet metal and the dining area is very brightly lit by natural light thru the large windows.  Even though we had a reservation, we still had to wait for about 10 mins, but once seated service was very attentive.  Pancakes are yumma, soft but not too mushy.  Overall good place for sunday brunch!
author: Chi N.

description: One of my favorite brunches ever! Great space, industrial and modern, without being cold or uninviting-has a lot of warm touches to the decor. My friends and I ordered the Red Flannel Hash, Maine Coast Crab Benedict and Savory Bread Pudding-all superb. I loved my Crispy potatoes, best side ever. My Crab Benedict was both light and substantial at the same time, quite rich, not in a sickening diner way, but a refined taste. Service was fine. Thought it was totally cool that they played the Requiem for a Dream soundtrack.
author: Jenny W.

description:
I really enjoyed the dinner the last Saturday.
We came to the restaurant really early. It was empty. 
We sat at the bar and had cocktails. All were good. 
Then we sat at table for dinner. The foods were all well prepared. 
Wine selection was very good. Decent price wine and taste great.
 
The slow club was my favorite restaurant for long time so I was sure that the place should be good too since the same owner. 
I was not wrong. 
After 8 pm, the place was all packed. Since the place is located at Dog patch, I could reserve the place even one day before. 
If this place is located in Misson or SOMA, I could not see the seat.

I will definitely come back this place.
author: Miho O.

description:
Well I'm deducting 2 more stars...
1. for charging my card TWICE over a 6 day period.
2. for not having anyone answer the phone and no voicemail to leave a message for them.
3. sloppiness for the charges and giving me the trouble of calling my credit card company to take care of this.
author: ML ..

description:
The nectarine salad, daiquiri, whiskey smash, and burger are total home runs. The other menu items were good, but not craveable. I walked in sans reservation and was told I could sit at the bar or go home. Too bad for me! I checked out opentable on my phone and hey wait, there is still a 9 and 9:30 slot?? So I made one. Came back in and the dude was like well yeah but it's still a few mins. 

Dude, I clearly don't care and the offer to put my name on the list for a later reservation would really have been appreciated.

Anyway, once our server greeted us with the biggest smile and brought another round of drinks all was forgiven. Get the nectarine salad. You will not be sorry! Also if you are hungry the burger is phenomenal. It was good enough that it was enjoyed the next day, all soggy and at that point it was apparently "an average burger."

I had fishies and it was better than any fish that I could make but I think I'll try something else next time. Plum upside down cake was really neat - the cake had a bit of a cornmeal texture that really complimented the juicy plums well. It was balanced out by the creamy tang of creme fraiche. Mmmmm.

Nice spot, great for romantic dinner and also good for taking visiting parents and in laws. Remember to get a reservation and if there is still a wait go across the street to Dogpatch Saloon. Not cheap, but you get high quality food and service so it's worth it on special occasions.
author: Allegra F.

description:
I've been on a hunt for the best burger in the City and Serpentine is currently the top contender. 

They have a great bartender. The house margarita is excellent and they have an interesting cocktail list.

I think they hired a new chef fairly recently and since then every experience has been consistently good. I had a few misses in the past.

The staff is very friendly and accomodating.
author: Meg P.

description: Not sure what the hype is all about, and all the stars everyone's giving this place.  Went there on a recent Sunday afternoon for brunch, and they just didn't have it together, maybe it was an off day and they were short staffed.. but we seemed to be waiting the whole time we were there... we waited to be seated (finally 10 mins past our reservation), waited for our drinks, then our food, decided to pass on any additional drinks or dessert as everything TOOK WAY TOO LONG, and the restaurant wasn't all that busy.  Oh, and the food? Nuttin' special, just like the service.
author: W D.

description:
Just in time for festive dining over the holidays comes the opening of SERPENTINE.
It's in the DogPatch neighborhood south of the ball park, on 3rd St. at 22nd (a properly psychedelic SF address).
I dined on opening night, and it is deeeeelicious! Who cares the heating was being fussy, I was busy imbibing amazing cocktails, consuming fried oysters, cod in a chowdery broth... mmmm....
And the ambiance is GOOD, raw materials of brick and wood, modern and industrial at the same time, with such nice attention to the feel of everything... I was petting the smooth slate bar... and that was BEFORE my bourbon!
SERPENTINE feels like it has always been there, 
and always should be!
author: coco l.

description:
Took my pal who is from Chicago the other night. She is from a very cool little area called Lincoln Square that has so many great places to eat, so the pressure was on. She said that she wanted to eat in my neighborhood. So off to Serpentine we walked....
Very good place. Yes, it was very loud, but what places aren't now? 
She ordered the Bread Pudding, which she was a huge fan of. I have never had it so I when I tried hers, I was jealous of her choice over mine. I ordered a skirt steak that was just so so.
But what I really liked about this place is the service and the great wine menu.
I will go back.
author: Christine S.

description: Perfect mix of industrial Dogpatch decor while still feeling warm & inviting. Delicious brunch. Sort of split the Great Savory Bread Pudding and Red Flannel Hash! Both amazing dishes. Never heard of a savory bread pudding, complete with ham! AMAZING! And never realized beef brisket & beets would task so good together in the hash!
author: Anna R.

description:
I work down the street and the news of a new restaurant in the area is the most exciting thing this year. The place went through a beautiful transformation in comparison to what the place was before - Cafeteria styled Chinese food place.

Lighting of the restaurant is very interesting. the windows are located near the ceiling which creates a very tall feeling to the place. the drawback is that right during peak lunch hours the sun blinds customers at several tables.

Ordered turkey sandwich with mushrooms and cheese on rye...very tasty. Also ordered the pull pork sandwich with egg. the egg along with a strong mustard layer made the sandwich very strong. overall the i enjoyed my first visit and plan on going back.
author: Gabe H.

description:
You really can't beat Serpentine's location.  It's right off the T-Third and parking is so easy you'd swear you were in the south bay.  

The restaurant itself is pretty small, however, and tends to fill up quickly.  There's pretty much no walk-in for dinner unless you happen to be hungry on a Tuesday right around 6:30.  In that case, hi Grandpa!  Sorry I haven't called, but work has been busy, ya know.  Love you!

Brunch was good, I wish the menu had been a little more extensive and a little more on the breakfast side of things, but the food was well made and I left full. Great natural light all though the room.  Had the baked eggs with butternut squash and a way-too-expensive mimosa.  Brunch isn't brunch without one too many mimosas, and the price of them here just made me sad.

Dinner is a whole different experience.  Dark.  Lots of waiting, even with a reservation, and God forbid you end up at that table in front of the kitchen and next to the bathrooms.  It's in a weird spot, and my friends who were in chairs on the outside felt really uncomfortable with all the foot traffic.  The lamb shank is off the hook delicious though.

I think I keep going back because I want to like it, not because I actually do.
author: Boots B.

description:
One of our favourite restaurants in the city
The quintessential Dogpatch restaurant: high quality, affordable, friendly
The menu changes regularly, the ingredients are super fresh, the food excellent
The staff has been there for years for the most part
The burger is great
We go there every other week
author: FOO D.

description:
Went to Serpentine because we heard that it had the same chef as Slow Club - which my husband and I both love. We had a lovely time, but overall I like the Slow Club better. 

I love the feel of Serpentine - high ceilings, very urban feeling, beautiful bar, nice lighting (very Slow Club-esque vibe). The menu had a lot of original offerings - duck rillettes, fried oysters with hush puppies. We got a heirloom chicory salad with mint and mandarins which was ok - not amazing. 

We shared a burger and fries, and a braised buffalo and butternut squash lasagna. I thought the lasagna was very tasty and delicious, but didn't think the burger was very good (my husband thought the opposite - wish we would have traded). I ordered my burger with blue cheese and they were a little skimpy with it, and it was a little over cooked and not that juicy.

The desserts were great - affogado with bi-rite creamery ice cream and decaf esspresso was the best. We also got an earl grey pot de creme topped with granita which was very subtle tasting and delicious too. 

We went early - 6:30 on a Friday night - because we had our sleeping 2 month old with us. In general I think this place isn't kid friendly - it is a pretty tight space, but they were nice about accomodating us at least at that hour.
author: Lynn G.

description: There's probably only one or two better ways to spend a lazy Sunday in the City. Starting with the crispy potatoes and the awesome sauce, onward to the buckwheat pancakes, the amazing hamburger, and the red flannel hash with roasted beets... one damn fine meal, let me tell you. Three bloody marys later...
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Stopped in at Yield for a glass of wine and learned that a new restaurant just opened right across the street! Same owners as the Slow Club, apparently. Older guy sitting at the bar at Yield suggested waiting a couple of weeks for them to hit their stride, but we decide to risk it. 

We wander in and can still smell the paint, but not in a bad way. There's a good bustle and the food smells good. We had small salad of some interesting greens with a bit of bleu cheese and a few nibs of farro (I would have liked a bit more, so as to be able to taste a bit more of it), the smaller serving of savory bread pudding - very nice combination of not-overpowering mushroom and gruyere cheese, and the lamb "riblets" (also excellent, but not an attractive word) to start, and then the (flank?) steak as a main. The steak arrived cooked perfectly and sliced, not sure if they did that because we were sharing or if that's standard, but it worked well, and the meat was very good. 

Wine list was a bit funky - lots of unusual varietals, and a focus on the lower end - it seemed like sort of a "bargain wines" list... Not super exciting, and so I expect that will be refined with time. The space is sort of recycled concrete/wood arty/industrial - it's OK but not going to wow anyone on design points. Service was solid, especially for their third night. Full bar - nice to have in the now fully "emerging" area. I'll be back.
author: Bowen D.

description:
Wonderfully simple, uncomplicated wine list with lots of good local selections.  

Starters were oysters with lemon, mignonette and fresh grated horseradish (love the little touches!), a meat board (sounds substantial -- maybe for 2, but not for 6) with yummy, if not artery clogging selections.  Very good in-house bread!

For entrees, two of us had the wild king salmon, very well presented with crispy skin and a melange of seasonal veg underneath.

Service for a party of 6 (seated in small alcove off side of bar -- very intimate) was perfect.
author: Don N.

description: Okay hipster breakfast food.  Nothing extraordinary.  They have something called "Red Flannel Hash" that I did not eat, but I could not decide if I loved the name or hated it.  I am sort of partial to more classic brunch places and would always prefer something to have larger, cheaper portions.  I don't think bunch ingredients are expensive (eggs, flour, sugar, toast) so the prices should reflect that.  I would rec Just for You right around the corner over this place any day. Seriously.  No need to overpay for brunch.  At least not when I'm around...
author: Julia D.

description:
I went there twice in a one week period and the first time, everything WAS SPOT ON. Service was great, food all amazing and the wine pairing was gorgeous. 2nd time around...not as hot, the fritters were a bit salty, the clams in the Fish dish were a bit undercooked, but I understand they are still new, so they figuiring things out. But the staff always did what they could to overcome the shortcomings when possible. 

Overall, a great place with easy parking
author: Joseph C.

description:
I've worked in this neighborhood for five plus years and was excited about this new place opening. Especially because I've gone to their other restaurant, The Slow Club numerous times over the years, and it has always been great!  
But the staff at Serpentine needs some help!

We got in for lunch about 2:40PM, they stop serving at 3PM. 
There were two tables of people already sitting and eating. We were seated immediately. And given menus and water. So far so good. 
It seemed that there were at least four people on the floor and whoever else was in the kitchen. So why did it take ten minuets to order and then 20 min to get our food?? We also order cocktails when our food arrived and those didn't come until well after we were finished eating. 

I think our total sit down time was an hour and fifteen minuets. If a restaurant says they serve till a certain time they need to be prepared to serve up to the last minuet, or change their times! 
What's going on with this place? I know we came in towards the end of the luck time, but we were the only table!!!

To top it all off our bill was $68.35. It was paid with a $100 bill. The change should of been 31.65.  $21.00 was brought back to our table.
Was that a self tipping custom that I not aware of?  After trying to get the waiters attention, we pointed out that the change was wrong. He said it would be fixed. This time he brought back $31.00. Still .65 cents short. which wouldn't of been a big deal if we weren't shorted the first time! Again we tried to get the waiter's attention, this time with major attitude he asked what was wrong. We told him It was still short. He then counted the cash in front of us at our table, and said, "oh a dollar". (65cents) He then tossed a dollar from his apron on the table with the rest of the money, and walked away. And that's exactly what he got a dollar! 

I don't know about the rest of you out there feel about this. But if a business is going to round change out, it should be in customers favor! It's my money and I have a right to it! No matter what the amount!

BTW-my $13 burger that I asked for medium-well, was so rare the bun was bloody. yuk!
author: O. S.

description:
Tried the cocktails and burger. I am a fan!

I give it 3 stars because, the seating is a bit tight and was hard to have a conversation without the table next to you chiming in.
author: Insi L.

description:
If you've been looking for a place to have one of those "talks"...

(You know the ones.  They usually start with something like "we need to talk" or "I've been meaning to discuss something with you" or "I was hoping you could help me with this problem I have" or "my parents are coming into town"...  Yeah, thooooose.)

... then you need to know about Serpentine.  

I will vouch for the puree of carrot soup with crispy leeks.  I will vouch for the roasted chicken with smashed potatoes.  And I will vouch for the lemonade.  My friend vouches for the pork sammich they serve at lunch.  But mostly, I vouch for the cozy seating, the high ceilings, the neutral decor and the quiet, efficient service surrounding the good food that allows one to have the "I've been doing a lot of thinking and" talk.   Serpentine is the martini mixer where food, booze and difficult conversations get shaken. 

Oh, totally P.S. -- the bathroom is unisex.   FYI, in case any of you laydeez have issues with having to drop the seat manually before doing your bidness.
author: Caroline E.

description: was taken here by a Serpentine addict, and I can see how he developed his habit. So yummy, great service and gorgeous presentation without any of the pretension one often sees with food at this level.
author: Maggie T.

description: Went here for lunch with a Brit friend. We tried the savory bread pudding based on reviews here. It was good, but not great. Can't understand what the hoopla is about. Still a beautiful place with modern furnishings, high ceilings and nice lighting. Other menu items seemed to reflect incredible care for food quality. The service was prompt and courteous, the wait was minimal, but I got there early and had reservations. The prices are also quite reasonable. My search for key lunch places in this area continues.
author: 和子

description:
I really wanted to like this place since I enjoy their sister restaurant Slow Club. Here's the down low:

Space: Very nice. I loved the setup. Sitting at the bar is not recommended until after 7pm since you will get FRIED by the sun coming in. Its just blinding!

Service: Good. Nothing to write home about but nothing to complain about either.

Food: Sorry, its just not up to par. I had the beet leaf salad and it looked MUCH better than it tasted. I then had the pork chop which was WAY too fatty and WAY too "citrusy". Almost kind of bitter. My friends had burgers and all were way overcooked; medium rare was well done... how weak is that?

Location: Sucks. You're stranded after dinner. Much like Slow Club.

Sorry Serpentine. I wanted to like you.
author: Simon S.

description:
Although it was a cute restaurant with nice ambiance, I didn't think the food in general was all too great. Maybe it was just what we ordered? However, the servers were very nice! 

We ordered the swordfish with carrot risotto, roasted chicken and a side of brussels sprouts. The swordfish was probably the best dish in my opinion. I enjoyed the carrot risotto which was different from the typical seafood risotto most places serve. 

My friend ordered the chicken. I told him I typically don't order chicken and salmon at most restaurants because they tend to overcook it. I'm all about the perfect temperature, especially for my seafood. Lo and behold, the chicken was a bit overcooked. I only did have a bite though. 

As for the brussels sprouts, I thought it was good but a little salty and some pieces over-fried. The pieces of brussels sprouts were also separated so it didn't taste like vegetables. 

But still definitely would go back to try something different. Their bread pudding sounds great and their burgers looked DELICIOUS!
author: Jessica T.

description: Solid brunch spot. I had the baked eggs which were cooked perfectly. The mimosas had freshly squeezed OJ that was delicious. The interior space is really cool / loft like which I enjoyed. It doesn't hurt that next door is Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous ice-cream shop - perfect way to end a great meal at Serpentine.
author: Brooke S.

description: Very, very noisy place. Ratio of food quality to money is negative. Service not very attentive (how could the waiter hear you given the horrendous noise?...). Nice decor. Interesting if you want to watch the variety of San Franciscans.
author: Ayala K.

description:
Amazing food! Just ate here again!!

I will be there again on Thursday, April 30th as the host for Dining Out for Life. Make your reservations for that night on http://www.opentable.com/rest_profile.aspx?rid=21049. 

Yum, even their burgers and drinks are tasty!!
author: Art A.

description:
If I could, I think I'd give this place 3.5 stars, but since I can't give halves, I'll round up since the staff were so friendly and good, and I generally had a good experience. 

The space was nice, but a bit hard to see once the sun went down. It was so dark we felt we were sitting outside on someone's deck, without lights. Which can be nice when you're on someone's deck in the dark without lights, but in a restaurant, personally, I prefer to be able to see my food when enjoying it. 

The menu was, um, a bit different. Different good or different bad, you ask? Well, we weren't quite sure, at first. All of us found ourselves flipping to the 2nd page to see what further food options there were (but it was just the drinks list). So at first, we were a bit skeptical. But when the food arrived, we were all very happy with the flavors and our selections. 

The savory (veggy, FYI) bread pudding is a must try simply because of its uniqueness. Had never seen that on a menu before, and it was quite good. I had the pork chop with grits and an interesting mango/tomato type of sauce. Could have been more tender, for sure. But again, the grits and mango/tomato sauce that came with were very nice. Another had the Cod, which was quite good. And another had the Bouillabaisse, which I didn't try, but heard was tasty.
author: beth l.

description: I had brunch here last weekend and I'll definitely be back. The decor is lovely and the food is amazing - I had the breakfast sandwich and my partner had the eggs benedict and we both loved our food. Plus, we only waited about 5 minutes for a table on a Sunday!
author: emalie h.

description:
Serpentine (and sister restaurant Slow Club) are our favorite restaurants in San Francisco! Great fresh, natural food. Menu changes daily. Never been disappointed. 

Both locations have easy parking (yeah!) and a relaxing and welcoming atmosphere. We like the fact that Serpentine takes reservations. Wait staff is friendly and helpful. Well paired wine list and good selection by the glass. Bartenders make delicious mixed drinks- especially martinis and gimlets. Specially drinks worth trying too. 

Go, go, go. You won't regret it.
author: Janet P.

description:
Serpentine doesn't look like a restaurant from the outside, but it is great!

It's located on the corner of 3rd and 22nd in Dogpatch (Potrero Hill).  They have a full bar -tons of liquor just waiting to be had.  You can sit at the bar, or you can sit at the tables.  

There isn't a ton of seating, but it's worth waiting for if there is a line.

I have gone one time for lunch and had a salad that was fabulous.  I have also gone for brunch on a Saturday morning, and the waiter had to keep coming back because I couldn't decide what I wanted.  Everything sounded delicious.   I ended up getting these eggs in a bowl with vegetables - GET IT if you are there for brunch.

I haven't gone to dinner there, but I'm sure it's great.  It's a little pricy but worth every penny.  Free street parking right outside!
author: Ana M.

description: Loved the Chickpea Battered Calamari to start. Got the burger which was perfect blend of freshness from the veggies, tart from the acidic onions and hearty burger flavor (medium rare if course). It was big enough to split so next time I'll try another appetizer and just do half a burger with someone else in my party.
author: Kendall A.

description: Great alternative when Piccino is fully booked.  So far I've tried halibut, burger, and steak which were delish. Their fries with aioli is irresistible.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I went to Serpentine with a few friends the other night and this is what we tried:

The Meat Board (great selection of cured meats and pate)
Chickpea Battered Calamari
Shaved Asparagus Salad
Grilled Hanger Steak (wonderful!)
Panseared Alaskan True Cod
Hamburgers
Meyer Lemon Pudding Cake (the BOMB)
Chocolate Cake

Everything tasted delicious. Wow. I haven't said that in a long time. Usually there's something to pick on and bitch about, but this meal was great. The side pairings for the main courses were just right and the flavors all went very well together. Portions are perfect. Presented elegantly.

A+ on Atmosphere. Raw brick, exposed pipes from the ceiling, a mix of industrial with modern. Very hip and sheik.

Service was good but I had one small issue with the fact that our server kneeled down when talking with us. I don't like when servers kneel down so their head is at table level, trying to talk to us on a more comfortable level - it's just unprofessional in my opinion, plus who knows what kind of germs are being breathed into our water glasses?

Besides that, Serpentine is a beautiful restaurant that has a solid and delicious menu.
author: Foodie F.

description:
Rock On!  (3.5+ rounding to 4)

Through rose tinted glasses -- literally, as we had a bottle of crisp French rose from the Rhone on a sizzling hot evening, and figuratively, as I am not sure whether I was more enamored with the place or the guy I was with -- I had a pleasant first experience at Serpentine.  Great ambiance; good food; nice wine list.; super service  Dinner for two with wine around $90.  Go back?  Sure.  

Place.  Small and dramatic; soaring raw concrete walls and ceilings; great industrial light fixtures and ceiling fans.  Metal topped dining tables a bit too small and crowded, but nice for being close to your dinner mate and friendly fellow diners; the bar tables actually looked to be the most comfortable; but avoid the table situated between the restrooms which simply jutted out into the open space.  Tealights added a charming romantic glow, perfect for lingering and chatting.

Food/Wine.  Interesting items; we shared various small plates.  Highlights included: the baby red mustard green salad in which the fresh mint punched up the spicy/bitter greens while the goat cheese and buttermilk dressing soothed things down; and the savory bread pudding that came looking like a piece of coffee cake but the dense, creamy concoction was tasty and filling.  Just OK were: the Monterrey sardine which was one fried fish (with head) without much character but the accompanying olives and roasted artichoke were delicious; and the generous portion of lamb riblets which were tender but smothered by a brown sauce that was a tad too salty.  Didn't get to dessert this first time (ducked across the street to Yield for apres dinner wine and chocolates instead).  Nice wine list, reasonably priced; decent stemware.

Service.  Really good -- now, that's a rarity in the City!  On one of the warmest SF nights ever on record, our waitress was super nice and not a bit grouchy (as I surely would have been), knowledgeable about the menu, efficient and got our small plates in a good order and flow, and refilled our iced water glasses a zillion times.  

P.S. Serpentine is the State Rock of California -- did you know we had a state rock?
author: Yan L.

description:
3.5 Stars from me. First of all, this whole neighborhood is way cool. I loved the urban-industrial decor. The husband and I met for lunch and were seated immediately by a friendly tattooed server. 

Here's how things went down: We ordered soup, salad and the pulled pork sandwich to share. We asked for mustard on the side since I hate mustard. 

The soup and salad were both plenty good but nothing to write home about. The sandwich arrived slathered in mustard. I did not know this so I took a big honking bite and then gagged. I could tell the sandwich was delicious but I hate mustard. We sent it back and asked again for mustard on the side....the sandwich returned. This time it was on fresh bread but they had used the same pulled pork as before and when I opened the sandwich it was streaked with mustard. I took a deep breath and tried to deal. My husband ate his half and sent mine back. He reported that it was, in fact, a delicious sandwich. I was still mighty hungry. 

Our server returned and broke the news that they were out of the bread that the sandwich came on and could they bring me something else? I was brain dead and cranky so I asked for french fries. What the hell? They brought me french fries (like Mc Donald's, but better) as well as a complimentary fresh baked chocolate chip cookie the size of my head. After I scarfed down all the salt, sugar and butter in Texas I was happy again. Our entire bill came to $8 and they were very gracious and apologetic about the "mustard incident." 

Since I liked the atmosphere and the service a lot I would definitely give it another shot. That cookie really saved the day.
author: Shira G.

description:
Hostess with the mostest...  the mostest attitude!

The food was exceptional.  I love how Serpentine recreates comfort food classics like porkchops, upside down cakes and cheesecakes and gives them a fresh twist.  I enjoyed my porkchop tremendously.  It was paired with nectarines instead of the more traditional apples.  The upside down cake with peaches and the goat cheese cake were divine.  The dining room was lovely.  The high ceilings, concrete walls and artwork give it a delightful urban look.

However, the hostess' unwelcoming demeanor proved to be a huge disappointment.  We arrived on time for a dinner reservation and had to wait for a full thirty minutes before we got seated.  It could have been longer but her obnoxious attitude was absolutely frustrating.
author: Jun B.

description:
So i went here with 2 friends for brunch yesterday. I had never been but my friend had been multiple times and raved about it, plus the yelp reviews were great. So i was actually very excited to go....but left very disappointed.

Our friend called ahead and told the restaurant he wold be late (about 10 minutes..no big deal) So my husband and I went ahead and were sat. They brought us water, but then the waitress would just look at us and pass by without talking to us. After about 10 minutes, i stopped her and asked if she was out waiter..she said yes. So i finally asked for some coffee and juice while we waited.

Based off reviews from here, the kitchen must have just been having an off morning. My friend who had been before couldnt believe how different an experience it was. He had the crab Benedict which came out cold and he said it didnt taste that fantastic. I just had the plain eggs, bread meat plate. I maybe ate a 1/3 of it at most. My scrambled eggs werent cooked all the way and were still wet and mushy, the sausage had no flavor. The home potatoes were very good though. My husband had the friend egg sandwich, ate little over half and also said his sausage had no flavor.

I just thought it was weird that our waitress didnt ask about our meal once. If i went to pick up plates from a table and every plate still had half its food on it, I would ask if something was wrong. I am glad that everyone previously had a good experience, but I wont be traveling back over to the dogpatch for this
author: laury g.

description:
Decor and space is fantastic.  Clean, comfy, modern (think natural steel and light, rift cut oak, not polished chrome and black leather) interior in a great warehouse space with great furniture classics, Thonet chairs and classic schoolhouse metal barstools.  We were here for brunch, as it's close to our brunch favorite, Just for You cafe, which had a super-long wait that day.  I had buckwheat pancakes with strawberry, and biscuits and gravy, which were both pretty good.  It does have potential to be good for kids for brunch as they have space and the tables aren't completely jammed together but they only have one high chair.  If you have a booster seat or a clip on one, bring it (Although with the clip on, sit at the bar-the tables are pedestal-type so not safe to attach the chair to the table).  
Definitely make reservations.  We often like to wing it but haven't been able to get in without reservations since shortly after it first opened.
author: katie b.

description:
I ate at Serpentine for the first time last weekend and the food was great.  Baked chicken, summer squash succotash and an amazing, warm peach-blackberry upside down cake with vanilla ice cream for dessert.

Unfortunately, it only gets three stars.  We showed up on time for our reservation and waited almost 40 minutes for our table.  Kristin, the hostess, acted amazed that we expected to get our table on time (uh, it's called a "reservation", lady).  

Our server was great and tried to get things back on track by saying "Kristin is really sorry for the wait and she's sending an egg plant over."  That was great, exactly right.  Why didn't Kristin tell us when we were waiting "hey guys, I'm so sorry for your wait; I'll make sure you have an appetizer on us."  Apparently Kristin can't be bothered with the little people (read: paying customers).
author: Nathan Y.

description: Went for brunch with my girlfriends on a lazy Sunday. We got lucky with a free table. We all had their crab benedict, one of my friends substituted crab for sausage. The food was creative, but a bit bland, lacked pizzazz that reigned in the decor. Will try to wait to get into "Plow" next time. May come back for dinner here, but can be persuaded otherwise.
author: Anastasiya G.

description: Great space, great service, and great food.   We loved brunch here until everyone else discovered it and now we need a reservation.  :(    Seriously - great coffee and the best brunch.  Love that breakfast sandwich thing!  Dinner is just as good, and I especially like sitting at the bar.  Bar tender is friendly and attentive and not in your face with the drinks and commentary.
author: Dyan F.

description: This place is awesome.  Great food, cool atmosphere.  It has a very hospitable feeling, I just want to stay there all night and hang out.
author: Alex F.

description:
I've been to Serpentine twice in the last few months, once for dinner and today for lunch.  I'm "averaging" my two ratings into one for a 3. 

Lunch today = 2.  My rating is largely based on the poor experience we had with our waiter, Victor.  Such attitude!  I have some dietary constraints so was asking if certain dishes were made with dairy and my questions were met with such impatience and near disdain.  That already soured the dining experience, but later when I found a hair in my salad and pointed it out to Victor, instead of an apology (there was never an apology) his response was a blunt "so you want a new salad?" and then as he was walking away a frustrated shaking of his head and I imagine (since his back was to us) a rolling of the eyes to go with it.  As a whole, his demeanor was unpleasant, unfriendly, and certainly not about serving the customer.  

Dinner in December = 5.  In this case, when I was asking the waiter (unfortunately I don't remember his name) which dishes could be made to accommodate my dietary constraints, he not only pointed out items on the menu but pro-actively asked if I wanted the chef to make me a dish of roasted vegetables instead.  I went with the latter and I swear it was one of the tastiest dishes ever and certainly worthy of being added as a "real" menu item.  

All to say - the staff of a restaurant sure can make or break an experience.
author: Q E.

description:
Solid brunch spot in the Dogpatch.  Never been there for dinner.

For brunch, get there before 12 or make reservations. 

Lovely space - high ceilings with an industrial interior feel.  Reminds me of something I would find in Brooklyn. 

The brunch food is good as well.  Reasonable portions and interesting takes on pretty classic dishes like benedicts and eggs & hash.
author: n s.

description: Best burger I've ever had.  Craveable.  If you mention their burger to me I will obsess over it for a week.  Perfect paired with one of their unique cocktails or craft beers.  Great spot for brunch as well.
author: Suzy K.

description:
-Easy Parking
-No Wait
-AMAZING SERVICE
-Fancy gin cocktail off their menu was DELICIOUS
-Kick Ass Bread Pudding (Savory kind)
-Fish Stew To Die For
-Half Roast Chicken good but no Zuni
-Ambiance was just right although lots of two tops on top of one another

Worth the trip, great neighborhood spot, I would recommend sitting at the bar and enjoying the appetizers with a great drink or bottle of wine.
author: Scott P.

description:
I've been to Serpentine a handful of times for lunch or drinks after work and it's such a great addition to the neighborhood. It's a cute space and has a great bar with a tasty cocktail list. 

I've tried a lot of different menu items over the last year and everything is always tasty. Sometimes I wish there were a more few options on the menu, but the simplicity is refreshing at the same time. The big standouts for me are the savory bread pudding and the burger. The bread pudding has morphed from an eggier richer version from a year ago to a looser, breadier version served in a baking dish. All iterations have been delicious, and luckily, the high butter content remains consistent! What I love about the burger is that when you ask for medium rare, you always get a perfectly cooked, juicy burger with just enough toppings to make it interesting, but not overwhelm. I also love the blue cheese they are using at the moment - it's a thick slice of creamy blue instead of a mountain of blue cheese crumbles that always overpower. 

Looking forward to my next meal!
author: Crissy G.

description:
I am so excited to have this place in our neighborhood. I am a huge fan of Slow Club and I have high hopes that we'll see the same quality of food, drinks and atmosphere here. The space is nicely designed, with a long bar and a few bar tables which is nice for a casual gathering. 

Our manhattans were well prepared and we had some very tasty fried oysters and hush puppies. We were excited to see Marin Sun Farms steak on the menu, it was on the smaller side but still good.

I look forward to coming back to try the unique cocktails and more of the food.
author: Kai H.

description:
Sunday brunch down in Dogpatch. Serpentine has a cool industrial feel to it and looks very American. 

Started with a decent enough Bloody Mary at the bar while we waited for a both. Had a turkey and cranberry sandwich (I'm a sucker for these) with some greens. It was good, but not tremendously amazing, but the service was nice and I really liked the calmness I felt in there. 

Also, I ate a cocktail onion for $3. I'm not proud, but I will always remember Serpentine for that.
author: Cory G.

description:
Lunch could have been so much better. Arriving at 12:45 we were seated immediately. LG was really hungry after a morning workout and no breakfast. We order drinks and lunch. Table after table seated after us were getting their orders. Twenty-five...thirty...thirty-five minutes...whats up? Mistake in the kitchen. LG was ready to get all kung-fu when lunch finally arrived. Her lunch was on the house...a nice gesture but too little. If the waiter had kept us informed we would have been more forgiving. The meal itself was good...not great but good. See my previous review for more detail on the restaurant and food.

Rounding up to 3 stars.
author: Gary C.

description:
Serpentine. 

Named for the ROCK that comprises most of Potrero Hill - and I suppose that the restaurant stands on - NOT a snake reference.  Thankfully.

The place has major potential.  Just needs a little seasoning.  As in it stills has that new restaurant feel.  Once it gets some weathering, it should be smokin.   

The food was/is excellent, although I think they have some fine tuning to do.  We had the bread pudding which is fantastic.  Not sure it will work in the summer months as it conjures up Thanksgiving.   The cod was good, but the chowderish sauce a little odd.  Little small portion too, but over all nothing bad here folks.  Solid 4 stars, and the staff rocks.  If you love Slow Club, you'll like this place too.
author: sutton t.

description:
Serpentine is situated in an old warehouse, & it still feels a bit warehouse-y. There's something about the cold starkness of former industrial spaces that I really enjoy (maybe in a past life I lived in the Eastern Bloc or something?), & I really dug the high ceilings & poured concrete floors.

Since we were a party of four who arrived sans reservation, we bellied up to the bar for a few cocktails. I really enjoyed the Whiskey Smash, although it was a little bit too sweet & left me feeling pretty hyper. I sipped on some Old Potrero next, & then it was dinner time. Since the bar tab was very much on the expensive side, I opted to go with the burger for dinner, which was superb. I cleaned my plate, fries & all.

In summation, I loved the space, the food was fantastic, service attentive, but drinks were on the expensive side.

I'd definitely go back if another situation called for it.
author: Pete J.

description:
I'd driven past this place plenty of times and never realized it was a restaurant.  

It's completely nondescript from the outside, but inside hides a very cool restaurant and bar, tastefully and contemporary decorated, inventive and tasty menu, and excellent service.

Can't believe I hadn't heard more about this place, but it's certainly on my radar for a return trip.

It's not a cheap place, you can easily drop $100 for two people with wine, but it is very appropriately priced for this quality of dining.
author: Doug M.

description:
My wife and I dined here for Valentines Day.  I chose this place because its in a somewhat isolated part of town, so I knew there would be little traffic going there and a lot of street parking.  

I ordered the steak and my wife the gnocchi, we did not order an appetizer.  The steak was delicious and very tender.  I did not care for the mustard greens, they were too bitter for my taste.  Maybe they were cooked beautifully, but I just did not like them.  One of the things that bothers me about places like Serpentine is how skimpy they are with the wine servings .  The serving was not even half a glass. If the glass is about ten bucks, I expect a little more.  

i ordered the mascarpone cheesecake with candied kumquats and meyer lemon curd for dessert, and I was disappointed.  There was one small kumquat peel and a maybe a tablespoon of the lemon curd.  Without more of these two essential elements, there was nothing special about the cheesecake.
author: Jaime T.

description:
steak and eggs were good as was the pale ale and bloody mary. 

service could have been improved. 

decor was very nice and hipster-esque. 

would come back for brunch.
author: Bobby B.

description: Go for the steak and the chicken.  Great Apertif cocktail choices also.
author: Dom P.

description: Used to love this place but both the food and drink aren't consistent.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Finally, the Dogpatch is stepping up its foodie game!  I hopped over to Serpentine this weekend (courtesy of their new reservation line) and had a great dinner.

Crispy Hama Hama Oysters: The oysters were fresh and tender, as their Washington pedigree would suggest, accompanied by a decent litter of hush puppies.  Definitely recommended.

Pork Rillettes: I was expecting a bit more flavor out of the rillettes, having to cover for its extra-mild presence with the accompanying mustard.  The texture was nice, and would have made nice pyramids to hold a pig's tail like how the old Frenchie's used to do, but ultimately needed a bit more salting.  Recommended if you're one of those people that likes unsalted over salted peanut butter.

Savory Bread Pudding: Awesome.  Bread pudding with some body to it.  I'm usually not much of a fan of bread pudding, but the nettles pesto (where'd they pull that one out of?) made me reach for more.  Definitely recommended.  Although, +$4 for mixed greens to go with...really?  

Braised Prather Ranch Beef Cheeks: Really solid all around.  Braised to perfection, and well buffered by the leek and potato puree, it was the perfect course for a colder night.

Almond Blancmange: A close cousin of panna cotta, this dessert left me a bit wanting.  It was just a chalky taste from start to finish, and the sprinkle of blood oranges wasn't sweet enough to keep it together.

Overall, it's a gem.  I'll be headed over there for lunch sometime soon.
author: John H.

description: Great space. High ceilings and nice vibe. Small bar but we sat at the bar. The cocktails were yummy, great recipes and the bartenders have professional technique. Came here for the burger and it was pretty good, definitely in the top 10 in SF. Really juicy and flavorful Prather ranch burger, swiss cheese, homemade pickles. I was impressed and would definitely recommend the burger here.
author: Cori B.

description: Wow, what a find!!  That's what I'm thinking after a friend recommended we come here after happy hour to get some food.  The place is definitely small but we waited by the bar to get our food there.  They offer some really good beers on the menu though they are pricier for 12oz pours ($6-7).  As for food, we both ordered the burgers done medium and they were DELICIOUS!!  The burger was pink in the middle and juicy...kind of like other things I like but we won't talk about that.  The fries were also really good and helped cap off all the beers I had during happy hour.  The burger was $14 but well worth it.  I would definitely come back as this place is a great find in a less crowded neighborhood of SF.
author: Paul C.

description: They said they have one of the seven best hamburgers in SF, so i believed them.... and they're right!  YUMMM!!!!!   Also try the marinated olives for an appetizer.  The potato gnocchi were so so, but we also shared the hanger steak which was good - and best of all: the swordfish.  Really tender and not at all dry.  I'd go back.
author: Mindo P.

description:
Love the industrial warehouse look. This restaurant is not noticeable if you were driving down 3rd ave. It's across the street from Yield Wine Bar. 

We had:

Baby Arugula & Mizuna Salad
blood oranges - roasted beets - watermelon radishes -
levain croutons - sherry vinaigrette 

Roasted Duck Breast
nero venere black rice - glazed baby carrots & turnips
shaved fennel & mizuna salad - brooks cherry
reduction 

(Loved this dish and all the sides!)

Pan Seared Blue Nose Bass
yukon gold potato gnocchi - fava beans - pea shoots -
charred spring onion relish - toasted almonds 

Lavender Creme Friache Panna Cotta. Yum!


Beware of Waitress service because it is a hit or miss. It was a "Plop the food down" type of service.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
aw that sh*t was good! lamb belly? really? yum!

our server tommy rocked! knowledgeable, great table-side manner, solid cocktail recommendations.

love the repurposed space as well. nice job team!
author: Clover Dan ..

description: Very high open ceiling with exposed brick interior, really nice people working there, full bar and tastey cocktails, local high quality food, five-star burgers, great brunch and across the street from Mr. & Mrs. Misc. so you can't go wrong with Serpentine.
author: Mel H.

description:
Three of us had a wonderful dinner at Serpentine. To start we recommend the savory bread pudding. It was amazingly delicious. I personally could eat two of these on my own and call it a night.  The buffalo short ribs were fantastic-very flavorful. The pan roasted liberty duck breast was also fabulous-the leek and potato puree was yummy; I wish there had been more of it on the plate. The flat iron steak gets two thumbs up.  

We waited at 30-35 minutes for a table. We sat at the bar table and not in the main dining area. Next time we would probably not sit there. On a cold night with the door opening and closing it gets a bit drafty. 

The service was attentive and very friendly. 

Our only suggestion at this time is to start taking reservations.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
I really, really wanted to like this place. But the food is underwhelming. Maybe the chef was having an off night - maybe they're still finding their stride. 

My pork dish was chewy and tough; it came with a remoulade that had the consistency of cottage cheese (except cottage cheese is tastier). The sauce/broth was watery and tasteless. The only redeeming quality of the dish was the cabbage - and I don't even like cabbage. My companion's chicken was overly seasoned and salty. 

I would come back for a cocktail and maybe small plates but not for a full meal. I agree that the vibe was nice - the people seemed nice too.
author: Maya F.

description:
Edit: OK I changed my mind. 4 stars.

I usually don't enjoy restaurants that price their food significantly higher than what the residents of the neighborhood said restaurant is in can afford. However, 3rd Street has been transforming a lot lately, so I'm a bit torn on whether I should hate this place right away or not.

This place is loud, and there's a level of pretentiousness that I generally loathe, and if it weren't for the company I was in, I probably would be adding this to my list of places to destroy when the Revolution comes. Our group of 5 had a reservation, but we weren't seated for what seemed like forever. Calculate how long it takes to drink a bottle of wine while engaging in conversation. That's how long the wait was.

Looking at the menu, I was saddened at the prices. $11.50 for a hamburger. Good lord that's a lotta money. It is a reasonable price for an entree, but the idea of paying $12 for a burger and fries just seemed off to me. The service was great and accommodating though, checking to see what the chef could concoct for our Vegan friend (note to vegans: ask them what they can make for you, as there is nothing on the menu that is strictly vegan).

All of our food was delicious, and I'm very torn on giving this place only 3 stars. In the end, the 5 of paid $40/person, which was alright by me.  I really wish Yelp allowed half star reviews, because this place definitely deserves higher than 3 stars. I may come back and change it to 4 stars later, so if my review says 4 stars and you're reading this, ignore this paragraph.
author: Alexis C.

description:
I finally had the chance to eat here and loved it. Four stars for the decor, our waiter's demeanor, the food, and clean bathroom. Minus one star for the indifferent bartenders and hostess, which I'll mention in a bit. 

Easy to make a reservation via phone, arrived on time and were told by the hostess our table would be ready in about ten minutes and we were welcome to wait at the bar. No problem. At the bar, I ordered an absinthe, of which there were two on the menu, but I wasn't asked which I would prefer, so was given the $14 version, which was better I was told by the waiter later during my meal. Usually, the bartender is supposed to prepare the absinthe for you, but in this case, I was given all the necessary items and left to my own devices. Minus one half a star. 

The hostess passed by after ten minutes and we stopped to ask her if our table was ready. She said it was but she'd bring us menus if we wanted to eat at the bar. I got the sense she was annoyed by our inquiries, but oh well. I was annoyed by the other bartender telling us we needed to pay for our drinks at the bar, rather than being able to put them on our tab and take them to our table. For such a classy place, you shouldn't have to be told what to do. Minus another half star. 

Our waiter was superb, funny and informative, with excellent knowledge of the menu and suggestion for wine pairings. The lamb riblettes were amazing, as was the chicken with trumpet mushrooms, black rice, and carrots. A starter salad with cranberries and goat cheese was also delicious. Another amazing starter were the fried oysters with fried asparagus with a side of aioli. No dessert, but was really full from everything else.
author: David G.

description: Came for a late dinner recently.  The food is fine- nothing to write home about- but tasty and nicely prepared.  Won't be back due to the service.  Because of a lack of open tables, the hostess agreed reluctantly to let us begin with an appetizer at the bar and then move to a table.  Never saw her again, despite tables opening up.  Want to take home your leftovers? They give you a box and you scrape your plate yourself while sitting at the bar next to the other customers-- makes for an elegant dining experience. yuck!
author: pam m.

description:
I've been here twice for lunch and both times were excellent. 

The service is great! I love the red headed waitress, she is super smiley and on it! 

They have a bread pudding which changes weekly and it is super yummy. I had the butternut squash version and it was a little crunchy on top, and soft on the inside. mmmmm purrrrfect. I'm not normally a fan of bread pudding either. 

Also tried their tuna sandwich which was not slathered in mayo as tuna can often be. They have great burgers too, the organic beef is from Prather Ranch. 

I like the ambiance of the restaurant, it has a brick warehouse, barebones feel and it fits well with the neighborhood. 

Also, their coffee is super tasty, and they have these cookies baked daily that are seriously, the size of your head. Oh, choco chip how I love you!
author: Ingrid K.

description: I've been meaning to try Serpentine forever, so when they popped up on Blackboardeats and a friend was in town, we gathered a group and made our way there. Turned out everyone had been there before except for me, and they all loved the place. I can see why. There wasn't one thing I tasted that I didn't love. The burger was incredible, the fresh fish was packed with flavor but still healthy, the apps were creative (loved the chicken liver salad) and spanned sinful to guiltless snacking (great pickled veggies).... a nice combination that ensures everyone's happy. Good service and a nice atmosphere rounded out the quality food, and easy parking is a major perk! I can't wait to go back and try more. They were also very accommodating of our large group, which I really appreciate.
author: Shoshana D.

description: Last night my bf and I walked in at about 8ish and sat at the bar. Come to think of it I I always sit at the bar at Serpentine.  Its my fourth visit here and have never been disappointed. There's always something interesting on the menu from the soups to the entrees.  We were promptly served our first course (kudos says the Frenchie). For a Wednesday night they were quite busy. Our bartender-server did the best she could considering.  While the prices may seem expensive we both ordered drinks, appetizers, entrees and dessert for under $100. For San Francisco that's quite a bargain!
author: Olivia R.

description:
This place was fantastic. We arrived and were seated right away in a cozy yet comfortable part of the dining room.  The menu is mostly small plates, with the exception of a few larger items, but my girlfriend and I decided to just spilt a bunch of small plates which worked out perfectly.  We ended up getting 6 small plates which was just enough food (I eat way too much) so normal sized people can probably get away with ordering slightly less.  Everything was fresh and tasted great.  The drink list was unique and I thought the whiskey mash was outstanding.  Our waiter didn't try to upsell anything and was knowledgeable and prompt.  

Great dinner, great value. With a few drinks and all that food our bill was well under $80 which isn't bad at all.  Check this place out.
author: Eli Z.

description: The service was poor (unfriendly and slow) and our food wasn't properly cooked (burger was over cooked)
author: Joshua R.

description:
I can't comment on Serpentine as a dinner destination, but I think they serve a pretty damn good lunch. Tasty, high-quality food that doesn't break the bank (it ain't cheap, but it isn't super expensive either). Friendly service too. Nicely done.

The "bathroom right there in the middle of the room" thing is a little odd, but hey - small complaint.
author: Bob M.

description:
I really want to like this place and I'm trying.  But each time I've eaten here something has been a little off.

I had an early dinner here with a friend last week.  We each ordered a glass of red wine.  The wine we got was warm.  Not room temperature warm.  But warm warm.  Warmer than wine should be served.  We called over the waiter and told him that we felt the wine was too warm.  He said that those bottles were probably sitting in the sunlight streaming into the place and that he would replace it from wine from new bottles.

The place has a long row of windows that face west.  It had been a warm sunny day and was quite warm in the restaurant.  The waiter did not seem the least bit surprised about how warm our wine was.  It was like he had heard it before.  So, why don't they do something about.  Or get some damn air conditioning!

The waiter was very accommodating about the wine and provided us with great service over all.  

The reason for the upgrade despite the warm wine was his service and how good the food was.  

We shared a beet salad which was really tasty and came with delicious slices of pancetta.  My friend also tremendously enjoyed their olive plate.  We each ordered a burger.  And, I have to say that it was the best burger that I've had in a really long time.  It was perfectly cooked and was just tasty quality meat.  

We both really liked the food and I intend to come back.  But, please!  No more warm wine!!
author: Jeff P.

description:
Unlike others, we were seated right after we walked in. The place is loud--even early in the evening (645p). Everything I ordered came late. My appetizer was about 10 min later than everyone else's (they comp'd it) and my entree came about a minute after the others. Plate was hot--been kept warm?

I had the anchovy appetizer with breadcrumbs. Fish were good, but plate was a mess. And thinking back on it, I'm not certain they were even anchovies. They were honking big, and mild. More like sardines. 

For the entree I had steak--and somehow the description of the meal on the menu didn't quite get across to me. Surprisingly spicy sauce, but that's a good thing for me. Didn't grok that it was going to be sliced. I had a solid steak pictured. Medium rare? More toward medium, but not dry.

Finally, the person assisting the waitress was really out of sync with the meal. Brought my entree, but had taken my fork without replacing it. And as I mentioned, both parts of the meal came late.

We passed on dessert for coffee at our friends' house.

Had 2 good belgian beers.


Here are some disclaimers:

As you'll come to find out, I'm a demanding patron. Also, I was freaking hungry. I had had very little for lunch and had done a pretty significant work out that morning. People were nice. Place has interesting appearance. I came expecting attitude from hostess and got none. I don't like places that are too loud. I could converse with people immediately next to me, but couldn't hear people two seats away very well.
author: Thomas R.

description: I went here for brunch. We passed the crazy line out front of Just For You and we headed straight for Serpentine. We waited about 10 minutes and then got two seats at the bar- not bad for prime time Sunday brunch. I had the Dungeness Crab Benedict and it rocked. The fried lemon slices that top the benedict were fabulous. They were salty sweet bites that paired perfectly with the crab. Who ever thought of frying lemon is genius!
author: Katie C.

description:
Eh...  not bad.  Not great.

3.5 Stars

Seems to me that this place may be a study in a chef trying to open his own place and trying a bit too hard.  The cheap rent in what amounts to a storage warehouse (with a couple of bathrooms and a kitchen thrown in) plus the spartan furnishings and the overemphasis on funky combos with the food, screams that this chef just wants to have his creations tasted.  I dunno...  it was good, but seemed a bit amature-ish.

Bread pudding = good.  But anything slathered in butter is going to be good.

Sirloin Salad = good.  Hearty and substantial, and like the idea of a salad with meat in it.  Seems very manly.

Marrow = eh.  A bit fatty.  Pretty good taste and the sea salt is a neat spin, but the salad / garnish was a pile parsley...  maybe it was just a garnish.

The chicken looked good and much of it was eaten by the individuals who ordered it.  The short ribs looked tasty and tender and there was a pretty good pile of it.  I had the duck and it was ok.  Maybe I just don't like duck, but it seemed a bit gamey.  I ate it all, though.
