Great ice cream, but why drive all the way to Hunter's Point for Bi-Rite 'scream when I can walk to 18th Street?  The lemon tart was tarty and lemony.

Average space, slightly above average food, and way the fuck out there spells a quick death to this place.  But then again, I though that Google was going to tank too.

BTW --  Serpentine = group of common rock-forming hydrous magnesium iron phyllosilicate ((Mg, Fe)3Si2O5(OH)4) minerals.  

Take that!
author: Tony A.

description:
Just had dinner here last night with a few friends - the food was tasty but 

Atmosphere - buzzy and spacious, nicely lit, although a bit dark in the seats near the door.  We had to use the candles to read our menus and we ended up taking a few of the candles from the wall decorations so we could see our dinner.

Service - very friendly and helpful staff.  No complaints.

Food - very tasty and good portions.  However the cooking could do with a little less salt.  The olive and brussel sprouts we had as starters were a bit too salty.  The main course were very flavorful, but again, could have  tad bit salt.  Although we enjoyed our dinner - we were thirsty all night from all the salt intake.

Price - reasonably priced dishes and a fairly good wine list.

All in all, a nice local spot for a quick bite.  Just giving it an Ok - but will certainly try it again and say 'easy on the salt' please.
author: Gina C.

description:
We went here last weekend and am sad to say we were very disappointed.  We waited a couple of months for them to "work out the kinks" and it appears they have not yet.

We are big fans of Slow Club and went here with a high school friend of the joint owner of both Slow Club and Serpentine -  Erin - even then we were not treated very well.  

Our reservation was at 9:00 PM - we arrived at 9:02 (I looked at my watch) and we were told that our table was not quite ready - we went to the bar "to wait."

Thirty minutes later we were still not seated and were HUNGRY - I looked around to see several empty tables - I saw the hostess chatting through the kitchen window to the chefs - I walked over and tapped on her shoulder and asked when we were going to be seated.  Her reply and I quote:

"oh my god....I forgot!"

Not professional.

The food was so-so.  My friends burger got rave reviews - my lamb chops were scant for the price and mostly fat and bone - my husband's gratin tiny and cold when served and our other friend's quail undercooked.

On the bright side the kitchen sent out duck pate and lamb rilettes as an apology for the delay in seating us and both these items were fantastic.  Also my cocktail was delicious - they only stock top shelf liquor - and the wine list is decent.

We live nearby and so will probably give them another try.  The space is amazing but this is San Francisco and I am all about food quality and good service - both were unfortunately lacking here - with so many other places to go they will have to WOW us on our 2nd visit to get us back again and this is walking distance from our house.
author: Mylea C.

description: Just came here for lunch and I got the burger (again) but added gruyere and boy what a nice addition.  I thought the burger was great when I had it for brunch but that added gruyere flavor was like a delicious medly in my mouth.  The fries were quite memorable as well--a bit of cilantro (I believe) and garlic sprinkled on it with a side of subtle aioli.  Add a nice cold mexican coke and you have the perfect lunch.
author: Karen N.

description:
Just delicious! I have been coming here fairly regularly for a few years now, since it's in my neighborhood. The service has been consistently awesome, and the food is consistently fantastic. 

I love to have a long, lazy, delicious, Bloody Mary filled brunch that they serve on weekends. The baked eggs du jour (seasonal) and the fried egg sandwich have been exceptional. I'm personally not much for sweet breakfast, but I have heard from quite a few folks, that the pancakes are stellar. 

And, the supper they serve most other evenings is simply scrumptious. The Monice's Shrine cocktail is my absolute favorite (I love, love grapefruit juice and sparkling wine). If up to me, we would get a meat board to share, pickled vegetables to share, chicken livers to share, any salad they make to share (every salad I have had has been amazing), and either a fresh fish dish (seasonal), or a cheeseburger for the main course. 

For dessert, an ice cream sandwich or the meyer lemon buttermilk cake (my most favorite), if they have it. Though, I did just have their autumn ice cream sandwich with pumpkin cookies, vanilla ice cream, a salted caramel sauce, with pepita praline - absolutely phenomenal. 

Honestly, having eaten many different dishes they have had, I would recommend almost anything off their menu, depending on what you have a tooth out for. The ingredients are fresh and seasonal, and the dishes are creative. 

I would definitely recommend a reservation on the weekend (you can do this through Open Table), and if you are driving, parking is easy in this area. 

All in all, a great place with great food!
author: Zea M.

description: We just finished brunch at Serpentine and while I can't speak to the cocktails, the food was pretty average. We had the biscuit & gravy, granola with yogurt and buckwheat pancakes. The biscuit was nice and texturally was spot on, but my problem was with the gravy which was way over-salted. The granola was tasty, but was served with ordinary natural yogurt which really diluted the flavor of the homemade granola. Greek yogurt would have been a better pairing because of its thickness. The buckwheat pancakes were also just ok. They were a little dry. The candied walnuts, fruit and maple syrup that they were served with really made the dish and a bite including all the components was quite satisfying. Sadly, there wasn't enough of anything but the syrup to have with every bite and I haven't enjoyed drenching my breakfast in maple syrup since before puberty. The interior is quite cool, but service was slow and I got the impression our server lost interest in us when we didn't order cocktails. The tables are super close together, so if you have any junk in the trunk you run the risk of grazing the neighboring table's meal. I would consider going back for dinner (and cocktails!) but only with a four top and I'd request one of the booths so as not to be wedged in next to other dinners.
author: WaltzingMatilda T.

description: New favorite restaurant. Unpretentious atmosphere, very friendly wait staff, delicious food. Highly recommend. Need a rez for sure.
author: Amy L.

description:
This place has good food. They make a decent eggs benedict. The eggs are overcooked about 1 out of every 3 times I order it though so it's not totally consistent but it's still good. They add a little lemon zest to the dish which gives it a nice bit of extra flavor when done right but they often add way too much. I've had the fettuccine for lunch here before and it was pretty bland. The bread putting is quite tasty and savory. I still haven't tried this place for dinner but will eventually.

Overall the food is ok. I'll keep going here for the benedict on days when Butler and the Chef isn't an option. I'd recommend this to a friend if they are looking for a decent meal in the dog patch area.
author: g m.

description:
Went in for lunch, and the food was great!  I ordered the savory bread pudding (swiss cheese, butternut squash) which did not disappoint.  The carrot side was absolutely delicious, and the side salad was enormous.  I didn't want the bread pudding to get cold, so I saved the salad for last.  At $10, this was a great value.

Service wasn't too prompt- between waiting for a host to appear, having empty glasses of water and also having my check come a little bit too quick, there could be some improvement here.

I really like the industrial aspect of the space.  I like how the restaurant is flooded in natural light, and the noises from the street wander into the restaurant.
author: Jeff A.

description: I had a very delicious burger, cooked medium (as ordered), as well as a couple very well made daiquris (with Pampero).  But the reason for the five star review is a drink that the bartender concocted that day, made with Johnnie Black and fresh fennel seeds.  Scotch cocktails are tougher to pull off, and I was a little hesitant on the fennel, but the end product was an anise-y ambrosia, the definition of a well-balanced cocktail.  Didn't catch the name of it, but shouldn't be too hard to describe.
author: David C.

description:
I was in the area with some friends and found out that my friend works here so we stopped by for lunch. If it wasn't for my friend's recommendation, I would have never known this place existed since there were no street level windows to peep in. The painted sign on the building's corner column was a subtle hint of the industrial feel of the dining area.  We were graciously seated and kept busy with some bread while the kitchen warmed up.  I ordered the open face ham sandwich with fries.  I don't even like ham but I think I do now thanks to Serpentine.  The open face part of the sandwich took some getting use to.  I saw how goofy my friend looked trying to eat it like a pizza so I opted for the knife and fork.  The same goofy friend later tells me that SFWeekly voted Serpentine as having the best burger in the city or bay or general area.  I would have loved that piece of information when we were ordering.  Regardless, the great food and service has definitely put this place on my radar.

I plan to come back and try the infamous burger.
author: Will L.

description:
As Dogpatch starts to really blossom, I'd expect to see more restaurants like Serpentine popping up. Certainly not a bad thing, and the meal I had here was good, just not amazing. Service, pacing, and overall ambiance were very pleasant.

The bottle of wine suggested didn't match the flavor profile we were looking for, but was decent all the same. As for the food, the pork chop ordered was tasty, but that was about it. We ordered the lemon tart and marshmallow dessert, which was pretty underwhelming. The lemon was too warm and runny, and the marshmallow was pretty much just baked meringue. 

I'd say if you're in or near the Dogpatch, Serpentine is definitely worth dropping in on. However, if you're not exactly on the T-line, it may not be worth the hike.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Review for brunch only.

Food: 4.5 stars

Service: 4 stars

Price: 5 stars

Fav. Dish so far: Fennel Red Hash; hubby had the fried steak, he thinks it's only ok. Looking forward to try the crab benedict.
author: Brandon F.

description: Of all the places I have had a burger in the city, this was the worst. That doesn't mean it's bad, but it wasn't anything to write home about. I would like to come back and try something else though. I would definitely give this place a second chance, the rest of the menu looked great.
author: Alfredo A.

description:
We had a late reservation at 8:30. 3 out of the 4 of us made it there by that time and the last was 2min away. Literally parking and walking over. The hostess asked us to wait until everyone was here...ummmm...okay.

That was the first awkward moment. The service was ok, but the big building acoustics made it hard to chat and talk.

Food was ok. They ran out of what we had all wanted to order (duck) and we all had to settle for something else. What we did have was good, but nothing outstanding. I feel like the place is still trying to make that jump to find a signature taste.

Three stars for the ease of parking, the courage to open in an evolving semi-sketch area, and the comfort food.
author: Eugene L.

description:
Um...it's my neighborhood supposedly a "nice and hip" new restaurant.
Yet...I am barely giving 3stars,

I will give some starts for a place. Sleek design using industrial warehouse with high ceiling and all...

Food is really a OK.
Me and my boyfriend went there for a chill dinner. Lucky enough we didn't have to wait to get seated at the bar. We ordered wild arugula  salad and  Mary's Chicken Leg al Mattone.  Salad was good but Chicken was way too salty and brown butter nettles was not the right ingredients choice for this dish. It just didn't go very well together. 
Though they have good ideas and intentions for using organic ingredients but execution was just not up there.
Dessert, we shared a pear tart. It was ok but whipped cream was too heavy.

Though I'd say service was decent. 

Over all, its really a OK restaurant sadly. For a fancy place, it need a little more effort.
author: Mayumi Y.

description:
Dinner last night was wonderful.  We're glad to find such a place in our new SF neighborhood.
Started out w/ a couple of cocktails.  I enjoyed my bourbon smash which was a mojito w/ bourbon.
Lentil soup was delicious as were the sardines.  (I always go for what's in season, it may not be there the next time I eat at a place.)
Entree was haddock for the wife and pork osso buco for myself.  How do you spell delicious!  Rapini was a garlic delivery mechanism (mmm) and the sunchokes were excellent like everything else.
We had a bottle of Eaderly Pinot Noir which should be opened and allowed to breath for at least 20 minutes, it was best as we were finishing the meal.
Dessert was pear crisp and salt-caramel pot-de-creme.

We'll be back!

PS - The chef being of Indian heritage has introduced a touch of flavorings that accent each dish in a nice and novel way.
author: David M.

description: We were met at the door by the most unfriendly and nasty Hostess.  She said they were booked up and only had two seats at an already packed bar.  When we pointed out that there were only two occupied tables she said they were still booked up.  After I pointed out that we had called and were told to come because there would be walk in tables available.  She changed her tune and informed us that one reservation just cancelled and we could be seated immediately. As we sat at our table no one appeared to take a drink order or offer us any information in a timely manner.  Eventually I got someones attention and  our waitress did appear she redeemed herself because she was friendly and attentive.  She brought our drinks which were very good and we placed our food order.  The food was served in record time and it was indeed very good.  The wait staff works as a team so once things got going our experience improved.  The most ironic point was  we were in and out of there in less than 40 minutes and there were still tables available.  I liked the food but the overall experience was dampened by the reception we received upon entering the place.  Such a shame because it only takes a smile and a bit of kindness to make a good lasting impression.
author: Jon P.

description: This place has consistently great fresh food. They source many of their ingredients from local organic farms, and use high quality free range meats. Their burger is one of the best in San Francisco! They also have really tasty cocktails at their fun and lively bar. Love this place and will continue to go back often!
author: Tim A.

description: I've been 3 times so far and so far so good. I really like the Savory Bread Pudding I had for brunch. Really yummy and not too big. All my friends liked their dishes as well.
author: Gregg T.

description:
The best were the cocktails, on par with NYC.  The lemon cocktail (called the Ancient something?) was so refreshing I was downing as if it were lemonade.  I'd go back to Serpentine's bar just for drinks.

I really love the space, with its converted loft/warehouse high ceilings and candlelit ambiance.  The lamb t-bone and spigariello salad were excellent, the savory bread pudding quite filling.  For dessert, I tried the apple galette which was pretty good and made even better with Bi-Rite Creamery ice cream.  Mmm mmm!  Great choice on their part.  Most of their desserts came with Bi-Rite ice cream, or you could order by the scoop.

I'd been wanting to try Serpentine since I love their other restaurant, Slow Club.  Overall, I still prefer Slow Club, but I'm glad to see great new restaurants popping up in Dogpatch/Potrero.  Easy parking!
author: Chris P.

description: The Flannel dish -- great hang-over food.  Nice lofty industrial interiors.
author: Paul M.

description: YUMMY!!!! I've only eaten here for brunch or else I'd feel educated enough to give it that last star. But the brunch is beyond delicious! My favorite is the savory bread pudding - Some may think it's too greasy, I say that's a good breakfast. And save room for dessert... Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous is right across the street!!!!
author: Sarah T.

description: I went here the other night with a friend and we had AMAZING burgers! The fries that came with them were even better though! They bring the sauce in those little dishes which sucks because I like a lot of ketchup, etc. But our waitress was really nice and I am sure would have brought us more if I asked, but it wasn't that big of a deal. Its expensive but what isn't in SF? I would have tried another dish but one was $5 and the rest were $10 more than the burger sooooooooo yea. Burger it is (well, was). It was delicious though :) Since I got the cheapest entree I felt okay about buying a $10 cocktail which was quite good! For SF I would say it was worth the money. If you want to get out of the bustling city and explore a local place in the dogpatch, visit this modern restaurant and I am sure you will enjoy yourself.
author: Ramey D.

description: Brunch is awesome... eggs benedict and one of the best burgers you can get to help with a hangover... nice atmosphere also.
author: Geronimo K.

description:
Met my cousins here for dinner on a Saturday.  The place was packed.  Luckily we made reservations.  The menu looked delicious and we couldn't resist so we got a little bit of everything...

Appetizers: 
- Lamb belly - crispy on the outside tender and tasty on the inside 
- Oysters on the half shell - what's expected if you like raw oysters
- Sauteed chicken liver - Perfectly cooked and marinated
- Shaved vegetable salad - light, great dressing

Entrees:
- Housemade potato gnocchi - very tender, bits of bacon optional, tho a little too salty
- Roasted Chicken - good, not overcooked
- Burger - can't comment because I didn't taste but my cousin said it was delicious and a good sized patty too

Cocktails:
- The Acadian - not to be missed!  Michter's rye, sloe gin, honey, lemon, rosemary, and just a touch of absinthe.  Served beautifully in a martini glass with a sprig of Rosemary floating in the center.  The flavors are very balanced and the lingering taste of Rosemary rounds out the sweet and sour of the honey and lemon.
- Whiskey Smash - comparable to a whiskey mojito with the muddled mint
- Blood & Sand - lenmorangie scotch, blood orange,
sutton cellars vermouth, housemade grenadine - for those who like a stronger drink with a little bite from the blood orange
 
Server was very friendly and helpful, not too attentive since they were very busy on a Saturday night but not to the point where we weren't getting proper service.  Solid choice for a Saturday night dinner.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
This place shouts CALIFORNIA everywhere from its lofty industrial interior to the local-grown menu. If you like filling but clean food, this is a good place to go. I've been here twice recently, brunch and dinner.

BRUNCH
Fried egg sandwich (with biscuit, arugula, and aioli) and golden potatoes on the side... pretty big portion (everything on the brunch menu is) but I didn't come out of the meal feeling oily and nasty like brunch usually does to me. My friends enjoyed their red flannel hash and country fried steak too.

DINNER
Violet crush cocktail is like a mojito but less sweet. Oysters, good. Meat board is not something I would order on my own, but the pork and duck liver pate was yum. The gnocchi was pretty darn good. And I didn't try the burger or ice cream sandwich, but my friends raved about both.

My only complaint was that it was so dark inside during dinner. There was pretty much no interior lighting other than a single candle at each table.
author: S L.

description: Food was delish and the atmosphere was great. We had a wonderful time with our friends and it was a great place to double date. We brought our own wine but the wine list looked pretty good.
author: Elisa T.

description:
been here for lunch/brunch a few times.  the food is quite good and reasonably priced.  portions are not large but are sufficient.  service is pretty good, but i would have appreciated more refills on water.  

ambiance is great on sunny days.  very high ceilings and big windows make it very cheerful.

try the red flannel hash and savory bread pudding.  they are both very good.

usually ample parking available.
author: Oliver C.

description: This is a pretty legit restaurant. After eating college food for a year, the quality of this food pretty much blew my mind. Which isn't to say that it'll blow your mind, but it is pretty good.
author: Grant M.

description: Rushed service. Mosquito in bread. Cramped seating for two. I live near by and am so upset that this place isn't better. I've given it a few tries now and am underwelmed each time. The portions are tiny and the food is only so-so. I'd rather walk up to 20th St and catch some much nicer fare in Potrero Hill.
author: Darin A.

description: A well designed local joint, but go early or make a reservation. We went at 10:30am on a Sunday without a reservation and were seated at the bar - and treated as definite second class citizens. Food wasn't good enough for that kind of service.
author: Nick K.

description: got the little gems salad with chicken for brunch.  it was delicious.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Very cool spot in Dog Patch, great food which is interesting and varied, good veggie choices and superb wine list. The best part is that its cheap for what you get.
author: Tim B.

description: My first time at Serpentine after hearing so much about it. The food was really nice and made in such a way that the dishes were about each item and not covering with sauce or too much, but allowing the natural flavors to be tasted. The pickled veggies were a bit firmer than I would prefer and they should be more bite size since cutting is quite difficult without the proper utensils. The calamari was fresh and very tasty. Mains and desert were also really nice and very well portioned. Hand crafted drinks top it off and make for a custom experience vs. a generic one. Service was a bit hap-hazard but didn't affect the overall evening. Looking forward to going back!
author: Dr F.

description:
We had a reservation, but still had to wait nearly 30 minutes for our table.  That was a bummer.  But the bar area is nice, and they have a great cocktail list, and wines by the glass.

The food is good, solid, but not spectacular.  I expected a little something more "wow" from the descriptions on the menu.  Also, the portions were too large (and how often do you get to say that?).  I felt that the plating / presentation needed some refinement - smaller slices of bread, smaller slices of meat, etc.  But for people who like a lot of food they'll be happy.  2 people could share a starter/small plate and an entree and be quite satisfied.

Pluses were a very nice waiter, attentive but not overly so (can't say the same about the bus boy who wanted to grab plates up before we were done); wine pairing recommendations (the cote du rhone with the steak was a perfect match); and having bone marrow on the menu.  Bonus for using local, sustainable, etc.

Minuses - waiting for a table even with a reservation (and one of our party was 8 mos preggers), LOUD making it v. difficult to talk, feeling rushed by the busboy.

If the place were closer, I might go there again, but it's not worth the hour + MUNI ride I had to take to get there.
author: darla s.

description:
On the fence... 3.... 4...  3.... 4... 

I am usually probably more generous than I should be with reviews (I recently realized this when I saw I had more 5 star reviews than 4 star) so I'm going to try to start being a bit more of a stickler.  

Service here wasn't really anything that special and none of the dishes were that stand out. They were all quite good but that's about it... I really liked my lettuce cup salad... but doing a salad well doesn't really make you all that special.

Basically there are a ton of other places I'd try for the first time before going back to Serpentine.  With that said I don't regret trying this place at all and highly recommend checking it out at least once.  And get the lettuce cup salad.
author: Derek B.

description: My wife and I love this place, and are thrilled to have it in our neighborhood.  Great food, great drinks and great staff.  The porkchop is my favorite.
author: Michael A.

description: The burger & fries were pretty good, plenty of ketchup for me to smother it on. Waitress was very chatty and told us about every drink - which were good, kind of fruity and tropical, but maybe not the best for a cold night.
author: Tracy C.

description:
OMG, the savory bread pudding was DELICIOUS!!! It was my first time having savory bread pudding and I'm equally in love with savory and sweet bp. My friend and I had it for our appetizer and it was amazing. First of all, it was huge, we barely finished the whole thing. I really wanted too, but if I did, I knew I wouldn't have room for my entree. It was SO crispy on the outside and moist, rich and savory in the inside. You could really taste the herbs and the occasional bites of veggies were really good. You MUST order this. I think I will go back just to have cocktails and bp at the bar. Heavenly.

For my entree, I had the pork chop. The big chop was served with cauliflower, spinach and some type of bulgar wheat. The pork was a little of a tougher side, but I thought overall, it was very tasty and good. I had a slice of my friend's steak and it was very good too.

For dessert, we shared the almond cake with rhubarb compote and strawberry ice cream. YUM! The cake had the right texture and the rhubarb compote was sweet and refreshing with the strawberry ice cream. 

Serpentine had a nice casual, cool vibe. I loved the "warehouse" feel of the restaurant and overall the service was excellent!
author: Denise L.

description:
I would actually give Serpentine 3.5-4 stars, but as Nathan and Jun already posted earlier, the hostess was very frustrating. Despite having made a reservation in advance, we had to wait ~30 minutes for our table. Not unreasonable on a busy Friday night, but the hostess clearly needs some lessons on customer service. A simple smile, apology would have been enough.

Fortunately, our actual waitress was awesome. The poor woman had to deal with our stone cold faces when we first sat down. However, the food, wine, and free appetizer soon warmed our hearts. The dessert (Bi-Rite vanilla ice cream w/ peach and blackberry upside-down cafe) was heavenly.
author: Richie K.

description:
oh mah lawd-a restaurant in SF you can actually drive to and park your car at.  i am old, i have bunions, my thighs rubs together and i like to wear heels- you automatically win me over if i'm not huffing it over three hills to get to you, or shelling out for cab ride.  i also just had a baby three months ago and don't get out much anymore.  the stakes are now very high when i am occasionally freed from my domestic prison and allowed to go eat expensive meals and get fucked up with my gays.  

the staff is incredibly perky and friendly, also a plus.  the adorable bartender mike, mixed us perfect drinks the entire time, chatted us up and provided excellent menu suggestions. the gnocci and the confit of duck gesier on polenta were the real standouts.  this is a pretty classy joint, so when we started loudly talking about the power exchange and getting the stink eye from the sober patrons behind us we knew it was time to hit the road- we were late for our 9:00 showing of the golden girls: the christmas episodes drag show anyway.  still, i somehow got talked into doing a shot at the bar across the street- oh fuck it, it's christmas time.

moral of the story is: go to serpentine, just hopefully not like we did which was after finishing half a sigg bottle of grey goose on the train beforehand.  you may actually remember your experience more and not offend the other paying patrons.
author: Jessie J.

description: I had the biscuits & gravy and followed it up with the crab eggs benedict. The food was delicious, prices were good for the quality of the food, service staff polite and attentive. My only complaint is that the ledge near where we sat was super dusty.
author: Tom C.

description:
A new restaurant in lonely Dogpatch is always great news and I was pleasantly surprised that this offshoot of Slo Club could put together a really good and creative meal.  Prices are reasonable and just about every dish was pretty well executed (although the steak was very average and I suggest bypassing it).  The restaurant design was also very average.  I was expecting very hip industrial design but it appeared Serpentine budgeted lower.

All the same, the food and price gets me to 4 stars and is a place I would go again.
author: Laurence H.

description:
THE FOLKS: 
The hostess and waitstaff were great - friendly, attentive, and they indulged, well, our indulgences. They are laid back (no stuffy dress code), but knowledgeable about the menu, the wine, and professional.  

Reservations Note: if you reserve and then don't show up, or if you reserve for a certain number of people and not all of them show up, then you are charged $10 per head that didn't show. Lock in your dining companions by 24 hours before your reservation! 

THE AMBIENCE:
This place is not that big so you can take a small group here, but I wouldn't take more than 7. We were maybe a little too cozy at our table. It's also awkward if you get there early and you are hanging out behind the people sitting at the crowded bar, trying desperately not to let that lady with the bulldozer method of moving through crowds knock over your Ancient Lemon martini. 

This is definitely a great date place - you don't have to dress up, it's intimate and dim, great food, great atmosphere, cozy seating arrangements. 

THE FOOD:
The hush puppies were OK, but the fried Hama Hama clams were very good - crispy, hot, and perfectly cooked on the inside. I didn't partcularly care for the toasts with anchovies - the bread was too hard and the soft stuff just fell off. The short ribs were EXCELLENT - my knife slid through them "like buttah!" Very flavorful, nice crust on the outside. The pork had an excellent taste but was a little tough to cut into. The pan seared halibut was devoured. The goat cheese cheescake was surprisingly good, as was the warm chocolate cake. Yum. Nothing better than warm chocolate ooziness with fresh raspberries and creme anglaise. We pretty much all licked our plates clean by the end of the meal.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Serpentine is your typical hip SF restaurant  - dim lighting...high ceilings...brick walls.. noisy acoustics makes for a pretty spot at the Patch (minus the acoustics).  I actually would have given this place 4 stars - but one of the servers decided to tell my party to tone it down a bit  while we were waiting for more than 20 minutes for a table- the nerve! 
Food was decent I had a well cooked Black Bass - friend had  yummy savory bread pudding and others had burgers and delicious cod cakes. Bonus points for a really good Canadian beer - La Fin Du Monde (belgian style)
author: Christian S.

description:
GREAT FOOD!
-all the dishes are cook very nicely, no overcooked dry fish or steak or anything.  Perfect.

[LITTLE GEMS LETTUCES: zoe's bacon - toasted hazelnuts - shaved red onions - blue cheese dressing]
-What a great refreshing appetizer.  The lettuces are REALLY REALLY fresh and good.  The blue cheese doesn't overpower the dish at all and the hazelnuts made the dish superb.

[SAVORY BREAD PUDDING: fennel - green garlic - carmelized onions -
swiss cheese]
-This is a GREAT dish.  Definitely a must if you are a bread pudding fan-

[CORNMEAL CRUSTED HAMA HAMA OYSTERS: frisée - lemon vinaigrette - horseradish aioli]
-This dish is good, but I don't find it too special considering the sauce is pretty normal.  If i were to go again, I'd want to try something else-

[WILD BOAR SUGO: hand cut papparedelle - fresh oregano -
grana padano]
-For pasta lovers, this is really really good.  This is a dish i would go back and order again-

[PAN SEARED BLUE NOSE BASS: yukon gold potato gnocchi - fava beans - pea shoots - charred spring onion relish - toasted almonds]
-the charred spring onion relish on top of the fish did the trick.  Great fish dish-

[GRILLED MEYER RANCH FLAT IRON STEAK: truffled potatoe croquette - grilled asparagus - red wine demi glace]
-the truffled potato croquette is SOOO GOOD.  I would say this is also a must here-

[SEARED MASSACHUSETTS SEA SCALLOPS: english pea & green garlic risotto - pea puree - pancetta crumbles]
-scallops are cooked very nicely and you can't really go wrong with green garlic sauce!  Anything with green garlic sauce is great, and this is no exception-
author: Jonathan C.

description: I was impressed with the meat board, which was quite good. Other than that, no real surprises here. The portion sizes are too small for the price. Perhaps I will give it another try...
author: C. H.

description:
Minus one star for the wait-staff's disengaged, disinterested and somewhat annoyed attitude!
Seriously, isn't anyone interested in a good tip for the least?!
The brunch menu however is outstanding: the fried steak and gravy is rich and delicious. The beet salad and poached egg light and satisfying.
Pancakes are yummy too with candied walnuts and bananas to boot!
author: Sara K.

description: This is our new favorite brunch place.  Me and the hubby are both in love  with certain menu items.  For me it the savory bread pudding with cheese and house smoked ham. He loves the country fried steak.  The wait staff is super friendly and the bar makes awesome drinks.  We haven't tried dinner there yet but plan to.
author: ruby r.

description: best ravioli I have had in a while! Everyone at the table loved what they ordered and man their drinks hit the spot!
author: S R.

description:
Food is too salty!

In terms of service and ambience, I actually give this place 5 stars. Host and waiters are kind, helpful (our table was uneven and rocking back and forth, we told our waitress and they immediately sent someone to place some cardboard under our table leg - rocking stopped). Waiter constantly refilled my water glass, brought out drinks and meal very promptly. 

The ambience is modern-charm, feels a bit industrial, very nice space and I'd love to come back for dinner.

To drink I had an iced latte - tasted perfect, exactly as I like it.

But the food is sort of...fine. I ordered the salmon eggs benedict. It was too salty - the greens it is served with were very salty. Salmon was salty. Potatoes tasted like tater tots and were salty. Salty salty!

My boyfriend's burger was pretty blah as well...you could walk into any place and get a burger like the one they serve.

And it is a bit pricey as well.

But for those of us who love great ambience, appreciate good service and need a perfect caffeinated drink exactly as we want it, this place does well. I will probably go back.
author: Latte Queen W.

description: Post Chef Chris Konner, now the food isn't as creative or realized, but still altogether a pleasant experience in a fabulous loft-like space with lots of concrete, steel and wood.
author: Angelo S.

description:
Serpentine was the 4th (and #7 on the 7x7 Best Burgers list) stop on our BurgerFest tour. Feeling hungry for some grilled meatness after the holidays I made a reservation on Friday night and showed up in Dogpatch with my burger companions, Melanie N. and Gene X. Turned out I screwed up and made the reservation for the next day, but the folks at Serpentine were kind enough to still give us a table with a minimum of wait. We took our spot in a nice booth and ordered some drinks. I got a cocktail made with brandy, vermouth, Cynar, and a lemon twist which was great and had a nice balance between sweetness and bitterness. Usually we just get the burger, but the menu looked appetizing enough that we decided to get an order of Chickpea Battered Calamari. The decision process went like this: Gene and I, "I'd be up for X, Y and Z", Melanie - "Calamari". No sense in arguing. :) In any case, I'm not a big fan of calamari normally, but Serpentine's version turned out to be delightful.

The burgers were delivered soon after. They came with arugula, pickled onions, pickle slices and a plateful of fries. I was disappointed to see that mine was medium, since I ordered it medium-rare, while Melanie had the opposite problem. The burger itself was decent, with that specific flavor of Prather Ranch that I've learned to recognize. One thing that turned me off a bit was that half of the burger- and by that I mean not one side or another, but actually half - was charred enough to give each bite an acrid taste. Uneven grill temp is all I can think of. The pickled stuff worked well with the meat, and I enjoyed the fries as well. However, I just can't get excited about this meal since it was simply a decently executed burger with nothing special to make it memorable. I could buy Prather Ranch meat, grill the same patty, use the same Acme roll and come up with a version damn close to or better than what I had. So this puts this burger in 4th place on my list so far.

I wish I could give Serpentine 3.5 stars, since the calamari and the service were good. But it'll have to be 3 stars, because of the problems with the burger and the lack of imagination that it conveyed, despite the cost ($14 with cheese). I hope to return to try something else on the menu and update my review then.
author: Andrei Z.

description: Sparks fly in this intimate, urban space.  Everything about this restaurant lends itself to cozy conversations.  I came here with a group of friends, enjoying rounds of courses and cocktails, forgetting that there were others in the space.  The food was delicious and our server was attentive and kind.  I'd definitely recommend Serpentine for a meal with close friends or a loved one.
author: Zuzzi E.

description: The cocktails are pretty solid. Nothing to write home about, but kind of B+. Similarly, the food is solid -- a bit uninspired. Lacking in subtle flavors -- perhaps there's a freshness/quality issue there? Well prepared, I guess.
author: Guillermo K.

description: After enjoying our Mother's Day brunch, we finally had the opportunity to go for dinner on the Dine Out for Meals on Wheels night. The food was great - lentil soup, cheese plate, gnocchi, and chicken. Our server was extremely attentive. I was so happy after my great brunch experience to see dinner was the same!
author: Christine O.

description:
Yeah! Another cool spot for dinner on a weeknight close to my hood.   It use to be cannery and then a chinese food kitchen.  I love the high ceiling yet intimate interior, but enough about that...

The food was great.  My boyf had the pork chop...yum.  I had a bite of course. My black cod was perfectly cooked.    Then we had the chocolate cake.  

And did I mention our server?  He was attentive and super nice.

Another plus...easy parking.   That was great for a Weds night.  :)
author: Julia H.

description:
Anyone who knows me knows that my all-time favorite restaurant in SF is the Slow Club so I've been dying to try Serpentine (the last time I tried late-ish on a Sunday night, they were already closing down for the night).  Ten of us went for a friend's birthday (and we had a great table at 8:15 pm; probably didn't hurt that we know the owner); overall it was thumbs up.  We couldn't fault the food at all - everything was delicious.  The downside was the service - though I couldn't fault our server; she was lovely and attentitive.  However, the cocktails were slow in arriving and  a bit meager for the $10 per - what can I say?  We're used to Martuni's pours.  I was put off when the salads arrived before the half dozen appetizers we'd ordered for the table to share, which made the fact that two of the appetizers never arrived a moot point.

I would definitely come back, but my favorite still remains the Slow Club.
author: Lorraine F.

description: Great food.  Service was fine, though the servers didn't smile.  (They were friendly though and turned the music down upon request.)
author: Maulik S.

description: Really good food at very reasonable prices; ate there today.
author: Kendall Austin S.

description: 7x7 Magazine put it best when they described their famous grass-fed beef burger as being "the girl next door." There is nothing exotic about its presentation or taste--it's just a thin patty on a thick bun. But the rich flavor of the beef paired with house made bread and butter pickles and thick slices of tomato makes this burger one of the "10 best burgers in the city." I consider the Serpentine burger the highlight of the dishes. Brunch is fresh, decent. Lunch has some good items. But the burger cuts the cake and is a must eat when dining about San Francisco.
author: Alex H.

description: I've only been here for Brunch and if you factor in service, I would give it 4 stars but the food is so good it makes up for the slow service. It took 20 min. for us to get coffee. It came out after our food. That being said, the crab benedict was SO good! It was so delicate and delicious. The crispy potatoes are awesome too. I normally don't like breakfast potatoes. My husband got the burger and fries. He ordered the burger medium rare but it was very rare. It would be hard to cook it less so I couldn't eat it, but he said it was good and the french fries were awesome. I would pass on the cornbread. So I know it seems like I found a lot of stuff wrong, but the good stuff really made up for it. I just like to be very complete in my reviews. I normally don't love brunch because I don't eat pork, but this place is pretty good at giving you really good non-vegetarian options.
author: mazzy s.

description:
Serpentine has incredible potential!

I love the vintage school-house-meets-stripped-industrial-space decor, the high ceilings, the heavy wooden entrance door , but not so much the tiny vintage chairs that were a little uncomfortable.

The drink menu and the drinks were very imaginitive but still very drinkable (unlike some of the off-the-wall combinations at the bleeding edge bars like Bourbon & Branch) and were well made.  I absolutely adored my tequila and grapefruit concoction, but my friends were off-put by the liberal dose of bitters in their bellinis.   The other bummer about the cocktails is that it took FOREVER for me to get my Ruby drink - it definitely prevented me from ordering another, and I really wanted to!

The brunch menu is incredibly tempting - egg sandwhiches, red flannel hash, eggs benedict, chicken-fried steak - how can anyone with a hearty appetite and no fear of cholesterol resist???

I had the red flannel hash and really enjoyed it - the beets were delicious and the beef morsels were well cooked and extremely flavorful - but, there wasn't a lot of the beef in the dish.  The eggs on top looked like perfect little round ghosts, but, inside my yolk was overcooked and almost entirely hard.

The table also ordered the egg sandwhich - and the home-made sausage on that was outstanding, but the rest was pretty standard.  The chicken fried steak was probably the best of them all - really delicious steak and coating.  We also ordered the savory bread pudding, which was really good, but my friends said the savory bread pudding at Picino nearby is much better.

The potatoes that were servered were the little peeled, cubed and fried type - which, I like, but I normally prefer the unpeeled earthier type of friend potatoes with break fast.

I loved our server - she was warm and fun and genuine and she also made sure that we ordered their delicious buckwheat pancakes with apples for the table, and, I must say, was really the highlight of the meal!  The pancakes are topped with a delicious hand-whipped, not-too-sweet whipped cream and were certainly worth going back for.

By the end of the meal we were all stuffed - and because of the pancakes, we could not bring ourselves to order dessert...but, I have to say I really enjoyed the meal and want to return.  And hopefully I can upgrade my rating!
author: Jim K.

description: This might still be my favorite brunch place in the city. The bread pudding is amazing, the hash is delicious and the bloody marys are perfect. The staff is super friendly and chill and I never have a bad meal or experience here. Whenever I come for dinner... the burger is my go to item but again, never had anything bad on the menu.
author: shadi m.

description:
I love Serpentine.  And it is practically in walking distance to my house - hooray! 

About the neighborhood: Dogpatch is coming along. What a nice blend of old warehouses & sketchiness with a flair of new restaurants and bars.  The neighborhood reminds me of Brooklyn's DUMBO in the 1990's.  Very cool.  

Serpentine is small restaurant with a hip crowd and atmosphere.  

I thought the appetizers were only OK - the antipasto was weak. However, the savory bread pudding was to die for!  Yes, you can have it for your main course, it might be too rich for an appetizer.  The side of brussel sprouts were so good that we almost ordered another dish.  

Note, you'll need a reservation, especially on the weekend, and most tables are for two people.
author: Jill D.

description:
Please: Cook the meat as ordered.

I don't know what else to say.  Out of the four mains, three were not as ordered.  Steak, ordered medium, came medium rare. Burger, ordered medium rare, came medium well.  Duck, ordered medium rare, came medium.  Scallops were properly cooked.  They comped us the duck (which is the only one we bothered to complain about), which was nice.  But come on--get the orders right!

The space is really cool, industrial, with windows high on the walls.  As seems to be the trend in a lot of places, appetizers were more interesting than the mains.  Liked the bruschetta and the savory bread pudding quite a bit.
author: David K.

description: The building looks like a warehouse conversion, the decor is kind of industrial which may not suit everyone and it can get loud when it is crowded.  However, the food was well-executed, the drinks were creative, everything was tasty, and the employees were nice.  I've heard this place described several times as a hidden gem and I would agree.
author: Katerina T.

description:
I'm really torn between 3 and 4 stars...I'll go with 4 since I can't really blame them for being kind of a trek to get to. 
I liked the atmosphere a lot. Drinks were superb. I had a rum daiquiri of sorts, followed by a lemon martini (not quite a lemondrop, but close) and a few sips of my friend's espresso martini. 

I went with 5 other girls, so I got to taste quite a bit of the menu. Had a bite of the salmon, which looked amazing but a teensy bit too rare in the middle.
Bread pudding was amazing but definitely glad I shared; it would've been way too rich to handle on my own. 
Brussell Sprouts were OK, but didn't even come close to the divine brussels at Laiola's! 
Crab cakes were yummy w/ a dill aioli. 
Delish maple creme brulee!

Our waitress was great. My only complaint is that we didn't see her enough. Had to wait a few times to order food and cocktails but in her defense, I don't think it was her fault. It was very busy and maybe she had too many tables? 

Cool spot, I'm curious about their brunch and to compare their Red Flannel Hash to the one we serve at Presidio Social Club.
author: Kelly K.

description: Organized a birthday celebration for my wife and 12 friends here.  The evening went flawless, from the cocktails to the food to the atmosphere.  Well done Serpentine.  Thanks.
author: Blake R.

description:
The menu is a bit different. This is the place to go when you're tired of ordering eggs florentine. 

*baked eggs: loved the brussel sprouts and herb cream. filling but  light enough that you don't feel crappy afterwards.
*flannel hash: the beef brisket was perfect. heavier though, because of the fried potatoes.
*buckwheat pancakes: not so much. I appreciated the difference between Serpentines menu and others, but when it comes to sweet, I still want my french toast and Belgian waffle. And, I'd like to put the syrup on myself, else it gets soggy.
*coffee: excellent.

Bottom line: I'd go back.
author: Mehul P.

description:
all i have to say is BLTA. i dream of this. crispy bacon, smooth avocado, aioli... dear god. i seriously crave this.

fries are excellent and so are the arnold palmers. really a good place to come have a great meal with good conversation.

i've also been with a huge group and the service and food was still excellent even though there was more than a dozen of us in addition to the normal lunchtime crowd.
author: laura f.

description: I just had lunch here today. We had made reservations and everything went smoothly with really great service. I had the savory bread pudding and it was fantastic! A+! The Dogpatch is really coming up in the world!!
author: Dana H.

description: Great food, great cocktails, great help. Had an awesome server nice guy. All in all I would recommend hitting this place up.  Great salads and burgers ( they have fancier stuff).
author: Atom H.

description: The menu is really good. I've eaten both at the bar and in the main dining area. The place actually isn't that big so when we wanted a table, I was glad I booked a reservation. The service also is great. There was a large party next to my table but our server still checked in with us regularly. And when I wanted to order dessert to take home, they were able to package the ice cream for me, too. It's definitely a great locals spot.
author: Ingrid R.

description: I've been here for brunch and most recently, dinner.  I had a fantastic time!  For dinner, I enjoyed how our server explained what went into each dish we ordered and how it would be cooked.  The place was crowded, but despite that, she took her time with each table.  Service at its best!  I had osso bucco and it did not disappoint!  Please visit Serpentine and you and your stomach will be satisfied!!
author: Stacey C.

description:
I doubt we'll go back.  Four of us went on Saturday night, and we were all unimpressed.  Two people had the little gems salad, and both agreed it wasn't good.  It had great potential with such simple, beautiful ingredients -- it just had no flavor.  Maybe try a different little gems supplier?  The menu said it came with a "blue cheese dressing," but we detected nothing of the sort.  This salad was a giant disappointment.  

Then, on to the main course, the hangar steak was cooked perfectly, and had a nice pepper crust, but the meat itself was so salty it was inedible.  Our friend ate a few bites and refused to eat any more.  The sea bass surely started as a beautiful piece of fresh fish, but it too was disappointing.  It was way overcooked to the point of being dry and tasteless.  How can fava beans, cherry tomatoes, olives, and romaine hearts have no flavor?  Somehow, at Serpentine, they did...and they added nothing to an already overcooked, tasteless piece of fish.  The sea bass was a giant waste of otherwise great ingredients.

The highlight of the meal was several delicious cocktails, including a mojito that everyone said was "perfect."  The Russian River Red Pinot Noir was also good.  Our server was professional and attentive.  We all had nothing but compliments for our server. 

But the food was so bad that we said no to dessert and we got our check and left.  My suggestion is to avoid Serpentine.  With so many good restaurants within a mile of this place, why bother?
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Excellent decor. For some reason, the reviews I read made me think this was some cavernous, industrial space -- not so. It's standard issue SF / CHI / NYC  urban hip restaurant decor. 

I recommend everything we had: the savory bread pudding was like a rich mac & cheese -- utter comfort food. Foodies would probably say the white radichio salad was too salty, but my detroit-bred tastebuds were fine with it. The crispy oysters and white shrimp (fried) were delectable. The burger was a solid gourmet offering.

Espresso: A.
Cocktails: B+ (i had the Martinez)
Service: attentive without hovering, stealthy to the point of being ninja-like.
author: John M.

description:
Great new place in an area that needs all the help it can get.  The space is lovely... someone put a lot of care into the decor and it shows.  I didn't like the metal tables (loud, cold) but besides that, no complaints.  We went for lunch... savory bread pudding w/ nettles and pesto to start (which was okay, a little... monotonous or something after a few bites)... roast beef for me (yummy) and a burger for the 'spund (burgery).  Why people order burgers when they aren't in their car on HWY 5 is kind of beyond me, but I guess I did marry the guy, after all.  Anyway.  

For dessert we had an Earl Grey pot de creme, interesting take on the concept.  The server was organized and knowledgeable... I hate it when I ask for a wine suggestion and they say, "let me get you the list."  No, my food is sitting here, you see it and should know what will go well with it if you know your list well... so just suggest something.  He suggested a lovely young Rioja that went perfectly with my dish.  

Only slightly odd thing was the portion sizes.  My 'spund had the bread pudding last week and said it was half the size it was this time... and my beef dish was decidely the mini-version of the same dish at the next table.  It was plenty for me; I was horrified when my neighbor's dish came out and dreading a half-cow-portion when my turn came, but mine was back down to a normal 8-10 oz or so.  Looks like the kitchen needs a little fine tuning there.

So, definatly try them out.  If they're doing this well after only a few months around, they'll be great in a year.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
As everyone has gushed about the bread pudding....it is pretty darned good.  i got it with the veggies (less impressive addition that kicks your bill up by $5--quite a lot for what you get....i thought they would be baked in, but instead it was a leaf salad with vinaigrette dressing and steamed buttered mini carrots.  

I will gush about the flank steak that comes with pureed celery root.  As one person in our party put "it's like someone left a butter flavored cloud on my plate."  And that it was.  The flank steak was really well cooked, minimal fat, great flavor that made use of the amazing meat.  

The duck was allegedly heavenly, as well.  That member ate it right up! without even offering anyone else a try, which should tell you a bit about how good it was.  

But some of the other suggestions, well, less impressive.  The whiskey smash was so much a girlie drink, it should have come with a paper umbrella and a maraschino cherry it was so damned sweet.  Not very many guts either.  The drink was also so watered down, i think i actually hydrated myself. The wine list is pretty impressive though, with a good smattering of choices in each category of wine.  Some reasonable, some a special treat (but not too special).  

We didn't try the most recommended treat (the earl grey creme brulee), but the lemon tart with marshmallows felt like a cheap combo.  At least it made the lemon tart part feel cheap.  Not that it was badly prepared, it's just that marshmallows have a distinct flavor that took from the experience for some reason.  

Our waiter swooshed his rump and pivoted like the best runway model.  And everyone was attentive.  Wine was quickly refilled, he was super fast with pretty much everything, and knew when to make his presence known and also was nice enough to ask us if we were going to hang out and talk or we'd like to pay (we were there later in the evening).

In all, it's a nice place that has a really nice ambience, without being too loud or too poorly lit.  Most of the menu is what you'll see on every SanFran menu:  prather ranch burgers, steaks, a pasta dish, though not much in the way of vegetarian fare.  But their diversions from the norm are top drawer.
author: Andrea C.

description:
My gf and I went to Serpentine for our 1 year anniversary last night. She lives in Dogpatch so it was wonderful to walk around the corner to a great restaurant. 

1. Rhum Punch - frickin best I've ever had. Way better than the Slanted Door Rhum Punch. 

2. $13 Burger was perfect. French fries that came with were fresh, slim and crispy. Not oily at all. Delightful!

3. My GF/BFF had the CA Sea Bass. She said it was delish.

4. Did I mention the Rhum Punch was frickin wonderful! Like Xmas in July. We ordered two and could have two more.

5. Wait staff was attentive. Couldn't have asked for better service.

Tuesday night dinner in the Dogpatch? Couldn't recommend dinner at Serpentine more highly. We'll be going back often.

Seriously, order the Rhum Punch. It's earned that extra "h"
author: eric P.

description:
Yum! Everything was flavorful, tender, delicious. Great for the price. 

Tried the biscuits and gravy for brunch. Biscuits were great, unusually flaky and creative (vs traditional). The gravy was just salty. The pancakes were wonderful - substantial, thick, grainy texture - and I don't normally like pancakes.
author: Aiko S.

description: Tonight was my first time dining at Serpentine- it was certainly delicious! Definitely try the shaved vegetable salad, chickpea calamari, and the oh so good burger. The service was nice and attentive, next time I want to try one of their drinks and a dessert. The location is a little off the grid, but luckily I live nearby!
author: Grace C.

description:
I hadn't even heard of Serpentine until my cousin told me that we were going there for brunch with friends one lovely Sunday. It's in a pretty cool spot and the inside is very open and light. 

Anywho, we got the delicious buckwheat pancakes (candied walnuts, bananas, and whip cream...you really can't go wrong there!) and then I got the fried egg sandwich, which I loved. I can't remember what everyone else got, but I do know that we all left full and happy!
author: renata L.

description: We had reservations and still had to wait 45 minutes for our table.  Overpriced for not much food.  The gnocchi was tasty but the rabbit was not.
author: Stacie F.

description: One of my favorite brunch spots in the city.  Cool, hip atmosphere and none of the lines and mechanical service you find elsewhere in the city like at Mama's.  Just good, classic American brunch deliciousness.
author: Jori P.

description:
I will get right to the point. I never take the time to write reviews. But I felt I must for this place. Its my local and I go all the time.

1. Food is wonderful - the gnocchi and the hanger steak are superb
2. Service if way above par - this is my local and they keep info on where you like to sit and are always happy to reserve you a bar table if they are booked out. The staff are extremely friendly and attentive
3. The decor and ambience are great - exposed brick, high ceilings
4. Its across the street from the friendliest wine bar around - Check out Yield for pre or post drink

In my opinion, those not rating this 4-5 stars, might just be they types that just can't be pleased.
author: Kathleen M.

description: love the ambiance, high exposed brick walls.  though it is always cold inside due to said cool ambiance.  the food is very good. the veggie burger was outstanding. the service is atrocious however. at least it was on monday (MLK day) during lunchtime. it appeared none of the wait staff worked in unison at all. it took someone at least 15 minutes to come over and even bring us water, and the waiter seemed more interested in sashaying around in his satin vest than actually serving us. the food took at least 30 minutes, and when someone (not our server) came by 20 mins later and asked me if id like another coffee, i said yes but it never came. they did take it off the bill, but the server was all over the place and seemed very unorganized and very unfocused. the food IS very good, and luckily we had 90 minutes to spare, but don't make any plans.
author: Kat R.

description: Serpentine is a fantastic neighborhood gem.  The servers are painfully friendly and helpful as you navigate the farm to table options of the night.  Pork Osso Bucco, hanger steak, and halibut were very tasty options, but the starter shaved spring veggie salad was the superstar.  Wines are well selected (but the pour isn't very generous for a $9-12 glass price).  Fresh made cocktails shine as well.
author: Wino K.

description: Cosy fun place with a friendly staff and seemingly good menu -- as it turns out everything we ordered from salad to burger to linguine was over salted.
author: Reza A.

description:
We had mixed reactions about this place. We really wanted to like it and after walking 2.6 miles from Union Square to get there, we were hungry enough to be generous but it just didn't mesh.  The area, dog patch, is interesting enough and unique enough to be intriguing. After walking through a mile of a literal no-man's land of parking lots and empty lots, we got to this area of kind of warehouse like businesses and then this little downtown. There's a bar down the street, and ice cream store across the street and a couple of coffee shops (that close up early, however). All seem relatively new and we were kind of excited to be exploring a new neighborhood. Serpentine itself has a kind of cold, concrete, metal feel to it. High ceilings and small space with a bar (the stools looked very uncomfortable) and some tables up front split by the bathrooms and a few tables in the rear. We were seated up front next to another table for two, with two empty tables to our right (along a banquette like seating area). A big table for 10 was being seated right across from us.  The waiter was attentive, almost to much so.  We like slow meals, we like to finish our drinks and take our time over the menu, and perhaps unfairly, we like the waiter to figure this out.  This waiter did not and even after I specifically said we do not want the food to come until we finish the drinks, the food came too soon. I said it again and the next couple of courses slowed down.
The cocktails we started with were good and interesting. I had . . . and we also had a drink with a cinnamon rim which was unusual but good.  We also had a glass of wine and a second cocktail, with tequila.  We ordered the fried, salted little peppers to start. These were tasty (but nothing compared to the similar dish at A16).  Two pieces of bread and butter were brough then. The bread was flavorful and good.  Our next course was fresh tomato salad with pecorino, I believe. This we give mixed reviews. Some of the tomatoes were good while others seemed a bit old, mushy and cold (as if they'd been in the fridge). It was quite a disappointment everytime we'd bite into one of those. Then we had gnocchi with fresh oregano and tomato. It was exceptionally tasty but a strong bite from the fresh oregano, something some people might not like.  We ate this very slowly, hoping to slow down the next course. The wait staff came by the table lots (it's almost as if they have too many wait people). They were constantly trying to clear things and it was disruptive.  Keep away from the table for a while already!
After the gnocchi, we had smoked goat, that they smoke on the premises, and their hamburger on an egg bun with french fries.  The goat was very tasty but for some it might be too gamy. The hamburger was cooked medium rare as we requested, but parts of the outside were so seared they were inedible (and hard as rocks).  The french fries were good.  
In the middle of our meal, the host asked us if we could please move to a table at the end of the banquette so they could seat a larger party using our table and one next to it.  He explained he'd comp one of our drinks. We said fine, and moved down.
We passed on the desserts and finished up our drinks.  When we got the bill, it was inaccurate but the waiter realized it and brought us the accurate one before we even said anything. But, in addition on that second bill the drinks weren't comped. But, we didn't want the hassle of complaining about it and it wasn't like it was a huge pain to move, but it did seem indicative of the general lack of training, maybe?, of the staff?  Overall, the experience was fine and maybe we'll be back. But given it's location, in the middle of nowhere, it would probably have taken a more positive overall experience to make us go through the hassle to go again.
author: Vivek V.

description:
"Do you do BRUNCH?"

I learned that, no matter how many times you ask, waiters cannot suddenly make a restaurant start serving brunch.  One of my dining companions was convinced that Serpentine would make a great brunch place so he asked every single person if the restaurant is open for weekend brunch (multiple times).  

Fortunately, the staff at Serpentine was very friendly and they all entertained his inquiries.  "Sorry, no, but we hope to soon."  "Um, no, we don't have eggs florentine for you tonight."

All that aside, our meal at Serpentine was delish and educational!  I learned what a sunchoke was since they were shaved onto my escarole salad and I lapped up my egg noodle with beef brisket dish.  One of my dining companions had a tasty roasted squash salad and a very yummy lamb t-bone.  The other dining companion feasted on a warm potato and shrimp salad and ate all around the little tiny bones of his stuffed quail (or pajarito, as the bus boy called it).

But the star of the meal - the superstar diva, if you will - was the SAVORY BREAD PUDDING (with nettles, roasted onions and swiss cheese).  We all shared this delightful little dish and swooned with pleasure...

I can't wait to go for brunch!
author: Marcus C.

description:
DELICIOUS!  Great servers, hostess and atmosphere.  The hush puppies and fried oysters were fair, after all I have lived in the south for a while. This is why they lost one star.

P.S.

When looking for the bathroom, look up...I almost walked into the ladies room.
author: Geoffrey B.

description:
Serpentine was good, but not great. 

Excellent service, especially one smiley woman (you're at work, lady!?). The bar stools and the waiting area and the hall through which waiters rush hot plates occupy one and the same space, but once we sat down I felt less cramped. 

I loved the Pinot Blanc (can't remember the name), loved the arugula salad (minus bacon). The bread pudding was decadent but too rich to finish. My Alaskan cod was beyond tender, but its surroundings (orzo I think?) were super bland. The Earl Grey pot de creme was a good gimmick but it didn't last through the bowl. 

Overall an excellent place to be taken to dinner, but not somewhere I'm rushing to reserve when I'm on my own dime.
author: Liz G.

description: I had the Numan burger and peach and nectarine salad and it was absolutely delicious!!  Topped it off with the banana ice cream sandwich and I almost died and went to heaven!! Maybe it was the Bi-Rite banana ice cream (?)  At any rate, great restaurant and the prices was reasonable.  The only drawback is looking for parking on the streets.
author: j m.

description:
Went here for Brunch with friends and had a wonderful time. My husband and a friend had the Burger and said it was one of the best they've had in the city! Another friend had the eggs benedict which looked amazing.
All in all, fantastic food and very fairly priced. We will be returning.
author: Amanda T.

description: Consistency is Key and Serpentine knows it. They are serious about their burgers too! Service is very good and food is also very good. Menu doesn't change very often, but I guess that's because they research their food thoroughly in order to be consistent with their quality. I'll take that over frequently changing menu's with varying degrees of success. Getting in without reservations during meal times can be challenging as can the noise level... but hey, I like their food!
author: gary a.

description:
There's a lot to like about this place-- elegant simple space with a menu that is both affordable and quality and a wine list with some nice choices.  We did dinner for 5 with wine and got out of there with a generous tip at about 50 bucks a person.  Not many places in town you can do that.  
Service was attentive with good menu and wine advice.  It was a great night.
author: George N.

description: Went there for lunch with a friend the other day. I had a savory bread pudding that sounded so good on the menu but it was bland and a bit dry. I also ordered a butternut squash soup that came with a drizzle of hot oil in it -- the peppery taste was too much, overwhelming the delicious squash taste. My friend had a pretty good salad. We both agreed that the cuisine isn't quite up to expectations.
author: Casey C.

description: Fantastic! Food was delicious and unique (not your typical "beets & goat cheese salad" here). Great service, reasonable prices and fun atmosphere.
author: Kirsten B.

description: We came there to celebrate my buddy's birthday towards the end of December. Our food was a pleasant surprise. The Prather Ranch hamburger is on par w/ Nopa's hamburger. As requested my hamburger came out a true medium. The meat patty was moist and succulent and the acme roll was crunchy. The meat board and the pan seared Petaluma chicken livers are a must. They were absolutely delectable. I'm salivating as I write this review. Not surprisingly, the birthday was satisfied and conceded that we should visit this establishment again.
author: Richard L.

description: Good place for dinner, but even better for brunch!  Highly recommend the country fried steak, the red flannel hash, and the salmon eggs benedict.   A neighborhood gem.  Also, the restaurant itself is architecturally cool, a converted warehouse type building.
author: Jordan W.

description: I give too many things 4 stars because there are so many  houses of dee-lish in San Francisco.  This place is no exception.  Serpentine is fabulous.  I was introduced to Serpentine by my cool, new co-workers and grabbed lunch.  The place was packed, the service was friendly but, not invasively so and they had a wide array of appetizers, drinks, dishes to choose from.  It was hard to pick something because everything sounded good.  I ended up going with the Spring Pea Risotto.  Crisp, green peas nested in creamy - oniony risotto with herbed spring pea foam around the edge.  I ate it too fast, which means ((ah, pity)) I shall have to go back and try the rest of the menu.
author: Gwen P.

description:
We dropped by Serpentine last night as we live not too far away. At 8pm on a Friday night the place was full and the wait for a table long; the place had a nice buzz about it. My wife and I managed to score a couple of stools at the bar and ate there, which we actually prefer to do. I quite liked the space though its a bit smaller than I thought it would be. The decor is industrial and minimalist with lots of concrete and pillars, soaring ceilings and low lighting.

It took us quite a while to be served at the bar which was a bit annoying as we had to sit there like statues trying to catch someone's eye. All it takes is a nod of acknowledgement to let us know we've been seen and you'll get to us when you can; but alas nary a nod nor a  smile were to be had for quite a while. 

Eventually we were able to get our orders in - we shared the carrot puree soup to start while I had the stuffed quail and my wife the flat iron steak for mains (they had run out of the beef short ribs which is what she originally ordered). The soup was quite nice - hearty and wholesome. The highlight of the night was the quail - juicy sweet and tender, contrasted by bits of smoky bacon which were part of the stuffing. It also came with a beautifully soft butternut squash mash with grilled broccoli. The flat iron steak however was chewy and didn't have any taste. I forget what came with it as the dish was not worth remembering.

The service did improve once we got over the initial impasse and in general we had a good time. The food overall was good and I would go back again as I hope the poor quality of the steak was simply because it was a rushed substitute for the sold out beef ribs. I had heard the food can be a bit hit or miss, and that seemed to be the case. Thankfully its not something that cannot be fixed.
author: Nam D.

description:
Went to Serpentine this weekend with my friend from Chicago. We had a reservation for a table but ended up sitting at the bar, I love the bar, and it was perfect. 

Their greuner veltliner white wine is sooo good and crisp and fresh and was perfect with what we ordered. We opted for soup and a tasting menu of their appetizers. The carrot soup was sublime. Then we had the heirloom chickory salad, yum, and the warm shrimp and potato salad. It was not at all what I expected, had a sort of mole type sauce, but I really liked it. We got the oysters at the end (I think the bartender forgot to order them) and although they were tasty I was not really that into them because I thought they were going to be fresh and they were fried. I think I read the menu wrong. 

All together though we had a lovely time and I highly recommend it! It also seems like a really good date place.
author: sarah k.

description:
My husband and I headed to Serpentine on a recent Saturday, and had a great experience there.  This is a restaurant that feels like it has always been a part of the neighborhood, and due to the closeness of the tables to each other it's very easy to get to know your neighbors if you so choose.  However, the real draw is the food.

Serpentine has a great, creative menu that is both well-executed and which features delicious local ingredients.  Besides creativity in pairing of flavors, they use some top-notch local meats such as Marin Sun Farms pork and Prather Ranch beef, yum!  Besides being won over by the meats, we were further won over by Serpentine's savory bread pudding, a dish not meant to be relegated to the dessert menu.

We'll definitely be heading back to Serpentine.
author: Jennifer V.

description:
I went here with a big group of people for dinner one Saturday night. I give this place extra bonus points because we were able to make a reservation for 11 people 3 hours beforehand. The place isn't that big but they were able to fit a big party in. 

One of my friends said that previous Yelp reviews mentioned the pork belly but the waiter was honest enough to tell us that it was the size of an appetizer and that we might want to order a side dish as well to make a meal out of it. I was deterred by that comment and ended up ordering the hanger steak; about 3/4 of my party ordered the burger. The burger was a big, hearty size and was served with shoestring french fries, which were really good. My steak was good as well. However, I ordered it medium and it felt as though the meat went from medium-rare to medium as I ate from one end of the steak to the other. The sauce was good but the rest of the veggies didn't stand out to me. I liked the dish overall, though. 

My friends and I had a good time here, catching up and eating. It was a nice atmosphere and the wait staff were really nice and attentive, especially with our big party.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
It is official. I am a fan of Serpentine. Having been out of the country for the last eight months traveling to countries where beef is not high on the food choices where did I want to go to get some of the  beast, or should I say feed the beef craving? It had to be  Serpentine, and it had to be the burger. 

It exceeded by my rather beef deprived memories, and it certainly met all my cravings. So juicy, the right amount of juices, the right color red, and the perfect flavor. Thank you, oh thank you!  Will be back in the summer as soon as I permanently return.

Oh and before I forget  - the brussell sprouts!  Oh baby, we have come a long way from the boiled greens of my childhhood days (think UK and boil baby boil back in the 70s!). Who knew sprouts could be so delicious exciting?

Loved everything, and this place is on my "must make the trek up from the burbs often" for.
author: Sue N.

description: Nice menu choices.   Friendly service.  Good location (Dog Patch).  Waiter recommended fish, yet my partner thought it wasn't very good...over cooked.   My gniocchi was good but maybe a tad salty.      Overall:  "Good" but not "Very Good".
author: Roger S.

description:
Just had a great meal at Serpentine.
Food is seasonal so it pays to think ahead about what might be in season and order accordingly.
The menu included "crunchy grass Shrimp" - a new one for me.  The shrimp were shell-on, small, crunchy, and very flavorful. Excellent.
Fried oysters were not on the menu tonight, but they have been consistently amazing. They are a must-have if available.
The chef uses Anson Mills grains (oats, polenta, grits).  This may not sound like a big deal, but the difference between Anson Mills and other grains is night and day.
Regrettably the deserts are not at the same caliber.
author: Christyan M.

description: Too rarely do i get on here to leave good ratings.  This place deserves it though!  A really nice dinner with good cocktails and friendly service.
author: adam m.

description: My favorite spot in the Dogpatch to sit at the bar and have a late dinner.
author: Geoffrey C.

description:
Serpentine was A-OK.  Hue L., our non-yelper friend, and I had 8:00pm reservations on a Friday night.  We were a little late because we took the scenic route to get there, but parking was no problem whatsoever.  We got a prime parking spot right across the street.  I had only just recently discovered the Dogpatch neighborhood after being introduced to Axis Cafe and am eager to try more places here.

Serpentine is located in an old warehouse, I believe.  It's a very industrial looking building and the decor inside goes with that.  We were seated right away in a cute little booth when we arrived and our server was very nice.  

As for food, we shared the Chickpea Battered Calamari and the Braised Grass-Fed Lamb Meatballs.  I liked the meatballs.  They were tasty.  They came four to the dish, so I got two, while Hue L. and our non yelper friend had one each.  The calamari was good.  It wasn't as breaded as most fried calamari is and not as crunchy.  It has a softer texture, but was still very good.  For my entree, I ordered the House Made Potato Gnocchi, because I love gnocchi!  It didn't look like much on the plate, but it was super duper filling.  Hue L. ordered the Prather Ranch Hamburger which came with fries.  He was getting really full, but still managed to stuff the whole burger in his mouth.  His only complaint was that it was a bit salty.  That might've been because he requested blue cheese.  He thought they were just going to put blue cheese crumbles on it, but they put a whole slab of cheese on it.
