Our non-yelper friend ordered the Braised Eden Farms Berkshire Pork Osso Bucco, which was totally huge and she managed to finish the whole thing.  She said it was very good.  Even after being totally stuffed, we decided to all split one dessert.  I believe we decided on the Salted Caramel Pot de Creme with Earl Grey Shortbread Cookies.  The Pot de Creme was good, but I was not a fan of the shortbread cookies.  The Earl Grey taste was overwhelming.  Probably because I'm not an Earl Grey fan.

Overall, a very good experience.  I'd like to come back to try out brunch.
author: Kris L.

description: Had a wonderful dinner last month and the staff was awesome. They let us hog a table for the whole evening. The vibe was great and so was the food.
author: Dave L.

description: Came here last night for "date night" with the boyfriend and it was well worth the drive out here!  In addition to the free parking, the atmosphere is intimate, yet modern.  Our server was right on; not too anxious or obnoxious.  We enjoyed both of our wines and started with the calamari, which was delicious; I had the fragrant and yummy yellowtail and my boyfriend had the tender and juicy chicken.  Definitely will be back!
author: Sheri H.

description:
I've been to Serpentine twice now.  It's a cool industrial space with high ceilings and lots of natural light.

My first visit I had a savory bread pudding and the rest of my table ordered burgers. Both items were great. The bread pudding tasted delicious and flavorful - though it was so rich that I couldn't finish it. But that's bread pudding for you :P Three of us ordered cocktails and I think we all agreed 1/3 was really good and the rest were ok.

The second time we ordered the Shaved Spring Squash Salad which was also pretty good. Unfortunately the entrees this time brought my average rating down. I had the Alaskan Wild Sockeye Salmon and my boyfriend had House Made Potato Gnocchi. The salmon was 2-star worthy :(  The fish was overcooked and rubbery instead of soft and melting in your mouth. The gnocchi was better, but they sat amongst porcini mushrooms which were also firm and rubbery. We had a decent dessert of warm almond cake to end the meal. I won't be rushing back, but I wouldn't mind giving this place a try for brunch. Seems like you just have to do some careful ordering.
author: Sushmita S.

description:
Sadly, I have to downgrade my initial review of this place.  My husband and I live in Dogpatch and we loved Serpentine until last night.  We usually dine here once every month or so.  It used to be our "special place" in the 'hood we would bring friends.  I can't even relay the disappointment in the food quality and presentation.

First, I noticed that several months ago the bread pudding presentation changed.  Now it is off the menu entirely.

Second, my favorite cocktail changed names and ingredients.  I have a suspicion that there has been a major (unannounced) change in the kitchen.

Third, unlike other times we dined here, the entree menu hardly changed from out last visit.  Which is not impressive.  We ordered the calamari and it was cold and greasy and the batter fell off.  I ordered the chicken and it underwhelmed: way too much thyme seasoning.  My husband ordered the mushroom gnocchi and the broth that it was drowning in tasted like mushroom water left over from reconstituting dried mushrooms.

Fourth, why is this restaurant dead on a Friday night in December?  We are in the beginning of the holiday party season and this place is usually JAMMED on any other Friday evening we have dined here.

Sadly, the restaurant has been crossed off our list of restaurants to return.
author: Linda B.

description: Yummy, yummy, yummy!  I went with a big group and resounding thumbs up for many different dishes ordered including the savory bread pudding, benedict, hash and some tasty bloody mary's.  Well worth a return!
author: Amanda S.

description: Very tasty brunch food (particularly the beef hash) marred by needlessly unfriendly service. News flash: No, you're not too good to smile and ask how the food is, whether we need anything else, etc., just because you're a trendy restaurant in the Dogpatch.
author: Geoffrey U.

description:
My partner and I went to Serp. last night.  We live near Slow Club, their sister restaurant, and have been there over 10 times in the past year.  We wanted to try Serpentine out.  

As a vegetarian, I was happy to see more than one option.  Most places offer a simple risotto and that's it.  The entree I had (egg noodles with goat cheese, fiddleheads and peppers) was great.  I even asked them to go light on the cheese and they listened.  My partner was very happy with his duck.

Downsides:

1.  It was HOT out last night.  It seemed even more warm in the restaurant.  Many diners were visibly uncomfortable.  

2.  The wine list.  Too many so-so wines that were overpriced.

Overall, a great place though!
author: Timothy S.

description:
My girl and I went last weekend. Friday night- it was crowded but we had a reservation and were seated right away. Didn't find it too loud for conversation.

The food was right on. Not a dish we didn't like and the service was great. Friendly, efficient but not overbearing. 

I definitely recommend it.
(oh yeah-  parking is plentiful)
author: Dan k.

description: Just moved to the neighborhood and I had heard great things about this restaurant. As a former chef, I pride myself on being a SF Foodie. I had a couple great items, and equally a couple less desirable ones. The appetizer & and first course salad were great and excited both my boyfriend and I for the main courses to come. However our gnocchi and main course dishes leaved very much to be desired. I may consider trying again, but ONLY because it's so close to my home and there isn't much to choose from within walking distance. Hopefully since the menu changes regularly it was just an off-night... ?
author: Maria M.

description:
Great Brunch for the money, you'll spend more on the fabulous cocktails. They always win.

Evening menu has changed and improved with better selections. The service is always top shelf, from the hostess to the waiters and bartenders, and Chef Deep will come out from time to time to check on things and answers the most annoying questions with passion and interest e.g. "how do you make / what is headcheese?"
author: mc b.

description: Went here for lunch yesterday and it was so good! The food looked simple, but had some very surprising flavors that really made it somewhere I will go back to again and again.
author: Pam J.

description: I don't go many places for brunch that I would rave about. This one is an exception. Great coffee and easy parking which are important in a brunch spot that you have to drive to.  It is kinda expensive...but everything I've tried has been yum town. Esp. that Hibiscus Fizz. Danger. This could make you lay around in the park the rest of the afternoon and not get those errands done! bwahahaha
author: Marianne s.

description: Cute little restaurant and good service. Came here on a double date, meaning great company, great food. Got the calamari, oysters, meat plate for apps and shared the chicken w/ Brussel sprouts and bacon-yummy! don't remember if we got dessert, so if we did it must have not been that good since i don't remember.....
author: Karen H.

description: We always have a great meal here, which makes us wonder "Why don't we come here more often?" The salads are to-die-for. Inventive, lots of veggies and not just the usual ingredients. Great entrees. We love it.
author: Michele H.

description: A funny little place that okay food and awkward but cute service.
author: S W.

description: This has got to be one of my favorite brunch spots in the city.  The food is fantastic and very fresh.  We just had a reunion there and they were great!
author: She-Rae C.

description: Love Serpentine. Went here last weekend with some friends for brunch. The wait wasn't long at all since we sat at the bar. Bartender was awesome. Friendly and on point. I ordered the Crab Benedict and helllllo! Can we say foodgasm? Totally yummy. I want more.
author: Maricel B.

description: After readng about SFist raving about this, and wanting a good burger around here, I headed out to the Dogpatch (what sort of name is this for a neighbourhood, but I digress) and this place. The burger wasn't bad. It wasn't good either. Maybe "Medium well" means something different overseas? It was a very dry burger. The price wasn't bad, though. Of course, my favourite place remains Yield, which is across 3rd. I may give this place another try and update my review accordingly.
author: Hasan D.

description: One of my colleagues suggested this spot for lunch. I honestly wouldn't have noticed this restaurant because it is in a block that has alot of warehouses.  Parking is always challenging during the day, so if possible take Muni it stops right across the street (T Line...next stop after UCSF Mission Bay going away from AT&T park).  Serpintine has trendy decor and soft colors that are pleasing to the eye. It's cozy, so come early and be prepared to move your table in and out a few times to let patrons around you "squeeze" into their table. I had the roasted corn soup (which was absolutely scrumptious) and one of the burgers (nice as well).   Based on the food, I would definitely recommend checking this restaurant out. They have a nice lunch menu, and I'm not sure what their dinner service is like, but would go back to give it a try. Great for a pair, and up to 3-4 people at a time. Like i said this place is cozy, so don't bring your whole possey up here thinking they can create a miracle. They CAN'T! Lol...
author: Anisha W.

description: Wow! I had a spectacular dinner here the other night. I went with a couple of girlfriends and we did family style, so we got to sample a bunch of different things. I think my favorite dish was the savory bread pudding, but everything we ordered was amazing - arancini, butternut squash and spinach lasagna, the best brussel sprouts EVER!! I also loved dessert. A light as air strawberry and almond cake. And mint chip ice cream sandwich. Yum! I can't wait to go back!
author: Caitlin L.

description: Fantastic brunches and great atmosphere.  The only problem is that it is all the way out in the dog patch.  If you go for brunch you must try the savory bread pudding or the beef hash...
author: David A.

description: Dinner was pretty good here. I had a medium-rare burger and they cooked it to perfection. We also had oysters for appetizers, and those were just as delicious. Overall, it was a good experience, and I would definitely recommend this place to my friends. It's a hidden gem that I would never have visited were it not for my friend who works in the area.
author: Ty L.

description:
Great experience, soup to nuts (I had neither soup nor nuts).

Nothing on the menu is totally unconventional -- salmon and rice, meats, potatoes, etc -- but the things we ordered, if simple, were simply delicious. And subtle aspects of the preparation told you they cared. The wild arugula salad rode from four stars to five on the backs of fresh raspberries, and the hamburger with bleu cheese was, for lack of a better word, dope. My date had the 'little gems' salad and the beef tartare (and a dirty martini -- she's out of my league).

With our main courses, we drank a reasonably priced 'A to Z' Pinot Noir, recommended by our waitress as an 'easy red.' Perfect for an 'unqualified diner.'

From the hostess to the bartendress to the waitress, the service was quick, helpful, and friendly. Quite friendly, actually: our waitress's eye-contact habits as well as her conception of personal space were more, well, intimate than some others'.

But now I'm just nit-picking. Five stars.
author: Ben S.

description: Lunch date with a good friend.  Great atmosphere and surprisingly busy for a Wednesday afternoon - but not overcrowded. Ordered the Handmade Trofie Pasta (basil & mint pesto - cherry tomatoes - fennel confit - roasted cipollini onions - grana padano).  It was good but not great, slightly too salty but overall was still a good dish. My friend ordered the Housemade Veggie Burger (chickpea patty - swiss cheese - sauteed mushrooms - caramelized onions - little gems -special sauce) and thought is was quite delicious. I also tried a few of the fries that came with her veggie burger, the fries were fantastic.  Overall, I would visit again, it's a great spot for lunch - and I would love to check it out for dinner as well.
author: Kavita M.

description: Wholesome well prepared food, modern vibe, cool service and parking!  Dined at dinner and brunch and brought first time fussy foodie friends.   Both times got a thumbs up!
author: Kim D.

description: I love this place.  Food is fresh and well seasoned.  Cocktails are delicious!  Service is friendly.
author: Colleen B.

description: Recently had brunch here with a group of friends and I'm happy to say that Serpentine has now been added to my list of go-to Sunday brunch spots.  The food is very good (the House Cured Steelhead Benedict is OUTstanding!), the prices are reasonable, and the cocktail menu is... extremely dangerous when you're having brunch. Try the Hibiscus Fizz and you will know exactly what I mean.
author: Ed K.

description:
I am so glad I found this restaurant. I was searching for a place that was casual, interesting, and had a wide range of menu items. I usually search SOMA and Mission area for restaurants that appeal to my taste, so it wasn't an easy find. I hope Serpentine gets the crowds it deserves... or maybe the "hidden gem" factor is just in my mind. 

Anyways, about the food! The food was delicious with that Mediterranean style that makes you feel satisfied, healthy, and good about yourself when you leave. I loved all the seasonal aspects about the menu, and the variety of small plates made it perfect for sharing amongst our table of 3. I love being able to share plates without ordering too much, or too little. The dishes are perfect for sharing between 2-4 people, which allows you to experience the menu fully. 

The chickpea battered calamari was so delicious and extremely light, especially with the mint added to the tomato sauce. But the best was the gnocchi with peas, mushrooms and light breadcrumbs on top.The cocktail list was very fun, and was hard to choose.  I wish the had a more interesting variety of ice cream to match the desserts. 
All in all, I had an enjoyable meal, and the booths feel very private and comfortable for the small (even though very tall) space. The staff was friendly and our waiter was very accommodating, as well as quick and efficient. I'm always bothered when the waiter/waitress will linger around and have a fake enthusiasm (not that it's bad to be enthusiastic or eager, but putting on a show for guests is different).  
I encourage those far from the Dogpatch to definitely make the trek over... parking isn't difficult.....aaaasss long as there isn't a Giants game going on!
author: Alexandra a.

description: Went for lunch. Lovely place, food was good but not spectacular, i had an enjoyable time and the wait staff were attentive. Solid 4 stars.
author: Stephen C.

description:
a inconspicuous spot in potrero hill that my friends & I randomly stumbled upon.  the decor is adorable- loft-like with high ceilings.  great ambience.

I've only been for brunch but am amazed (& secretly thankful) that the crowds haven't found this place yet....

food is fresh & never disappoints!  my favs are the smoked salmon (house smoked no less!) benedict, red flannel hash & savory bread pudding.  the fries w/ garlic aioli are pretty tasty as well.

another huge plus is that weekend parking is a breeze!
author: Karen F.

description: I was very pleasantly surprised by my experience here.  Its located in a fairly gnarly neighborhood, but the place was packed.  Love the essentially industrial feel, softened by votive candles everywhere.  Food was great across the board, and great service too.  I'd definitely go back.
author: Jay M.

description:
Thankfully Dogpatch finally has a restaurant that I can take clients to! 
I have nothing bad to say, it would be 5 stars, but it can get a little loud :)
author: Julie M.

description:
This place has the best mixture of industrial and urban flavor.
Food is amazing, so delicate and delicious and wines are really good.
Well folks... this is a five stars place!!
author: stephan c.

description: I had breakfast at Serpentine the morning after my bachelorette party. I was seriously hung over, but the fried egg sandwich and a big mug of coffee helped me survive the day. So yummy and the service was great. I can't wait to go back.
author: Karin F.

description: Don't get me wrong: I love Serpentine, I really do. I've been several times and really like the food, decor, location. But it seems the service just gets worse and worse with each visit. And I think it has reached the point where it overshadows any decent dish they set down in front of me. This time, we arrived on time for our reservation for 4 people. The hostess pointed to our empty table and said she would need to just set it up. That took 10 mintues. Then she sat us without giving us menus. We waited another 10 mintues for someome to come by to offer us water and to realize we had not yet received menus. Two of us had to get up and walk to the bar to request our one and only refill on our iced tea since no one came by to check on us after we had already sat there for a long time with empty glasses. Then we had to sit there for another eternity waiting for our check. After waiting for another unacceptable period of time for someone to come run the credit card, we just got up to give it to someone. Very disappointing. AND embarrassing, might I add. I was bringing friends here to celebrate a girlfriend's birthday and felt like a schmuck for suggesting the place. Listen, I will return to Serpentine. I live in the area and do like their food quite a bit. But I will come alone and bring a book. Or perhaps do take-out. For special events, dates, or occasions when good service is imperative: go elsewhere where good food AND good service are reliable.
author: Amy K.

description:
Had brunch with friends and loved it. 

First: there's street parking! 

Second: they take reservations. 

Third, and most important: the food is delicious. I had the savory bread pudding and loved the original taste. Even the salad it came with had a subtle and tasty light dressing. I also tasted some of my friends' food and oh boy, those little fried potatoes are to die for. 

Fourth: the service is impeccable. Our cups/glasses were never empty, servers were prompt and attentive, and even quite patient as our large group lingered after paying our check (sorry...).
author: Sol V.

description: OK...but just OK.  Lot's of hype with this place, so I tried....and tried again.  It's just OK.  I wouldn't wait in line here for an hour for brunch EVER...or dinner actually.  Get a reservation and try it, but don't expect anything spectacular.  It's just another new spot with some decent options.  A tad pricey for what you get too, but that's SF for you.
author: jacob s.

description: Yet another fabulous meal at Serpentine! We ordered every salad and each one was delicious. Salmon was my entree and it was cooked and seasoned to perfection. I love that this place seems to be a hidden gem, but seriously, more people need to check this place out!
author: Plumeria P.

description: This place is top-notch. A nice iteration of its sister, Slow Club.  For some reason I've been on a real burger kick lately and this one is fantastic.  You should eat one.
author: Val U.

description: We had such a fantastic experience at Serpentine! Everything was delicious, service was exemplary, and price was ridiculously reasonable. Can't wait to try them for brunch.
author: C. M.

description:
Cool atmosphere, and we can often get a last minute reservation, even on a Friday night. Still, the place is always packed. Sitting at the bar is an acceptable alternative to a table. 

Interesting salads--the panzanella was outstanding last time, but the food is inconsistent--one time the fries were limp, another time our medium-rare burger was closer to raw-in-the-middle. They correct these minor flaws when you order to counter them, i.e. "fries extra crispy", but I don't need to go out to dinner and tutor the chef in what medium-rare should be.
author: Simone E.

description: So, I am eating my words and adding some stars.  Serpentine got its groove back.  I now enjoy taking out of towners here for dinner.  I end up here regularly for brunch when Just for You is too crowded or we feel like something a little more chi-chi.  The burger was the single most delicious thing I ate while pregnant.  The bun, which is brushed in clarified butter, is incredible.  Now that my little bun is out of the oven, I've also been impressed with the service.  Even for customers with kids.
author: Katina M.

description: Great industrial atmosphere and excellent brunch!
author: Thomas K.

description: Give me a huge scoop of the savory bread pudding and leave me in peace.  Oh, but dont forget the yummy cocktails.  And dont forget that lovely pork chop, served with a brussels sprout, apple, celery root and butternut squash hash.  And one more cocktail, please.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
nice little spot on 3rd st with hit and miss dishes.

the bartenders are really friendly.  

the miss was bringing all of my food at once and my dinnermate waited till both of his app and entree arrived at the same time after i already finished mine.

but a one time glitch i hope.

the arugula salad is a must - light and peppered with edible flowers.
the asparagus soup was a nice chill dish but not memorable
the ribs were a real miss.  soft but no substance
the lamb shoulder was much better great sauce, the small touches of tomato were a perfect acid.

so good and with great potential.
author: Anh V.

description: Great classic American/California food. Hearty portions. And the hipsters as servers are friendly, but a little too casual at times. Wonderful space with plenty of light. This place should bring you out to Dogpatch so that the area livens up a bit.
author: Scott S.

description: After my friend made several call and never got an answer we thought, hey why not just head over early and take our chances. It was a Thursday night, at 5:30 and the hostess was very surly about us getting a table without reservations. But she finally concluded that she would have a table for us in 20-30 minutes. The bar didn't have 4 seats together, so we asked if we could go across the street and come back in 20 minutes. The hostess told us she would take our cell number and call when our table was ready. After an hour we went to Hard Knocks, where the food is amazing, the menu is more extensive, the prices are fabulous, and there is no pretentious bleach blond stringing us along for a table. PS she never did call...
author: Annie D.

description: Came here for dinner on a Friday night with a friend - loved the ambiance of the restaurant very relaxed but still pretty vibrant.  The menu was simple, but it was still difficult to make a choice!  We split the calamari appetizer (incredible - with white beans and a sprinkling of olives) and I had the gnocchi for dinner.  Perfectly browned, comfort food, with a bit of flair.  I rounded out dinner with the dark chocolate cake with coconut ice cream.  The cake was surprisingly rich but not dense at all.  The service was fantastic - we were a bit late and the maitre d was very kind about seating us regardless.  All in all - wonderful food and a very good price.  The menu is changed daily - I'll definitely be back for more!
author: Jessica T.

description: Love, love, love this place. I love the fact that it's a converted warehouse We always sit at the bar Chris is awesome, but everyone there is friendly. My guy always gets the burger, but I love the meat board for openers and the olives. Last night, I had the rabbit three ways. I was literally sicking the bone, it was so good! I highly recommend this place, but make a reservation if you want a table. It's tiny, but it is SO worth it!
author: Loren S.

description: A much-needed addition to a funky hood where everyone living there (at least not yet) isn't white and driving some big-ass SUV.  The food was good (albeit heavy on the meat) and the affogato/mint dessert didn't work for me.  My drinks were crack-lickin' good and so I'm gonna give these peeps 5 stars for doing something right, even if it may take a couple times to get it perfect.
author: rerun w.

description:
Where is everyone?
Okay, so we visited here for brunch this morning and the area feels a bit like Culver City???.....in a good way.  This was my first visit to Dogpatch and I thought it was a nice, edgy and upcoming district, but was a bit surprised that there were not a lot of people hanging out.  Did I mention that locating a parking spot was oh so easy!  On THAT note, I will reel my South Bay arse back to the review.  
Decor was simple, industrial and clean.  Gotta check out the painting of the mountains just to the right of the entry - 3rd street wall.  The sunshine peeking through the window, shining across the painting made it come alive - really!
Sorry for the detour........we ordered the Eggs/Meat/Potato/Bread, Fried Egg Sandwich, Red Flannel Hash and Baked Eggs.  Everyone gave rave reviews of the dishes and combinations, the coffee was tasty and arresting and the service was extremely friendly and attentive.  
Ya just gotta go and check it out!
author: Grant T.

description: Went here for my sister's bf's fathers day. Anyway we were a big party, they were very accommodating in seating us. Very nice cocktail menu. All the dishes we had were very tasteful and delicious. Flat iron steak, salmon, chard, pork belly. Just a few if the dishes I sampled. We eat family style. I recommend.
author: Cheyenne B.

description: The baked eggs are great!  Celery is reminescent of thanksgiving stuffing, but not heavy or gross. Serpentine is a good spot to have in the hood.
author: Amar P.

description:
Mmmmmm.....burger....

Oh yeah, and the salads were great, the duck sandwich I tasted was amazing, the spaghetti special was remarkably flavorful for such a simple preparation, the service was fantastic and the atmosphere was haute and cool. 

And, did I mention the burger? With the Prather Ranch beef? The heirloom tomato? The Gruyere cheese and pickled onions? Cooked a perfect medium rare? 

Mmmmm.... burger....
author: Sage R.

description:
It's three days later and I'm still thinking about my meal. The cocktail list was intriguing from top to bottom. I went with a Violet Crush and it was tasty. After lamenting the fact that everything on the menu looked great,  I chose the haddock. I  also managed to eat all of my bf's cauliflower gratin that came with his steak. Every bite was delicious. The desert menu wasn't overly impressive, but I went with the ice cream sandwich. It was good, but nothing to write home about. 
The place was packed so it was a little bit loud, but the service was wonderful. I'm looking forward to coming back for brunch!
author: Kate O.

description: I like the interior design of this place.  However, the food was just mediocre and it seemed like they sold out of everything I wanted to get!  At least the wait staff was good and friendly.  I'd like to support this restaurant since I love the artist community it serves, the Dogpatch, but after this disappointment it would be awhile before I go back.
author: Jay A.

description:
Went here with Nathaniel R. the other day.  Gotta say - not too impressed.  The ambiance is kinda cool - kinda modern and clean, fits the neighborhood well with the industrial look, concrete pillars, sandblasted ceiling.  Food was kinda eh.  I just had the burger - sounded great - Acme bread, pickled shallots, gruyere cheese.  It was kinda dry and blah.  As Nathaniel R. detailed in his review, the chicken pot pie was so poorly executed.  It was comical to see him get a pie with a big chicken bone sticking out of it.  A+ for comedy effect, but how weird is that?

Slow club is literally down the street - IMNSHO, it seems like a way better way to go if you are choosing between the two...
author: Jon B.

description:
this place tastes like a restaurant that has gone downhill.  unfortunately, or perhaps fortunately, the place is brand spanking new, so it still has a chance.

my burger - which is perfect at Slow Club, was imperfect at Serpentine.  The bun, rock hard.  but at least the meat is identicaly seasoned as SC.

the carrot soup might have been hot, once.  but it wasn;t at our table.  twas a step above room temp.

the fiancee's steak, she claims, was hardly worth the 24 bucks.  Compare it to Luna Park and you'll race back to the safety of the mission.

the best part of the dinner - Le Fin du Monde Beer.  Try it.  go there for the beer and only the beer.  and that will help you forget when the hostess took a few extra moments with her friend who was hanging out there while could have just seated you.  perhaps you had to be there.  but then again, what's the purpose of yelp?
author: david b.

description:
My family and I went in here for a late Sunday Brunch and I was really looking forward to it. I had walked by several times and wanted to try it. It sounds like according to other reviews, maybe we should have come for dinner because the brunch was really un-remarkable. 
I loved my bloody mary and my husband's cocktail was good, but something that would have been better at night, very strong and too intense for brunch. Ok.
The food arrived. I had eggs, meat, potatoes and toast. AND THAT was exactly what I got. Frankly, why didn't I stay home and make it myself? If the sausage wasn't so overcooked it was like dull, dull, dull....maybe the dish would have redeemed itself. I didn't love the spice in it, it somehow tasted a little off and I attributed that to a spice I might not like...not sure.The eggs were great..tasted really fresh.
My son's hamburger looked anemic, really dry. He liked it enough.
My daughter's fried egg sandwich also looked like something I could make at home. It was a fried egg on a bun with arugula and avocado (which was extra). It came with potatoes.
My husband asked for some bearnaise on the side, as it was an option on another dish. It arrived completely broken and inedible. Plus, after some vigorous stirring when we tasted it, it was hollandaise not bearnaise. Lemony not made with tarragon, the essential ingredient in bearnaise....And they charged me for it.
Our bill with drinks came to $85 and I was left feeling completely fleeced. I didn't have a remarkable experience and was sorry I didn't stay home. I almost never feel this way about any restaurant but I was kind of angry. 
With other restaurants in the neighborhood that don't charge that much, I won't be coming back here.
author: Betty M.

description: one of the top contenders for best burger + fries in SF. Prather Ranch beef is so amazing - and the greens,homemade pickles, tomato, and cheddar were divine. ate every last fry....
author: Mariangela S.

description: I loved the chicken liver!  Food, location, service and ambiance were all fantastic!
author: Gran A.

description: One of my new favorite SF dining spots. Came here for the 1st time In a party of 6 to celebrate with a Xmas dinner. Loved the small, intimate, industrial, and high energy environment.the ceilings being 20 feet high give the room a much bigger feel. The warm greeting from the hostess and then the waitress started things off well. We had delicious and strong cocktails. The antique lemon cocktail and straight up martinis were  big hits. For appetizers, we had the sweet breads, fried calamari, chicken livers, marinated olives, and a seasonal salad. Everything was very fresh and delicious. For entrees, we ordered the Hangar Steak (medium rare), oven roasted chicken, pork belly with Manila clams, and the rock cod. Everyone gave big thumbs up for the dishes  especially the 2 of us who ordered the steaks. For desserts, we ordered the ice cream cookie with salted caramel and the coffee with ice cream In it. Good way to finish our great meal. Kudos on the ambiance, food, and service!!! Will bring more friends in the future!
author: H E.

description:
Wow what a find! This place was so cute and the food was amazing. My friend and I each got our own salads and shared the gnocchi! The gnocchi was probably the best I've ever tasted! The staff was really nice and the location was great (so easy to find street parking).

I'm glad we found this place. I would definitely go back!
author: Lisa G.

description: After two more visits, I'm definitely keeping Serpentine at five stars. The food has delivered every time, from the flank steak to the cod to the boullabaise. The last two visits involved dessert and the Chocolate Marquis is a plate of heaven right here on earth (and gluten-free!). The service is top-notch and very affordable overall. Last night we had dinner for five with wine, appetizers and dessert - all for $250. Very affordable for five people with such top-quality food!
author: Nissa A.

description:
Seems like the affiliation with slow club is loose at best.  We love slow club but serpentine needs major work.  We ate there tonight with friends and we were all disappointed.  Two of us ate fish, one beef cheeks, and one lamb.  The same could be said for each dish - 'holy crap is that salty'!!  WTF - salty lentils?  Get the salt out of the kitchen and get the guys from slow club in the kitchen to train the chef.  We truly hope you guys succeed but you need help asap.  With that said, the waiter, Demetris, was great and the cocktails rocked.  We'll be back in a couple months.  Finger crossed and hoping this is just growing pains.  

PS - the oysters and hush puppies are not worth trying..
author: Jason K.

description: I have been here for both dinner and brunch and both times have been wonderful. The food is delicious and the service was great. The industrial, concrete interior provides a cool and intimate place to dine. I only wish it was closer to my new neighborhood, but I'll still make it out for special treats!
author: Tiff C.

description:
I made a reservation here on Open Table for my husband's birthday.  We showed up at the appropriate time and were told that our reservation was not in the system.  I showed them my email confirmation from Open Table and was unapologetic and told us that they could seat us after 9 pm (our reservation was at 6:45!) or we could wait at the bar and see if someone didn't show up for their reservation.  The host didn't make any attempt to figure out what happened to our reservation nor did he even offer to buy us a drink as we waited almost 30 minutes.  Normally we wouldn't have bothered to stay but we were meeting a group for drinks across the street afterward.

It turned out fine, we got a table... the food was delicious and we had a good time but we definitely won't be back based on our initial incident.  It's a shame because it was a great burger!
author: Jessica W.

description:
disclosure:  slow club is my favorite resto in SF so there is potential for me to be completely biased. 

had been waiting for months for serpentine to open and finally got a chance to go last week.  i'm so thrilled to have a 2nd option to slow club (and just down the street from my office) where i can sample chris kronner's ridiculously good food.

everything we ate was delish and the atmosphere is great.  very different from the industrial chic, sleek interior at slow club.  the food, obvi, was just as good with chris at the helm.  everything was fantastic, from the hama hama oysters with hushpuppies(!) to the butternut squash bread pudding to the steelhead trout.  

like slow club, serpentine will definitely become a regular dinner stop.
author: Lija H.

description: I really like Serpentine, and it's great to see another serious addition to Potrero Hill/Dogpatch.  Located on Third St. in a spot where you'd never in a million years figure it for a restaurant, Serpentine reveals itself as both casual and intimate, with a simple menu prepared very well.  Two things stand out in my mind from my last visit:  First, I had a few fantastic glasses of wine, and second, my wife had a bread pudding that made her very happy.  Second, my wife and I--who almost never fight--got into a heated argument over campaign finance reform!  Seriously, who the hell would fight over that?  (Not that I was wrong.)  This has to have been one of the most pointless arguments of all time, but obviously, we're made for one and other, and I'm looking forward to another visit to Serpentine, so long as my wife doesn't bring up health care reform or the auto industry.
author: Ty D.

description:
3.5 stars.

I stopped by Serpentine on Sat. around 9 PM.  We didn't have a res, but found two seats at the bar easily, where they serve a full dinner menu.  

The place definitely has a warehouse feel but the light, warmth, and chatter makes it feel cozy juxtaposed to 3rd St outside.  It looks like the restaurant was also going for cozy by nestling a table between the two bathroom entrances, but I don't think this juxtaposition of consumption and excretion works as well.  

As mentioned by previous reviewers, the space gets kind of loud, which lends a misleading air of privacy.  The only person not chatting away throughout the night however, was the bartender, who barely said a word to us the whole night in a really awkward kind of way.   I occasionally got the feeling he was eavesdropping, while not refilling my water glass.  WEIRD.  Maybe he didn't want to explain why we waited 45 minutes between our appetizer and entrees.

The food was good.  Not as good as Slow Club, but better priced.  I thought the menu was confusing, since it was difficult to tell what was an entree and what was an appetizer.  I had the burger, which is fantastic considering it is $13 (with cheese).  My friend had the flank steak with red wine reduction, which appeared to come with tater tots and asparagus.  I thought the proportions looked a bit off: lots and lots of meat, to three tots, and 4 pieces of asparagus, but a guy might feel differently.  We shared the asparagus soup, which we agreed was a good deal better than any other green soup we had tasted.  I tried to remember which way was the proper way to tip the bowl when scraping the bottom.

Bottomline: Eh, I'd rather go to Slow Club.
author: Brooke G.

description:
This is a 3.5 star review, rounded down until I can go again for re-assessment. 

I went here with my old G-crew when Piccino's kitchen denied us at 9pm (boo!). Immediate reaction was echo, echo, echo, echo, echo. The restaurant was full, which in turn means it was loud. High ceilings and cement walls do not provide the best acoustics, in my humble opinion. The host asked us to wait by the bar for ~20 min. We got some drinks - I enjoyed a Blanche de Bruxelles and Christian S. fell in love with Le Fin Du Monde (I heart French). During our wait, which was longer than 20 minutes, one of the waiters had the nerve to ask us to lower our voices. I really didn't appreciate this when it was impossible to hear anyone over the echoes of the other parties. Throughout our meal, that waiter continued to give us nasty stares from across the room even though we were tucked away in the corner, by the bar, away from the rest of the restaurant. Chill, dude. Onto the food - food was excellent. I love Slow Club and this was on par. I had the savory bread pudding, which was tasty and perfect if you don't want a big meal. Christian S. had the black bass, which was done very well. Meg C. had the last cod cakes of the night, which rocked. Others at the table had the burger and they seemed satisfied. Fries were delish! 

All in all, this is a 4-star restaurant but I had a knock a half star for the acoustics and unpleasant glares.
author: Susan L.

description: Met some friends here for dinner a few days ago. Definitely recommend splitting the Savory Bread Pudding as an appetizer, its delicious and sized perfectly for four. The buffalo short ribs are really good, very tender and nicely flavored. Finally the chocolate pistachio dessert really capped off the meal nicely. I'll definitely eat there again if I have reason to be down in the Dogpatch.
author: Joseph R.

description: You know when you have a great meal and it just hits the spot?  Thats what Serpentine is.  Not fancy, but just solid. We went on a weeknight, so no lines to contend with. Great space, attentive service, and totally yummy comfort food with reasonable prices.  We ordered a plate of fries (so good, they got dusted in minutes), and the oven roasted chicken, steak and brussel sprouts were delicious too.  Well be back!
author: Fogdog M.

description: Country steak and eggs!  Pretty delicious, and my baby girl loved it too!  I got the gravy on the side, which is what I recommend.  This place is pretty easy to get seating on a Saturday afternoon.
author: Kit E.

description: Really delicious brunch! Thumbs up on the buckwheat strawberry pancakes and standing ovation on the salmon benedict -- one of the best benedicts I've ever had. The fried green tomato on the bottom tops it off. Light and fluffy egg, perfectly poached. The bloody mary has a mini salad on top, which I love. The drink menu alone will make you keep coming back to try them. Parking was so easy b/c it's a bit out of the way and businesses in that area are closed on Sunday. Clean, hip decor. Great service.
author: Jessica G.

description: Come early on a Sunday before the reservations book up for the day and order the red flannel hash and a bloody mary. So good it will make you cry. The breakfast bread pudding is a ridiculously delicious alternative.
author: Nicole G.

description: decided to try out the dogpatch...and am i glad we did.  we were told about serpentine, and our friends were spot on right.  great, great food...so simple but SO good.  perfect portions...easy service...hubby had the burger...cooked EXACTLY as he wanted...as well as his fries.  my fettucine was too good for words.  tomato sauce based with home made fettucine with cauliflower...sounds strange?  trust me...it wasn't.  affogato for dessert and a bite of his ice cream sandwich.  i'd go again...and again...and again.
author: Sonia C.

description: Met friends here for a little cocktail and app thing.  I couldn't believe that I could park within 25 yards of the place for FREE.  In San Francisco!  The waiter knew his wine list and made a good recommendation.  The apps looked tasty, but by the time I got there it was more about the company.  I would go back to this place for sure, just based on the space, the vibe, and the friendly staff.
author: Brent F.

description: I love this neighborhood, so I am thrilled that Serpentine has opened up here.  The cocktails were different and really tasty, every dish at our table was good.  The wait for our food to come out was forever (resulting in some cold items) but they were clearly still working the kinks out - I will revisit and update my review.
author: Melissa B.

description: Industrial chic.  Very nice for a weeknight dinner or leisurely lunch.  Nothing I ate was a home run, but I have faith they'll be stepping up their game once they're more settled in.
author: Bibby G.

description: I've eaten at Serpentine a few times now and it's very consistent.  I love the space, with it's super high ceilings of exposed concrete and pipes.  The bar is cool, too.  The staff is all super friendly, which makes it even more enjoyable.  Drinks are good.  The way the seating is laid out is great because every table seems pretty private, yet still part of a happening place.  The burger and fries are my favorite, even if the fries are a little heavy on the garlic.  Good date place.
author: Kevin M.

description: My bf brought me here for dinner one night to get out of the regular neighborhoods.  We found parking right around the corner and were seated immediately (we had reservations).  The restaurant was nicely decorated.  The service was lacking from the start but the food was delicious.  Delicious enough that I would definitely return.
author: Dominique K.

description:
Yowza! I might have just eaten the most decadent meal of my life. And it was worth every moment of belly-aching agony that I suffered at 3 o'clock this morning.  So much so that I, with full awareness of what I was doing and what the repercussions would be, ate the leftover savory bread pudding for brekkers this morning. Yup, I speak the truth.
Everything about Serpentine was enjoyable, right down to the hip music being played (where else can you have a candle-lit dinner and be serenaded by the likes of Common?). The menu is somewhat limited, especially if you are a veg. But everything we ate was taaaasty. We started with the fried oysters (typically I prefer them raw, but what the hell?) and the South Carolina hush puppies, which we dipped into aioli (I think I actually felt my heart struggling to continue pumping). Next was the Warm Ruby Crescent Potato & White Shrimp Salad with lemon vinaigrette, mmmmmmm. I had the savory bread pudding (nettles, roated onion and swiss cheese) which was so rich and indulgent that I barely managed to eat half of it (until this morning, of course). I feel a little conflicted: I would like to recommend you order it to share, as it's a little too rich for just one person, but once you taste it you won't want to let anyone else get his grubby hands on it! You'll turn into a selfish only child who has never learned to share! ANYHOW, the wine selection was pretty good and the service fantastic. I dig it.
author: Lisa F.

description:
two words:  monesa's shrine.  i don't know what fantastic concoction of booze it contains but sweet baby jesus is it delicious.  and it goes down like lemonade on a hot summer day so beware.

oh and because i'm an alcoholic,  i'll go ahead and admit that i've only ever been to serpentine for lunch.  i actually think it's pretty solid, certainly a big step up from the crap-e-teria in my building, and certainly worth a visit.  i think the burger is pretty great though not quite up to it's big sis at slow club.  i've had the special sandwiches and they've always been good, too.
author: nic f.

description:
Yum! Everything on the menu was so creative and tasty. Love the high-ceilinged space and black/grey modern decor. The space is  crowded, but our booth felt very private and shielded us from ambient noise.

Some knock-out appetizers:  the oysters, chicken livers, and grilled sardines (with fennel puree!) were SO DELICIOUS.  Likewise the burger, with unusually savory garnishes.

We wouldn't order the fried calamari again - too much fried-ness, not enough calamari flavor.

The asparagus salad sounded good, and the asparagus was fresh and tasty, but  overall too many different textures going on and rather bland cheese.

If I lived in the neighborhood I would definitely become a regular here!
author: heather h.

description: Went here last night with a few girlfriends and had a really great time. I really love the space that this restaurant is in - very industrial. From the outside, you'd never know it was a restaurant. The inside has nice low lighting, a beautiful cement ceiling, and an intimate seating area (plus bar seating and seating to the side of the bar). We had the Roasted Chiles de Padrone, fries, Sockeye salmon, Seared Ling Cod and House Made Potato Gnocchi  - plus vino - everything was really great. We also closed the place down and our waitress was awesome and didn't push us out. I would recommend this place and will be going back!
author: Jenn D.

description: It was a Tuesday evening, and a college friend was in town for business, and we were meeting at Serpentine for dinner. I made reservations, but due to the Giants game, my friend coming from the financial district was a bit late, and as I sat at the bar enjoying a glass of Old Potrero Straight Rye Whiskey, our table was relegated to a corner near the entrance. We both ordered burgers which were pretty good. The bun was soft and the burger was a good size. The place is open and had great natural lighting. It got crowded and as I was leaving the bar to get our table, 2 cougars approached and asked if they could take our seats, but then a random couple behind them informed the cougars that they were waiting for a bar seat before them. I do not know the protocol when it comes to waiting for bar seats, but I thought it would go the people asking for the seats. Who knows? Anyhow, the food was good, nice atmosphere, and a good location.
author: Mike C.

description:
Serpentine is next door to my business, but it's the food, atmosphere and great staff that makes it my favorite restaurant. 

I've almost never had anything that I didn't really like, and the food under the current chef seems to be getting better and better. From the day they opened, everything is fresh, and as locally sourced as possible. The owner goes the extra mile to source from sustainable as well as more humane sources for their meats. This isn't just hype, as it usually translates as tastier and better quality.

An extra star for their desserts, too, which were a bit of  weak point when they opened but now are consistently delicious. I am trying to cut back on their huuuge chocolate chip cookies at lunch time, which may be a little too good.They're often hot from the oven and they're kind of addictive.

As my neighborhood restaurant, it has become my no-fail place to bring clients and friends for lunch or drinks.
author: Neil H.

description:
Food took forever to get and they were not busy for brunch so I'm not sure why it took that long. The food itself...not tasty at all. It wasn't disgusting, but I've definitely eaten better breakfasts (and even at places not known for their food, like Starbucks). On the plus side, easy parking, pretty cheap and nice servers. 

Overall, I will not return.
author: E P.

description:
I was thrilled to learn that I had a new haunt to patronize in my neighborhood that wasn't considered a hole-in-the-wall gem (not to knock those).  I arrived at Serpentine with a party of 4 at 9:30pm on a Friday night.  We were directed to the bar for 20 minutes until our table was ready.  

Overall the service was stellar.  Our waiter offered us recommendations and was friendly and attentive.  The ambiance was fantastic.  Simple, yet elegant.  

The food was better than average.  Everything was cooked perfectly, I just felt that the layers of flavors didn't exactly jive perfectly.  I ordered the duck which would have been perfect except for the addition of bacon.  Normally, I'm of the school that bacon makes everything better.  However, on this dish it only made it too salty.  My dinner companions made the same comments about their dishes.  Cooked well, but the flavor palette could be improved.  

Overall, I give Serpentine a four.  I wasn't blown away by the food, but it was better than most restaurants.  I also, loved that they focus on seasonal local ingredients.  

And lastly...their prices were fine.  Exactly what I expect to pay for the quality of ingredients and service.
author: Jennie B.

description: The only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars is because the fish may have made me sick... that said, everything about it was great... loved my muddled whiskey drink and the appetizers were yummy, just steer clear of the halibut.
author: Gingerkitty K.

description: Serpentine had a clean, modern environment and fairly friendly staff.  We were seated immediately, but the service was very slow (I think they were missing a server).  Either way, food was okay.....DRINKS WERE FABULOUS--- creative, yummy, different.  I decided to go tapas-style and order a few small plates.  The lamb meatballs were okay.... VERY small.... I expected them to be a little bit more substantial.  The brussel sprouts were yummy--- nice and crispy.  My partner ordered the hanger steak (of course we had to share) and it was definitely the best.  The cut was tender and they cooked it per our direction.  The cauliflower bake that came with the steak was also creamy and comforting.  Overall, good experience.... other than having to wait awhile for service.
author: anna p.

description:
I love Slow Club, it's one of my fav stand bys, and now I have something almost just as good even closer to me!  My friend had been wanting to explore Potrero Hill (though I try to keep my neighborhood as secret as possible), so I suggested Serpentine because I still hadn't gone.  We had a great time.  The atmosphere is very similar to Slow Club, industrial, but much brighter, lots of light, beautiful flower arrangements, etc.  We sat at the bar because it was a Sat night and pretty busy.  The menu is also similar to Slow Club, clipped on boards, they have the pasta, burger, chicken, etc. but there were some surprises on there.  I had the bread pudding, actually my first bread pudding ever, and like everyone said, it's great.  I got it with the salad and carrots on the side, for only $11.50.  What a deal!  I was so full.  My friend had the escarole salad w/ goat cheese souffle.  Also very good.
Their drink list was a little confusing.  A lot of drinks were made with things I had never heard of.  I ended up getting the Rhum punch.  It was good and strong.  My friend had a drink with sparkling wine, grapefruit juice, and elderflower.  Also very good.  They are on the pricey side $9-$9.50.
Definitely will be back!
author: Sarah M.

description:
not really happy about this place. the dishes that the server recommended were terrible - the lamb chop was fatty and a chocoloate pot was just eh.

the bar service was prompt and the drinks were yummy.

But since the food was less than stellar and it is a bit out there in Dog Patch, I probably will not return.
author: Jami C.

description: It's just too loud in there. And the layout isn't so good. I left with a headache.
author: David S.

description: Went on a date here last night and I really liked it. I am a fan of the Slow Club, but honestly enjoyed the scene and food way better here. I had black cod with celery root puree and beets. It was bomb. Loved the decor and the waitress was super nice. I will absolutley be back
author: Liz C.

description: We had a long relaxing lunch here recently.  Nice spot for going with a group on a weekend day - reminds me a bit of the interior of Foreign Cinema.  Bright and sunny space with the industrial vibe going on.  Excellent service.  Easy place to drive to because parking is a breeze.  I am looking forward to coming back and enjoying dinner here w/ some cocktails.  We shared a salad, sandwich and soup.  Pretty straight forward menu but executed well and with some interesting twists.  I'll see you soon for dinner Serpentine!
author: Piper B.

description: Loved it! Can't find anything to complain about. First off, I love that parking is plentiful - yay! Once inside, the atmosphere is casual, inviting, clean and simple. I wished I had come more hungry once I took a look at the menu but I knew I wouldn't be able to order a starter - bummer. My friend and I split the halibut and the pork chop and both were outstanding. Service was very attentive too...great experience and would definitely recommend Serpentine to anyone...great for a date, great for catching up with friends...clearly this place is one of my new faves...
author: Kate S.

description:
i'm falling more and more in love with the dogpatch area and it's entities.

serpentine is across the street from yield wine bar, and i checked it out for dinner last night.  the burger was $12 and delicious.  the brussel sprouts were amazing, and the french fries were fried to perfection.

the modern loft/converted warehouse feel is apparent, yet clean and spacious feeling. i like the high ceilings and windows.
author: Ameer N.

description: This restaurant is such a shining example of all that is good in San Francisco!  The space is so trendy without going overboard.   The  food was FANTASTIC without being too pricey and the waitstaff was extremely attentive, made great recommendations, and engaged us in conversation.   We actually went back 2 days later for brunch.   The biscuits are TO DIE FOR!   I think we are going to now make this our weekly friday night outing.
author: Michael S.

description: We came here for dinner after an evening of drinks at Yield (across the street).  The service was excellent and the food was fantastic.....I had the SeaBass special.  We also had to change our reservations at the last minute, and were accommodated without any issue.
author: Sonal P.

description:
I went here for lunch the second day it was open. I was excited for a new lunch possibility as I freelance 2 blocks away. I can definitely say that the Mahi was good. Likewise, I can definitely say that it's fortunate for me that I am a fishatarian, pescatarian, or my personal favorite aquatarian because if I weren't, I wouldn't have been able to have a meal here. This is NOT a vegetarian/vegan friendly place, which is fine. There is no law (though there should be) that every decent restaurant should have a yummy vegetarian and vegan option on their menus. Still, that just means that unless I'm really hankering for Mahi, I won't be eating here very often. The service was good and the Mahi was quite good. The portions were fancy (re: small), but at least it was yummy.
****
Went here again in the last couple of months for lunch. It's just too expensive for what you get. Period. The portions are too small because I'm hungry two hours later. They just don't accommodate vegetarians, which I am now. Not going to bother with this place anymore. I will say that if you eat meat you will find better choices but it still costs too much for lunch.
author: K H.

description:
this place is becoming one of my favorite spot. fresh ingredient and menu changes all the time, you can also try something new and never get bored. 

especially love the neighborhood~ the restaurant is inside of an old industrial building, decor is very simple and cozy. we met couple of the bartender there and they are awesome. they make great drinks and are so nice. 

we usually sit at the bar(our favorite spot in any restaurant), service is good, one of the must try item on the list is Savory Bread Pudding!! it is exactly what it sound like, bread pudding texture with cheese, fennel and fresh vegetable. it's a very unique experience with this dish, all the different type of flavor merging together. trust me, you gotta try it!

as far as the dinner plate, it was a hit or miss for me, but boyfriend didn't have that problem. i order the duck the first time and it was a bit salty. but the next time when i order it again, it was great! so it may just be that day with that specific plate. overall, the food is good. really fresh stuff, and you can taste it.
author: Cindy C.

description: Great atmosphere, drinks, service and food. The restaurant used to be a Chinese Food joint for 22 years- so imagine the cleaning and gutting completed. They tore down the walls to expose the brick. The giant windows above provide gorgeous lighting during the day. The service is laid back and very friendly. Not for anyone impatient to get served, they take their time, but are in a good mood about it, and so was I. I genuinely felt comfortable and respected here. Drinks were delicious- I had a side car and enjoyed the brandied cherries. For food we started with fried green tomatoes and cod cakes, which were delish. My main, salmon, was good, with polenta, excellent. They are not shy with salt here. For dessert we had the ginger snap cookie ice cream sandwich- we literally fought for the last bite and agreed we'd never had a better ginger snap! I will be back to try brunch soon!
author: Rena B.

description: Great restaurant in the Dogpatch neighborhood.  Food really good Waitstaff really nice. JG
author: Jackie G.

description: Like the rest of SF I fell for the myth that Just For You is the best brunch spot in the Dogpatch. JFU is okay however if you venture one block away to Serpentine you will be greatly rewarded for your extra effort. Serpentine's pancakes are the best in the city, the service is great and the rest of the menu is fantastic as well. You also don't have to wait in a line like you do at JFU. My only negative is that the coffee isn't so great . I hope to go again tomorrow!
author: T O.

description:
went back this week and have only good things to say.  the drinks were fabulous (el diablo), service efficient and very pleasant.

the chilled asparagus soup and heirloom tomatoes with fromage blanc: to die for.  i was ready to lick my plates.
author: marie m.

description: Place was surprisingly packed for its first week opening. Service was good but could be smoother. I'll give them a break since they just opened. The appetizers were much more interesting than the main courses. Not to miss- the crispy oysters and green beans. If you going to eat any fried, eat these! Lamb riblets and spinach salad were really good. Skip the buffalo for the main course- taste like chicken.. I mean beef. We were too stuffed to try the dessert because the bread pudding, while super good,  was rather dense and put us over.
author: Lily C.

description: i'm gonna give this the same review as Slow Club because it's the same owner.  Meh.  i mean ya know, i got a fancy sounding salad with chicken, fries...some other stuff.  the fries were really good...everything else was kinda boring and not that good.
author: Hella M.

description: This is a great local place to eat.  Just the right amount of crowded-- you can get a table with less than 1 week's notice but the place is always hopping.  The food is interesting and very fresh-- and I always find something new to try.  The only downside is that it can get really loud.  My solution is to go with one person and sit at the bar or ask for the booth in the back when I reserve.  Don't miss this fun spot.
author: Shannon T.

description:
lovely! enjoyed a delicious lunch there today. full bar, good wine list, good service. Wonderful addition to the neighborhood. 

i've only given three stars for the following reasons... i agree with Gabe H about the blinding lunch hour light. but i work in the same building and can tell you that it doesn't occur all year... still it's a little uncomfortable. a bit expensive as a daily lunch alternative but great for something different once in awhile or a drink after work. Also, tables are so close together and that tends to make me feel self conscious. It's a small space but cramming us in like sardines is not the best. In the future I'll sit at the bar to avoid that aspect as it's a thoroughly enjoyable menu!
author: Casey H.

description:
Drove all the way across town for lunch...worth every mile.

Make sure to get the sparkling Rose...wonderful.
The server waited until presenting my date's sandwich, before announcing that they were out of the savory bread pudding (the dish I drove all the way over here for)...she handled the mistake with such courtesy and easy charm (even comped our dessert - God, that goat cheese cake), that I had no problem with substituting (duck sandwich is equally fabulous).

Kristin, you're the best!
author: Tonya M.

description:
I consider this place one of the hidden treasures of the Dogpatch neighborhood. I work in the area, so I've been here quite a few times with coworkers and love it every time!  The menu is always changing, and super simple which I really like, and the service is pretty quick too.  They have a full bar which seems like it would be nice if you have dinner here (I've only been here for lunch).

If you're in the dogpatch and looking for a good meal, check this place out.
author: Isaac W.

description:
This spot has all the elements of an instant classic: a large, welcoming central bar, a modern interior that manges to preserve elements of the building's history, and an innovative menu. In a city where too many restaurants open without being truly "new", Serpentine advances the SF dine-out dialogue by making contributions to both its neighborhood and the local palate. 

The English pea puree might as well be a stand-alone dish on the menu. The numerous table nooks create a more personal experience. The whole effort makes you want to go back.
author: Michael C.

description:
amazing food, but it was the creativity of the cocktails that *really* impressed our little foursome, intimately comfortable in the booth with the glass windows... 

i only have one thing to say: WHISKEY SNATCH.
author: natashka o.

description: I've been here for dinner before which was very good, but this review is for a recent brunch visit.  I'm rarely impressed by brunch food but they did it right.  I ordered the chicken fried steak and scrambled eggs.  I don't know what they put in the eggs, but it was very tasty.  And the breading on the chicken fried steak was light and crisp - not the diner style chicken fried steak.
author: Eric C.

description:
Been here twice, once for dinner and once for brunch. I'd say dinner was 4 star and brunch was a 3.

The burger for dinner was great. For brunch, we tried the oyster benedict. Very strange combination of flavors. Fried oysters, a tangy/sour bernaise sauce served on sweet corn bread. Looked unique and appetizing on the menu, but just tasted weird.

The buckwheat pancake would've been great. But they served it floating in maple syrup. Ruined it. I'll ask for syrup on the side (the way pretty much every restaurant serves it) next time.

Service was great and we didn't have to wait for a table both times... but they do take reservations (even for brunch) and they do get pretty busy.

I'll definitely give this spot another chance and next time I'll make a reservation, get the pancake syrup on the side and try something other than the benedict.
author: Nithin R.

description: Good drinks, great fresh foods, fun space, and friendly tatooed staff. Try the  roasted chilies and toasted gnocchi.
author: Peter H.

description: 4.5  I've only tried the burger. I love that this place is by my office.  the quality was always good, but a little inconsistent (especially the fries).  They sometimes forget the yummy sauces with take out so make sure you get them.
author: carleigh r.

description:
I had been told Serpentine was stark, but I did not find it to be that way at all. True, the setting is industrial, but I was surprised by the dark wood screen which enclosed the dining area in a kind of old tavern way: very warm and attracive setting on a cold damp night.
Our waitress was wonderful, and I let her choose a cocktail for me which was terrific ( a kind of bourbon mojito)
The chicory salad and haddok were delicious.
A very pleasant experience. I loved it.
author: Philip B.

description: This place turned out just OKAY. The wine offerings were good however the appetizer and entrees quite disappointing .The brussel sprouts dish (appetizer) was so salty and overly soaked in EVVO. The savory bread pudding which they say is their signature dish -- definitely not signature in any way :( It lacked flavor and the swordfish too was not quite worth remembering! A bumming experience overall! HOWEVER I would like to give this place a second chance especially because the people there seemed so nice :)
author: sandhya ..

description: My friend and I just had brunch today at Serpentine and the food was delicious. I had the brisket with eggs on the brunch menu and it was amazing. The flavor of the beets mixed with the delicious brisket and eggs cooked to perfection made for a wonderful meal. We will be back soon!
author: Jessica D.

description: Yumtastic!  I live closeby its sister-restaurant, but decided to go to the distance to give them a chance - and it is the same great food and drink as Slow Club.  You're gonna love it.  I especially appreciate brussel sprouts ...as a side - :)
author: Jenn D.

description: Unfortunately i have to give this restaurant a negative review for the following reasons: my husband and i went there tonite tuesday nite. My choices were not great: fried calamari: drenched in oil and with mostly tiny calamari pieces - not great flavor. Then, crispy veal sweeebreads. Basically deep fried with not sauce what so ever so plain and tasteless. The artichokes and salad in the sweet bread dish were ok - they saved the dish. The Sinski pino was not great either. I was willing to ignore the bad experience w the food but then i got annoyed by the fact that they sat 3 loud people next to us in the small/cramped table for two next to us. We were so close i can hear their conversation and one of them sat on my coat. The space between the tables was already quite small and it got anjoyingly cramped when they put 3 people in a 2 people table
author: Jamie T.

description: they were out of a lot of things when i went to dinner here.  the space is interesting and cool for a date but the food wasn't that memorable.  i can't really recall what i ordered besides it was some kind of grilled fish and it had some sea asparagus (sea beans) on it.  oh yeah, the salad was wilted too and not on purpose.  overall, an ok experience - not bad, but not great. except the upside down cake dessert.  now that, i suddenly remember :)
author: Priscilla T.

description:
i've been here twice, for brunch, and both times the food was on point. i've had the savory bread pudding and the meat, eggs and potato breakfast. the bread pudding is so freaking awesome, words cannot do it justice. the house-made sausage that comes with the MEP breakfast is soooo good. my cousins had it also in their fried egg sandwiches and both commented on how good it was. the bf has had the corned beef hash and chicken fried steak and those were also scrumptious. 

the first time i came in, the waitress was very kind and attentive. we didnt feel rushed or that our presence was an inconvenience. 

earlier today, not so much. my cousins, the bf and i had to find a brunch place quick after the Giant race. we got this very rude euro lady who obviously was not looking for a good tip. i understand we were a group of 5 without a reservation, but you're still about to take my money. how about a damn smile? i really dont do well with servers who speak rudely to me, especially when i havent done anything except sit down. personally, i think she just looked at us and assumed we were a bunch of punk kids who were gonna be loud and annoying and cheap. listen lady. i can afford to tip you as much as i want, so you might want to change your stinkin attitude and learn how to be polite not only when you put the check on the table. like i havent remembered the last 45 minutes of terrible service. 

i would go back but only if i didnt have her as my server.
author: n m.

description:
Loved it! The chickpea battered calamari had a great light crunchy coating. The salmon and burger were very good. The mascarpone cheesecake was awesome and I'm not a cheesecake person!
Wanted to take home the light fixtures.
author: steve k.

description: You need to try their housemade smoked cod appetizer. And their olives. And their wild boar sugo with papparadelle. The interior is beautiful and the waitstaff really nice. I felt a little bad that our party of 5 lingered for so long on a Friday night but no one tried to rush us out.
author: Angi C.

description: Really enjoyed Serpentine, we received a gift cert from a friend and used it for a birthday dinner.  Great menu selection, the night we went, there were oysters on the halfshell as one of the apps. As well as the chickpea flour coated calamari. Both delicious! My entree was the roasted chicken with bacon dabbled asparagus and sorrel sauce.  The breast was tad dry, but that didn't stop me and I still took home half my meal as portion sizes are not lacking here. Others in our party had the skirt steak, pork osso buck on a bed of chickpeas, and the artichoke gratin that tasted oddly like a pepperoni pizza (not in a bad way) don't miss the artfully and aptly named cocktails like the 'Blood and Sand' or 'Czech Mate', dessert was ok with the banana ice cream sandie.  Our knowledgable hip server was great, he did forget the cheese plate, but quickly recovered. Overall, Serpentine was a wonderful dining experience @ a reasonable price point by SF standards. A welcome addition to Dogpatch.
author: Sfgpgirl G.

description: I bump Serpentine up to 3.5 stars simply for their burger and fries.  SO good.  The service has gotten marginally better, but it's still not great.
author: fi l.

description: Ok so I decided to upgrade my review.  Thank you, Serpentine, for bringing back the braised pork sandwich.  It was one of the first dishes on the lunch menu when the restaurant opened.  My only request is that you serve it on a toasted torpedo roll instead of the whole wheat bread.  I'll eat here everyday as long as this sandwich is on the menu.  But I'll still get the food to go because parking is crazy at lunch time.
author: Lauren R.

description: What a wonderful surprise to enjoy a lovely evening with good friends.  The food was delicious, the service was top notch and the drinks were yummy and hit the spot.  If you are looking for a cool setting with friends or that special one, consider Serpentine the next time you go out to dinner.
author: Mikael B.

description:
I went to Serpentine yesterday with a friend for brunch. Even upon walking into the restaurant, the service was great, and the space is truly fantastic. The texture on the warehouse walls and ceiling, the sweet light fixtures, the metal booth walls, the amazingly beautiful wood floor - it's just captivating. And warm and inviting, which is always hard to balance with industrial/warehouse.
 We started with the best cocktails I have had in quite some time, and my friend said his peach bellini was -the best- that he'd ever had. Here is the only lack I found in our entire meal: I wish they'd had a pastry or coffee cake to share, because I was really hungry, and there was no pre-brunch snack to be found.
Next were our mains, I had eggs-meat-potatoes-bread and each bit was really great. My eggs had cheese just like I asked, the potatoes were soft AND crispy, my housemade sausage was delicious, and the raspberry jam for my Acme toast was great. My friend had the savory bread pudding, and though he didn't finish it, his review was equally glowing.
We did decide to share a little dessert (possibly because they didn't have any pastry goodness?), and had the maple creme brulee with ginger snaps. The creme brulee was creamy and thick but not gloppy, the top was crispy, and it was mellow maple-flavored. Unfortunately, my ginger snaps weren't so snappy, they were more bendy. Oh well, the flavor was good.
All in all, it was a fabulous experience. The food was great, very reasonably priced, and the service was helpful but not overbearing. The space was really amazing - one of the best parts of an already great meal. I will definitely be going back for dinner. And brunch again, and so on...
author: Colleen M.

description: Has great salads and ambiance.  If they had more chicken options, I'd frequent a lot more.  Still love it!
author: D A.

description: Food was good, waiter absolutely terrific, table not good: don't sit at the table near the bar. Now I know what the animals at the Zoo feel like when drunk yuppies are staring at them. Hanger steak was good but would be better  with less bell peppers and fries included. Skip the gnochi but will return for burger and maybe brunch.
author: Edward D.

description:
this is a sibling to slow club, which is one of my favorite spots for an easy dinner with friends in SF.  serpentine feels very similar to slow club - great cocktails, interesting menu, etc., but for some reason, feels more like a lunch place to me, where slow club feels more dinnery.  this is probably totally arbitrary, because i've only been here for lunch, but hey.  

the burger is solid, though i prefer the one at slow club to it - yet i'm finding it hard to articulate exactly why.  most of the sandwiches have been consistently really good, except for the tuna melt, which i'd pass on if it were on the menu again.

all in all, definitely a great spot for lunch if you work in SOMA/mission bay.  and if you've had a tough morning, try the monesa's shrine - it's delish.
author: brian g.

description: You can definitely tell it is related to the Slow Club, everything from the menu items, to the menu clipboards, to the design of the place. Serpentine's space is nicer though, with the high ceiling and the windows all around. We had no trouble getting a table for a late lunch on a weekday. There were several vegetarian salads and a vegetarian sandwich, and the sandwich was very good, maybe a little too rich. I'm not sure whether having veggie options carries through to dinner - I've already stopped going to the Slow Club for dinner (even though I live very close) for lack of vegetarian options, so I'd definitely check that before going back for dinner.
author: Amy E.

description: This place was pretty amazing. The veggie options were limited but what they had was utterly wonderful. The only reason I gave it four instead of five is I felt the wait staff was a little off.
author: Jerry S.

description: I really should be giving this place 3.5 stars, but damn the yelp rating system (and the inability to give 1/2 starts). I love the industrial, minimalist feel of the decor. Food ain't that bad either, although I prefer the sister restaurant, Slow Club.
author: Sandy Y.

description:
Fantastic for brunch, this must be still a sleeper because there is not too much wait. All the food I have tried there is great but if I had to pick I would get the fried egg sandwich with sausage (I could get coaxed into splitting some pancakes too)

You can also call for a reservation. Vive le Dogpatch
author: xo x.

description: My girlfriend recevied a gift to go to Serpentine.  I normally do not visit Dog Patch but I heard great things about this place.  We went on a Friday and had reservations for 9:30pm.  We went early to see if we could get a seat earlier.  It was packed.  We decided to eat at the bar.  The food was great and the service was awesome!  I would recommend this place to all my friends.  Try the burger!
author: Al G.

description: This restaurant is excellent in every way.  The food is impeccable and the atmosphere is great.  Nice drink selection with great wines.  We had their bread pudding made with house cured ham and gruyere cheese with vegetables.  Also we had the prather ranch burger which is unbelievably tasty.  You cannot go wrong here!
author: Jerry H.

description:
Delicious discovery!!

Great service, casual atmosphere, a relaxing Friday night dinner spot!

The menu was simple but elegant, packed with seasonal vegetables and fresh fish.  We loved the peach salad, seared cod, and grilled salmon.... fixed simply but perfectly.  The restaurant is flooded with natural light, highlighted by the high ceilings, making it the perfect summer nighttime destination.
author: L D.

description: Damn good place for brunch and very cool urban digs. Stretch had the fried country steak dish and it was amazing. I never liked fried country steak but with one bite I was converted.
