I had the beef hash dish and it was very very good and done in such unique fashion. I'm not sure if I can explain it and do it justice. We are already planning to go back. We walked out stating that this is one of the best brunch places in SF. Service was attentive and solid. This place could make our go-to or clutch list. Stay tuned.
author: Seymour S.

description: Even though we made a reservation the day before and were assured by the woman answering the phone that we'd be given her "best table," she didn't reserve us any table.  When we arrived at the reservation time, we were nowhere on their records.  We'd eaten there a couple times in the past and had good experiences, so were disappointed at this carelessness.  The tables are crowded together, so "cozy" would be one way of describing it.  Our wait person was friendly, cute and as attentive as could be in the crowded conditions, but the wine we ordered didn't arrive until we were half-finished with our entrees.  The food was tasty, but over-priced.  No need to go there again.
author: Kate H.

description: It is really hard for me to write a harsh review because I used to work as a server but I have to say I am rather disappointed with the service here. I really like the meals I have had here the three times I have been. But the service has just been disappointing all three times. Our server has always been nice, but the food would come out irregularly, somebody in our party would have to wait 15 minutes for his or her food later than everybody else, we would have our leftover given to somebody else by accident, or have our meals but no silverware for a while. If it has been only one time, I would just say: oh, it's on off night. But three times, it's a strike.
author: caroline w.

description: Anybody who gives this place less than 5 stars should have their tastebuds examined.
author: Luna K.

description: Yum, Yum!  Serpentine was a delicious treat in this up-and-coming Dogpatch neighborhood.  I thoroughly enjoyed my deliciously light goat cheese souffle--almost licked the plate clean. The ambiance here is cool and airy-almost loft-like.  The food tasted fresh and our waitress was very friendly.  Lastly, the prices were pretty reasonable for lunch.  What more could you want?  I'll be back again.
author: Barbara P.

description: I like Serpentine, it wasn't mind blowing...but I would go back for sure.  Atmosphere is really nice, would be great for a date or any occasion for that matter.  Food and wine selection is good.  Service was great.  Love the location.  Overall, it is a place to check out and try for yourself.  Oh, and before or after stop by Yield Wine Bar across the street.  It is seriously the best wine bar in San Francisco.
author: Christie A.

description: Me & T popped over the hill for a bite in the middle of the heat wave last week. Started with some outstanding cocktails from the friendly bartender, and not feeling very hungry we both ordered two small plates - she a lovely nectarine salad and the bread pudding, me the chilled carrot soup and tuna confit with white beans on toast. Her small order of bread pudding was big enough for her to take some home. I thought my chilled soup really didn't develop it's flavor until it hit room temp, but I'm definitely going back to try some of the bigger plates. Gorgeous room!
author: J. R.

description: Despite the warnings about the salty food my wife and I decided to give Serpentine a try. We loved the decor, and the service was excellent.  I had the Mizuna and Shaved Spring Vegetable Salad and my wife had the Little Gems Lettuces which were both fabulous. We decided on the burgers which were cooked to our requested medium rare, but they were salty and almost inedible. I would recommend this restaurant, but I would at least stay clear of the burgers.
author: Greg N.

description: I liked this place. The dining room has a great open-ness  and airy-ness to it and I like how it still feels industrial with the exposed beams and brick walls (very appropriate for this part of town), though it did get a bit loud because there isn't much to buffer the sound.  My husband got the gnocci as his main course and I had some serious food envy. It was delicious! My burger was also yummy, but not as good as the gnocci. Another item of note was the side of French fries with Aioli. These were tasty, thin, crispy fries. Couldn't eat enough of them.
author: Amy L.

description: A warmed-up industrial space, savory bread pudding, boar pasta, among the best of the SF neighborhood restaurants.
author: chris o.

description:
This is an excellent restaurant and a great place to have in the neighborhood. The industrial vibe is both modern and comfortable at the same time. The service is friendly and attentive. And the food is dependable and interesting. 

Like others say, one of the star attractions is the savory bread pudding. Incredibly tasty. One of my top ten favorite things I ate in 2008. The cod brandade was also excellent. The little gems salad was fine, but not as interesting as the other dishes. The brussel sprouts, also excellent. The desserts (Bi-rite ice cream sandwich, strawberry almond cake, and chocolate mousse) were all delightful. Burger and fries were fabulous as well. My one warning would be on the vegetarian lasagna. I am a cheese addict, and yet this white lasagna was way too heavy, creamy, and rich. It desperately needed some side veggies and it was way too large for one person.
author: Jammy M.

description: I went here only once for my birthday and I still dream of it to this day.  Whitefish in browned butter, goat cheese cake, and upside down cake (with some fruit I forget).  Don't worry, I had friends to help me with the dessert.  Plus we all drooled over each other's plates - the savory bread Pudding is rich and so yummy, and the pork chop is just perfect.  I think we all dream of going back - yes, repeat visits.  And different dishes to try, as the menu changes daily with some favorites always on the menu.  The place is great, with a nice ambiance.  Service is a little off, hence the four stars, but that won't deter me from coming back.
author: Julie C.

description:
it's a nice place... not as great as we thought it will be.
we made reservations for 9, and didn't get a table until 9:30... but we got free drinks for the waiting.
i had the stake, and it was ok. rest of people wasn't that happy with they're food. but... overall, it's a chic place, nice stuff, a bit over priced.
i am not sure i will go back, but it's not a bad place.
author: bit b.

description: Trying a little too hard to be Nopa... (the restaurant, not the neighborhood).
author: Paige B.

description:
Been here twice, first time (in May) had mediocre food and service, forgettable desserts.  

Second time (this week) made up for it.  Had a great waitress who answered all our questions and stayed friendly and real.  Yellowtail was fantastic, nice and rare with lovely subtle flavors and garlic scapes that were SO good.  Warm peach/blackberry upside down cake was mind blowing.  Seriously.  Simultaneously crispy and soft....are you kidding with that?  Even my skeptical date who prefers Mitchells to an $8 dessert any day of the week was totally won over.  I'm stoked to see this go in my neighborhood, I'll be back for sure.
author: Gwen S.

description: Friendly service, and very comfortable and modern atmosphere. We went there for lunch and the food was a little slow to arrive, about a 15-20 minutes wait. Serving sizes for the entrees are reasonable, not too tiny nor too large- our party of 3 were all able to finish our food with no problem. Overall good-tasting food, and I would go there again.
author: Dee H.

description:
a little pricey served with a little food. the quality of the food is worth the expensive meal, but the portions are tiny....and i'm a tiny person.....

it's nice to come here and treat myself from time to time. i've had their halibut (which was great) and their tomato salad with flank steak...service has always been friendly.

industrial chic ambiance
author: Sprout S.

description: While at first this addition to the Dogpatch was a stellar and completely pleasurable dinning experience, since the departure of the opening chef both quality of food and service levels have dropped dramatically.  On numerous occasions we've been met with unaccommodating and rude phone personnel, mediocre service while in the restaurant and generally bland, uninteresting food obfuscated by what reads as a promising and inventive menu.  While the space and food is meant to be a casual experience  what we've taken away on our last few visits is an unwelcoming, unprofessional and almost consistently unstimulating eating experience.
author: scott m.

description:
Food was okay, not stellar.  

Like the interior, although the chairs are so wobbly, it's hard to relax.

Service was crap.  We were told we couldn't sit at a certain table because it was reserved in 1 hour.  Not 10 minutes later, a couple came in and moved to that table.  The hostess didn't have the balls to make them move.  Strike one.  I ordered flank steak cooked medium rare.  It was cooked medium and cut against the grain.  Strike two.  While waiting for my husband to return to pay, I was asked to vacate the table even though there were 2 tables available and no space for me at the bar.  Strike three.

There are quite simply too many fantastic restaurants in SF to waste your time on this one.
author: Britta N.

description: Thursday night at 8 p.m. and only a couple of tables were taken. The burger was very good and the lasagna was interesting but I'm not sure I would get it again. The waitress was very nice but the overall tone of the restaurant was quite and a little dim.
author: Jessica W.

description: We went to Serpentine for a second time recently for Dining Out for Life. We had a 8 pm reservation. Unfortunately, our table was inhabited by two clueless women who felt the need to park their asses at the table for almost two and a half hours. The staff finally had to tell them to move along (awkward), which was around 8:30. They were really apologetic to us and we ended up being given two glasses of Prosecco and 10% off our bill. Wow. I was happy enough with just the Prosecco. They went above and beyond given that we weren't really that put out because it wasn't like we had later plans. Once seated, we shared the shaved salad, my better half had the chicken and I had the burger. Everything was really, really good, and we got nice wine suggestions from our server. Oh, and the affogato - good lord. Bartender was also very nice, made a nice cocktail and answered a few questions. So bravo Serpentine. Thanks for being so nice about the delay and thanks for the fantastic food/drink. We'll be back.
author: Natalie T.

description: We had a birthday brunch here today for seven people...I had the chicken fried steak with biscuits and gravy,eggs and potatoes...it was delicious...best chicken fried steak i've ever had...would be easy to over eat, but the portions are moderate,which I think is a good thing!! My daughter had the savory bread pudding and it was exceptional...everyone else was very happy with their food,a fresh take on brunch classics...We had a reservation,so we didn't wait for more than a minute or so..the service was good,the atmosphere, young... The prices were fair...I'd definitely go again!!
author: Lily W.

description: Food was excellent. I had a lamb spaghetti, and I ate my whole plate. Service is a little lacking. Good wine options.
author: suz s.

description: Went here last night for dinner. It's right near where we're staying so really convenient for me in the Dogpatch neighborhood. It's a very nice industrial space and the service is top notch. Very professional team in a well thought-out space. We enjoyed the wine we had although I find the selection of open wines quite small and as typical, high priced. Good wines though which we ended up ordering. Dinner was good too but we found one thing wrong with the meal. My girlfriend had the chicken dish and I had the hangar steak. Everything was awesome except for the steak. The sides of the steak dish were so much better than the meat that they actually drowned out the flavor of the meat. It was still really good but not perfect. All-in-all we really enjoyed the place. Had one of the two-top booths near the kitchen. Nice view of the bar area and yet somewhat separate. We'll be back for brunch during our two week stay as we really enjoyed the place and heard brunch was amazing.
author: Joizee_HH

description: Yummmmm!! I went here for brunch on Valentine's day and it was the best idea ever! The exposed brick (my fave) and big metal beams  made for beautiful ambiance, and the bloody mary's were perfect! A good bloody mary should be like a salad, with lots of vegetables and sauces, and these were exactly that. The savory bread pudding was so awesome, as were the baked eggs with brussel sprouts. I'll be back for dinner.
author: Emily G.

description: Been to lunch two days in a row- going for the trifecta tomorrow. I think I'm just spoiled for anywhere else now. Very high-quality, fresh food.
author: Jonny A.

description:
having eaten here twice I can say the food has been consistently very very good. savory bread pudding is worth trying ( and saving room for - its rich). seafood entrees were good too. the hamburger at a neigboring table looked excellent.

the cocktails are nice, and somewhat unique. however, i have twice asked for something slightly different ( vodka instead of gin) and was given major attitude by the servers. if there is a reason they cant make the switch, it would be so much more pleasant to hear that, than be treated with half condescension, half disapproval. kinda random 'tude over a cocktail, especially in SF (isnt it supposed to be laid back and non judgemental here?)
author: Christine B.

description: Every dish we ordered was incredibly good. When was the last time I had a salad that perfectly seasoned? I'd go back time and again for those greens. The main course flavors were rich and complex....worth every penny. Great chill atmosphere, no too loud, but still fun. What a great night. Perfect for a date or to hang with some friends. I'll be back for sure.
author: Richard F.

description: Still serving the best burgers in SF in my local opinion. However, it's a nice upscale (but not pretentious) environment, good for taking a date out or hanging out with friends for an evening. Drink list is good. The other food I've had (keep coming back to the burger) is really good too. Service has been good if not outstanding every time I've been there. Perhaps even overly friendly (I've been comp'd stuff more than once for minor things other restaurants would ignore like waiting a few minutes for a table).
author: Jon I.

description:
Just went for bunch on Sunday and it was really good.
I still think that the interiors are great - and loved my waitress to pieces!
Had the steak and egg hash and it was FAB!
Everyone else loved their food- but I took a bite of the burger and it was super greasy.
author: Presidio H.

description:
Four of us had an outstanding experience at Serpentine on a Saturday night.  The atmosphere had a good buzz and every table was filled.  Every dish ordered met with rave reviews.  The combination of flavors with the bass was quite tasty.  Ahi tuna - very good.  Chicken - scrumptious.  Everyone thought the fries were done perfectly.  And, we all fought over the two orders of brussel sprouts - yes, brussel sprouts. 

To cancel out the brussel sprouts, we all split the mint ice cream sandwich and the espresso martini for dessert.  The ice cream sandwich was really yummy and rich - perfect for splitting.  The espresso martini was good, but I probably would not order it again. It was more of a novelty than a dessert.

On top of all the good food, the service was just the right balance of attentive, yet casual.  All in all, we all enjoyed the evening.  I look forward to trying Serpentine again to see if it meets the "consistency test".
author: Robin O.

description:
My SO and I are frequent guests at Serpentine.  The bar is wonderful, both for the quality of the cocktails and the friendliness of the staff.  The food is AMAZING.  The volume can be a bit high at times, but my fellow diners are almost always happy.  The staff are great.  One time when i was there, a bunch of older, bitter-looking women were at the table next to us, and one of them started grandstanding about the variety of lettuce they were being served.  The chef had to actually come out and show her a sample of the two different types of lettuce to convince her that she had been served the correct one.  All this was done with grace and politeness by the wait staff, when they should have decked this woman for being so high-maintenance.  

And to Persimmon girl below, WTF?  Do you really have nothing else to do but lower your Yelp review for this restaurant to three stars because there were not enough persimmons in your salad on one visit?  Please get a life.  This is a wonderful place, I highly recommend it to all for a lovely, sophisticated but laid back dinner.
author: Sienna L.

description: Great cocktails... for both brunch and dinner.  I enjoy a spicy bloody mary and the bartender has a brown bottle w/ a glass dropper in it - so it looks kind a sketchy - and it has some good spice in it.  For evening cocktails recommend the muddled lemon & mint w/ bourbon.  The food is good too.  Watch out - service can be painfully slow at times, but generally worth the wait.
author: Nate H.

description: Nice atmosphere, not too stuffy.  We sat at the bar and had good service.  The burger was great, but not as good as its sister restaurant, Slow Club.  All in all, a nice place to venture off to if you're in that part of the City.
author: Ricky P.

description:
Went there last Friday night for dinner with a group of eight people. I was intrigued by the exterior of the restaurant (cool, trendy looking) and the fact it was started by the same folks at the Slow Club, one of my faves.
Overall, I was somewhat disappointed by this restaurant. We ordered a few small plates to start, and the savory bread pudding seemed to be a crowd favorite. The cucumber salad and the ribs were really nothing special. 
Being the tomato lover that I am, I ordered the heirloom tomato bouilabaisse with high hopes of a tasty, acidic experience. It was too way too salty and there wasn't a single chunk of tomato in the entire dish. 
Too, it was a bit too noisy. The layout of the restaurant was a bit awkward, I thought. We were wedged into a table in between the kitchen and the bar. Not great.
Overall, I'd recommend it as a place to grab a drink but probably not worth the money, given you could go to another great restaurant for the same price.
author: Shari F.

description: Like many San Francisco residents, I find myself drawn to the new buzz - sometimes like a moth to a flame. Serpentine blazed a fiery trail of disappointment for me. With a friend visiting from London and another SF denizen, I thought we'd initiate ourselves in the "latest and greatest" find. Entering the non-descript entrance on a Dogpatch corner, we settled into our cold-steel table in the bunker-like, boxed ambience. While the drinks were good, the food was literally unmemorable (I can't even remember what I ate, it was so forgettable) and the service was sloppy. I'm pretty casual but was disappointed that our waiter decided not to bother with tucking in half of his front shirt. The food seemed like glorified diner food served on plates meant for a more dignified debut. When the mouth-dropping check arrived, I was compelled to apologize to my companions for a meal to forget.
author: Geo G.

description: the service was so slow and so bad today at brunch - i really cant be positive about this place.  the drinks were good. the food was average and the service was really poor.  we had the bread pudding to share - funny flavor so not my cup of tea.  three ladies had the crabs benedict and not one person commented on their food - not remarkable.  and as for the red hash that i had.... nothing set it apart as unique other than adding chopped beets to not very flavorable meat.  and hash is somewhat of a misnomer... the potatoes, beets and beef are just cubed and not very well blended together. in a city like San Francisco - we wont need to go back.
author: Amalia S.

description: Had a fantastic dinner the other night! The flank steak was cooked perfectly and was sooooo tasty! We shared a few appetizers and they were really really good. I was kind of surprised how inexpensive the food is for the quality. Truly...great value! The atmosphere was nice and cozy in the industrial style space. I highly recommend!
author: c.t. d.

description: This has become one of my favorite brunch spots in the City.  The space is nice, the service is fast and friendly, and the RED FLANNEL HASH is INCREDIBLE.  The BAKED EGGS (over brussell sprouts) is a close second.  Highly reccomended.
author: Glenn G.

description: A friend and I stopped in for lunch and each ordered the Tuna Nicoise.  The moment we saw the portions we both had the exact same reaction: "rip off!"  Very little food for the $13 they charge.  Granted, the (very tiny piece of) tuna is prepared perfectly, but $13!  We didn't event get a piece of bread as an accompaniment to the salad.  As soon as we were done eating it, we were presented with the check without the option of ordering anything else (we were still quite hungry).  We ended up walking one block to Just For You,  had ourselves a a killer piece of pecan pie and coffee and will most likeliy go there next time we're in the mood for a Salade Nicoise.
author: John S.

description: portions here are tiny.  even w/appetizers, we felt hungry soon after dinner.  i had the cod w/clams, it was okay but not fantastic or memorable whatsoever.  i also didn't taste the pancetta that was supposed to be in the dish and didn't see any point in having it in there.  i'd not recommend coming here on a hot day - there's no AC and it's stuffy, it was actually breezy and cool outside but felt like a sauna inside.
author: Nana S.

description: We loved it here! Went with a friend of mine over the weekend. The ambiance is very cool, has a New York restaurant vibe / feel. The food was incredible (and not outrageously priced either). Our waitress very nice as well. It was lively and fun. My only complaint is the restaurant is very far away from everything, so hard to get a cab. We asked our waitress to call us one though, and it was no biggie they arrived 20 minutes later.
author: Kristal L.

description:
S is for SALTY!!  I was quite excited to try this new restaurant in the Dogpatch for a few reasons...first and foremost being the tasty looking menu and the appeal of local/organic food.  I went with a group of about 13 friends for a birthday dinner.  Upon entrance, I was immediately taken in by the juxtaposition of the industrial cement ceilings and metal fixtures with the warmth of the brick walls upon which hang gorgeous large format photos of seascapes, a la Richard Misrach style.
For the sparseness of being out in the lonely Dogpatch this place definitely has a warmth and coziness upon entering.  Our servers (two of them) were fantastic for dealing with a group of rambunctious celebratory winos.  They treated each one of us as if we were the only person at the table, which is rare for large groups.
We started by ordering a round of appetizers, the best being the bread pudding (definitely the star of the evening).  The rest of the food was quite dissapointing as everything was much too salty. Every item on this menu has great potential (Fried Green Tomatoes & Summer Cardoons
smoked pimenton aioli - lemon , Seafood Boullibaise, Pork Rillettes with santa rosa plum preserves  with whole grain mustard and pickled shallots; Marinated Squid with coco blanc beans, padron peppers and cherry tomatoes - aioli ).  
I am giving them three stars because due only to my disappointment of tasting salt instead of flavor, but would definitely go back in the hopes that this was an off night for the kitchen.
author: BLACK M.

description: I love Serpentine, because their menu is almost a mirror of Slow Club, but parking is much easier and they take reservations with Open Table or by phone.  The food is phenomenal.  The coffee and cookies are fantastic.  The service has always been spectacular.  I've eaten here for lunch about 5 times, and every meal has been wonderful.  Can't wait to try this place for dinner one night.
author: Michael S.

description: My boyfriend and I ate at Serpentine recently.  We loved everything we ordered and the service was great. I cannot wait to return!
author: Allison R.

description:
out of control delicious. this restaurant has everything going for it. 

1. free parking all over
2. incredible seasonal menu that's constantly evolving and changing
3. amazing service and personable staff
4. desserts that will blow your mind
5. awesome exposed brick walls and beautiful candle lit interior 

seriously one of my fave restaurants in the whole of san francisco.
author: D B.

description: I love this place.   The housemade veggie burgers ROCK!  Fresh veggies....organic....nothing processed or packaged!  I have not had a bad meal or bad service here!
author: Lana A.

description: We went to this place because we saw a good review in a magazine. But first, we had to rush to make the only reservation available at 6:30, which is fine. Second, the waitress kept pushing us to order fast when we weren't ready yet. The appetizers were good but once the main courses came I was not happy at all. I didn't eat any of it and she never asked if there was anything wrong with it, which obviously there was. Third, we felt really uncomfortable to realize the hostess kept coming to check on us, she must of come like 3 times, what made me get upset. When you are spending a good deal of money in a place, you do NOT rush people to finish their meal! The desert was good. I'm giving this place one star for the salad dressing and the other one for the dessert but that's it, never coming back for sure.
author: Narayana M.

description: Love the restaurant design. Similar to the Chris Kronner  other restaurant Slow Club. Food was excellent. Short ribs were tender. Menu changes based on availablity. Parking is not very hard in that area and you could get a glass of wine at yield before dinner.
author: Phill and Molly O.

description: this place is right next to my house so I decided to check it out. The good was good and the atmosphere is very homie. I'll definitely come back to try some of the othher things on the menu.
author: cj b.

description: Horrible dinner experience.  My friend and I had chef Deepak's chick pea coated deep fried calamari, okay, nothing great, typical Indian garam masala flavor.  My friend had the cheese burger, a burger you can find at a lot of places in town, which I should have ordered--and I had the pan seared fish over what seems to be the same sauce as the calamari, but worse--OVERLY SALTED.  It had the same chick peas and white bean sauce, YUK!  You can fool some of the people some of the time.  After our meal, our wonderful waitress asked us how everyting was, I told her my dish was soo salty that I could only eat the fish and nothing else.  She said she would let the chef know.  After about 10 minutes she came back to our table, looking as if she had been verbally assulted and didn't say a word about my comment.  I felt sorry for her and didn't bring it up.  This place is gross and insulting.
author: John G.

description: Feels good inside, service is terrific and the food is super yummy. I dream about the bread pudding but it's even BETTER at weekend brunch. Deelish drinky-poos. Two thumbs up!
author: mindy a.

description: It was just so so, but way overpriced for what we got. The food was fine - the sweet corn chowder and ice cream sandwich dessert were delicious, but the gnocchi and sea bass were not very exciting (no flavor). The sea bass was the smallest piece of fish that I've ever seen served at a measly 2x1.5 inches for a whopping 24.50! After 3 beers, a shared appetizer (cheese tray consisting on one piece of cheese and four small pieces of bread), soup, an entree each, and a shared dessert for $100, my husband and I both left hungry. We are both normal weight, so it really was that the portions were ridiculously small. I definitely would not go back.
author: k r.

description: Delicious food, super nice service. Only (small) issue? Food was very salty. We were drinking water like horses, while we were there and back home. But heck, it just tasted damn good.
author: Heiko P.

description: We love loved it. It is way smaller than you think- our neighbors were two inches from us and -ahem- switched from English to French as soon as our cocktails arrived. We were like "We may not know what you're saying, but *we know what you're saying*". Anyhoots, there was nary a clunker in our entire evening.  Admittedly, we stuck to the ribular area.  The lamb riblets are cooked and seasoned perfectly, w/ dreamy French feta scattered throughout.  The braised shortribs are gooey and perfect w/ horseradishey puree underneath.  OK: let's get it out of the way- the bread pudding is ridiculous and so good- K? K. Strangely enough, the star of the night for me was the sirloin salad. I know, right?  Perfect cups of butter lettuce hold tender, buttery strips of beast w/ artichokes and tiny crispy potatoes that look just like croutons.  It's all splashed in this there-but-not-there herby vinagrette and I will meet y'all there. Our server Dimitrius totally got us- no small feat- and thus, ergo, I will return post haste.  That is all.
author: David M.

description: Ate a good, filling meal with my own wine for my party and shared a snort of it with our excellent server, noise level was manageable, drink/food menu good to excellent, quality of service and food top notch. Would definitely go back. The ease of parking was a real plus.
author: M B.

description: Great food, service, atmosphere and price. Can't go wrong here.
author: kris k.

description:
i love this neighborhood and feel like Serpentine fits right in here.  

great service, tasty cocktails and the flat iron steak was fantastic.  wish there was a bit more room as it got a bit crowded when trying to walk to the loo, but what can you do.
author: Christine B.

description: I've been there many times for brunch, lunch and dinner.  I'm never disappointed.  The food is great.  The menu is small and seasonal.  They update it often.  The cocktails are also excellent.
author: Laura L.

description: my first question is, how come not a lot of people seem to know about this place? at least that was my general assumption when i walked in here. its in this very unnoticeable location in potrero hill, i almost missed it while driving by. when we walked in, there was almost no one in the restaurant, and it was brunch time, right around noon, or a little before. i had this sinking feeling that the daily candy lied to me, and perhaps this place was not fantastic after all. however, after trying their mixed green salad with chicken, buckwheat pancakes, the egg succotosh, and their beef hash, those doubts were immediately quashed. ALL dishes i mentioned above were fantastic! the atmosphere is nice and sunny, service is attentive and friendly 5 stars hands down!
author: Angie K.

description: Great cocktails! Delicious ribs! Romantic Ambiance! If your not sold yet, they also employ the loveliest blonde waitress in town.
author: magdalena w.

description: Just OK. Forgetting about the fact that the waitress spilled half my cocktail and didn't offer to bring me a new one and the fact that while dining a deux they brought us a measly 2 pieces of bread - the food was simply... well "eh." I found the menu rather uninspired and the portion sizes inconsistent. The bread pudding that everyone is talking about was fine but nothing THAT special. I mean, c'mon people. The fish stew was salty at best and they didn't bring a separate vessel for shells. There was a weird sort of mayo or butter on several of the dishes which I actually found rather... well gross. Desserts were disappointing at best. The 1 star is for the cocktail (or rather 1/2 of a cocktail) I had consisting of some sort of fizzy tasty grapefruit concoction. Cool space though.
author: AceGirl ..

description:
really more like 3 1/2 stars, but i am going to give serpentine the extra half based on the dessert (yum!!) and the dishes my friend got, that looked better than mine (food envy for sure).  
first let me say that i was pleasantly surprised by the interior and atmosphere - i am not sure exactly what i was expecting, but it was so much cozier and i loved the big booths, the bar, and the brick wall near our table.  our service was spot-on, not too much or too little.  i started with the gin/grapefruit cocktail ( completely forget the name of it) - so delicious!  
my friend and i each had salads to start - i chose the wild arugula with strawberries, and she chose the squash salad.  mine was fine - the arugula was a bit too "wild" for my taste, but i tried the squash salad and it was so tasty!  the squash was sliced super thin and dressed just perfectly.  next time... 
for my entree i had the chicken which sounded tasty and warm, and had great veggie sides.  sometimes its all about the sides.  the flavor on the chicken was great, but it was really difficult to cut.  i felt like i had to work a little too hard.  everything else about it was good though.  my friend had the yellow-tail, which again was great.  beautifully presented, and perfectly cooked.  
now - the dessert!  as soon as we got our dessert menus, we knew we had to get the peach and blackberry upside-down cake.  doesnt that sound like heaven?  and to top it off, it comes with vanilla ice cream of course, AND all of their ice cream is from bi-rite creamery!  wow.  it was worth the hype - fantastic flavors, and i wanted to steal every bite and have it all to myself.  
i would definitely try serpentine again, there were more dishes on the menu that looked great, and i want more of that cake...
author: Carolyn B.

description: I wanted to like it even more.  Went for Sunday brunch, easy street parking and not too crowded.  In a dive and warehouse gentrifying part of town, but the interior was nice concrete and wood.  Like the reach for the unusual. The execution was pretty inconsistent and all the ingredients were excellent.  If they can put it all together at the same time could be 4-5 stars. Went for the alaskan sockeye salmon benedict over fried green tomatoes - lemon cucumber - pickled red onion - dill - hollandaise - crispy potatoes.  Perfectly cooked and really nice piece of salmon.  Depending on what part you were eating it was either quite underseasoned (salmon) or overly salted (potatoes) so if you couldn't get all of the ingredients just right in each bite (pretty tough to do) it could be either quite bland, too intense in one direction or really balanced and yummy.  It also took nearly an hour to get the meal to the table do to some glitch and they went out of their way to make this right by additional discount off bill, but we didn't mind since allowed us to enjoy the no kids morning and get through a bit more of the NYTimes.
author: Bob K.

description: Good space, bad food, bad drinks.  I knew things were going to be bad when the bartender couldn't make a decent martini.  Later on 3 people from our group actually sent their drinks back which I haven't seen in a long time.  This is not a knock on the service, the waitress was great.  The food was truly mediocre though, in our group of 6, no one really liked their meal (that's a problem).  I ordered the osso bucco.  Even osso bucco at my company cafeteria has some amount of tenderness.  This osso bucco was tough and flavorless, the worst I have ever had.  That is meaningful especially when they tell you that it is the best thing on the menu.  Go somewhere else, don't waste your money here.
author: Rob S.

description: Absolute best meal ever!  I adore Slow Club and had been excited to check out their new spot. During the last warm spell in SF four friends and I decided to try Serpentine on a Saturday evening.  They were booked but were very accommodating and pushed their two tall bar tables together for us.  It was a bit toasty from the weather, but I'm sure that's a rarity.  We started with tasty cocktails including a very strong Anise Anise and some grapefruit gin thing that negated the hot weather.  The bread pudding is awesome and I generally think fennel is overdone these days, but it was perfect in this dish.  I think I ate and entire half a roast chicken on creamy heavenly polenta or was it grits? some creamy corn deliciousness.  mmmm.  The little warm chocolate torte with candied kumquats and vanilla ice cream rekindled my lost love for heavy chocolate desserts.  Oh, and stop by Yield wine bar across the street after dinner...
author: Kate T.

description: another solid SF California cuisine eatery.  Small but comfortable in an exposed-brick / steel bar stool / loft style sort of way.  walk across the street to Yield for a pre or post dinner glass of wine.  A very pleasant evening.
author: Fallon C.

description: I still can't get over how trendy the dog patch area is becoming - well enough of that observation. I have to say that the best part of my meal was the spinach salad I had. For the first time I didn't get that weird film on my palate that I so often get each time I eat spinach salad - maybe it was the shallot vinegarette? Or perhaps the poached egg on top - what ever the case it was delicious! I want to go back just for that. I learned that it's the sister restaurant to the Slow Club and the space and design does reflect that. My pregant taste buds only allowed me to have the burger but I'm glad I did - it wasn't monsterous but just the right size. As for dessert - they ran out of the apple galette but the chocolate hazelnut tarte did not disappoint especially since it's served with a big scoop of ice cream from Bi-Rite, which reminds me to get my ass there toute suite - I'm probably the only SF resident that hasn't had the damn salted caramel that you wet your panties over! Back to the tarte - big chunks of hazelnuts and dense but not dry. Delicious. Also good the fried oyster starter w/hush puppies - oysters were better than the hush puppies though. I really want to go back now for that damn salad but then again it must just be my pregnant taste buds that are driving me to go back. Either that or my baby just really needs more folic acids!
author: Alexis D.

description: Excellent!!  They just opened over a week ago.  The food, wine selections and cocktails are all Slow Club quality for those of you who is a big fan of Slow Club like me!!  Oh yeah, of course, same owner and chef!!  I had a mahi mahi and a glass of sauvignon blanc for lunch two days ago.  It was exquisite!!  Then I went again tonight for dinner.  We ordered rabbit stew and spinach salad for starter.  The rabbit stew was  rich in flavor and tasty.  The spinach salad was refreshing with just the right amount of dressing and sprinkle of bacon for flavor.  The main dishes we had were Alaskan halibut and steak(medium).  They both were extremely satisfying and delicious!  I ordered monice shine,  an infused martini to pair with the starters and a glass of Rioja to complement the steak.  I highly recommend Rioja and steak pair.  When I drank Rioja by itself, nothing extraordinary, but with the steak and mashed celery roots was a WOW experience.  Unfortunately we had to leave early therefore no time to try their desserts.  Will definitely go back again soon!
author: Gina W.

description:
i thought the food was pretty good.  had the bread salad and the steak.  desserts were a bit on the small side i thought.  

it is really difficult to wait for a table at the bar here.  unless you are seated, waiters will be running into you left and right b/c you are in the way.  

parking was good.
author: n. h.

description: I just returned from meeting a few friends for lunch at Serpentine and all in all solid food and delicious dessert.  Good basic sandwiches with quality ingredients and piles of crispy fries.  I had the Prather burger with homemade condiments and if messiness is a sign of tastiness, it was very good.  Friends had the turkey sandwich and the little gem sandwich and were happy, although they struggled with the grilled bread a bit.  The highlight was the dessert, so save room!  We each had a peanut butter cookie ice cream sandwich with Bi-Rite banana ice cream drizzled with caramel - I am tempted next time to just pop in for one of these, it was my fav part of the meal!
author: Lori G.

description: for reasons unknown, i ordered the most ordinary item from the brunch menu, 2 eggs, 2 bacon,with country potatoes and still came out wowed by the dish.  the potatoes were cooked perfectly golden brown on the outside and tasted great.  it was a very simple dish but absolutely delicious.  i can't wait to go back.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Big downer. I'd been meaning to try this place, since sitting across the street at Yield and seeing the cool space and loving the populating of Dogpatch with another good eaterie. So I thought. 
Went there on a saturday night with another couple. On the plus side, the hostess was very nice and sat us down a bit earlier than our reservations. Our waitress was also very attentive. Kudos also for Acme bread, although we had to ask for a bread set-up. 
One of us ordered the soup, some type of cream of vegetable. Basically tasted like a stick of melted butter with lots of salt added to it. Two of us ordered the cod, the other two ordered the beef ribs. The cod was, well, bad.  It did manage to taste both dry and oily, too salty and bland. While that may represent some kind of culinary prowess in a twisted way, to a paying customer it simply tasted-well-bad. The fish sat in a puddle of green mush meant to be blackened eggplant (???) scattered with a few forlorn canned chickpeas. 
Wish I could say the ribs were better. Nope. Stringy, and slightly gamey. 
Dessert followed suit. My friends ordered the scoop of Bi-Rite Mint Chip ice cream, which nobody could mess with. They were right.  I ordered the chocolate pudding, which was not pudding, but instead a dry piece of chocolate sponge cake topped with some gummy chocolate concoction. 
Maybe this was an off-night. But in San Francisco, you are going to have to do better than that to lure me back. For this price I can go to Zuni Cafe or Delfina and KNOW I am getting a great meal every time. 
Sorry Serpentine.
author: Rebecca P.

description: a great addition to the neighborhood. lunch is a treat there with great food and good service. i loved it all except the coffee which was not so good.
author: David F.

description: the only reason they get two stars is for the cocktails otherwise one sad star. considering they already have a successful restaurant  they shouldn't be having the issues they do, and the food was nothing to return for. blech
author: rachel k.

description: I'm a big Slow Club fan so when I read that Serpentine is their sister restaurant I was excited to try it for brunch on Saturday. I don't know why I don't go to the Dogpatch more, the neighborhood seems really cool! Anyway, Serpentine is located there in a gorgeous space, it's pretty industrial but they've really done a great job with it. We were seated right away and my husband ordered the eggs with housemade bacon, crispy potatoes and toast. I ordered the red flannel hash which was brisket, chiogga beets, potatos, arugula and two poached eggs with a horseradish creme fraiche served with rye toast. Mine was pretty good although I thought the arugula threw the dish off balance because there was so much of it and it can be so peppery. Also the chiogga beets were a bit out of sync as well with the beef and potatoes, they were a bit too sweet. I might have preferred regular roasted beets instead. The eggs were poached and one was over poached and not pretty while the other one was poached well but they were kind of cold on top so they didn't really wilt the arugula much when I cut into them which I think was a detriment to the dish. I did love the horseradish creme fraiche though, it was wonderful and added the perfect kick to the brisket. I tried my husbands dish and it was excellent. I think they really excel at doing the basics well, just like Slow Club's excellent burger but I think they falter more when doing stuff outside the basics like my hash. Pete's eggs were perfectly scrambled and his potatoes were outrageously delicious, crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. I would definitely recommend this place for brunch.
author: Cathy T.

description: my favorite place to eat in the city (besides Bar Jules). i love brunch here and dinner is heaven. the waitstaff is so friendly. and the cocktails are killer.
author: Ariel C.

description: I hit up Serpentine for lunch last Thursday, and to be perfectly frank, everything about it worked for me.  The food (french onion soup, savory bread pudding) was outstanding and reasonably priced, the atmosphere and design of the space was just to my taste, and the staff was super attentive.  To get food of this quality for around $10 an entree is totally a treat in a city where I sometimes find myself paying $8 for a burrito.  Since it was lunch time I wasn't drinking, but the bar looked to be extremely well stocked with high end cocktail mixings.  Looks like an evening stop  might be in order.
author: Patrick P.

description: Go for the best burger in town and a Fin du Monde.  Great space and good service too.
author: Kim H.

description: I live in the neighborhood and have been waiting for 5 years for some more restaurants in Dogpatch.  Yes, I can walk up to Potrero Hill, but I'm always just a visitor there.  I still have to go home (down the hill and over I-280) at the end of the night.  But now I have Serpentine (and Piccino's of course).  I probably hold the record for number of savory bread puddings eaten there by someone not on the staff.  I can't get enough of it.  My only tiny whine is last night they served it in a ramakin, which meant it wasn't as crispy, and I just love the crispy edges.  It tastes the same, still rich and cheesy and bready, so don't let that deter you.  And order a rum punch to go with it.  It's fruity, it's refreshing, and it - well- packs a punch. (I know, I know, keep my day job ;).  And if the risotto cake is on the menu (it's got a funny name and makes no mention of either risotto or cake), get that too.  O-M-G, it's an explosion of awesome flavor.
author: Dana B.

description: serpentine was, at best, mediocre. having a deep and pure love for slow club, we had high hopes for serpentine, so i made the friday date-night ressies and we took our appetite over to the dogpatch.  and, i've actually had a meal here years ago with a friend that was pretty damn good.  but last night i wish i had stayed home and eaten taco bell because at least i would've known what i was in for.  the service was suspect: our waiter seemed either coked up or had some sort of agoraphobia.  the best part about dinner was the heirloom tomato salad - but i ask this of you, who could f*ck up an heirloom tomato salad?  we got something called the "meat board," which andronico's charcuterie section could put to shame.  i ordered the gnocchi, and, as a service to humankind i tell you now: do not order the gnocchi.  it was so sad, so dry, so tasteless that i could only eat three of the gnocchis before throwing in the towel. my beau got the roasted chicken - which was glazed with butter before soaked in olive oil. i could've rubbed my hair in it and walked outta there with a Jheri curl.  anyway.  maybe this was an off night, but we ended our evening coming home and microwaving a day-old burrito - and even that was more delicious than anything we ate at serpentine, save the heirloom tomato salad.
author: Veronica Y.

description: I had GREAT meals the last couple of times I visited. I still would like more vegetarian options, but the cocktails (and, subsequently, the bartender) really rock!!
author: Prem M.

description: only went for brunch but it was a good brunch.  i ordered their red flannel hash.  the portion was small but filling!  perfectly cubed potatoes were crunchy on the outside, soft in the middle, beets, creme fraiche and the 2 poached eggs offset the saltiness of the beef.  which was also cubed small.  i probably should re-review after going for dinner.  lame review, ah well
author: X X.

description:
lets roll with the good things first: the space is cool.  although acoustically speaking not so much. it was pretty loud but not unbearable. the service was excellent! was attentive and was accommodating. serpentine is the sister of the sloe club and i love THAT  place, so it had to be good right? ah hem,,,, now the not so good:
the food. im a vegetarian and never have a problem getting food anywhere! i have even eaten at the house of prime rib and had a decent meal... (thats hard to do when you dont do steak, but it was done) the menu was not really conducive to a good veggie meal so i asked the waiter for suggestions (can u do "blah blah w/o the slab o beef"? etc) pretty much it was a NO. but he hooked me up with a salad which sounded good, and said the chef could do like a vegetable plate. cool! im happy with that. the salad was some weird "weed" lookin and tastin shite. it seriously tasted like grass or weed. eeew. the veggie plate consisted of asparagus (yumm) crispy tatos and it was drowned in some gross thick creamy aioli sauce that had a funky taste. totally ruined it. so, while my food was pretty nasty, the others thought theirs was "OK" .  i might try it one more time, but chances are i wont.
author: nicole d.

description: This is a review based on a weekday lunch with a group from work. Serpentine had three nonsalad vegetarian options for lunch, way to go for a restaurant named after a suborder of carnivorous reptiles! I tried the heirloom tomato sandwich: the bread, cheese, and pesto were all good, but the intense tomato flavor knocked it out of the park. Others at the table had the pork and turkey sandwiches, and agreed that the meat was fine but the relish and jam condiments were particularly tasty. We didn't have dessert, which I regretted when we passed by their giant cookies on the way out. Giant! Cookies! I'm fine now, thanks for asking. The service was good and the decor is that stripped-down industrial look of which my lazy secret self approves. With drinks and no dessert the total was ~$15 per person, a bit too much for a regular outing but the price together with the quality of the food was fine for a special lunch occasion.
author: Kathleen S.

description: Solid meal.  Could use some color on the walls to make it a little more inviting and warm.
author: Theresa S.

description: I went for brunch for the first time and I really enjoyed the space and general vibe of the place. My meal, the savory bread pudding, was  disappointing. It was too salty and should be a side rather than a main menu option. That said, the other dishes my friends had were very tasty. We also split the buckweat pancakes and it was delicious. Despite my meal being below par I'm going to give Serpentine four stars. Next time I'll try other dishes and perhaps go for dinner.
author: David W.

description: serpentine gets high marks - both for the food and (of course) the cocktails.  on the recommendation of several other yelpers, we started with the savory bread pudding and it did not disappoint!  i'll definitely be back for that dish alone - yum.  for the main courses, the portions were on the small side, but that's okay by me - they were delicious, and combined with the hearty appetizer (and three strong martinis) it was the perfect amount of food.  its also nice to see the neighborhood is on the upswing - the last time i was on that block i was leaving sublounge in the wee hours of the morning - oh how things have changed.
author: Erin C.

description: We eat out a lot and are always searching for restaurants that serve unique meals and Serpentine definitely offers some great options.  We had the opportunity to dine at Serpentine on the opening night.  We thought the meal was fantastic and the service was friendly and accommodating.  They have gone to great lengths to create some unique meals.  Our favorite part of the meal was dessert.  Definitely try the chocolate stout with mint ice cream.  The energy is high and the ambiance fits the area well.  As with any new restaurant, there were the typical challenges on opening night.  Our waiter managed through all of the issues with professionalism.
author: Gayathri B.

description: Loved the slow-food/seasonal approach.  Enjoyed my trip to the Dogpatch.
author: Adam D.

description: can't believe such a nice restaurant is hidden over here on 3rd st.  no sign so you might walk past it at first, but make sure you find it, because the food is fantastic, bar too.  don't miss it!
author: Amy D.

description: So happy to have another decent restaurant in Dogpatch! I had really high hopes for Serpentine, since I heard it was the same people as Slow Club, one of my favorites. Not quite as good as Slow Club, but still great food. Better to go with several people and order a bunch of things that everyone can try. Our server was really nice and recommended a great local wine, which of course I've forgotten the name of already. Now that I read other people's reviews, I need to go back and try the cocktails. Didn't seem at all pretentious to me, but I was focused on the food.
author: Margaret C.

description: The neighborhood is completely sketch.  The interior is fabulously warehouse-chic.  And the food seemed ridiculously bland, especially given all the hype.
author: P L.

description: We went here for lunch and it was one of the best places we have been to in a while. Considering the decor (modern and stylish but not overreaching), the price point (most expensive thing was a $13 pork shoulder which was AMAZING) and the food (delicious), it was a pleasant surprise and a great find.  Decent glasses of wine by the glass,  good food (braised pork shoulder with spinach, burger and warm shrimp salad). The service was also very friendly and knowledgeable.  We try a lot of new restaurants and have not been impressed enough to return to most but this one we would go back to in a heartbeat.  Kudos to the owners.
author: Elisa L.

description: the skinny: got there right when they opened, so no one was there. so it was empty and quiet. everyone was quite nice and attentive. nice selection of alcohol (some good local whiskey), and the food selection was good. the lamb riblettes to start, damn good. cream of asparagus soup, flavorful, but not really creamy. then the steak, good too. overall, the food was good, but a bit salty. i mean i like salt as much as the next salt-a-holic, but first few bites were a bit much. still, food was good. overall, a great experience, and the price was super reasonable. get's kinda loud when it's crowded, but it's expected, it's a small place. and if you're still hungry, hard knox is across the street...
author: armand t.

description: Went to dinner at Serpentine the other night, and it was DELISH! My friend and I split a bunch of items, including the fava bean salad (delish) and calamari salad (a bit salty for me but good), then on to the savory bread pudding (YUM!) and egg noodles with short ribs(Um..amazing). Then we had the goat cheese cheese cake for dessert, delicious, delicious, and a great staff to boot. Can't wait to try slow club!
author: Kristin L.

description: Nice place but Meh food.  Went for brunch with an out of town guest.  Nice looking place.  Packed by 10:30 am.  Glad we had made reservations.  Nice staff.  Nice sounding menu.  Poorly executed food.  It was really nothing special or even that good.  My husband got the Red Flannel Corned Beef Hash which sans Corned Beef.  Just fried potatoes kinda thrown together with some roasted beets and some bits of corned beef.  Not all crispy and melded together.  Otherwise pancakes were basic with a super-STICKY/GUMMY glaze-y syrup that was already doused.  Bloody marys were pretty good.  All in all we spent $90 on brunch that we felt pretty "Meh" about.
author: Lisa C.

description: We had a 45 minute wait as the group at our table before us refused to leave, even after being asked by the hostess. The staff was very apologetic, had the kitchen send out an appetizer as soon as we sat down and ended up comping our other two appetizers. I considered this to be very accommodating for a situation that was out of their control. I tasted from three plates and three apps and found everything was consistently good and well priced. In discussion with our server at the end of the meal she conveyed knowledge beyond the menu into the mission behind the restaurant and where it sees itself in the future of the neighborhood. Serpentine just earned itself a new regular.
author: Matt S.

description: Review solely based upon breakfast/brunch. Serpentine is great in accomodating large groups - a group of 9 of us came for brunch (with 2 babies - who loved to destroy their menus) and the quality of food didn't suffer because of it. For those of you who want to know, they use Mr. Espresso for coffee. The chicken fried steak is the thing to get ... if you like that type of stuff for breakfast - nothing like fabulously seasoned chicken fried steak and biscuits topped with a mushroom gravy and eggs. Yum! The potatoes are more similar to french fries, nothing to ride home about, but nothing to cause you to pull your skin that you paid money for it. We also got the buckwheat pancakes, very dense, but loved the texture - BE WARNED - these suckers are HUGE....and by huge I mean monstrous - 4 huge buckwheat pancakes - these aren't the light & fluffy pancakes, we're talking.....dense buckwheat pancakes. We couldn't finish it among our table :(, sadly enough. There were some other yummy things at the table, but I still stand by if you're a lover of chicken fried steak, please order it, you shain't be disappointed.
author: Jeannette L.
